author: Thomas Hobbes
text: TRANSCRIBER'S NOTES ON THE E-TEXT:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: This E-text was prepared from the Pelican Classics edition of Leviathan,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which in turn was prepared from the first edition. I have tried to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: follow as closely as possible the original, and to give the flavour of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the text that Hobbes himself proof-read, but the following differences

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: were unavoidable.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Hobbes used capitals and italics very extensively, for emphasis, for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: proper names, for quotations, and sometimes, it seems, just because.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The original has very extensive margin notes, which are used to show

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: where he introduces the definitions of words and concepts, to give in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: short the subject that a paragraph or section is dealing with, and to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: give references to his quotations, largely but not exclusively biblical.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To some degree, these margin notes seem to have been intended to serve

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in place of an index, the original having none. They are all in italics.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: He also used italics for words in other languages than English, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there are a number of Greek words, in the Greek alphabet, in the text.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To deal with these within the limits of plain vanilla ASCII, I have done

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the following in this E-text.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: I have restricted my use of full capitalization to those places where

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Hobbes used it, except in the chapter headings, which I have fully

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: capitalized, where Hobbes used a mixture of full capitalization and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: italics.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Where it is clear that the italics are to indicate the text is quoting,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: I have introduced quotation marks. Within quotation marks I have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: retained the capitalization that Hobbes used.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Where italics seem to be used for emphasis, or for proper names, or just

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: because, I have capitalized the initial letter of the words. This has

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the disadvantage that they are not then distinguished from those that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Hobbes capitalized in plain text, but the extent of his italics would

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: make the text very ugly if I was to use an underscore or slash.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Where the margin notes are either to introduce the paragraph subject,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or to show where he introduces word definitions, I have included them as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: headers to the paragraph, again with all words having initial capitals,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and on a shortened line.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For margin references to quotes, I have included them in the text,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in brackets immediately next to the quotation. Where Hobbes included

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: references in the main text, I have left them as he put them, except to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: change his square brackets to round.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For the Greek alphabet, I have simply substituted the nearest ordinary

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: letters that I can, and I have used initial capitals for foreign

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: language words.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Neither Thomas Hobbes nor his typesetters seem to have had many

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: inhibitions about spelling and punctuation. I have tried to reproduce

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: both exactly, with the exception of the introduction of quotation marks.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In preparing the text, I have found that it has much more meaning if

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: I read it with sub-vocalization, or aloud, rather than trying to read

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: silently. Hobbes' use of emphasis and his eccentric punctuation and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: construction seem then to work.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: TO MY MOST HONOR'D FRIEND Mr. FRANCIS GODOLPHIN of GODOLPHIN

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: HONOR'D SIR.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Your most worthy Brother Mr SIDNEY GODOLPHIN, when he lived, was pleas'd

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to think my studies something, and otherwise to oblige me, as you know,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with reall testimonies of his good opinion, great in themselves, and the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: greater for the worthinesse of his person. For there is not any vertue

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that disposeth a man, either to the service of God, or to the service

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of his Country, to Civill Society, or private Friendship, that did not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: manifestly appear in his conversation, not as acquired by necessity,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or affected upon occasion, but inhaerent, and shining in a generous

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: constitution of his nature. Therefore in honour and gratitude to him,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and with devotion to your selfe, I humbly Dedicate unto you this my

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: discourse of Common-wealth. I know not how the world will receive it,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: nor how it may reflect on those that shall seem to favour it. For in a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: way beset with those that contend on one side for too great Liberty, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: on the other side for too much Authority, 'tis hard to passe between the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: points of both unwounded. But yet, me thinks, the endeavour to advance

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Civill Power, should not be by the Civill Power condemned; nor

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: private men, by reprehending it, declare they think that Power too

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: great. Besides, I speak not of the men, but (in the Abstract) of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Seat of Power, (like to those simple and unpartiall creatures in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Roman Capitol, that with their noyse defended those within it, not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: because they were they, but there) offending none, I think, but those

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: without, or such within (if there be any such) as favour them. That

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which perhaps may most offend, are certain Texts of Holy Scripture,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: alledged by me to other purpose than ordinarily they use to be by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: others. But I have done it with due submission, and also (in order to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: my Subject) necessarily; for they are the Outworks of the Enemy, from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whence they impugne the Civill Power. If notwithstanding this, you find

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: my labour generally decryed, you may be pleased to excuse your selfe,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and say that I am a man that love my own opinions, and think all true I

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: say, that I honoured your Brother, and honour you, and have presum'd on

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that, to assume the Title (without your knowledge) of being, as I am,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sir,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Your most humble, and most obedient servant, Thomas Hobbes.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Paris APRILL 15/25 1651.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: THE INTRODUCTION

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nature (the art whereby God hath made and governes the world) is by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: art of man, as in many other things, so in this also imitated, that it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: can make an Artificial Animal. For seeing life is but a motion of Limbs,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the begining whereof is in some principall part within; why may we not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: say, that all Automata (Engines that move themselves by springs and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: wheeles as doth a watch) have an artificiall life? For what is the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Heart, but a Spring; and the Nerves, but so many Strings; and the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Joynts, but so many Wheeles, giving motion to the whole Body, such as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was intended by the Artificer? Art goes yet further, imitating that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Rationall and most excellent worke of Nature, Man. For by Art is created

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that great LEVIATHAN called a COMMON-WEALTH, or STATE, (in latine

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CIVITAS) which is but an Artificiall Man; though of greater stature

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and strength than the Naturall, for whose protection and defence it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was intended; and in which, the Soveraignty is an Artificiall Soul, as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: giving life and motion to the whole body; The Magistrates, and other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Officers of Judicature and Execution, artificiall Joynts; Reward and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Punishment (by which fastned to the seat of the Soveraignty, every joynt

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and member is moved to performe his duty) are the Nerves, that do the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: same in the Body Naturall; The Wealth and Riches of all the particular

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: members, are the Strength; Salus Populi (the Peoples Safety) its

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Businesse; Counsellors, by whom all things needfull for it to know,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are suggested unto it, are the Memory; Equity and Lawes, an artificiall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Reason and Will; Concord, Health; Sedition, Sicknesse; and Civill War,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Death. Lastly, the Pacts and Covenants, by which the parts of this Body

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Politique were at first made, set together, and united, resemble that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Fiat, or the Let Us Make Man, pronounced by God in the Creation.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To describe the Nature of this Artificiall man, I will consider

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: First the Matter thereof, and the Artificer; both which is Man.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Secondly, How, and by what Covenants it is made; what are the Rights and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: just Power or Authority of a Soveraigne; and what it is that Preserveth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Dissolveth it.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Thirdly, what is a Christian Common-Wealth.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lastly, what is the Kingdome of Darkness.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Concerning the first, there is a saying much usurped of late, That

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Wisedome is acquired, not by reading of Books, but of Men. Consequently

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whereunto, those persons, that for the most part can give no other proof

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of being wise, take great delight to shew what they think they have read

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in men, by uncharitable censures of one another behind their backs.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But there is another saying not of late understood, by which they might

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: learn truly to read one another, if they would take the pains; and that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is, Nosce Teipsum, Read Thy Self: which was not meant, as it is now

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: used, to countenance, either the barbarous state of men in power,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: towards their inferiors; or to encourage men of low degree, to a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sawcie behaviour towards their betters; But to teach us, that for the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: similitude of the thoughts, and Passions of one man, to the thoughts,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Passions of another, whosoever looketh into himselfe, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: considereth what he doth, when he does Think, Opine, Reason, Hope,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Feare, &c, and upon what grounds; he shall thereby read and know,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: what are the thoughts, and Passions of all other men, upon the like

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: occasions. I say the similitude of Passions, which are the same in all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: men, Desire, Feare, Hope, &c; not the similitude or The Objects of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Passions, which are the things Desired, Feared, Hoped, &c: for these the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: constitution individuall, and particular education do so vary, and they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are so easie to be kept from our knowledge, that the characters of mans

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: heart, blotted and confounded as they are, with dissembling, lying,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: counterfeiting, and erroneous doctrines, are legible onely to him that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: searcheth hearts. And though by mens actions wee do discover their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: designee sometimes; yet to do it without comparing them with our own,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and distinguishing all circumstances, by which the case may come to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be altered, is to decypher without a key, and be for the most part

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: deceived, by too much trust, or by too much diffidence; as he that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: reads, is himselfe a good or evill man.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But let one man read another by his actions never so perfectly, it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: serves him onely with his acquaintance, which are but few. He that is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to govern a whole Nation, must read in himselfe, not this, or that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: particular man; but Man-kind; which though it be hard to do, harder than

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to learn any Language, or Science; yet, when I shall have set down my

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: own reading orderly, and perspicuously, the pains left another, will be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: onely to consider, if he also find not the same in himselfe. For this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: kind of Doctrine, admitteth no other Demonstration.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: PART 1 OF MAN

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CHAPTER I. OF SENSE

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Concerning the Thoughts of man, I will consider them first Singly, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: afterwards in Trayne, or dependance upon one another. Singly, they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are every one a Representation or Apparence, of some quality, or other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Accident of a body without us; which is commonly called an Object. Which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Object worketh on the Eyes, Eares, and other parts of mans body; and by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: diversity of working, produceth diversity of Apparences.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Originall of them all, is that which we call Sense; (For there is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: no conception in a mans mind, which hath not at first, totally, or by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: parts, been begotten upon the organs of Sense.) The rest are derived

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from that originall.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To know the naturall cause of Sense, is not very necessary to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: business now in hand; and I have els-where written of the same at large.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nevertheless, to fill each part of my present method, I will briefly

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: deliver the same in this place.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The cause of Sense, is the Externall Body, or Object, which presseth the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: organ proper to each Sense, either immediatly, as in the Tast and Touch;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or mediately, as in Seeing, Hearing, and Smelling: which pressure, by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the mediation of Nerves, and other strings, and membranes of the body,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: continued inwards to the Brain, and Heart, causeth there a resistance,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or counter-pressure, or endeavour of the heart, to deliver it self:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which endeavour because Outward, seemeth to be some matter without. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: this Seeming, or Fancy, is that which men call sense; and consisteth, as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to the Eye, in a Light, or Colour Figured; To the Eare, in a Sound; To

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Nostrill, in an Odour; To the Tongue and Palat, in a Savour; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to the rest of the body, in Heat, Cold, Hardnesse, Softnesse, and such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other qualities, as we discern by Feeling. All which qualities called

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sensible, are in the object that causeth them, but so many several

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: motions of the matter, by which it presseth our organs diversly. Neither

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in us that are pressed, are they anything els, but divers motions; (for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: motion, produceth nothing but motion.) But their apparence to us is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Fancy, the same waking, that dreaming. And as pressing, rubbing,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or striking the Eye, makes us fancy a light; and pressing the Eare,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: produceth a dinne; so do the bodies also we see, or hear, produce the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: same by their strong, though unobserved action, For if those Colours,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Sounds, were in the Bodies, or Objects that cause them, they could

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not bee severed from them, as by glasses, and in Ecchoes by reflection,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: wee see they are; where we know the thing we see, is in one place; the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: apparence, in another. And though at some certain distance, the reall,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and very object seem invested with the fancy it begets in us; Yet still

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the object is one thing, the image or fancy is another. So that Sense in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all cases, is nothing els but originall fancy, caused (as I have said)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by the pressure, that is, by the motion, of externall things upon our

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Eyes, Eares, and other organs thereunto ordained.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But the Philosophy-schooles, through all the Universities of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christendome, grounded upon certain Texts of Aristotle, teach another

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: doctrine; and say, For the cause of Vision, that the thing seen, sendeth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: forth on every side a Visible Species(in English) a Visible Shew,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Apparition, or Aspect, or a Being Seen; the receiving whereof into the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Eye, is Seeing. And for the cause of Hearing, that the thing heard,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sendeth forth an Audible Species, that is, an Audible Aspect, or Audible

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Being Seen; which entring at the Eare, maketh Hearing. Nay for the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: cause of Understanding also, they say the thing Understood sendeth forth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Intelligible Species, that is, an Intelligible Being Seen; which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: comming into the Understanding, makes us Understand. I say not this,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as disapproving the use of Universities: but because I am to speak

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hereafter of their office in a Common-wealth, I must let you see on

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all occasions by the way, what things would be amended in them; amongst

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which the frequency of insignificant Speech is one.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CHAPTER II. OF IMAGINATION

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: That when a thing lies still, unlesse somewhat els stirre it, it will

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: lye still for ever, is a truth that no man doubts of. But that when a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thing is in motion, it will eternally be in motion, unless somewhat els

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: stay it, though the reason be the same, (namely, that nothing can change

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it selfe,) is not so easily assented to. For men measure, not onely

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other men, but all other things, by themselves: and because they find

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: themselves subject after motion to pain, and lassitude, think every

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thing els growes weary of motion, and seeks repose of its own accord;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: little considering, whether it be not some other motion, wherein that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: desire of rest they find in themselves, consisteth. From hence it is,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that the Schooles say, Heavy bodies fall downwards, out of an appetite

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to rest, and to conserve their nature in that place which is most proper

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for them; ascribing appetite, and Knowledge of what is good for their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: conservation, (which is more than man has) to things inanimate absurdly.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: When a Body is once in motion, it moveth (unless something els hinder

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it) eternally; and whatsoever hindreth it, cannot in an instant, but in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: time, and by degrees quite extinguish it: And as wee see in the water,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: though the wind cease, the waves give not over rowling for a long

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: time after; so also it happeneth in that motion, which is made in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: internall parts of a man, then, when he Sees, Dreams, &c. For after the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: object is removed, or the eye shut, wee still retain an image of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thing seen, though more obscure than when we see it. And this is it,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that Latines call Imagination, from the image made in seeing; and apply

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the same, though improperly, to all the other senses. But the Greeks

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: call it Fancy; which signifies Apparence, and is as proper to one sense,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as to another. Imagination therefore is nothing but Decaying Sense; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is found in men, and many other living Creatures, as well sleeping, as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: waking.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Memory

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The decay of Sense in men waking, is not the decay of the motion made in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sense; but an obscuring of it, in such manner, as the light of the Sun

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: obscureth the light of the Starres; which starrs do no less exercise

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their vertue by which they are visible, in the day, than in the night.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But because amongst many stroaks, which our eyes, eares, and other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: organs receive from externall bodies, the predominant onely is sensible;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore the light of the Sun being predominant, we are not affected

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with the action of the starrs. And any object being removed from our

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: eyes, though the impression it made in us remain; yet other objects more

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: present succeeding, and working on us, the Imagination of the past is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: obscured, and made weak; as the voyce of a man is in the noyse of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: day. From whence it followeth, that the longer the time is, after the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sight, or Sense of any object, the weaker is the Imagination. For the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: continuall change of mans body, destroyes in time the parts which in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sense were moved: So that the distance of time, and of place, hath one

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and the same effect in us. For as at a distance of place, that which wee

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: look at, appears dimme, and without distinction of the smaller parts;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and as Voyces grow weak, and inarticulate: so also after great distance

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of time, our imagination of the Past is weak; and wee lose( for example)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Cities wee have seen, many particular Streets; and of Actions, many

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: particular Circumstances. This Decaying Sense, when wee would express

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the thing it self, (I mean Fancy it selfe,) wee call Imagination, as I

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: said before; But when we would express the Decay, and signifie that the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sense is fading, old, and past, it is called Memory. So that Imagination

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Memory, are but one thing, which for divers considerations hath

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: divers names.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Much memory, or memory of many things, is called Experience. Againe,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Imagination being only of those things which have been formerly

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: perceived by Sense, either all at once, or by parts at severall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: times; The former, (which is the imagining the whole object, as it was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: presented to the sense) is Simple Imagination; as when one imagineth a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man, or horse, which he hath seen before. The other is Compounded; as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: when from the sight of a man at one time, and of a horse at another, we

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: conceive in our mind a Centaure. So when a man compoundeth the image of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his own person, with the image of the actions of an other man; as when a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man imagins himselfe a Hercules, or an Alexander, (which happeneth often

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to them that are much taken with reading of Romants) it is a compound

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: imagination, and properly but a Fiction of the mind. There be also other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Imaginations that rise in men, (though waking) from the great impression

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: made in sense; As from gazing upon the Sun, the impression leaves an

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: image of the Sun before our eyes a long time after; and from being long

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and vehemently attent upon Geometricall Figures, a man shall in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: dark, (though awake) have the Images of Lines, and Angles before his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: eyes: which kind of Fancy hath no particular name; as being a thing that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: doth not commonly fall into mens discourse.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Dreams

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The imaginations of them that sleep, are those we call Dreams. And these

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: also (as all other Imaginations) have been before, either totally, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by parcells in the Sense. And because in sense, the Brain, and Nerves,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which are the necessary Organs of sense, are so benummed in sleep, as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not easily to be moved by the action of Externall Objects, there can

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: happen in sleep, no Imagination; and therefore no Dreame, but what

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: proceeds from the agitation of the inward parts of mans body; which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: inward parts, for the connexion they have with the Brayn, and other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Organs, when they be distempered, do keep the same in motion; whereby

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Imaginations there formerly made, appeare as if a man were waking;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: saving that the Organs of Sense being now benummed, so as there is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: no new object, which can master and obscure them with a more vigorous

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: impression, a Dreame must needs be more cleare, in this silence of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sense, than are our waking thoughts. And hence it cometh to pass, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it is a hard matter, and by many thought impossible to distinguish

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: exactly between Sense and Dreaming. For my part, when I consider, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in Dreames, I do not often, nor constantly think of the same Persons,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Places, Objects, and Actions that I do waking; nor remember so long a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: trayne of coherent thoughts, Dreaming, as at other times; And because

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: waking I often observe the absurdity of Dreames, but never dream of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the absurdities of my waking Thoughts; I am well satisfied, that being

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: awake, I know I dreame not; though when I dreame, I think my selfe

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: awake.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And seeing dreames are caused by the distemper of some of the inward

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: parts of the Body; divers distempers must needs cause different Dreams.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And hence it is, that lying cold breedeth Dreams of Feare, and raiseth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the thought and Image of some fearfull object (the motion from the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: brain to the inner parts, and from the inner parts to the Brain being

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: reciprocall:) and that as Anger causeth heat in some parts of the Body,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: when we are awake; so when we sleep, the over heating of the same parts

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: causeth Anger, and raiseth up in the brain the Imagination of an Enemy.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In the same manner; as naturall kindness, when we are awake causeth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: desire; and desire makes heat in certain other parts of the body; so

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: also, too much heat in those parts, while wee sleep, raiseth in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: brain an imagination of some kindness shewn. In summe, our Dreams are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the reverse of our waking Imaginations; The motion when we are awake,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: beginning at one end; and when we Dream, at another.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Apparitions Or Visions

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The most difficult discerning of a mans Dream, from his waking thoughts,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is then, when by some accident we observe not that we have slept:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which is easie to happen to a man full of fearfull thoughts; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whose conscience is much troubled; and that sleepeth, without the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: circumstances, of going to bed, or putting off his clothes, as one that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: noddeth in a chayre. For he that taketh pains, and industriously layes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: himselfe to sleep, in case any uncouth and exorbitant fancy come unto

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him, cannot easily think it other than a Dream. We read of Marcus

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Brutes, (one that had his life given him by Julius Caesar, and was also

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his favorite, and notwithstanding murthered him,) how at Phillipi,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the night before he gave battell to Augustus Caesar, he saw a fearfull

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: apparition, which is commonly related by Historians as a Vision: but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: considering the circumstances, one may easily judge to have been but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a short Dream. For sitting in his tent, pensive and troubled with the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: horrour of his rash act, it was not hard for him, slumbering in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: cold, to dream of that which most affrighted him; which feare, as by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: degrees it made him wake; so also it must needs make the Apparition by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: degrees to vanish: And having no assurance that he slept, he could have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: no cause to think it a Dream, or any thing but a Vision. And this is no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: very rare Accident: for even they that be perfectly awake, if they be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: timorous, and supperstitious, possessed with fearfull tales, and alone

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the dark, are subject to the like fancies, and believe they see

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: spirits and dead mens Ghosts walking in Churchyards; whereas it is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: either their Fancy onely, or els the knavery of such persons, as make

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: use of such superstitious feare, to pass disguised in the night, to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: places they would not be known to haunt.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: From this ignorance of how to distinguish Dreams, and other strong

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Fancies, from vision and Sense, did arise the greatest part of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Religion of the Gentiles in time past, that worshipped Satyres, Fawnes,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: nymphs, and the like; and now adayes the opinion than rude people have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Fayries, Ghosts, and Goblins; and of the power of Witches. For as for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Witches, I think not that their witch craft is any reall power; but yet

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that they are justly punished, for the false beliefe they have, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they can do such mischiefe, joyned with their purpose to do it if they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: can; their trade being neerer to a new Religion, than to a Craft or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Science. And for Fayries, and walking Ghosts, the opinion of them has I

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: think been on purpose, either taught, or not confuted, to keep in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: credit the use of Exorcisme, of Crosses, of holy Water, and other such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: inventions of Ghostly men. Neverthelesse, there is no doubt, but God can

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: make unnaturall Apparitions. But that he does it so often, as men need

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to feare such things, more than they feare the stay, or change, of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: course of Nature, which he also can stay, and change, is no point of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christian faith. But evill men under pretext that God can do any thing,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are so bold as to say any thing when it serves their turn, though

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they think it untrue; It is the part of a wise man, to believe them no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: further, than right reason makes that which they say, appear credible.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: If this superstitious fear of Spirits were taken away, and with it,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Prognostiques from Dreams, false Prophecies, and many other things

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: depending thereon, by which, crafty ambitious persons abuse the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: simple people, men would be much more fitted than they are for civill

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Obedience.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And this ought to be the work of the Schooles; but they rather nourish

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such doctrine. For (not knowing what Imagination, or the Senses are),

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: what they receive, they teach: some saying, that Imaginations rise of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: themselves, and have no cause: Others that they rise most commonly from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Will; and that Good thoughts are blown (inspired) into a man, by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: God; and evill thoughts by the Divell: or that Good thoughts are powred

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (infused) into a man, by God; and evill ones by the Divell. Some say

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Senses receive the Species of things, and deliver them to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-sense; and the Common Sense delivers them over to the Fancy, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Fancy to the Memory, and the Memory to the Judgement, like

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: handing of things from one to another, with many words making nothing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: understood.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Understanding

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Imagination that is raysed in man (or any other creature indued with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the faculty of imagining) by words, or other voluntary signes, is that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: we generally call Understanding; and is common to Man and Beast. For a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: dogge by custome will understand the call, or the rating of his Master;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and so will many other Beasts. That Understanding which is peculiar to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man, is the Understanding not onely his will; but his conceptions and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thoughts, by the sequell and contexture of the names of things into

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Affirmations, Negations, and other formes of Speech: And of this kinde

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Understanding I shall speak hereafter.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CHAPTER III. OF THE CONSEQUENCE OR TRAYNE OF IMAGINATIONS

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: By Consequence, or Trayne of Thoughts, I understand that succession

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of one Thought to another, which is called (to distinguish it from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Discourse in words) Mentall Discourse.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: When a man thinketh on any thing whatsoever, His next Thought after, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not altogether so casuall as it seems to be. Not every Thought to every

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Thought succeeds indifferently. But as wee have no Imagination, whereof

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: we have not formerly had Sense, in whole, or in parts; so we have no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Transition from one Imagination to another, whereof we never had the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: like before in our Senses. The reason whereof is this. All Fancies

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are Motions within us, reliques of those made in the Sense: And those

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: motions that immediately succeeded one another in the sense, continue

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: also together after Sense: In so much as the former comming again to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: take place, and be praedominant, the later followeth, by coherence of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the matter moved, is such manner, as water upon a plain Table is drawn

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which way any one part of it is guided by the finger. But because

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in sense, to one and the same thing perceived, sometimes one thing,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sometimes another succeedeth, it comes to passe in time, that in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Imagining of any thing, there is no certainty what we shall Imagine

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: next; Onely this is certain, it shall be something that succeeded the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: same before, at one time or another.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Trayne Of Thoughts Unguided

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: This Trayne of Thoughts, or Mentall Discourse, is of two sorts. The

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: first is Unguided, Without Designee, and inconstant; Wherein there is no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Passionate Thought, to govern and direct those that follow, to it self,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as the end and scope of some desire, or other passion: In which case the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thoughts are said to wander, and seem impertinent one to another, as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in a Dream. Such are Commonly the thoughts of men, that are not onely

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: without company, but also without care of any thing; though even then

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their Thoughts are as busie as at other times, but without harmony; as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the sound which a Lute out of tune would yeeld to any man; or in tune,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to one that could not play. And yet in this wild ranging of the mind,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a man may oft-times perceive the way of it, and the dependance of one

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thought upon another. For in a Discourse of our present civill warre,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: what could seem more impertinent, than to ask (as one did) what was the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: value of a Roman Penny? Yet the Cohaerence to me was manifest enough.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For the Thought of the warre, introduced the Thought of the delivering

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: up the King to his Enemies; The Thought of that, brought in the Thought

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the delivering up of Christ; and that again the Thought of the 30

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: pence, which was the price of that treason: and thence easily followed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that malicious question; and all this in a moment of time; for Thought

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is quick.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Trayne Of Thoughts Regulated

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The second is more constant; as being Regulated by some desire, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: designee. For the impression made by such things as wee desire, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: feare, is strong, and permanent, or, (if it cease for a time,) of quick

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: return: so strong it is sometimes, as to hinder and break our sleep.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: From Desire, ariseth the Thought of some means we have seen produce the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: like of that which we ayme at; and from the thought of that, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thought of means to that mean; and so continually, till we come to some

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: beginning within our own power. And because the End, by the greatnesse

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the impression, comes often to mind, in case our thoughts begin to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: wander, they are quickly again reduced into the way: which observed by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: one of the seven wise men, made him give men this praecept, which is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: now worne out, Respice Finem; that is to say, in all your actions,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: look often upon what you would have, as the thing that directs all your

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thoughts in the way to attain it.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Remembrance

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Trayn of regulated Thoughts is of two kinds; One, when of an effect

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: imagined, wee seek the causes, or means that produce it: and this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is common to Man and Beast. The other is, when imagining any thing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whatsoever, wee seek all the possible effects, that can by it be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: produced; that is to say, we imagine what we can do with it, when wee

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have it. Of which I have not at any time seen any signe, but in man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: onely; for this is a curiosity hardly incident to the nature of any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: living creature that has no other Passion but sensuall, such as are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hunger, thirst, lust, and anger. In summe, the Discourse of the Mind,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: when it is governed by designee, is nothing but Seeking, or the faculty

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Invention, which the Latines call Sagacitas, and Solertia; a hunting

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: out of the causes, of some effect, present or past; or of the effects,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of some present or past cause, sometimes a man seeks what he hath lost;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and from that place, and time, wherein hee misses it, his mind runs

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: back, from place to place, and time to time, to find where, and when

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he had it; that is to say, to find some certain, and limited time and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: place, in which to begin a method of seeking. Again, from thence, his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thoughts run over the same places and times, to find what action, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other occasion might make him lose it. This we call Remembrance,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or Calling to mind: the Latines call it Reminiscentia, as it were a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Re-Conning of our former actions.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sometimes a man knows a place determinate, within the compasse whereof

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his is to seek; and then his thoughts run over all the parts thereof,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the same manner, as one would sweep a room, to find a jewell; or as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Spaniel ranges the field, till he find a sent; or as a man should run

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: over the alphabet, to start a rime.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Prudence

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sometime a man desires to know the event of an action; and then he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thinketh of some like action past, and the events thereof one after

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: another; supposing like events will follow like actions. As he that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: foresees what wil become of a Criminal, re-cons what he has seen follow

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: on the like Crime before; having this order of thoughts, The Crime,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Officer, the Prison, the Judge, and the Gallowes. Which kind

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of thoughts, is called Foresight, and Prudence, or Providence; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sometimes Wisdome; though such conjecture, through the difficulty of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: observing all circumstances, be very fallacious. But this is certain; by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: how much one man has more experience of things past, than another; by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: so much also he is more Prudent, and his expectations the seldomer faile

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him. The Present onely has a being in Nature; things Past have a being

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the Memory onely, but things To Come have no being at all; the Future

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: being but a fiction of the mind, applying the sequels of actions Past,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to the actions that are Present; which with most certainty is done by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him that has most Experience; but not with certainty enough. And though

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it be called Prudence, when the Event answereth our Expectation; yet in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: its own nature, it is but Presumption. For the foresight of things to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: come, which is Providence, belongs onely to him by whose will they are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to come. From him onely, and supernaturally, proceeds Prophecy. The best

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Prophet naturally is the best guesser; and the best guesser, he that is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: most versed and studied in the matters he guesses at: for he hath most

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Signes to guesse by.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Signes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: A Signe, is the Event Antecedent, of the Consequent; and contrarily,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Consequent of the Antecedent, when the like Consequences have been

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: observed, before: And the oftner they have been observed, the lesse

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: uncertain is the Signe. And therefore he that has most experience in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: any kind of businesse, has most Signes, whereby to guesse at the Future

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: time, and consequently is the most prudent: And so much more prudent

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: than he that is new in that kind of business, as not to be equalled by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: any advantage of naturall and extemporary wit: though perhaps many young

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: men think the contrary.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Neverthelesse it is not Prudence that distinguisheth man from beast.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: There be beasts, that at a year old observe more, and pursue that which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is for their good, more prudently, than a child can do at ten.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Conjecture Of The Time Past

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: As Prudence is a Praesumtion of the Future, contracted from the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Experience of time Past; So there is a Praesumtion of things Past taken

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from other things (not future but) past also. For he that hath seen

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by what courses and degrees, a flourishing State hath first come into

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: civill warre, and then to ruine; upon the sights of the ruines of any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other State, will guesse, the like warre, and the like courses have been

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there also. But his conjecture, has the same incertainty almost with the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: conjecture of the Future; both being grounded onely upon Experience.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: There is no other act of mans mind, that I can remember, naturally

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: planted in him, so, as to need no other thing, to the exercise of it,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but to be born a man, and live with the use of his five Senses. Those

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other Faculties, of which I shall speak by and by, and which seem proper

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to man onely, are acquired, and encreased by study and industry; and of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: most men learned by instruction, and discipline; and proceed all from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the invention of Words, and Speech. For besides Sense, and Thoughts, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Trayne of thoughts, the mind of man has no other motion; though by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the help of Speech, and Method, the same Facultyes may be improved to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such a height, as to distinguish men from all other living Creatures.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Whatsoever we imagine, is Finite. Therefore there is no Idea, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: conception of anything we call Infinite. No man can have in his mind an

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Image of infinite magnitude; nor conceive the ends, and bounds of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the thing named; having no Conception of the thing, but of our own

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: inability. And therefore the Name of GOD is used, not to make us

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: conceive him; (for he is Incomprehensible; and his greatnesse, and power

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are unconceivable;) but that we may honour him. Also because whatsoever

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (as I said before,) we conceive, has been perceived first by sense,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: either all at once, or by parts; a man can have no thought, representing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: any thing, not subject to sense. No man therefore can conceive any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thing, but he must conceive it in some place; and indued with some

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: determinate magnitude; and which may be divided into parts; nor that any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thing is all in this place, and all in another place at the same time;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: nor that two, or more things can be in one, and the same place at once:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for none of these things ever have, or can be incident to Sense; but are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: absurd speeches, taken upon credit (without any signification at all,)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from deceived Philosophers, and deceived, or deceiving Schoolemen.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CHAPTER IV. OF SPEECH

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Originall Of Speech

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Invention of Printing, though ingenious, compared with the invention

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Letters, is no great matter. But who was the first that found the use

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Letters, is not known. He that first brought them into Greece, men

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: say was Cadmus, the sonne of Agenor, King of Phaenicia. A profitable

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Invention for continuing the memory of time past, and the conjunction of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: mankind, dispersed into so many, and distant regions of the Earth; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with all difficult, as proceeding from a watchfull observation of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: divers motions of the Tongue, Palat, Lips, and other organs of Speech;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whereby to make as many differences of characters, to remember them.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But the most noble and profitable invention of all other, was that of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Speech, consisting of Names or Apellations, and their Connexion; whereby

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: men register their Thoughts; recall them when they are past; and also

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: declare them one to another for mutuall utility and conversation;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: without which, there had been amongst men, neither Common-wealth, nor

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Society, nor Contract, nor Peace, no more than amongst Lyons, Bears,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Wolves. The first author of Speech was GOD himselfe, that instructed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Adam how to name such creatures as he presented to his sight; For the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Scripture goeth no further in this matter. But this was sufficient

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to direct him to adde more names, as the experience and use of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: creatures should give him occasion; and to joyn them in such manner by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: degrees, as to make himselfe understood; and so by succession of time,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: so much language might be gotten, as he had found use for; though not so

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: copious, as an Orator or Philosopher has need of. For I do not find any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thing in the Scripture, out of which, directly or by consequence can

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be gathered, that Adam was taught the names of all Figures, Numbers,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Measures, Colours, Sounds, Fancies, Relations; much less the names

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Words and Speech, as Generall, Speciall, Affirmative, Negative,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Interrogative, Optative, Infinitive, all which are usefull; and least of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all, of Entity, Intentionality, Quiddity, and other significant words of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the School.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But all this language gotten, and augmented by Adam and his posterity,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was again lost at the tower of Babel, when by the hand of God, every man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was stricken for his rebellion, with an oblivion of his former language.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And being hereby forced to disperse themselves into severall parts of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the world, it must needs be, that the diversity of Tongues that now is,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: proceeded by degrees from them, in such manner, as need (the mother of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all inventions) taught them; and in tract of time grew every where more

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: copious.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Use Of Speech

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The generall use of Speech, is to transferre our Mentall Discourse, into

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Verbal; or the Trayne of our Thoughts, into a Trayne of Words; and that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for two commodities; whereof one is, the Registring of the Consequences

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of our Thoughts; which being apt to slip out of our memory, and put

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: us to a new labour, may again be recalled, by such words as they were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: marked by. So that the first use of names, is to serve for Markes,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or Notes of remembrance. Another is, when many use the same words,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to signifie (by their connexion and order,) one to another, what they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: conceive, or think of each matter; and also what they desire, feare,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or have any other passion for, and for this use they are called

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Signes. Speciall uses of Speech are these; First, to Register, what by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: cogitation, wee find to be the cause of any thing, present or past; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: what we find things present or past may produce, or effect: which in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: summe, is acquiring of Arts. Secondly, to shew to others that knowledge

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which we have attained; which is, to Counsell, and Teach one another.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Thirdly, to make known to others our wills, and purposes, that we may

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have the mutuall help of one another. Fourthly, to please and delight

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: our selves, and others, by playing with our words, for pleasure or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ornament, innocently.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Abuses Of Speech

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To these Uses, there are also foure correspondent Abuses. First,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: when men register their thoughts wrong, by the inconstancy of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: signification of their words; by which they register for their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: conceptions, that which they never conceived; and so deceive themselves.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Secondly, when they use words metaphorically; that is, in other sense

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: than that they are ordained for; and thereby deceive others. Thirdly,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: when by words they declare that to be their will, which is not.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Fourthly, when they use them to grieve one another: for seeing nature

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hath armed living creatures, some with teeth, some with horns, and some

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with hands, to grieve an enemy, it is but an abuse of Speech, to grieve

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him with the tongue, unlesse it be one whom wee are obliged to govern;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and then it is not to grieve, but to correct and amend.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The manner how Speech serveth to the remembrance of the consequence

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of causes and effects, consisteth in the imposing of Names, and the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Connexion of them.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Names Proper & Common Universall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of Names, some are Proper, and singular to one onely thing; as Peter,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: John, This Man, This Tree: and some are Common to many things; as Man,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Horse, Tree; every of which though but one Name, is nevertheless the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: name of divers particular things; in respect of all which together, it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is called an Universall; there being nothing in the world Universall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but Names; for the things named, are every one of them Individual and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Singular.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: One Universall name is imposed on many things, for their similitude in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: some quality, or other accident: And whereas a Proper Name bringeth to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: mind one thing onely; Universals recall any one of those many.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And of Names Universall, some are of more, and some of lesse extent; the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: larger comprehending the lesse large: and some again of equall extent,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: comprehending each other reciprocally. As for example, the Name Body is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of larger signification than the word Man, and conprehendeth it; and the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: names Man and Rationall, are of equall extent, comprehending mutually

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: one another. But here wee must take notice, that by a Name is not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: alwayes understood, as in Grammar, one onely word; but sometimes by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: circumlocution many words together. For all these words, Hee That In

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: His Actions Observeth The Lawes Of His Country, make but one Name,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: equivalent to this one word, Just.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: By this imposition of Names, some of larger, some of stricter

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: signification, we turn the reckoning of the consequences of things

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: imagined in the mind, into a reckoning of the consequences of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Appellations. For example, a man that hath no use of Speech at all,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (such, as is born and remains perfectly deafe and dumb,) if he set

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: before his eyes a triangle, and by it two right angles, (such as are the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: corners of a square figure,) he may by meditation compare and find, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the three angles of that triangle, are equall to those two right angles

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that stand by it. But if another triangle be shewn him different in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shape from the former, he cannot know without a new labour, whether the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: three angles of that also be equall to the same. But he that hath the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: use of words, when he observes, that such equality was consequent, not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to the length of the sides, nor to any other particular thing in his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: triangle; but onely to this, that the sides were straight, and the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: angles three; and that that was all, for which he named it a Triangle;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: will boldly conclude Universally, that such equality of angles is in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all triangles whatsoever; and register his invention in these generall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: termes, Every Triangle Hath Its Three Angles Equall To Two Right Angles.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And thus the consequence found in one particular, comes to be registred

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and remembred, as a Universall rule; and discharges our mentall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: reckoning, of time and place; and delivers us from all labour of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: mind, saving the first; and makes that which was found true Here, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Now, to be true in All Times and Places.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But the use of words in registring our thoughts, is in nothing so

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: evident as in Numbering. A naturall foole that could never learn by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: heart the order of numerall words, as One, Two, and Three, may observe

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: every stroak of the Clock, and nod to it, or say one, one, one; but can

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: never know what houre it strikes. And it seems, there was a time when

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: those names of number were not in use; and men were fayn to apply their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: fingers of one or both hands, to those things they desired to keep

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: account of; and that thence it proceeded, that now our numerall words

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are but ten, in any Nation, and in some but five, and then they begin

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: again. And he that can tell ten, if he recite them out of order, will

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: lose himselfe, and not know when he has done: Much lesse will he be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: able to add, and substract, and performe all other operations of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Arithmetique. So that without words, there is no possibility of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: reckoning of Numbers; much lesse of Magnitudes, of Swiftnesse, of Force,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and other things, the reckonings whereof are necessary to the being, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: well-being of man-kind.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: When two Names are joyned together into a Consequence, or Affirmation;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as thus, A Man Is A Living Creature; or thus, If He Be A Man, He Is A

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Living Creature, If the later name Living Creature, signifie all that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the former name Man signifieth, then the affirmation, or consequence is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: True; otherwise False. For True and False are attributes of Speech, not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of things. And where Speech in not, there is neither Truth nor Falshood.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Errour there may be, as when wee expect that which shall not be; or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: suspect what has not been: but in neither case can a man be charged with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Untruth.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Seeing then that Truth consisteth in the right ordering of names in our

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: affirmations, a man that seeketh precise Truth, had need to remember

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: what every name he uses stands for; and to place it accordingly; or els

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he will find himselfe entangled in words, as a bird in lime-twiggs; the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: more he struggles, the more belimed. And therefore in Geometry, (which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is the onely Science that it hath pleased God hitherto to bestow on

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: mankind,) men begin at settling the significations of their words; which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: settling of significations, they call Definitions; and place them in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: beginning of their reckoning.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: By this it appears how necessary it is for any man that aspires to true

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Knowledge, to examine the Definitions of former Authors; and either

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to correct them, where they are negligently set down; or to make them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: himselfe. For the errours of Definitions multiply themselves, according

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as the reckoning proceeds; and lead men into absurdities, which at last

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they see, but cannot avoyd, without reckoning anew from the beginning;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in which lyes the foundation of their errours. From whence it happens,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that they which trust to books, do as they that cast up many little

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: summs into a greater, without considering whether those little summes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: were rightly cast up or not; and at last finding the errour visible,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and not mistrusting their first grounds, know not which way to cleere

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: themselves; but spend time in fluttering over their bookes; as birds

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that entring by the chimney, and finding themselves inclosed in a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: chamber, flitter at the false light of a glasse window, for want of wit

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to consider which way they came in. So that in the right Definition

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Names, lyes the first use of Speech; which is the Acquisition of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Science: And in wrong, or no Definitions' lyes the first abuse; from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which proceed all false and senslesse Tenets; which make those men that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: take their instruction from the authority of books, and not from their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: own meditation, to be as much below the condition of ignorant men, as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: men endued with true Science are above it. For between true Science,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and erroneous Doctrines, Ignorance is in the middle. Naturall sense and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: imagination, are not subject to absurdity. Nature it selfe cannot erre:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and as men abound in copiousnesse of language; so they become more wise,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or more mad than ordinary. Nor is it possible without Letters for any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man to become either excellently wise, or (unless his memory be hurt by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: disease, or ill constitution of organs) excellently foolish. For words

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are wise mens counters, they do but reckon by them: but they are the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: mony of fooles, that value them by the authority of an Aristotle, a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Cicero, or a Thomas, or any other Doctor whatsoever, if but a man.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Subject To Names

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Subject To Names, is whatsoever can enter into, or be considered in an

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: account; and be added one to another to make a summe; or substracted one

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from another, and leave a remainder. The Latines called Accounts of mony

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Rationes, and accounting, Ratiocinatio: and that which we in bills or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: books of account call Items, they called Nomina; that is, Names: and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thence it seems to proceed, that they extended the word Ratio, to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: faculty of Reckoning in all other things. The Greeks have but one word

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Logos, for both Speech and Reason; not that they thought there was no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Speech without Reason; but no Reasoning without Speech: And the act of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: reasoning they called syllogisme; which signifieth summing up of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consequences of one saying to another. And because the same things may

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: enter into account for divers accidents; their names are (to shew that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: diversity) diversly wrested, and diversified. This diversity of names

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: may be reduced to foure generall heads.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: First, a thing may enter into account for Matter, or Body; as Living,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sensible, Rationall, Hot, Cold, Moved, Quiet; with all which names the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: word Matter, or Body is understood; all such, being names of Matter.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Secondly, it may enter into account, or be considered, for some accident

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or quality, which we conceive to be in it; as for Being Moved, for Being

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: So Long, for Being Hot, &c; and then, of the name of the thing it selfe,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by a little change or wresting, wee make a name for that accident, which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: we consider; and for Living put into account Life; for Moved, Motion;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for Hot, Heat; for Long, Length, and the like. And all such Names, are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the names of the accidents and properties, by which one Matter, and Body

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is distinguished from another. These are called Names Abstract; Because

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Severed (not from Matter, but) from the account of Matter.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Thirdly, we bring into account, the Properties of our own bodies,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whereby we make such distinction: as when any thing is Seen by us, we

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: reckon not the thing it selfe; but the Sight, the Colour, the Idea of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it in the fancy: and when any thing is Heard, wee reckon it not; but the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Hearing, or Sound onely, which is our fancy or conception of it by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Eare: and such are names of fancies.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Fourthly, we bring into account, consider, and give names, to Names

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: themselves, and to Speeches: For, Generall, Universall, Speciall,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Oequivocall, are names of Names. And Affirmation, Interrogation,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Commandement, Narration, Syllogisme, Sermon, Oration, and many other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such, are names of Speeches.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Use Of Names Positive

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And this is all the variety of Names Positive; which are put to mark

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: somewhat which is in Nature, or may be feigned by the mind of man, as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Bodies that are, or may be conceived to be; or of bodies, the Properties

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that are, or may be feigned to be; or Words and Speech.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Negative Names With Their Uses

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: There be also other Names, called Negative; which are notes to signifie

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that a word is not the name of the thing in question; as these words

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nothing, No Man, Infinite, Indocible, Three Want Foure, and the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: like; which are nevertheless of use in reckoning, or in correcting of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: reckoning; and call to mind our past cogitations, though they be not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: names of any thing; because they make us refuse to admit of Names not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: rightly used.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Words Insignificant

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: All other names, are but insignificant sounds; and those of two

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sorts. One, when they are new, and yet their meaning not explained by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Definition; whereof there have been aboundance coyned by Schoole-men,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and pusled Philosophers.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Another, when men make a name of two Names, whose significations are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: contradictory and inconsistent; as this name, an Incorporeall Body, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (which is all one) an Incorporeall Substance, and a great number more.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For whensoever any affirmation is false, the two names of which it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is composed, put together and made one, signifie nothing at all. For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: example if it be a false affirmation to say A Quadrangle Is Round,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the word Round Quadrangle signifies nothing; but is a meere sound. So

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: likewise if it be false, to say that vertue can be powred, or blown up

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and down; the words In-powred Vertue, In-blown Vertue, are as absurd

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and insignificant, as a Round Quadrangle. And therefore you shall hardly

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: meet with a senselesse and insignificant word, that is not made up of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: some Latin or Greek names. A Frenchman seldome hears our Saviour called

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by the name of Parole, but by the name of Verbe often; yet Verbe and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Parole differ no more, but that one is Latin, the other French.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Understanding

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: When a man upon the hearing of any Speech, hath those thoughts which the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: words of that Speech, and their connexion, were ordained and constituted

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to signifie; Then he is said to understand it; Understanding being

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: nothing els, but conception caused by Speech. And therefore if Speech

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be peculiar to man (as for ought I know it is,) then is Understanding

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: peculiar to him also. And therefore of absurd and false affirmations,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in case they be universall, there can be no Understanding; though many

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: think they understand, then, when they do but repeat the words softly,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or con them in their mind.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: What kinds of Speeches signifie the Appetites, Aversions, and Passions

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of mans mind; and of their use and abuse, I shall speak when I have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: spoken of the Passions.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Inconstant Names

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The names of such things as affect us, that is, which please, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: displease us, because all men be not alike affected with the same thing,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: nor the same man at all times, are in the common discourses of men, of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Inconstant signification. For seeing all names are imposed to signifie

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: our conceptions; and all our affections are but conceptions; when we

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: conceive the same things differently, we can hardly avoyd different

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: naming of them. For though the nature of that we conceive, be the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: same; yet the diversity of our reception of it, in respect of different

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: constitutions of body, and prejudices of opinion, gives everything a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: tincture of our different passions. And therefore in reasoning, a man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: bust take heed of words; which besides the signification of what we

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: imagine of their nature, disposition, and interest of the speaker; such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as are the names of Vertues, and Vices; For one man calleth Wisdome,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: what another calleth Feare; and one Cruelty, what another Justice;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: one Prodigality, what another Magnanimity; one Gravity, what another

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Stupidity, &c. And therefore such names can never be true grounds of any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ratiocination. No more can Metaphors, and Tropes of speech: but these

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are less dangerous, because they profess their inconstancy; which the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other do not.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CHAPTER V. OF REASON, AND SCIENCE.

author: Thomas Hobbes
