text: Reason What It Is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: When a man Reasoneth, hee does nothing els but conceive a summe totall,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from Addition of parcels; or conceive a Remainder, from Substraction of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: one summe from another: which (if it be done by Words,) is conceiving of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the consequence of the names of all the parts, to the name of the whole;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or from the names of the whole and one part, to the name of the other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: part. And though in some things, (as in numbers,) besides Adding and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Substracting, men name other operations, as Multiplying and Dividing;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: yet they are the same; for Multiplication, is but Addition together of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: things equall; and Division, but Substracting of one thing, as often as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: we can. These operations are not incident to Numbers onely, but to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all manner of things that can be added together, and taken one out of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: another. For as Arithmeticians teach to adde and substract in Numbers;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: so the Geometricians teach the same in Lines, Figures (solid and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: superficiall,) Angles, Proportions, Times, degrees of Swiftnesse, Force,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Power, and the like; The Logicians teach the same in Consequences

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of Words; adding together Two Names, to make an Affirmation; and Two

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Affirmations, to make a syllogisme; and Many syllogismes to make a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Demonstration; and from the Summe, or Conclusion of a syllogisme, they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: substract one Proposition, to finde the other. Writers of Politiques,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: adde together Pactions, to find mens Duties; and Lawyers, Lawes and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Facts, to find what is Right and Wrong in the actions of private men.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In summe, in what matter soever there is place for Addition and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Substraction, there also is place for Reason; and where these have no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: place, there Reason has nothing at all to do.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Reason Defined

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Out of all which we may define, (that is to say determine,) what that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is, which is meant by this word Reason, when wee reckon it amongst

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Faculties of the mind. For Reason, in this sense, is nothing but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Reckoning (that is, Adding and Substracting) of the Consequences of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: generall names agreed upon, for the Marking and Signifying of our

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thoughts; I say Marking them, when we reckon by our selves; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Signifying, when we demonstrate, or approve our reckonings to other men.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Right Reason Where

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And as in Arithmetique, unpractised men must, and Professors themselves

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: may often erre, and cast up false; so also in any other subject of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Reasoning, the ablest, most attentive, and most practised men, may

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: deceive themselves, and inferre false Conclusions; Not but that Reason

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it selfe is always Right Reason, as well as Arithmetique is a certain

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and infallible art: But no one mans Reason, nor the Reason of any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: one number of men, makes the certaintie; no more than an account is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore well cast up, because a great many men have unanimously

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: approved it. And therfore, as when there is a controversy in an account,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the parties must by their own accord, set up for right Reason, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Reason of some Arbitrator, or Judge, to whose sentence they will

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: both stand, or their controversie must either come to blowes, or be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: undecided, for want of a right Reason constituted by Nature; so is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it also in all debates of what kind soever: And when men that think

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: themselves wiser than all others, clamor and demand right Reason for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: judge; yet seek no more, but that things should be determined, by no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other mens reason but their own, it is as intolerable in the society of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: men, as it is in play after trump is turned, to use for trump on every

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: occasion, that suite whereof they have most in their hand. For they do

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: nothing els, that will have every of their passions, as it comes to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: bear sway in them, to be taken for right Reason, and that in their own

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: controversies: bewraying their want of right Reason, by the claym they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: lay to it.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Use Of Reason

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Use and End of Reason, is not the finding of the summe, and truth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of one, or a few consequences, remote from the first definitions, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: settled significations of names; but to begin at these; and proceed from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: one consequence to another. For there can be no certainty of the last

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Conclusion, without a certainty of all those Affirmations and Negations,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: on which it was grounded, and inferred. As when a master of a family,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in taking an account, casteth up the summs of all the bills of expence,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: into one sum; and not regarding how each bill is summed up, by those

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that give them in account; nor what it is he payes for; he advantages

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: himselfe no more, than if he allowed the account in grosse, trusting to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: every of the accountants skill and honesty; so also in Reasoning of all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other things, he that takes up conclusions on the trust of Authors, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: doth not fetch them from the first Items in every Reckoning, (which are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the significations of names settled by definitions), loses his labour;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and does not know any thing; but onely beleeveth.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of Error And Absurdity

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: When a man reckons without the use of words, which may be done in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: particular things, (as when upon the sight of any one thing, wee

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: conjecture what was likely to have preceded, or is likely to follow upon

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it;) if that which he thought likely to follow, followes not; or that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which he thought likely to have preceded it, hath not preceded it, this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is called ERROR; to which even the most prudent men are subject. But

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: when we Reason in Words of generall signification, and fall upon a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: generall inference which is false; though it be commonly called Error,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it is indeed an ABSURDITY, or senseless Speech. For Error is but a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: deception, in presuming that somewhat is past, or to come; of which,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: though it were not past, or not to come; yet there was no impossibility

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: discoverable. But when we make a generall assertion, unlesse it be a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: true one, the possibility of it is unconceivable. And words whereby we

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: conceive nothing but the sound, are those we call Absurd, insignificant,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Non-sense. And therefore if a man should talk to me of a Round

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Quadrangle; or Accidents Of Bread In Cheese; or Immaterial Substances;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or of A Free Subject; A Free Will; or any Free, but free from being

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hindred by opposition, I should not say he were in an Errour; but that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his words were without meaning; that is to say, Absurd.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: I have said before, (in the second chapter,) that a Man did excell

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all other Animals in this faculty, that when he conceived any thing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whatsoever, he was apt to enquire the consequences of it, and what

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: effects he could do with it. And now I adde this other degree of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: same excellence, that he can by words reduce the consequences he findes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to generall Rules, called Theoremes, or Aphorismes; that is, he can

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Reason, or reckon, not onely in number; but in all other things, whereof

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: one may be added unto, or substracted from another.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But this priviledge, is allayed by another; and that is, by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: priviledge of Absurdity; to which no living creature is subject, but man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: onely. And of men, those are of all most subject to it, that professe

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Philosophy. For it is most true that Cicero sayth of them somewhere;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that there can be nothing so absurd, but may be found in the books of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Philosophers. And the reason is manifest. For there is not one of them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that begins his ratiocination from the Definitions, or Explications of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the names they are to use; which is a method that hath been used onely

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in Geometry; whose Conclusions have thereby been made indisputable.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Causes Of Absurditie

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The first cause of Absurd conclusions I ascribe to the want of Method;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in that they begin not their Ratiocination from Definitions; that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is, from settled significations of their words: as if they could cast

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: account, without knowing the value of the numerall words, One, Two, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Three.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And whereas all bodies enter into account upon divers considerations,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (which I have mentioned in the precedent chapter;) these considerations

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: being diversly named, divers absurdities proceed from the confusion, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: unfit connexion of their names into assertions. And therefore

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The second cause of Absurd assertions, I ascribe to the giving of names

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Bodies, to Accidents; or of Accidents, to Bodies; As they do, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: say, Faith Is Infused, or Inspired; when nothing can be Powred, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Breathed into any thing, but body; and that, Extension is Body; that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Phantasmes are Spirits, &c.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The third I ascribe to the giving of the names of the Accidents of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Bodies Without Us, to the Accidents of our Own Bodies; as they do that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: say, the Colour Is In The Body; The Sound Is In The Ayre, &c.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The fourth, to the giving of the names of Bodies, to Names, or Speeches;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as they do that say, that There Be Things Universall; that A Living

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Creature Is Genus, or A Generall Thing, &c.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The fifth, to the giving of the names of Accidents, to Names and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Speeches; as they do that say, The Nature Of A Thing Is In Its

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Definition; A Mans Command Is His Will; and the like.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The sixth, to the use of Metaphors, Tropes, and other Rhetoricall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: figures, in stead of words proper. For though it be lawfull to say, (for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: example) in common speech, The Way Goeth, Or Leadeth Hither, Or Thither,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Proverb Sayes This Or That (whereas wayes cannot go, nor Proverbs

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: speak;) yet in reckoning, and seeking of truth, such speeches are not to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be admitted.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The seventh, to names that signifie nothing; but are taken up, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: learned by rote from the Schooles, as Hypostatical, Transubstantiate,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Consubstantiate, Eternal-now, and the like canting of Schoole-men.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To him that can avoyd these things, it is not easie to fall into any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: absurdity, unlesse it be by the length of an account; wherein he may

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: perhaps forget what went before. For all men by nature reason alike, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: well, when they have good principles. For who is so stupid, as both to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: mistake in Geometry, and also to persist in it, when another detects his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: error to him?

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Science

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: By this it appears that Reason is not as Sense, and Memory, borne with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: us; nor gotten by Experience onely; as Prudence is; but attayned by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Industry; first in apt imposing of Names; and secondly by getting a good

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and orderly Method in proceeding from the Elements, which are Names,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to Assertions made by Connexion of one of them to another; and so to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: syllogismes, which are the Connexions of one Assertion to another, till

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: we come to a knowledge of all the Consequences of names appertaining to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the subject in hand; and that is it, men call SCIENCE. And whereas

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sense and Memory are but knowledge of Fact, which is a thing past, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: irrevocable; Science is the knowledge of Consequences, and dependance

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of one fact upon another: by which, out of that we can presently do, we

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: know how to do something els when we will, or the like, another time;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Because when we see how any thing comes about, upon what causes, and by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: what manner; when the like causes come into our power, wee see how to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: make it produce the like effects.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Children therefore are not endued with Reason at all, till they have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: attained the use of Speech: but are called Reasonable Creatures, for the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: possibility apparent of having the use of Reason in time to come. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the most part of men, though they have the use of Reasoning a little

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: way, as in numbring to some degree; yet it serves them to little use in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: common life; in which they govern themselves, some better, some worse,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: according to their differences of experience, quicknesse of memory, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: inclinations to severall ends; but specially according to good or evill

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: fortune, and the errors of one another. For as for Science, or certain

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: rules of their actions, they are so farre from it, that they know

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not what it is. Geometry they have thought Conjuring: but for other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sciences, they who have not been taught the beginnings, and some

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: progresse in them, that they may see how they be acquired and generated,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are in this point like children, that having no thought of generation,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are made believe by the women, that their brothers and sisters are not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: born, but found in the garden.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But yet they that have no Science, are in better, and nobler condition

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with their naturall Prudence; than men, that by mis-reasoning, or by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: trusting them that reason wrong, fall upon false and absurd generall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: rules. For ignorance of causes, and of rules, does not set men so farre

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: out of their way, as relying on false rules, and taking for causes of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: what they aspire to, those that are not so, but rather causes of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: contrary.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To conclude, The Light of humane minds is Perspicuous Words, but by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: exact definitions first snuffed, and purged from ambiguity; Reason is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Pace; Encrease of Science, the Way; and the Benefit of man-kind, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: End. And on the contrary, Metaphors, and senslesse and ambiguous words,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are like Ignes Fatui; and reasoning upon them, is wandering amongst

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: innumerable absurdities; and their end, contention, and sedition, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: contempt.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Prudence & Sapience, With Their Difference

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: As, much Experience, is Prudence; so, is much Science, Sapience. For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: though wee usually have one name of Wisedome for them both; yet

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Latines did always distinguish between Prudentia and Sapientia,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ascribing the former to Experience, the later to Science. But to make

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their difference appeare more cleerly, let us suppose one man endued

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with an excellent naturall use, and dexterity in handling his armes; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: another to have added to that dexterity, an acquired Science, of where

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he can offend, or be offended by his adversarie, in every possible

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: posture, or guard: The ability of the former, would be to the ability

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the later, as Prudence to Sapience; both usefull; but the later

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: infallible. But they that trusting onely to the authority of books,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: follow the blind blindly, are like him that trusting to the false rules

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the master of fence, ventures praesumptuously upon an adversary, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: either kills, or disgraces him.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Signes Of Science

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The signes of Science, are some, certain and infallible; some,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: uncertain. Certain, when he that pretendeth the Science of any thing,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: can teach the same; that is to say, demonstrate the truth thereof

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: perspicuously to another: Uncertain, when onely some particular events

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: answer to his pretence, and upon many occasions prove so as he sayes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they must. Signes of prudence are all uncertain; because to observe by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: experience, and remember all circumstances that may alter the successe,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is impossible. But in any businesse, whereof a man has not infallible

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Science to proceed by; to forsake his own natural judgement, and be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: guided by generall sentences read in Authors, and subject to many

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: exceptions, is a signe of folly, and generally scorned by the name of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Pedantry. And even of those men themselves, that in Councells of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth, love to shew their reading of Politiques and History,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: very few do it in their domestique affaires, where their particular

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: interest is concerned; having Prudence enough for their private

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: affaires: but in publique they study more the reputation of their owne

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: wit, than the successe of anothers businesse.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CHAPTER VI. OF THE INTERIOUR BEGINNINGS OF VOLUNTARY MOTIONS

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: COMMONLY CALLED THE PASSIONS. AND THE SPEECHES BY WHICH THEY ARE

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: EXPRESSED.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Motion Vitall And Animal

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: There be in Animals, two sorts of Motions peculiar to them: One called

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Vitall; begun in generation, and continued without interruption through

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their whole life; such as are the Course of the Bloud, the Pulse, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Breathing, the Concoctions, Nutrition, Excretion, &c; to which Motions

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there needs no help of Imagination: The other in Animal Motion,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: otherwise called Voluntary Motion; as to Go, to Speak, to Move any of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: our limbes, in such manner as is first fancied in our minds. That Sense,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is Motion in the organs and interiour parts of mans body, caused by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the action of the things we See, Heare, &c.; And that Fancy is but the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Reliques of the same Motion, remaining after Sense, has been already

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sayd in the first and second Chapters. And because Going, Speaking, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the like Voluntary motions, depend alwayes upon a precedent thought of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Whither, Which Way, and What; it is evident, that the Imagination is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the first internall beginning of all Voluntary Motion. And although

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: unstudied men, doe not conceive any motion at all to be there, where

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the thing moved is invisible; or the space it is moved in, is (for the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shortnesse of it) insensible; yet that doth not hinder, but that such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Motions are. For let a space be never so little, that which is moved

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: over a greater space, whereof that little one is part, must first be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: moved over that. These small beginnings of Motion, within the body

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Man, before they appear in walking, speaking, striking, and other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: visible actions, are commonly called ENDEAVOUR.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Endeavour; Appetite; Desire; Hunger; Thirst; Aversion

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: This Endeavour, when it is toward something which causes it, is called

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: APPETITE, or DESIRE; the later, being the generall name; and the other,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: oftentimes restrayned to signifie the Desire of Food, namely Hunger and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Thirst. And when the Endeavour is fromward something, it is generally

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: called AVERSION. These words Appetite, and Aversion we have from the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Latines; and they both of them signifie the motions, one of approaching,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the other of retiring. So also do the Greek words for the same, which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are orme and aphorme. For nature it selfe does often presse upon men

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: those truths, which afterwards, when they look for somewhat beyond

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nature, they stumble at. For the Schooles find in meere Appetite to go,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or move, no actuall Motion at all: but because some Motion they must

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: acknowledge, they call it Metaphoricall Motion; which is but an absurd

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: speech; for though Words may be called metaphoricall; Bodies, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Motions cannot.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: That which men Desire, they are also sayd to LOVE; and to HATE those

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: things, for which they have Aversion. So that Desire, and Love, are the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: same thing; save that by Desire, we alwayes signifie the Absence of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the object; by Love, most commonly the Presence of the same. So also

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by Aversion, we signifie the Absence; and by Hate, the Presence of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Object.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of Appetites, and Aversions, some are born with men; as Appetite of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: food, Appetite of excretion, and exoneration, (which may also and more

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: properly be called Aversions, from somewhat they feele in their Bodies;)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and some other Appetites, not many. The rest, which are Appetites of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: particular things, proceed from Experience, and triall of their effects

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: upon themselves, or other men. For of things wee know not at all, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: believe not to be, we can have no further Desire, than to tast and try.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But Aversion wee have for things, not onely which we know have hurt us;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but also that we do not know whether they will hurt us, or not.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Contempt

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Those things which we neither Desire, nor Hate, we are said to Contemne:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CONTEMPT being nothing els but an immobility, or contumacy of the Heart,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in resisting the action of certain things; and proceeding from that the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Heart is already moved otherwise, by either more potent objects; or from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: want of experience of them.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And because the constitution of a mans Body, is in continuall mutation;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it is impossible that all the same things should alwayes cause in him

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the same Appetites, and aversions: much lesse can all men consent, in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Desire of almost any one and the same Object.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Good Evill

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But whatsoever is the object of any mans Appetite or Desire; that is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it, which he for his part calleth Good: And the object of his Hate,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Aversion, evill; And of his contempt, Vile, and Inconsiderable.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For these words of Good, evill, and Contemptible, are ever used with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: relation to the person that useth them: There being nothing simply and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: absolutely so; nor any common Rule of Good and evill, to be taken from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the nature of the objects themselves; but from the Person of the man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (where there is no Common-wealth;) or, (in a Common-wealth,) From the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Person that representeth it; or from an Arbitrator or Judge, whom men

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: disagreeing shall by consent set up, and make his sentence the Rule

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thereof.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Pulchrum Turpe; Delightfull Profitable; Unpleasant Unprofitable

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Latine Tongue has two words, whose significations approach to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: those of Good and Evill; but are not precisely the same; And those are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Pulchrum and Turpe. Whereof the former signifies that, which by some

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: apparent signes promiseth Good; and the later, that, which promiseth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: evill. But in our Tongue we have not so generall names to expresse them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by. But for Pulchrum, we say in some things, Fayre; in other Beautifull,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or Handsome, or Gallant, or Honourable, or Comely, or Amiable; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for Turpe, Foule, Deformed, Ugly, Base, Nauseous, and the like, as the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: subject shall require; All which words, in their proper places signifie

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: nothing els, but the Mine, or Countenance, that promiseth Good and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: evill. So that of Good there be three kinds; Good in the Promise,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that is Pulchrum; Good in Effect, as the end desired, which is called

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Jucundum, Delightfull; and Good as the Means, which is called Utile,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Profitable; and as many of evill: For evill, in Promise, is that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they call Turpe; evill in Effect, and End, is Molestum, Unpleasant,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Troublesome; and evill in the Means, Inutile, Unprofitable, Hurtfull.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Delight Displeasure

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: As, in Sense, that which is really within us, is (As I have sayd

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: before) onely Motion, caused by the action of externall objects, but in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: apparence; to the Sight, Light and Colour; to the Eare, Sound; to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nostrill, Odour, &c: so, when the action of the same object is continued

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from the Eyes, Eares, and other organs to the Heart; the real effect

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there is nothing but Motion, or Endeavour; which consisteth in Appetite,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or Aversion, to, or from the object moving. But the apparence, or sense

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of that motion, is that wee either call DELIGHT, or TROUBLE OF MIND.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Pleasure Offence

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: This Motion, which is called Appetite, and for the apparence of it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Delight, and Pleasure, seemeth to be, a corroboration of Vitall motion,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and a help thereunto; and therefore such things as caused Delight, were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not improperly called Jucunda, (A Juvando,) from helping or fortifying;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and the contrary, Molesta, Offensive, from hindering, and troubling the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: motion vitall.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Pleasure therefore, (or Delight,) is the apparence, or sense of Good;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Molestation or Displeasure, the apparence, or sense of evill. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consequently all Appetite, Desire, and Love, is accompanied with some

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Delight more or lesse; and all Hatred, and Aversion, with more or lesse

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Displeasure and Offence.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Pleasures Of Sense; Pleasures Of The Mind; Joy Paine Griefe

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of Pleasures, or Delights, some arise from the sense of an object

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Present; And those may be called Pleasures Of Sense, (The word Sensuall,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as it is used by those onely that condemn them, having no place till

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there be Lawes.) Of this kind are all Onerations and Exonerations of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: body; as also all that is pleasant, in the Sight, Hearing, Smell,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Tast, Or Touch; Others arise from the Expectation, that proceeds from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: foresight of the End, or Consequence of things; whether those things in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Sense Please or Displease: And these are Pleasures Of The Mind of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him that draweth those consequences; and are generally called JOY. In

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the like manner, Displeasures, are some in the Sense, and called PAYNE;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: others, in the Expectation of consequences, and are called GRIEFE.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: These simple Passions called Appetite, Desire, Love, Aversion, Hate,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Joy, and griefe, have their names for divers considerations diversified.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: As first, when they one succeed another, they are diversly called from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the opinion men have of the likelihood of attaining what they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: desire. Secondly, from the object loved or hated. Thirdly, from the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consideration of many of them together. Fourthly, from the Alteration or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: succession it selfe.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Hope-- For Appetite with an opinion of attaining, is called HOPE.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Despaire-- The same, without such opinion, DESPAIRE.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Feare-- Aversion, with opinion of Hurt from the object, FEARE.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Courage-- The same, with hope of avoyding that Hurt by resistance,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: COURAGE.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Anger-- Sudden Courage, ANGER.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Confidence-- Constant Hope, CONFIDENCE of our selves.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Diffidence-- Constant Despayre, DIFFIDENCE of our selves.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Indignation-- Anger for great hurt done to another, when we conceive the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: same to be done by Injury, INDIGNATION.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Benevolence-- Desire of good to another, BENEVOLENCE, GOOD WILL,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CHARITY. If to man generally, GOOD NATURE.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Covetousnesse-- Desire of Riches, COVETOUSNESSE: a name used alwayes in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: signification of blame; because men contending for them, are displeased

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with one anothers attaining them; though the desire in it selfe, be to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be blamed, or allowed, according to the means by which those Riches are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sought.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ambition-- Desire of Office, or precedence, AMBITION: a name used also

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the worse sense, for the reason before mentioned.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Pusillanimity-- Desire of things that conduce but a little to our ends;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And fear of things that are but of little hindrance, PUSILLANIMITY.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Magnanimity-- Contempt of little helps, and hindrances, MAGNANIMITY.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Valour-- Magnanimity, in danger of Death, or Wounds, VALOUR, FORTITUDE.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Liberality-- Magnanimity in the use of Riches, LIBERALITY

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Miserablenesse-- Pusillanimity, in the same WRETCHEDNESSE,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: MISERABLENESSE; or PARSIMONY; as it is liked or disliked.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kindnesse-- Love of Persons for society, KINDNESSE.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Naturall Lust-- Love of Persons for Pleasing the sense onely, NATURAL

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: LUST.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Luxury-- Love of the same, acquired from Rumination, that is Imagination

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Pleasure past, LUXURY.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Passion Of Love; Jealousie-- Love of one singularly, with desire to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be singularly beloved, THE PASSION OF LOVE. The same, with fear that the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: love is not mutuall, JEALOUSIE.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Revengefulnesse-- Desire, by doing hurt to another, to make him condemn

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: some fact of his own, REVENGEFULNESSE.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Curiosity-- Desire, to know why, and how, CURIOSITY; such as is in no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: living creature but Man; so that Man is distinguished, not onely by his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Reason; but also by this singular Passion from other Animals; in whom

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the appetite of food, and other pleasures of Sense, by praedominance,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: take away the care of knowing causes; which is a Lust of the mind,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that by a perseverance of delight in the continuall and indefatigable

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: generation of Knowledge, exceedeth the short vehemence of any carnall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Pleasure.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Religion Superstition; True Religion-- Feare of power invisible, feigned

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by the mind, or imagined from tales publiquely allowed, RELIGION; not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: allowed, superstition. And when the power imagined is truly such as we

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: imagine, TRUE RELIGION.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Panique Terrour-- Feare, without the apprehension of why, or what,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: PANIQUE TERROR; called so from the fables that make Pan the author of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them; whereas in truth there is always in him that so feareth, first,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: some apprehension of the cause, though the rest run away by example;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: every one supposing his fellow to know why. And therefore this Passion

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: happens to none but in a throng, or multitude of people.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Admiration-- Joy, from apprehension of novelty, ADMIRATION; proper to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man, because it excites the appetite of knowing the cause.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Glory Vaine-glory-- Joy, arising from imagination of a man's own power

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and ability, is that exultation of the mind which is called GLORYING:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which, if grounded upon the experience of his own former actions, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the same with Confidence: but if grounded on the flattery of others, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: onely supposed by himselfe, for delight in the consequences of it,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is called VAINE-GLORY: which name is properly given; because a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: well-grounded Confidence begetteth attempt; whereas the supposing of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: power does not, and is therefore rightly called Vaine.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Dejection-- Griefe, from opinion of want of power, is called dejection

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of mind.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Vaine-glory which consisteth in the feigning or supposing of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: abilities in ourselves, which we know are not, is most incident to young

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: men, and nourished by the Histories or Fictions of Gallant Persons; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is corrected often times by Age, and Employment.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sudden Glory Laughter-- Sudden glory, is the passion which maketh those

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Grimaces called LAUGHTER; and is caused either by some sudden act of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their own, that pleaseth them; or by the apprehension of some

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: deformed thing in another, by comparison whereof they suddenly applaud

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: themselves. And it is incident most to them, that are conscious of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: fewest abilities in themselves; who are forced to keep themselves in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their own favour, by observing the imperfections of other men.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And therefore much Laughter at the defects of others is a signe of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Pusillanimity. For of great minds, one of the proper workes is, to help

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and free others from scorn; and compare themselves onely with the most

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: able.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sudden Dejection Weeping-- On the contrary, Sudden Dejection is the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: passion that causeth WEEPING; and is caused by such accidents, as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: suddenly take away some vehement hope, or some prop of their power: and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they are most subject to it, that rely principally on helps externall,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such as are Women, and Children. Therefore, some Weep for the loss of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Friends; Others for their unkindnesse; others for the sudden stop made

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to their thoughts of revenge, by Reconciliation. But in all cases, both

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Laughter and Weeping, are sudden motions; Custome taking them both away.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For no man Laughs at old jests; or Weeps for an old calamity.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Shame Blushing-- Griefe, for the discovery of some defect of ability

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is SHAME, or the passion that discovereth itself in BLUSHING; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consisteth in the apprehension of some thing dishonourable; and in young

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: men, is a signe of the love of good reputation; and commendable: in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: old men it is a signe of the same; but because it comes too late, not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: commendable.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Impudence-- The Contempt of good reputation is called IMPUDENCE.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Pitty-- Griefe, for the calamity of another is PITTY; and ariseth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from the imagination that the like calamity may befall himselfe; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore is called also COMPASSION, and in the phrase of this present

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: time a FELLOW-FEELING: and therefore for Calamity arriving from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: great wickedness, the best men have the least Pitty; and for the same

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Calamity, those have least Pitty, that think themselves least obnoxious

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to the same.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Cruelty-- Contempt, or little sense of the calamity of others, is that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which men call CRUELTY; proceeding from Security of their own fortune.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For, that any man should take pleasure in other mens' great harmes,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: without other end of his own, I do not conceive it possible.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Emulation Envy-- Griefe, for the success of a Competitor in wealth,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: honour, or other good, if it be joyned with Endeavour to enforce our own

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: abilities to equal or exceed him, is called EMULATION: but joyned with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Endeavour to supplant or hinder a Competitor, ENVIE.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Deliberation-- When in the mind of man, Appetites and Aversions, Hopes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Feares, concerning one and the same thing, arise alternately; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: divers good and evill consequences of the doing, or omitting the thing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: propounded, come successively into our thoughts; so that sometimes we

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have an Appetite to it, sometimes an Aversion from it; sometimes Hope to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be able to do it; sometimes Despaire, or Feare to attempt it; the whole

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sum of Desires, Aversions, Hopes and Feares, continued till the thing be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: either done, or thought impossible, is that we call DELIBERATION.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Therefore of things past, there is no Deliberation; because manifestly

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: impossible to be changed: nor of things known to be impossible, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thought so; because men know, or think such Deliberation vaine. But

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of things impossible, which we think possible, we may Deliberate; not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: knowing it is in vain. And it is called DELIBERATION; because it is a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: putting an end to the Liberty we had of doing, or omitting, according to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: our own Appetite, or Aversion.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: This alternate succession of Appetites, Aversions, Hopes and Feares is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: no less in other living Creatures than in Man; and therefore Beasts also

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Deliberate.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Every Deliberation is then sayd to End when that whereof they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Deliberate, is either done, or thought impossible; because till then wee

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: retain the liberty of doing, or omitting, according to our Appetite, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Aversion.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Will

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In Deliberation, the last Appetite, or Aversion, immediately adhaering

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to the action, or to the omission thereof, is that wee call the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: WILL; the Act, (not the faculty,) of Willing. And Beasts that have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Deliberation must necessarily also have Will. The Definition of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Will, given commonly by the Schooles, that it is a Rationall Appetite,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is not good. For if it were, then could there be no Voluntary Act

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: against Reason. For a Voluntary Act is that, which proceedeth from the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Will, and no other. But if in stead of a Rationall Appetite, we shall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: say an Appetite resulting from a precedent Deliberation, then the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Definition is the same that I have given here. Will, therefore, Is The

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Last Appetite In Deliberating. And though we say in common Discourse, a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man had a Will once to do a thing, that neverthelesse he forbore to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: do; yet that is properly but an Inclination, which makes no Action

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Voluntary; because the action depends not of it, but of the last

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Inclination, or Appetite. For if the intervenient Appetites make any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: action Voluntary, then by the same reason all intervenient Aversions

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: should make the same action Involuntary; and so one and the same action

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: should be both Voluntary & Involuntary.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: By this it is manifest, that not onely actions that have their beginning

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from Covetousness, Ambition, Lust, or other Appetites to the thing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: propounded; but also those that have their beginning from Aversion,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or Feare of those consequences that follow the omission, are Voluntary

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Actions.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Formes Of Speech, In Passion

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The formes of Speech by which the Passions are expressed, are partly the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: same, and partly different from those, by which we express our Thoughts.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And first generally all Passions may be expressed Indicatively; as, I

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Love, I Feare, I Joy, I Deliberate, I Will, I Command: but some of them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have particular expressions by themselves, which nevertheless are not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: affirmations, unless it be when they serve to make other inferences,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: besides that of the Passion they proceed from. Deliberation is expressed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Subjunctively; which is a speech proper to signifie suppositions, with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their consequences; as, If This Be Done, Then This Will Follow; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: differs not from the language of Reasoning, save that Reasoning is in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: generall words, but Deliberation for the most part is of Particulars.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The language of Desire, and Aversion, is Imperative; as, Do This,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Forbear That; which when the party is obliged to do, or forbear, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Command; otherwise Prayer; or els Counsell. The language of Vaine-Glory,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Indignation, Pitty and Revengefulness, Optative: but of the Desire to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: know, there is a peculiar expression called Interrogative; as, What Is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: It, When Shall It, How Is It Done, and Why So? Other language of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Passions I find none: for Cursing, Swearing, Reviling, and the like, do

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not signifie as Speech; but as the actions of a tongue accustomed.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: These forms of Speech, I say, are expressions, or voluntary

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: significations of our Passions: but certain signes they be not; because

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they may be used arbitrarily, whether they that use them, have such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Passions or not. The best signes of Passions present, are either in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: countenance, motions of the body, actions, and ends, or aims, which we

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: otherwise know the man to have.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Good And Evill Apparent

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And because in Deliberation the Appetites and Aversions are raised by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: foresight of the good and evill consequences, and sequels of the action

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whereof we Deliberate; the good or evill effect thereof dependeth on the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: foresight of a long chain of consequences, of which very seldome any man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is able to see to the end. But for so far as a man seeth, if the Good

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in those consequences be greater than the evill, the whole chain is that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which Writers call Apparent or Seeming Good. And contrarily, when the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: evill exceedeth the good, the whole is Apparent or Seeming Evill: so

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that he who hath by Experience, or Reason, the greatest and surest

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: prospect of Consequences, Deliberates best himself; and is able, when he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: will, to give the best counsel unto others.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Felicity

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Continual Successe in obtaining those things which a man from time to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: time desireth, that is to say, continual prospering, is that men call

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: FELICITY; I mean the Felicity of this life. For there is no such thing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as perpetual Tranquillity of mind, while we live here; because Life

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: itself is but Motion, and can never be without Desire, nor without

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Feare, no more than without Sense. What kind of Felicity God hath

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ordained to them that devoutly honour him, a man shall no sooner know,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: than enjoy; being joys, that now are as incomprehensible, as the word of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: School-men, Beatifical Vision, is unintelligible.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Praise Magnification

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The form of speech whereby men signifie their opinion of the Goodnesse

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of anything is PRAISE. That whereby they signifie the power and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: greatness of anything is MAGNIFYING. And that whereby they signifie

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the opinion they have of a man's felicity is by the Greeks called

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Makarismos, for which we have no name in our tongue. And thus much is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sufficient for the present purpose to have been said of the passions.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CHAPTER VII. OF THE ENDS OR RESOLUTIONS OF DISCOURSE

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of all Discourse, governed by desire of Knowledge, there is at last

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: an End, either by attaining, or by giving over. And in the chain of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Discourse, wheresoever it be interrupted, there is an End for that time.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Judgement, or Sentence Final; Doubt

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: If the Discourse be meerly Mentall, it consisteth of thoughts that the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thing will be, and will not be; or that it has been, and has not been,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: alternately. So that wheresoever you break off the chayn of a mans

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Discourse, you leave him in a Praesumption of It Will Be, or, It Will

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Not Be; or it Has Been, or, Has Not Been. All which is Opinion. And that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which is alternate Appetite, in Deliberating concerning Good and Evil,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the same is alternate Opinion in the Enquiry of the truth of Past, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Future. And as the last Appetite in Deliberation is called the Will, so

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the last Opinion in search of the truth of Past, and Future, is called

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the JUDGEMENT, or Resolute and Final Sentence of him that Discourseth.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And as the whole chain of Appetites alternate, in the question of Good

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or Bad is called Deliberation; so the whole chain of Opinions alternate,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the question of True, or False is called DOUBT.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: No Discourse whatsoever, can End in absolute knowledge of Fact, past, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to come. For, as for the knowledge of Fact, it is originally, Sense; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ever after, Memory. And for the knowledge of consequence, which I have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: said before is called Science, it is not Absolute, but Conditionall. No

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man can know by Discourse, that this, or that, is, has been, or will

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be; which is to know absolutely: but onely, that if This be, That is; if

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: This has been, That has been; if This shall be, That shall be: which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is to know conditionally; and that not the consequence of one thing to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: another; but of one name of a thing, to another name of the same thing.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Science Opinion Conscience

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And therefore, when the Discourse is put into Speech, and begins with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Definitions of Words, and proceeds by Connexion of the same into

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: general Affirmations, and of these again into Syllogismes, the end or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: last sum is called the Conclusion; and the thought of the mind by it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: signified is that conditional Knowledge, or Knowledge of the consequence

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of words, which is commonly called Science. But if the first ground of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such Discourse be not Definitions, or if the Definitions be not rightly

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: joyned together into Syllogismes, then the End or Conclusion is again

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: OPINION, namely of the truth of somewhat said, though sometimes in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: absurd and senslesse words, without possibility of being understood.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: When two, or more men, know of one and the same fact, they are said

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to be CONSCIOUS of it one to another; which is as much as to know it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: together. And because such are fittest witnesses of the facts of one

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: another, or of a third, it was, and ever will be reputed a very Evill

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: act, for any man to speak against his Conscience; or to corrupt or force

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: another so to do: Insomuch that the plea of Conscience, has been always

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hearkened unto very diligently in all times. Afterwards, men made use

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the same word metaphorically, for the knowledge of their own secret

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: facts, and secret thoughts; and therefore it is Rhetorically said that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Conscience is a thousand witnesses. And last of all, men, vehemently

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in love with their own new opinions, (though never so absurd,) and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: obstinately bent to maintain them, gave those their opinions also that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: reverenced name of Conscience, as if they would have it seem unlawful,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to change or speak against them; and so pretend to know they are true,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: when they know at most but that they think so.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Beliefe Faith

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: When a mans Discourse beginneth not at Definitions, it beginneth either

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: at some other contemplation of his own, and then it is still called

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Opinion; Or it beginneth at some saying of another, of whose ability to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: know the truth, and of whose honesty in not deceiving, he doubteth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not; and then the Discourse is not so much concerning the Thing, as the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Person; And the Resolution is called BELEEFE, and FAITH: Faith, In the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man; Beleefe, both Of the man, and Of the truth of what he sayes. So

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: then in Beleefe are two opinions; one of the saying of the man; the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other of his vertue. To Have Faith In, or Trust To, or Beleeve A Man,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: signifie the same thing; namely, an opinion of the veracity of the man:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But to Beleeve What Is Said, signifieth onely an opinion of the truth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the saying. But wee are to observe that this Phrase, I Beleeve In;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as also the Latine, Credo In; and the Greek, Pisteno Eis, are never used

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but in the writings of Divines. In stead of them, in other writings are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: put, I Beleeve Him; I Have Faith In Him; I Rely On Him: and in Latin,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Credo Illi; Fido Illi: and in Greek, Pisteno Anto: and that this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: singularity of the Ecclesiastical use of the word hath raised many

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: disputes about the right object of the Christian Faith.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But by Beleeving In, as it is in the Creed, is meant, not trust in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Person; but Confession and acknowledgement of the Doctrine. For not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: onely Christians, but all manner of men do so believe in God, as to hold

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all for truth they heare him say, whether they understand it, or not;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which is all the Faith and trust can possibly be had in any person

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whatsoever: But they do not all believe the Doctrine of the Creed.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: From whence we may inferre, that when wee believe any saying whatsoever

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it be, to be true, from arguments taken, not from the thing it selfe, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from the principles of naturall Reason, but from the Authority, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: good opinion wee have, of him that hath sayd it; then is the speaker, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: person we believe in, or trust in, and whose word we take, the object of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: our Faith; and the Honour done in Believing, is done to him onely. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consequently, when wee Believe that the Scriptures are the word of God,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: having no immediate revelation from God himselfe, our Beleefe, Faith,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Trust is in the Church; whose word we take, and acquiesce therein.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And they that believe that which a Prophet relates unto them in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: name of God, take the word of the Prophet, do honour to him, and in him

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: trust, and believe, touching the truth of what he relateth, whether he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be a true, or a false Prophet. And so it is also with all other History.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For if I should not believe all that is written By Historians, of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: glorious acts of Alexander, or Caesar; I do not think the Ghost of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Alexander, or Caesar, had any just cause to be offended; or any body

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: else, but the Historian. If Livy say the Gods made once a Cow speak, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: we believe it not; wee distrust not God therein, but Livy. So that it is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: evident, that whatsoever we believe, upon no other reason, than what is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: drawn from authority of men onely, and their writings; whether they be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sent from God or not, is Faith in men onely.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CHAPTER VIII. OF THE VERTUES COMMONLY CALLED INTELLECTUAL;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: AND THEIR CONTRARY DEFECTS

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Intellectuall Vertue Defined

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Vertue generally, in all sorts of subjects, is somewhat that is valued

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for eminence; and consisteth in comparison. For if all things

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: were equally in all men, nothing would be prized. And by Vertues

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: INTELLECTUALL, are always understood such abilityes of the mind, as men

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: praise, value, and desire should be in themselves; and go commonly under

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the name of a Good Witte; though the same word Witte, be used also, to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: distinguish one certain ability from the rest.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Wit, Naturall, Or Acquired

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: These Vertues are of two sorts; Naturall, and Acquired. By Naturall, I

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: mean not, that which a man hath from his Birth: for that is nothing else

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but Sense; wherein men differ so little one from another, and from brute

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Beasts, as it is not to be reckoned amongst Vertues. But I mean, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Witte, which is gotten by Use onely, and Experience; without Method,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Culture, or Instruction. This NATURALL WITTE, consisteth principally

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in two things; Celerity Of Imagining, (that is, swift succession of one

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thought to another;) and Steddy Direction to some approved end. On the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Contrary a slow Imagination, maketh that Defect, or fault of the mind,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which is commonly called DULNESSE, Stupidity, and sometimes by other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: names that signifie slownesse of motion, or difficulty to be moved.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Good Wit, Or Fancy; Good Judgement; Discretion

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And this difference of quicknesse, is caused by the difference of mens

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: passions; that love and dislike, some one thing, some another: and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore some mens thoughts run one way, some another: and are held to,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and observe differently the things that passe through their imagination.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And whereas in his succession of mens thoughts, there is nothing to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: observe in the things they think on, but either in what they be Like One

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Another, or in what they be Unlike, or What They Serve For, or How They

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Serve To Such A Purpose; Those that observe their similitudes, in case

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they be such as are but rarely observed by others, are sayd to have a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Good Wit; by which, in this occasion, is meant a Good Fancy. But they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that observe their differences, and dissimilitudes; which is called

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Distinguishing, and Discerning, and Judging between thing and thing; in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: case, such discerning be not easie, are said to have a Good Judgement:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and particularly in matter of conversation and businesse; wherein,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: times, places, and persons are to be discerned, this Vertue is called

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: DISCRETION. The former, that is, Fancy, without the help of Judgement,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is not commended as a Vertue: but the later which is Judgement, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Discretion, is commended for it selfe, without the help of Fancy.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Besides the Discretion of times, places, and persons, necessary to a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: good Fancy, there is required also an often application of his thoughts

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to their End; that is to say, to some use to be made of them. This done;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he that hath this Vertue, will be easily fitted with similitudes, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: will please, not onely by illustration of his discourse, and adorning it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with new and apt metaphors; but also, by the rarity or their invention.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But without Steddinesse, and Direction to some End, a great Fancy is one

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: kind of Madnesse; such as they have, that entring into any discourse,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are snatched from their purpose, by every thing that comes in their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thought, into so many, and so long digressions, and parentheses, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they utterly lose themselves: Which kind of folly, I know no particular

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: name for: but the cause of it is, sometimes want of experience; whereby

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that seemeth to a man new and rare, which doth not so to others:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sometimes Pusillanimity; by which that seems great to him, which other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: men think a trifle: and whatsoever is new, or great, and therefore

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thought fit to be told, withdrawes a man by degrees from the intended

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: way of his discourse.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In a good Poem, whether it be Epique, or Dramatique; as also in Sonnets,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Epigrams, and other Pieces, both Judgement and Fancy are required:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But the Fancy must be more eminent; because they please for the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Extravagancy; but ought not to displease by Indiscretion.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In a good History, the Judgement must be eminent; because the goodnesse

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consisteth, in the Method, in the Truth, and in the Choyse of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: actions that are most profitable to be known. Fancy has no place, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: onely in adorning the stile.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In Orations of Prayse, and in Invectives, the Fancy is praedominant;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: because the designe is not truth, but to Honour or Dishonour; which is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: done by noble, or by vile comparisons. The Judgement does but suggest

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: what circumstances make an action laudable, or culpable.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In Hortatives, and Pleadings, as Truth, or Disguise serveth best to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Designe in hand; so is the Judgement, or the Fancy most required.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In Demonstration, in Councell, and all rigourous search of Truth,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Judgement does all; except sometimes the understanding have need to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: opened by some apt similitude; and then there is so much use of Fancy.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But for Metaphors, they are in this case utterly excluded. For seeing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they openly professe deceipt; to admit them into Councell, or Reasoning,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: were manifest folly.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And in any Discourse whatsoever, if the defect of Discretion be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: apparent, how extravagant soever the Fancy be, the whole discourse

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: will be taken for a signe of want of wit; and so will it never when the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Discretion is manifest, though the Fancy be never so ordinary.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The secret thoughts of a man run over all things, holy, prophane,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: clean, obscene, grave, and light, without shame, or blame; which verball

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: discourse cannot do, farther than the Judgement shall approve of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Time, Place, and Persons. An Anatomist, or a Physitian may speak, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: write his judgement of unclean things; because it is not to please,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but profit: but for another man to write his extravagant, and pleasant

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: fancies of the same, is as if a man, from being tumbled into the dirt,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: should come and present himselfe before good company. And 'tis the want

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Discretion that makes the difference. Again, in profest remissnesse

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of mind, and familiar company, a man may play with the sounds, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: aequivocal significations of words; and that many times with encounters

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of extraordinary Fancy: but in a Sermon, or in publique, or before

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: persons unknown, or whom we ought to reverence, there is no Gingling of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: words that will not be accounted folly: and the difference is onely in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the want of Discretion. So that where Wit is wanting, it is not Fancy

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that is wanting, but Discretion. Judgement therefore without Fancy is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Wit, but Fancy without Judgement not.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Prudence

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: When the thoughts of a man, that has a designe in hand, running over a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: multitude of things, observes how they conduce to that designe; or what

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: designe they may conduce into; if his observations be such as are not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: easie, or usuall, This wit of his is called PRUDENCE; and dependeth on

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: much Experience, and Memory of the like things, and their consequences

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: heretofore. In which there is not so much difference of Men, as there is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in their Fancies and Judgements; Because the Experience of men equall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in age, is not much unequall, as to the quantity; but lyes in different

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: occasions; every one having his private designes. To govern well a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: family, and a kingdome, are not different degrees of Prudence; but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: different sorts of businesse; no more then to draw a picture in little,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or as great, or greater then the life, are different degrees of Art. A

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: plain husband-man is more Prudent in affaires of his own house, then a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Privy Counseller in the affaires of another man.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Craft

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To Prudence, if you adde the use of unjust, or dishonest means, such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as usually are prompted to men by Feare, or Want; you have that Crooked

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Wisdome, which is called CRAFT; which is a signe of Pusillanimity. For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Magnanimity is contempt of unjust, or dishonest helps. And that which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Latines Call Versutia, (translated into English, Shifting,) and is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a putting off of a present danger or incommodity, by engaging into

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a greater, as when a man robbs one to pay another, is but a shorter

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sighted Craft, called Versutia, from Versura, which signifies taking

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: mony at usurie, for the present payment of interest.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Acquired Wit

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: As for Acquired Wit, (I mean acquired by method and instruction,) there

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is none but Reason; which is grounded on the right use of Speech; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: produceth the Sciences. But of Reason and Science, I have already spoken

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the fifth and sixth Chapters.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The causes of this difference of Witts, are in the Passions: and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the difference of Passions, proceedeth partly from the different

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Constitution of the body, and partly from different Education. For if

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the difference proceeded from the temper of the brain, and the organs of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sense, either exterior or interior, there would be no lesse difference

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of men in their Sight, Hearing, or other Senses, than in their Fancies,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Discretions. It proceeds therefore from the Passions; which are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: different, not onely from the difference of mens complexions; but also

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from their difference of customes, and education.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Passions that most of all cause the differences of Wit, are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: principally, the more or lesse Desire of Power, of Riches, of Knowledge,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and of Honour. All which may be reduced to the first, that is Desire of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Power. For Riches, Knowledge and Honour are but severall sorts of Power.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Giddinesse Madnesse

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And therefore, a man who has no great Passion for any of these things;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but is as men terme it indifferent; though he may be so farre a good

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man, as to be free from giving offence; yet he cannot possibly have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: either a great Fancy, or much Judgement. For the Thoughts, are to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Desires, as Scouts, and Spies, to range abroad, and find the way to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: things Desired: All Stedinesse of the minds motion, and all quicknesse

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the same, proceeding from thence. For as to have no Desire, is to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be Dead: so to have weak Passions, is Dulnesse; and to have Passions

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: indifferently for every thing, GIDDINESSE, and Distraction; and to have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: stronger, and more vehement Passions for any thing, than is ordinarily

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: seen in others, is that which men call MADNESSE.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Whereof there be almost as many kinds, as of the Passions themselves.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sometimes the extraordinary and extravagant Passion, proceedeth from the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: evill constitution of the organs of the Body, or harme done them; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sometimes the hurt, and indisposition of the Organs, is caused by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: vehemence, or long continuance of the Passion. But in both cases the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Madnesse is of one and the same nature.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Passion, whose violence, or continuance maketh Madnesse, is either

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: great Vaine-Glory; which is commonly called Pride, and Selfe-Conceipt;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or great Dejection of mind.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Rage

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Pride, subjecteth a man to Anger, the excesse whereof, is the Madnesse

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: called RAGE, and FURY. And thus it comes to passe that excessive desire

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Revenge, when it becomes habituall, hurteth the organs, and becomes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Rage: That excessive love, with jealousie, becomes also Rage: Excessive

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: opinion of a mans own selfe, for divine inspiration, for wisdome,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: learning, forme, and the like, becomes Distraction, and Giddinesse:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the same, joyned with Envy, Rage: Vehement opinion of the truth of any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thing, contradicted by others, Rage.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Melancholy

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Dejection, subjects a man to causelesse fears; which is a Madnesse

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: commonly called MELANCHOLY, apparent also in divers manners; as in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: haunting of solitudes, and graves; in superstitious behaviour; and in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: fearing some one, some another particular thing. In summe, all Passions

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that produce strange and unusuall behaviour, are called by the generall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: name of Madnesse. But of the severall kinds of Madnesse, he that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: would take the paines, might enrowle a legion. And if the Excesses be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: madnesse, there is no doubt but the Passions themselves, when they tend
