author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to Evill, are degrees of the same.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (For example,) Though the effect of folly, in them that are possessed of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: an opinion of being inspired, be not visible alwayes in one man, by any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: very extravagant action, that proceedeth from such Passion; yet when

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: many of them conspire together, the Rage of the whole multitude is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: visible enough. For what argument of Madnesse can there be greater, than

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to clamour, strike, and throw stones at our best friends? Yet this is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: somewhat lesse than such a multitude will do. For they will clamour,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: fight against, and destroy those, by whom all their lifetime before,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they have been protected, and secured from injury. And if this be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Madnesse in the multitude, it is the same in every particular man. For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as in the middest of the sea, though a man perceive no sound of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that part of the water next him; yet he is well assured, that part

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: contributes as much, to the Roaring of the Sea, as any other part, of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the same quantity: so also, thought wee perceive no great unquietnesse,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in one, or two men; yet we may be well assured, that their singular

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Passions, are parts of the Seditious roaring of a troubled Nation. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: if there were nothing else that bewrayed their madnesse; yet that very

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: arrogating such inspiration to themselves, is argument enough. If some

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man in Bedlam should entertaine you with sober discourse; and you desire

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in taking leave, to know what he were, that you might another time

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: requite his civility; and he should tell you, he were God the Father;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: I think you need expect no extravagant action for argument of his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Madnesse.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: This opinion of Inspiration, called commonly, Private Spirit, begins

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: very often, from some lucky finding of an Errour generally held by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: others; and not knowing, or not remembring, by what conduct of reason,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they came to so singular a truth, (as they think it, though it be many

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: times an untruth they light on,) they presently admire themselves; as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: being in the speciall grace of God Almighty, who hath revealed the same

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to them supernaturally, by his Spirit.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Again, that Madnesse is nothing else, but too much appearing Passion,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: may be gathered out of the effects of Wine, which are the same with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: those of the evill disposition of the organs. For the variety of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: behaviour in men that have drunk too much, is the same with that of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Mad-men: some of them Raging, others Loving, others laughing, all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: extravagantly, but according to their severall domineering Passions:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For the effect of the wine, does but remove Dissimulation; and take from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them the sight of the deformity of their Passions. For, (I believe) the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: most sober men, when they walk alone without care and employment of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: mind, would be unwilling the vanity and Extravagance of their thoughts

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: at that time should be publiquely seen: which is a confession, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Passions unguided, are for the most part meere Madnesse.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The opinions of the world, both in antient and later ages, concerning

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the cause of madnesse, have been two. Some, deriving them from the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Passions; some, from Daemons, or Spirits, either good, or bad, which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they thought might enter into a man, possesse him, and move his organs

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is such strange, and uncouth manner, as mad-men use to do. The former

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sort therefore, called such men, Mad-men: but the Later, called them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sometimes Daemoniacks, (that is, possessed with spirits;) sometimes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Energumeni, (that is agitated, or moved with spirits;) and now in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Italy they are called not onely Pazzi, Mad-men; but also Spiritati, men

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: possest.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Greeks, at the acting of the Tragedy of Andromeda, upon an extream hot

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: day: whereupon, a great many of the spectators falling into Fevers, had

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: this accident from the heat, and from The Tragedy together, that they

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: story sayes cured that madnesse. But on the other side, the same

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Graecians, did often ascribe madnesse, to the operation of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Eumenides, or Furyes; and sometimes of Ceres, Phoebus, and other Gods:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: so much did men attribute to Phantasmes, as to think them aereal living

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: bodies; and generally to call them Spirits. And as the Romans in this,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: held the same opinion with the Greeks: so also did the Jewes; For they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: calle mad-men Prophets, or (according as they thought the spirits

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: good or bad) Daemoniacks; and some of them called both Prophets, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Daemoniacks, mad-men; and some called the same man both Daemoniack, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: mad-man. But for the Gentiles, 'tis no wonder; because Diseases, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Health; Vices, and Vertues; and many naturall accidents, were with them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: termed, and worshipped as Daemons. So that a man was to understand by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Daemon, as well (sometimes) an Ague, as a Divell. But for the Jewes to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have such opinion, is somewhat strange. For neither Moses, nor Abraham

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: pretended to Prophecy by possession of a Spirit; but from the voyce of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: God; or by a Vision or Dream: Nor is there any thing in his Law,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Morall, or Ceremoniall, by which they were taught, there was any such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Enthusiasme; or any Possession. When God is sayd, (Numb. 11. 25.) to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: take from the Spirit that was in Moses, and give it to the 70. Elders,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Spirit of God (taking it for the substance of God) is not divided.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Scriptures by the Spirit of God in man, mean a mans spirit, enclined

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to Godlinesse. And where it is said (Exod. 28. 3.) "Whom I have filled

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with the Spirit of wisdome to make garments for Aaron," is not meant a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: spirit put into them, that can make garments; but the wisdome of their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: own spirits in that kind of work. In the like sense, the spirit of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man, when it produceth unclean actions, is ordinarily called an unclean

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: spirit; and so other spirits, though not alwayes, yet as often as the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: vertue or vice so stiled, is extraordinary, and Eminent. Neither did the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other Prophets of the old Testament pretend Enthusiasme; or, that God

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: spake in them; but to them by Voyce, Vision, or Dream; and the Burthen

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of The Lord was not Possession, but Command. How then could the Jewes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: fall into this opinion of possession? I can imagine no reason, but that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which is common to all men; namely, the want of curiosity to search

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: naturall causes; and their placing Felicity, in the acquisition of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: grosse pleasures of the Senses, and the things that most immediately

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: conduce thereto. For they that see any strange, and unusuall ability, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: defect in a mans mind; unlesse they see withall, from what cause it may

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: probably proceed, can hardly think it naturall; and if not naturall,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they must needs thinke it supernaturall; and then what can it be, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that either God, or the Divell is in him? And hence it came to passe,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: when our Saviour (Mark 3.21.) was compassed about with the multitude,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: those of the house doubted he was mad, and went out to hold him: but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Scribes said he had Belzebub, and that was it, by which he cast out

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: divels; as if the greater mad-man had awed the lesser. And that (John

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 10. 20.) some said, "He hath a Divell, and is mad;" whereas others

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: holding him for a Prophet, sayd, "These are not the words of one that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hath a Divell." So in the old Testament he that came to anoynt Jehu, (2

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kings 9.11.) was a Prophet; but some of the company asked Jehu, "What

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: came that mad-man for?" So that in summe, it is manifest, that whosoever

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: behaved himselfe in extraordinary manner, was thought by the Jewes to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: possessed either with a good, or evill spirit; except by the Sadduces,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: who erred so farre on the other hand, as not to believe there were at

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all any spirits, (which is very neere to direct Atheisme;) and thereby

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: perhaps the more provoked others, to terme such men Daemoniacks, rather

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: than mad-men.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But why then does our Saviour proceed in the curing of them, as if they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: were possest; and not as if they were mad. To which I can give no other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: kind of answer, but that which is given to those that urge the Scripture

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in like manner against the opinion of the motion of the Earth. The

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Scripture was written to shew unto men the kingdome of God; and to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: prepare their mindes to become his obedient subjects; leaving the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: world, and the Philosophy thereof, to the disputation of men, for the

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: make the day, and night; or whether the Exorbitant actions of men,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: proceed from Passion, or from the Divell, (so we worship him not) it is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all one, as to our obedience, and subjection to God Almighty; which is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the thing for which the Scripture was written. As for that our Saviour

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: speaketh to the disease, as to a person; it is the usuall phrase of all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that cure by words onely, as Christ did, (and Inchanters pretend to

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (Math. 8.26.) to have rebuked the winds? Is not he said also (Luk. 4.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 39.) to rebuke a Fever? Yet this does not argue that a Fever is a Divel.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And whereas many of these Divels are said to confesse Christ; it is not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: necessary to interpret those places otherwise, than that those mad-men

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: confessed him. And whereas our Saviour (Math. 12. 43.) speaketh of an

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: unclean Spirit, that having gone out of a man, wandreth through dry

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: places, seeking rest, and finding none; and returning into the same

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man, with seven other spirits worse than himselfe; It is manifestly a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Parable, alluding to a man, that after a little endeavour to quit his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: lusts, is vanquished by the strength of them; and becomes seven times

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: worse than he was. So that I see nothing at all in the Scripture, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: requireth a beliefe, that Daemoniacks were any other thing but Mad-men.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CHAPTER IX. OF THE SEVERALL SUBJECTS OF KNOWLEDGE

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: There are of KNOWLEDGE two kinds; whereof one is Knowledge Of Fact: the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other Knowledge Of The Consequence Of One Affirmation To Another. The

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: former is nothing else, but Sense and Memory, and is Absolute Knowledge;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as when we see a Fact doing, or remember it done: And this is the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Knowledge required in a Witnesse. The later is called Science; and is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Conditionall; as when we know, that, If The Figure Showne Be A Circle,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Then Any Straight Line Through The Centre Shall Divide It Into Two

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Equall Parts. And this is the Knowledge required in a Philosopher; that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is to say, of him that pretends to Reasoning.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Register of Knowledge Of Fact is called History. Whereof there be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: two sorts: one called Naturall History; which is the History of such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Facts, or Effects of Nature, as have no Dependance on Mans Will; Such as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are the Histories of Metals, Plants, Animals, Regions, and the like. The

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other, is Civill History; which is the History of the Voluntary Actions

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of men in Common-wealths.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Registers of Science, are such Books as contain the Demonstrations

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Consequences of one Affirmation, to another; and are commonly called

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Books of Philosophy; whereof the sorts are many, according to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: diversity of the Matter; And may be divided in such manner as I have

author: Thomas Hobbes
