author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CHAPTER X. OF POWER, WORTH, DIGNITY, HONOUR AND WORTHINESS

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Power

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The POWER of a Man, (to take it Universally,) is his present means,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to obtain some future apparent Good. And is either Originall, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Instrumentall.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Naturall Power, is the eminence of the Faculties of Body, or Mind: as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: extraordinary Strength, Forme, Prudence, Arts, Eloquence, Liberality,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nobility. Instrumentall are those Powers, which acquired by these, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by fortune, are means and Instruments to acquire more: as Riches,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Reputation, Friends, and the Secret working of God, which men call

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Good Luck. For the nature of Power, is in this point, like to Fame,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: increasing as it proceeds; or like the motion of heavy bodies, which the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: further they go, make still the more hast.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Greatest of humane Powers, is that which is compounded of the Powers

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of most men, united by consent, in one person, Naturall, or civill, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: has the use of all their Powers depending on his will; such as is the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Power of a Common-wealth: or depending on the wills of each particular;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such as is the Power of a Faction, or of divers factions leagued.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Therefore to have servants, is Power; To have Friends, is Power: for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they are strengths united.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Also Riches joyned with liberality, is Power; because it procureth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: friends, and servants: Without liberality, not so; because in this case

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they defend not; but expose men to Envy, as a Prey.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Reputation of power, is Power; because it draweth with it the adhaerance

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of those that need protection.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: So is Reputation of love of a mans Country, (called Popularity,) for the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: same Reason.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Also, what quality soever maketh a man beloved, or feared of many; or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the reputation of such quality, is Power; because it is a means to have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the assistance, and service of many.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Good successe is Power; because it maketh reputation of Wisdome, or good

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: fortune; which makes men either feare him, or rely on him.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Affability of men already in power, is encrease of Power; because it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: gaineth love.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Reputation of Prudence in the conduct of Peace or War, is Power; because

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to prudent men, we commit the government of our selves, more willingly

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: than to others.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nobility is Power, not in all places, but onely in those Common-wealths,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: where it has Priviledges: for in such priviledges consisteth their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Power.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Eloquence is Power; because it is seeming Prudence.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Forme is Power; because being a promise of Good, it recommendeth men to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the favour of women and strangers.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Sciences, are small Power; because not eminent; and therefore, not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: acknowledged in any man; nor are at all, but in a few; and in them, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of a few things. For Science is of that nature, as none can understand

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it to be, but such as in a good measure have attayned it.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Arts of publique use, as Fortification, making of Engines, and other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Instruments of War; because they conferre to Defence, and Victory,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are Power; And though the true Mother of them, be Science, namely the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Mathematiques; yet, because they are brought into the Light, by the hand

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Artificer, they be esteemed (the Midwife passing with the vulgar

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for the Mother,) as his issue.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Worth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Value, or WORTH of a man, is as of all other things, his Price;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that is to say, so much as would be given for the use of his Power:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and therefore is not absolute; but a thing dependant on the need and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: judgement of another. An able conductor of Souldiers, is of great Price

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in time of War present, or imminent; but in Peace not so. A learned and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: uncorrupt Judge, is much Worth in time of Peace; but not so much in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: War. And as in other things, so in men, not the seller, but the buyer

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: determines the Price. For let a man (as most men do,) rate themselves as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the highest Value they can; yet their true Value is no more than it is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: esteemed by others.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The manifestation of the Value we set on one another, is that which is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: commonly called Honouring, and Dishonouring. To Value a man at a high

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: rate, is to Honour him; at a low rate, is to Dishonour him. But high,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and low, in this case, is to be understood by comparison to the rate

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that each man setteth on himselfe.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Dignity

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The publique worth of a man, which is the Value set on him by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth, is that which men commonly call DIGNITY. And this Value

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of him by the Common-wealth, is understood, by offices of Command,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Judicature, publike Employment; or by Names and Titles, introduced for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: distinction of such Value.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To Honour and Dishonour

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To pray to another, for ayde of any kind, is to HONOUR; because a signe

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: we have an opinion he has power to help; and the more difficult the ayde

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is, the more is the Honour.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To obey, is to Honour; because no man obeyes them, whom they think

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have no power to help, or hurt them. And consequently to disobey, is to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Dishonour.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To give great gifts to a man, is to Honour him; because 'tis buying

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Protection, and acknowledging of Power. To give little gifts, is to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Dishonour; because it is but Almes, and signifies an opinion of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: need of small helps. To be sedulous in promoting anothers good; also

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to flatter, is to Honour; as a signe we seek his protection or ayde. To

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: neglect, is to Dishonour.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To give way, or place to another, in any Commodity, is to Honour; being

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a confession of greater power. To arrogate, is to Dishonour.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To shew any signe of love, or feare of another, is to Honour; for both

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to love, and to feare, is to value. To contemne, or lesse to love or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: feare then he expects, is to Dishonour; for 'tis undervaluing.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To praise, magnifie, or call happy, is to Honour; because nothing but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: goodnesse, power, and felicity is valued. To revile, mock, or pitty, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to Dishonour.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To speak to another with consideration, to appear before him with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: decency, and humility, is to Honour him; as signes of fear to offend.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To speak to him rashly, to do anything before him obscenely, slovenly,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: impudently, is to Dishonour.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To believe, to trust, to rely on another, is to Honour him; signe of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: opinion of his vertue and power. To distrust, or not believe, is to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Dishonour.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To hearken to a mans counsell, or discourse of what kind soever, is to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Honour; as a signe we think him wise, or eloquent, or witty. To sleep,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or go forth, or talk the while, is to Dishonour.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To do those things to another, which he takes for signes of Honour, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which the Law or Custome makes so, is to Honour; because in approving

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Honour done by others, he acknowledgeth the power which others

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: acknowledge. To refuse to do them, is to Dishonour.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To agree with in opinion, is to Honour; as being a signe of approving

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his judgement, and wisdome. To dissent, is Dishonour; and an upbraiding

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of errour; and (if the dissent be in many things) of folly.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To imitate, is to Honour; for it is vehemently to approve. To imitate

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ones Enemy, is to Dishonour.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To honour those another honours, is to Honour him; as a signe of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: approbation of his judgement. To honour his Enemies, is to Dishonour

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To employ in counsell, or in actions of difficulty, is to Honour; as a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: signe of opinion of his wisdome, or other power. To deny employment in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the same cases, to those that seek it, is to Dishonour.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: All these wayes of Honouring, are naturall; and as well within, as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: without Common-wealths. But in Common-wealths, where he, or they that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have the supreme Authority, can make whatsoever they please, to stand

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for signes of Honour, there be other Honours.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: A Soveraigne doth Honour a Subject, with whatsoever Title, or Office, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Employment, or Action, that he himselfe will have taken for a signe of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his will to Honour him.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The King of Persia, Honoured Mordecay, when he appointed he should be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: conducted through the streets in the Kings Garment, upon one of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kings Horses, with a Crown on his head, and a Prince before him,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: proclayming, "Thus shall it be done to him that the King will honour."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And yet another King of Persia, or the same another time, to one that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: demanded for some great service, to weare one of the Kings robes, gave

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him leave so to do; but with his addition, that he should weare it as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Kings foole; and then it was Dishonour. So that of Civill Honour;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such as are Magistracy, Offices, Titles; and in some places Coats, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Scutchions painted: and men Honour such as have them, as having so many

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: signes of favour in the Common-wealth; which favour is Power.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Honourable is whatsoever possession, action, or quality, is an argument

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and signe of Power.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And therefore To be Honoured, loved, or feared of many, is Honourable;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as arguments of Power. To be Honoured of few or none, Dishonourable.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Good fortune (if lasting,) Honourable; as a signe of the favour of God.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ill fortune, and losses, Dishonourable. Riches, are Honourable; for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they are Power. Poverty, Dishonourable. Magnanimity, Liberality,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Hope, Courage, Confidence, are Honourable; for they proceed from the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: conscience of Power. Pusillanimity, Parsimony, Fear, Diffidence, are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Dishonourable.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Timely Resolution, or determination of what a man is to do, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Honourable; as being the contempt of small difficulties, and dangers.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And Irresolution, Dishonourable; as a signe of too much valuing of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: little impediments, and little advantages: For when a man has weighed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: things as long as the time permits, and resolves not, the difference

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of weight is but little; and therefore if he resolve not, he overvalues

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: little things, which is Pusillanimity.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: All Actions, and Speeches, that proceed, or seem to proceed from much

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Experience, Science, Discretion, or Wit, are Honourable; For all these

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are Powers. Actions, or Words that proceed from Errour, Ignorance, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Folly, Dishonourable.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Gravity, as farre forth as it seems to proceed from a mind employed on

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: some thing else, is Honourable; because employment is a signe of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Power. But if it seem to proceed from a purpose to appear grave, it is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Dishonourable. For the gravity of the Former, is like the steddinesse of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Ship laden with Merchandise; but of the later, like the steddinesse of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Ship ballasted with Sand, and other trash.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To be Conspicuous, that is to say, to be known, for Wealth, Office,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: great Actions, or any eminent Good, is Honourable; as a signe of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: power for which he is conspicuous. On the contrary, Obscurity, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Dishonourable.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To be descended from conspicuous Parents, is Honourable; because they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the more easily attain the aydes, and friends of their Ancestors. On the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: contrary, to be descended from obscure Parentage, is Dishonourable.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Actions proceeding from Equity, joyned with losse, are Honourable;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as signes of Magnanimity: for Magnanimity is a signe of Power. On the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: contrary, Craft, Shifting, neglect of Equity, is Dishonourable.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nor does it alter the case of Honour, whether an action (so it be great

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and difficult, and consequently a signe of much power,) be just or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: unjust: for Honour consisteth onely in the opinion of Power. Therefore

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the ancient Heathen did not thinke they Dishonoured, but greatly

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Honoured the Gods, when they introduced them in their Poems, committing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Rapes, Thefts, and other great, but unjust, or unclean acts: In so much

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as nothing is so much celebrated in Jupiter, as his Adulteries; nor

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in Mercury, as his Frauds, and Thefts: of whose praises, in a hymne

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Homer, the greatest is this, that being born in the morning, he had

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: invented Musique at noon, and before night, stolen away the Cattell of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Appollo, from his Herdsmen.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Also amongst men, till there were constituted great Common-wealths,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it was thought no dishonour to be a Pyrate, or a High-way Theefe; but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: rather a lawfull Trade, not onely amongst the Greeks, but also amongst

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all other Nations; as is manifest by the Histories of antient time. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: at this day, in this part of the world, private Duels are, and alwayes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: will be Honourable, though unlawfull, till such time as there shall be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Honour ordained for them that refuse, and Ignominy for them that make

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Challenge. For Duels also are many times effects of Courage; and the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ground of Courage is alwayes Strength or Skill, which are Power; though

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for the most part they be effects of rash speaking, and of the fear of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Dishonour, in one, or both the Combatants; who engaged by rashnesse, are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: driven into the Lists to avoyd disgrace.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Scutchions, and coats of Armes haereditary, where they have any eminent

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Priviledges, are Honourable; otherwise not: for their Power consisteth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: either in such Priviledges, or in Riches, or some such thing as is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: equally honoured in other men. This kind of Honour, commonly called

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Gentry, has been derived from the Antient Germans. For there never was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: any such thing known, where the German Customes were unknown. Nor is it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: now any where in use, where the Germans have not inhabited. The antient

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Greek Commanders, when they went to war, had their Shields painted with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such Devises as they pleased; insomuch as an unpainted Buckler was a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: signe of Poverty, and of a common Souldier: but they transmitted not the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Inheritance of them. The Romans transmitted the Marks of their Families:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but they were the Images, not the Devises of their Ancestors. Amongst

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the people of Asia, Afrique, and America, there is not, nor was ever,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: any such thing. The Germans onely had that custome; from whom it has

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: been derived into England, France, Spain, and Italy, when in great

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: numbers they either ayded the Romans, or made their own Conquests in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: these Westerne parts of the world.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For Germany, being antiently, as all other Countries, in their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: beginnings, divided amongst an infinite number of little Lords, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Masters of Families, that continually had wars one with another; those

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Masters, or Lords, principally to the end they might, when they were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Covered with Arms, be known by their followers; and partly for ornament,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: both painted their Armor, or their Scutchion, or Coat, with the picture

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of some Beast, or other thing; and also put some eminent and visible

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: mark upon the Crest of their Helmets. And his ornament both of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Armes, and Crest, descended by inheritance to their Children; to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: eldest pure, and to the rest with some note of diversity, such as the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Old master, that is to say in Dutch, the Here-alt thought fit. But when

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: many such Families, joyned together, made a greater Monarchy, this duty

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Herealt, to distinguish Scutchions, was made a private Office

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a part. And the issue of these Lords, is the great and antient Gentry;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which for the most part bear living creatures, noted for courage, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: rapine; or Castles, Battlements, Belts, Weapons, Bars, Palisadoes, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other notes of War; nothing being then in honour, but vertue military.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Afterwards, not onely Kings, but popular Common-wealths, gave divers

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: manners of Scutchions, to such as went forth to the War, or returned

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from it, for encouragement, or recompence to their service. All which,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by an observing Reader, may be found in such ancient Histories, Greek

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Latine, as make mention of the German Nation, and Manners, in their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: times.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Titles of Honour

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Titles of Honour, such as are Duke, Count, Marquis, and Baron, are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Honourable; as signifying the value set upon them by the Soveraigne

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Power of the Common-wealth: Which Titles, were in old time titles

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Office, and Command, derived some from the Romans, some from the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Germans, and French. Dukes, in Latine Duces, being Generalls in War:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Counts, Comites, such as bare the Generall company out of friendship;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and were left to govern and defend places conquered, and pacified:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Marquises, Marchiones, were Counts that governed the Marches, or bounds

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Empire. Which titles of Duke, Count, and Marquis, came into the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Empire, about the time of Constantine the Great, from the customes of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the German Militia. But Baron, seems to have been a Title of the Gaules,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and signifies a Great man; such as were the Kings, or Princes men, whom

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they employed in war about their persons; and seems to be derived from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Vir, to Ber, and Bar, that signified the same in the Language of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Gaules, that Vir in Latine; and thence to Bero, and Baro: so that such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: men were called Berones, and after Barones; and (in Spanish) Varones.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But he that would know more particularly the originall of Titles of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Honour, may find it, as I have done this, in Mr. Seldens most excellent

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Treatise of that subject. In processe of time these offices of Honour,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by occasion of trouble, and for reasons of good and peacable government,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: were turned into meer Titles; serving for the most part, to distinguish

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the precedence, place, and order of subjects in the Common-wealth: and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: men were made Dukes, Counts, Marquises, and Barons of Places, wherein

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they had neither possession, nor command: and other Titles also, were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: devised to the same end.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Worthinesse Fitnesse

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: WORTHINESSE, is a thing different from the worth, or value of a man; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: also from his merit, or desert; and consisteth in a particular power,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or ability for that, whereof he is said to be worthy: which particular

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ability, is usually named FITNESSE, or Aptitude.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For he is Worthiest to be a Commander, to be a Judge, or to have any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other charge, that is best fitted, with the qualities required to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: well discharging of it; and Worthiest of Riches, that has the qualities

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: most requisite for the well using of them: any of which qualities being

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: absent, one may neverthelesse be a Worthy man, and valuable for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: some thing else. Again, a man may be Worthy of Riches, Office, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Employment, that neverthelesse, can plead no right to have it before

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: another; and therefore cannot be said to merit or deserve it. For Merit,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: praesupposeth a right, and that the thing deserved is due by promise: Of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which I shall say more hereafter, when I shall speak of Contracts.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CHAPTER XI. OF THE DIFFERENCE OF MANNERS

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: What Is Here Meant By Manners

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: By MANNERS, I mean not here, Decency of behaviour; as how one man should

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: salute another, or how a man should wash his mouth, or pick his teeth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: before company, and such other points of the Small Morals; But those

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: qualities of man-kind, that concern their living together in Peace, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Unity. To which end we are to consider, that the Felicity of this life,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consisteth not in the repose of a mind satisfied. For there is no such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Finis Ultimus, (utmost ayme,) nor Summum Bonum, (greatest good,) as is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: spoken of in the Books of the old Morall Philosophers. Nor can a man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: any more live, whose Desires are at an end, than he, whose Senses and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Imaginations are at a stand. Felicity is a continuall progresse of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: desire, from one object to another; the attaining of the former, being

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: still but the way to the later. The cause whereof is, That the object

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of mans desire, is not to enjoy once onely, and for one instant of time;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but to assure for ever, the way of his future desire. And therefore the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: voluntary actions, and inclinations of all men, tend, not only to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: procuring, but also to the assuring of a contented life; and differ

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: onely in the way: which ariseth partly from the diversity of passions,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in divers men; and partly from the difference of the knowledge, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: opinion each one has of the causes, which produce the effect desired.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: A Restlesse Desire Of Power, In All Men

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: So that in the first place, I put for a generall inclination of all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: mankind, a perpetuall and restlesse desire of Power after power, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ceaseth onely in Death. And the cause of this, is not alwayes that a man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hopes for a more intensive delight, than he has already attained to; or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that he cannot be content with a moderate power: but because he cannot

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: assure the power and means to live well, which he hath present, without

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the acquisition of more. And from hence it is, that Kings, whose power

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is greatest, turn their endeavours to the assuring it a home by Lawes,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or abroad by Wars: and when that is done, there succeedeth a new desire;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in some, of Fame from new Conquest; in others, of ease and sensuall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: pleasure; in others, of admiration, or being flattered for excellence in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: some art, or other ability of the mind.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Love Of Contention From Competition

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Competition of Riches, Honour, command, or other power, enclineth to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Contention, Enmity, and War: because the way of one Competitor, to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: attaining of his desire, is to kill, subdue, supplant, or repell the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other. Particularly, competition of praise, enclineth to a reverence of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Antiquity. For men contend with the living, not with the dead; to these

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ascribing more than due, that they may obscure the glory of the other.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Civil Obedience From Love Of Ease

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Desire of Ease, and sensuall Delight, disposeth men to obey a common

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Power: because by such Desires, a man doth abandon the protection might

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be hoped for from his own Industry, and labour.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: From Feare Of Death Or Wounds

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Fear of Death, and Wounds, disposeth to the same; and for the same

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: reason. On the contrary, needy men, and hardy, not contented with their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: present condition; as also, all men that are ambitious of Military

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: command, are enclined to continue the causes of warre; and to stirre up

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: trouble and sedition: for there is no honour Military but by warre; nor

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: any such hope to mend an ill game, as by causing a new shuffle.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And From Love Of Arts

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Desire of Knowledge, and Arts of Peace, enclineth men to obey a common

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Power: For such Desire, containeth a desire of leasure; and consequently

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: protection from some other Power than their own.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Love Of Vertue, From Love Of Praise

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Desire of Praise, disposeth to laudable actions, such as please them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whose judgement they value; for of these men whom we contemn, we contemn

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: also the Praises. Desire of Fame after death does the same. And though

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: after death, there be no sense of the praise given us on Earth, as being

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: joyes, that are either swallowed up in the unspeakable joyes of Heaven,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or extinguished in the extreme torments of Hell: yet is not such Fame

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: vain; because men have a present delight therein, from the foresight

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of it, and of the benefit that may rebound thereby to their posterity:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which though they now see not, yet they imagine; and any thing that is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: pleasure in the sense, the same also is pleasure in the imagination.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Hate, From Difficulty Of Requiting Great Benefits

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To have received from one, to whom we think our selves equall, greater

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: benefits than there is hope to Requite, disposeth to counterfiet love;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but really secret hatred; and puts a man into the estate of a desperate

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: debtor, that in declining the sight of his creditor, tacitely wishes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him there, where he might never see him more. For benefits oblige; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: obligation is thraldome; which is to ones equall, hateful. But to have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: received benefits from one, whom we acknowledge our superiour, enclines

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to love; because the obligation is no new depession: and cheerfull

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: acceptation, (which men call Gratitude,) is such an honour done to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the obliger, as is taken generally for retribution. Also to receive

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: benefits, though from an equall, or inferiour, as long as there is hope

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of requitall, disposeth to love: for in the intention of the receiver,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the obligation is of ayd, and service mutuall; from whence proceedeth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: an Emulation of who shall exceed in benefiting; the most noble and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: profitable contention possible; wherein the victor is pleased with his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: victory, and the other revenged by confessing it.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And From Conscience Of Deserving To Be Hated

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To have done more hurt to a man, than he can, or is willing to expiate,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: enclineth the doer to hate the sufferer. For he must expect revenge, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: forgivenesse; both which are hatefull.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Promptnesse To Hurt, From Fear

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Feare of oppression, disposeth a man to anticipate, or to seek ayd by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: society: for there is no other way by which a man can secure his life

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and liberty.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And From Distrust Of Their Own Wit

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Men that distrust their own subtilty, are in tumult, and sedition,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: better disposed for victory, than they that suppose themselves wise,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or crafty. For these love to consult, the other (fearing to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: circumvented,) to strike first. And in sedition, men being alwayes in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the procincts of Battell, to hold together, and use all advantages of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: force, is a better stratagem, than any that can proceed from subtilty of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Wit.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Vain Undertaking From Vain-glory

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Vain-glorious men, such as without being conscious to themselves of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: great sufficiency, delight in supposing themselves gallant men, are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: enclined onely to ostentation; but not to attempt: Because when

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: danger or difficulty appears, they look for nothing but to have their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: insufficiency discovered.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Vain-glorious men, such as estimate their sufficiency by the flattery

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of other men, or the fortune of some precedent action, without assured

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ground of hope from the true knowledge of themselves, are enclined to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: rash engaging; and in the approach of danger, or difficulty, to retire

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: if they can: because not seeing the way of safety, they will rather

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hazard their honour, which may be salved with an excuse; than their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: lives, for which no salve is sufficient.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ambition, From Opinion Of Sufficiency

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Men that have a strong opinion of their own wisdome in matter of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: government, are disposed to Ambition. Because without publique

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Employment in counsell or magistracy, the honour of their wisdome is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: lost. And therefore Eloquent speakers are enclined to Ambition; for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Eloquence seemeth wisdome, both to themselves and others

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Irresolution, From Too Great Valuing Of Small Matters

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Pusillanimity disposeth men to Irresolution, and consequently to lose

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the occasions, and fittest opportunities of action. For after men have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: been in deliberation till the time of action approach, if it be not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: then manifest what is best to be done, tis a signe, the difference of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Motives, the one way and the other, are not great: Therefore not to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: resolve then, is to lose the occasion by weighing of trifles; which is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: pusillanimity.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Frugality,(though in poor men a Vertue,) maketh a man unapt to atchieve

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such actions, as require the strength of many men at once: For it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: weakeneth their Endeavour, which is to be nourished and kept in vigor by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Reward.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Confidence In Others From Ignorance Of The Marks Of Wisdome and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kindnesse Eloquence, with flattery, disposeth men to confide in them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that have it; because the former is seeming Wisdome, the later seeming

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kindnesse. Adde to them Military reputation, and it disposeth men to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: adhaere, and subject themselves to those men that have them. The two

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: former, having given them caution against danger from him; the later

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: gives them caution against danger from others.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And From The Ignorance Of Naturall Causes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Want of Science, that is, Ignorance of causes, disposeth, or rather

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: constraineth a man to rely on the advise, and authority of others. For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all men whom the truth concernes, if they rely not on their own,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: must rely on the opinion of some other, whom they think wiser than

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: themselves, and see not why he should deceive them.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And From Want Of Understanding

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ignorance of the signification of words; which is, want of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: understanding, disposeth men to take on trust, not onely the truth they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: know not; but also the errors; and which is more, the non-sense of them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they trust: For neither Error, nor non-sense, can without a perfect

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: understanding of words, be detected.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: From the same it proceedeth, that men give different names, to one and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the same thing, from the difference of their own passions: As they that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: approve a private opinion, call it Opinion; but they that mislike it,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Haeresie: and yet haeresie signifies no more than private opinion; but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: has onely a greater tincture of choler.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: From the same also it proceedeth, that men cannot distinguish, without

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: study and great understanding, between one action of many men, and many

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: actions of one multitude; as for example, between the one action of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all the Senators of Rome in killing Catiline, and the many actions of a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: number of Senators in killing Caesar; and therefore are disposed to take

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for the action of the people, that which is a multitude of actions done

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by a multitude of men, led perhaps by the perswasion of one.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Adhaerence To Custome, From Ignorance Of The Nature Of Right And Wrong

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ignorance of the causes, and originall constitution of Right, Equity,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Law, and Justice, disposeth a man to make Custome and Example the rule

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of his actions; in such manner, as to think that Unjust which it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hath been the custome to punish; and that Just, of the impunity and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: approbation whereof they can produce an Example, or (as the Lawyers

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which onely use the false measure of Justice barbarously call it) a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Precedent; like little children, that have no other rule of good and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: evill manners, but the correction they receive from their Parents, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Masters; save that children are constant to their rule, whereas men are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not so; because grown strong, and stubborn, they appeale from custome

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to reason, and from reason to custome, as it serves their turn; receding

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from custome when their interest requires it, and setting themselves

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: against reason, as oft as reason is against them: Which is the cause,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that the doctrine of Right and Wrong, is perpetually disputed, both by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Pen and the Sword: whereas the doctrine of Lines, and Figures, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not so; because men care not, in that subject what be truth, as a thing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that crosses no mans ambition, profit, or lust. For I doubt not, but if

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it had been a thing contrary to any mans right of dominion, or to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: interest of men that have dominion, That The Three Angles Of A Triangle

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Should Be Equall To Two Angles Of A Square; that doctrine should have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: been, if not disputed, yet by the burning of all books of Geometry,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: suppressed, as farre as he whom it concerned was able.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Adhaerence To Private Men, From Ignorance Of The Causes Of Peace

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ignorance of remote causes, disposeth men to attribute all events, to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the causes immediate, and Instrumentall: For these are all the causes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they perceive. And hence it comes to passe, that in all places, men that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are grieved with payments to the Publique, discharge their anger upon

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Publicans, that is to say, Farmers, Collectors, and other Officers

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the publique Revenue; and adhaere to such as find fault with the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: publike Government; and thereby, when they have engaged themselves

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: beyond hope of justification, fall also upon the Supreme Authority, for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: feare of punishment, or shame of receiving pardon.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Credulity From Ignorance Of Nature

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ignorance of naturall causes disposeth a man to Credulity, so as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to believe many times impossibilities: for such know nothing to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the contrary, but that they may be true; being unable to detect the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Impossibility. And Credulity, because men love to be hearkened unto in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: company, disposeth them to lying: so that Ignorance it selfe without

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Malice, is able to make a man bothe to believe lyes, and tell them; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sometimes also to invent them.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Curiosity To Know, From Care Of Future Time

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Anxiety for the future time, disposeth men to enquire into the causes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of things: because the knowledge of them, maketh men the better able to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: order the present to their best advantage.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Naturall Religion, From The Same

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Curiosity, or love of the knowledge of causes, draws a man from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consideration of the effect, to seek the cause; and again, the cause of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that cause; till of necessity he must come to this thought at last, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there is some cause, whereof there is no former cause, but is eternall;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which is it men call God. So that it is impossible to make any profound

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: enquiry into naturall causes, without being enclined thereby to believe

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there is one God Eternall; though they cannot have any Idea of him in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their mind, answerable to his nature. For as a man that is born blind,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hearing men talk of warming themselves by the fire, and being brought

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to warm himself by the same, may easily conceive, and assure himselfe,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there is somewhat there, which men call Fire, and is the cause of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: heat he feeles; but cannot imagine what it is like; nor have an Idea of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it in his mind, such as they have that see it: so also, by the visible

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: things of this world, and their admirable order, a man may conceive

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there is a cause of them, which men call God; and yet not have an Idea,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or Image of him in his mind.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And they that make little, or no enquiry into the naturall causes of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: things, yet from the feare that proceeds from the ignorance it selfe,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of what it is that hath the power to do them much good or harm, are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: enclined to suppose, and feign unto themselves, severall kinds of Powers

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Invisible; and to stand in awe of their own imaginations; and in time

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of distresse to invoke them; as also in the time of an expected good

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: successe, to give them thanks; making the creatures of their own

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: fancy, their Gods. By which means it hath come to passe, that from the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: innumerable variety of Fancy, men have created in the world innumerable

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sorts of Gods. And this Feare of things invisible, is the naturall Seed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of that, which every one in himself calleth Religion; and in them that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: worship, or feare that Power otherwise than they do, Superstition.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And this seed of Religion, having been observed by many; some of those

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that have observed it, have been enclined thereby to nourish, dresse,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and forme it into Lawes; and to adde to it of their own invention,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: any opinion of the causes of future events, by which they thought they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: should best be able to govern others, and make unto themselves the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: greatest use of their Powers.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CHAPTER XII. OF RELIGION

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Religion, In Man Onely

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Seeing there are no signes, nor fruit of Religion, but in Man onely;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there is no cause to doubt, but that the seed of Religion, is also onely

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in Man; and consisteth in some peculiar quality, or at least in some

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: eminent degree thereof, not to be found in other Living creatures.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: First, From His Desire Of Knowing Causes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And first, it is peculiar to the nature of Man, to be inquisitive into

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Causes of the Events they see, some more, some lesse; but all men so

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: much, as to be curious in the search of the causes of their own good and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: evill fortune.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: From The Consideration Of The Beginning Of Things

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Secondly, upon the sight of any thing that hath a Beginning, to think

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: also it had a cause, which determined the same to begin, then when it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: did, rather than sooner or later.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: From His Observation Of The Sequell Of Things

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Thirdly, whereas there is no other Felicity of Beasts, but the enjoying

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of their quotidian Food, Ease, and Lusts; as having little, or no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: foresight of the time to come, for want of observation, and memory

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the order, consequence, and dependance of the things they see; Man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: observeth how one Event hath been produced by another; and remembreth in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them Antecedence and Consequence; And when he cannot assure himselfe of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the true causes of things, (for the causes of good and evill fortune for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the most part are invisible,) he supposes causes of them, either such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as his own fancy suggesteth; or trusteth to the Authority of other men,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such as he thinks to be his friends, and wiser than himselfe.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Naturall Cause Of Religion, The Anxiety Of The Time To Come The

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: two first, make Anxiety. For being assured that there be causes of all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: things that have arrived hitherto, or shall arrive hereafter; it is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: impossible for a man, who continually endeavoureth to secure himselfe

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: against the evill he feares, and procure the good he desireth, not to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be in a perpetuall solicitude of the time to come; So that every man,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: especially those that are over provident, are in an estate like to that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Prometheus. For as Prometheus, (which interpreted, is, The Prudent

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Man,) was bound to the hill Caucasus, a place of large prospect, where,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: an Eagle feeding on his liver, devoured in the day, as much as was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: repayred in the night: So that man, which looks too far before him, in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the care of future time, hath his heart all the day long, gnawed on by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: feare of death, poverty, or other calamity; and has no repose, nor pause

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of his anxiety, but in sleep.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Which Makes Them Fear The Power Of Invisible Things

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: This perpetuall feare, alwayes accompanying mankind in the ignorance of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: causes, as it were in the Dark, must needs have for object something.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And therefore when there is nothing to be seen, there is nothing to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: accuse, either of their good, or evill fortune, but some Power, or Agent

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Invisible: In which sense perhaps it was, that some of the old Poets

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: said, that the Gods were at first created by humane Feare: which spoken

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Gods, (that is to say, of the many Gods of the Gentiles) is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: very true. But the acknowledging of one God Eternall, Infinite, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Omnipotent, may more easily be derived, from the desire men have to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: know the causes of naturall bodies, and their severall vertues, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: operations; than from the feare of what was to befall them in time to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: come. For he that from any effect hee seeth come to passe, should reason

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to the next and immediate cause thereof, and from thence to the cause

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of that cause, and plonge himselfe profoundly in the pursuit of causes;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shall at last come to this, that there must be (as even the Heathen

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Philosophers confessed) one First Mover; that is, a First, and an

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Eternall cause of all things; which is that which men mean by the name

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of God: And all this without thought of their fortune; the solicitude

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whereof, both enclines to fear, and hinders them from the search of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: causes of other things; and thereby gives occasion of feigning of as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: many Gods, as there be men that feigne them.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And Suppose Them Incorporeall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And for the matter, or substance of the Invisible Agents, so fancyed;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they could not by naturall cogitation, fall upon any other conceipt, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that it was the same with that of the Soule of man; and that the Soule

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of man, was of the same substance, with that which appeareth in a Dream,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to one that sleepeth; or in a Looking-glasse, to one that is awake;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which, men not knowing that such apparitions are nothing else but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: creatures of the Fancy, think to be reall, and externall Substances;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and therefore call them Ghosts; as the Latines called them Imagines,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Umbrae; and thought them Spirits, that is, thin aereall bodies; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: those Invisible Agents, which they feared, to bee like them; save that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they appear, and vanish when they please. But the opinion that such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Spirits were Incorporeall, or Immateriall, could never enter into the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: mind of any man by nature; because, though men may put together words of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: contradictory signification, as Spirit, and Incorporeall; yet they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: can never have the imagination of any thing answering to them:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And therefore, men that by their own meditation, arrive to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: acknowledgement of one Infinite, Omnipotent, and Eternall God,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: choose rather to confesse he is Incomprehensible, and above their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: understanding; than to define his Nature By Spirit Incorporeall, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: then Confesse their definition to be unintelligible: or if they give him

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such a title, it is not Dogmatically, with intention to make the Divine

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nature understood; but Piously, to honour him with attributes, of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: significations, as remote as they can from the grossenesse of Bodies

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Visible.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But Know Not The Way How They Effect Anything

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Then, for the way by which they think these Invisible Agents wrought

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their effects; that is to say, what immediate causes they used, in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: bringing things to passe, men that know not what it is that we call

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Causing, (that is, almost all men) have no other rule to guesse by, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by observing, and remembring what they have seen to precede the like

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: effect at some other time, or times before, without seeing between the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: antecedent and subsequent Event, any dependance or connexion at all:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And therefore from the like things past, they expect the like things to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: come; and hope for good or evill luck, superstitiously, from things that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have no part at all in the causing of it: As the Athenians did for their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: war at Lepanto, demand another Phormio; the Pompeian faction for their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: warre in Afrique, another Scipio; and others have done in divers other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: occasions since. In like manner they attribute their fortune to a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: stander by, to a lucky or unlucky place, to words spoken, especially

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: if the name of God be amongst them; as Charming, and Conjuring (the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Leiturgy of Witches;) insomuch as to believe, they have power to turn a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: stone into bread, bread into a man, or any thing, into any thing.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But Honour Them As They Honour Men

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Thirdly, for the worship which naturally men exhibite to Powers

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: invisible, it can be no other, but such expressions of their reverence,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as they would use towards men; Gifts, Petitions, Thanks, Submission

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Body, Considerate Addresses, sober Behaviour, premeditated Words,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Swearing (that is, assuring one another of their promises,) by invoking

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them. Beyond that reason suggesteth nothing; but leaves them either to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: rest there; or for further ceremonies, to rely on those they believe to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be wiser than themselves.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And Attribute To Them All Extraordinary Events

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lastly, concerning how these Invisible Powers declare to men the things

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which shall hereafter come to passe, especially concerning their good

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or evill fortune in generall, or good or ill successe in any particular

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: undertaking, men are naturally at a stand; save that using to conjecture

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the time to come, by the time past, they are very apt, not onely to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: take casuall things, after one or two encounters, for Prognostiques

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the like encounter ever after, but also to believe the like

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Prognostiques from other men, of whom they have once conceived a good

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: opinion.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Foure Things, Naturall Seeds Of Religion

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And in these foure things, Opinion of Ghosts, Ignorance of second

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: causes, Devotion towards what men fear, and Taking of things Casuall for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Prognostiques, consisteth the Naturall seed of Religion; which by reason

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the different Fancies, Judgements, and Passions of severall men, hath

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: grown up into ceremonies so different, that those which are used by one

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man, are for the most part ridiculous to another.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Made Different By Culture

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For these seeds have received culture from two sorts of men. One sort

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have been they, that have nourished, and ordered them, according to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their own invention. The other, have done it, by Gods commandement, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: direction: but both sorts have done it, with a purpose to make those men

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that relyed on them, the more apt to Obedience, Lawes, Peace, Charity,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and civill Society. So that the Religion of the former sort, is a part

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of humane Politiques; and teacheth part of the duty which Earthly Kings

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: require of their Subjects. And the Religion of the later sort is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Divine Politiques; and containeth Precepts to those that have yeelded

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: themselves subjects in the Kingdome of God. Of the former sort, were all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Founders of Common-wealths, and the Law-givers of the Gentiles: Of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the later sort, were Abraham, Moses, and our Blessed Saviour; by whom

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have been derived unto us the Lawes of the Kingdome of God.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Absurd Opinion Of Gentilisme

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And for that part of Religion, which consisteth in opinions concerning

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the nature of Powers Invisible, there is almost nothing that has a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: name, that has not been esteemed amongst the Gentiles, in one place or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: another, a God, or Divell; or by their Poets feigned to be inanimated,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: inhabited, or possessed by some Spirit or other.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The unformed matter of the World, was a God, by the name of Chaos.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Heaven, the Ocean, the Planets, the Fire, the Earth, the Winds, were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: so many Gods.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Men, Women, a Bird, a Crocodile, a Calf, a Dogge, a Snake, an Onion,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Leeke, Deified. Besides, that they filled almost all places, with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: spirits called Daemons; the plains, with Pan, and Panises, or Satyres;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Woods, with Fawnes, and Nymphs; the Sea, with Tritons, and other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nymphs; every River, and Fountayn, with a Ghost of his name, and with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nymphs; every house, with it Lares, or Familiars; every man, with his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Genius; Hell, with Ghosts, and spirituall Officers, as Charon, Cerberus,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and the Furies; and in the night time, all places with Larvae, Lemures,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ghosts of men deceased, and a whole kingdome of Fayries, and Bugbears.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: They have also ascribed Divinity, and built Temples to meer Accidents,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Qualities; such as are Time, Night, Day, Peace, Concord, Love,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Contention, Vertue, Honour, Health, Rust, Fever, and the like; which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: when they prayed for, or against, they prayed to, as if there were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ghosts of those names hanging over their heads, and letting fall, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: withholding that Good, or Evill, for, or against which they prayed. They

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: invoked also their own Wit, by the name of Muses; their own Ignorance,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by the name of Fortune; their own Lust, by the name of Cupid; their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: own Rage, by the name Furies; their own privy members by the name of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Priapus; and attributed their pollutions, to Incubi, and Succubae:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: insomuch as there was nothing, which a Poet could introduce as a person

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in his Poem, which they did not make either a God, or a Divel.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The same authors of the Religion of the Gentiles, observing the second

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ground for Religion, which is mens Ignorance of causes; and thereby

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their aptnesse to attribute their fortune to causes, on which there

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was no dependence at all apparent, took occasion to obtrude on their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ignorance, in stead of second causes, a kind of second and ministeriall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Gods; ascribing the cause of Foecundity, to Venus; the cause of Arts, to

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Designes Of The Authors Of The Religion Of The Heathen And therefore

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the first Founders, and Legislators of Common-wealths amongst the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Gentiles, whose ends were only to keep the people in obedience, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: peace, have in all places taken care; First, to imprint in their minds a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: beliefe, that those precepts which they gave concerning Religion, might

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not be thought to proceed from their own device, but from the dictates

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of some God, or other Spirit; or else that they themselves were of a

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be received: So Numa Pompilius pretended to receive the Ceremonies he

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and founder of the Kingdome of Peru, pretended himselfe and his wife to

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be appeased; and that ill success in War, great contagions of Sicknesse,

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which in the Poets is written of the paines, and pleasures after this

text: cherished, than the contrary.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And by these, and such other Institutions, they obtayned in order to

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The True Religion, And The Lawes Of Gods Kingdome The Same But where God

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: himselfe, by supernaturall Revelation, planted Religion; there he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: also made to himselfe a peculiar Kingdome; and gave Lawes, not only of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: behaviour towards himselfe; but also towards one another; and thereby

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the Kingdome of God, the Policy, and lawes Civill, are a part of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Religion; and therefore the distinction of Temporall, and Spirituall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Domination, hath there no place. It is true, that God is King of all the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Earth: Yet may he be King of a peculiar, and chosen Nation. For there is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: no more incongruity therein, than that he that hath the generall command

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the whole Army, should have withall a peculiar Regiment, or Company

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of his own. God is King of all the Earth by his Power: but of his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: chosen people, he is King by Covenant. But to speake more largly of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kingdome of God, both by Nature, and Covenant, I have in the following

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: discourse assigned an other place.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Causes Of Change In Religion

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: From the propagation of Religion, it is not hard to understand

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the causes of the resolution of the same into its first seeds, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: principles; which are only an opinion of a Deity, and Powers invisible,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and supernaturall; that can never be so abolished out of humane nature,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but that new Religions may againe be made to spring out of them, by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: culture of such men, as for such purpose are in reputation.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For seeing all formed Religion, is founded at first, upon the faith

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which a multitude hath in some one person, whom they believe not only to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be a wise man, and to labour to procure their happiness, but also to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be a holy man, to whom God himselfe vouchsafeth to declare his will

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: supernaturally; It followeth necessarily, when they that have the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Goverment of Religion, shall come to have either the wisedome of those

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: men, their sincerity, or their love suspected; or that they shall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be unable to shew any probable token of divine Revelation; that the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Religion which they desire to uphold, must be suspected likewise; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (without the feare of the Civill Sword) contradicted and rejected.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Injoyning Beleefe Of Impossibilities

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: That which taketh away the reputation of Wisedome, in him that formeth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Religion, or addeth to it when it is allready formed, is the enjoyning

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of a beliefe of contradictories: For both parts of a contradiction

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: cannot possibly be true: and therefore to enjoyne the beliefe of them,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is an argument of ignorance; which detects the Author in that; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: discredits him in all things else he shall propound as from revelation

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: supernaturall: which revelation a man may indeed have of many things

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: above, but of nothing against naturall reason.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Doing Contrary To The Religion They Establish

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: That which taketh away the reputation of Sincerity, is the doing, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: saying of such things, as appeare to be signes, that what they require

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other men to believe, is not believed by themselves; all which doings,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or sayings are therefore called Scandalous, because they be stumbling

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: blocks, that make men to fall in the way of Religion: as Injustice,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Cruelty, Prophanesse, Avarice, and Luxury. For who can believe, that he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that doth ordinarily such actions, as proceed from any of these

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: rootes, believeth there is any such Invisible Power to be feared, as he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: affrighteth other men withall, for lesser faults?

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: That which taketh away the reputation of Love, is the being detected of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: private ends: as when the beliefe they require of others, conduceth or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: seemeth to conduce to the acquiring of Dominion, Riches, Dignity, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: secure Pleasure, to themselves onely, or specially. For that which men

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: reap benefit by to themselves, they are thought to do for their own

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sakes, and not for love of others

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Want Of The Testimony Of Miracles

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lastly, the testimony that men can render of divine Calling, can be no

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the places, in which they be educated, have wrought into them. For as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in naturall things, men of judgement require naturall signes,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and arguments; so in supernaturall things, they require signes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: supernaturall, (which are Miracles,) before they consent inwardly, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from their hearts.

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

text: Salvation, there be so many, manifestly to the advantage of the Pope,

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Authority, as easily as it has been excluded in England. For who is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there that does not see, to whose benefit it conduceth, to have it

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for no cause; and his Kingdome given to one of his Subjects? That the

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or Probity of their Teachers? So that I may attribute all the changes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Religion in the world, to one and the some cause; and that is,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: unpleasing Priests; and those not onely amongst Catholiques, but even in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that Church that hath presumed most of Reformation.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CHAPTER XIII. OF THE NATURALL CONDITION OF MANKIND,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: AS CONCERNING THEIR FELICITY, AND MISERY

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nature hath made men so equall, in the faculties of body, and mind; as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that though there bee found one man sometimes manifestly stronger

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in body, or of quicker mind then another; yet when all is reckoned

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: together, the difference between man, and man, is not so considerable,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as that one man can thereupon claim to himselfe any benefit, to which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: another may not pretend, as well as he. For as to the strength of body,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the weakest has strength enough to kill the strongest, either by secret

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: machination, or by confederacy with others, that are in the same danger

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with himselfe.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And as to the faculties of the mind, (setting aside the arts grounded

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: upon words, and especially that skill of proceeding upon generall, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: infallible rules, called Science; which very few have, and but in few

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: things; as being not a native faculty, born with us; nor attained,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (as Prudence,) while we look after somewhat els,) I find yet a greater

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: equality amongst men, than that of strength. For Prudence, is but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Experience; which equall time, equally bestowes on all men, in those

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: things they equally apply themselves unto. That which may perhaps make

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such equality incredible, is but a vain conceipt of ones owne wisdome,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which almost all men think they have in a greater degree, than the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Vulgar; that is, than all men but themselves, and a few others, whom by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Fame, or for concurring with themselves, they approve. For such is the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: nature of men, that howsoever they may acknowledge many others to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: more witty, or more eloquent, or more learned; Yet they will hardly

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: believe there be many so wise as themselves: For they see their own wit

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: at hand, and other mens at a distance. But this proveth rather that men

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are in that point equall, than unequall. For there is not ordinarily a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: greater signe of the equall distribution of any thing, than that every

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man is contented with his share.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: From Equality Proceeds Diffidence

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: From this equality of ability, ariseth equality of hope in the attaining

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of our Ends. And therefore if any two men desire the same thing, which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: neverthelesse they cannot both enjoy, they become enemies; and in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: way to their End, (which is principally their owne conservation, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sometimes their delectation only,) endeavour to destroy, or subdue one

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: an other. And from hence it comes to passe, that where an Invader hath

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: no more to feare, than an other mans single power; if one plant, sow,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: build, or possesse a convenient Seat, others may probably be expected to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: come prepared with forces united, to dispossesse, and deprive him, not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: only of the fruit of his labour, but also of his life, or liberty. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Invader again is in the like danger of another.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: From Diffidence Warre

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And from this diffidence of one another, there is no way for any man to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: secure himselfe, so reasonable, as Anticipation; that is, by force, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: wiles, to master the persons of all men he can, so long, till he see no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other power great enough to endanger him: And this is no more than his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: own conservation requireth, and is generally allowed. Also because there

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be some, that taking pleasure in contemplating their own power in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the acts of conquest, which they pursue farther than their security

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: requires; if others, that otherwise would be glad to be at ease within

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: modest bounds, should not by invasion increase their power, they would

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not be able, long time, by standing only on their defence, to subsist.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And by consequence, such augmentation of dominion over men, being

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: necessary to a mans conservation, it ought to be allowed him.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Againe, men have no pleasure, (but on the contrary a great deale of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: griefe) in keeping company, where there is no power able to over-awe

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them all. For every man looketh that his companion should value him, at

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the same rate he sets upon himselfe: And upon all signes of contempt,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or undervaluing, naturally endeavours, as far as he dares (which amongst

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them that have no common power, to keep them in quiet, is far enough

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to make them destroy each other,) to extort a greater value from his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: contemners, by dommage; and from others, by the example.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: So that in the nature of man, we find three principall causes of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: quarrel. First, Competition; Secondly, Diffidence; Thirdly, Glory.

author: Thomas Hobbes
