text: The first, maketh men invade for Gain; the second, for Safety; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the third, for Reputation. The first use Violence, to make themselves

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Masters of other mens persons, wives, children, and cattell; the second,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to defend them; the third, for trifles, as a word, a smile, a different

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: opinion, and any other signe of undervalue, either direct in their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Persons, or by reflexion in their Kindred, their Friends, their Nation,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their Profession, or their Name.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Out Of Civil States,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: There Is Alwayes Warre Of Every One Against Every One Hereby it is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: manifest, that during the time men live without a common Power to keep

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them all in awe, they are in that condition which is called Warre;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and such a warre, as is of every man, against every man. For WARRE,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consisteth not in Battell onely, or the act of fighting; but in a tract

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of time, wherein the Will to contend by Battell is sufficiently known:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and therefore the notion of Time, is to be considered in the nature of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Warre; as it is in the nature of Weather. For as the nature of Foule

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: weather, lyeth not in a showre or two of rain; but in an inclination

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thereto of many dayes together: So the nature of War, consisteth not in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: actuall fighting; but in the known disposition thereto, during all the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: time there is no assurance to the contrary. All other time is PEACE.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Incommodites Of Such A War

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Whatsoever therefore is consequent to a time of Warre, where every man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is Enemy to every man; the same is consequent to the time, wherein men

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: live without other security, than what their own strength, and their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: own invention shall furnish them withall. In such condition, there is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: no place for Industry; because the fruit thereof is uncertain; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consequently no Culture of the Earth; no Navigation, nor use of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: commodities that may be imported by Sea; no commodious Building; no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Instruments of moving, and removing such things as require much force;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: no Knowledge of the face of the Earth; no account of Time; no Arts; no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Letters; no Society; and which is worst of all, continuall feare, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: danger of violent death; And the life of man, solitary, poore, nasty,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: brutish, and short.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: It may seem strange to some man, that has not well weighed these things;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that Nature should thus dissociate, and render men apt to invade,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and destroy one another: and he may therefore, not trusting to this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Inference, made from the Passions, desire perhaps to have the same

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: confirmed by Experience. Let him therefore consider with himselfe, when

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: taking a journey, he armes himselfe, and seeks to go well accompanied;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: when going to sleep, he locks his dores; when even in his house he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: locks his chests; and this when he knows there bee Lawes, and publike

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Officers, armed, to revenge all injuries shall bee done him; what

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: opinion he has of his fellow subjects, when he rides armed; of his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: fellow Citizens, when he locks his dores; and of his children, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: servants, when he locks his chests. Does he not there as much accuse

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: mankind by his actions, as I do by my words? But neither of us accuse

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: mans nature in it. The Desires, and other Passions of man, are in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: themselves no Sin. No more are the Actions, that proceed from those

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Passions, till they know a Law that forbids them; which till Lawes be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: made they cannot know: nor can any Law be made, till they have agreed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: upon the Person that shall make it.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: It may peradventure be thought, there was never such a time, nor

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: condition of warre as this; and I believe it was never generally so,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: over all the world: but there are many places, where they live so now.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For the savage people in many places of America, except the government

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of small Families, the concord whereof dependeth on naturall lust, have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: no government at all; and live at this day in that brutish manner, as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: I said before. Howsoever, it may be perceived what manner of life there

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: would be, where there were no common Power to feare; by the manner of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: life, which men that have formerly lived under a peacefull government,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: use to degenerate into, in a civill Warre.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But though there had never been any time, wherein particular men were in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a condition of warre one against another; yet in all times, Kings, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: persons of Soveraigne authority, because of their Independency, are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in continuall jealousies, and in the state and posture of Gladiators;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: having their weapons pointing, and their eyes fixed on one another;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that is, their Forts, Garrisons, and Guns upon the Frontiers of their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kingdomes; and continuall Spyes upon their neighbours; which is a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: posture of War. But because they uphold thereby, the Industry of their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Subjects; there does not follow from it, that misery, which accompanies

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Liberty of particular men.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In Such A Warre, Nothing Is Unjust

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To this warre of every man against every man, this also is consequent;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that nothing can be Unjust. The notions of Right and Wrong, Justice and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Injustice have there no place. Where there is no common Power, there is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: no Law: where no Law, no Injustice. Force, and Fraud, are in warre the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: two Cardinall vertues. Justice, and Injustice are none of the Faculties

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: neither of the Body, nor Mind. If they were, they might be in a man that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: were alone in the world, as well as his Senses, and Passions. They

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are Qualities, that relate to men in Society, not in Solitude. It is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consequent also to the same condition, that there be no Propriety, no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Dominion, no Mine and Thine distinct; but onely that to be every mans

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that he can get; and for so long, as he can keep it. And thus much

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for the ill condition, which man by meer Nature is actually placed in;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: though with a possibility to come out of it, consisting partly in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Passions, partly in his Reason.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Passions That Incline Men To Peace

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Passions that encline men to Peace, are Feare of Death; Desire of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such things as are necessary to commodious living; and a Hope by their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Industry to obtain them. And Reason suggesteth convenient Articles of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Peace, upon which men may be drawn to agreement. These Articles, are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they, which otherwise are called the Lawes of Nature: whereof I shall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: speak more particularly, in the two following Chapters.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CHAPTER XIV. OF THE FIRST AND SECOND NATURALL LAWES, AND OF CONTRACTS

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Right Of Nature What

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The RIGHT OF NATURE, which Writers commonly call Jus Naturale, is the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Liberty each man hath, to use his own power, as he will himselfe, for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the preservation of his own Nature; that is to say, of his own Life;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and consequently, of doing any thing, which in his own Judgement, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Reason, hee shall conceive to be the aptest means thereunto.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Liberty What

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: By LIBERTY, is understood, according to the proper signification of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: word, the absence of externall Impediments: which Impediments, may oft

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: take away part of a mans power to do what hee would; but cannot hinder

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him from using the power left him, according as his judgement, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: reason shall dictate to him.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: A Law Of Nature What

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: A LAW OF NATURE, (Lex Naturalis,) is a Precept, or generall Rule,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: found out by Reason, by which a man is forbidden to do, that, which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is destructive of his life, or taketh away the means of preserving the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: same; and to omit, that, by which he thinketh it may be best preserved.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For though they that speak of this subject, use to confound Jus, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lex, Right and Law; yet they ought to be distinguished; because RIGHT,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consisteth in liberty to do, or to forbeare; Whereas LAW, determineth,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and bindeth to one of them: so that Law, and Right, differ as much,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as Obligation, and Liberty; which in one and the same matter are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: inconsistent.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Naturally Every Man Has Right To Everything

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And because the condition of Man, (as hath been declared in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: precedent Chapter) is a condition of Warre of every one against every

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: one; in which case every one is governed by his own Reason; and there

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is nothing he can make use of, that may not be a help unto him, in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: preserving his life against his enemyes; It followeth, that in such a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: condition, every man has a Right to every thing; even to one anothers

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: body. And therefore, as long as this naturall Right of every man to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: every thing endureth, there can be no security to any man, (how strong

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or wise soever he be,) of living out the time, which Nature ordinarily

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: alloweth men to live.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Fundamental Law Of Nature

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And consequently it is a precept, or generall rule of Reason, "That

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: every man, ought to endeavour Peace, as farre as he has hope of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: obtaining it; and when he cannot obtain it, that he may seek, and use,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all helps, and advantages of Warre." The first branch, of which Rule,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: containeth the first, and Fundamentall Law of Nature; which is, "To seek

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Peace, and follow it." The Second, the summe of the Right of Nature;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which is, "By all means we can, to defend our selves."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Second Law Of Nature

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: From this Fundamentall Law of Nature, by which men are commanded to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: endeavour Peace, is derived this second Law; "That a man be willing,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: when others are so too, as farre-forth, as for Peace, and defence of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: himselfe he shall think it necessary, to lay down this right to all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: things; and be contented with so much liberty against other men, as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he would allow other men against himselfe." For as long as every man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: holdeth this Right, of doing any thing he liketh; so long are all men in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the condition of Warre. But if other men will not lay down their Right,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as well as he; then there is no Reason for any one, to devest himselfe

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of his: For that were to expose himselfe to Prey, (which no man is bound

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to) rather than to dispose himselfe to Peace. This is that Law of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Gospell; "Whatsoever you require that others should do to you, that do

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ye to them." And that Law of all men, "Quod tibi feiri non vis, alteri

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ne feceris."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: What it is to lay down a Right

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To Lay Downe a mans Right to any thing, is to Devest himselfe of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Liberty, of hindring another of the benefit of his own Right to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: same. For he that renounceth, or passeth away his Right, giveth not to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: any other man a Right which he had not before; because there is nothing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to which every man had not Right by Nature: but onely standeth out of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his way, that he may enjoy his own originall Right, without hindrance

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from him; not without hindrance from another. So that the effect which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: redoundeth to one man, by another mans defect of Right, is but so much

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: diminution of impediments to the use of his own Right originall.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Renouncing (or) Transferring Right What; Obligation Duty Justice

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Right is layd aside, either by simply Renouncing it; or by Transferring

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it to another. By Simply RENOUNCING; when he cares not to whom the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: benefit thereof redoundeth. By TRANSFERRING; when he intendeth the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: benefit thereof to some certain person, or persons. And when a man hath

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in either manner abandoned, or granted away his Right; then is he said

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to be OBLIGED, or BOUND, not to hinder those, to whom such Right is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: granted, or abandoned, from the benefit of it: and that he Ought, and it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his DUTY, not to make voyd that voluntary act of his own: and that such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hindrance is INJUSTICE, and INJURY, as being Sine Jure; the Right being

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: before renounced, or transferred. So that Injury, or Injustice, in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the controversies of the world, is somewhat like to that, which in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: disputations of Scholers is called Absurdity. For as it is there called

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: an Absurdity, to contradict what one maintained in the Beginning: so in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the world, it is called Injustice, and Injury, voluntarily to undo that,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which from the beginning he had voluntarily done. The way by which a man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: either simply Renounceth, or Transferreth his Right, is a Declaration,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or Signification, by some voluntary and sufficient signe, or signes,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that he doth so Renounce, or Transferre; or hath so Renounced, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Transferred the same, to him that accepteth it. And these Signes are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: either Words onely, or Actions onely; or (as it happeneth most often)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: both Words and Actions. And the same are the BONDS, by which men are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: bound, and obliged: Bonds, that have their strength, not from their own

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nature, (for nothing is more easily broken then a mans word,) but from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Feare of some evill consequence upon the rupture.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Not All Rights Are Alienable

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Whensoever a man Transferreth his Right, or Renounceth it; it is either

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in consideration of some Right reciprocally transferred to himselfe; or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for some other good he hopeth for thereby. For it is a voluntary act:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and of the voluntary acts of every man, the object is some Good To

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Himselfe. And therefore there be some Rights, which no man can be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: understood by any words, or other signes, to have abandoned, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: transferred. As first a man cannot lay down the right of resisting them,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that assault him by force, to take away his life; because he cannot be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: understood to ayme thereby, at any Good to himselfe. The same may be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sayd of Wounds, and Chayns, and Imprisonment; both because there is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: no benefit consequent to such patience; as there is to the patience of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: suffering another to be wounded, or imprisoned: as also because a man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: cannot tell, when he seeth men proceed against him by violence, whether

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they intend his death or not. And lastly the motive, and end for which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: this renouncing, and transferring or Right is introduced, is nothing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: else but the security of a mans person, in his life, and in the means of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: so preserving life, as not to be weary of it. And therefore if a man by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: words, or other signes, seem to despoyle himselfe of the End, for which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: those signes were intended; he is not to be understood as if he meant

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it, or that it was his will; but that he was ignorant of how such words

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and actions were to be interpreted.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Contract What

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The mutuall transferring of Right, is that which men call CONTRACT.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: There is difference, between transferring of Right to the Thing; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: transferring, or tradition, that is, delivery of the Thing it selfe. For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Thing may be delivered together with the Translation of the Right;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as in buying and selling with ready mony; or exchange of goods, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: lands: and it may be delivered some time after.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Covenant What

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Again, one of the Contractors, may deliver the Thing contracted for on

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his part, and leave the other to perform his part at some determinate

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: time after, and in the mean time be trusted; and then the Contract on

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his part, is called PACT, or COVENANT: Or both parts may contract now,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to performe hereafter: in which cases, he that is to performe in time

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to come, being trusted, his performance is called Keeping Of Promise, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Faith; and the fayling of performance (if it be voluntary) Violation Of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Faith.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Free-gift

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: When the transferring of Right, is not mutuall; but one of the parties

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: transferreth, in hope to gain thereby friendship, or service from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: another, or from his friends; or in hope to gain the reputation of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Charity, or Magnanimity; or to deliver his mind from the pain of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: compassion; or in hope of reward in heaven; This is not Contract, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: GIFT, FREEGIFT, GRACE: which words signifie one and the same thing.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Signes Of Contract Expresse

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Signes of Contract, are either Expresse, or By Inference. Expresse, are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: words spoken with understanding of what they signifie; And such words

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are either of the time Present, or Past; as, I Give, I Grant, I Have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Given, I Have Granted, I Will That This Be Yours: Or of the future;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as, I Will Give, I Will Grant; which words of the future, are called

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Promise.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Signes Of Contract By Inference

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Signes by Inference, are sometimes the consequence of Words; sometimes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the consequence of Silence; sometimes the consequence of Actions;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sometimes the consequence of Forbearing an Action: and generally a signe

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by Inference, of any Contract, is whatsoever sufficiently argues the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: will of the Contractor.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Free Gift Passeth By Words Of The Present Or Past

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Words alone, if they be of the time to come, and contain a bare promise,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are an insufficient signe of a Free-gift and therefore not obligatory.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For if they be of the time to Come, as, To Morrow I Will Give, they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are a signe I have not given yet, and consequently that my right is not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: transferred, but remaineth till I transferre it by some other Act. But

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: if the words be of the time Present, or Past, as, "I have given, or do

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: give to be delivered to morrow," then is my to morrows Right given away

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to day; and that by the vertue of the words, though there were no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other argument of my will. And there is a great difference in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: signification of these words, Volos Hoc Tuum Esse Cras, and Cros Dabo;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that is between "I will that this be thine to morrow," and, "I will

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: give it to thee to morrow:" For the word I Will, in the former manner

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of speech, signifies an act of the will Present; but in the later, it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: signifies a promise of an act of the will to Come: and therefore the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: former words, being of the Present, transferre a future right; the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: later, that be of the Future, transferre nothing. But if there be other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: signes of the Will to transferre a Right, besides Words; then, though

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the gift be Free, yet may the Right be understood to passe by words of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the future: as if a man propound a Prize to him that comes first to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: end of a race, The gift is Free; and though the words be of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Future, yet the Right passeth: for if he would not have his words so be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: understood, he should not have let them runne.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Signes Of Contract Are Words Both Of The Past, Present, and Future In

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Contracts, the right passeth, not onely where the words are of the time

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Present, or Past; but also where they are of the Future; because all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Contract is mutuall translation, or change of Right; and therefore he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that promiseth onely, because he hath already received the benefit for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which he promiseth, is to be understood as if he intended the Right

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: should passe: for unlesse he had been content to have his words so

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: understood, the other would not have performed his part first. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for that cause, in buying, and selling, and other acts of Contract, A

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Promise is equivalent to a Covenant; and therefore obligatory.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Merit What

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: He that performeth first in the case of a Contract, is said to MERIT

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that which he is to receive by the performance of the other; and he hath

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it as Due. Also when a Prize is propounded to many, which is to be given

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to him onely that winneth; or mony is thrown amongst many, to be enjoyed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by them that catch it; though this be a Free Gift; yet so to Win, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: so to Catch, is to Merit, and to have it as DUE. For the Right is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: transferred in the Propounding of the Prize, and in throwing down the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: mony; though it be not determined to whom, but by the Event of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: contention. But there is between these two sorts of Merit, this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: difference, that In Contract, I Merit by vertue of my own power, and the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Contractors need; but in this case of Free Gift, I am enabled to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Merit onely by the benignity of the Giver; In Contract, I merit at The

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Contractors hand that hee should depart with his right; In this case of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: gift, I Merit not that the giver should part with his right; but that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: when he has parted with it, it should be mine, rather than anothers.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And this I think to be the meaning of that distinction of the Schooles,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: between Meritum Congrui, and Meritum Condigni. For God Almighty, having

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: promised Paradise to those men (hoodwinkt with carnall desires,) that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: can walk through this world according to the Precepts, and Limits

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: prescribed by him; they say, he that shall so walk, shall Merit Paradise

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ex Congruo. But because no man can demand a right to it, by his own

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Righteousnesse, or any other power in himselfe, but by the Free Grace of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: God onely; they say, no man can Merit Paradise Ex Condigno. This I say,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: I think is the meaning of that distinction; but because Disputers do not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: agree upon the signification of their own termes of Art, longer than it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: serves their turn; I will not affirme any thing of their meaning:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: onely this I say; when a gift is given indefinitely, as a prize to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: contended for, he that winneth Meriteth, and may claime the Prize as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Due.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Covenants Of Mutuall Trust, When Invalid

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: If a Covenant be made, wherein neither of the parties performe

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: presently, but trust one another; in the condition of meer Nature,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (which is a condition of Warre of every man against every man,) upon

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: any reasonable suspition, it is Voyd; But if there be a common Power set

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: over them bothe, with right and force sufficient to compell performance;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it is not Voyd. For he that performeth first, has no assurance the other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: will performe after; because the bonds of words are too weak to bridle

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: mens ambition, avarice, anger, and other Passions, without the feare of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: some coerceive Power; which in the condition of meer Nature, where all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: men are equall, and judges of the justnesse of their own fears cannot

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: possibly be supposed. And therefore he which performeth first, does

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but betray himselfe to his enemy; contrary to the Right (he can never

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: abandon) of defending his life, and means of living.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But in a civill estate, where there is a Power set up to constrain

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: those that would otherwise violate their faith, that feare is no more

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: reasonable; and for that cause, he which by the Covenant is to perform

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: first, is obliged so to do.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The cause of Feare, which maketh such a Covenant invalid, must be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: alwayes something arising after the Covenant made; as some new fact,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or other signe of the Will not to performe; else it cannot make the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Covenant Voyd. For that which could not hinder a man from promising,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ought not to be admitted as a hindrance of performing.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Right To The End, Containeth Right To The Means

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: He that transferreth any Right, transferreth the Means of enjoying it,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as farre as lyeth in his power. As he that selleth Land, is understood

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to transferre the Herbage, and whatsoever growes upon it; Nor can he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that sells a Mill turn away the Stream that drives it. And they that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: give to a man The Right of government in Soveraignty, are understood

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to give him the right of levying mony to maintain Souldiers; and of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: appointing Magistrates for the administration of Justice.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: No Covenant With Beasts

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To make Covenant with bruit Beasts, is impossible; because not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: understanding our speech, they understand not, nor accept of any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: translation of Right; nor can translate any Right to another; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: without mutuall acceptation, there is no Covenant.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nor With God Without Speciall Revelation

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To make Covenant with God, is impossible, but by Mediation of such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as God speaketh to, either by Revelation supernaturall, or by his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lieutenants that govern under him, and in his Name; For otherwise we

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: know not whether our Covenants be accepted, or not. And therefore they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that Vow any thing contrary to any law of Nature, Vow in vain; as being

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a thing unjust to pay such Vow. And if it be a thing commanded by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Law of Nature, it is not the Vow, but the Law that binds them.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: No Covenant, But Of Possible And Future

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The matter, or subject of a Covenant, is alwayes something that falleth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: under deliberation; (For to Covenant, is an act of the Will; that is to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: say an act, and the last act, of deliberation;) and is therefore alwayes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: understood to be something to come; and which is judged Possible for him

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that Covenanteth, to performe.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And therefore, to promise that which is known to be Impossible, is no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Covenant. But if that prove impossible afterwards, which before was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thought possible, the Covenant is valid, and bindeth, (though not to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thing it selfe,) yet to the value; or, if that also be impossible, to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the unfeigned endeavour of performing as much as is possible; for to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: more no man can be obliged.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Covenants How Made Voyd

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Men are freed of their Covenants two wayes; by Performing; or by being

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Forgiven. For Performance, is the naturall end of obligation; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Forgivenesse, the restitution of liberty; as being a retransferring of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that Right, in which the obligation consisted.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Covenants Extorted By Feare Are Valide

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Covenants entred into by fear, in the condition of meer Nature, are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: obligatory. For example, if I Covenant to pay a ransome, or service for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: my life, to an enemy; I am bound by it. For it is a Contract, wherein

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: one receiveth the benefit of life; the other is to receive mony,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or service for it; and consequently, where no other Law (as in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: condition, of meer Nature) forbiddeth the performance, the Covenant

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is valid. Therefore Prisoners of warre, if trusted with the payment of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their Ransome, are obliged to pay it; And if a weaker Prince, make a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: disadvantageous peace with a stronger, for feare; he is bound to keep

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it; unlesse (as hath been sayd before) there ariseth some new, and just

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: cause of feare, to renew the war. And even in Common-wealths, if I be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: forced to redeem my selfe from a Theefe by promising him mony, I am

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: bound to pay it, till the Civill Law discharge me. For whatsoever I may

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: lawfully do without Obligation, the same I may lawfully Covenant to do

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: through feare: and what I lawfully Covenant, I cannot lawfully break.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Former Covenant To One, Makes Voyd The Later To Another

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: A former Covenant, makes voyd a later. For a man that hath passed away

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his Right to one man to day, hath it not to passe to morrow to another:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and therefore the later promise passeth no Right, but is null.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: A Mans Covenant Not To Defend Himselfe, Is Voyd

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: A Covenant not to defend my selfe from force, by force, is alwayes voyd.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For (as I have shewed before) no man can transferre, or lay down his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Right to save himselfe from Death, Wounds, and Imprisonment, (the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: avoyding whereof is the onely End of laying down any Right,)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and therefore the promise of not resisting force, in no Covenant

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: transferreth any right; nor is obliging. For though a man may Covenant

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thus, "Unlesse I do so, or so, kill me;" he cannot Covenant thus "Unless

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: I do so, or so, I will not resist you, when you come to kill me." For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man by nature chooseth the lesser evill, which is danger of death in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: resisting; rather than the greater, which is certain and present death

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in not resisting. And this is granted to be true by all men, in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that they lead Criminals to Execution, and Prison, with armed men,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: notwithstanding that such Criminals have consented to the Law, by which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they are condemned.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: No Man Obliged To Accuse Himselfe

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: A Covenant to accuse ones Selfe, without assurance of pardon, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: likewise invalide. For in the condition of Nature, where every man is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Judge, there is no place for Accusation: and in the Civill State, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Accusation is followed with Punishment; which being Force, a man is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not obliged not to resist. The same is also true, of the Accusation of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: those, by whose Condemnation a man falls into misery; as of a Father,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Wife, or Benefactor. For the Testimony of such an Accuser, if it be not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: willingly given, is praesumed to be corrupted by Nature; and therefore

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not to be received: and where a mans Testimony is not to be credited,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his not bound to give it. Also Accusations upon Torture, are not to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be reputed as Testimonies. For Torture is to be used but as means of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: conjecture, and light, in the further examination, and search of truth;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and what is in that case confessed, tendeth to the ease of him that is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Tortured; not to the informing of the Torturers: and therefore ought

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not to have the credit of a sufficient Testimony: for whether he deliver

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: himselfe by true, or false Accusation, he does it by the Right of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: preserving his own life.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The End Of An Oath; The Forme Of As Oath

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The force of Words, being (as I have formerly noted) too weak to hold

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: men to the performance of their Covenants; there are in mans nature, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: two imaginable helps to strengthen it. And those are either a Feare

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the consequence of breaking their word; or a Glory, or Pride in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: appearing not to need to breake it. This later is a Generosity too

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: rarely found to be presumed on, especially in the pursuers of Wealth,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Command, or sensuall Pleasure; which are the greatest part of Mankind.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Passion to be reckoned upon, is Fear; whereof there be two very

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: generall Objects: one, the Power of Spirits Invisible; the other, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Power of those men they shall therein Offend. Of these two, though the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: former be the greater Power, yet the feare of the later is commonly

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the greater Feare. The Feare of the former is in every man, his own

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Religion: which hath place in the nature of man before Civill Society.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The later hath not so; at least not place enough, to keep men to their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: promises; because in the condition of meer Nature, the inequality of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Power is not discerned, but by the event of Battell. So that before the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: time of Civill Society, or in the interruption thereof by Warre, there

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is nothing can strengthen a Covenant of Peace agreed on, against the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: temptations of Avarice, Ambition, Lust, or other strong desire, but the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: feare of that Invisible Power, which they every one Worship as God; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Feare as a Revenger of their perfidy. All therefore that can be done

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: between two men not subject to Civill Power, is to put one another

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to swear by the God he feareth: Which Swearing or OATH, is a Forme Of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Speech, Added To A Promise; By Which He That Promiseth, Signifieth, That

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Unlesse He Performe, He Renounceth The Mercy Of His God, Or Calleth To

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Him For Vengeance On Himselfe. Such was the Heathen Forme, "Let Jupiter

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: kill me else, as I kill this Beast." So is our Forme, "I shall do thus,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and thus, so help me God." And this, with the Rites and Ceremonies,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which every one useth in his own Religion, that the feare of breaking

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: faith might be the greater.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: No Oath, But By God

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: By this it appears, that an Oath taken according to any other Forme, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Rite, then his, that sweareth, is in vain; and no Oath: And there is no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Swearing by any thing which the Swearer thinks not God. For though men

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have sometimes used to swear by their Kings, for feare, or flattery; yet

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they would have it thereby understood, they attributed to them Divine

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: honour. And that Swearing unnecessarily by God, is but prophaning of his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: name: and Swearing by other things, as men do in common discourse, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not Swearing, but an impious Custome, gotten by too much vehemence of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: talking.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: An Oath Addes Nothing To The Obligation

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: It appears also, that the Oath addes nothing to the Obligation. For a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Covenant, if lawfull, binds in the sight of God, without the Oath,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as much as with it; if unlawfull, bindeth not at all; though it be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: confirmed with an Oath.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CHAPTER XV. OF OTHER LAWES OF NATURE

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Third Law Of Nature, Justice

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: From that law of Nature, by which we are obliged to transferre to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: another, such Rights, as being retained, hinder the peace of Mankind,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there followeth a Third; which is this, That Men Performe Their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Covenants Made: without which, Covenants are in vain, and but Empty

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: words; and the Right of all men to all things remaining, wee are still

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the condition of Warre.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Justice And Injustice What

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And in this law of Nature, consisteth the Fountain and Originall of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: JUSTICE. For where no Covenant hath preceded, there hath no Right been

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: transferred, and every man has right to every thing; and consequently,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: no action can be Unjust. But when a Covenant is made, then to break it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is Unjust: And the definition of INJUSTICE, is no other than The Not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Performance Of Covenant. And whatsoever is not Unjust, is Just.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Justice And Propriety Begin With The Constitution of Common-wealth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But because Covenants of mutuall trust, where there is a feare of not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: performance on either part, (as hath been said in the former Chapter,)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are invalid; though the Originall of Justice be the making of Covenants;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: yet Injustice actually there can be none, till the cause of such feare

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be taken away; which while men are in the naturall condition of Warre,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: cannot be done. Therefore before the names of Just, and Unjust can have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: place, there must be some coercive Power, to compell men equally to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the performance of their Covenants, by the terrour of some punishment,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: greater than the benefit they expect by the breach of their Covenant;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and to make good that Propriety, which by mutuall Contract men acquire,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in recompence of the universall Right they abandon: and such power there

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is none before the erection of a Common-wealth. And this is also to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: gathered out of the ordinary definition of Justice in the Schooles: For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they say, that "Justice is the constant Will of giving to every man his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: own." And therefore where there is no Own, that is, no Propriety, there

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is no Injustice; and where there is no coerceive Power erected, that is,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: where there is no Common-wealth, there is no Propriety; all men having

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Right to all things: Therefore where there is no Common-wealth, there

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: nothing is Unjust. So that the nature of Justice, consisteth in keeping

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of valid Covenants: but the Validity of Covenants begins not but with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Constitution of a Civill Power, sufficient to compell men to keep

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them: And then it is also that Propriety begins.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Justice Not Contrary To Reason

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Foole hath sayd in his heart, there is no such thing as Justice;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and sometimes also with his tongue; seriously alleaging, that every mans

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: conservation, and contentment, being committed to his own care, there

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: could be no reason, why every man might not do what he thought conduced

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thereunto; and therefore also to make, or not make; keep, or not keep

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Covenants, was not against Reason, when it conduced to ones benefit.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: He does not therein deny, that there be Covenants; and that they are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sometimes broken, sometimes kept; and that such breach of them may

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be called Injustice, and the observance of them Justice: but he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: questioneth, whether Injustice, taking away the feare of God, (for the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: same Foole hath said in his heart there is no God,) may not sometimes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: stand with that Reason, which dictateth to every man his own good; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: particularly then, when it conduceth to such a benefit, as shall put a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man in a condition, to neglect not onely the dispraise, and revilings,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but also the power of other men. The Kingdome of God is gotten by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: violence; but what if it could be gotten by unjust violence? were it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: against Reason so to get it, when it is impossible to receive hurt by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it? and if it be not against Reason, it is not against Justice; or else

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Justice is not to be approved for good. From such reasoning as this,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Succesfull wickednesse hath obtained the Name of Vertue; and some that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in all other things have disallowed the violation of Faith; yet have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: allowed it, when it is for the getting of a Kingdome. And the Heathen

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that believed, that Saturn was deposed by his son Jupiter, believed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: neverthelesse the same Jupiter to be the avenger of Injustice: Somewhat

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: like to a piece of Law in Cokes Commentaries on Litleton; where he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sayes, If the right Heire of the Crown be attainted of Treason; yet the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Crown shall descend to him, and Eo Instante the Atteynder be voyd; From

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which instances a man will be very prone to inferre; that when the Heire

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: apparent of a Kingdome, shall kill him that is in possession, though his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: father; you may call it Injustice, or by what other name you will; yet

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it can never be against Reason, seeing all the voluntary actions of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: men tend to the benefit of themselves; and those actions are most

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Reasonable, that conduce most to their ends. This specious reasoning is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: nevertheless false.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For the question is not of promises mutuall, where there is no security

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of performance on either side; as when there is no Civill Power erected

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: over the parties promising; for such promises are no Covenants: But

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: either where one of the parties has performed already; or where there

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is a Power to make him performe; there is the question whether it be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: against reason, that is, against the benefit of the other to performe,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or not. And I say it is not against reason. For the manifestation

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whereof, we are to consider; First, that when a man doth a thing, which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: notwithstanding any thing can be foreseen, and reckoned on, tendeth to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his own destruction, howsoever some accident which he could not expect,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: arriving may turne it to his benefit; yet such events do not make it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: reasonably or wisely done. Secondly, that in a condition of Warre,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: wherein every man to every man, for want of a common Power to keep them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all in awe, is an Enemy, there is no man can hope by his own strength,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or wit, to defend himselfe from destruction, without the help

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Confederates; where every one expects the same defence by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Confederation, that any one else does: and therefore he which declares

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he thinks it reason to deceive those that help him, can in reason expect

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: no other means of safety, than what can be had from his own single

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Power. He therefore that breaketh his Covenant, and consequently

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: declareth that he thinks he may with reason do so, cannot be received

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: into any Society, that unite themselves for Peace and defence, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by the errour of them that receive him; nor when he is received, be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: retayned in it, without seeing the danger of their errour; which errours

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a man cannot reasonably reckon upon as the means of his security; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore if he be left, or cast out of Society, he perisheth; and if he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: live in Society, it is by the errours of other men, which he could not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: foresee, nor reckon upon; and consequently against the reason of his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: preservation; and so, as all men that contribute not to his destruction,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: forbear him onely out of ignorance of what is good for themselves.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: As for the Instance of gaining the secure and perpetuall felicity of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Heaven, by any way; it is frivolous: there being but one way imaginable;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and that is not breaking, but keeping of Covenant.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And for the other Instance of attaining Soveraignty by Rebellion; it is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: manifest, that though the event follow, yet because it cannot reasonably

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be expected, but rather the contrary; and because by gaining it so,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: others are taught to gain the same in like manner, the attempt thereof

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is against reason. Justice therefore, that is to say, Keeping of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Covenant, is a Rule of Reason, by which we are forbidden to do any thing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: destructive to our life; and consequently a Law of Nature.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: There be some that proceed further; and will not have the Law of Nature,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to be those Rules which conduce to the preservation of mans life on

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: earth; but to the attaining of an eternall felicity after death; to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which they think the breach of Covenant may conduce; and consequently

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be just and reasonable; (such are they that think it a work of merit

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to kill, or depose, or rebell against, the Soveraigne Power constituted

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: over them by their own consent.) But because there is no naturall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: knowledge of mans estate after death; much lesse of the reward that is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: then to be given to breach of Faith; but onely a beliefe grounded upon

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other mens saying, that they know it supernaturally, or that they know

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: those, that knew them, that knew others, that knew it supernaturally;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Breach of Faith cannot be called a Precept of Reason, or Nature.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Covenants Not Discharged By The Vice Of The Person To Whom Made

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Others, that allow for a Law of Nature, the keeping of Faith, do

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: neverthelesse make exception of certain persons; as Heretiques, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such as use not to performe their Covenant to others: And this also is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: against reason. For if any fault of a man, be sufficient to discharge

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: our Covenant made; the same ought in reason to have been sufficient to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have hindred the making of it.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Justice Of Men, And Justice Of Actions What

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The names of Just, and Unjust, when they are attributed to Men, signifie

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: one thing; and when they are attributed to Actions, another. When they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are attributed to Men, they signifie Conformity, or Inconformity of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Manners, to Reason. But when they are attributed to Actions, they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: signifie the Conformity, or Inconformity to Reason, not of Manners, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: manner of life, but of particular Actions. A Just man therefore, is he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that taketh all the care he can, that his Actions may be all Just: and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: an Unjust man, is he that neglecteth it. And such men are more often

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in our Language stiled by the names of Righteous, and Unrighteous; then

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Just, and Unjust; though the meaning be the same. Therefore a Righteous

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man, does not lose that Title, by one, or a few unjust Actions, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: proceed from sudden Passion, or mistake of Things, or Persons: nor does

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: an Unrighteous man, lose his character, for such Actions, as he does,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of forbeares to do, for feare: because his Will is not framed by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Justice, but by the apparant benefit of what he is to do. That which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: gives to humane Actions the relish of Justice, is a certain Noblenesse

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or Gallantnesse of courage, (rarely found,) by which a man scorns to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be beholding for the contentment of his life, to fraud, or breach of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: promise. This Justice of the Manners, is that which is meant, where

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Justice is called a Vertue; and Injustice a Vice.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But the Justice of Actions denominates men, not Just, but Guiltlesse;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and the Injustice of the same, (which is also called Injury,) gives them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but the name of Guilty.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Justice Of Manners, And Justice Of Actions

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Again, the Injustice of Manners, is the disposition, or aptitude to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: do Injurie; and is Injustice before it proceed to Act; and without

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: supposing any individuall person injured. But the Injustice of an

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Action, (that is to say Injury,) supposeth an individuall person

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Injured; namely him, to whom the Covenant was made: And therefore many

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: times the injury is received by one man, when the dammage redoundeth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to another. As when The Master commandeth his servant to give mony to a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: stranger; if it be not done, the Injury is done to the Master, whom

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he had before Covenanted to obey; but the dammage redoundeth to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: stranger, to whom he had no Obligation; and therefore could not Injure

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him. And so also in Common-wealths, private men may remit to one another

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their debts; but not robberies or other violences, whereby they are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: endammaged; because the detaining of Debt, is an Injury to themselves;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but Robbery and Violence, are Injuries to the Person of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nothing Done To A Man, By His Own Consent Can Be Injury

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Whatsoever is done to a man, conformable to his own Will signified to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the doer, is no Injury to him. For if he that doeth it, hath not passed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: away his originall right to do what he please, by some Antecedent

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Covenant, there is no breach of Covenant; and therefore no Injury done

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him. And if he have; then his Will to have it done being signified, is a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: release of that Covenant; and so again there is no Injury done him.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Justice Commutative, And Distributive

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Justice of Actions, is by Writers divided into Commutative, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Distributive; and the former they say consisteth in proportion

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Arithmeticall; the later in proportion Geometricall. Commutative

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore, they place in the equality of value of the things contracted

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for; And Distributive, in the distribution of equall benefit, to men of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: equall merit. As if it were Injustice to sell dearer than we buy; or to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: give more to a man than he merits. The value of all things contracted

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for, is measured by the Appetite of the Contractors: and therefore the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: just value, is that which they be contented to give. And Merit (besides

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that which is by Covenant, where the performance on one part, meriteth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the performance of the other part, and falls under Justice Commutative,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not Distributive,) is not due by Justice; but is rewarded of Grace

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: onely. And therefore this distinction, in the sense wherein it useth to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be expounded, is not right. To speak properly, Commutative Justice,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is the Justice of a Contractor; that is, a Performance of Covenant,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in Buying, and Selling; Hiring, and Letting to Hire; Lending, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Borrowing; Exchanging, Bartering, and other acts of Contract.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And Distributive Justice, the Justice of an Arbitrator; that is to say,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the act of defining what is Just. Wherein, (being trusted by them that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: make him Arbitrator,) if he performe his Trust, he is said to distribute

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to every man his own: and his is indeed Just Distribution, and may

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be called (though improperly) Distributive Justice; but more properly

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Equity; which also is a Law of Nature, as shall be shewn in due place.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Fourth Law Of Nature, Gratitude

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: As Justice dependeth on Antecedent Covenant; so does Gratitude depend

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: on Antecedent Grace; that is to say, Antecedent Free-gift: and is the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: fourth Law of Nature; which may be conceived in this Forme, "That a man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which receiveth Benefit from another of meer Grace, Endeavour that he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which giveth it, have no reasonable cause to repent him of his good

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: will." For no man giveth, but with intention of Good to himselfe;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: because Gift is Voluntary; and of all Voluntary Acts, the Object is to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: every man his own Good; of which if men see they shall be frustrated,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there will be no beginning of benevolence, or trust; nor consequently of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: mutuall help; nor of reconciliation of one man to another; and therefore

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they are to remain still in the condition of War; which is contrary to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the first and Fundamentall Law of Nature, which commandeth men to Seek

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Peace. The breach of this Law, is called Ingratitude; and hath the same

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: relation to Grace, that Injustice hath to Obligation by Covenant.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Fifth, Mutuall accommodation, or Compleasance

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: A fifth Law of Nature, is COMPLEASANCE; that is to say, "That every

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man strive to accommodate himselfe to the rest." For the understanding

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whereof, we may consider, that there is in mens aptnesse to Society;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a diversity of Nature, rising from their diversity of Affections; not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: unlike to that we see in stones brought together for building of an

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Aedifice. For as that stone which by the asperity, and irregularity of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Figure, takes more room from others, than it selfe fills; and for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the hardnesse, cannot be easily made plain, and thereby hindereth the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: building, is by the builders cast away as unprofitable, and troublesome:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: so also, a man that by asperity of Nature, will strive to retain those

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: things which to himselfe are superfluous, and to others necessary; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for the stubbornness of his Passions, cannot be corrected, is to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: left, or cast out of Society, as combersome thereunto. For seeing every

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man, not onely by Right, but also by necessity of Nature, is supposed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to endeavour all he can, to obtain that which is necessary for his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: conservation; He that shall oppose himselfe against it, for things

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: superfluous, is guilty of the warre that thereupon is to follow; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore doth that, which is contrary to the fundamentall Law of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nature, which commandeth To Seek Peace. The observers of this Law,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: may be called SOCIABLE, (the Latines call them Commodi;) The contrary,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Stubborn, Insociable, Froward, Intractable.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Sixth, Facility To Pardon

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: A sixth Law of Nature is this, "That upon caution of the Future time,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a man ought to pardon the offences past of them that repenting, desire

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it." For PARDON, is nothing but granting of Peace; which though granted

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to them that persevere in their hostility, be not Peace, but Feare; yet

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not granted to them that give caution of the Future time, is signe of an

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: aversion to Peace; and therefore contrary to the Law of Nature.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Seventh, That In Revenges, Men Respect Onely The Future Good

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: A seventh is, " That in Revenges, (that is, retribution of evil for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: evil,) Men look not at the greatnesse of the evill past, but the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: greatnesse of the good to follow." Whereby we are forbidden to inflict

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: punishment with any other designe, than for correction of the offender,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or direction of others. For this Law is consequent to the next before

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it, that commandeth Pardon, upon security of the Future Time. Besides,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Revenge without respect to the Example, and profit to come, is a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: triumph, or glorying in the hurt of another, tending to no end; (for the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: End is alwayes somewhat to Come;) and glorying to no end, is vain-glory,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and contrary to reason; and to hurt without reason, tendeth to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: introduction of Warre; which is against the Law of Nature; and is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: commonly stiled by the name of Cruelty.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Eighth, Against Contumely

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And because all signes of hatred, or contempt, provoke to fight;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: insomuch as most men choose rather to hazard their life, than not to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: revenged; we may in the eighth place, for a Law of Nature set down this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Precept, "That no man by deed, word, countenance, or gesture, declare

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Hatred, or Contempt of another." The breach of which Law, is commonly

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: called Contumely.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Ninth, Against Pride

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The question who is the better man, has no place in the condition of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: meer Nature; where, (as has been shewn before,) all men are equall. The

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: inequallity that now is, has been introduced by the Lawes civill. I know

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that Aristotle in the first booke of his Politiques, for a foundation of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his doctrine, maketh men by Nature, some more worthy to Command, meaning

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the wiser sort (such as he thought himselfe to be for his Philosophy;)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: others to Serve, (meaning those that had strong bodies, but were not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Philosophers as he;) as if Master and Servant were not introduced by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consent of men, but by difference of Wit; which is not only against

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: reason; but also against experience. For there are very few so foolish,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that had not rather governe themselves, than be governed by others:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nor when the wise in their own conceit, contend by force, with them who

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: distrust their owne wisdome, do they alwaies, or often, or almost at any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: time, get the Victory. If Nature therefore have made men equall, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: equalitie is to be acknowledged; or if Nature have made men unequall;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: yet because men that think themselves equall, will not enter into

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: conditions of Peace, but upon Equall termes, such equalitie must be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: admitted. And therefore for the ninth Law of Nature, I put this, "That

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: every man acknowledge other for his Equall by Nature." The breach of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: this Precept is Pride.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Tenth Against Arrogance

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: On this law, dependeth another, "That at the entrance into conditions of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Peace, no man require to reserve to himselfe any Right, which he is not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: content should be reserved to every one of the rest." As it is necessary

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for all men that seek peace, to lay down certaine Rights of Nature; that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is to say, not to have libertie to do all they list: so is it necessarie

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for mans life, to retaine some; as right to governe their owne bodies;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: enjoy aire, water, motion, waies to go from place to place; and all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: things else without which a man cannot live, or not live well. If in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: this case, at the making of Peace, men require for themselves, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which they would not have to be granted to others, they do contrary

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to the precedent law, that commandeth the acknowledgement of naturall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: equalitie, and therefore also against the law of Nature. The observers

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of this law, are those we call Modest, and the breakers Arrogant Men.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Greeks call the violation of this law pleonexia; that is, a desire

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of more than their share.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Eleventh Equity

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Also "If a man be trusted to judge between man and man," it is a precept

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Law of Nature, "that he deale Equally between them." For without

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that, the Controversies of men cannot be determined but by Warre.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: He therefore that is partiall in judgment, doth what in him lies, to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: deterre men from the use of Judges, and Arbitrators; and consequently,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (against the fundamentall Lawe of Nature) is the cause of Warre.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The observance of this law, from the equall distribution to each man, of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that which in reason belongeth to him, is called EQUITY, and (as I have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sayd before) distributive justice: the violation, Acception Of Persons,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Prosopolepsia.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Twelfth, Equall Use Of Things Common

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And from this followeth another law, "That such things as cannot be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: divided, be enjoyed in Common, if it can be; and if the quantity of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thing permit, without Stint; otherwise Proportionably to the number of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them that have Right." For otherwise the distribution is Unequall, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: contrary to Equitie.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Thirteenth, Of Lot

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But some things there be, that can neither be divided, nor enjoyed in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: common. Then, The Law of Nature, which prescribeth Equity, requireth,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "That the Entire Right; or else, (making the use alternate,) the First

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Possession, be determined by Lot." For equall distribution, is of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Law of Nature; and other means of equall distribution cannot be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: imagined.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Fourteenth, Of Primogeniture, And First Seising

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of Lots there be two sorts, Arbitrary, and Naturall. Arbitrary, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that which is agreed on by the Competitors; Naturall, is either

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Primogeniture, (which the Greek calls Kleronomia, which signifies, Given

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by Lot;) or First Seisure.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And therefore those things which cannot be enjoyed in common, nor

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: divided, ought to be adjudged to the First Possessor; and is some cases

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to the First-Borne, as acquired by Lot.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Fifteenth, Of Mediators

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: It is also a Law of Nature, "That all men that mediate Peace, be allowed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: safe Conduct." For the Law that commandeth Peace, as the End, commandeth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Intercession, as the Means; and to Intercession the Means is safe

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Conduct.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Sixteenth, Of Submission To Arbitrement

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And because, though men be never so willing to observe these Lawes,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there may neverthelesse arise questions concerning a mans action; First,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whether it were done, or not done; Secondly (if done) whether against

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Law, or not against the Law; the former whereof, is called a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: question Of Fact; the later a question Of Right; therefore unlesse the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: parties to the question, Covenant mutually to stand to the sentence

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of another, they are as farre from Peace as ever. This other, to whose

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sentence they submit, is called an ARBITRATOR. And therefore it is of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Law of Nature, "That they that are at controversie, submit their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Right to the judgement of an Arbitrator."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Seventeenth, No Man Is His Own Judge

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And seeing every man is presumed to do all things in order to his own

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: benefit, no man is a fit Arbitrator in his own cause: and if he were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: never so fit; yet Equity allowing to each party equall benefit, if one

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be admitted to be Judge, the other is to be admitted also; & so the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: controversie, that is, the cause of War, remains, against the Law of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nature.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Eighteenth, No Man To Be Judge, That Has In Him Cause Of Partiality

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For the same reason no man in any Cause ought to be received for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Arbitrator, to whom greater profit, or honour, or pleasure apparently

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ariseth out of the victory of one party, than of the other: for he hath

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: taken (though an unavoydable bribe, yet) a bribe; and no man can be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: obliged to trust him. And thus also the controversie, and the condition

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of War remaineth, contrary to the Law of Nature.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Nineteenth, Of Witnesse

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And in a controversie of Fact, the Judge being to give no more credit

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to one, than to the other, (if there be no other Arguments) must give

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: credit to a third; or to a third and fourth; or more: For else the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: question is undecided, and left to force, contrary to the Law of Nature.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: These are the Lawes of Nature, dictating Peace, for a means of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: conservation of men in multitudes; and which onely concern the doctrine

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Civill Society. There be other things tending to the destruction of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: particular men; as Drunkenness, and all other parts of Intemperance;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which may therefore also be reckoned amongst those things which the Law

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Nature hath forbidden; but are not necessary to be mentioned, nor are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: pertinent enough to this place.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: A Rule, By Which The Laws Of Nature May Easily Be Examined

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And though this may seem too subtile a deduction of the Lawes of Nature,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to be taken notice of by all men; whereof the most part are too busie in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: getting food, and the rest too negligent to understand; yet to leave

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all men unexcusable, they have been contracted into one easie sum,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: intelligible even to the meanest capacity; and that is, "Do not that to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: another, which thou wouldest not have done to thy selfe;" which sheweth

author: Thomas Hobbes
