text: him, that he has no more to do in learning the Lawes of Nature, but,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: when weighing the actions of other men with his own, they seem too

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: heavy, to put them into the other part of the ballance, and his own into

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their place, that his own passions, and selfe-love, may adde nothing to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the weight; and then there is none of these Lawes of Nature that will

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not appear unto him very reasonable.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Lawes Of Nature Oblige In Conscience Alwayes,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But In Effect Then Onely When There Is Security The Lawes of Nature

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: oblige In Foro Interno; that is to say, they bind to a desire they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: should take place: but In Foro Externo; that is, to the putting them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in act, not alwayes. For he that should be modest, and tractable, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: performe all he promises, in such time, and place, where no man els

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: should do so, should but make himselfe a prey to others, and procure his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: own certain ruine, contrary to the ground of all Lawes of Nature, which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: tend to Natures preservation. And again, he that shall observe the same

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lawes towards him, observes them not himselfe, seeketh not Peace, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: War; & consequently the destruction of his Nature by Violence.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And whatsoever Lawes bind In Foro Interno, may be broken, not onely by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a fact contrary to the Law but also by a fact according to it, in case a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man think it contrary. For though his Action in this case, be according

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to the Law; which where the Obligation is In Foro Interno, is a breach.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Laws Of Nature Are Eternal;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Lawes of Nature are Immutable and Eternall, For Injustice,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ingratitude, Arrogance, Pride, Iniquity, Acception of persons, and the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: rest, can never be made lawfull. For it can never be that Warre shall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: preserve life, and Peace destroy it.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And Yet Easie

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The same Lawes, because they oblige onely to a desire, and endeavour, I

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: mean an unfeigned and constant endeavour, are easie to be observed. For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in that they require nothing but endeavour; he that endeavoureth their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: performance, fulfilleth them; and he that fulfilleth the Law, is Just.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Science Of These Lawes, Is The True Morall Philosophy

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And the Science of them, is the true and onely Moral Philosophy. For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Morall Philosophy is nothing else but the Science of what is Good, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Evill, in the conversation, and Society of mankind. Good, and Evill,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are names that signifie our Appetites, and Aversions; which in different

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: tempers, customes, and doctrines of men, are different: And divers men,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: differ not onely in their Judgement, on the senses of what is pleasant,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and unpleasant to the tast, smell, hearing, touch, and sight; but also

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of what is conformable, or disagreeable to Reason, in the actions of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: common life. Nay, the same man, in divers times, differs from himselfe;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and one time praiseth, that is, calleth Good, what another time

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he dispraiseth, and calleth Evil: From whence arise Disputes,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Controversies, and at last War. And therefore so long as man is in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: condition of meer Nature, (which is a condition of War,) as private

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Appetite is the measure of Good, and Evill: and consequently all men

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: agree on this, that Peace is Good, and therefore also the way, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: means of Peace, which (as I have shewed before) are Justice, Gratitude,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Modesty, Equity, Mercy, & the rest of the Laws of Nature, are good; that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is to say, Morall Vertues; and their contrarie Vices, Evill. Now the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: science of Vertue and Vice, is Morall Philosophie; and therfore the true

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Doctrine of the Lawes of Nature, is the true Morall Philosophie. But the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Writers of Morall Philosophie, though they acknowledge the same Vertues

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Vices; Yet not seeing wherein consisted their Goodnesse; nor that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they come to be praised, as the meanes of peaceable, sociable, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: comfortable living; place them in a mediocrity of passions: as if not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Cause, but the Degree of daring, made Fortitude; or not the Cause,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but the Quantity of a gift, made Liberality.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: These dictates of Reason, men use to call by the name of Lawes; but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: improperly: for they are but Conclusions, or Theoremes concerning what

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: conduceth to the conservation and defence of themselves; whereas Law,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: properly is the word of him, that by right hath command over others. But

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: yet if we consider the same Theoremes, as delivered in the word of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: God, that by right commandeth all things; then are they properly called

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lawes.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CHAPTER XVI. OF PERSONS, AUTHORS, AND THINGS PERSONATED

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: A Person What

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: A PERSON, is he "whose words or actions are considered, either as his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: own, or as representing the words or actions of an other man, or of any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other thing to whom they are attributed, whether Truly or by Fiction."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Person Naturall, And Artificiall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: When they are considered as his owne, then is he called a Naturall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Person: And when they are considered as representing the words and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: actions of an other, then is he a Feigned or Artificiall person.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Word Person, Whence

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The word Person is latine: instead whereof the Greeks have Prosopon,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which signifies the Face, as Persona in latine signifies the Disguise,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or Outward Appearance of a man, counterfeited on the Stage; and somtimes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: more particularly that part of it, which disguiseth the face, as a Mask

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or Visard: And from the Stage, hath been translated to any Representer

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of speech and action, as well in Tribunalls, as Theaters. So that a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Person, is the same that an Actor is, both on the Stage and in common

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Conversation; and to Personate, is to Act, or Represent himselfe, or an

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other; and he that acteth another, is said to beare his Person, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: act in his name; (in which sence Cicero useth it where he saies, "Unus

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sustineo Tres Personas; Mei, Adversarii, & Judicis, I beare three

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Persons; my own, my Adversaries, and the Judges;") and is called in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: diverse occasions, diversly; as a Representer, or Representative, a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lieutenant, a Vicar, an Attorney, a Deputy, a Procurator, an Actor, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the like.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Actor, Author; Authority

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of Persons Artificiall, some have their words and actions Owned by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: those whom they represent. And then the Person is the Actor; and he that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: owneth his words and actions, is the AUTHOR: In which case the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Actor acteth by Authority. For that which in speaking of goods and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: possessions, is called an Owner, and in latine Dominus, in Greeke

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kurios; speaking of Actions, is called Author. And as the Right of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: possession, is called Dominion; so the Right of doing any Action, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: called AUTHORITY. So that by Authority, is alwayes understood a Right

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of doing any act: and Done By Authority, done by Commission, or Licence

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from him whose right it is.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Covenants By Authority, Bind The Author

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: From hence it followeth, that when the Actor maketh a Covenant by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Authority, he bindeth thereby the Author, no lesse than if he had made

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it himselfe; and no lesse subjecteth him to all the consequences of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: same. And therfore all that hath been said formerly, (Chap. 14) of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: nature of Covenants between man and man in their naturall capacity,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is true also when they are made by their Actors, Representers, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Procurators, that have authority from them, so far-forth as is in their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Commission, but no farther.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And therefore he that maketh a Covenant with the Actor, or Representer,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not knowing the Authority he hath, doth it at his own perill. For no man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is obliged by a Covenant, whereof he is not Author; nor consequently by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Covenant made against, or beside the Authority he gave.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But Not The Actor

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: When the Actor doth any thing against the Law of Nature by command of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Author, if he be obliged by former Covenant to obey him, not he, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Author breaketh the Law of Nature: for though the Action be against

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Law of Nature; yet it is not his: but contrarily; to refuse to do

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it, is against the Law of Nature, that forbiddeth breach of Covenant.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Authority Is To Be Shewne

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And he that maketh a Covenant with the Author, by mediation of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Actor, not knowing what Authority he hath, but onely takes his word;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in case such Authority be not made manifest unto him upon demand, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: no longer obliged: For the Covenant made with the Author, is not valid,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: without his Counter-assurance. But if he that so Covenanteth, knew

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: before hand he was to expect no other assurance, than the Actors word;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: then is the Covenant valid; because the Actor in this case maketh

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: himselfe the Author. And therefore, as when the Authority is evident,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Covenant obligeth the Author, not the Actor; so when the Authority

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is feigned, it obligeth the Actor onely; there being no Author but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: himselfe.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Things Personated, Inanimate

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: There are few things, that are uncapable of being represented by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Fiction. Inanimate things, as a Church, an Hospital, a Bridge, may

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be Personated by a Rector, Master, or Overseer. But things Inanimate,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: cannot be Authors, nor therefore give Authority to their Actors: Yet the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Actors may have Authority to procure their maintenance, given them by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: those that are Owners, or Governours of those things. And therefore,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such things cannot be Personated, before there be some state of Civill

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Government.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Irrational

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Likewise Children, Fooles, and Mad-men that have no use of Reason, may

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be Personated by Guardians, or Curators; but can be no Authors (during

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that time) of any action done by them, longer then (when they shall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: recover the use of Reason) they shall judge the same reasonable.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Yet during the Folly, he that hath right of governing them, may give

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Authority to the Guardian. But this again has no place but in a State

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Civill, because before such estate, there is no Dominion of Persons.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: False Gods

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: An Idol, or meer Figment of the brain, my be Personated; as were the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Gods of the Heathen; which by such Officers as the State appointed, were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Personated, and held Possessions, and other Goods, and Rights, which men

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from time to time dedicated, and consecrated unto them. But idols cannot

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be Authors: for a Idol is nothing. The Authority proceeded from the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: State: and therefore before introduction of Civill Government, the Gods

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Heathen could not be Personated.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The True God

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The true God may be Personated. As he was; first, by Moses; who governed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Israelites, (that were not his, but Gods people,) not in his own

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: name, with Hoc Dicit Moses; but in Gods Name, with Hoc Dicit Dominus.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Secondly, by the son of man, his own Son our Blessed Saviour Jesus

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christ, that came to reduce the Jewes, and induce all Nations into the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kingdome of his Father; not as of himselfe, but as sent from his Father.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And thirdly, by the Holy Ghost, or Comforter, speaking, and working

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the Apostles: which Holy Ghost, was a Comforter that came not of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: himselfe; but was sent, and proceeded from them both.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: A Multitude Of Men, How One Person

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: A Multitude of men, are made One Person, when they are by one man, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: one Person, Represented; so that it be done with the consent of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: every one of that Multitude in particular. For it is the Unity of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Representer, not the Unity of the Represented, that maketh the Person

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: One. And it is the Representer that beareth the Person, and but one

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Person: And Unity, cannot otherwise be understood in Multitude.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Every One Is Author

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And because the Multitude naturally is not One, but Many; they cannot

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be understood for one; but many Authors, of every thing their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Representative faith, or doth in their name; Every man giving their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: common Representer, Authority from himselfe in particular; and owning

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all the actions the Representer doth, in case they give him Authority

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: without stint: Otherwise, when they limit him in what, and how farre

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he shall represent them, none of them owneth more, than they gave him

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: commission to Act.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: An Actor May Be Many Men Made One By Plurality Of Voyces

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And if the Representative consist of many men, the voyce of the greater

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: number, must be considered as the voyce of them all. For if the lesser

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: number pronounce (for example) in the Affirmative, and the greater in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Negative, there will be Negatives more than enough to destroy

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Affirmatives; and thereby the excesse of Negatives, standing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: uncontradicted, are the onely voyce the Representative hath.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Representatives, When The Number Is Even, Unprofitable

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And a Representative of even number, especially when the number is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not great, whereby the contradictory voyces are oftentimes equall, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore oftentimes mute, and uncapable of Action. Yet in some cases

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: contradictory voyces equall in number, may determine a question; as in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: condemning, or absolving, equality of votes, even in that they condemne

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not, do absolve; but not on the contrary condemne, in that they absolve

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not. For when a Cause is heard; not to condemne, is to absolve; but on

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the contrary, to say that not absolving, is condemning, is not true. The

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: like it is in a deliberation of executing presently, or deferring

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: till another time; For when the voyces are equall, the not decreeing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Execution, is a decree of Dilation.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Negative Voyce

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Or if the number be odde, as three, or more, (men, or assemblies;)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whereof every one has by a Negative Voice, authority to take away the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: effect of all the Affirmative Voices of the rest, This number is no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Representative; because by the diversity of Opinions, and Interests of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: men, it becomes oftentimes, and in cases of the greatest consequence, a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: mute Person, and unapt, as for may things else, so for the government of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Multitude, especially in time of Warre.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of Authors there be two sorts. The first simply so called; which I have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: before defined to be him, that owneth the Action of another simply.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The second is he, that owneth an Action, or Covenant of another

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: conditionally; that is to say, he undertaketh to do it, if the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other doth it not, at, or before a certain time. And these Authors

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: conditionall, are generally called SURETYES, in Latine Fidejussores, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sponsores; and particularly for Debt, Praedes; and for Appearance before

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Judge, or Magistrate, Vades.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: PART II. OF COMMON-WEALTH

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CHAPTER XVII. OF THE CAUSES, GENERATION, AND DEFINITION OF A

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: COMMON-WEALTH

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The End Of Common-wealth, Particular Security

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The finall Cause, End, or Designe of men, (who naturally love Liberty,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Dominion over others,) in the introduction of that restraint upon

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: themselves, (in which wee see them live in Common-wealths,) is the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: foresight of their own preservation, and of a more contented life

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thereby; that is to say, of getting themselves out from that miserable

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: condition of Warre, which is necessarily consequent (as hath been shewn)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to the naturall Passions of men, when there is no visible Power to keep

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them in awe, and tye them by feare of punishment to the performance of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their Covenants, and observation of these Lawes of Nature set down in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the fourteenth and fifteenth Chapters.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Which Is Not To Be Had From The Law Of Nature:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For the Lawes of Nature (as Justice, Equity, Modesty, Mercy, and (in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: summe) Doing To Others, As Wee Would Be Done To,) if themselves, without

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the terrour of some Power, to cause them to be observed, are contrary to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: our naturall Passions, that carry us to Partiality, Pride, Revenge, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the like. And Covenants, without the Sword, are but Words, and of no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: strength to secure a man at all. Therefore notwithstanding the Lawes of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nature, (which every one hath then kept, when he has the will to keep

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them, when he can do it safely,) if there be no Power erected, or not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: great enough for our security; every man will and may lawfully rely on

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his own strength and art, for caution against all other men. And in all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: places, where men have lived by small Families, to robbe and spoyle one

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: another, has been a Trade, and so farre from being reputed against the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Law of Nature, that the greater spoyles they gained, the greater was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their honour; and men observed no other Lawes therein, but the Lawes of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Honour; that is, to abstain from cruelty, leaving to men their lives,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and instruments of husbandry. And as small Familyes did then; so now

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: do Cities and Kingdomes which are but greater Families (for their own

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: security) enlarge their Dominions, upon all pretences of danger, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: fear of Invasion, or assistance that may be given to Invaders, endeavour

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as much as they can, to subdue, or weaken their neighbours, by open

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: force, and secret arts, for want of other Caution, justly; and are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: rememdbred for it in after ages with honour.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nor From The Conjunction Of A Few Men Or Familyes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nor is it the joyning together of a small number of men, that gives them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: this security; because in small numbers, small additions on the one side

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or the other, make the advantage of strength so great, as is sufficient

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to carry the Victory; and therefore gives encouragement to an Invasion.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Multitude sufficient to confide in for our Security, is not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: determined by any certain number, but by comparison with the Enemy we

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: feare; and is then sufficient, when the odds of the Enemy is not of so

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: visible and conspicuous moment, to determine the event of warre, as to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: move him to attempt.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nor From A Great Multitude, Unlesse Directed By One Judgement

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And be there never so great a Multitude; yet if their actions be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: directed according to their particular judgements, and particular

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: appetites, they can expect thereby no defence, nor protection, neither

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: against a Common enemy, nor against the injuries of one another. For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: being distracted in opinions concerning the best use and application

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of their strength, they do not help, but hinder one another; and reduce

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their strength by mutuall opposition to nothing: whereby they are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: easily, not onely subdued by a very few that agree together; but also

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: when there is no common enemy, they make warre upon each other, for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their particular interests. For if we could suppose a great Multitude of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: men to consent in the observation of Justice, and other Lawes of Nature,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: without a common Power to keep them all in awe; we might as well suppose

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all Man-kind to do the same; and then there neither would be nor need to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be any Civill Government, or Common-wealth at all; because there would

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be Peace without subjection.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And That Continually

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nor is it enough for the security, which men desire should last all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the time of their life, that they be governed, and directed by one

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: judgement, for a limited time; as in one Battell, or one Warre. For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: though they obtain a Victory by their unanimous endeavour against a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: forraign enemy; yet afterwards, when either they have no common enemy,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or he that by one part is held for an enemy, is by another part held for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a friend, they must needs by the difference of their interests dissolve,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and fall again into a Warre amongst themselves.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Why Certain Creatures Without Reason, Or Speech,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Do Neverthelesse Live In Society, Without Any Coercive Power

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: It is true, that certain living creatures, as Bees, and Ants, live

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sociably one with another, (which are therefore by Aristotle numbred

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: amongst Politicall creatures;) and yet have no other direction, than

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their particular judgements and appetites; nor speech, whereby one of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them can signifie to another, what he thinks expedient for the common

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: benefit: and therefore some man may perhaps desire to know, why Man-kind

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: cannot do the same. To which I answer,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: First, that men are continually in competition for Honour and Dignity,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which these creatures are not; and consequently amongst men there

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ariseth on that ground, Envy and Hatred, and finally Warre; but amongst

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: these not so.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Secondly, that amongst these creatures, the Common good differeth not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from the Private; and being by nature enclined to their private, they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: procure thereby the common benefit. But man, whose Joy consisteth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in comparing himselfe with other men, can relish nothing but what is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: eminent.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Thirdly, that these creatures, having not (as man) the use of reason,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: do not see, nor think they see any fault, in the administration of their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: common businesse: whereas amongst men, there are very many, that thinke

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: themselves wiser, and abler to govern the Publique, better than the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: rest; and these strive to reforme and innovate, one this way, another

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that way; and thereby bring it into Distraction and Civill warre.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Fourthly, that these creatures, though they have some use of voice, in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: making knowne to one another their desires, and other affections; yet

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they want that art of words, by which some men can represent to others,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that which is Good, in the likenesse of Evill; and Evill, in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: likenesse of Good; and augment, or diminish the apparent greatnesse of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Good and Evill; discontenting men, and troubling their Peace at their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: pleasure.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Fiftly, irrationall creatures cannot distinguish betweene Injury, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Dammage; and therefore as long as they be at ease, they are not offended

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with their fellowes: whereas Man is then most troublesome, when he is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: most at ease: for then it is that he loves to shew his Wisdome, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: controule the Actions of them that governe the Common-wealth.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lastly, the agreement of these creatures is Naturall; that of men, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by Covenant only, which is Artificiall: and therefore it is no wonder

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: if there be somewhat else required (besides Covenant) to make their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Agreement constant and lasting; which is a Common Power, to keep them in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: awe, and to direct their actions to the Common Benefit.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Generation Of A Common-wealth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The only way to erect such a Common Power, as may be able to defend them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from the invasion of Forraigners, and the injuries of one another, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thereby to secure them in such sort, as that by their owne industrie,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and by the fruites of the Earth, they may nourish themselves and live

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: contentedly; is, to conferre all their power and strength upon one

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Man, or upon one Assembly of men, that may reduce all their Wills,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by plurality of voices, unto one Will: which is as much as to say, to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: appoint one man, or Assembly of men, to beare their Person; and every

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: one to owne, and acknowledge himselfe to be Author of whatsoever he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that so beareth their Person, shall Act, or cause to be Acted, in those

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: things which concerne the Common Peace and Safetie; and therein to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: submit their Wills, every one to his Will, and their Judgements, to his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Judgment. This is more than Consent, or Concord; it is a reall Unitie of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them all, in one and the same Person, made by Covenant of every man with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: every man, in such manner, as if every man should say to every man, "I

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Authorise and give up my Right of Governing my selfe, to this Man, or to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: this Assembly of men, on this condition, that thou give up thy Right

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to him, and Authorise all his Actions in like manner." This done, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Multitude so united in one Person, is called a COMMON-WEALTH, in latine

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CIVITAS. This is the Generation of that great LEVIATHAN, or rather (to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: speake more reverently) of that Mortall God, to which wee owe under the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Immortall God, our peace and defence. For by this Authoritie, given him

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by every particular man in the Common-Wealth, he hath the use of so

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: much Power and Strength conferred on him, that by terror thereof, he is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: inabled to forme the wills of them all, to Peace at home, and mutuall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ayd against their enemies abroad.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Definition Of A Common-wealth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And in him consisteth the Essence of the Common-wealth; which (to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: define it,) is "One Person, of whose Acts a great Multitude, by mutuall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Covenants one with another, have made themselves every one the Author,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to the end he may use the strength and means of them all, as he shall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: think expedient, for their Peace and Common Defence."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraigne, And Subject, What

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And he that carryeth this Person, as called SOVERAIGNE, and said to have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraigne Power; and every one besides, his SUBJECT.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The attaining to this Soveraigne Power, is by two wayes. One, by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Naturall force; as when a man maketh his children, to submit themselves,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and their children to his government, as being able to destroy them if

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they refuse, or by Warre subdueth his enemies to his will, giving them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their lives on that condition. The other, is when men agree amongst

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: themselves, to submit to some Man, or Assembly of men, voluntarily, on

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: confidence to be protected by him against all others. This later, may be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: called a Politicall Common-wealth, or Common-wealth by Institution; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the former, a Common-wealth by Acquisition. And first, I shall speak of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Common-wealth by Institution.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CHAPTER XVIII. OF THE RIGHTS OF SOVERAIGNES BY INSTITUTION

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Act Of Instituting A Common-wealth, What

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: A Common-wealth is said to be Instituted, when a Multitude of men do

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Agree, and Covenant, Every One With Every One, that to whatsoever Man,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or Assembly Of Men, shall be given by the major part, the Right

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to Present the Person of them all, (that is to say, to be their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Representative;) every one, as well he that Voted For It, as he that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Voted Against It, shall Authorise all the Actions and Judgements, of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that Man, or Assembly of men, in the same manner, as if they were his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: own, to the end, to live peaceably amongst themselves, and be protected

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: against other men.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Consequences To Such Institution, Are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: I. The Subjects Cannot Change The Forme Of Government

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: From this Institution of a Common-wealth are derived all the Rights, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Facultyes of him, or them, on whom the Soveraigne Power is conferred by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the consent of the People assembled.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: First, because they Covenant, it is to be understood, they are not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: obliged by former Covenant to any thing repugnant hereunto. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Consequently they that have already Instituted a Common-wealth, being

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thereby bound by Covenant, to own the Actions, and Judgements of one,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: cannot lawfully make a new Covenant, amongst themselves, to be obedient

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to any other, in any thing whatsoever, without his permission. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore, they that are subjects to a Monarch, cannot without his leave

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: cast off Monarchy, and return to the confusion of a disunited Multitude;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: nor transferre their Person from him that beareth it, to another Man,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or other Assembly of men: for they are bound, every man to every man,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to Own, and be reputed Author of all, that he that already is their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraigne, shall do, and judge fit to be done: so that any one man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: dissenting, all the rest should break their Covenant made to that man,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which is injustice: and they have also every man given the Soveraignty

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to him that beareth their Person; and therefore if they depose him,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they take from him that which is his own, and so again it is injustice.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Besides, if he that attempteth to depose his Soveraign, be killed, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: punished by him for such attempt, he is author of his own punishment,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as being by the Institution, Author of all his Soveraign shall do: And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: because it is injustice for a man to do any thing, for which he may be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: punished by his own authority, he is also upon that title, unjust.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And whereas some men have pretended for their disobedience to their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign, a new Covenant, made, not with men, but with God; this also

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is unjust: for there is no Covenant with God, but by mediation of some

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: body that representeth Gods Person; which none doth but Gods Lieutenant,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: who hath the Soveraignty under God. But this pretence of Covenant with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: God, is so evident a lye, even in the pretenders own consciences, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it is not onely an act of an unjust, but also of a vile, and unmanly

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: disposition.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 2. Soveraigne Power Cannot Be Forfeited

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Secondly, Because the Right of bearing the Person of them all, is given

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to him they make Soveraigne, by Covenant onely of one to another, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not of him to any of them; there can happen no breach of Covenant on the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: part of the Soveraigne; and consequently none of his Subjects, by any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: pretence of forfeiture, can be freed from his Subjection. That he which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is made Soveraigne maketh no Covenant with his Subjects beforehand, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: manifest; because either he must make it with the whole multitude, as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: one party to the Covenant; or he must make a severall Covenant with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: every man. With the whole, as one party, it is impossible; because as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: yet they are not one Person: and if he make so many severall Covenants

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as there be men, those Covenants after he hath the Soveraignty are voyd,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: because what act soever can be pretended by any one of them for breach

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thereof, is the act both of himselfe, and of all the rest, because done

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the Person, and by the Right of every one of them in particular.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Besides, if any one, or more of them, pretend a breach of the Covenant

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: made by the Soveraigne at his Institution; and others, or one other of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his Subjects, or himselfe alone, pretend there was no such breach,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there is in this case, no Judge to decide the controversie: it returns

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore to the Sword again; and every man recovereth the right of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Protecting himselfe by his own strength, contrary to the designe they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: had in the Institution. It is therefore in vain to grant Soveraignty by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: way of precedent Covenant. The opinion that any Monarch receiveth his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Power by Covenant, that is to say on Condition, proceedeth from want

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of understanding this easie truth, that Covenants being but words, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: breath, have no force to oblige, contain, constrain, or protect any man,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but what it has from the publique Sword; that is, from the untyed hands

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of that Man, or Assembly of men that hath the Soveraignty, and whose

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: actions are avouched by them all, and performed by the strength of them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all, in him united. But when an Assembly of men is made Soveraigne; then

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: no man imagineth any such Covenant to have past in the Institution; for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: no man is so dull as to say, for example, the People of Rome, made

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Covenant with the Romans, to hold the Soveraignty on such or such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: conditions; which not performed, the Romans might lawfully depose the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Roman People. That men see not the reason to be alike in a Monarchy, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in a Popular Government, proceedeth from the ambition of some, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are kinder to the government of an Assembly, whereof they may hope to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: participate, than of Monarchy, which they despair to enjoy.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 3. No Man Can Without Injustice Protest Against The

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Institution Of The Soveraigne Declared By The Major Part. Thirdly,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: because the major part hath by consenting voices declared a Soveraigne;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he that dissented must now consent with the rest; that is, be contented

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to avow all the actions he shall do, or else justly be destroyed by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: rest. For if he voluntarily entered into the Congregation of them that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: were assembled, he sufficiently declared thereby his will (and therefore

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: tacitely covenanted) to stand to what the major part should ordayne: and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore if he refuse to stand thereto, or make Protestation against

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: any of their Decrees, he does contrary to his Covenant, and therfore

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: unjustly. And whether he be of the Congregation, or not; and whether his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consent be asked, or not, he must either submit to their decrees, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be left in the condition of warre he was in before; wherein he might

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: without injustice be destroyed by any man whatsoever.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 4. The Soveraigns Actions Cannot Be Justly Accused By The Subject

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Fourthly, because every Subject is by this Institution Author of all the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Actions, and Judgements of the Soveraigne Instituted; it followes, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whatsoever he doth, it can be no injury to any of his Subjects; nor

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ought he to be by any of them accused of Injustice. For he that doth any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thing by authority from another, doth therein no injury to him by whose

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: authority he acteth: But by this Institution of a Common-wealth, every

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: particular man is Author of all the Soveraigne doth; and consequently

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he that complaineth of injury from his Soveraigne, complaineth of that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whereof he himselfe is Author; and therefore ought not to accuse any man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but himselfe; no nor himselfe of injury; because to do injury to ones

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: selfe, is impossible. It is true that they that have Soveraigne

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: power, may commit Iniquity; but not Injustice, or Injury in the proper

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: signification.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 5. What Soever The Soveraigne Doth, Is Unpunishable By The Subject

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Fiftly, and consequently to that which was sayd last, no man that hath

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraigne power can justly be put to death, or otherwise in any manner

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by his Subjects punished. For seeing every Subject is author of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: actions of his Soveraigne; he punisheth another, for the actions

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: committed by himselfe.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 6. The Soveraigne Is Judge Of What Is Necessary For The Peace

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And Defence Of His Subjects

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And because the End of this Institution, is the Peace and Defence of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them all; and whosoever has right to the End, has right to the Means;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it belongeth of Right, to whatsoever Man, or Assembly that hath the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraignty, to be Judge both of the meanes of Peace and Defence;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and also of the hindrances, and disturbances of the same; and to do

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whatsoever he shall think necessary to be done, both beforehand, for the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: preserving of Peace and Security, by prevention of discord at home and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Hostility from abroad; and, when Peace and Security are lost, for the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: recovery of the same. And therefore,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And Judge Of What Doctrines Are Fit To Be Taught Them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sixtly, it is annexed to the Soveraignty, to be Judge of what Opinions

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Doctrines are averse, and what conducing to Peace; and consequently,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: on what occasions, how farre, and what, men are to be trusted withall,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in speaking to Multitudes of people; and who shall examine the Doctrines

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of all bookes before they be published. For the Actions of men proceed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from their Opinions; and in the wel governing of Opinions, consisteth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the well governing of mens Actions, in order to their Peace, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Concord. And though in matter of Doctrine, nothing ought to be regarded

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but the Truth; yet this is not repugnant to regulating of the same by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Peace. For Doctrine Repugnant to Peace, can no more be True, than Peace

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Concord can be against the Law of Nature. It is true, that in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Common-wealth, where by the negligence, or unskilfullnesse of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Governours, and Teachers, false Doctrines are by time generally

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: received; the contrary Truths may be generally offensive; Yet the most

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sudden, and rough busling in of a new Truth, that can be, does never

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: breake the Peace, but onely somtimes awake the Warre. For those men that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are so remissely governed, that they dare take up Armes, to defend, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: introduce an Opinion, are still in Warre; and their condition not Peace,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but only a Cessation of Armes for feare of one another; and they live

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as it were, in the procincts of battaile continually. It belongeth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore to him that hath the Soveraign Power, to be Judge, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: constitute all Judges of Opinions and Doctrines, as a thing necessary to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Peace, thereby to prevent Discord and Civill Warre.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 7. The Right Of Making Rules, Whereby The Subject May

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Every Man Know What Is So His Owne, As No Other Subject

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Can Without Injustice Take It From Him

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Seventhly, is annexed to the Soveraigntie, the whole power of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: prescribing the Rules, whereby every man may know, what Goods he may

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: enjoy and what Actions he may doe, without being molested by any of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his fellow Subjects: And this is it men Call Propriety. For before

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: constitution of Soveraign Power (as hath already been shewn) all men had

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: right to all things; which necessarily causeth Warre: and therefore this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Proprietie, being necessary to Peace, and depending on Soveraign Power,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is the Act of the Power, in order to the publique peace. These Rules of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Propriety (or Meum and Tuum) and of Good, Evill, Lawfull and Unlawfull

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the actions of subjects, are the Civill Lawes, that is to say, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: lawes of each Commonwealth in particular; though the name of Civill Law

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be now restrained to the antient Civill Lawes of the City of Rome; which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: being the head of a great part of the World, her Lawes at that time were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in these parts the Civill Law.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 8. To Him Also Belongeth The Right Of All Judicature

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And Decision Of Controversies:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Eightly, is annexed to the Soveraigntie, the Right of Judicature; that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is to say, of hearing and deciding all Controversies, which may arise

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: concerning Law, either Civill, or naturall, or concerning Fact. For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: without the decision of Controversies, there is no protection of one

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Subject, against the injuries of another; the Lawes concerning Meum and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Tuum are in vaine; and to every man remaineth, from the naturall and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: necessary appetite of his own conservation, the right of protecting

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: himselfe by his private strength, which is the condition of Warre; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: contrary to the end for which every Common-wealth is instituted.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 9. And Of Making War, And Peace, As He Shall Think Best:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ninthly, is annexed to the Soveraignty, the Right of making Warre, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Peace with other Nations, and Common-wealths; that is to say, of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Judging when it is for the publique good, and how great forces are to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be assembled, armed, and payd for that end; and to levy mony upon the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Subjects, to defray the expenses thereof. For the Power by which the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: people are to be defended, consisteth in their Armies; and the strength

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of an Army, in the union of their strength under one Command; which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Command the Soveraign Instituted, therefore hath; because the command

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Militia, without other Institution, maketh him that hath it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign. And therefore whosoever is made Generall of an Army, he that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hath the Soveraign Power is alwayes Generallissimo.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 10. And Of Choosing All Counsellours, And Ministers,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Both Of Peace, And Warre:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Tenthly, is annexed to the Soveraignty, the choosing of all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Councellours, Ministers, Magistrates, and Officers, both in peace, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: War. For seeing the Soveraign is charged with the End, which is the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: common Peace and Defence; he is understood to have Power to use such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Means, as he shall think most fit for his discharge.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 11. And Of Rewarding, And Punishing, And That (Where No

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Former Law hath Determined The Measure Of It) Arbitrary:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Eleventhly, to the Soveraign is committed the Power of Rewarding

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with riches, or honour; and of Punishing with corporall, or pecuniary

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: punishment, or with ignominy every Subject according to the Lawe he hath

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: formerly made; or if there be no Law made, according as he shall judge

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: most to conduce to the encouraging of men to serve the Common-wealth, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: deterring of them from doing dis-service to the same.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 12. And Of Honour And Order

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lastly, considering what values men are naturally apt to set upon

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: themselves; what respect they look for from others; and how little they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: value other men; from whence continually arise amongst them, Emulation,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Quarrells, Factions, and at last Warre, to the destroying of one

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: another, and diminution of their strength against a Common Enemy; It

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is necessary that there be Lawes of Honour, and a publique rate of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: worth of such men as have deserved, or are able to deserve well of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth; and that there be force in the hands of some or other, to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: put those Lawes in execution. But it hath already been shown, that not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: onely the whole Militia, or forces of the Common-wealth; but also the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Judicature of all Controversies, is annexed to the Soveraignty. To the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign therefore it belongeth also to give titles of Honour; and to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: appoint what Order of place, and dignity, each man shall hold; and what

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: signes of respect, in publique or private meetings, they shall give to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: one another.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: These Rights Are Indivisible

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: These are the Rights, which make the Essence of Soveraignty; and which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are the markes, whereby a man may discern in what Man, or Assembly

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of men, the Soveraign Power is placed, and resideth. For these are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: incommunicable, and inseparable. The Power to coyn Mony; to dispose of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the estate and persons of Infant heires; to have praeemption in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Markets; and all other Statute Praerogatives, may be transferred by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign; and yet the Power to protect his Subject be retained. But if

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he transferre the Militia, he retains the Judicature in vain, for want

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of execution of the Lawes; Or if he grant away the Power of raising

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Mony; the Militia is in vain: or if he give away the government of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: doctrines, men will be frighted into rebellion with the feare of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Spirits. And so if we consider any one of the said Rights, we shall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: presently see, that the holding of all the rest, will produce no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: effect, in the conservation of Peace and Justice, the end for which all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealths are Instituted. And this division is it, whereof it is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: said, "A kingdome divided in it selfe cannot stand:" For unlesse this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: division precede, division into opposite Armies can never happen. If

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there had not first been an opinion received of the greatest part of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: England, that these Powers were divided between the King, and the Lords,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and the House of Commons, the people had never been divided, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: fallen into this Civill Warre; first between those that disagreed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in Politiques; and after between the Dissenters about the liberty of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Religion; which have so instructed men in this point of Soveraign Right,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that there be few now (in England,) that do not see, that these Rights

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are inseparable, and will be so generally acknowledged, at the next

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: return of Peace; and so continue, till their miseries are forgotten; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: no longer, except the vulgar be better taught than they have hetherto

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: been.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And Can By No Grant Passe Away Without Direct

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Renouncing Of The Soveraign Power

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And because they are essentiall and inseparable Rights, it follows

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: necessarily, that in whatsoever, words any of them seem to be granted

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: away, yet if the Soveraign Power it selfe be not in direct termes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: renounced, and the name of Soveraign no more given by the Grantees to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him that Grants them, the Grant is voyd: for when he has granted all he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: can, if we grant back the Soveraignty, all is restored, as inseparably

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: annexed thereunto.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Power And Honour Of Subjects Vanisheth In The Presence

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of The Power Soveraign

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: This great Authority being indivisible, and inseparably annexed to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraignty, there is little ground for the opinion of them, that say of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign Kings, though they be Singulis Majores, of greater Power than

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: every one of their Subjects, yet they be Universis Minores, of lesse

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: power than them all together. For if by All Together, they mean not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the collective body as one person, then All Together, and Every One,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: signifie the same; and the speech is absurd. But if by All Together,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they understand them as one Person (which person the Soveraign bears,)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: then the power of all together, is the same with the Soveraigns power;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and so again the speech is absurd; which absurdity they see well enough,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: when the Soveraignty is in an Assembly of the people; but in a Monarch

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they see it not; and yet the power of Soveraignty is the same in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whomsoever it be placed.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And as the Power, so also the Honour of the Soveraign, ought to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: greater, than that of any, or all the Subjects. For in the Soveraignty

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is the fountain of Honour. The dignities of Lord, Earle, Duke, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Prince are his Creatures. As in the presence of the Master, the Servants

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are equall, and without any honour at all; So are the Subjects, in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: presence of the Soveraign. And though they shine some more, some lesse,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: when they are out of his sight; yet in his presence, they shine no more

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: than the Starres in presence of the Sun.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraigne Power Not Hurtfull As The Want Of It,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And The Hurt Proceeds For The Greatest Part From Not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Submitting Readily, To A Lesse

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But a man may here object, that the Condition of Subjects is very

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: miserable; as being obnoxious to the lusts, and other irregular passions

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of him, or them that have so unlimited a Power in their hands. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: commonly they that live under a Monarch, think it the fault of Monarchy;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and they that live under the government of Democracy, or other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign Assembly, attribute all the inconvenience to that forme of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth; whereas the Power in all formes, if they be perfect

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: enough to protect them, is the same; not considering that the estate

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Man can never be without some incommodity or other; and that the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: greatest, that in any forme of Government can possibly happen to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: people in generall, is scarce sensible, in respect of the miseries, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: horrible calamities, that accompany a Civill Warre; or that dissolute

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: condition of masterlesse men, without subjection to Lawes, and a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: coercive Power to tye their hands from rapine, and revenge: nor

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: considering that the greatest pressure of Soveraign Governours,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: proceedeth not from any delight, or profit they can expect in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: dammage, or weakening of their subjects, in whose vigor, consisteth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their own selves, that unwillingly contributing to their own defence,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: make it necessary for their Governours to draw from them what they can

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in time of Peace, that they may have means on any emergent occasion, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sudden need, to resist, or take advantage on their Enemies. For all men

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are by nature provided of notable multiplying glasses, (that is their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Passions and Self-love,) through which, every little payment appeareth a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: great grievance; but are destitute of those prospective glasses, (namely

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Morall and Civill Science,) to see a farre off the miseries that hang

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: over them, and cannot without such payments be avoyded.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CHAPTER XIX. OF THE SEVERALL KINDS OF COMMON-WEALTH BY INSTITUTION,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: AND OF SUCCESSION TO THE SOVERAIGNE POWER

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Different Formes Of Common-wealths But Three

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The difference of Common-wealths, consisteth in the difference of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign, or the Person representative of all and every one of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Multitude. And because the Soveraignty is either in one Man, or in an

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Assembly of more than one; and into that Assembly either Every man hath

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: right to enter, or not every one, but Certain men distinguished from the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: rest; it is manifest, there can be but Three kinds of Common-wealth. For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Representative must needs be One man, or More: and if more, then it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is the Assembly of All, or but of a Part. When the Representative is One

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man, then is the Common-wealth a MONARCHY: when an Assembly of All that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: will come together, then it is a DEMOCRACY, or Popular Common-wealth:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: when an Assembly of a Part onely, then it is called an ARISTOCRACY.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Other kind of Common-wealth there can be none: for either One, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: More, or All must have the Soveraign Power (which I have shewn to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: indivisible) entire.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Tyranny And Oligarchy, But Different Names Of Monarchy, And Aristocracy

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: There be other names of Government, in the Histories, and books of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Policy; as Tyranny, and Oligarchy: But they are not the names of other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Formes of Government, but of the same Formes misliked. For they that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are discontented under Monarchy, call it Tyranny; and they that are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: displeased with Aristocracy, called it Oligarchy: so also, they which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: find themselves grieved under a Democracy, call it Anarchy, (which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: signifies want of Government;) and yet I think no man believes, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: want of Government, is any new kind of Government: nor by the same

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: reason ought they to believe, that the Government is of one kind, when

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they like it, and another, when they mislike it, or are oppressed by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Governours.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Subordinate Representatives Dangerous

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: It is manifest, that men who are in absolute liberty, may, if they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: please, give Authority to One Man, to represent them every one; as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: well as give such Authority to any Assembly of men whatsoever; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consequently may subject themselves, if they think good, to a Monarch,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as absolutely, as to any other Representative. Therefore, where there is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: already erected a Soveraign Power, there can be no other Representative

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the same people, but onely to certain particular ends, by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign limited. For that were to erect two Soveraigns; and every

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man to have his person represented by two Actors, that by opposing one

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: another, must needs divide that Power, which (if men will live in Peace)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is indivisible, and thereby reduce the Multitude into the condition of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Warre, contrary to the end for which all Soveraignty is instituted. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore as it is absurd, to think that a Soveraign Assembly, inviting

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the People of their Dominion, to send up their Deputies, with power

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to make known their Advise, or Desires, should therefore hold such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Deputies, rather than themselves, for the absolute Representative of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the people: so it is absurd also, to think the same in a Monarchy. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: I know not how this so manifest a truth, should of late be so little

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: observed; that in a Monarchy, he that had the Soveraignty from a descent

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of 600 years, was alone called Soveraign, had the title of Majesty from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: every one of his Subjects, and was unquestionably taken by them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for their King; was notwithstanding never considered as their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Representative; that name without contradiction passing for the title

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of those men, which at his command were sent up by the people to carry

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their Petitions, and give him (if he permitted it) their advise. Which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: may serve as an admonition, for those that are the true, and absolute

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Representative of a People, to instruct men in the nature of that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Office, and to take heed how they admit of any other generall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Representation upon any occasion whatsoever, if they mean to discharge

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the truth committed to them.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Comparison Of Monarchy, With Soveraign Assemblyes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The difference between these three kindes of Common-wealth, consisteth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not in the difference of Power; but in the difference of Convenience, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Aptitude to produce the Peace, and Security of the people; for which end

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they were instituted. And to compare Monarchy with the other two, we may

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: observe; First, that whosoever beareth the Person of the people, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is one of that Assembly that bears it, beareth also his own naturall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Person. And though he be carefull in his politique Person to procure

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the common interest; yet he is more, or no lesse carefull to procure the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: private good of himselfe, his family, kindred and friends; and for the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: most part, if the publique interest chance to crosse the private, he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: preferrs the private: for the Passions of men, are commonly more potent

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: than their Reason. From whence it follows, that where the publique and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: private interest are most closely united, there is the publique most

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: advanced. Now in Monarchy, the private interest is the same with the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: publique. The riches, power, and honour of a Monarch arise onely from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the riches, strength and reputation of his Subjects. For no King can

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be rich, nor glorious, nor secure; whose Subjects are either poore, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: contemptible, or too weak through want, or dissention, to maintain a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: war against their enemies: Whereas in a Democracy, or Aristocracy, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: publique prosperity conferres not so much to the private fortune of one

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that is corrupt, or ambitious, as doth many times a perfidious advice, a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: treacherous action, or a Civill warre.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Secondly, that a Monarch receiveth counsell of whom, when, and where he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: pleaseth; and consequently may heare the opinion of men versed in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: matter about which he deliberates, of what rank or quality soever, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as long before the time of action, and with as much secrecy, as he will.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But when a Soveraigne Assembly has need of Counsell, none are admitted

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but such as have a Right thereto from the beginning; which for the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: most part are of those who have beene versed more in the acquisition

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Wealth than of Knowledge; and are to give their advice in long

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: discourses, which may, and do commonly excite men to action, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not governe them in it. For the Understanding is by the flame of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Passions, never enlightned, but dazled: Nor is there any place, or time,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: wherein an Assemblie can receive Counsell with secrecie, because of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their owne Multitude.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Thirdly, that the Resolutions of a Monarch, are subject to no other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Inconstancy, than that of Humane Nature; but in Assemblies, besides that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Nature, there ariseth an Inconstancy from the Number. For the absence

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of a few, that would have the Resolution once taken, continue firme,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (which may happen by security, negligence, or private impediments,) or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the diligent appearance of a few of the contrary opinion, undoes to day,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all that was concluded yesterday.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Fourthly, that a Monarch cannot disagree with himselfe, out of envy, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: interest; but an Assembly may; and that to such a height, as may produce

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Civill Warre.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Fifthly, that in Monarchy there is this inconvenience; that any Subject,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by the power of one man, for the enriching of a favourite or flatterer,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: may be deprived of all he possesseth; which I confesse is a great and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: inevitable inconvenience. But the same may as well happen, where the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraigne Power is in an Assembly: for their power is the same; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they are as subject to evill Counsell, and to be seduced by Orators, as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Monarch by Flatterers; and becoming one an others Flatterers, serve

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: one anothers Covetousnesse and Ambition by turnes. And whereas the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Favorites of an Assembly, are many; and the Kindred much more numerous,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: than of any Monarch. Besides, there is no Favourite of a Monarch, which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: cannot as well succour his friends, as hurt his enemies: But Orators,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that is to say, Favourites of Soveraigne Assemblies, though they have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: great power to hurt, have little to save. For to accuse, requires lesse

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Eloquence (such is mans Nature) than to excuse; and condemnation, than

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: absolution more resembles Justice.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sixtly, that it is an inconvenience in Monarchie, that the Soveraigntie

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: may descend upon an Infant, or one that cannot discerne between Good and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Evill: and consisteth in this, that the use of his Power, must be in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hand of another Man, or of some Assembly of men, which are to governe by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his right, and in his name; as Curators, and Protectors of his Person,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Authority. But to say there is inconvenience, in putting the use of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Soveraign Power, into the hand of a Man, or an Assembly of men; is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to say that all Government is more Inconvenient, than Confusion, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Civill Warre. And therefore all the danger that can be pretended, must

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: arise from the Contention of those, that for an office of so great

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: honour, and profit, may become Competitors. To make it appear, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: this inconvenience, proceedeth not from that forme of Government we call

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Monarchy, we are to consider, that the precedent Monarch, hath appointed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: who shall have the Tuition of his Infant Successor, either expressely

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by Testament, or tacitly, by not controlling the Custome in that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: case received: And then such inconvenience (if it happen) is to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: attributed, not to the Monarchy, but to the Ambition, and Injustice of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Subjects; which in all kinds of Government, where the people are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not well instructed in their Duty, and the Rights of Soveraignty, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the same. Or else the precedent Monarch, hath not at all taken order for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such Tuition; And then the Law of Nature hath provided this sufficient

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: rule, That the Tuition shall be in him, that hath by Nature most

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: interest in the preservation of the Authority of the Infant, and to whom

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: least benefit can accrue by his death, or diminution. For seeing every

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man by nature seeketh his own benefit, and promotion; to put an Infant

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: into the power of those, that can promote themselves by his destruction,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or dammage, is not Tuition, but Trechery. So that sufficient provision

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: being taken, against all just quarrell, about the Government under a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Child, if any contention arise to the disturbance of the publique Peace,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it is not to be attributed to the forme of Monarchy, but to the ambition

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Subjects, and ignorance of their Duty. On the other side, there is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: no great Common-wealth, the Soveraignty whereof is in a great Assembly,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which is not, as to consultations of Peace, and Warre, and making of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lawes, in the same condition, as if the Government were in a Child. For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as a Child wants the judgement to dissent from counsell given him, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is thereby necessitated to take the advise of them, or him, to whom he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is committed: So an Assembly wanteth the liberty, to dissent from the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: counsell of the major part, be it good, or bad. And as a Child has need

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of a Tutor, or Protector, to preserve his Person, and Authority: So also

author: Thomas Hobbes
