text: (in great Common-wealths,) the Soveraign Assembly, in all great dangers

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and troubles, have need of Custodes Libertatis; that is of Dictators, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Protectors of their Authoritie; which are as much as Temporary Monarchs;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to whom for a time, they may commit the entire exercise of their Power;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and have (at the end of that time) been oftner deprived thereof, than

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Infant Kings, by their Protectors, Regents, or any other Tutors.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Though the Kinds of Soveraigntie be, as I have now shewn, but three;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that is to say, Monarchie, where one Man has it; or Democracie, where

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the generall Assembly of Subjects hath it; or Aristocracie, where it is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in an Assembly of certain persons nominated, or otherwise distinguished

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from the rest: Yet he that shall consider the particular Common-wealthes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that have been, and are in the world, will not perhaps easily reduce

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them to three, and may thereby be inclined to think there be other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Formes, arising from these mingled together. As for example, Elective

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kingdomes; where Kings have the Soveraigne Power put into their hands

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for a time; of Kingdomes, wherein the King hath a power limited: which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Governments, are nevertheless by most Writers called Monarchie. Likewise

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: if a Popular, or Aristocraticall Common-wealth, subdue an Enemies

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Countrie, and govern the same, by a President, Procurator, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other Magistrate; this may seeme perhaps at first sight, to be a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Democraticall, or Aristocraticall Government. But it is not so. For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Elective Kings, are not Soveraignes, but Ministers of the Soveraigne;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: nor limited Kings Soveraignes, but Ministers of them that have the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraigne Power: nor are those Provinces which are in subjection to a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Democracie, or Aristocracie of another Common-wealth, Democratically, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Aristocratically governed, but Monarchically.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And first, concerning an Elective King, whose power is limited to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his life, as it is in many places of Christendome at this day; or to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: certaine Yeares or Moneths, as the Dictators power amongst the Romans;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: If he have Right to appoint his Successor, he is no more Elective but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Hereditary. But if he have no Power to elect his Successor, then there

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is some other Man, or Assembly known, which after his decease may elect

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a new, or else the Common-wealth dieth, and dissolveth with him, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: returneth to the condition of Warre. If it be known who have the power

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to give the Soveraigntie after his death, it is known also that the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraigntie was in them before: For none have right to give that which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they have not right to possesse, and keep to themselves, if they think

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: good. But if there be none that can give the Soveraigntie, after the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: decease of him that was first elected; then has he power, nay he is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: obliged by the Law of Nature, to provide, by establishing his Successor,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to keep those that had trusted him with the Government, from relapsing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: into the miserable condition of Civill warre. And consequently he was,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: when elected, a Soveraign absolute.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Secondly, that King whose power is limited, is not superiour to him, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them that have the power to limit it; and he that is not superiour, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not supreme; that is to say not Soveraign. The Soveraignty therefore

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was alwaies in that Assembly which had the Right to Limit him; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by consequence the government not Monarchy, but either Democracy, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Aristocracy; as of old time in Sparta; where the Kings had a priviledge

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to lead their Armies; but the Soveraignty was in the Ephori.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Thirdly, whereas heretofore the Roman People, governed the land of Judea

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (for example) by a President; yet was not Judea therefore a Democracy;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: because they were not governed by any Assembly, into which, any of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them, had right to enter; nor by an Aristocracy; because they were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not governed by any Assembly, into which, any man could enter by their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Election: but they were governed by one Person, which though as to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: people of Rome was an Assembly of the people, or Democracy; yet as to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the people of Judea, which had no right at all of participating in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: government, was a Monarch. For though where the people are governed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by an Assembly, chosen by themselves out of their own number, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: government is called a Democracy, or Aristocracy; yet when they are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: governed by an Assembly, not of their own choosing, 'tis a Monarchy; not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of One man, over another man; but of one people, over another people.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of The Right Of Succession

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of all these Formes of Government, the matter being mortall, so that not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: onely Monarchs, but also whole Assemblies dy, it is necessary for the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: conservation of the peace of men, that as there was order taken for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: an Artificiall Man, so there be order also taken, for an Artificiall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Eternity of life; without which, men that are governed by an Assembly,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: should return into the condition of Warre in every age; and they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that are governed by One man, as soon as their Governour dyeth. This

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Artificiall Eternity, is that which men call the Right of Succession.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: There is no perfect forme of Government, where the disposing of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Succession is not in the present Soveraign. For if it be in any other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: particular Man, or private Assembly, it is in a person subject, and may

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be assumed by the Soveraign at his pleasure; and consequently the Right

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is in himselfe. And if it be in no particular man, but left to a new

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: choyce; then is the Common-wealth dissolved; and the Right is in him

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that can get it; contrary to the intention of them that did institute

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Common-wealth, for their perpetuall, and not temporary security.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In a Democracy, the whole Assembly cannot faile, unlesse the Multitude

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that are to be governed faile. And therefore questions of the right of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Succession, have in that forme of Government no place at all.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In an Aristocracy, when any of the Assembly dyeth, the election of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: another into his room belongeth to the Assembly, as the Soveraign, to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whom belongeth the choosing of all Counsellours, and Officers. For that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which the Representative doth, as Actor, every one of the Subjects doth,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as Author. And though the Soveraign assembly, may give Power to others,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to elect new men, for supply of their Court; yet it is still by their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Authority, that the Election is made; and by the same it may (when the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: publique shall require it) be recalled.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Present Monarch Hath Right To Dispose Of The Succession The greatest

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: difficultie about the right of Succession, is in Monarchy: And the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: difficulty ariseth from this, that at first sight, it is not manifest

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: who is to appoint the Successor; nor many times, who it is whom he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hath appointed. For in both these cases, there is required a more exact

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ratiocination, than every man is accustomed to use. As to the question,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: who shall appoint the Successor, of a Monarch that hath the Soveraign

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Authority; that is to say, (for Elective Kings and Princes have not the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign Power in propriety, but in use only,) we are to consider, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: either he that is in possession, has right to dispose of the Succession,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or else that right is again in the dissolved Multitude. For the death

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of him that hath the Soveraign power in propriety, leaves the Multitude

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: without any Soveraign at all; that is, without any Representative in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whom they should be united, and be capable of doing any one action at

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all: And therefore they are incapable of Election of any new Monarch;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: every man having equall right to submit himselfe to such as he thinks

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: best able to protect him, or if he can, protect himselfe by his owne

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sword; which is a returne to Confusion, and to the condition of a War of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: every man against every man, contrary to the end for which Monarchy had

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: its first Institution. Therfore it is manifest, that by the Institution

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Monarchy, the disposing of the Successor, is alwaies left to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Judgment and Will of the present Possessor.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And for the question (which may arise sometimes) who it is that the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Monarch in possession, hath designed to the succession and inheritance

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of his power; it is determined by his expresse Words, and Testament; or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by other tacite signes sufficient.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Succession Passeth By Expresse Words;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: By expresse Words, or Testament, when it is declared by him in his life

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: time, viva voce, or by Writing; as the first Emperours of Rome declared

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: who should be their Heires. For the word Heire does not of it selfe

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: imply the Children, or nearest Kindred of a man; but whomsoever a man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shall any way declare, he would have to succeed him in his Estate.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: If therefore a Monarch declare expresly, that such a man shall be his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Heire, either by Word or Writing, then is that man immediately after the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: decease of his Predecessor, Invested in the right of being Monarch.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Or, By Not Controlling A Custome;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But where Testament, and expresse Words are wanting, other naturall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: signes of the Will are to be followed: whereof the one is Custome. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore where the Custome is, that the next of Kindred absolutely

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: succeedeth, there also the next of Kindred hath right to the Succession;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for that, if the will of him that was in posession had been otherwise,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he might easily have declared the same in his life time. And likewise

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: where the Custome is, that the next of the Male Kindred succeedeth,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there also the right of Succession is in the next of the Kindred Male,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for the same reason. And so it is if the Custome were to advance the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Female. For whatsoever Custome a man may by a word controule, and does

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not, it is a naturall signe he would have that Custome stand.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Or, By Presumption Of Naturall Affection

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But where neither Custome, nor Testament hath preceded, there it is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to be understood, First, that a Monarchs will is, that the government

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: remain Monarchicall; because he hath approved that government in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: himselfe. Secondly, that a Child of his own, Male, or Female, be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: preferred before any other; because men are presumed to be more enclined

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by nature, to advance their own children, than the children of other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: men; and of their own, rather a Male than a Female; because men, are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: naturally fitter than women, for actions of labour and danger. Thirdly,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: where his own Issue faileth, rather a Brother than a stranger; and so

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: still the neerer in bloud, rather than the more remote, because it is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: alwayes presumed that the neerer of kin, is the neerer in affection; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 'tis evident that a man receives alwayes, by reflexion, the most honour

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from the greatnesse of his neerest kindred.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To Dispose Of The Succession, Though To A King Of Another Nation,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Not Unlawfull

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But if it be lawfull for a Monarch to dispose of the Succession by words

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Contract, or Testament, men may perhaps object a great inconvenience:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for he may sell, or give his Right of governing to a stranger; which,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: because strangers (that is, men not used to live under the same

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: government, not speaking the same language) do commonly undervalue one

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: another, may turn to the oppression of his Subjects; which is indeed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a great inconvenience; but it proceedeth not necessarily from the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: subjection to a strangers government, but from the unskilfulnesse of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Governours, ignorant of the true rules of Politiques. And therefore

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Romans when they had subdued many Nations, to make their Government

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: digestible, were wont to take away that grievance, as much as they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thought necessary, by giving sometimes to whole Nations, and sometimes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to Principall men of every Nation they conquered, not onely the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Privileges, but also the Name of Romans; and took many of them into the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Senate, and Offices of charge, even in the Roman City. And this was it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: our most wise King, King James, aymed at, in endeavouring the Union of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his two Realms of England and Scotland. Which if he could have obtained,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: had in all likelihood prevented the Civill warres, which make both those

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kingdomes at this present, miserable. It is not therefore any injury to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the people, for a Monarch to dispose of the Succession by Will; though

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by the fault of many Princes, it hath been sometimes found inconvenient.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of the lawfulnesse of it, this also is an argument, that whatsoever

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: inconvenience can arrive by giving a Kingdome to a stranger, may arrive

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: also by so marrying with strangers, as the Right of Succession may

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: descend upon them: yet this by all men is accounted lawfull.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CHAPTER XX. OF DOMINION PATERNALL AND DESPOTICALL

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: A Common-wealth by Acquisition, is that, where the Soveraign Power is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: acquired by Force; And it is acquired by force, when men singly, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: many together by plurality of voyces, for fear of death, or bonds, do

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: authorise all the actions of that Man, or Assembly, that hath their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: lives and liberty in his Power.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Wherein Different From A Common-wealth By Institution

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And this kind of Dominion, or Soveraignty, differeth from Soveraignty by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Institution, onely in this, That men who choose their Soveraign, do it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for fear of one another, and not of him whom they Institute: But in this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: case, they subject themselves, to him they are afraid of. In both cases

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they do it for fear: which is to be noted by them, that hold all such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Covenants, as proceed from fear of death, or violence, voyd: which if

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it were true, no man, in any kind of Common-wealth, could be obliged

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to Obedience. It is true, that in a Common-wealth once Instituted, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: acquired, Promises proceeding from fear of death, or violence, are no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Covenants, nor obliging, when the thing promised is contrary to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lawes; But the reason is not, because it was made upon fear, but because

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he that promiseth, hath no right in the thing promised. Also, when he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: may lawfully performe, and doth not, it is not the Invalidity of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Covenant, that absolveth him, but the Sentence of the Soveraign.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Otherwise, whensoever a man lawfully promiseth, he unlawfully breaketh:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But when the Soveraign, who is the Actor, acquitteth him, then he is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: acquitted by him that exorted the promise, as by the Author of such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: absolution.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Rights Of Soveraignty The Same In Both

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But the Rights, and Consequences of Soveraignty, are the same in both.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: His Power cannot, without his consent, be Transferred to another: He

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: cannot Forfeit it: He cannot be Accused by any of his Subjects, of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Injury: He cannot be Punished by them: He is Judge of what is necessary

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for Peace; and Judge of Doctrines: He is Sole Legislator; and Supreme

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Judge of Controversies; and of the Times, and Occasions of Warre,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Peace: to him it belongeth to choose Magistrates, Counsellours,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Commanders, and all other Officers, and Ministers; and to determine of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Rewards, and punishments, Honour, and Order. The reasons whereof, are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the same which are alledged in the precedent Chapter, for the same

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Rights, and Consequences of Soveraignty by Institution.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Dominion Paternall How Attained Not By Generation, But By Contract

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Dominion is acquired two wayes; By Generation, and by Conquest. The

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: right of Dominion by Generation, is that, which the Parent hath over

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his Children; and is called PATERNALL. And is not so derived from the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Generation, as if therefore the Parent had Dominion over his Child

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: because he begat him; but from the Childs Consent, either expresse, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by other sufficient arguments declared. For as to the Generation, God

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hath ordained to man a helper; and there be alwayes two that are equally

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Parents: the Dominion therefore over the Child, should belong equally to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: both; and he be equally subject to both, which is impossible; for no man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: can obey two Masters. And whereas some have attributed the Dominion to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Man onely, as being of the more excellent Sex; they misreckon in it.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For there is not always that difference of strength or prudence between

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the man and the woman, as that the right can be determined without War.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In Common-wealths, this controversie is decided by the Civill Law: and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for the most part, (but not alwayes) the sentence is in favour of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Father; because for the most part Common-wealths have been erected by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Fathers, not by the Mothers of families. But the question lyeth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: now in the state of meer Nature; where there are supposed no lawes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Matrimony; no lawes for the Education of Children; but the Law of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nature, and the naturall inclination of the Sexes, one to another, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to their children. In this condition of meer Nature, either the Parents

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: between themselves dispose of the dominion over the Child by Contract;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or do not dispose thereof at all. If they dispose thereof, the right

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: passeth according to the Contract. We find in History that the Amazons

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Contracted with the Men of the neighbouring Countries, to whom they had

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: recourse for issue, that the issue Male should be sent back, but the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Female remain with themselves: so that the dominion of the Females was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the Mother.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Or Education;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: If there be no Contract, the Dominion is in the Mother. For in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: condition of Meer Nature, where there are no Matrimoniall lawes, it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: cannot be known who is the Father, unlesse it be declared by the Mother:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and therefore the right of Dominion over the Child dependeth on her

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: will, and is consequently hers. Again, seeing the Infant is first in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: power of the Mother; so as she may either nourish, or expose it, if she

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: nourish it, it oweth its life to the Mother; and is therefore obliged to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: obey her, rather than any other; and by consequence the Dominion over

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it is hers. But if she expose it, and another find, and nourish it, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Dominion is in him that nourisheth it. For it ought to obey him by whom

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it is preserved; because preservation of life being the end, for which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: one man becomes subject to another, every man is supposed to promise

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: obedience, to him, in whose power it is to save, or destroy him.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Or Precedent Subjection Of One Of The Parents To The Other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: If the Mother be the Fathers subject, the Child, is in the Fathers

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: power: and if the Father be the Mothers subject, (as when a Soveraign

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Queen marrieth one of her subjects,) the Child is subject to the Mother;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: because the Father also is her subject.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: If a man and a woman, Monarches of two severall Kingdomes, have a Child,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and contract concerning who shall have the Dominion of him, the Right of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Dominion passeth by the Contract. If they contract not, the Dominion

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: followeth the Dominion of the place of his residence. For the Soveraign

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of each Country hath Dominion over all that reside therein.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: He that hath the Dominion over the Child, hath Dominion also over their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Childrens Children. For he that hath Dominion over the person of a man,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hath Dominion over all that is his; without which, Dominion were but a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Title, without the effect.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Right Of Succession Followeth The Rules Of The Rights Of Possession

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Right of Succession to Paternall dominion, proceedeth in the same

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: manner, as doth the Right of Succession to Monarchy; of which I have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: already sufficiently spoken in the precedent chapter.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Despoticall Dominion, How Attained

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Dominion acquired by Conquest, or Victory in war, is that which some

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Writers call DESPOTICALL, from Despotes, which signifieth a Lord, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Master; and is the Dominion of the Master over his Servant. And this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Dominion is then acquired to the Victor, when the Vanquished, to avoyd

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the present stroke of death, covenanteth either in expresse words, or by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other sufficient signes of the Will, that so long as his life, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the liberty of his body is allowed him, the Victor shall have the use

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thereof, at his pleasure. And after such Covenant made, the Vanquished

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is a SERVANT, and not before: for by the word Servant (whether it be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: derived from Servire, to Serve, or from Servare, to Save, which I leave

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to Grammarians to dispute) is not meant a Captive, which is kept in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: prison, or bonds, till the owner of him that took him, or bought him

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of one that did, shall consider what to do with him: (for such men,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (commonly called Slaves,) have no obligation at all; but may break their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: bonds, or the prison; and kill, or carry away captive their Master,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: justly:) but one, that being taken, hath corporall liberty allowed him;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and upon promise not to run away, nor to do violence to his Master, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: trusted by him.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Not By The Victory, But By The Consent Of The Vanquished

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: It is not therefore the Victory, that giveth the right of Dominion over

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Vanquished, but his own Covenant. Nor is he obliged because he is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Conquered; that is to say, beaten, and taken, or put to flight; but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: because he commeth in, and submitteth to the Victor; Nor is the Victor

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: obliged by an enemies rendring himselfe, (without promise of life,) to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: spare him for this his yeelding to discretion; which obliges not the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Victor longer, than in his own discretion hee shall think fit.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And that men do, when they demand (as it is now called) Quarter, (which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Greeks called Zogria, taking alive,) is to evade the present fury of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Victor, by Submission, and to compound for their life, with Ransome,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or Service: and therefore he that hath Quarter, hath not his life given,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but deferred till farther deliberation; For it is not an yeelding on

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: condition of life, but to discretion. And then onely is his life in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: security, and his service due, when the Victor hath trusted him with his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: corporall liberty. For Slaves that work in Prisons, or Fetters, do it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not of duty, but to avoyd the cruelty of their task-masters.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Master of the Servant, is Master also of all he hath; and may exact

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the use thereof; that is to say, of his goods, of his labour, of his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: servants, and of his children, as often as he shall think fit. For he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: holdeth his life of his Master, by the covenant of obedience; that is,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of owning, and authorising whatsoever the Master shall do. And in case

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Master, if he refuse, kill him, or cast him into bonds, or otherwise

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: punish him for his disobedience, he is himselfe the author of the same;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and cannot accuse him of injury.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In summe the Rights and Consequences of both Paternall and Despoticall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Dominion, are the very same with those of a Soveraign by Institution;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and for the same reasons: which reasons are set down in the precedent

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: chapter. So that for a man that is Monarch of divers Nations, whereof he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hath, in one the Soveraignty by Institution of the people assembled, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in another by Conquest, that is by the Submission of each particular,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to avoyd death or bonds; to demand of one Nation more than of the other,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from the title of Conquest, as being a Conquered Nation, is an act of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ignorance of the Rights of Soveraignty. For the Soveraign is absolute

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: over both alike; or else there is no Soveraignty at all; and so every

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man may Lawfully protect himselfe, if he can, with his own sword, which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is the condition of war.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Difference Between A Family And A Kingdom

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: By this it appears, that a great Family if it be not part of some

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth, is of it self, as to the Rights of Soveraignty, a little

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Monarchy; whether that Family consist of a man and his children; or of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a man and his servants; or of a man, and his children, and servants

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: together: wherein the Father of Master is the Soveraign. But yet a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Family is not properly a Common-wealth; unlesse it be of that power by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: its own number, or by other opportunities, as not to be subdued without

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the hazard of war. For where a number of men are manifestly too weak to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: defend themselves united, every one may use his own reason in time of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: danger, to save his own life, either by flight, or by submission to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the enemy, as hee shall think best; in the same manner as a very small

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: company of souldiers, surprised by an army, may cast down their armes,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and demand quarter, or run away, rather than be put to the sword. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thus much shall suffice; concerning what I find by speculation, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: deduction, of Soveraign Rights, from the nature, need, and designes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of men, in erecting of Commonwealths, and putting themselves under

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Monarchs, or Assemblies, entrusted with power enough for their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: protection.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Right Of Monarchy From Scripture

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Let us now consider what the Scripture teacheth in the same point. To

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Moses, the children of Israel say thus. (Exod. 20. 19) "Speak thou to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: us, and we will heare thee; but let not God speak to us, lest we dye."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: This is absolute obedience to Moses. Concerning the Right of Kings, God

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: himself by the mouth of Samuel, saith, (1 Sam. 8. 11, 12, &c.) "This

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shall be the Right of the King you will have to reigne over you. He

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shall take your sons, and set them to drive his Chariots, and to be his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: horsemen, and to run before his chariots; and gather in his harvest; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to make his engines of War, and Instruments of his chariots; and shall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: take your daughters to make perfumes, to be his Cookes, and Bakers. He

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shall take your fields, your vine-yards, and your olive-yards, and give

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them to his servants. He shall take the tyth of your corne and wine, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: give it to the men of his chamber, and to his other servants. He shall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: take your man-servants, and your maid-servants, and the choice of your

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: youth, and employ them in his businesse. He shall take the tyth of your

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: flocks; and you shall be his servants." This is absolute power, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: summed up in the last words, "you shall be his servants." Againe, when

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the people heard what power their King was to have, yet they consented

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thereto, and say thus, (Verse. 19 &c.) "We will be as all other nations,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and our King shall judge our causes, and goe before us, to conduct our

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: wars." Here is confirmed the Right that Soveraigns have, both to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Militia, and to all Judicature; in which is conteined as absolute power,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as one man can possibly transferre to another. Again, the prayer of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: King Salomon to God, was this. (1 Kings 3. 9) "Give to thy servant

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: understanding, to judge thy people, and to discerne between Good and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Evill." It belongeth therefore to the Soveraigne to bee Judge, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to praescribe the Rules of Discerning Good and Evill; which Rules are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lawes; and therefore in him is the Legislative Power. Saul sought

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the life of David; yet when it was in his power to slay Saul, and his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Servants would have done it, David forbad them, saying (1 Sam. 24. 9)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "God forbid I should do such an act against my Lord, the anoynted of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: God." For obedience of servants St. Paul saith, (Coll. 3. 20) "Servants

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: obey your masters in All things," and, (Verse. 22) "Children obey your

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Parents in All things." There is simple obedience in those that are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: subject to Paternall, or Despoticall Dominion. Again, (Math. 23. 2,3)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "The Scribes and Pharisees sit in Moses chayre and therefore All that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they shall bid you observe, that observe and do." There again is simple

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: obedience. And St. Paul, (Tit. 3. 2) "Warn them that they subject

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: themselves to Princes, and to those that are in Authority, & obey

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them." This obedience is also simple. Lastly, our Saviour himselfe

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: acknowledges, that men ought to pay such taxes as are by Kings imposed,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: where he sayes, "Give to Caesar that which is Caesars;" and payed such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: taxes himselfe. And that the Kings word, is sufficient to take any thing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from any subject, when there is need; and that the King is Judge of that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: need: For he himselfe, as King of the Jewes, commanded his Disciples to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: take the Asse, and Asses Colt to carry him into Jerusalem, saying, (Mat.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 21. 2,3) "Go into the Village over against you, and you shall find a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shee Asse tyed, and her Colt with her, unty them, and bring them to me.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And if any man ask you, what you mean by it, Say the Lord hath need

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of them: And they will let them go." They will not ask whether his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: necessity be a sufficient title; nor whether he be judge of that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: necessity; but acquiesce in the will of the Lord.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To these places may be added also that of Genesis, (Gen. 3. 5) "You

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shall be as Gods, knowing Good and Evill." and verse 11. "Who told thee

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that thou wast naked? hast thou eaten of the tree, of which I commanded

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thee thou shouldest not eat?" For the Cognisance of Judicature of Good

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Evill, being forbidden by the name of the fruit of the tree of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Knowledge, as a triall of Adams obedience; The Divell to enflame the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ambition of the woman, to whom that fruit already seemed beautifull,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: told her that by tasting it, they should be as Gods, knowing Good and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Evill. Whereupon having both eaten, they did indeed take upon them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Gods office, which is Judicature of Good and Evill; but acquired no new

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ability to distinguish between them aright. And whereas it is sayd, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: having eaten, they saw they were naked; no man hath so interpreted that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: place, as if they had formerly blind, as saw not their own skins: the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: meaning is plain, that it was then they first judged their nakednesse

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (wherein it was Gods will to create them) to be uncomely; and by being

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ashamed, did tacitely censure God himselfe. And thereupon God saith,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "Hast thou eaten, &c." as if he should say, doest thou that owest me

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: obedience, take upon thee to judge of my Commandements? Whereby it is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: cleerly, (though Allegorically,) signified, that the Commands of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them that have the right to command, are not by their Subjects to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: censured, nor disputed.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign Power Ought In All Common-wealths To Be Absolute

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: So it appeareth plainly, to my understanding, both from Reason, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Scripture, that the Soveraign Power, whether placed in One Man, as in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Monarchy, or in one Assembly of men, as in Popular, and Aristocraticall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealths, is as great, as possibly men can be imagined to make

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it. And though of so unlimited a Power, men may fancy many evill

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consequences, yet the consequences of the want of it, which is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: perpetuall warre of every man against his neighbour, are much worse. The

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: condition of man in this life shall never be without Inconveniences; but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there happeneth in no Common-wealth any great Inconvenience, but what

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: proceeds from the Subjects disobedience, and breach of those Covenants,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from which the Common-wealth had its being. And whosoever thinking

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign Power too great, will seek to make it lesse; must subject

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: himselfe, to the Power, that can limit it; that is to say, to a greater.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The greatest objection is, that of the Practise; when men ask, where,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and when, such Power has by Subjects been acknowledged. But one may

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ask them again, when, or where has there been a Kingdome long free from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sedition and Civill Warre. In those Nations, whose Common-wealths have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: been long-lived, and not been destroyed, but by forraign warre, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Subjects never did dispute of the Soveraign Power. But howsoever, an

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: argument for the Practise of men, that have not sifted to the bottom,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and with exact reason weighed the causes, and nature of Common-wealths,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and suffer daily those miseries, that proceed from the ignorance

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thereof, is invalid. For though in all places of the world, men should

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: lay the foundation of their houses on the sand, it could not thence be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: inferred, that so it ought to be. The skill of making, and maintaining

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealths, consisteth in certain Rules, as doth Arithmetique and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Geometry; not (as Tennis-play) on Practise onely: which Rules, neither

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: poor men have the leisure, nor men that have had the leisure, have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hitherto had the curiosity, or the method to find out.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CHAPTER XXI. OF THE LIBERTY OF SUBJECTS

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Liberty What

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Liberty, or FREEDOME, signifieth (properly) the absence of Opposition;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (by Opposition, I mean externall Impediments of motion;) and may

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be applyed no lesse to Irrational, and Inanimate creatures, than to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Rationall. For whatsoever is so tyed, or environed, as it cannot move,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but within a certain space, which space is determined by the opposition

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of some externall body, we say it hath not Liberty to go further. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: so of all living creatures, whilest they are imprisoned, or restrained,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with walls, or chayns; and of the water whilest it is kept in by banks,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or vessels, that otherwise would spread it selfe into a larger space, we

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: use to say, they are not at Liberty, to move in such manner, as without

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: those externall impediments they would. But when the impediment of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: motion, is in the constitution of the thing it selfe, we use not to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: say, it wants the Liberty; but the Power to move; as when a stone lyeth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: still, or a man is fastned to his bed by sicknesse.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: What It Is To Be Free

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And according to this proper, and generally received meaning of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: word, A FREE-MAN, is "he, that in those things, which by his strength

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and wit he is able to do, is not hindred to doe what he has a will

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to." But when the words Free, and Liberty, are applyed to any thing but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Bodies, they are abused; for that which is not subject to Motion, is not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: subject to Impediment: And therefore, when 'tis said (for example) The

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: way is free, no liberty of the way is signified, but of those that walk

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in it without stop. And when we say a Guift is free, there is not meant

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: any liberty of the Guift, but of the Giver, that was not bound by any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: law, or Covenant to give it. So when we Speak Freely, it is not the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: liberty of voice, or pronunciation, but of the man, whom no law hath

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: obliged to speak otherwise then he did. Lastly, from the use of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: word Freewill, no liberty can be inferred to the will, desire, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: inclination, but the liberty of the man; which consisteth in this, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he finds no stop, in doing what he has the will, desire, or inclination

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to doe.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Feare And Liberty Consistent

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Feare and Liberty are consistent; as when a man throweth his goods into

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Sea for Feare the ship should sink, he doth it neverthelesse very

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: willingly, and may refuse to doe it if he will: It is therefore the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: action, of one that was Free; so a man sometimes pays his debt, only for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Feare of Imprisonment, which because no body hindred him from detaining,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was the action of a man at Liberty. And generally all actions which men

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: doe in Common-wealths, for Feare of the law, or actions, which the doers

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: had Liberty to omit.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Liberty And Necessity Consistent

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Liberty and Necessity are Consistent: As in the water, that hath not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: only Liberty, but a Necessity of descending by the Channel: so likewise

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the Actions which men voluntarily doe; which (because they proceed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from their will) proceed from Liberty; and yet because every act of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: mans will, and every desire, and inclination proceedeth from some cause,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which causes in a continuall chaine (whose first link in the hand of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: God the first of all causes) proceed from Necessity. So that to him

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that could see the connexion of those causes, the Necessity of all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: mens voluntary actions, would appeare manifest. And therefore God, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: seeth, and disposeth all things, seeth also that the Liberty of man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in doing what he will, is accompanied with the Necessity of doing that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which God will, & no more, nor lesse. For though men may do many things,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which God does not command, nor is therefore Author of them; yet they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: can have no passion, nor appetite to any thing, of which appetite Gods

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: will is not the cause. And did not his will assure the Necessity of mans

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: will, and consequently of all that on mans will dependeth, the Liberty

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of men would be a contradiction, and impediment to the omnipotence and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Liberty of God. And this shall suffice, (as to the matter in hand) of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that naturall Liberty, which only is properly called Liberty.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Artificiall Bonds, Or Covenants

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But as men, for the atteyning of peace, and conservation of themselves

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thereby, have made an Artificiall Man, which we call a Common-wealth; so

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: also have they made Artificiall Chains, called Civill Lawes, which they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: themselves, by mutuall covenants, have fastned at one end, to the lips

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of that Man, or Assembly, to whom they have given the Soveraigne Power;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and at the other end to their own Ears. These Bonds in their own nature

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but weak, may neverthelesse be made to hold, by the danger, though not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by the difficulty of breaking them.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Liberty Of Subjects Consisteth In Liberty From Covenants

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In relation to these Bonds only it is, that I am to speak now, of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Liberty of Subjects. For seeing there is no Common-wealth in the world,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for the regulating of all the actions, and words of men, (as being

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a thing impossible:) it followeth necessarily, that in all kinds of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: actions, by the laws praetermitted, men have the Liberty, of doing what

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their own reasons shall suggest, for the most profitable to themselves.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For if wee take Liberty in the proper sense, for corporall Liberty; that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is to say, freedome from chains, and prison, it were very absurd for men

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to clamor as they doe, for the Liberty they so manifestly enjoy. Againe,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: if we take Liberty, for an exemption from Lawes, it is no lesse absurd,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for men to demand as they doe, that Liberty, by which all other men may

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be masters of their lives. And yet as absurd as it is, this is it they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: demand; not knowing that the Lawes are of no power to protect them,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: without a Sword in the hands of a man, or men, to cause those laws to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be put in execution. The Liberty of a Subject, lyeth therefore only

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in those things, which in regulating their actions, the Soveraign hath

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: praetermitted; such as is the Liberty to buy, and sell, and otherwise

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: contract with one another; to choose their own aboad, their own diet,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their own trade of life, and institute their children as they themselves

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: think fit; & the like.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Liberty Of The Subject Consistent With Unlimited Power Of The Soveraign

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Neverthelesse we are not to understand, that by such Liberty, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign Power of life, and death, is either abolished, or limited. For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it has been already shewn, that nothing the Soveraign Representative

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: can doe to a Subject, on what pretence soever, can properly be called

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Injustice, or Injury; because every Subject is Author of every act the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign doth; so that he never wanteth Right to any thing, otherwise,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: than as he himself is the Subject of God, and bound thereby to observe

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the laws of Nature. And therefore it may, and doth often happen in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealths, that a Subject may be put to death, by the command of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Soveraign Power; and yet neither doe the other wrong: as when Jeptha

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: caused his daughter to be sacrificed: In which, and the like cases,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he that so dieth, had Liberty to doe the action, for which he is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: neverthelesse, without Injury put to death. And the same holdeth also

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in a Soveraign Prince, that putteth to death an Innocent Subject. For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: though the action be against the law of Nature, as being contrary to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Equitie, (as was the killing of Uriah, by David;) yet it was not an

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Injurie to Uriah; but to God. Not to Uriah, because the right to doe

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: what he pleased, was given him by Uriah himself; And yet to God, because

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: David was Gods Subject; and prohibited all Iniquitie by the law of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nature. Which distinction, David himself, when he repented the fact,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: evidently confirmed, saying, "To thee only have I sinned." In the same

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: manner, the people of Athens, when they banished the most potent of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their Common-wealth for ten years, thought they committed no Injustice;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and yet they never questioned what crime he had done; but what hurt he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: would doe: Nay they commanded the banishment of they knew not whom; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: every Citizen bringing his Oystershell into the market place, written

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with the name of him he desired should be banished, without actuall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: accusing him, sometimes banished an Aristides, for his reputation of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Justice; And sometimes a scurrilous Jester, as Hyperbolus, to make a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Jest of it. And yet a man cannot say, the Soveraign People of Athens

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: wanted right to banish them; or an Athenian the Libertie to Jest, or to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be Just.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Liberty Which Writers Praise, Is The Liberty Of Soveraigns;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Not Of Private Men

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Libertie, whereof there is so frequent, and honourable mention, in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Histories, and Philosophy of the Antient Greeks, and Romans, and in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the writings, and discourse of those that from them have received all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their learning in the Politiques, is not the Libertie of Particular

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: men; but the Libertie of the Common-wealth: which is the same with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that, which every man then should have, if there were no Civil Laws,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: nor Common-wealth at all. And the effects of it also be the same. For as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: amongst masterlesse men, there is perpetuall war, of every man against

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his neighbour; no inheritance, to transmit to the Son, nor to expect

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from the Father; no propriety of Goods, or Lands; no security; but a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: full and absolute Libertie in every Particular man: So in States, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealths not dependent on one another, every Common-wealth, (not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: every man) has an absolute Libertie, to doe what it shall judge (that is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to say, what that Man, or Assemblie that representeth it, shall judge)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: most conducing to their benefit. But withall, they live in the condition

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of a perpetuall war, and upon the confines of battel, with their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: frontiers armed, and canons planted against their neighbours

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: round about. The Athenians, and Romanes, were free; that is, free

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealths: not that any particular men had the Libertie to resist

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their own Representative; but that their Representative had the Libertie

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to resist, or invade other people. There is written on the Turrets of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the city of Luca in great characters at this day, the word LIBERTAS; yet

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: no man can thence inferre, that a particular man has more Libertie,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or Immunitie from the service of the Commonwealth there, than in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Constantinople. Whether a Common-wealth be Monarchicall, or Popular, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Freedome is still the same.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But it is an easy thing, for men to be deceived, by the specious name

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Libertie; and for want of Judgement to distinguish, mistake that for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their Private Inheritance, and Birth right, which is the right of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Publique only. And when the same errour is confirmed by the authority of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: men in reputation for their writings in this subject, it is no wonder if

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it produce sedition, and change of Government. In these westerne

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: parts of the world, we are made to receive our opinions concerning the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Institution, and Rights of Common-wealths, from Aristotle, Cicero, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other men, Greeks and Romanes, that living under Popular States, derived

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: those Rights, not from the Principles of Nature, but transcribed them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: into their books, out of the Practice of their own Common-wealths, which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: were Popular; as the Grammarians describe the Rules of Language, out of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Practise of the time; or the Rules of Poetry, out of the Poems of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Homer and Virgil. And because the Athenians were taught, (to keep them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from desire of changing their Government,) that they were Freemen, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all that lived under Monarchy were slaves; therefore Aristotle puts it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: down in his Politiques,(lib.6.cap.2) "In democracy, Liberty is to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: supposed: for 'tis commonly held, that no man is Free in any other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Government." And as Aristotle; so Cicero, and other Writers have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: grounded their Civill doctrine, on the opinions of the Romans, who were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: taught to hate Monarchy, at first, by them that having deposed their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign, shared amongst them the Soveraignty of Rome; and afterwards

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by their Successors. And by reading of these Greek, and Latine Authors,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: men from their childhood have gotten a habit (under a false shew of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Liberty,) of favouring tumults, and of licentious controlling the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: actions of their Soveraigns; and again of controlling those controllers,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with the effusion of so much blood; as I think I may truly say, there

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was never any thing so deerly bought, as these Western parts have bought

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the learning of the Greek and Latine tongues.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Liberty Of The Subject How To Be Measured

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To come now to the particulars of the true Liberty of a Subject; that is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to say, what are the things, which though commanded by the Soveraign, he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: may neverthelesse, without Injustice, refuse to do; we are to consider,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: what Rights we passe away, when we make a Common-wealth; or (which is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all one,) what Liberty we deny our selves, by owning all the Actions

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (without exception) of the Man, or Assembly we make our Soveraign. For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the act of our Submission, consisteth both our Obligation, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: our Liberty; which must therefore be inferred by arguments taken from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thence; there being no Obligation on any man, which ariseth not from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: some Act of his own; for all men equally, are by Nature Free. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: because such arguments, must either be drawn from the expresse words, "I

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Authorise all his Actions," or from the Intention of him that submitteth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: himselfe to his Power, (which Intention is to be understood by the End

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for which he so submitteth;) The Obligation, and Liberty of the Subject,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is to be derived, either from those Words, (or others equivalent;) or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: else from the End of the Institution of Soveraignty; namely, the Peace

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Subjects within themselves, and their Defence against a common

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Enemy.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Subjects Have Liberty To Defend Their Own Bodies,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Even Against Them That Lawfully Invade Them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: First therefore, seeing Soveraignty by Institution, is by Covenant of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: every one to every one; and Soveraignty by Acquisition, by Covenants of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Vanquished to the Victor, or Child to the Parent; It is manifest,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that every Subject has Liberty in all those things, the right whereof

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: cannot by Covenant be transferred. I have shewn before in the 14.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Chapter, that Covenants, not to defend a mans own body, are voyd.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Therefore,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Are Not Bound To Hurt Themselves;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: If the Soveraign command a man (though justly condemned,) to kill,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: wound, or mayme himselfe; or not to resist those that assault him; or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to abstain from the use of food, ayre, medicine, or any other thing,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: without which he cannot live; yet hath that man the Liberty to disobey.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: If a man be interrogated by the Soveraign, or his Authority, concerning

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a crime done by himselfe, he is not bound (without assurance of Pardon)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to confesse it; because no man (as I have shewn in the same Chapter) can

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be obliged by Covenant to accuse himselfe.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Again, the Consent of a Subject to Soveraign Power, is contained in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: these words, "I Authorise, or take upon me, all his actions;" in which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there is no restriction at all, of his own former naturall Liberty:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For by allowing him to Kill Me, I am not bound to Kill my selfe when

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he commands me. "'Tis one thing to say 'Kill me, or my fellow, if you

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: please;' another thing to say, 'I will kill my selfe, or my fellow.'" It

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: followeth therefore, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: No man is bound by the words themselves, either to kill himselfe, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: any other man; And consequently, that the Obligation a man may sometimes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have, upon the Command of the Soveraign to execute any dangerous, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: dishonourable Office, dependeth not on the Words of our Submission; but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: on the Intention; which is to be understood by the End thereof. When

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore our refusall to obey, frustrates the End for which the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraignty was ordained; then there is no Liberty to refuse: otherwise

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there is.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nor To Warfare, Unless They Voluntarily Undertake It

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Upon this ground, a man that is commanded as a Souldier to fight against

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the enemy, though his Soveraign have Right enough to punish his refusall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with death, may neverthelesse in many cases refuse, without Injustice;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as when he substituteth a sufficient Souldier in his place: for in this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: case he deserteth not the service of the Common-wealth. And there is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: allowance to be made for naturall timorousnesse, not onely to women, (of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whom no such dangerous duty is expected,) but also to men of feminine

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: courage. When Armies fight, there is on one side, or both, a running

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: away; yet when they do it not out of trechery, but fear, they are not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: esteemed to do it unjustly, but dishonourably. For the same reason, to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: avoyd battell, is not Injustice, but Cowardise. But he that inrowleth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: himselfe a Souldier, or taketh imprest mony, taketh away the excuse of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a timorous nature; and is obliged, not onely to go to the battell,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but also not to run from it, without his Captaines leave. And when the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Defence of the Common-wealth, requireth at once the help of all that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are able to bear Arms, every one is obliged; because otherwise the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Institution of the Common-wealth, which they have not the purpose, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: courage to preserve, was in vain.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To resist the Sword of the Common-wealth, in defence of another man,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: guilty, or innocent, no man hath Liberty; because such Liberty, takes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: away from the Soveraign, the means of Protecting us; and is therefore

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: destructive of the very essence of Government. But in case a great many

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: men together, have already resisted the Soveraign Power Unjustly, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: committed some Capitall crime, for which every one of them expecteth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: death, whether have they not the Liberty then to joyn together, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: assist, and defend one another? Certainly they have: For they but defend

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their lives, which the guilty man may as well do, as the Innocent. There

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was indeed injustice in the first breach of their duty; Their bearing of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Arms subsequent to it, though it be to maintain what they have done, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: no new unjust act. And if it be onely to defend their persons, it is not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: unjust at all. But the offer of Pardon taketh from them, to whom it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is offered, the plea of self-defence, and maketh their perseverance in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: assisting, or defending the rest, unlawfull.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Greatest Liberty Of Subjects, Dependeth On The Silence Of The Law

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: As for other Lyberties, they depend on the silence of the Law. In cases

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: where the Soveraign has prescribed no rule, there the Subject hath

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the liberty to do, or forbeare, according to his own discretion. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore such Liberty is in some places more, and in some lesse; and in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: some times more, in other times lesse, according as they that have the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraignty shall think most convenient. As for Example, there was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a time, when in England a man might enter in to his own Land,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (and dispossesse such as wrongfully possessed it) by force. But in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: after-times, that Liberty of Forcible entry, was taken away by a Statute

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: made (by the King) in Parliament. And is some places of the world, men

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have the Liberty of many wives: in other places, such Liberty is not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: allowed.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: If a Subject have a controversie with his Soveraigne, of Debt, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of right of possession of lands or goods, or concerning any service

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: required at his hands, or concerning any penalty corporall, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: pecuniary, grounded on a precedent Law; He hath the same Liberty to sue

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for his right, as if it were against a Subject; and before such Judges,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as are appointed by the Soveraign. For seeing the Soveraign demandeth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by force of a former Law, and not by vertue of his Power; he declareth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thereby, that he requireth no more, than shall appear to be due by that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Law. The sute therefore is not contrary to the will of the Soveraign;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and consequently the Subject hath the Liberty to demand the hearing of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his Cause; and sentence, according to that Law. But if he demand, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: take any thing by pretence of his Power; there lyeth, in that case, no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: action of Law: for all that is done by him in Vertue of his Power, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: done by the Authority of every subject, and consequently, he that brings

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: an action against the Soveraign, brings it against himselfe.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: If a Monarch, or Soveraign Assembly, grant a Liberty to all, or any of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his Subjects; which Grant standing, he is disabled to provide for their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: safety, the Grant is voyd; unlesse he directly renounce, or transferre

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Soveraignty to another. For in that he might openly, (if it had been

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his will,) and in plain termes, have renounced, or transferred it, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: did not; it is to be understood it was not his will; but that the Grant

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: proceeded from ignorance of the repugnancy between such a Liberty and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Soveraign Power; and therefore the Soveraignty is still retayned;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and consequently all those Powers, which are necessary to the exercising

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thereof; such as are the Power of Warre, and Peace, of Judicature, of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: appointing Officers, and Councellours, of levying Mony, and the rest

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: named in the 18th Chapter.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In What Cases Subjects Absolved Of Their Obedience To Their Soveraign

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Obligation of Subjects to the Soveraign is understood to last as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: long, and no longer, than the power lasteth, by which he is able to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: protect them. For the right men have by Nature to protect themselves,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: when none else can protect them, can by no Covenant be relinquished. The

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraignty is the Soule of the Common-wealth; which once departed from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Body, the members doe no more receive their motion from it. The end

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Obedience is Protection; which, wheresoever a man seeth it, either in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his own, or in anothers sword, Nature applyeth his obedience to it, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his endeavour to maintaine it. And though Soveraignty, in the intention

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of them that make it, be immortall; yet is it in its own nature, not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: only subject to violent death, by forreign war; but also through

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the ignorance, and passions of men, it hath in it, from the very

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: institution, many seeds of a naturall mortality, by Intestine Discord.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In Case Of Captivity

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: If a Subject be taken prisoner in war; or his person, or his means of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: life be within the Guards of the enemy, and hath his life and corporall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Libertie given him, on condition to be Subject to the Victor, he hath

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Libertie to accept the condition; and having accepted it, is the subject

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of him that took him; because he had no other way to preserve himselfe.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The case is the same, if he be deteined on the same termes, in a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: forreign country. But if a man be held in prison, or bonds, or is not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: trusted with the libertie of his bodie; he cannot be understood to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: bound by Covenant to subjection; and therefore may, if he can, make his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: escape by any means whatsoever.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In Case The Soveraign Cast Off The Government From Himself And Heyrs

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: If a Monarch shall relinquish the Soveraignty, both for himself, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his heires; His Subjects returne to the absolute Libertie of Nature;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: because, though Nature may declare who are his Sons, and who are the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: nerest of his Kin; yet it dependeth on his own will, (as hath been said

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the precedent chapter,) who shall be his Heyr. If therefore he will

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have no Heyre, there is no Soveraignty, nor Subjection. The case is the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: same, if he dye without known Kindred, and without declaration of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his Heyre. For then there can no Heire be known, and consequently no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Subjection be due.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In Case Of Banishment

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: If the Soveraign Banish his Subject; during the Banishment, he is not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Subject. But he that is sent on a message, or hath leave to travell, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: still Subject; but it is, by Contract between Soveraigns, not by vertue

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the covenant of Subjection. For whosoever entreth into anothers

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: dominion, is Subject to all the Lawes thereof; unless he have a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: privilege by the amity of the Soveraigns, or by speciall licence.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In Case The Soveraign Render Himself Subject To Another

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: If a Monarch subdued by war, render himself Subject to the Victor; his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Subjects are delivered from their former obligation, and become obliged

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to the Victor. But if he be held prisoner, or have not the liberty

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of his own Body; he is not understood to have given away the Right of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraigntie; and therefore his Subjects are obliged to yield obedience

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to the Magistrates formerly placed, governing not in their own name,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but in his. For, his Right remaining, the question is only of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Administration; that is to say, of the Magistrates and Officers; which,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: if he have not means to name, he is supposed to approve those, which he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: himself had formerly appointed.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CHAPTER XXII. OF SYSTEMES SUBJECT, POLITICALL, AND PRIVATE

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Divers Sorts Of Systemes Of People

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Having spoken of the Generation, Forme, and Power of a Common-wealth, I

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: am in order to speak next of the parts thereof. And first of Systemes,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which resemble the similar parts, or Muscles of a Body naturall. By

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: SYSTEMES; I understand any numbers of men joyned in one Interest, or one

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Businesse. Of which, some are Regular, and some Irregular. Regular are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: those, where one Man, or Assembly of men, is constituted Representative

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the whole number. All other are Irregular.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of Regular, some are Absolute, and Independent, subject to none but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their own Representative: such are only Common-wealths; Of which I have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: spoken already in the 5. last preceding chapters. Others are Dependent;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that is to say, Subordinate to some Soveraign Power, to which every one,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as also their Representative is Subject.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of Systemes subordinate, some are Politicall, and some Private.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Politicall (otherwise Called Bodies Politique, and Persons In Law,)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are those, which are made by authority from the Soveraign Power of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth. Private, are those, which are constituted by Subjects

author: Thomas Hobbes
