text: amongst themselves, or by authoritie from a stranger. For no authority

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: derived from forraign power, within the Dominion of another, is Publique

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there, but Private.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And of Private Systemes, some are Lawfull; some Unlawfull: Lawfull, are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: those which are allowed by the Common-wealth: all other are Unlawfull.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Irregular Systemes, are those which having no Representative,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consist only in concourse of People; which if not forbidden by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth, nor made on evill designe, (such as are conflux of People

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to markets, or shews, or any other harmelesse end,) are Lawfull. But

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: when the Intention is evill, or (if the number be considerable) unknown,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they are Unlawfull.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In All Bodies Politique The Power Of The Representative Is Limited

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In Bodies Politique, the power of the Representative is alwaies Limited:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And that which prescribeth the limits thereof, is the Power Soveraign.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For Power Unlimited, is absolute Soveraignty. And the Soveraign, in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: every Commonwealth, is the absolute Representative of all the Subjects;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and therefore no other, can be Representative of any part of them,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but so far forth, as he shall give leave; And to give leave to a Body

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Politique of Subjects, to have an absolute Representative to all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: intents and purposes, were to abandon the Government of so much of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Commonwealth, and to divide the Dominion, contrary to their Peace and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Defence, which the Soveraign cannot be understood to doe, by any Grant,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that does not plainly, and directly discharge them of their subjection.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For consequences of words, are not the signes of his will, when other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consequences are signes of the contrary; but rather signes of errour,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and misreckoning; to which all mankind is too prone.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The bounds of that Power, which is given to the Representative of a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Bodie Politique, are to be taken notice of, from two things. One is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their Writt, or Letters from the Soveraign: the other is the Law of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: By Letters Patents

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For though in the Institution or Acquisition of a Common-wealth,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which is independent, there needs no Writing, because the Power of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Representative has there no other bounds, but such as are set out by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the unwritten Law of Nature; yet in subordinate bodies, there are such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: diversities of Limitation necessary, concerning their businesses, times,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and places, as can neither be remembred without Letters, nor taken

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: notice of, unlesse such Letters be Patent, that they may be read to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them, and withall sealed, or testified, with the Seales, or other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: permanent signes of the Authority Soveraign.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And The Lawes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And because such Limitation is not alwaies easie, or perhaps possible

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to be described in writing; the ordinary Lawes, common to all Subjects,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: must determine, that the Representative may lawfully do, in all Cases,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: where the Letters themselves are silent. And therefore

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: When The Representative Is One Man, His Unwarranted Acts His Own Onely

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In a Body Politique, if the Representative be one man, whatsoever he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: does in the Person of the Body, which is not warranted in his Letters,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: nor by the Lawes, is his own act, and not the act of the Body, nor of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: any other Member thereof besides himselfe: Because further than his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Letters, or the Lawes limit, he representeth no mans person, but his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: own. But what he does according to these, is the act of every one: For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Act of the Soveraign every one is Author, because he is their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Representative unlimited; and the act of him that recedes not from the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Letters of the Soveraign, is the act of the Soveraign, and therefore

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: every member of the Body is Author of it.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: When It Is An Assembly, It Is The Act Of Them That Assented Onely

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But if the Representative be an Assembly, whatsoever that Assembly shall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Decree, not warranted by their Letters, or the Lawes, is the act of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Assembly, or Body Politique, and the act of every one by whose Vote the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Decree was made; but not the act of any man that being present Voted to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the contrary; nor of any man absent, unlesse he Voted it by procuration.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: It is the act of the Assembly, because Voted by the major part; and if

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it be a crime, the Assembly may be punished, as farre-forth as it is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: capable, as by dissolution, or forfeiture of their Letters (which is to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such artificiall, and fictitious Bodies, capitall,) or (if the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Assembly have a Common stock, wherein none of the Innocent Members have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: propriety,) by pecuniary Mulct. For from corporall penalties Nature hath

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: exempted all Bodies Politique. But they that gave not their Vote, are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore Innocent, because the Assembly cannot Represent any man in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: things unwarranted by their Letters, and consequently are not involved

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in their Votes.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: When The Representative Is One Man, If He Borrow Mony, Or Owe It, By

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Contract; He Is Lyable Onely, The Members Not If the person of the Body

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Politique being in one man, borrow mony of a stranger, that is, of one

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that is not of the same Body, (for no Letters need limit borrowing,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: seeing it is left to mens own inclinations to limit lending) the debt is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Representatives. For if he should have Authority from his Letters,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to make the members pay what he borroweth, he should have by consequence

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Soveraignty of them; and therefore the grant were either voyd,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as proceeding from Errour, commonly incident to humane Nature, and an

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: unsufficient signe of the will of the Granter; or if it be avowed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by him, then is the Representer Soveraign, and falleth not under the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: present question, which is onely of Bodies subordinate. No member

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore is obliged to pay the debt so borrowed, but the Representative

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: himselfe: because he that lendeth it, being a stranger to the Letters,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and to the qualification of the Body, understandeth those onely for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his debtors, that are engaged; and seeing the Representer can ingage

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: himselfe, and none else, has him onely for Debtor; who must therefore

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: pay him, out of the common stock (if there be any), or (if there be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: none) out of his own estate.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: If he come into debt by Contract, or Mulct, the case is the same.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: When It Is An Assembly, They Onely Are Liable That Have Assented

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But when the Representative is an Assembly, and the debt to a stranger;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all they, and onely they are responsible for the debt, that gave their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: votes to the borrowing of it, or to the Contract that made it due, or to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the fact for which the Mulct was imposed; because every one of those in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: voting did engage himselfe for the payment: For he that is author of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the borrowing, is obliged to the payment, even of the whole debt, though

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: when payd by any one, he be discharged.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: If The Debt Be To One Of The Assembly, The Body Onely Is Obliged

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But if the debt be to one of the Assembly, the Assembly onely is obliged

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to the payment, out of their common stock (if they have any:) For having

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: liberty of Vote, if he Vote the Mony, shall be borrowed, he Votes it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shall be payd; If he Vote it shall not be borrowed, or be absent, yet

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: because in lending, he voteth the borrowing, he contradicteth his former

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Vote, and is obliged by the later, and becomes both borrower and lender,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and consequently cannot demand payment from any particular man, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from the common Treasure onely; which fayling he hath no remedy, nor

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: complaint, but against himselfe, that being privy to the acts of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Assembly, and their means to pay, and not being enforced, did

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: neverthelesse through his own folly lend his mony.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Protestation Against The Decrees Of Bodies Politique

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sometimes Lawful; But Against Soveraign Power Never It is manifest by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: this, that in Bodies Politique subordinate, and subject to a Soveraign

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Power, it is sometimes not onely lawfull, but expedient, for a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: particular man to make open protestation against the decrees of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Representative Assembly, and cause their dissent to be Registred, or to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: take witnesse of it; because otherwise they may be obliged to pay debts

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: contracted, and be responsible for crimes committed by other men: But in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Soveraign Assembly, that liberty is taken away, both because he that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: protesteth there, denies their Soveraignty; and also because whatsoever

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is commanded by the Soveraign Power, is as to the Subject (though not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: so alwayes in the sight of God) justified by the Command; for of such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: command every Subject is the Author.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Bodies Politique For Government Of A Province, Colony, Or Town

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The variety of Bodies Politique, is almost infinite; for they are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not onely distinguished by the severall affaires, for which they are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: constituted, wherein there is an unspeakable diversitie; but also by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: times, places, and numbers, subject to many limitations. And as to their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: affaires, some are ordained for Government; As first, the Government

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of a Province may be committed to an Assembly of men, wherein all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: resolutions shall depend on the Votes of the major part; and then this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Assembly is a Body Politique, and their power limited by Commission.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: This word Province signifies a charge, or care of businesse, which he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whose businesse it is, committeth to another man, to be administred for,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and under him; and therefore when in one Common-wealth there be divers

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Countries, that have their Lawes distinct one from another, or are farre

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: distant in place, the Administration of the Government being committed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to divers persons, those Countries where the Soveraign is not resident,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but governs by Commission, are called Provinces. But of the government

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of a Province, by an Assembly residing in the Province it selfe, there

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be few examples. The Romans who had the Soveraignty of many Provinces;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: yet governed them alwaies by Presidents, and Praetors; and not by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Assemblies, as they governed the City of Rome, and Territories adjacent.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In like manner, when there were Colonies sent from England, to Plant

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Virginia, and Sommer-Ilands; though the government of them here, were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: committed to Assemblies in London, yet did those Assemblies never

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: commit the Government under them to any Assembly there; but did to each

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Plantation send one Governour; For though every man, where he can be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: present by Nature, desires to participate of government; yet where

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they cannot be present, they are by Nature also enclined, to commit the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Government of their common Interest rather to a Monarchicall, then a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Popular form of Government: which is also evident in those men that have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: great private estates; who when they are unwilling to take the paines of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: administring the businesse that belongs to them, choose rather to trust

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: one Servant, than a Assembly either of their friends or servants.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But howsoever it be in fact, yet we may suppose the Government of a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Province, or Colony committed to an Assembly: and when it is, that which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in this place I have to say, is this; that whatsoever debt is by that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Assembly contracted; or whatsoever unlawfull Act is decreed, is the Act

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: onely of those that assented, and not of any that dissented, or were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: absent, for the reasons before alledged. Also that an Assembly residing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: out of the bounds of that Colony whereof they have the government,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: cannot execute any power over the persons, or goods of any of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Colonie, to seize on them for debt, or other duty, in any place

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: without the Colony it selfe, as having no Jurisdiction, nor Authoritie

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: elsewhere, but are left to the remedie, which the Law of the place

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: alloweth them. And though the Assembly have right, to impose a Mulct

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: upon any of their members, that shall break the Lawes they make; yet

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: out of the Colonie it selfe, they have no right to execute the same.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And that which is said here, of the Rights of an Assembly, for the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: government of a Province, or a Colony, is appliable also to an Assembly

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for the Government of a Town, or University, or a College, or a Church,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or for any other Government over the persons of men.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And generally, in all Bodies Politique, if any particular member

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: conceive himself Injured by the Body it self, the Cognisance of his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: cause belongeth to the Soveraign, and those the Soveraign hath ordained

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for Judges in such causes, or shall ordaine for that particular cause;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and not to the Body it self. For the whole Body is in this case his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: fellow subject, which in a Soveraign Assembly, is otherwise: for there,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: if the Soveraign be not Judge, though in his own cause, there can be no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Judge at all.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Bodies Politique For Ordering Of Trade

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In a Bodie Politique, for the well ordering of forraigne Traffique, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: most commodious Representative is an Assembly of all the members; that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is to say, such a one, as every one that adventureth his mony, may be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: present at all the Deliberations, and Resolutions of the Body, if they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: will themselves. For proof whereof, we are to consider the end, for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which men that are Merchants, and may buy and sell, export, and import

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their Merchandise, according to their own discretions, doe neverthelesse

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: bind themselves up in one Corporation. It is true, there be few

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Merchants, that with the Merchandise they buy at home, can fraight a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ship, to export it; or with that they buy abroad, to bring it home; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have therefore need to joyn together in one Society; where every man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: may either participate of the gaine, according to the proportion of his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: adventure; or take his own; and sell what he transports, or imports, at

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such prices as he thinks fit. But this is no Body Politique, there being

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: no Common Representative to oblige them to any other Law, than that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which is common to all other subjects. The End of their Incorporating,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is to make their gaine the greater; which is done two wayes; by sole

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: buying, and sole selling, both at home, and abroad. So that to grant

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to a Company of Merchants to be a Corporation, or Body Politique, is to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: grant them a double Monopoly, whereof one is to be sole buyers; another

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to be sole sellers. For when there is a Company incorporate for any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: particular forraign Country, they only export the Commodities vendible

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in that Country; which is sole buying at home, and sole selling abroad.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For at home there is but one buyer, and abroad but one that selleth:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: both which is gainfull to the Merchant, because thereby they buy at home

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: at lower, and sell abroad at higher rates: And abroad there is but one

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: buyer of forraign Merchandise, and but one that sels them at home; both

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which againe are gainfull to the adventurers.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of this double Monopoly one part is disadvantageous to the people at

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: home, the other to forraigners. For at home by their sole exportation

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they set what price they please on the husbandry and handy-works of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the people; and by the sole importation, what price they please on all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: forraign commodities the people have need of; both which are ill for the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: people. On the contrary, by the sole selling of the native commodities

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: abroad, and sole buying the forraign commodities upon the place,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they raise the price of those, and abate the price of these, to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the disadvantage of the forraigner: For where but one selleth, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Merchandise is the dearer; and where but one buyeth the cheaper: Such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Corporations therefore are no other then Monopolies; though they would

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be very profitable for a Common-wealth, if being bound up into one body

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in forraigne Markets they were at liberty at home, every man to buy, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sell at what price he could.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The end then of these Bodies of Merchants, being not a Common benefit

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to the whole Body, (which have in this case no common stock, but what

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is deducted out of the particular adventures, for building, buying,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: victualling and manning of Ships,) but the particular gaine of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: every adventurer, it is reason that every one be acquainted with the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: employment of his own; that is, that every one be of the Assembly, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shall have the power to order the same; and be acquainted with their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: accounts. And therefore the Representative of such a Body must be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: an Assembly, where every member of the Body may be present at the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consultations, if he will.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: If a Body Politique of Merchants, contract a debt to a stranger by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: act of their Representative Assembly, every Member is lyable by himself

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for the whole. For a stranger can take no notice of their private Lawes,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but considereth them as so many particular men, obliged every one to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whole payment, till payment made by one dischargeth all the rest: But if

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the debt be to one of the Company, the creditor is debter for the whole

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to himself, and cannot therefore demand his debt, but only from the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: common stock, if there be any.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: If the Common-wealth impose a Tax upon the Body, it is understood to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: layd upon every member proportionably to his particular adventure in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Company. For there is in this case no other common stock, but what is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: made of their particular adventures.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: If a Mulct be layd upon the Body for some unlawfull act, they only are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: lyable by whose votes the act was decreed, or by whose assistance it was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: executed; for in none of the rest is there any other crime but being

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Body; which if a crime, (because the Body was ordeyned by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: authority of the Common-wealth,) is not his.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: If one of the Members be indebted to the Body, he may be sued by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Body; but his goods cannot be taken, nor his person imprisoned by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: authority of the Body; but only by Authority of the Common-wealth:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for if they can doe it by their own Authority, they can by their own

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Authority give judgement that the debt is due, which is as much as to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Judge in their own Cause.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: A Bodie Politique For Counsel To Be Give To The Soveraign

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: These Bodies made for the government of Men, or of Traffique, be either

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: perpetuall, or for a time prescribed by writing. But there be Bodies

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: also whose times are limited, and that only by the nature of their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: businesse. For example, if a Soveraign Monarch, or a Soveraign Assembly,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shall think fit to give command to the towns, and other severall parts

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of their territory, to send to him their Deputies, to enforme him of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: condition, and necessities of the Subjects, or to advise with him for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the making of good Lawes, or for any other cause, as with one Person

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: representing the whole Country, such Deputies, having a place and time

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of meeting assigned them, are there, and at that time, a Body Politique,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: representing every Subject of that Dominion; but it is onely for such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: matters as shall be propounded unto them by that Man, or Assembly, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by the Soveraign Authority sent for them; and when it shall be declared

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that nothing more shall be propounded, nor debated by them, the Body is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: dissolved. For if they were the absolute Representative of the people,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: then were it the Soveraign Assembly; and so there would be two Soveraign

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Assemblies, or two Soveraigns, over the same people; which cannot

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consist with their Peace. And therefore where there is once a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraignty, there can be no absolute Representation of the people, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by it. And for the limits of how farre such a Body shall represent the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whole People, they are set forth in the Writing by which they were sent

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for. For the People cannot choose their Deputies to other intent, than

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is in the Writing directed to them from their Soveraign expressed.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: A Regular Private Body, Lawfull, As A Family

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Private Bodies Regular, and Lawfull, are those that are constituted

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: without Letters, or other written Authority, saving the Lawes common

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to all other Subjects. And because they be united in one Person

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Representative, they are held for Regular; such as are all Families, in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which the Father, or Master ordereth the whole Family. For he obligeth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his Children, and Servants, as farre as the Law permitteth, though not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: further, because none of them are bound to obedience in those actions,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which the Law hath forbidden to be done. In all other actions, during

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the time they are under domestique government, they are subject to their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Fathers, and Masters, as to their immediate Soveraigns. For the Father,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Master being before the Institution of Common-wealth, absolute

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraigns in their own Families, they lose afterward no more of their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Authority, than the Law of the Common-wealth taketh from them.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Private Bodies Regular, But Unlawfull

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Private Bodies Regular, but Unlawfull, are those that unite themselves

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: into one person Representative, without any publique Authority at all;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such as are the Corporations of Beggars, Theeves and Gipsies, the better

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to order their trade of begging, and stealing; and the Corporations of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: men, that by Authority from any forraign Person, unite themselves in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: anothers Dominion, for easier propagation of Doctrines, and for making a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: party, against the Power of the Common-wealth.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Systemes Irregular, Such As Are Private Leagues

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Irregular Systemes, in their nature, but Leagues, or sometimes meer

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: concourse of people, without union to any particular designe, not by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: obligation of one to another, but proceeding onely from a similitude of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: wills and inclinations, become Lawfull, or Unlawfull, according to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: lawfulnesse, or unlawfulnesse of every particular mans design therein:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And his designe is to be understood by the occasion.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Leagues of Subjects, (because Leagues are commonly made for mutuall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: defence,) are in a Common-wealth (which is no more than a League of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all the Subjects together) for the most part unnecessary, and savour of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: unlawfull designe; and are for that cause Unlawfull, and go commonly by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the name of factions, or Conspiracies. For a League being a connexion of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: men by Covenants, if there be no power given to any one Man or Assembly,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (as in the condition of meer Nature) to compell them to performance,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is so long onely valid, as there ariseth no just cause of distrust: and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore Leagues between Common-wealths, over whom there is no humane

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Power established, to keep them all in awe, are not onely lawfull, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: also profitable for the time they last. But Leagues of the Subjects of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: one and the same Common-wealth, where every one may obtain his right

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by means of the Soveraign Power, are unnecessary to the maintaining of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Peace and Justice, and (in case the designe of them be evill, or Unknown

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to the Common-wealth) unlawfull. For all uniting of strength by private

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: men, is, if for evill intent, unjust; if for intent unknown, dangerous

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to the Publique, and unjustly concealed.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Secret Cabals

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: If the Soveraign Power be in a great Assembly, and a number of men,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: part of the Assembly, without authority, consult a part, to contrive

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the guidance of the rest; This is a Faction, or Conspiracy unlawfull,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as being a fraudulent seducing of the Assembly for their particular

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: interest. But if he, whose private interest is to be debated, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: judged in the Assembly, make as many friends as he can; in him it is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: no Injustice; because in this case he is no part of the Assembly. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: though he hire such friends with mony, (unlesse there be an expresse Law

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: against it,) yet it is not Injustice. For sometimes, (as mens manners

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are,) Justice cannot be had without mony; and every man may think his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: own cause just, till it be heard, and judged.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Feuds Of Private Families

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In all Common-wealths, if a private man entertain more servants, than

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the government of his estate, and lawfull employment he has for them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: requires, it is Faction, and unlawfull. For having the protection of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth, he needeth not the defence of private force. And whereas

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in Nations not throughly civilized, severall numerous Families have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: lived in continuall hostility, and invaded one another with private

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: force; yet it is evident enough, that they have done unjustly; or else

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that they had no Common-wealth.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Factions For Government

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And as Factions for Kindred, so also Factions for Government of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Religion, as of Papists, Protestants, &c. or of State, as Patricians,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Plebeians of old time in Rome, and of Aristocraticalls and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Democraticalls of old time in Greece, are unjust, as being contrary to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the peace and safety of the people, and a taking of the Sword out of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hand of the Soveraign.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Concourse of people, is an Irregular Systeme, the lawfulnesse, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: unlawfulnesse, whereof dependeth on the occasion, and on the number of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them that are assembled. If the occasion be lawfull, and manifest, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Concourse is lawfull; as the usuall meeting of men at Church, or at a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: publique Shew, in usuall numbers: for if the numbers be extraordinarily

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: great, the occasion is not evident; and consequently he that cannot

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: render a particular and good account of his being amongst them, is to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be judged conscious of an unlawfull, and tumultuous designe. It may be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: lawfull for a thousand men, to joyn in a Petition to be delivered to a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Judge, or Magistrate; yet if a thousand men come to present it, it is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a tumultuous Assembly; because there needs but one or two for that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: purpose. But in such cases as these, it is not a set number that makes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Assembly Unlawfull, but such a number, as the present Officers are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not able to suppresse, and bring to Justice.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: When an unusuall number of men, assemble against a man whom they accuse;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Assembly is an Unlawfull tumult; because they may deliver their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: accusation to the Magistrate by a few, or by one man. Such was the case

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of St. Paul at Ephesus; where Demetrius, and a great number of other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: men, brought two of Pauls companions before the Magistrate, saying with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: one Voyce, "Great is Diana of the Ephesians;" which was their way of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: demanding Justice against them for teaching the people such doctrine,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as was against their Religion, and Trade. The occasion here, considering

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Lawes of that People, was just; yet was their Assembly Judged

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Unlawfull, and the Magistrate reprehended them for it, in these

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: words,(Acts 19. 40) "If Demetrius and the other work-men can accuse any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man, of any thing, there be Pleas, and Deputies, let them accuse one

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: another. And if you have any other thing to demand, your case may

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be judged in an Assembly Lawfully called. For we are in danger to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: accused for this dayes sedition, because, there is no cause by which any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man can render any reason of this Concourse of People." Where he calleth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: an Assembly, whereof men can give no just account, a Sedition, and such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as they could not answer for. And this is all I shall say concerning

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Systemes, and Assemblyes of People, which may be compared (as I said,)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to the Similar parts of mans Body; such as be Lawfull, to the Muscles;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such as are Unlawfull, to Wens, Biles, and Apostemes, engendred by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: unnaturall conflux of evill humours.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CHAPTER XXIII. OF THE PUBLIQUE MINISTERS OF SOVERAIGN POWER

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In the last Chapter I have spoken of the Similar parts of a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth; In this I shall speak of the parts Organicall, which are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Publique Ministers.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Publique Minister Who

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: A PUBLIQUE MINISTER, is he, that by the Soveraign, (whether a Monarch,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or an Assembly,) is employed in any affaires, with Authority to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: represent in that employment, the Person of the Common-wealth. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whereas every man, or assembly that hath Soveraignty, representeth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: two Persons, or (as the more common phrase is) has two Capacities, one

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Naturall, and another Politique, (as a Monarch, hath the person not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: onely of the Common-wealth, but also of a man; and a Soveraign Assembly

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hath the Person not onely of the Common-wealth, but also of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Assembly); they that be servants to them in their naturall Capacity,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are not Publique Ministers; but those onely that serve them in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Administration of the Publique businesse. And therefore neither Ushers,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: nor Sergeants, nor other Officers that waite on the Assembly, for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: no other purpose, but for the commodity of the men assembled, in an

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Aristocracy, or Democracy; nor Stewards, Chamberlains, Cofferers, or any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other Officers of the houshold of a Monarch, are Publique Ministers in a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Monarchy.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ministers For The Generall Administration

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of Publique Ministers, some have charge committed to them of a general

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Administration, either of the whole Dominion, or of a part thereof.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of the whole, as to a Protector, or Regent, may bee committed by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Predecessor of an Infant King, during his minority, the whole

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Administration of his Kingdome. In which case, every Subject is so far

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: obliged to obedience, as the Ordinances he shall make, and the commands

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he shall give be in the Kings name, and not inconsistent with his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraigne Power. Of a Part, or Province; as when either a Monarch, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Soveraign Assembly, shall give the generall charge thereof to a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Governour, Lieutenant, Praefect, or Vice-Roy: And in this case also,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: every one of that Province, is obliged to all he shall doe in the name

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Soveraign, and that not incompatible with the Soveraigns Right.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For such Protectors, Vice-Roys, and Governours, have no other right, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: what depends on the Soveraigns Will; and no Commission that can be given

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them, can be interpreted for a Declaration of the will to transferre the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraignty, without expresse and perspicuous words to that purpose. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: this kind of Publique Ministers resembleth the Nerves, and Tendons that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: move the severall limbs of a body naturall.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For Speciall Administration, As For Oeconomy

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Others have speciall Administration; that is to say, charges of some

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: speciall businesse, either at home, or abroad: As at home, First, for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Oeconomy of a Common-wealth, They that have Authority concerning the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Treasure, as Tributes, Impositions, Rents, Fines, or whatsoever publique

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: revenue, to collect, receive, issue, or take the Accounts thereof,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are Publique Ministers: Ministers, because they serve the Person

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Representative, and can doe nothing against his Command, nor without his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Authority: Publique, because they serve him in his Politicall Capacity.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Secondly, they that have Authority concerning the Militia; to have the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: custody of Armes, Forts, Ports; to Levy, Pay, or Conduct Souldiers; or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to provide for any necessary thing for the use of war, either by Land or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sea, are publique Ministers. But a Souldier without Command, though he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: fight for the Common-wealth, does not therefore represent the Person of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it; because there is none to represent it to. For every one that hath

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: command, represents it to them only whom he commandeth.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For Instruction Of The People

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: They also that have authority to teach, or to enable others to teach

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the people their duty to the Soveraign Power, and instruct them in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: knowledge of what is just, and unjust, thereby to render them more apt

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to live in godlinesse, and in peace among themselves, and resist the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: publique enemy, are Publique Ministers: Ministers, in that they doe it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not by their own Authority, but by anothers; and Publique, because they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: doe it (or should doe it) by no Authority, but that of the Soveraign.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Monarch, or the Soveraign Assembly only hath immediate Authority

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from God, to teach and instruct the people; and no man but the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign, receiveth his power Dei Gratia simply; that is to say, from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the favour of none but God: All other, receive theirs from the favour

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and providence of God, and their Soveraigns; as in a Monarchy Dei Gratia

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: & Regis; or Dei Providentia & Voluntate Regis.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For Judicature

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: They also to whom Jurisdiction is given, are Publique Ministers. For in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their Seats of Justice they represent the person of the Soveraign; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their Sentence, is his Sentence; For (as hath been before declared) all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Judicature is essentially annexed to the Soveraignty; and therefore all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other Judges are but Ministers of him, or them that have the Soveraign

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Power. And as Controversies are of two sorts, namely of Fact, and of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Law; so are judgements, some of Fact, some of Law: And consequently in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the same controversie, there may be two Judges, one of Fact, another of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Law.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And in both these controversies, there may arise a controversie between

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the party Judged, and the Judge; which because they be both Subjects to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Soveraign, ought in Equity to be Judged by men agreed on by consent

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of both; for no man can be Judge in his own cause. But the Soveraign

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is already agreed on for Judge by them both, and is therefore either to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: heare the Cause, and determine it himself, or appoint for Judge such as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they shall both agree on. And this agreement is then understood to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: made between them divers wayes; as first, if the Defendant be allowed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to except against such of his Judges, whose interest maketh him suspect

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them, (for as to the Complaynant he hath already chosen his own Judge,)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: those which he excepteth not against, are Judges he himself agrees on.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Secondly, if he appeale to any other Judge, he can appeale no further;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for his appeale is his choice. Thirdly, if he appeale to the Soveraign

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: himself, and he by himself, or by Delegates which the parties shall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: agree on, give Sentence; that Sentence is finall: for the Defendant is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Judged by his own Judges, that is to say, by himself.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: These properties of just and rationall Judicature considered, I cannot

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: forbeare to observe the excellent constitution of the Courts of Justice,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: established both for Common, and also for Publique Pleas in England. By

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common Pleas, I meane those, where both the Complaynant and Defendant

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are Subjects: and by Publique, (which are also called Pleas of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Crown) those, where the Complaynant is the Soveraign. For whereas there

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: were two orders of men, whereof one was Lords, the other Commons; The

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lords had this Priviledge, to have for Judges in all Capitall crimes,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: none but Lords; and of them, as many as would be present; which being

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ever acknowledged as a Priviledge of favour, their Judges were none but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such as they had themselves desired. And in all controversies, every

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Subject (as also in civill controversies the Lords) had for Judges, men

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Country where the matter in controversie lay; against which he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: might make his exceptions, till at last Twelve men without exception

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: being agreed on, they were Judged by those twelve. So that having

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his own Judges, there could be nothing alledged by the party, why the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sentence should not be finall, These publique persons, with Authority

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from the Soveraign Power, either to Instruct, or Judge the people,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are such members of the Common-wealth, as may fitly be compared to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: organs of Voice in a Body naturall.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For Execution

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Publique Ministers are also all those, that have Authority from the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign, to procure the Execution of Judgements given; to publish the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraigns Commands; to suppresse Tumults; to apprehend, and imprison

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Malefactors; and other acts tending to the conservation of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Peace. For every act they doe by such Authority, is the act of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth; and their service, answerable to that of the Hands, in a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Bodie naturall.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Publique Ministers abroad, are those that represent the Person of their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: own Soveraign, to forraign States. Such are Ambassadors, Messengers,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Agents, and Heralds, sent by publique Authoritie, and on publique

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Businesse.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But such as are sent by Authoritie only of some private partie of a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: troubled State, though they be received, are neither Publique, nor

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Private Ministers of the Common-wealth; because none of their actions

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have the Common-wealth for Author. Likewise, an Ambassador sent from a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Prince, to congratulate, condole, or to assist at a solemnity, though

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Authority be Publique; yet because the businesse is Private, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: belonging to him in his naturall capacity; is a Private person. Also if

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a man be sent into another Country, secretly to explore their counsels,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and strength; though both the Authority, and the Businesse be Publique;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: yet because there is none to take notice of any Person in him, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his own; he is but a Private Minister; but yet a Minister of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth; and may be compared to an Eye in the Body naturall. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: those that are appointed to receive the Petitions or other informations

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the People, and are as it were the publique Eare, are Publique

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ministers, and represent their Soveraign in that office.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Counsellers Without Other Employment Then To Advise

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Are Not Publique Ministers

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Neither a Counsellor, nor a Councell of State, if we consider it with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: no Authority of Judicature or Command, but only of giving Advice to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Soveraign when it is required, or of offering it when it is not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: required, is a Publique Person. For the Advice is addressed to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign only, whose person cannot in his own presence, be represented

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to him, by another. But a Body of Counsellors, are never without some

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other Authority, either of Judicature, or of immediate Administration:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: As in a Monarchy, they represent the Monarch, in delivering his Commands

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to the Publique Ministers: In a Democracy, the Councell, or Senate

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: propounds the Result of their deliberations to the people, as a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Councell; but when they appoint Judges, or heare Causes, or give

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Audience to Ambassadors, it is in the quality of a Minister of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: People: And in an Aristocracy the Councell of State is the Soveraign

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Assembly it self; and gives counsell to none but themselves.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CHAPTER XXIV. OF THE NUTRITION, AND PROCREATION OF A COMMON-WEALTH

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Nourishment Of A Common-wealth Consisteth In The Commodities

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of Sea And Land

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The NUTRITION of a Common-wealth consisteth, in the Plenty, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Distribution of Materials conducing to Life: In Concoction, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Preparation; and (when concocted) in the Conveyance of it, by convenient

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: conduits, to the Publique use.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: As for the Plenty of Matter, it is a thing limited by Nature, to those

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: commodities, which from (the two breasts of our common Mother) Land,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Sea, God usually either freely giveth, or for labour selleth to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man-kind.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For the Matter of this Nutriment, consisting in Animals, Vegetals, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Minerals, God hath freely layd them before us, in or neer to the face of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Earth; so as there needeth no more but the labour, and industry

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of receiving them. Insomuch as Plenty dependeth (next to Gods favour)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: meerly on the labour and industry of men.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: This Matter, commonly called Commodities, is partly Native, and partly

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Forraign: Native, that which is to be had within the Territory of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Common-wealth; Forraign, that which is imported from without. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: because there is no Territory under the Dominion of one Common-wealth,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (except it be of very vast extent,) that produceth all things needfull

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for the maintenance, and motion of the whole Body; and few that produce

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not something more than necessary; the superfluous commodities to be had

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: within, become no more superfluous, but supply these wants at home, by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: importation of that which may be had abroad, either by Exchange, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by just Warre, or by Labour: for a mans Labour also, is a commodity

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: exchangeable for benefit, as well as any other thing: And there have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: been Common-wealths that having no more Territory, than hath served

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them for habitation, have neverthelesse, not onely maintained, but also

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: encreased their Power, partly by the labour of trading from one place to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: another, and partly by selling the Manifactures, whereof the Materials

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: were brought in from other places.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And The Right Of Distribution Of Them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Distribution of the Materials of this Nourishment, is the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: constitution of Mine, and Thine, and His, that is to say, in one word

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Propriety; and belongeth in all kinds of Common-wealth to the Soveraign

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Power. For where there is no Common-wealth, there is, (as hath been

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: already shewn) a perpetuall warre of every man against his neighbour;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And therefore every thing is his that getteth it, and keepeth it by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: force; which is neither Propriety nor Community; but Uncertainty. Which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is so evident, that even Cicero, (a passionate defender of Liberty,) in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a publique pleading, attributeth all Propriety to the Law Civil, "Let

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Civill Law," saith he, "be once abandoned, or but negligently

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: guarded, (not to say oppressed,) and there is nothing, that any man can

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be sure to receive from his Ancestor, or leave to his Children." And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: again; "Take away the Civill Law, and no man knows what is his own, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: what another mans." Seeing therefore the Introduction of Propriety is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: an effect of Common-wealth; which can do nothing but by the Person that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Represents it, it is the act onely of the Soveraign; and consisteth in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Lawes, which none can make that have not the Soveraign Power. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: this they well knew of old, who called that Nomos, (that is to say,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Distribution,) which we call Law; and defined Justice, by distributing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to every man his own.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: All Private Estates Of Land Proceed Originally

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: From The Arbitrary Distribution Of The Soveraign

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In this Distribution, the First Law, is for Division of the Land it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: selfe: wherein the Soveraign assigneth to every man a portion, according

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as he, and not according as any Subject, or any number of them, shall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: judge agreeable to Equity, and the Common Good. The Children of Israel,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: were a Common-wealth in the Wildernesse; but wanted the commodities

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Earth, till they were masters of the Land of Promise; which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: afterward was divided amongst them, not by their own discretion, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by the discretion of Eleazar the Priest, and Joshua their Generall: who

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: when there were twelve Tribes, making them thirteen by subdivision of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Tribe of Joseph; made neverthelesse but twelve portions of the Land;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and ordained for the Tribe of Levi no land; but assigned them the Tenth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: part of the whole fruits; which division was therefore Arbitrary. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: though a People comming into possession of a land by warre, do not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: alwaies exterminate the antient Inhabitants, (as did the Jewes,) but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: leave to many, or most, or all of them their Estates; yet it is manifest

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they hold them afterwards, as of the Victors distribution; as the people

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of England held all theirs of William the Conquerour.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Propriety Of A Subject Excludes Not The Dominion Of The Soveraign,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But Onely Of Another Subject

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: From whence we may collect, that the Propriety which a subject hath in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his lands, consisteth in a right to exclude all other subjects from the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: use of them; and not to exclude their Soveraign, be it an Assembly, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Monarch. For seeing the Soveraign, that is to say, the Common-wealth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (whose Person he representeth,) is understood to do nothing but in order

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to the common Peace and Security, this Distribution of lands, is to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: understood as done in order to the same: And consequently, whatsoever

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Distribution he shall make in prejudice thereof, is contrary to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: will of every subject, that committed his Peace, and safety to his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: discretion, and conscience; and therefore by the will of every one of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them, is to be reputed voyd. It is true, that a Soveraign Monarch, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the greater part of a Soveraign Assembly, may ordain the doing of many

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: things in pursuit of their Passions, contrary to their own consciences,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which is a breach of trust, and of the Law of Nature; but this is not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: enough to authorise any subject, either to make warre upon, or so much

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as to accuse of Injustice, or any way to speak evill of their Soveraign;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: because they have authorised all his actions, and in bestowing the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign Power, made them their own. But in what cases the Commands

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Soveraigns are contrary to Equity, and the Law of Nature, is to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: considered hereafter in another place.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Publique Is Not To Be Dieted

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In the Distribution of land, the Common-wealth it selfe, may be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: conceived to have a portion, and possesse, and improve the same by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their Representative; and that such portion may be made sufficient, to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: susteine the whole expence to the common Peace, and defence necessarily

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: required: Which were very true, if there could be any Representative

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: conceived free from humane passions, and infirmities. But the nature

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of men being as it is, the setting forth of Publique Land, or of any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: certaine Revenue for the Common-wealth, is in vaine; and tendeth to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: dissolution of Government, and to the condition of meere Nature, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: War, assoon as ever the Soveraign Power falleth into the hands of a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Monarch, or of an Assembly, that are either too negligent of mony, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: too hazardous in engaging the publique stock, into a long, or costly

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: war. Common-wealths can endure no Diet: For seeing their expence is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not limited by their own appetite, but by externall Accidents, and the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: appetites of their neighbours, the Publique Riches cannot be limited by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other limits, than those which the emergent occasions shall require. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whereas in England, there were by the Conquerour, divers Lands

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: reserved to his own use, (besides Forrests, and Chases, either for his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: recreation, or for preservation of Woods,) and divers services reserved

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: on the Land he gave his Subjects; yet it seems they were not reserved

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for his Maintenance in his Publique, but in his Naturall capacity: For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he, and his Successors did for all that, lay Arbitrary Taxes on all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Subjects land, when they judged it necessary. Or if those publique

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lands, and Services, were ordained as a sufficient maintenance of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth, it was contrary to the scope of the Institution; being

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (as it appeared by those ensuing Taxes) insufficient, and (as it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: appeares by the late Revenue of the Crown) Subject to Alienation,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Diminution. It is therefore in vaine, to assign a portion to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth; which may sell, or give it away; and does sell, and give

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it away when tis done by their Representative.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Places And Matter Of Traffique Depend, As Their Distribution,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: On The Soveraign

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: As the Distribution of Lands at home; so also to assigne in what places,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and for what commodities, the Subject shall traffique abroad, belongeth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to the Soveraign. For if it did belong to private persons to use their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: own discretion therein, some of them would bee drawn for gaine, both

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to furnish the enemy with means to hurt the Common-wealth, and hurt it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: themselves, by importing such things, as pleasing mens appetites, be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: neverthelesse noxious, or at least unprofitable to them. And therefore

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it belongeth to the Common-wealth, (that is, to the Soveraign only,)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to approve, or disapprove both of the places, and matter of forraign

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Traffique.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Laws Of Transferring Property Belong Also To The Soveraign

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Further, seeing it is not enough to the Sustentation of a Common-wealth,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that every man have a propriety in a portion of Land, or in some few

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: commodities, or a naturall property in some usefull art, and there is no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: art in the world, but is necessary either for the being, or well being

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: almost of every particular man; it is necessary, that men distribute

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that which they can spare, and transferre their propriety therein,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: mutually one to another, by exchange, and mutuall contract. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore it belongeth to the Common-wealth, (that is to say, to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign,) to appoint in what manner, all kinds of contract between

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Subjects, (as buying, selling, exchanging, borrowing, lending, letting,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and taking to hire,) are to bee made; and by what words, and signes they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shall be understood for valid. And for the Matter, and Distribution of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Nourishment, to the severall Members of the Common-wealth, thus much

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (considering the modell of the whole worke) is sufficient.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Mony The Bloud Of A Common-wealth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: By Concoction, I understand the reducing of all commodities, which are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not presently consumed, but reserved for Nourishment in time to come, to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: some thing of equal value, and withall so portably, as not to hinder

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the motion of men from place to place; to the end a man may have in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: what place soever, such Nourishment as the place affordeth. And this is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: nothing else but Gold, and Silver, and Mony. For Gold and Silver, being

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (as it happens) almost in all Countries of the world highly valued, is a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: commodious measure for the value of all things else between Nations; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Mony (of what matter soever coyned by the Soveraign of a Common-wealth,)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is a sufficient measure of the value of all things else, between the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Subjects of that Common-wealth. By the means of which measures, all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: commodities, Moveable, and Immoveable, are made to accompany a man, to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all places of his resort, within and without the place of his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ordinary residence; and the same passeth from Man to Man, within the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth; and goes round about, Nourishing (as it passeth)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: every part thereof; In so much as this Concoction, is as it were the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sanguification of the Common-wealth: For naturall Bloud is in like

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: manner made of the fruits of the Earth; and circulating, nourisheth by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the way, every Member of the Body of Man.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And because Silver and Gold, have their value from the matter it self;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they have first this priviledge, that the value of them cannot be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: altered by the power of one, nor of a few Common-wealths; as being a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: common measure of the commodities of all places. But base Mony, may

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: easily be enhanced, or abased. Secondly, they have the priviledge to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: make Common-wealths, move, and stretch out their armes, when need is,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: into forraign Countries; and supply, not only private Subjects that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: travell, but also whole Armies with provision. But that Coyne, which is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not considerable for the Matter, but for the Stamp of the place, being

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: unable to endure change of ayr, hath its effect at home only; where

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: also it is subject to the change of Laws, and thereby to have the value

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: diminished, to the prejudice many times of those that have it.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Conduits And Way Of Mony To The Publique Use

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Conduits, and Wayes by which it is conveyed to the Publique use, are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of two sorts; One, that Conveyeth it to the Publique Coffers; The other,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that Issueth the same out againe for publique payments. Of the first

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sort, are Collectors, Receivers, and Treasurers; of the second are the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Treasurers againe, and the Officers appointed for payment of severall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: publique or private Ministers. And in this also, the Artificiall Man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: maintains his resemblance with the Naturall; whose Veins receiving the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Bloud from the severall Parts of the Body, carry it to the Heart; where

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: being made Vitall, the Heart by the Arteries sends it out again, to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: enliven, and enable for motion all the Members of the same.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Children Of A Common-wealth Colonies

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Procreation, or Children of a Common-wealth, are those we call

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Plantations, or Colonies; which are numbers of men sent out from the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth, under a Conductor, or Governour, to inhabit a Forraign

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Country, either formerly voyd of Inhabitants, or made voyd then, by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: warre. And when a Colony is setled, they are either a Common-wealth of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: themselves, discharged of their subjection to their Soveraign that sent

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them, (as hath been done by many Common-wealths of antient time,) in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which case the Common-wealth from which they went was called their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Metropolis, or Mother, and requires no more of them, then Fathers

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: require of the Children, whom they emancipate, and make free from their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: domestique government, which is Honour, and Friendship; or else they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: remain united to their Metropolis, as were the Colonies of the people of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Rome; and then they are no Common-wealths themselves, but Provinces, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: parts of the Common-wealth that sent them. So that the Right of Colonies

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (saving Honour, and League with their Metropolis,) dependeth wholly on

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their Licence, or Letters, by which their Soveraign authorised them to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Plant.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CHAPTER XXV. OF COUNSELL

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Counsell What

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: How fallacious it is to judge of the nature of things, by the ordinary

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and inconstant use of words, appeareth in nothing more, than in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: confusion of Counsels, and Commands, arising from the Imperative manner

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of speaking in them both, and in many other occasions besides. For the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: words "Doe this," are the words not onely of him that Commandeth; but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: also of him that giveth Counsell; and of him that Exhorteth; and yet

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there are but few, that see not, that these are very different things;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or that cannot distinguish between them, when they perceive who it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is that speaketh, and to whom the Speech is directed, and upon what

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: occasion. But finding those phrases in mens writings, and being not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: able, or not willing to enter into a consideration of the circumstances,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they mistake sometimes the Precepts of Counsellours, for the Precepts

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of them that command; and sometimes the contrary; according as it best

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: agreeth with the conclusions they would inferre, or the actions

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they approve. To avoyd which mistakes, and render to those termes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Commanding, Counselling, and Exhorting, their proper and distinct

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: significations, I define them thus.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Differences Between Command And Counsell

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: COMMAND is, where a man saith, "Doe this," or "Doe this not," without

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: expecting other reason than the Will of him that sayes it. From this it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: followeth manifestly, that he that Commandeth, pretendeth thereby his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: own Benefit: For the reason of his Command is his own Will onely, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the proper object of every mans Will, is some Good to himselfe.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: COUNSELL, is where a man saith, "Doe" or "Doe not this," and deduceth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his own reasons from the benefit that arriveth by it to him to whom he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: saith it. And from this it is evident, that he that giveth Counsell,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: pretendeth onely (whatsoever he intendeth) the good of him, to whom he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: giveth it.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Therefore between Counsell and Command, one great difference is, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Command is directed to a mans own benefit; and Counsell to the benefit

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of another man. And from this ariseth another difference, that a man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: may be obliged to do what he is Commanded; as when he hath covenanted

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to obey: But he cannot be obliged to do as he is Counselled, because the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hurt of not following it, is his own; or if he should covenant to follow

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it, then is the Counsell turned into the nature of a Command. A third

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: difference between them is, that no man can pretend a right to be of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: another mans Counsell; because he is not to pretend benefit by it to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: himselfe; but to demand right to Counsell another, argues a will to know

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his designes, or to gain some other Good to himselfe; which (as I said

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: before) is of every mans will the proper object.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: This also is incident to the nature of Counsell; that whatsoever it be,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he that asketh it, cannot in equity accuse, or punish it: For to ask

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Counsell of another, is to permit him to give such Counsell as he shall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: think best; And consequently, he that giveth counsell to his Soveraign,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (whether a Monarch, or an Assembly) when he asketh it, cannot in equity

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be punished for it, whether the same be conformable to the opinion of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the most, or not, so it be to the Proposition in debate. For if the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sense of the Assembly can be taken notice of, before the Debate be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ended, they should neither ask, nor take any further Counsell; For the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sense of the Assembly, is the Resolution of the Debate, and End of all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Deliberation. And generally he that demandeth Counsell, is Author of it;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and therefore cannot punish it; and what the Soveraign cannot, no man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: else can. But if one Subject giveth Counsell to another, to do any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thing contrary to the Lawes, whether that Counsell proceed from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: evill intention, or from ignorance onely, it is punishable by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth; because ignorance of the Law, is no good excuse, where

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: every man is bound to take notice of the Lawes to which he is subject.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Exhortation And Dehortation What

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: EXHORTATION, and DEHORTATION, is Counsell, accompanied with signes in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him that giveth it, of vehement desire to have it followed; or to say it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: more briefly, Counsell Vehemently Pressed. For he that Exhorteth, doth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not deduce the consequences of what he adviseth to be done, and tye

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: himselfe therein to the rigour of true reasoning; but encourages him he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Counselleth, to Action: As he that Dehorteth, deterreth him from it. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore they have in their speeches, a regard to the common Passions,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and opinions of men, in deducing their reasons; and make use of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Similitudes, Metaphors, Examples, and other tooles of Oratory, to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: perswade their Hearers of the Utility, Honour, or Justice of following

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their advise.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: From whence may be inferred, First, that Exhortation and Dehortation,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is directed to the Good of him that giveth the Counsell, not of him that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: asketh it, which is contrary to the duty of a Counsellour; who (by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: definition of Counsell) ought to regard, not his own benefits, but his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whom he adviseth. And that he directeth his Counsell to his own

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: benefit, is manifest enough, by the long and vehement urging, or by
