author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the artificial giving thereof; which being not required of him, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consequently proceeding from his own occasions, is directed principally

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to his own benefit, and but accidentarily to the good of him that is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Counselled, or not at all.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Secondly, that the use of Exhortation and Dehortation lyeth onely, where

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a man is to speak to a Multitude; because when the Speech is addressed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to one, he may interrupt him, and examine his reasons more rigorously,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: than can be done in a Multitude; which are too many to enter into

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Dispute, and Dialogue with him that speaketh indifferently to them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all at once. Thirdly, that they that Exhort and Dehort, where they are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: required to give Counsell, are corrupt Counsellours, and as it were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: bribed by their own interest. For though the Counsell they give be never

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: so good; yet he that gives it, is no more a good Counsellour, than he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that giveth a Just Sentence for a reward, is a just Judge. But where a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man may lawfully Command, as a Father in his Family, or a Leader in an

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Army, his Exhortations and Dehortations, are not onely lawfull, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: also necessary, and laudable: But then they are no more Counsells, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Commands; which when they are for Execution of soure labour; sometimes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: necessity, and alwayes humanity requireth to be sweetned in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: delivery, by encouragement, and in the tune and phrase of Counsell,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: rather then in harsher language of Command.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Examples of the difference between Command and Counsell, we may take

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from the formes of Speech that expresse them in Holy Scripture. "Have no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other Gods but me; Make to thy selfe no graven Image; Take not Gods name

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in vain; Sanctifie the Sabbath; Honour thy Parents; Kill not; Steale

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not," &c. are Commands; because the reason for which we are to obey

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them, is drawn from the will of God our King, whom we are obliged to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: obey. But these words, "Sell all thou hast; give it to the poore; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: follow me," are Counsell; because the reason for which we are to do

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: so, is drawn from our own benefit; which is this, that we shall have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "Treasure in Heaven." These words, "Go into the village over against

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: you, and you shall find an Asse tyed, and her Colt; loose her, and bring

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: her to me," are a Command: for the reason of their fact is drawn from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the will of their Master: but these words, "Repent, and be Baptized in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Name of Jesus," are Counsell; because the reason why we should so

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: do, tendeth not to any benefit of God Almighty, who shall still be King

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in what manner soever we rebell; but of our selves, who have no other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: means of avoyding the punishment hanging over us for our sins.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Differences Of Fit And Unfit Counsellours

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: As the difference of Counsell from Command, hath been now deduced from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the nature of Counsell, consisting in a deducing of the benefit, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hurt that may arise to him that is to be Counselled, by the necessary

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or probable consequences of the action he propoundeth; so may also the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: differences between apt, and inept counsellours be derived from the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: same. For Experience, being but Memory of the consequences of like

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: actions formerly observed, and Counsell but the Speech whereby that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: experience is made known to another; the Vertues, and Defects of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Counsell, are the same with the Vertues, and Defects Intellectuall:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And to the Person of a Common-wealth, his Counsellours serve him in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: place of Memory, and Mentall Discourse. But with this resemblance of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth, to a naturall man, there is one dissimilitude joyned,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of great importance; which is, that a naturall man receiveth his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: experience, from the naturall objects of sense, which work upon him

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: without passion, or interest of their own; whereas they that give

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Counsell to the Representative person of a Common-wealth, may have,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and have often their particular ends, and passions, that render their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Counsells alwayes suspected, and many times unfaithfull. And therefore

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: we may set down for the first condition of a good Counsellour, That His

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ends, And Interest, Be Not Inconsistent With The Ends And Interest Of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Him He Counselleth.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Secondly, Because the office of a Counsellour, when an action comes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: into deliberation, is to make manifest the consequences of it, in such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: manner, as he that is Counselled may be truly and evidently informed; he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ought to propound his advise, in such forme of speech, as may make

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the truth most evidently appear; that is to say, with as firme

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ratiocination, as significant and proper language, and as briefly, as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the evidence will permit. And therefore Rash, And Unevident Inferences;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (such as are fetched onely from Examples, or authority of Books, and are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not arguments of what is good, or evill, but witnesses of fact, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of opinion,) Obscure, Confused, And Ambiguous Expressions, Also All

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Metaphoricall Speeches, Tending To The Stirring Up Of Passion, (because

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such reasoning, and such expressions, are usefull onely to deceive, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to lead him we Counsell towards other ends than his own) Are Repugnant

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To The Office Of A Counsellour.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Thirdly, Because the Ability of Counselling proceedeth from Experience,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and long study; and no man is presumed to have experience in all those

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: things that to the Administration of a great Common-wealth are necessary

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to be known, No Man Is Presumed To Be A Good Counsellour, But In Such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Businesse, As He Hath Not Onely Been Much Versed In, But Hath Also

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Much Meditated On, And Considered. For seeing the businesse of a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth is this, to preserve the people at home, and defend them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: against forraign Invasion, we shall find, it requires great knowledge

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the disposition of Man-kind, of the Rights of Government, and of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: nature of Equity, Law, Justice, and Honour, not to be attained without

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: study; And of the Strength, Commodities, Places, both of their own

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Country, and their Neighbours; as also of the inclinations, and designes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of all Nations that may any way annoy them. And this is not attained to,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: without much experience. Of which things, not onely the whole summe, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: every one of the particulars requires the age, and observation of a man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in years, and of more than ordinary study. The wit required for Counsel,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as I have said before is Judgement. And the differences of men in that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: point come from different education, of some to one kind of study, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: businesse, and of others to another. When for the doing of any thing,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there be Infallible rules, (as in Engines, and Edifices, the rules of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Geometry,) all the experience of the world cannot equall his Counsell,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that has learnt, or found out the Rule. And when there is no such Rule,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he that hath most experience in that particular kind of businesse, has

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therein the best Judgement, and is the best Counsellour.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Fourthly, to be able to give Counsell to a Common-wealth, in a businesse

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that hath reference to another Common-wealth, It Is Necessary To Be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Acquainted With The Intelligences, And Letters That Come From Thence,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And With All The Records Of Treaties, And Other Transactions Of State

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Between Them; which none can doe, but such as the Representative

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shall think fit. By which we may see, that they who are not called to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Counsell, can have no good Counsell in such cases to obtrude.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Fifthly, Supposing the number of Counsellors equall, a man is better

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Counselled by hearing them apart, then in an Assembly; and that for many

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: causes. First, in hearing them apart, you have the advice of every man;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but in an Assembly may of them deliver their advise with I, or No, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with their hands, or feet, not moved by their own sense, but by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: eloquence of another, or for feare of displeasing some that have spoken,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or the whole Assembly, by contradiction; or for feare of appearing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: duller in apprehension, than those that have applauded the contrary

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: opinion. Secondly, in an Assembly of many, there cannot choose but be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: some whose interests are contrary to that of the Publique; and these

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their Interests make passionate, and Passion eloquent, and Eloquence

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: drawes others into the same advice. For the Passions of men, which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: asunder are moderate, as the heat of one brand; in Assembly are like

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: many brands, that enflame one another, (especially when they blow one

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: another with Orations) to the setting of the Common-wealth on fire,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: under pretence of Counselling it. Thirdly, in hearing every man apart,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: one may examine (when there is need) the truth, or probability of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his reasons, and of the grounds of the advise he gives, by frequent

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: interruptions, and objections; which cannot be done in an Assembly,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: where (in every difficult question) a man is rather astonied, and dazled

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with the variety of discourse upon it, than informed of the course he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ought to take. Besides, there cannot be an Assembly of many, called

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: together for advice, wherein there be not some, that have the ambition

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to be thought eloquent, and also learned in the Politiques; and give not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their advice with care of the businesse propounded, but of the applause

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of their motly orations, made of the divers colored threds, or shreds of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Authors; which is an Impertinence at least, that takes away the time

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of serious Consultation, and in the secret way of Counselling apart, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: easily avoided. Fourthly, in Deliberations that ought to be kept secret,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (whereof there be many occasions in Publique Businesse,) the Counsells

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of many, and especially in Assemblies, are dangerous; And therefore

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: great Assemblies are necessitated to commit such affaires to lesser

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: numbers, and of such persons as are most versed, and in whose fidelity

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they have most confidence.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To conclude, who is there that so far approves the taking of Counsell

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from a great Assembly of Counsellours, that wisheth for, or would accept

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of their pains, when there is a question of marrying his Children,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: disposing of his Lands, governing his Household, or managing his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: private Estate, especially if there be amongst them such as wish not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his prosperity? A man that doth his businesse by the help of many and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: prudent Counsellours, with every one consulting apart in his proper

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: element, does it best, as he that useth able Seconds at Tennis play,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: placed in their proper stations. He does next best, that useth his own

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Judgement only; as he that has no Second at all. But he that is carried

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: up and down to his businesse in a framed Counsell, which cannot move

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but by the plurality of consenting opinions, the execution whereof is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: commonly (out of envy, or interest) retarded by the part dissenting,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: does it worst of all, and like one that is carried to the ball, though

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by good Players, yet in a Wheele-barrough, or other frame, heavy of it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: self, and retarded also by the inconcurrent judgements, and endeavours

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of them that drive it; and so much the more, as they be more that set

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their hands to it; and most of all, when there is one, or more amongst

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them, that desire to have him lose. And though it be true, that many eys

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: see more then one; yet it is not to be understood of many Counsellours;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but then only, when the finall Resolution is in one man. Otherwise,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: because many eyes see the same thing in divers lines, and are apt to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: look asquint towards their private benefit; they that desire not to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: misse their marke, though they look about with two eyes, yet they never

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ayme but with one; And therefore no great Popular Common-wealth was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ever kept up; but either by a forraign Enemy that united them; or by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the reputation of some one eminent Man amongst them; or by the secret

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Counsell of a few; or by the mutuall feare of equall factions; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not by the open Consultations of the Assembly. And as for very little

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealths, be they Popular, or Monarchicall, there is no humane

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: wisdome can uphold them, longer then the Jealousy lasteth of their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: potent Neighbours.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CHAPTER XXVI. OF CIVILL LAWES

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Civill Law what

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: By CIVILL LAWES, I understand the Lawes, that men are therefore bound to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: observe, because they are Members, not of this, or that Common-wealth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in particular, but of a Common-wealth. For the knowledge of particular

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lawes belongeth to them, that professe the study of the Lawes of their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: severall Countries; but the knowledge of Civill Law in generall, to any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man. The antient Law of Rome was called their Civil Law, from the word

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Civitas, which signifies a Common-wealth; And those Countries, which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: having been under the Roman Empire, and governed by that Law, retaine

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: still such part thereof as they think fit, call that part the Civill

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Law, to distinguish it from the rest of their own Civill Lawes. But that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is not it I intend to speak of here; my designe being not to shew what

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is Law here, and there; but what is Law; as Plato, Aristotle, Cicero,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and divers others have done, without taking upon them the profession of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the study of the Law.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And first it manifest, that Law in generall, is not Counsell, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Command; nor a Command of any man to any man; but only of him, whose

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Command is addressed to one formerly obliged to obey him. And as for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Civill Law, it addeth only the name of the person Commanding, which is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Persona Civitatis, the Person of the Common-wealth.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Which considered, I define Civill Law in this Manner. "CIVILL LAW, Is to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: every Subject, those Rules, which the Common-wealth hath Commanded him,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by Word, Writing, or other sufficient Sign of the Will, to make use

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of, for the Distinction of Right, and Wrong; that is to say, of what is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: contrary, and what is not contrary to the Rule."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In which definition, there is nothing that is not at first sight

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: evident. For every man seeth, that some Lawes are addressed to all the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Subjects in generall; some to particular Provinces; some to particular

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Vocations; and some to particular Men; and are therefore Lawes, to every

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of those to whom the Command is directed; and to none else. As also,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that Lawes are the Rules of Just, and Unjust; nothing being reputed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Unjust, that is not contrary to some Law. Likewise, that none can

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: make Lawes but the Common-wealth; because our Subjection is to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth only: and that Commands, are to be signified by sufficient

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Signs; because a man knows not otherwise how to obey them. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore, whatsoever can from this definition by necessary consequence

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be deduced, ought to be acknowledged for truth. Now I deduce from it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: this that followeth.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Soveraign Is Legislator

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 1. The Legislator in all Common-wealths, is only the Soveraign, be he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: one Man, as in a Monarchy, or one Assembly of men, as in a Democracy,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or Aristocracy. For the Legislator, is he that maketh the Law. And the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth only, praescribes, and commandeth the observation of those

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: rules, which we call Law: Therefore the Common-wealth is the Legislator.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But the Common-wealth is no Person, nor has capacity to doe any thing,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but by the Representative, (that is, the Soveraign;) and therefore the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign is the sole Legislator. For the same reason, none can abrogate

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Law made, but the Soveraign; because a Law is not abrogated, but by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: another Law, that forbiddeth it to be put in execution.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And Not Subject To Civill Law

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 2. The Soveraign of a Common-wealth, be it an Assembly, or one Man, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not subject to the Civill Lawes. For having power to make, and repeale

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lawes, he may when he pleaseth, free himselfe from that subjection,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by repealing those Lawes that trouble him, and making of new; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consequently he was free before. For he is free, that can be free when

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he will: Nor is it possible for any person to be bound to himselfe;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: because he that can bind, can release; and therefore he that is bound to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: himselfe onely, is not bound.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Use, A Law Not By Vertue Of Time, But Of The Soveraigns Consent

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 3. When long Use obtaineth the authority of a Law, it is not the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Length of Time that maketh the Authority, but the Will of the Soveraign

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: signified by his silence, (for Silence is sometimes an argument of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Consent;) and it is no longer Law, then the Soveraign shall be silent

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therein. And therefore if the Soveraign shall have a question of Right

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: grounded, not upon his present Will, but upon the Lawes formerly

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: made; the Length of Time shal bring no prejudice to his Right; but the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: question shal be judged by Equity. For many unjust Actions, and unjust

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sentences, go uncontrolled a longer time, than any man can remember.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And our Lawyers account no Customes Law, but such as are reasonable, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that evill Customes are to be abolished; But the Judgement of what is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: reasonable, and of what is to be abolished, belongeth to him that maketh

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Law, which is the Soveraign Assembly, or Monarch.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Law Of Nature, And The Civill Law Contain Each Other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 4. The Law of Nature, and the Civill Law, contain each other, and are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of equall extent. For the Lawes of Nature, which consist in Equity,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Justice, Gratitude, and other morall Vertues on these depending, in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: condition of meer Nature (as I have said before in the end of the 15th

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Chapter,) are not properly Lawes, but qualities that dispose men to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: peace, and to obedience. When a Common-wealth is once settled, then are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they actually Lawes, and not before; as being then the commands of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth; and therefore also Civill Lawes: for it is the Soveraign

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Power that obliges men to obey them. For in the differences of private

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: men, to declare, what is Equity, what is Justice, and what is morall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Vertue, and to make them binding, there is need of the Ordinances of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign Power, and Punishments to be ordained for such as shall break

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them; which Ordinances are therefore part of the Civill Law. The Law of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nature therefore is a part of the Civill Law in all Common-wealths of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the world. Reciprocally also, the Civill Law is a part of the Dictates

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Nature. For Justice, that is to say, Performance of Covenant, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: giving to every man his own, is a Dictate of the Law of Nature. But

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: every subject in a Common-wealth, hath covenanted to obey the Civill

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Law, (either one with another, as when they assemble to make a common

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Representative, or with the Representative it selfe one by one, when

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: subdued by the Sword they promise obedience, that they may receive

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: life;) And therefore Obedience to the Civill Law is part also of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Law of Nature. Civill, and Naturall Law are not different kinds, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: different parts of Law; whereof one part being written, is called

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Civill, the other unwritten, Naturall. But the Right of Nature, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is, the naturall Liberty of man, may by the Civill Law be abridged,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and restrained: nay, the end of making Lawes, is no other, but such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Restraint; without the which there cannot possibly be any Peace. And Law

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was brought into the world for nothing else, but to limit the naturall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: liberty of particular men, in such manner, as they might not hurt, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: assist one another, and joyn together against a common Enemy.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Provinciall Lawes Are Not Made By Custome, But By The Soveraign Power

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 5. If the Soveraign of one Common-wealth, subdue a people that have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: lived under other written Lawes, and afterwards govern them by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: same Lawes, by which they were governed before; yet those Lawes are the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Civill Lawes of the Victor, and not of the Vanquished Common-wealth, For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Legislator is he, not by whose authority the Lawes were first made,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but by whose authority they now continue to be Lawes. And therefore

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: where there be divers Provinces, within the Dominion of a Common-wealth,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and in those Provinces diversity of Lawes, which commonly are called the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Customes of each severall Province, we are not to understand that such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Customes have their Force, onely from Length of Time; but that they were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: antiently Lawes written, or otherwise made known, for the Constitutions,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Statutes of their Soveraigns; and are now Lawes, not by vertue of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Praescription of time, but by the Constitutions of their present

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraigns. But if an unwritten Law, in all the Provinces of a Dominion,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shall be generally observed, and no iniquity appear in the use thereof;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that law can be no other but a Law of Nature, equally obliging all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man-kind.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Some Foolish Opinions Of Lawyers Concerning The Making Of Lawes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 6. Seeing then all Lawes, written, and unwritten, have their Authority,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and force, from the Will of the Common-wealth; that is to say, from the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Will of the Representative; which in a Monarchy is the Monarch, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in other Common-wealths the Soveraign Assembly; a man may wonder from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whence proceed such opinions, as are found in the Books of Lawyers of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: eminence in severall Common-wealths, directly, or by consequence making

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Legislative Power depend on private men, or subordinate Judges.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: As for example, "That the Common Law, hath no Controuler but the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Parlament;" which is true onely where a Parlament has the Soveraign

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Power, and cannot be assembled, nor dissolved, but by their own

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: discretion. For if there be a right in any else to dissolve them, there

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is a right also to controule them, and consequently to controule their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: controulings. And if there be no such right, then the Controuler of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lawes is not Parlamentum, but Rex In Parlamento. And where a Parlament

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is Soveraign, if it should assemble never so many, or so wise men, from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Countries subject to them, for whatsoever cause; yet there is no man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: will believe, that such an Assembly hath thereby acquired to themselves

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Legislative Power. Item, that the two arms of a Common-wealth,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are Force, and Justice; The First Whereof Is In The King; The Other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Deposited In The Hands Of The Parlament. As if a Common-wealth could

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consist, where the Force were in any hand, which Justice had not the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Authority to command and govern.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 7. That Law can never be against Reason, our Lawyers are agreed; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that not the Letter,(that is, every construction of it,) but that which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is according to the Intention of the Legislator, is the Law. And it is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: true: but the doubt is, of whose Reason it is, that shall be received

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for Law. It is not meant of any private Reason; for then there would be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as much contradiction in the Lawes, as there is in the Schooles; nor yet

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (as Sr. Ed, Coke makes it (Sir Edward Coke, upon Littleton Lib.2. Ch.6

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: fol 97.b),) an Artificiall Perfection of Reason, Gotten By Long Study,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Observation, And Experience, (as his was.) For it is possible long study

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: may encrease, and confirm erroneous Sentences: and where men build on

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: false grounds, the more they build, the greater is the ruine; and of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: those that study, and observe with equall time, and diligence, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: reasons and resolutions are, and must remain discordant: and therefore

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it is not that Juris Prudentia, or wisedome of subordinate Judges;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but the Reason of this our Artificiall Man the Common-wealth, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his Command, that maketh Law: And the Common-wealth being in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their Representative but one Person, there cannot easily arise any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: contradiction in the Lawes; and when there doth, the same Reason is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: able, by interpretation, or alteration, to take it away. In all Courts

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Justice, the Soveraign (which is the Person of the Common-wealth,)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is he that Judgeth: The subordinate Judge, ought to have regard to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: reason, which moved his Soveraign to make such Law, that his Sentence

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: may be according thereunto; which then is his Soveraigns Sentence;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: otherwise it is his own, and an unjust one.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Law Made, If Not Also Made Known, Is No Law

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 8. From this, that the Law is a Command, and a Command consisteth in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: declaration, or manifestation of the will of him that commandeth, by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: voyce, writing, or some other sufficient argument of the same, we may

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: understand, that the Command of the Common-wealth, is Law onely to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: those, that have means to take notice of it. Over naturall fooles,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: children, or mad-men there is no Law, no more than over brute beasts;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: nor are they capable of the title of just, or unjust; because they had

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: never power to make any covenant, or to understand the consequences

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thereof; and consequently never took upon them to authorise the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: actions of any Soveraign, as they must do that make to themselves a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth. And as those from whom Nature, or Accident hath taken

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: away the notice of all Lawes in generall; so also every man, from whom

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: any accident, not proceeding from his own default, hath taken away the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: means to take notice of any particular Law, is excused, if he observe it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not; And to speak properly, that Law is no Law to him. It is therefore

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: necessary, to consider in this place, what arguments, and signes be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sufficient for the knowledge of what is the Law; that is to say, what is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the will of the Soveraign, as well in Monarchies, as in other formes of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: government.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Unwritten Lawes Are All Of Them Lawes Of Nature

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And first, if it be a Law that obliges all the Subjects without

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: exception, and is not written, nor otherwise published in such places as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they may take notice thereof, it is a Law of Nature. For whatsoever men

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are to take knowledge of for Law, not upon other mens words, but every

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: one from his own reason, must be such as is agreeable to the reason of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all men; which no Law can be, but the Law of Nature. The Lawes of Nature

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore need not any publishing, nor Proclamation; as being contained

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in this one Sentence, approved by all the world, "Do not that to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: another, which thou thinkest unreasonable to be done by another to thy

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: selfe."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Secondly, if it be a Law that obliges only some condition of men, or one

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: particular man and be not written, nor published by word, then also it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is a Law of Nature; and known by the same arguments, and signs,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that distinguish those in such a condition, from other Subjects. For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whatsoever Law is not written, or some way published by him that makes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it Law, can be known no way, but by the reason of him that is to obey

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it; and is therefore also a Law not only Civill, but Naturall. For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: example, if the Soveraign employ a Publique Minister, without written

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Instructions what to doe; he is obliged to take for Instructions the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Dictates of Reason; As if he make a Judge, The Judge is to take notice,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that his Sentence ought to be according to the reason of his Soveraign,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which being alwaies understood to be Equity, he is bound to it by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Law of Nature: Or if an Ambassador, he is (in al things not conteined

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in his written Instructions) to take for Instruction that which Reason

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: dictates to be most conducing to his Soveraigns interest; and so of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all other Ministers of the Soveraignty, publique and private. All which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Instructions of naturall Reason may be comprehended under one name of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Fidelity; which is a branch of naturall Justice.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Law of Nature excepted, it belongeth to the essence of all other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lawes, to be made known, to every man that shall be obliged to obey

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them, either by word, or writing, or some other act, known to proceed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from the Soveraign Authority. For the will of another, cannot be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: understood, but by his own word, or act, or by conjecture taken from his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: scope and purpose; which in the person of the Common-wealth, is to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: supposed alwaies consonant to Equity and Reason. And in antient time,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: before letters were in common use, the Lawes were many times put into

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: verse; that the rude people taking pleasure in singing, or reciting

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them, might the more easily reteine them in memory. And for the same

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: reason Solomon adviseth a man, to bind the ten Commandements (Prov. 7.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 3) upon his ten fingers. And for the Law which Moses gave to the people

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Israel at the renewing of the Covenant, (Deut. 11. 19) he biddeth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them to teach it their Children, by discoursing of it both at home, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: upon the way; at going to bed, and at rising from bed; and to write

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it upon the posts, and dores of their houses; and (Deut. 31. 12) to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: assemble the people, man, woman, and child, to heare it read.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nothing Is Law Where The Legislator Cannot Be Known

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nor is it enough the Law be written, and published; but also that there

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be manifest signs, that it proceedeth from the will of the Soveraign.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For private men, when they have, or think they have force enough to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: secure their unjust designes, and convoy them safely to their ambitious

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ends, may publish for Lawes what they please, without, or against

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Legislative Authority. There is therefore requisite, not only a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Declaration of the Law, but also sufficient signes of the Author, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Authority. The Author, or Legislator is supposed in every Common-wealth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to be evident, because he is the Soveraign, who having been Constituted

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by the consent of every one, is supposed by every one to be sufficiently

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: known. And though the ignorance, and security of men be such, for the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: most part, as that when the memory of the first Constitution of their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth is worn out, they doe not consider, by whose power they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: use to be defended against their enemies, and to have their industry

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: protected, and to be righted when injury is done them; yet because no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man that considers, can make question of it, no excuse can be derived

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from the ignorance of where the Soveraignty is placed. And it is a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Dictate of Naturall Reason, and consequently an evident Law of Nature,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that no man ought to weaken that power, the protection whereof he hath

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: himself demanded, or wittingly received against others. Therefore of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: who is Soveraign, no man, but by his own fault, (whatsoever evill men

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: suggest,) can make any doubt. The difficulty consisteth in the evidence

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Authority derived from him; The removing whereof, dependeth on

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the knowledge of the publique Registers, publique Counsels, publique

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ministers, and publique Seales; by which all Lawes are sufficiently

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: verified.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Difference Between Verifying And Authorising

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Verifyed, I say, not Authorised: for the Verification, is but the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Testimony and Record; not the Authority of the law; which consisteth in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Command of the Soveraign only.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Law Verifyed By The Subordinate Judge

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: If therefore a man have a question of Injury, depending on the Law of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nature; that is to say, on common Equity; the Sentence of the Judge,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that by Commission hath Authority to take cognisance of such causes, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a sufficient Verification of the Law of Nature in that individuall case.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For though the advice of one that professeth the study of the Law, be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: usefull for the avoyding of contention; yet it is but advice; tis the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Judge must tell men what is Law, upon the hearing of the Controversy.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: By The Publique Registers

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But when the question is of injury, or crime, upon a written Law; every

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man by recourse to the Registers, by himself, or others, may (if he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: will) be sufficiently enformed, before he doe such injury, or commit the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: crime, whither it be an injury, or not: Nay he ought to doe so: for when

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a man doubts whether the act he goeth about, be just, or injust; and may

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: informe himself, if he will; the doing is unlawfull. In like manner, he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that supposeth himself injured, in a case determined by the written Law,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which he may by himself, or others see and consider; if he complaine

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: before he consults with the Law, he does unjustly, and bewrayeth a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: disposition rather to vex other men, than to demand his own right.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: By Letters Patent, And Publique Seale

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: If the question be of Obedience to a publique Officer; To have seen his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Commission, with the Publique Seale, and heard it read; or to have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: had the means to be informed of it, if a man would, is a sufficient

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Verification of his Authority. For every man is obliged to doe his best

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: endeavour, to informe himself of all written Lawes, that may concerne

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his own future actions.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Interpretation Of The Law Dependeth On The Soveraign Power

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Legislator known; and the Lawes, either by writing, or by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: light of Nature, sufficiently published; there wanteth yet another

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: very materiall circumstance to make them obligatory. For it is not the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Letter, but the Intendment, or Meaning; that is to say, the authentique

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Interpretation of the Law (which is the sense of the Legislator,) in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which the nature of the Law consisteth; And therefore the Interpretation

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of all Lawes dependeth on the Authority Soveraign; and the Interpreters

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: can be none but those, which the Soveraign, (to whom only the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Subject oweth obedience) shall appoint. For else, by the craft of an

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Interpreter, the Law my be made to beare a sense, contrary to that of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Soveraign; by which means the Interpreter becomes the Legislator.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: All Lawes Need Interpretation

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: All Laws, written, and unwritten, have need of Interpretation.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The unwritten Law of Nature, though it be easy to such, as without

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: partiality, and passion, make use of their naturall reason, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore leaves the violators thereof without excuse; yet considering

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there be very few, perhaps none, that in some cases are not blinded by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: self love, or some other passion, it is now become of all Laws the most

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: obscure; and has consequently the greatest need of able Interpreters.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The written Laws, if they be short, are easily mis-interpreted, from the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: divers significations of a word, or two; if long, they be more obscure

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by the diverse significations of many words: in so much as no written

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Law, delivered in few, or many words, can be well understood, without a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: perfect understanding of the finall causes, for which the Law was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: made; the knowledge of which finall causes is in the Legislator. To him

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore there can not be any knot in the Law, insoluble; either by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: finding out the ends, to undoe it by; or else by making what ends he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: will, (as Alexander did with his sword in the Gordian knot,) by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Legislative power; which no other Interpreter can doe.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Authenticall Interpretation Of Law Is Not That Of Writers

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Interpretation of the Lawes of Nature, in a Common-wealth, dependeth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not on the books of Morall Philosophy. The Authority of writers, without

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Authority of the Common-wealth, maketh not their opinions Law,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be they never so true. That which I have written in this Treatise,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: concerning the Morall Vertues, and of their necessity, for the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: procuring, and maintaining peace, though it bee evident Truth, is not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore presently Law; but because in all Common-wealths in the world,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it is part of the Civill Law: For though it be naturally reasonable; yet

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it is by the Soveraigne Power that it is Law: Otherwise, it were a great

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: errour, to call the Lawes of Nature unwritten Law; whereof wee see

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: so many volumes published, and in them so many contradictions of one

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: another, and of themselves.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Interpreter Of The Law Is The Judge Giving Sentence Viva Voce

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In Every Particular Case

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Interpretation of the Law of Nature, is the Sentence of the Judge

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: constituted by the Soveraign Authority, to heare and determine such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: controversies, as depend thereon; and consisteth in the application of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Law to the present case. For in the act of Judicature, the Judge

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: doth no more but consider, whither the demand of the party, be consonant

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to naturall reason, and Equity; and the Sentence he giveth, is therefore

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Interpretation of the Law of Nature; which Interpretation is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Authentique; not because it is his private Sentence; but because

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he giveth it by Authority of the Soveraign, whereby it becomes the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraigns Sentence; which is Law for that time, to the parties

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: pleading.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Sentence Of A Judge, Does Not Bind Him, Or Another Judge

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To Give Like Sentence In Like Cases Ever After

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But because there is no Judge Subordinate, nor Soveraign, but may erre

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in a Judgement of Equity; if afterward in another like case he find it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: more consonant to Equity to give a contrary Sentence, he is obliged to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: doe it. No mans error becomes his own Law; nor obliges him to persist

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in it. Neither (for the same reason) becomes it a Law to other Judges,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: though sworn to follow it. For though a wrong Sentence given by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: authority of the Soveraign, if he know and allow it, in such Lawes as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are mutable, be a constitution of a new Law, in cases, in which every

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: little circumstance is the same; yet in Lawes immutable, such as are the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lawes of Nature, they are no Lawes to the same, or other Judges, in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: like cases for ever after. Princes succeed one another; and one Judge

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: passeth, another commeth; nay, Heaven and Earth shall passe; but not one

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: title of the Law of Nature shall passe; for it is the Eternall Law of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: God. Therefore all the Sentences of precedent Judges that have ever

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: been, cannot all together make a Law contrary to naturall Equity: Nor

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: any Examples of former Judges, can warrant an unreasonable Sentence, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: discharge the present Judge of the trouble of studying what is Equity

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (in the case he is to Judge,) from the principles of his own naturall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: reason. For example sake, 'Tis against the Law of Nature, To Punish The

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Innocent; and Innocent is he that acquitteth himselfe Judicially, and is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: acknowledged for Innocent by the Judge. Put the case now, that a man is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: accused of a capitall crime, and seeing the powers and malice of some

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: enemy, and the frequent corruption and partiality of Judges, runneth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: away for feare of the event, and afterwards is taken, and brought to a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: legall triall, and maketh it sufficiently appear, he was not guilty of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the crime, and being thereof acquitted, is neverthelesse condemned to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: lose his goods; this is a manifest condemnation of the Innocent. I say

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore, that there is no place in the world, where this can be an

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: interpretation of a Law of Nature, or be made a Law by the Sentences of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: precedent Judges, that had done the same. For he that judged it first,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: judged unjustly; and no Injustice can be a pattern of Judgement to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: succeeding Judges. A written Law may forbid innocent men to fly, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they may be punished for flying: But that flying for feare of injury,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: should be taken for presumption of guilt, after a man is already

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: absolved of the crime Judicially, is contrary to the nature of a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Presumption, which hath no place after Judgement given. Yet this is set

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: down by a great Lawyer for the common Law of England. "If a man," saith

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he, "that is Innocent, be accused of Felony, and for feare flyeth for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the same; albeit he judicially acquitteth himselfe of the Felony; yet

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: if it be found that he fled for the Felony, he shall notwithstanding his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Innocency, Forfeit all his goods, chattels, debts, and duties. For as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to the Forfeiture of them, the Law will admit no proofe against the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Presumption in Law, grounded upon his flight." Here you see, An Innocent

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Man, Judicially Acquitted, Notwithstanding His Innocency, (when no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: written Law forbad him to fly) after his acquitall, Upon A Presumption

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In Law, condemned to lose all the goods he hath. If the Law ground upon

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his flight a Presumption of the fact, (which was Capitall,) the Sentence

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ought to have been Capitall: if the presumption were not of the Fact,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for what then ought he to lose his goods? This therefore is no Law of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: England; nor is the condemnation grounded upon a Presumption of Law, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: upon the Presumption of the Judges. It is also against Law, to say

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that no Proofe shall be admitted against a Presumption of Law. For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all Judges, Soveraign and subordinate, if they refuse to heare Proofe,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: refuse to do Justice: for though the Sentence be Just, yet the Judges

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that condemn without hearing the Proofes offered, are Unjust Judges; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their Presumption is but Prejudice; which no man ought to bring with him

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to the Seat of Justice, whatsoever precedent judgements, or examples he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shall pretend to follow. There be other things of this nature, wherein

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: mens Judgements have been perverted, by trusting to Precedents: but this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is enough to shew, that though the Sentence of the Judge, be a Law to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the party pleading, yet it is no Law to any Judge, that shall succeed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him in that Office.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In like manner, when question is of the Meaning of written Lawes, he is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not the Interpreter of them, that writeth a Commentary upon them. For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Commentaries are commonly more subject to cavill, than the Text; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore need other Commentaries; and so there will be no end of such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Interpretation. And therefore unlesse there be an Interpreter authorised

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by the Soveraign, from which the subordinate Judges are not to recede,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Interpreter can be no other than the ordinary Judges, in the some

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: manner, as they are in cases of the unwritten Law; and their Sentences

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are to be taken by them that plead, for Lawes in that particular case;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but not to bind other Judges, in like cases to give like judgements.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For a Judge may erre in the Interpretation even of written Lawes; but no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: errour of a subordinate Judge, can change the Law, which is the generall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sentence of the Soveraigne.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Difference Between The Letter And Sentence Of The Law

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In written Lawes, men use to make a difference between the Letter, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Sentence of the Law: And when by the Letter, is meant whatsoever

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: can be gathered from the bare words, 'tis well distinguished. For the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: significations of almost all words, are either in themselves, or in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: metaphoricall use of them, ambiguous; and may be drawn in argument, to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: make many senses; but there is onely one sense of the Law. But if by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Letter, be meant the Literall sense, then the Letter, and the Sentence

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or intention of the Law, is all one. For the literall sense is that,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which the Legislator is alwayes supposed to be Equity: For it were a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: great contumely for a Judge to think otherwise of the Soveraigne.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: He ought therefore, if the Word of the Law doe not fully authorise a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: reasonable Sentence, to supply it with the Law of Nature; or if the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: case be difficult, to respit Judgement till he have received more ample

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: authority. For Example, a written Law ordaineth, that he which is thrust

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: out of his house by force, shall be restored by force: It happens that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a man by negligence leaves his house empty, and returning is kept out by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: force, in which case there is no speciall Law ordained. It is evident,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that this case is contained in the same Law: for else there is no remedy

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for him at all; which is to be supposed against the Intention of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Legislator. Again, the word of the Law, commandeth to Judge according

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to the Evidence: A man is accused falsly of a fact, which the Judge saw

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: himself done by another; and not by him that is accused. In this case

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: neither shall the Letter of the Law be followed to the condemnation of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Innocent, nor shall the Judge give Sentence against the evidence

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Witnesses; because the Letter of the Law is to the contrary:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but procure of the Soveraign that another be made Judge, and himselfe

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Witnesse. So that the incommodity that follows the bare words of a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: written Law, may lead him to the Intention of the Law, whereby to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: interpret the same the better; though no Incommodity can warrant a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sentence against the Law. For every Judge of Right, and Wrong, is not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Judge of what is Commodious, or Incommodious to the Common-wealth.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Abilities Required In A Judge

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The abilities required in a good Interpreter of the Law, that is to say,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in a good Judge, are not the same with those of an Advocate; namely the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: study of the Lawes. For a Judge, as he ought to take notice of the Fact,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from none but the Witnesses; so also he ought to take notice of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Law, from nothing but the Statutes, and Constitutions of the Soveraign,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: alledged in the pleading, or declared to him by some that have authority

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from the Soveraign Power to declare them; and need not take care

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: before-hand, what hee shall Judge; for it shall bee given him what hee

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shall say concerning the Fact, by Witnesses; and what hee shall say in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: point of Law, from those that shall in their pleadings shew it, and by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: authority interpret it upon the place. The Lords of Parlament in England

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: were Judges, and most difficult causes have been heard and determined

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by them; yet few of them were much versed in the study of the Lawes,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and fewer had made profession of them: and though they consulted with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lawyers, that were appointed to be present there for that purpose; yet

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they alone had the authority of giving Sentence. In like manner, in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the ordinary trialls of Right, Twelve men of the common People, are the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Judges, and give Sentence, not onely of the Fact, but of the Right; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: pronounce simply for the Complaynant, or for the Defendant; that is to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: say, are Judges not onely of the Fact, but also of the Right: and in a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: question of crime, not onely determine whether done, or not done; but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: also whether it be Murder, Homicide, Felony, Assault, and the like,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which are determinations of Law: but because they are not supposed to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: know the Law of themselves, there is one that hath Authority to enforme

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them of it, in the particular case they are to Judge of. But yet if they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: judge not according to that he tells them, they are not subject thereby

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to any penalty; unlesse it be made appear, they did it against their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consciences, or had been corrupted by reward. The things that make

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a good Judge, or good Interpreter of the Lawes, are, first A Right

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Understanding of that principall Law of Nature called Equity; which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: depending not on the reading of other mens Writings, but on the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: goodnesse of a mans own naturall Reason, and Meditation, is presumed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to be in those most, that have had most leisure, and had the most

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: inclination to meditate thereon. Secondly, Contempt Of Unnecessary

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Riches, and Preferments. Thirdly, To Be Able In Judgement To Devest

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Himselfe Of All Feare, Anger, Hatred, Love, And Compassion. Fourthly,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and lastly, Patience To Heare; Diligent Attention In Hearing; And Memory

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To Retain, Digest And Apply What He Hath Heard.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Divisions Of Law

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The difference and division of the Lawes, has been made in divers

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: manners, according to the different methods, of those men that have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: written of them. For it is a thing that dependeth not on Nature, but on

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the scope of the Writer; and is subservient to every mans proper method.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In the Institutions of Justinian, we find seven sorts of Civill Lawes.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 1. The Edicts, Constitutions, and Epistles Of The Prince, that is, of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Emperour; because the whole power of the people was in him. Like

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: these, are the Proclamations of the Kings of England.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 2. The Decrees Of The Whole People Of Rome (comprehending the Senate,)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: when they were put to the Question by the Senate. These were Lawes, at

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: first, by the vertue of the Soveraign Power residing in the people; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such of them as by the Emperours were not abrogated, remained Lawes by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Authority Imperiall. For all Lawes that bind, are understood to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lawes by his authority that has power to repeale them. Somewhat like to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: these Lawes, are the Acts of Parliament in England.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 3. The Decrees Of The Common People (excluding the Senate,) when they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: were put to the question by the Tribune of the people. For such of them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as were not abrogated by the Emperours, remained Lawes by the Authority

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Imperiall. Like to these, were the Orders of the House of Commons in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: England.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 4. Senatus Consulta, the Orders Of The Senate; because when the people

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Rome grew so numerous, as it was inconvenient to assemble them; it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was thought fit by the Emperour, that men should Consult the Senate in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: stead of the people: And these have some resemblance with the Acts of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Counsell.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 5. The Edicts Of Praetors, and (in some Cases) of the Aediles: such as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are the Chiefe Justices in the Courts of England.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 6. Responsa Prudentum; which were the Sentences, and Opinions of those

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lawyers, to whom the Emperour gave Authority to interpret the Law, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to give answer to such as in matter of Law demanded their advice;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which Answers, the Judges in giving Judgement were obliged by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Constitutions of the Emperour to observe; And should be like the Reports

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Cases Judged, if other Judges be by the Law of England bound to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: observe them. For the Judges of the Common Law of England, are not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: properly Judges, but Juris Consulti; of whom the Judges, who are either

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Lords, or Twelve men of the Country, are in point of Law to ask

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: advice.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 7. Also, Unwritten Customes, (which in their own nature are an imitation

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Law,) by the tacite consent of the Emperour, in case they be not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: contrary to the Law of Nature, are very Lawes.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Another division of Lawes, is into Naturall and Positive. Naturall are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: those which have been Lawes from all Eternity; and are called not onely

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Naturall, but also Morall Lawes; consisting in the Morall Vertues, as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Justice, Equity, and all habits of the mind that conduce to Peace, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Charity; of which I have already spoken in the fourteenth and fifteenth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Chapters.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Positive, are those which have not been for Eternity; but have been

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: made Lawes by the Will of those that have had the Soveraign Power over

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: others; and are either written, or made known to men, by some other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: argument of the Will of their Legislator.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Another Division Of Law

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Again, of Positive Lawes some are Humane, some Divine; And of Humane

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: positive lawes, some are Distributive, some Penal. Distributive are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: those that determine the Rights of the Subjects, declaring to every man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: what it is, by which he acquireth and holdeth a propriety in lands,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or goods, and a right or liberty of action; and these speak to all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Subjects. Penal are those, which declare, what Penalty shall be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: inflicted on those that violate the Law; and speak to the Ministers

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Officers ordained for execution. For though every one ought to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: informed of the Punishments ordained beforehand for their transgression;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: neverthelesse the Command is not addressed to the Delinquent, (who

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: cannot be supposed will faithfully punish himselfe,) but to publique

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ministers appointed to see the Penalty executed. And these Penal Lawes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are for the most part written together with the Lawes Distributive; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are sometimes called Judgements. For all Lawes are generall judgements,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or Sentences of the Legislator; as also every particular Judgement, is a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Law to him, whose case is Judged.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Divine Positive Law How Made Known To Be Law

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Divine Positive Lawes (for Naturall Lawes being Eternall, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Universall, are all Divine,) are those, which being the Commandements of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: God, (not from all Eternity, nor universally addressed to all men, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: onely to a certain people, or to certain persons,) are declared for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such, by those whom God hath authorised to declare them. But this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Authority of man to declare what be these Positive Lawes of God, how can

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it be known? God may command a man by a supernaturall way, to deliver

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lawes to other men. But because it is of the essence of Law, that he who

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is to be obliged, be assured of the Authority of him that declareth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it, which we cannot naturally take notice to be from God, How Can A Man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Without Supernaturall Revelation Be Assured Of The Revelation Received

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: By The Declarer? and How Can He Be Bound To Obey Them? For the first

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: question, how a man can be assured of the Revelation of another, without

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Revelation particularly to himselfe, it is evidently impossible:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for though a man may be induced to believe such Revelation, from the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Miracles they see him doe, or from seeing the Extraordinary sanctity of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his life, or from seeing the Extraordinary wisedome, or Extraordinary

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: felicity of his Actions, all which are marks of Gods extraordinary

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: favour; yet they are not assured evidence of speciall Revelation.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Miracles are Marvellous workes: but that which is marvellous to one,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: may not be so to another. Sanctity may be feigned; and the visible

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: felicities of this world, are most often the work of God by Naturall,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and ordinary causes. And therefore no man can infallibly know by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: naturall reason, that another has had a supernaturall revelation of Gods

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: will; but only a beliefe; every one (as the signs thereof shall appear

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: greater, or lesser) a firmer, or a weaker belief.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But for the second, how he can be bound to obey them; it is not so hard.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For if the Law declared, be not against the Law of Nature (which is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: undoubtedly Gods Law) and he undertake to obey it, he is bound by his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: own act; bound I say to obey it, but not bound to believe it: for mens

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: beliefe, and interiour cogitations, are not subject to the commands,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but only to the operation of God, ordinary, or extraordinary. Faith of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Supernaturall Law, is not a fulfilling, but only an assenting to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: same; and not a duty that we exhibite to God, but a gift which God

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: freely giveth to whom he pleaseth; as also Unbelief is not a breach

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of any of his Lawes; but a rejection of them all, except the Lawes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Naturall. But this that I say, will be made yet cleerer, by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Examples, and Testimonies concerning this point in holy Scripture. The

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Covenant God made with Abraham (in a Supernaturall Manner) was thus,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (Gen. 17. 10) "This is the Covenant which thou shalt observe between

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Me and Thee and thy Seed after thee." Abrahams Seed had not this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: revelation, nor were yet in being; yet they are a party to the Covenant,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and bound to obey what Abraham should declare to them for Gods Law;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which they could not be, but in vertue of the obedience they owed to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their Parents; who (if they be Subject to no other earthly power, as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: here in the case of Abraham) have Soveraign power over their children,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and servants. Againe, where God saith to Abraham, "In thee shall all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nations of the earth be blessed: For I know thou wilt command thy

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: children, and thy house after thee to keep the way of the Lord, and to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: observe Righteousnesse and Judgement," it is manifest, the obedience of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his Family, who had no Revelation, depended on their former obligation

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to obey their Soveraign. At Mount Sinai Moses only went up to God; the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: people were forbidden to approach on paine of death; yet were they bound

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to obey all that Moses declared to them for Gods Law. Upon what ground,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but on this submission of their own, "Speak thou to us, and we will

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: heare thee; but let not God speak to us, lest we dye?" By which two

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: places it sufficiently appeareth, that in a Common-wealth, a subject

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that has no certain and assured Revelation particularly to himself

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: concerning the Will of God, is to obey for such, the Command of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Common-wealth: for if men were at liberty, to take for Gods

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Commandements, their own dreams, and fancies, or the dreams and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: fancies of private men; scarce two men would agree upon what is Gods

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Commandement; and yet in respect of them, every man would despise the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Commandements of the Common-wealth. I conclude therefore, that in all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: things not contrary to the Morall Law, (that is to say, to the Law of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nature,) all Subjects are bound to obey that for divine Law, which is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: declared to be so, by the Lawes of the Common-wealth. Which also is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: evident to any mans reason; for whatsoever is not against the Law of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nature, may be made Law in the name of them that have the Soveraign

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: power; and there is no reason men should be the lesse obliged by it,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: when tis propounded in the name of God. Besides, there is no place in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the world where men are permitted to pretend other Commandements of God,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: than are declared for such by the Common-wealth. Christian States punish

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: those that revolt from Christian Religion, and all other States, those

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that set up any Religion by them forbidden. For in whatsoever is not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: regulated by the Common-wealth, tis Equity (which is the Law of Nature,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and therefore an eternall Law of God) that every man equally enjoy his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: liberty.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Another Division Of Lawes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: There is also another distinction of Laws, into Fundamentall, and Not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Fundamentall: but I could never see in any Author, what a Fundamentall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Law signifieth. Neverthelesse one may very reasonably distinguish Laws

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in that manner.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: A Fundamentall Law What

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For a Fundamentall Law in every Common-wealth is that, which being taken

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: away, the Common-wealth faileth, and is utterly dissolved; as a building

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whose Foundation is destroyed. And therefore a Fundamentall Law is that,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by which Subjects are bound to uphold whatsoever power is given to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign, whether a Monarch, or a Soveraign Assembly, without which the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth cannot stand, such as is the power of War and Peace, of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Judicature, of Election of Officers, and of doing whatsoever he shall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: think necessary for the Publique good. Not Fundamentall is that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the abrogating whereof, draweth not with it the dissolution of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-Wealth; such as are the Lawes Concerning Controversies between

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: subject and subject. Thus much of the Division of Lawes.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Difference Between Law And Right

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: I find the words Lex Civilis, and Jus Civile, that is to say, Law and

author: Thomas Hobbes
