text: Right Civil, promiscuously used for the same thing, even in the most

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: learned Authors; which neverthelesse ought not to be so. For Right is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Liberty, namely that Liberty which the Civil Law leaves us: But Civill

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Law is an Obligation; and takes from us the Liberty which the Law of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nature gave us. Nature gave a Right to every man to secure himselfe

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by his own strength, and to invade a suspected neighbour, by way of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: prevention; but the Civill Law takes away that Liberty, in all cases

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: where the protection of the Lawe may be safely stayd for. Insomuch as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lex and Jus, are as different as Obligation and Liberty.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And Between A Law And A Charter

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Likewise Lawes and Charters are taken promiscuously for the same

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thing. Yet Charters are Donations of the Soveraign; and not Lawes, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: exemptions from Law. The phrase of a Law is Jubeo, Injungo, I Command,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Enjoyn: the phrase of a Charter is Dedi, Concessi, I Have Given, I

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Have Granted: but what is given or granted, to a man, is not forced

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: upon him, by a Law. A Law may be made to bind All the Subjects of a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth: a Liberty, or Charter is only to One man, or some One

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: part of the people. For to say all the people of a Common-wealth, have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Liberty in any case whatsoever; is to say, that in such case, there hath

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: been no Law made; or else having been made, is now abrogated.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CHAPTER XXVII. OF CRIMES, EXCUSES, AND EXTENUATIONS

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sinne What

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: A Sinne, is not onely a Transgression of a Law, but also any Contempt of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Legislator. For such Contempt, is a breach of all his Lawes at once.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And therefore may consist, not onely in the Commission of a Fact, or in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Speaking of Words by the Lawes forbidden, or in the Omission of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: what the Law commandeth, but also in the Intention, or purpose to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: transgresse. For the purpose to breake the Law, is some degree of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Contempt of him, to whom it belongeth to see it executed. To be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: delighted in the Imagination onely, of being possessed of another mans

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: goods, servants, or wife, without any intention to take them from him

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by force, or fraud, is no breach of the Law, that sayth, "Thou shalt not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: covet:" nor is the pleasure a man my have in imagining, or dreaming of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the death of him, from whose life he expecteth nothing but dammage, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: displeasure, a Sinne; but the resolving to put some Act in execution,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that tendeth thereto. For to be pleased in the fiction of that, which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: would please a man if it were reall, is a Passion so adhaerent to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nature both of a man, and every other living creature, as to make it a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sinne, were to make Sinne of being a man. The consideration of this,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: has made me think them too severe, both to themselves, and others, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: maintain, that the First motions of the mind, (though checked with the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: fear of God) be Sinnes. But I confesse it is safer to erre on that hand,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: than on the other.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: A Crime What

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: A Crime, is a sinne, consisting in the Committing (by Deed, or Word)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of that which the Law forbiddeth, or the Omission of what it hath

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: commanded. So that every Crime is a sinne; but not every sinne a Crime.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To intend to steale, or kill, is a sinne, though it never appeare in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Word, or Fact: for God that seeth the thoughts of man, can lay it to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his charge: but till it appear by some thing done, or said, by which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the intention may be Crime; which distinction the Greeks observed in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the word amartema, and egklema, or aitia; wherof the former, (which is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: translated Sinne,) signifieth any swarving from the Law whatsoever; but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the two later, (which are translated Crime,) signifie that sinne onely,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whereof one man may accuse another. But of Intentions, which never

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: appear by any outward act, there is no place for humane accusation. In

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: like manner the Latines by Peccatum, which is Sinne, signifie all manner

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of deviation from the Law; but by crimen, (which word they derive from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Cerno, which signifies to perceive,) they mean onely such sinnes, as my

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be made appear before a Judge; and therfore are not meer Intentions.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Where No Civill Law Is, There Is No Crime

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: From this relation of Sinne to the Law, and of Crime to the Civill

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Law, may be inferred, First, that where Law ceaseth, Sinne ceaseth.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But because the Law of Nature is eternall, Violation of Covenants,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ingratitude, Arrogance, and all Facts contrary to any Morall vertue, can

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: never cease to be Sinne. Secondly, that the Civill Law ceasing, Crimes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: cease: for there being no other Law remaining, but that of Nature, there

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is no place for Accusation; every man being his own Judge, and accused

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: onely by his own Conscience, and cleared by the Uprightnesse of his own

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Intention. When therefore his Intention is Right, his fact is no Sinne:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: if otherwise, his fact is Sinne; but not Crime. Thirdly, That when the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign Power ceaseth, Crime also ceaseth: for where there is no such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Power, there is no protection to be had from the Law; and therefore

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: every one may protect himself by his own power: for no man in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Institution of Soveraign Power can be supposed to give away the Right

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of preserving his own body; for the safety whereof all Soveraignty was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ordained. But this is to be understood onely of those, that have not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: themselves contributed to the taking away of the Power that protected

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them: for that was a Crime from the beginning.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ignorance Of The Law Of Nature Excuseth No Man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The source of every Crime, is some defect of the Understanding; or some

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: errour in Reasoning, or some sudden force of the Passions. Defect in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Understanding, is Ignorance; in Reasoning, Erroneous Opinion. Again,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ignorance is of three sort; of the Law, and of the Soveraign, and of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Penalty. Ignorance of the Law of Nature Excuseth no man; because every

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man that hath attained to the use of Reason, is supposed to know, he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ought not to do to another, what he would not have done to himselfe.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Therefore into what place soever a man shall come, if he do any thing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: contrary to that Law, it is a Crime. If a man come from the Indies

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hither, and perswade men here to receive a new Religion, or teach them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: any thing that tendeth to disobedience of the Lawes of this Country,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: though he be never so well perswaded of the truth of what he teacheth,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he commits a Crime, and may be justly punished for the same, not onely

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: because his doctrine is false, but also because he does that which he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: would not approve in another, namely, that comming from hence, he should

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: endeavour to alter the Religion there. But ignorance of the Civill Law,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shall Excuse a man in a strange Country, till it be declared to him;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: because, till then no Civill Law is binding.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ignorance Of The Civill Law Excuseth Sometimes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In the like manner, if the Civill Law of a mans own Country, be not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: so sufficiently declared, as he may know it if he will; nor the Action

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: against the Law of Nature; the Ignorance is a good Excuse: In other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: cases ignorance of the Civill Law, Excuseth not.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ignorance Of The Soveraign Excuseth Not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ignorance of the Soveraign Power, in the place of a mans ordinary

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: residence, Excuseth him not; because he ought to take notice of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Power, by which he hath been protected there.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ignorance Of The Penalty Excuseth Not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ignorance of the Penalty, where the Law is declared, Excuseth no man:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For in breaking the Law, which without a fear of penalty to follow, were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not a Law, but vain words, he undergoeth the penalty, though he know not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: what it is; because, whosoever voluntarily doth any action, accepteth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all the known consequences of it; but Punishment is a known consequence

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the violation of the Lawes, in every Common-wealth; which punishment,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: if it be determined already by the Law, he is subject to that; if not,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: then is he subject to Arbitrary punishment. For it is reason, that he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which does Injury, without other limitation than that of his own Will,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: should suffer punishment without other limitation, than that of his Will

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whose Law is thereby violated.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Punishments Declared Before The Fact, Excuse From Greater Punishments

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: After It

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But when a penalty, is either annexed to the Crime in the Law it selfe,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or hath been usually inflicted in the like cases; there the Delinquent

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is Excused from a greater penalty. For the punishment foreknown, if not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: great enough to deterre men from the action, is an invitement to it:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: because when men compare the benefit of their Injustice, with the harm

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of their punishment, by necessity of Nature they choose that which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: appeareth best for themselves; and therefore when they are punished more

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: than the Law had formerly determined, or more than others were punished

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for the same Crime; it the Law that tempted, and deceiveth them.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nothing Can Be Made A Crime By A Law Made After The Fact

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: No Law, made after a Fact done, can make it a Crime: because if the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Fact be against the Law of Nature, the Law was before the Fact; and a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Positive Law cannot be taken notice of, before it be made; and therefore

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: cannot be Obligatory. But when the Law that forbiddeth a Fact, is made

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: before the Fact be done; yet he that doth the Fact, is lyable to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Penalty ordained after, in case no lesser Penalty were made known

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: before, neither by Writing, nor by Example, for the reason immediatly

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: before alledged.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: False Principles Of Right And Wrong Causes Of Crime

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: From defect in Reasoning, (that is to say, from Errour,) men are prone

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to violate the Lawes, three wayes. First, by Presumption of false

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Principles; as when men from having observed how in all places, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in all ages, unjust Actions have been authorised, by the force, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: victories of those who have committed them; and that potent men,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: breaking through the Cob-web Lawes of their Country, the weaker sort,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and those that have failed in their Enterprises, have been esteemed the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: onely Criminals; have thereupon taken for Principles, and grounds of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their Reasoning, "That Justice is but a vain word: That whatsoever a man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: can get by his own Industry, and hazard, is his own: That the Practice

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of all Nations cannot be unjust: That examples of former times are good

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Arguments of doing the like again;" and many more of that kind: Which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: being granted, no Act in it selfe can be a Crime, but must be made so

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (not by the Law, but) by the successe of them that commit it; and the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: same Fact be vertuous, or vicious, as Fortune pleaseth; so that what

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Marius makes a Crime, Sylla shall make meritorious, and Caesar (the same

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lawes standing) turn again into a Crime, to the perpetuall disturbance

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Peace of the Common-wealth.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: False Teachers Mis-interpreting The Law Of Nature Secondly, by false

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Teachers, that either mis-interpret the Law of Nature, making it thereby

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: repugnant to the Law Civill; or by teaching for Lawes, such Doctrines of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their own, or Traditions of former times, as are inconsistent with the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: duty of a Subject.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And False Inferences From True Principles, By Teachers

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Thirdly, by Erroneous Inferences from True Principles; which happens

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: commonly to men that are hasty, and praecipitate in concluding, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: resolving what to do; such as are they, that have both a great opinion

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of their own understanding, and believe that things of this nature

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: require not time and study, but onely common experience, and a good

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: naturall wit; whereof no man thinks himselfe unprovided: whereas the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: knowledge, of Right and Wrong, which is no lesse difficult, there is no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man will pretend to, without great and long study. And of those defects

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in Reasoning, there is none that can Excuse (though some of them may

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Extenuate) a Crime, in any man, that pretendeth to the administration of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his own private businesse; much lesse in them that undertake a publique

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: charge; because they pretend to the Reason, upon the want whereof they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: would ground their Excuse.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: By Their Passions;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of the Passions that most frequently are the causes of Crime, one,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is Vain-glory, or a foolish over-rating of their own worth; as if

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: difference of worth, were an effect of their wit, or riches, or bloud,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or some other naturall quality, not depending on the Will of those that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have the Soveraign Authority. From whence proceedeth a Presumption that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the punishments ordained by the Lawes, and extended generally to all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Subjects, ought not to be inflicted on them, with the same rigour they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are inflicted on poore, obscure, and simple men, comprehended under the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: name of the Vulgar.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Presumption Of Riches

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Therefore it happeneth commonly, that such as value themselves by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: greatnesse of their wealth, adventure on Crimes, upon hope of escaping

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: punishment, by corrupting publique Justice, or obtaining Pardon by Mony,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or other rewards.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And Friends

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And that such as have multitude of Potent Kindred; and popular men, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have gained reputation amongst the Multitude, take courage to violate

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Lawes, from a hope of oppressing the Power, to whom it belongeth to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: put them in execution.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Wisedome

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And that such as have a great, and false opinion of their own Wisedome,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: take upon them to reprehend the actions, and call in question the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Authority of them that govern, and so to unsettle the Lawes with their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: publique discourse, as that nothing shall be a Crime, but what their own

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: designes require should be so. It happeneth also to the same men, to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: prone to all such Crimes, as consist in Craft, and in deceiving of their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Neighbours; because they think their designes are too subtile to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: perceived. These I say are effects of a false presumption of their own

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Wisdome. For of them that are the first movers in the disturbance of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth, (which can never happen without a Civill Warre,) very few

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are left alive long enough, to see their new Designes established: so

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that the benefit of their Crimes, redoundeth to Posterity, and such as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: would least have wished it: which argues they were not as wise, as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they thought they were. And those that deceive upon hope of not being

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: observed, do commonly deceive themselves, (the darknesse in which they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: believe they lye hidden, being nothing else but their own blindnesse;)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and are no wiser than Children, that think all hid, by hiding their own

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: eyes.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And generally all vain-glorious men, (unlesse they be withall timorous,)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are subject to Anger; as being more prone than others to interpret for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: contempt, the ordinary liberty of conversation: And there are few Crimes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that may not be produced by Anger.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Hatred, Lust, Ambition, Covetousnesse, Causes Of Crime

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: As for the Passions, of Hate, Lust, Ambition, and Covetousnesse, what

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Crimes they are apt to produce, is so obvious to every mans experience

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and understanding, as there needeth nothing to be said of them, saving

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that they are infirmities, so annexed to the nature, both of man, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all other living creatures, as that their effects cannot be hindred,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but by extraordinary use of Reason, or a constant severity in punishing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them. For in those things men hate, they find a continuall, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: unavoydable molestation; whereby either a mans patience must be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: everlasting, or he must be eased by removing the power of that which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: molesteth him; The former is difficult; the later is many times

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: impossible, without some violation of the Law. Ambition, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Covetousnesse are Passions also that are perpetually incumbent, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: pressing; whereas Reason is not perpetually present, to resist them:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and therefore whensoever the hope of impunity appears, their effects

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: proceed. And for Lust, what it wants in the lasting, it hath in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: vehemence, which sufficeth to weigh down the apprehension of all easie,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or uncertain punishments.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Fear Sometimes Cause Of Crime, As When The Danger Is Neither Present,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nor Corporeall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of all Passions, that which enclineth men least to break the Lawes, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Fear. Nay, (excepting some generous natures,) it is the onely thing,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (when there is apparence of profit, or pleasure by breaking the Lawes,)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that makes men keep them. And yet in many cases a Crime may be committed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: through Feare.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For not every Fear justifies the Action it produceth, but the fear onely

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of corporeall hurt, which we call Bodily Fear, and from which a man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: cannot see how to be delivered, but by the action. A man is assaulted,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: fears present death, from which he sees not how to escape, but by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: wounding him that assaulteth him; If he wound him to death, this is no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Crime; because no man is supposed at the making of a Common-wealth, to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have abandoned the defence of his life, or limbes, where the Law cannot

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: arrive time enough to his assistance. But to kill a man, because from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his actions, or his threatnings, I may argue he will kill me when he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: can, (seeing I have time, and means to demand protection, from the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign Power,) is a Crime. Again, a man receives words of disgrace,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or some little injuries (for which they that made the Lawes, had

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: assigned no punishment, nor thought it worthy of a man that hath the use

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Reason, to take notice of,) and is afraid, unlesse he revenge it,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he shall fall into contempt, and consequently be obnoxious to the like

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: injuries from others; and to avoyd this, breaks the Law, and protects

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: himselfe for the future, by the terrour of his private revenge. This is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Crime; For the hurt is not Corporeall, but Phantasticall, and (though

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in this corner of the world, made sensible by a custome not many years

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: since begun, amongst young and vain men,) so light, as a gallant man,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and one that is assured of his own courage, cannot take notice of. Also

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a man may stand in fear of Spirits, either through his own superstition,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or through too much credit given to other men, that tell him of strange

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Dreams and visions; and thereby be made believe they will hurt him, for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: doing, or omitting divers things, which neverthelesse, to do, or omit,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is contrary to the Lawes; And that which is so done, or omitted, is not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to be Excused by this fear; but is a Crime. For (as I have shewn before

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the second Chapter) Dreams be naturally but the fancies remaining in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sleep, after the impressions our Senses had formerly received waking;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and when men are by any accident unassured they have slept, seem to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: reall Visions; and therefore he that presumes to break the Law upon his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: own, or anothers Dream, or pretended Vision, or upon other Fancy of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the power of Invisible Spirits, than is permitted by the Common-wealth,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: leaveth the Law of Nature, which is a certain offence, and followeth the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: imagery of his own, or another private mans brain, which he can never

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: know whether it signifieth any thing, or nothing, nor whether he that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: tells his Dream, say true, or lye; which if every private man should

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have leave to do, (as they must by the Law of Nature, if any one have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it) there could no Law be made to hold, and so all Common-wealth would

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be dissolved.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Crimes Not Equall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: From these different sources of Crimes, it appeares already, that all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Crimes are not (as the Stoicks of old time maintained) of the same

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: allay. There is place, not only for EXCUSE, by which that which seemed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Crime, is proved to be none at all; but also for EXTENUATION, by which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Crime, that seemed great, is made lesse. For though all Crimes doe

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: equally deserve the name of Injustice, as all deviation from a strait

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: line is equally crookednesse, which the Stoicks rightly observed; yet

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it does not follow that all Crimes are equally unjust, no more than that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all crooked lines are equally crooked; which the Stoicks not observing,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: held it as great a Crime, to kill a Hen, against the Law, as to kill

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ones Father.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Totall Excuses

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: That which totally Excuseth a Fact, and takes away from it the nature of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Crime, can be none but that, which at the same time, taketh away the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: obligation of the Law. For the fact committed once against the Law,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: if he that committed it be obliged to the Law, can be no other than a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Crime.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The want of means to know the Law, totally Excuseth: For the Law whereof

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a man has no means to enforme himself, is not obligatory. But the want

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of diligence to enquire, shall not be considered as a want of means; Nor

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shall any man, that pretendeth to reason enough for the Government of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his own affairs, be supposed to want means to know the Lawes of Nature;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: because they are known by the reason he pretends to: only Children, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Madmen are Excused from offences against the Law Naturall.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Where a man is captive, or in the power of the enemy, (and he is then in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the power of the enemy, when his person, or his means of living, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: so,) if it be without his own fault, the Obligation of the Law ceaseth;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: because he must obey the enemy, or dye; and consequently such obedience

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is no Crime: for no man is obliged (when the protection of the Law

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: faileth,) not to protect himself, by the best means he can.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: If a man by the terrour of present death, be compelled to doe a fact

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: against the Law, he is totally Excused; because no Law can oblige a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man to abandon his own preservation. And supposing such a Law were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: obligatory; yet a man would reason thus, "If I doe it not, I die

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: presently; if I doe it, I die afterwards; therefore by doing it, there

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is time of life gained;" Nature therefore compells him to the fact.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: When a man is destitute of food, or other thing necessary for his life,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and cannot preserve himselfe any other way, but by some fact against

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Law; as if in a great famine he take the food by force, or stealth,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which he cannot obtaine for mony nor charity; or in defence of his life,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: snatch away another mans Sword, he is totally Excused, for the reason

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: next before alledged.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Excuses Against The Author

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Again, Facts done against the Law, by the authority of another, are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by that authority Excused against the Author; because no man ought to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: accuse his own fact in another, that is but his instrument: but it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is not Excused against a third person thereby injured; because in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: violation of the law, bothe the Author, and Actor are Criminalls.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: From hence it followeth that when that Man, or Assembly, that hath the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign Power, commandeth a man to do that which is contrary to a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: former Law, the doing of it is totally Excused: For he ought not to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: condemn it himselfe, because he is the Author; and what cannot justly

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be condemned by the Soveraign, cannot justly be punished by any other.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Besides, when the Soveraign commandeth any thing to be done against

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his own former Law, the Command, as to that particular fact, is an

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: abrogation of the Law.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: If that Man, or Assembly, that hath the Soveraign Power, disclaime

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: any Right essentiall to the Soveraignty, whereby there accrueth to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Subject, any liberty inconsistent with the Soveraign Power, that is to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: say, with the very being of a Common-wealth, if the Subject shall refuse

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to obey the Command in any thing, contrary to the liberty granted, this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is neverthelesse a Sinne, and contrary to the duty of the Subject: for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he ought to take notice of what is inconsistent with the Soveraignty,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: because it was erected by his own consent, and for his own defence;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and that such liberty as is inconsistent with it, was granted through

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ignorance of the evill consequence thereof. But if he not onely disobey,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but also resist a publique Minister in the execution of it, then it is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Crime; because he might have been righted, (without any breach of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Peace,) upon complaint.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Degrees of Crime are taken on divers Scales, and measured, First, by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the malignity of the Source, or Cause: Secondly, by the contagion of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Example: Thirdly, by the mischiefe of the Effect; and Fourthly, by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: concurrence of Times, Places, and Persons.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Presumption Of Power, Aggravateth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The same Fact done against the Law, if it proceed from Presumption of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: strength, riches, or friends to resist those that are to execute the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Law, is a greater Crime, than if it proceed from hope of not being

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: discovered, or of escape by flight: For Presumption of impunity by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: force, is a Root, from whence springeth, at all times, and upon all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: temptations, a contempt of all Lawes; whereas in the later case, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: apprehension of danger, that makes a man fly, renders him more obedient

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for the future. A Crime which we know to be so, is greater than the same

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Crime proceeding from a false perswasion that it is lawfull: For he that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: committeth it against his own conscience, presumeth on his force, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other power, which encourages him to commit the same again: but he that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: doth it by errour, after the errour shewn him, is conformable to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Law.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Evill Teachers, Extenuate

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Hee, whose errour proceeds from the authority of a Teacher, or an

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Interpreter of the Law publiquely authorised, is not so faulty, as he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whose errour proceedeth from a peremptory pursute of his own principles,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and reasoning: For what is taught by one that teacheth by publique

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Authority, the Common-wealth teacheth, and hath a resemblance of Law,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: till the same Authority controuleth it; and in all Crimes that contain

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not in them a denyall of the Soveraign Power, nor are against an evident

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Law, Excuseth totally: whereas he that groundeth his actions, on his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: private Judgement, ought according to the rectitude, or errour thereof,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to stand, or fall.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Examples Of Impunity, Extenuate

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The same Fact, if it have been constantly punished in other men, as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a greater Crime, than if there have been may precedent Examples of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: impunity. For those Examples, are so many hopes of Impunity given by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Soveraign himselfe: And because he which furnishes a man with such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a hope, and presumption of mercy, as encourageth him to offend, hath his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: part in the offence; he cannot reasonably charge the offender with the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whole.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Praemeditation, Aggravateth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: A Crime arising from a sudden Passion, is not so great, as when the same

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ariseth from long meditation: For in the former case there is a place

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for Extenuation, in the common infirmity of humane nature: but he that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: doth it with praemeditation, has used circumspection, and cast his eye,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: on the Law, on the punishment, and on the consequence thereof to humane

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: society; all which in committing the Crime, hee hath contemned, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: postposed to his own appetite. But there is no suddennesse of Passion

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sufficient for a totall Excuse: For all the time between the first

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: knowing of the Law, and the Commission of the Fact, shall be taken for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a time of deliberation; because he ought by meditation of the Law, to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: rectifie the irregularity of his Passions.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Where the Law is publiquely, and with assiduity, before all the people

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: read, and interpreted; a fact done against it, is a greater Crime,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: than where men are left without such instruction, to enquire of it with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: difficulty, uncertainty, and interruption of their Callings, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be informed by private men: for in this case, part of the fault is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: discharged upon common infirmity; but in the former there is apparent

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: negligence, which is not without some contempt of the Soveraign Power.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Tacite Approbation Of The Soveraign, Extenuates

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Those facts which the Law expresly condemneth, but the Law-maker by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other manifest signes of his will tacitly approveth, are lesse Crimes,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: than the same facts, condemned both by the Law, and Lawmaker. For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: seeing the will of the Law-maker is a Law, there appear in this case two

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: contradictory Lawes; which would totally Excuse, if men were bound to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: take notice of the Soveraigns approbation, by other arguments, than are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: expressed by his command. But because there are punishments consequent,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not onely to the transgression of his Law, but also to the observing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of it, he is in part a cause of the transgression, and therefore cannot

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: reasonably impute the whole Crime to the Delinquent. For example, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Law condemneth Duells; the punishment is made capitall: On the contrary

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: part, he that refuseth Duell, is subject to contempt and scorne, without

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: remedy; and sometimes by the Soveraign himselfe thought unworthy to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have any charge, or preferment in Warre: If thereupon he accept Duell,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: considering all men lawfully endeavour to obtain the good opinion

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of them that have the Soveraign Power, he ought not in reason to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: rigorously punished; seeing part of the fault may be discharged on the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: punisher; which I say, not as wishing liberty of private revenges,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or any other kind of disobedience; but a care in Governours, not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to countenance any thing obliquely, which directly they forbid. The

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: examples of Princes, to those that see them, are, and ever have been,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: more potent to govern their actions, than the Lawes themselves. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: though it be our duty to do, not what they do, but what they say; yet

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: will that duty never be performed, till it please God to give men an

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: extraordinary, and supernaturall grace to follow that Precept.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Comparison Of Crimes From Their Effects

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Again, if we compare Crimes by the mischiefe of their Effects, First,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the same fact, when it redounds to the dammage of many, is greater, than

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: when it redounds to the hurt of few. And therefore, when a fact hurteth,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not onely in the present, but also, (by example) in the future, it is a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: greater Crime, than if it hurt onely in the present: for the former,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is a fertile Crime, and multiplyes to the hurt of many; the later is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: barren. To maintain doctrines contrary to the Religion established in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Common-wealth, is a greater fault, in an authorised Preacher, than

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in a private person: So also is it, to live prophanely, incontinently,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or do any irreligious act whatsoever. Likewise in a Professor of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Law, to maintain any point, on do any act, that tendeth to the weakning

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Soveraign Power, as a greater Crime, than in another man: Also in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a man that hath such reputation for wisedome, as that his counsells are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: followed, or his actions imitated by many, his fact against the Law, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a greater Crime, than the same fact in another: For such men not onely

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: commit Crime, but teach it for Law to all other men. And generally all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Crimes are the greater, by the scandall they give; that is to say, by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: becoming stumbling-blocks to the weak, that look not so much upon the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: way they go in, as upon the light that other men carry before them.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Laesae Majestas

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Also Facts of Hostility against the present state of the Common-wealth,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are greater Crimes, than the same acts done to private men; For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the dammage extends it selfe to all: Such are the betraying of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: strengths, or revealing of the secrets of the Common-wealth to an Enemy;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: also all attempts upon the Representative of the Common-wealth, be it a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: monarch, or an Assembly; and all endeavours by word, or deed to diminish

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Authority of the same, either in the present time, or in succession:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which Crimes the Latines understand by Crimina Laesae Majestatis, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consist in designe, or act, contrary to a Fundamentall Law.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Bribery And False Testimony

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Likewise those Crimes, which render Judgements of no effect, are greater

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Crimes, than Injuries done to one, or a few persons; as to receive

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: mony to give False judgement, or testimony, is a greater Crime, than

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: otherwise to deceive a man of the like, or a greater summe; because not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: onely he has wrong, that falls by such judgements; but all Judgements

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are rendered uselesse, and occasion ministred to force, and private

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: revenges.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Depeculation

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Also Robbery, and Depeculation of the Publique treasure, or Revenues,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is a greater Crime, than the robbing, or defrauding of a Private man;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: because to robbe the publique, is to robbe many at once.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Counterfeiting Authority

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Also the Counterfeit usurpation of publique Ministery, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Counterfeiting of publique Seales, or publique Coine, than

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: counterfeiting of a private mans person, or his seale; because the fraud

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thereof, extendeth to the dammage of many.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Crimes Against Private Men Compared

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of facts against the Law, done to private men, the greater Crime, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that, where the dammage in the common opinion of men, is most sensible.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And therefore

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To kill against the Law, is a greater Crime, that any other injury, life

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: preserved.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And to kill with Torment, greater, than simply to kill.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And Mutilation of a limbe, greater, than the spoyling a man of his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: goods.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And the spoyling a man of his goods, by Terrour of death, or wounds,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: than by clandestine surreption.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And by clandestine Surreption, than by consent fraudulently obtained.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And the violation of chastity by Force, greater, than by flattery.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And of a woman Married, than of a woman not married.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For all these things are commonly so valued; though some men are more,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and some lesse sensible of the same offence. But the Law regardeth not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the particular, but the generall inclination of mankind.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And therefore the offence men take, from contumely, in words, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: gesture, when they produce no other harme, than the present griefe of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him that is reproached, hath been neglected in the Lawes of the Greeks,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Romans, and other both antient, and moderne Common-wealths; supposing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the true cause of such griefe to consist, not in the contumely, (which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: takes no hold upon men conscious of their own Vertue,) but in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Pusillanimity of him that is offended by it.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Also a Crime against a private man, is much aggravated by the person,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: time, and place. For to kill ones Parent, is a greater Crime, than to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: kill another: for the Parent ought to have the honour of a Soveraign,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (though he have surrendred his Power to the Civill Law,) because he had

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it originally by Nature. And to Robbe a poore man, is a greater Crime,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: than to robbe a rich man; because 'tis to the poore a more sensible

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: dammage.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And a Crime committed in the Time, or Place appointed for Devotion, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: greater, than if committed at another time or place: for it proceeds

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from a greater contempt of the Law.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Many other cases of Aggravation, and Extenuation might be added: but by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: these I have set down, it is obvious to every man, to take the altitude

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of any other Crime proposed.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Publique Crimes What

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lastly, because in almost all Crimes there is an Injury done, not onely

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to some Private man, but also to the Common-wealth; the same Crime, when

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the accusation is in the name of the Common-wealth, is called Publique

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Crime; and when in the name of a Private man, a Private Crime; And the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Pleas according thereunto called Publique, Judicia Publica, Pleas of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Crown; or Private Pleas. As in an Accusation of Murder, if the accuser

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be a Private man, the plea is a Private plea; if the accuser be the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign, the plea is a Publique plea.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CHAPTER XXVIII. OF PUNISHMENTS, AND REWARDS

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Definition Of Punishment

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "A PUNISHMENT, is an Evill inflicted by publique Authority, on him that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hath done, or omitted that which is Judged by the same Authority to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Transgression of the Law; to the end that the will of men may thereby

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the better be disposed to obedience."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Right To Punish Whence Derived

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Before I inferre any thing from this definition, there is a question to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be answered, of much importance; which is, by what door the Right, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Authority of Punishing in any case, came in. For by that which has

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: been said before, no man is supposed bound by Covenant, not to resist

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: violence; and consequently it cannot be intended, that he gave any right

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to another to lay violent hands upon his person. In the making of a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth, every man giveth away the right of defending another; but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not of defending himselfe. Also he obligeth himselfe, to assist him that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hath the Soveraignty, in the Punishing of another; but of himselfe

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not. But to covenant to assist the Soveraign, in doing hurt to another,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: unlesse he that so covenanteth have a right to doe it himselfe, is not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to give him a Right to Punish. It is manifest therefore that the Right

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which the Common-wealth (that is, he, or they that represent it) hath to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Punish, is not grounded on any concession, or gift of the Subjects.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But I have also shewed formerly, that before the Institution of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth, every man had a right to every thing, and to do

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whatsoever he thought necessary to his own preservation; subduing,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hurting, or killing any man in order thereunto. And this is the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: foundation of that right of Punishing, which is exercised in every

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth. For the Subjects did not give the Soveraign that right;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but onely in laying down theirs, strengthned him to use his own, as he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: should think fit, for the preservation of them all: so that it was not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: given, but left to him, and to him onely; and (excepting the limits set

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him by naturall Law) as entire, as in the condition of meer Nature, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of warre of every one against his neighbour.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Private Injuries, And Revenges No Punishments

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: From the definition of Punishment, I inferre, First, that neither

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: private revenges, nor injuries of private men, can properly be stiled

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Punishment; because they proceed not from publique Authority.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nor Denyall Of Preferment

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Secondly, that to be neglected, and unpreferred by the publique

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: favour, is not a Punishment; because no new evill is thereby on any man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Inflicted; he is onely left in the estate he was in before.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nor Pain Inflicted Without Publique Hearing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Thirdly, that the evill inflicted by publique Authority, without

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: precedent publique condemnation, is not to be stiled by the name of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Punishment; but of an hostile act; because the fact for which a man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is Punished, ought first to be Judged by publique Authority, to be a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: transgression of the Law.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nor Pain Inflicted By Usurped Power

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Fourthly, that the evill inflicted by usurped power, and Judges

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: without Authority from the Soveraign, is not Punishment; but an act of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hostility; because the acts of power usurped, have not for Author, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: person condemned; and therefore are not acts of publique Authority.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nor Pain Inflicted Without Respect To The Future Good

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Fifthly, that all evill which is inflicted without intention, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: possibility of disposing the Delinquent, or (by his example) other men,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to obey the Lawes, is not Punishment; but an act of hostility; because

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: without such an end, no hurt done is contained under that name.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Naturall Evill Consequences, No Punishments

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sixthly, whereas to certain actions, there be annexed by Nature, divers

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hurtfull consequences; as when a man in assaulting another, is himselfe

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: slain, or wounded; or when he falleth into sicknesse by the doing of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: some unlawfull act; such hurt, though in respect of God, who is the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: author of Nature, it may be said to be inflicted, and therefore a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Punishment divine; yet it is not contaned in the name of Punishment in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: respect of men, because it is not inflicted by the Authority of man.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Hurt Inflicted, If Lesse Than The Benefit Of Transgressing,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Is Not Punishment

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Seventhly, If the harm inflicted be lesse than the benefit, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: contentment that naturally followeth the crime committed, that harm is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not within the definition; and is rather the Price, or Redemption, than

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Punishment of a Crime: Because it is of the nature of Punishment, to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have for end, the disposing of men to obey the Law; which end (if it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be lesse that the benefit of the transgression) it attaineth not, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: worketh a contrary effect.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Where The Punishment Is Annexed To The Law, A Greater Hurt Is Not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Punishment, But Hostility

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Eighthly, If a Punishment be determined and prescribed in the Law it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: selfe, and after the crime committed, there be a greater Punishment

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: inflicted, the excesse is not Punishment, but an act of hostility. For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: seeing the aym of Punishment is not a revenge, but terrour; and the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: terrour of a great Punishment unknown, is taken away by the declaration

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of a lesse, the unexpected addition is no part of the Punishment.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But where there is no Punishment at all determined by the Law, there

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whatsoever is inflicted, hath the nature of Punishment. For he that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: goes about the violation of a Law, wherein no penalty is determined,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: expecteth an indeterminate, that is to say, an arbitrary Punishment.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Hurt Inflicted For A Fact Done Before The Law, No Punishment

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ninthly, Harme inflicted for a Fact done before there was a Law that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: forbad it, is not Punishment, but an act of Hostility: For before the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Law, there is no transgression of the Law: But Punishment supposeth a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: fact judged, to have been a transgression of the Law; Therefore

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Harme inflicted before the Law made, is not Punishment, but an act of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Hostility.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Representative Of The Common-wealth Unpunishable

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Tenthly, Hurt inflicted on the Representative of the Common-wealth, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not Punishment, but an act of Hostility: Because it is of the nature

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Punishment, to be inflicted by publique Authority, which is the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Authority only of the Representative it self.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Hurt To Revolted Subjects Is Done By Right Of War, Not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: By Way Of Punishment

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lastly, Harme inflicted upon one that is a declared enemy, fals not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: under the name of Punishment: Because seeing they were either never

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: subject to the Law, and therefore cannot transgresse it; or having been

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: subject to it, and professing to be no longer so, by consequence deny

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they can transgresse it, all the Harmes that can be done them, must be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: taken as acts of Hostility. But in declared Hostility, all infliction of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: evill is lawfull. From whence it followeth, that if a subject shall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by fact, or word, wittingly, and deliberatly deny the authority of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Representative of the Common-wealth, (whatsoever penalty hath

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: been formerly ordained for Treason,) he may lawfully be made to suffer

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whatsoever the Representative will: For in denying subjection, he denyes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such Punishment as by the Law hath been ordained; and therefore suffers

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as an enemy of the Common-wealth; that is, according to the will of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Representative. For the Punishments set down in the Law, are to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Subjects, not to Enemies; such as are they, that having been by their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: own act Subjects, deliberately revolting, deny the Soveraign Power.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The first, and most generall distribution of Punishments, is into

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Divine, and Humane. Of the former I shall have occasion, to speak, in a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: more convenient place hereafter.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Humane, are those Punishments that be inflicted by the Commandement

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Man; and are either Corporall, or Pecuniary, or Ignominy, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Imprisonment, or Exile, or mixt of these.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Punishments Corporall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Corporall Punishment is that, which is inflicted on the body directly,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and according to the intention of him that inflicteth it: such as are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: stripes, or wounds, or deprivation of such pleasures of the body, as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: were before lawfully enjoyed.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Capitall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And of these, some be Capitall, some Lesse than Capitall. Capitall, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Infliction of Death; and that either simply, or with torment. Lesse

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: than Capitall, are Stripes, Wounds, Chains, and any other corporall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Paine, not in its own nature mortall. For if upon the Infliction of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Punishment death follow not in the Intention of the Inflicter, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Punishment is not be bee esteemed Capitall, though the harme prove

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: mortall by an accident not to be foreseen; in which case death is not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: inflicted, but hastened.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Pecuniary Punishment, is that which consisteth not only in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: deprivation of a Summe of Mony, but also of Lands, or any other goods

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which are usually bought and sold for mony. And in case the Law, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ordaineth such a punishment, be made with design to gather mony, from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such as shall transgresse the same, it is not properly a Punishment,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but the Price of priviledge, and exemption from the Law, which doth not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: absolutely forbid the fact, but only to those that are not able to pay

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the mony: except where the Law is Naturall, or part of Religion; for in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that case it is not an exemption from the Law, but a transgression of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it. As where a Law exacteth a Pecuniary mulct, of them that take the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: name of God in vaine, the payment of the mulct, is not the price of a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: dispensation to sweare, but the Punishment of the transgression of a Law

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: undispensable. In like manner if the Law impose a Summe of Mony to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: payd, to him that has been Injured; this is but a satisfaction for the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hurt done him; and extinguisheth the accusation of the party injured,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not the crime of the offender.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ignominy

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ignominy, is the infliction of such Evill, as is made Dishonorable;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or the deprivation of such Good, as is made Honourable by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth. For there be some things Honorable by Nature; as the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: effects of Courage, Magnanimity, Strength, Wisdome, and other abilities

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of body and mind: Others made Honorable by the Common-wealth; as Badges,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Titles, Offices, or any other singular marke of the Soveraigns favour.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The former, (though they may faile by nature, or accident,) cannot be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: taken away by a Law; and therefore the losse of them is not Punishment.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But the later, may be taken away by the publique authority that made

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them Honorable, and are properly Punishments: Such are degrading men

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: condemned, of their Badges, Titles, and Offices; or declaring them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: uncapable of the like in time to come.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Imprisonment

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Imprisonment, is when a man is by publique Authority deprived of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: liberty; and may happen from two divers ends; whereof one is the safe

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: custody of a man accused; the other is the inflicting of paine on a man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: condemned. The former is not Punishment; because no man is supposed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to be Punisht, before he be Judicially heard, and declared guilty.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And therefore whatsoever hurt a man is made to suffer by bonds, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: restraint, before his cause be heard, over and above that which is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: necessary to assure his custody, is against the Law of Nature. But the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Later is Punishment, because Evill, and inflicted by publique Authority,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for somewhat that has by the same Authority been Judged a Transgression

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Law. Under this word Imprisonment, I comprehend all restraint of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: motion, caused by an externall obstacle, be it a House, which is called

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by the generall name of a Prison; or an Iland, as when men are said to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be confined to it; or a place where men are set to worke, as in old time

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: men have been condemned to Quarries, and in these times to Gallies; or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be it a Chaine, or any other such impediment.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Exile

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Exile, (Banishment) is when a man is for a crime, condemned to depart

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: out of the dominion of the Common-wealth, or out of a certaine part

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thereof; and during a prefixed time, or for ever, not to return into it:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and seemeth not in its own nature, without other circumstances, to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Punishment; but rather an escape, or a publique commandement to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: avoid Punishment by flight. And Cicero sayes, there was never any such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Punishment ordained in the City of Rome; but cals it a refuge of men in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: danger. For if a man banished, be neverthelesse permitted to enjoy

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his Goods, and the Revenue of his Lands, the meer change of ayr is no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: punishment; nor does it tend to that benefit of the Common-wealth, for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which all Punishments are ordained, (that is to say, to the forming of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: mens wils to the observation of the Law;) but many times to the dammage

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Common-wealth. For a Banished man, is a lawfull enemy of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth that banished him; as being no more a Member of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: same. But if he be withall deprived of his Lands, or Goods, then

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Punishment lyeth not in the Exile, but is to be reckoned amongst

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Punishments Pecuniary.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Punishment Of Innocent Subjects Is Contrary To The Law Of Nature

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: All Punishments of Innocent subjects, be they great or little, are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: against the Law of Nature; For Punishment is only of Transgression of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Law, and therefore there can be no Punishment of the Innocent. It

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is therefore a violation, First, of that Law of Nature, which forbiddeth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all men, in their Revenges, to look at any thing but some future good:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For there can arrive no good to the Common-wealth, by Punishing the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Innocent. Secondly, of that, which forbiddeth Ingratitude: For seeing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all Soveraign Power, is originally given by the consent of every one of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Subjects, to the end they should as long as they are obedient, be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: protected thereby; the Punishment of the Innocent, is a rendring of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Evill for Good. And thirdly, of the Law that commandeth Equity; that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is to say, an equall distribution of Justice; which in Punishing the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Innocent is not observed.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But The Harme Done To Innocents In War, Not So

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But the Infliction of what evill soever, on an Innocent man, that is not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Subject, if it be for the benefit of the Common-wealth, and without

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: violation of any former Covenant, is no breach of the Law of Nature.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For all men that are not Subjects, are either Enemies, or else they have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ceased from being so, by some precedent covenants. But against Enemies,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whom the Common-wealth judgeth capable to do them hurt, it is lawfull by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the originall Right of Nature to make warre; wherein the Sword Judgeth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not, nor doth the Victor make distinction of Nocent and Innocent, as to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the time past; nor has other respect of mercy, than as it conduceth to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the good of his own People. And upon this ground it is, that also

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in Subjects, who deliberatly deny the Authority of the Common-wealth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: established, the vengeance is lawfully extended, not onely to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Fathers, but also to the third and fourth generation not yet in being,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and consequently innocent of the fact, for which they are afflicted:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: because the nature of this offence, consisteth in the renouncing of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: subjection; which is a relapse into the condition of warre, commonly

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: called Rebellion; and they that so offend, suffer not as Subjects, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as Enemies. For Rebellion, is but warre renewed.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Reward, Is Either Salary, Or Grace

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: REWARD, is either of Gift, or by Contract. When by Contract, it is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: called Salary, and Wages; which is benefit due for service performed, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: promised. When of Gift, it is benefit proceeding from the Grace of them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that bestow it, to encourage, or enable men to do them service. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore when the Soveraign of a Common-wealth appointeth a Salary

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to any publique Office, he that receiveth it, is bound in Justice

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to performe his office; otherwise, he is bound onely in honour, to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: acknowledgement, and an endeavour of requitall. For though men have no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: lawfull remedy, when they be commanded to quit their private businesse,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to serve the publique, without Reward, or Salary; yet they are not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: bound thereto, by the Law of Nature, nor by the institution of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth, unlesse the service cannot otherwise be done; because it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is supposed the Soveraign may make use of all their means, insomuch as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the most common Souldier, may demand the wages of his warrefare, as a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: debt.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Benefits Bestowed For Fear, Are Not Rewards

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The benefits which a Soveraign bestoweth on a Subject, for fear of some

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: power, and ability he hath to do hurt to the Common-wealth, are not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: properly Rewards; for they are not Salaryes; because there is in this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: case no contract supposed, every man being obliged already not to do the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth disservice: nor are they Graces; because they be extorted

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by feare, which ought not to be incident to the Soveraign Power: but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are rather Sacrifices, which the Soveraign (considered in his naturall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: person, and not in the person of the Common-wealth) makes, for the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: appeasing the discontent of him he thinks more potent than himselfe; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: encourage not to obedience, but on the contrary, to the continuance, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: increasing of further extortion.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Salaries Certain And Casuall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And whereas some Salaries are certain, and proceed from the publique

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Treasure; and others uncertain, and casuall, proceeding from the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: execution of the Office for which the Salary is ordained; the later

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is in some cases hurtfull to the Common-wealth; as in the case of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Judicature. For where the benefit of the Judges, and Ministers of a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Court of Justice, ariseth for the multitude of Causes that are brought

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to their cognisance, there must needs follow two Inconveniences: One,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is the nourishing of sutes; for the more sutes, the greater benefit: and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: another that depends on that, which is contention about Jurisdiction;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: each Court drawing to it selfe, as many Causes as it can. But in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: offices of Execution there are not those Inconveniences; because their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: employment cannot be encreased by any endeavour of their own. And thus

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: much shall suffice for the nature of Punishment, and Reward; which are,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as it were, the Nerves and Tendons, that move the limbes and joynts of a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Hitherto I have set forth the nature of Man, (whose Pride and other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Passions have compelled him to submit himselfe to Government;) together

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with the great power of his Governour, whom I compared to Leviathan,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: taking that comparison out of the two last verses of the one and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: fortieth of Job; where God having set forth the great power of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Leviathan, called him King of the Proud. "There is nothing," saith he,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "on earth, to be compared with him. He is made so as not be afraid. Hee

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: seeth every high thing below him; and is King of all the children of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: pride." But because he is mortall, and subject to decay, as all other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Earthly creatures are; and because there is that in heaven, (though not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: on earth) that he should stand in fear of, and whose Lawes he ought to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: obey; I shall in the next following Chapters speak of his Diseases, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the causes of his Mortality; and of what Lawes of Nature he is bound to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: obey.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CHAPTER XXIX. OF THOSE THINGS THAT WEAKEN, OR TEND TO THE DISSOLUTION OF

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: A COMMON-WEALTH

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Dissolution Of Common-wealths Proceedeth From Imperfect Institution

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Though nothing can be immortall, which mortals make; yet, if men had the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: use of reason they pretend to, their Common-wealths might be secured, at

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: least, from perishing by internall diseases. For by the nature of their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Institution, they are designed to live, as long as Man-kind, or as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Lawes of Nature, or as Justice it selfe, which gives them life.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Therefore when they come to be dissolved, not by externall violence, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: intestine disorder, the fault is not in men, as they are the Matter; but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as they are the Makers, and orderers of them. For men, as they become

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: at last weary of irregular justling, and hewing one another, and desire

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with all their hearts, to conforme themselves into one firme and lasting

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: edifice; so for want, both of the art of making fit Laws, to square

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their actions by, and also of humility, and patience, to suffer the rude

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and combersome points of their present greatnesse to be taken off, they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: cannot without the help of a very able Architect, be compiled, into any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other than a crasie building, such as hardly lasting out their own time,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: must assuredly fall upon the heads of their posterity.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Amongst the Infirmities therefore of a Common-wealth, I will reckon in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the first place, those that arise from an Imperfect Institution,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and resemble the diseases of a naturall body, which proceed from a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Defectuous Procreation.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Want Of Absolute Power

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of which, this is one, "That a man to obtain a Kingdome, is sometimes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: content with lesse Power, than to the Peace, and defence of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth is necessarily required." From whence it commeth to passe,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that when the exercise of the Power layd by, is for the publique safety

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to be resumed, it hath the resemblance of as unjust act; which disposeth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: great numbers of men (when occasion is presented) to rebell; In the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: same manner as the bodies of children, gotten by diseased parents, are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: subject either to untimely death, or to purge the ill quality, derived

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from their vicious conception, by breaking out into biles and scabbs.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And when Kings deny themselves some such necessary Power, it is not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: alwayes (though sometimes) out of ignorance of what is necessary to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: office they undertake; but many times out of a hope to recover the same

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: again at their pleasure: Wherein they reason not well; because such as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: will hold them to their promises, shall be maintained against them by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: forraign Common-wealths; who in order to the good of their own Subjects

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: let slip few occasions to Weaken the estate of their Neighbours. So was
