author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Thomas Beckett Archbishop of Canterbury, supported against Henry

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Second, by the Pope; the subjection of Ecclesiastiques to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth, having been dispensed with by William the Conqueror at

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his reception, when he took an Oath, not to infringe the liberty of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Church. And so were the Barons, whose power was by William Rufus (to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have their help in transferring the Succession from his Elder brother,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to himselfe,) encreased to a degree, inconsistent with the Soveraign

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Power, maintained in their Rebellion against King John, by the French.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nor does this happen in Monarchy onely. For whereas the stile of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: antient Roman Common-wealth, was, The Senate, and People of Rome;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: neither Senate, nor People pretended to the whole Power; which first

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: caused the seditions, of Tiberius Gracchus, Caius Gracchus, Lucius

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Saturnius, and others; and afterwards the warres between the Senate and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the People, under Marius and Sylla; and again under Pompey and Caesar,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to the Extinction of their Democraty, and the setting up of Monarchy.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The people of Athens bound themselves but from one onely Action; which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was, that no man on pain of death should propound the renewing of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: warre for the Island of Salamis; And yet thereby, if Solon had not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: caused to be given out he was mad, and afterwards in gesture and habit

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of a mad-man, and in verse, propounded it to the People that flocked

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: about him, they had had an enemy perpetually in readinesse, even at the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: gates of their Citie; such dammage, or shifts, are all Common-wealths

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: forced to, that have their Power never so little limited.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Private Judgement Of Good and Evill

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In the second place, I observe the Diseases of a Common-wealth, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: proceed from the poyson of seditious doctrines; whereof one is, "That

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: every private man is Judge of Good and Evill actions." This is true in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the condition of meer Nature, where there are no Civill Lawes; and also

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: under Civill Government, in such cases as are not determined by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Law. But otherwise, it is manifest, that the measure of Good and Evill

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: actions, is the Civill Law; and the Judge the Legislator, who is alwayes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Representative of the Common-wealth. From this false doctrine, men are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: disposed to debate with themselves, and dispute the commands of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth; and afterwards to obey, or disobey them, as in their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: private judgements they shall think fit. Whereby the Common-wealth is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: distracted and Weakened.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Erroneous Conscience

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Another doctrine repugnant to Civill Society, is, that "Whatsoever a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man does against his Conscience, is Sinne;" and it dependeth on the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: presumption of making himself judge of Good and Evill. For a mans

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Conscience, and his Judgement is the same thing; and as the Judgement,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: so also the Conscience may be erroneous. Therefore, though he that is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: subject to no Civill Law, sinneth in all he does against his Conscience,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: because he has no other rule to follow but his own reason; yet it is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not so with him that lives in a Common-wealth; because the Law is the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: publique Conscience, by which he hath already undertaken to be guided.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Otherwise in such diversity, as there is of private Consciences, which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are but private opinions, the Common-wealth must needs be distracted,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and no man dare to obey the Soveraign Power, farther than it shall seem

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: good in his own eyes.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Pretence Of Inspiration

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: It hath been also commonly taught, "That Faith and Sanctity, are not to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be attained by Study and Reason, but by supernaturall Inspiration, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Infusion," which granted, I see not why any man should render a reason

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of his Faith; or why every Christian should not be also a Prophet; or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: why any man should take the Law of his Country, rather than his own

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Inspiration, for the rule of his action. And thus wee fall again into

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the fault of taking upon us to Judge of Good and Evill; or to make

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Judges of it, such private men as pretend to be supernaturally Inspired,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to the Dissolution of all Civill Government. Faith comes by hearing,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and hearing by those accidents, which guide us into the presence of them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that speak to us; which accidents are all contrived by God Almighty; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: yet are not supernaturall, but onely, for the great number of them that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: concurre to every effect, unobservable. Faith, and Sanctity, are indeed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not very frequent; but yet they are not Miracles, but brought to passe

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by education, discipline, correction, and other naturall wayes, by which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: God worketh them in his elect, as such time as he thinketh fit. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: these three opinions, pernicious to Peace and Government, have in this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: part of the world, proceeded chiefly from the tongues, and pens of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: unlearned Divines; who joyning the words of Holy Scripture together,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: otherwise than is agreeable to reason, do what they can, to make men

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: think, that Sanctity and Naturall Reason, cannot stand together.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Subjecting The Soveraign Power To Civill Lawes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: A fourth opinion, repugnant to the nature of a Common-wealth, is this,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "That he that hath the Soveraign Power, is subject to the Civill Lawes."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: It is true, that Soveraigns are all subjects to the Lawes of Nature;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: because such lawes be Divine, and cannot by any man, or Common-wealth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be abrogated. But to those Lawes which the Soveraign himselfe, that is,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which the Common-wealth maketh, he is not subject. For to be subject to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lawes, is to be subject to the Common-wealth, that is to the Soveraign

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Representative, that is to himselfe; which is not subjection, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: freedome from the Lawes. Which errour, because it setteth the Lawes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: above the Soveraign, setteth also a Judge above him, and a Power to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: punish him; which is to make a new Soveraign; and again for the same

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: reason a third, to punish the second; and so continually without end, to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Confusion, and Dissolution of the Common-wealth.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Attributing Of Absolute Propriety To The Subjects

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: A Fifth doctrine, that tendeth to the Dissolution of a Common-wealth,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is, "That every private man has an absolute Propriety in his Goods;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such, as excludeth the Right of the Soveraign." Every man has indeed a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Propriety that excludes the Right of every other Subject: And he has it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: onely from the Soveraign Power; without the protection whereof, every

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other man should have equall Right to the same. But if the Right of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign also be excluded, he cannot performe the office they have put

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him into; which is, to defend them both from forraign enemies, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from the injuries of one another; and consequently there is no longer a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And if the Propriety of Subjects, exclude not the Right of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign Representative to their Goods; much lesse to their offices

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Judicature, or Execution, in which they Represent the Soveraign

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: himselfe.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Dividing Of The Soveraign Power

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: There is a Sixth doctrine, plainly, and directly against the essence

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of a Common-wealth; and 'tis this, "That the Soveraign Power may be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: divided." For what is it to divide the Power of a Common-wealth, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to Dissolve it; for Powers divided mutually destroy each other. And for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: these doctrines, men are chiefly beholding to some of those, that making

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: profession of the Lawes, endeavour to make them depend upon their own

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: learning, and not upon the Legislative Power.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Imitation Of Neighbour Nations

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And as False Doctrine, so also often-times the Example of different

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Government in a neighbouring Nation, disposeth men to alteration of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the forme already setled. So the people of the Jewes were stirred up to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: reject God, and to call upon the Prophet Samuel, for a King after

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the manner of the Nations; So also the lesser Cities of Greece, were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: continually disturbed, with seditions of the Aristocraticall, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Democraticall factions; one part of almost every Common-wealth, desiring

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to imitate the Lacedaemonians; the other, the Athenians. And I doubt

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not, but many men, have been contented to see the late troubles in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: England, out of an imitation of the Low Countries; supposing there

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: needed no more to grow rich, than to change, as they had done, the forme

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of their Government. For the constitution of mans nature, is of it selfe

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: subject to desire novelty: When therefore they are provoked to the same,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by the neighbourhood also of those that have been enriched by it, it is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: almost impossible for them, not to be content with those that solicite

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them to change; and love the first beginnings, though they be grieved

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with the continuance of disorder; like hot blouds, that having gotten

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the itch, tear themselves with their own nayles, till they can endure

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the smart no longer.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Imitation Of The Greeks, And Romans

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And as to Rebellion in particular against Monarchy; one of the most

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: frequent causes of it, is the Reading of the books of Policy, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Histories of the antient Greeks, and Romans; from which, young men,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and all others that are unprovided of the Antidote of solid Reason,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: receiving a strong, and delightfull impression, of the great exploits

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of warre, atchieved by the Conductors of their Armies, receive withall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a pleasing Idea, of all they have done besides; and imagine their great

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: prosperity, not to have proceeded from the aemulation of particular men,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but from the vertue of their popular form of government: Not considering

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the frequent Seditions, and Civill Warres, produced by the imperfection

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of their Policy. From the reading, I say, of such books, men have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: undertaken to kill their Kings, because the Greek and Latine writers,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in their books, and discourses of Policy, make it lawfull, and laudable,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for any man so to do; provided before he do it, he call him Tyrant. For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they say not Regicide, that is, killing of a King, but Tyrannicide, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is, killing of a Tyrant is lawfull. From the same books, they that live

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: under a Monarch conceive an opinion, that the Subjects in a Popular

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth enjoy Liberty; but that in a Monarchy they are all Slaves.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: I say, they that live under a Monarchy conceive such an opinion; not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they that live under a Popular Government; for they find no such matter.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In summe, I cannot imagine, how anything can be more prejudiciall to a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Monarchy, than the allowing of such books to be publikely read, without

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: present applying such correctives of discreet Masters, as are fit to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: take away their Venime; Which Venime I will not doubt to compare to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the biting of a mad Dogge, which is a disease the Physicians call

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Hydrophobia, or Fear Of Water. For as he that is so bitten, has a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: continuall torment of thirst, and yet abhorreth water; and is in such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: an estate, as if the poyson endeavoured to convert him into a Dogge:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: So when a Monarchy is once bitten to the quick, by those Democraticall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: writers, that continually snarle at that estate; it wanteth nothing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: more than a strong Monarch, which neverthelesse out of a certain

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Tyrannophobia, or feare of being strongly governed, when they have him,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they abhorre.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: As here have been Doctors, that hold there be three Soules in a man;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: so there be also that think there may be more Soules, (that is, more

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraigns,) than one, in a Common-wealth; and set up a Supremacy

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: against the Soveraignty; Canons against Lawes; and a Ghostly Authority

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: against the Civill; working on mens minds, with words and distinctions,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that of themselves signifie nothing, but bewray (by their obscurity)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that there walketh (as some think invisibly) another Kingdome, as it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: were a Kingdome of Fayries, in the dark. Now seeing it is manifest, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Civill Power, and the Power of the Common-wealth is the same

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thing; and that Supremacy, and the Power of making Canons, and granting

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Faculties, implyeth a Common-wealth; it followeth, that where one is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign, another Supreme; where one can make Lawes, and another

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: make Canons; there must needs be two Common-wealths, of one & the same

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Subjects; which is a Kingdome divided in it selfe, and cannot stand. For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: notwithstanding the insignificant distinction of Temporall, and Ghostly,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they are still two Kingdomes, and every Subject is subject to two

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Masters. For seeing the Ghostly Power challengeth the Right to declare

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: what is Sinne it challengeth by consequence to declare what is Law,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (Sinne being nothing but the transgression of the Law;) and again, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Civill Power challenging to declare what is Law, every Subject must

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: obey two Masters, who bothe will have their Commands be observed as Law;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which is impossible. Or, if it be but one Kingdome, either the Civill,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which is the Power of the Common-wealth, must be subordinate to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ghostly; or the Ghostly must be subordinate to the Temporall and then

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there is no Supremacy but the Temporall. When therefore these two Powers

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: oppose one another, the Common-wealth cannot but be in great danger

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Civill warre, and Dissolution. For the Civill Authority being more

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: visible, and standing in the cleerer light of naturall reason cannot

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: choose but draw to it in all times a very considerable part of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: people: And the Spirituall, though it stand in the darknesse of Schoole

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: distinctions, and hard words; yet because the fear of Darknesse, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ghosts, is greater than other fears, cannot want a party sufficient to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Trouble, and sometimes to Destroy a Common-wealth. And this is a Disease

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which not unfitly may be compared to the Epilepsie, or Falling-sicknesse

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (which the Jewes took to be one kind of possession by Spirits) in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Body Naturall. For as in this Disease, there is an unnaturall spirit,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or wind in the head that obstructeth the roots of the Nerves, and moving

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them violently, taketh away the motion which naturally they should have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from the power of the Soule in the Brain, and thereby causeth violent,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and irregular motions (which men call Convulsions) in the parts;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: insomuch as he that is seized therewith, falleth down sometimes into the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: water, and sometimes into the fire, as a man deprived of his senses;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: so also in the Body Politique, when the Spirituall power, moveth the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Members of a Common-wealth, by the terrour of punishments, and hope of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: rewards (which are the Nerves of it,) otherwise than by the Civill Power

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (which is the Soule of the Common-wealth) they ought to be moved; and by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: strange, and hard words suffocates the people, and either Overwhelm

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Common-wealth with Oppression, or cast it into the Fire of a Civill

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: warre.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Mixt Government

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sometimes also in the meerly Civill government, there be more than

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: one Soule: As when the Power of levying mony, (which is the Nutritive

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: faculty,) has depended on a generall Assembly; the Power of conduct and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: command, (which is the Motive Faculty,) on one man; and the Power of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: making Lawes, (which is the Rationall faculty,) on the accidentall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consent, not onely of those two, but also of a third; This endangereth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Common-wealth, somtimes for want of consent to good Lawes; but most

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: often for want of such Nourishment, as is necessary to Life, and Motion.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For although few perceive, that such government, is not government,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but division of the Common-wealth into three Factions, and call it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: mixt Monarchy; yet the truth is, that it is not one independent

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth, but three independent Factions; nor one Representative

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Person, but three. In the Kingdome of God, there may be three Persons

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: independent, without breach of unity in God that Reigneth; but where men

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Reigne, that be subject to diversity of opinions, it cannot be so. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore if the King bear the person of the People, and the generall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Assembly bear also the person of the People, and another assembly bear

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the person of a Part of the people, they are not one Person, nor one

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign, but three Persons, and three Soveraigns.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To what Disease in the Naturall Body of man, I may exactly compare this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: irregularity of a Common-wealth, I know not. But I have seen a man, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: had another man growing out of his side, with an head, armes, breast,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and stomach, of his own: If he had had another man growing out of his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other side, the comparison might then have been exact.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Want Of Mony

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Hitherto I have named such Diseases of a Common-wealth, as are of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: greatest, and most present danger. There be other, not so great; which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: neverthelesse are not unfit to be observed. As first, the difficulty of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: raising Mony, for the necessary uses of the Common-wealth; especially

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the approach of warre. This difficulty ariseth from the opinion, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: every Subject hath of a Propriety in his lands and goods, exclusive of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Soveraigns Right to the use of the same. From whence it commeth to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: passe, that the Soveraign Power, which foreseeth the necessities and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: dangers of the Common-wealth, (finding the passage of mony to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: publique Treasure obstructed, by the tenacity of the people,) whereas

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it ought to extend it selfe, to encounter, and prevent such dangers in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their beginnings, contracteth it selfe as long as it can, and when it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: cannot longer, struggles with the people by strategems of Law, to obtain

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: little summes, which not sufficing, he is fain at last violently to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: open the way for present supply, or Perish; and being put often to these

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: extremities, at last reduceth the people to their due temper; or else

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Common-wealth must perish. Insomuch as we may compare this Distemper

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: very aptly to an Ague; wherein, the fleshy parts being congealed, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by venomous matter obstructed; the Veins which by their naturall course

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: empty themselves into the Heart, are not (as they ought to be) supplyed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from the Arteries, whereby there succeedeth at first a cold contraction,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and trembling of the limbes; and afterwards a hot, and strong endeavour

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Heart, to force a passage for the Bloud; and before it can do

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that, contenteth it selfe with the small refreshments of such things as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: coole of a time, till (if Nature be strong enough) it break at last

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the contumacy of the parts obstructed, and dissipateth the venome into

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sweat; or (if Nature be too weak) the Patient dyeth.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Monopolies And Abuses Of Publicans

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Again, there is sometimes in a Common-wealth, a Disease, which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: resembleth the Pleurisie; and that is, when the Treasure of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth, flowing out of its due course, is gathered together in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: too much abundance, in one, or a few private men, by Monopolies, or by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Farmes of the Publique Revenues; in the same manner as the Blood in a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Pleurisie, getting into the Membrane of the breast, breedeth there an

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Inflammation, accompanied with a Fever, and painfull stitches.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Popular Men

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Also, the Popularity of a potent Subject, (unlesse the Common-wealth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have very good caution of his fidelity,) is a dangerous Disease; because

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the people (which should receive their motion from the Authority of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign,) by the flattery, and by the reputation of an ambitious man,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are drawn away from their obedience to the Lawes, to follow a man, of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whose vertues, and designes they have no knowledge. And this is commonly

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of more danger in a Popular Government, than in a Monarchy; as it may

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: easily be made believe, they are the People. By this means it was, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Julius Caesar, who was set up by the People against the Senate, having

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: won to himselfe the affections of his Army, made himselfe Master, both

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Senate and People. And this proceeding of popular, and ambitious men,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is plain Rebellion; and may be resembled to the effects of Witchcraft.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Excessive Greatnesse Of A Town, Multitude Of Corporations

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Another infirmity of a Common-wealth, is the immoderate greatnesse of a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Town, when it is able to furnish out of its own Circuit, the number, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: expence of a great Army: As also the great number of Corporations; which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are as it were many lesser Common-wealths in the bowels of a greater,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: like wormes in the entrayles of a naturall man.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Liberty Of Disputing Against Soveraign Power

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To which may be added, the Liberty of Disputing against absolute Power,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by pretenders to Politicall Prudence; which though bred for the most

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: part in the Lees of the people; yet animated by False Doctrines, are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: perpetually medling with the Fundamentall Lawes, to the molestation

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Common-wealth; like the little Wormes, which Physicians call

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ascarides.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: We may further adde, the insatiable appetite, or Bulimia, of enlarging

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Dominion; with the incurable Wounds thereby many times received from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the enemy; And the Wens, of ununited conquests, which are many times a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: burthen, and with lesse danger lost, than kept; As also the Lethargy of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ease, and Consumption of Riot and Vain Expence.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Dissolution Of The Common-wealth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lastly, when in a warre (forraign, or intestine,) the enemies got a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: final Victory; so as (the forces of the Common-wealth keeping the field

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: no longer) there is no farther protection of Subjects in their loyalty;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: then is the Common-wealth DISSOLVED, and every man at liberty to protect

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: himselfe by such courses as his own discretion shall suggest unto him.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For the Soveraign, is the publique Soule, giving Life and Motion to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth; which expiring, the Members are governed by it no more,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: than the Carcasse of a man, by his departed (though Immortal) Soule. For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: though the Right of a Soveraign Monarch cannot be extinguished by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: act of another; yet the Obligation of the members may. For he that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: wants protection, may seek it anywhere; and when he hath it, is obliged

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (without fraudulent pretence of having submitted himselfe out of fear,)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to protect his Protection as long as he is able. But when the Power of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: an Assembly is once suppressed, the Right of the same perisheth utterly;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: because the Assembly it selfe is extinct; and consequently, there is no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: possibility for the Soveraignty to re-enter.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CHAPTER XXX. OF THE OFFICE OF THE SOVERAIGN REPRESENTATIVE

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Procuration Of The Good Of The People

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The OFFICE of the Soveraign, (be it a Monarch, or an Assembly,)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consisteth in the end, for which he was trusted with the Soveraign

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Power, namely the procuration of the Safety Of The People; to which he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is obliged by the Law of Nature, and to render an account thereof to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: God, the Author of that Law, and to none but him. But by Safety here, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not meant a bare Preservation, but also all other Contentments of life,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which every man by lawfull Industry, without danger, or hurt to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth, shall acquire to himselfe.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: By Instruction & Lawes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And this is intended should be done, not by care applyed to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Individualls, further than their protection from injuries, when they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shall complain; but by a generall Providence, contained in publique

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Instruction, both of Doctrine, and Example; and in the making, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: executing of good Lawes, to which individuall persons may apply their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: own cases.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Against The Duty Of A Soveraign To Relinquish Any Essentiall Right

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Soveraignty Or Not To See The People Taught The Grounds Of Them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And because, if the essentiall Rights of Soveraignty (specified before

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the eighteenth Chapter) be taken away, the Common-wealth is thereby

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: dissolved, and every man returneth into the condition, and calamity of a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: warre with every other man, (which is the greatest evill that can happen

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in this life;) it is the Office of the Soveraign, to maintain those

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Rights entire; and consequently against his duty, First, to transferre

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to another, or to lay from himselfe any of them. For he that deserteth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Means, deserteth the Ends; and he deserteth the Means, that being

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Soveraign, acknowledgeth himselfe subject to the Civill Lawes; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: renounceth the Power of Supreme Judicature; or of making Warre, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Peace by his own Authority; or of Judging of the Necessities of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth; or of levying Mony, and Souldiers, when, and as much as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in his own conscience he shall judge necessary; or of making Officers,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Ministers both of Warre, and Peace; or of appointing Teachers, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: examining what Doctrines are conformable, or contrary to the Defence,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Peace, and Good of the people. Secondly, it is against his duty, to let

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the people be ignorant, or mis-in-formed of the grounds, and reasons

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of those his essentiall Rights; because thereby men are easie to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: seduced, and drawn to resist him, when the Common-wealth shall require

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their use and exercise.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And the grounds of these Rights, have the rather need to be diligently,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and truly taught; because they cannot be maintained by any Civill Law,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or terrour of legal punishment. For a Civill Law, that shall forbid

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Rebellion, (and such is all resistance to the essentiall Rights of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraignty,) is not (as a Civill Law) any obligation, but by vertue

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: onely of the Law of Nature, that forbiddeth the violation of Faith;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which naturall obligation if men know not, they cannot know the Right of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: any Law the Soveraign maketh. And for the Punishment, they take it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but for an act of Hostility; which when they think they have strength

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: enough, they will endeavour by acts of Hostility, to avoyd.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Objection Of Those That Say There Are No Principles Of Reason For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Absolute Soveraignty

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: As I have heard some say, that Justice is but a word, without substance;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and that whatsoever a man can by force, or art, acquire to himselfe,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (not onely in the condition of warre, but also in a Common-wealth,) is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his own, which I have already shewed to be false: So there be also

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that maintain, that there are no grounds, nor Principles of Reason, to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sustain those essentiall Rights, which make Soveraignty absolute. For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: if there were, they would have been found out in some place, or other;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whereas we see, there has not hitherto been any Common-wealth, where

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: those Rights have been acknowledged, or challenged. Wherein they argue

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as ill, as if the Savage people of America, should deny there were any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: grounds, or Principles of Reason, so to build a house, as to last as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: long as the materials, because they never yet saw any so well built.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Time, and Industry, produce every day new knowledge. And as the art

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of well building, is derived from Principles of Reason, observed by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: industrious men, that had long studied the nature of materials, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the divers effects of figure, and proportion, long after mankind

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: began (though poorly) to build: So, long time after men have begun to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: constitute Common-wealths, imperfect, and apt to relapse into disorder,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there may, Principles of Reason be found out, by industrious meditation,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to make use of them, or be neglected by them, or not, concerneth my

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: particular interest, at this day, very little. But supposing that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: these of mine are not such Principles of Reason; yet I am sure they are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Principles from Authority of Scripture; as I shall make it appear, when

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: I shall come to speak of the Kingdome of God, (administred by Moses,)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: over the Jewes, his peculiar people by Covenant.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Objection From The Incapacity Of The Vulgar

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But they say again, that though the Principles be right, yet Common

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: people are not of capacity enough to be made to understand them. I

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: should be glad, that the Rich, and Potent Subjects of a Kingdome, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: those that are accounted the most Learned, were no lesse incapable than

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they. But all men know, that the obstructions to this kind of doctrine,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: proceed not so much from the difficulty of the matter, as from the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: interest of them that are to learn. Potent men, digest hardly any thing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that setteth up a Power to bridle their affections; and Learned men,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: any thing that discovereth their errours, and thereby lesseneth their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Authority: whereas the Common-peoples minds, unlesse they be tainted

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with dependance on the Potent, or scribbled over with the opinions

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of their Doctors, are like clean paper, fit to receive whatsoever by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Publique Authority shall be imprinted in them. Shall whole Nations be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: brought to Acquiesce in the great Mysteries of Christian Religion, which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are above Reason; and millions of men be made believe, that the same

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Body may be in innumerable places, at one and the same time, which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is against Reason; and shall not men be able, by their teaching, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: preaching, protected by the Law, to make that received, which is so

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consonant to Reason, that any unprejudicated man, needs no more to learn

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it, than to hear it? I conclude therefore, that in the instruction

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the people in the Essentiall Rights (which are the Naturall, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Fundamentall Lawes) of Soveraignty, there is no difficulty, (whilest a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign has his Power entire,) but what proceeds from his own fault,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or the fault of those whom he trusteth in the administration of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth; and consequently, it is his Duty, to cause them so to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: instructed; and not onely his Duty, but his Benefit also, and Security,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: against the danger that may arrive to himselfe in his naturall Person,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from Rebellion.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Subjects Are To Be Taught, Not To Affect Change Of Government

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And (to descend to particulars) the People are to be taught, First, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they ought not to be in love with any forme of Government they see

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in their neighbour Nations, more than with their own, nor (whatsoever

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: present prosperity they behold in Nations that are otherwise governed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: than they,) to desire change. For the prosperity of a People ruled by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: an Aristocraticall, or Democraticall assembly, commeth not from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Aristocracy, nor from Democracy, but from the Obedience, and Concord of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Subjects; nor do the people flourish in a Monarchy, because one man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: has the right to rule them, but because they obey him. Take away in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: any kind of State, the Obedience, (and consequently the Concord of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: People,) and they shall not onely not flourish, but in short time be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: dissolved. And they that go about by disobedience, to doe no more than

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: reforme the Common-wealth, shall find they do thereby destroy it; like

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the foolish daughters of Peleus (in the fable;) which desiring to renew

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the youth of their decrepit Father, did by the Counsell of Medea, cut

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him in pieces, and boyle him, together with strange herbs, but made not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of him a new man. This desire of change, is like the breach of the first

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Gods Commandements: For there God says, Non Habebis Deos Alienos;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Thou shalt not have the Gods of other Nations; and in another place

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: concerning Kings, that they are Gods.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nor Adhere (Against The Soveraign) To Popular Men

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Secondly, they are to be taught, that they ought not to be led with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: admiration of the vertue of any of their fellow Subjects, how

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: high soever he stand, nor how conspicuously soever he shine in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth; nor of any Assembly, (except the Soveraign Assembly,)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: so as to deferre to them any obedience, or honour, appropriate to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign onely, whom (in their particular stations) they represent; nor

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to receive any influence from them, but such as is conveighed by them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from the Soveraign Authority. For that Soveraign, cannot be imagined to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: love his People as he ought, that is not Jealous of them, but suffers

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them by the flattery of Popular men, to be seduced from their loyalty,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as they have often been, not onely secretly, but openly, so as to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: proclaime Marriage with them In Facie Ecclesiae by Preachers; and by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: publishing the same in the open streets: which may fitly be compared to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the violation of the second of the ten Commandements.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nor To Dispute The Soveraign Power

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Thirdly, in consequence to this, they ought to be informed, how great

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: fault it is, to speak evill of the Soveraign Representative, (whether

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: One man, or an Assembly of men;) or to argue and dispute his Power, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: any way to use his Name irreverently, whereby he may be brought into

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Contempt with his People, and their Obedience (in which the safety

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Common-wealth consisteth) slackened. Which doctrine the third

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Commandement by resemblance pointeth to.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And To Have Dayes Set Apart To Learn Their Duty

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Fourthly, seeing people cannot be taught this, nor when 'tis taught,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: remember it, nor after one generation past, so much as know in whom the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign Power is placed, without setting a part from their ordinary

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: labour, some certain times, in which they may attend those that are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: appointed to instruct them; It is necessary that some such times be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: determined, wherein they may assemble together, and (after prayers and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: praises given to God, the Soveraign of Soveraigns) hear those their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Duties told them, and the Positive Lawes, such as generally concern them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all, read and expounded, and be put in mind of the Authority that maketh

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them Lawes. To this end had the Jewes every seventh day, a Sabbath, in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which the Law was read and expounded; and in the solemnity whereof they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: were put in mind, that their King was God; that having created the world

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in six days, he rested the seventh day; and by their resting on it from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their labour, that that God was their King, which redeemed them from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their servile, and painfull labour in Egypt, and gave them a time, after

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they had rejoyced in God, to take joy also in themselves, by lawfull

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: recreation. So that the first Table of the Commandements, is spent all,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in setting down the summe of Gods absolute Power; not onely as God,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but as King by pact, (in peculiar) of the Jewes; and may therefore give

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: light, to those that have the Soveraign Power conferred on them by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consent of men, to see what doctrine they Ought to teach their Subjects.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And To Honour Their Parents

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And because the first instruction of Children, dependeth on the care

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of their Parents; it is necessary that they should be obedient to them,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whilest they are under their tuition; and not onely so, but that also

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: afterwards (as gratitude requireth,) they acknowledge the benefit of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their education, by externall signes of honour. To which end they are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to be taught, that originally the Father of every man was also his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign Lord, with power over him of life and death; and that the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Fathers of families, when by instituting a Common-wealth, they resigned

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that absolute Power, yet it was never intended, they should lose the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: honour due unto them for their education. For to relinquish such right,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was not necessary to the Institution of Soveraign Power; nor would there

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be any reason, why any man should desire to have children, or take the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: care to nourish, and instruct them, if they were afterwards to have no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other benefit from them, than from other men. And this accordeth with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the fifth Commandement.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And To Avoyd Doing Of Injury:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Again, every Soveraign Ought to cause Justice to be taught, which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (consisting in taking from no man what is his) is as much as to say, to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: cause men to be taught not to deprive their Neighbour, by violence,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or fraud, of any thing which by the Soveraign Authority is theirs. Of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: things held in propriety, those that are dearest to a man are his own

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: life, & limbs; and in the next degree, (in most men,) those that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: concern conjugall affection; and after them riches and means of living.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Therefore the People are to be taught, to abstain from violence to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: one anothers person, by private revenges; from violation of conjugall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: honour; and from forcibly rapine, and fraudulent surreption of one

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: anothers goods. For which purpose also it is necessary they be shewed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the evill consequences of false Judgement, by corruption either of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Judges or Witnesses, whereby the distinction of propriety is taken away,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Justice becomes of no effect: all which things are intimated in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sixth, seventh, eighth, and ninth Commandements.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And To Do All This Sincerely From The Heart

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lastly, they are to be taught, that not onely the unjust facts, but the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: designes and intentions to do them, (though by accident hindred,) are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Injustice; which consisteth in the pravity of the will, as well as in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the irregularity of the act. And this is the intention of the tenth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Commandement, and the summe of the Second Table; which is reduced all to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: this one Commandement of mutuall Charity, "Thou shalt love thy neighbour

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as thy selfe:" as the summe of the first Table is reduced to "the love

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of God;" whom they had then newly received as their King.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Use Of Universities

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: As for the Means, and Conduits, by which the people may receive this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Instruction, wee are to search, by what means so may Opinions,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: contrary to the peace of Man-kind, upon weak and false Principles, have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: neverthelesse been so deeply rooted in them. I mean those, which I have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the precedent Chapter specified: as That men shall Judge of what is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: lawfull and unlawfull, not by the Law it selfe, but by their own

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: private Judgements; That Subjects sinne in obeying the Commands of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth, unlesse they themselves have first judged them to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: lawfull: That their Propriety in their riches is such, as to exclude the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Dominion, which the Common-wealth hath over the same: That it is lawfull

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for Subjects to kill such, as they call Tyrants: That the Soveraign

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Power may be divided, and the like; which come to be instilled into

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the People by this means. They whom necessity, or covetousnesse keepeth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: attent on their trades, and labour; and they, on the other side, whom

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: superfluity, or sloth carrieth after their sensuall pleasures, (which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: two sorts of men take up the greatest part of Man-kind,) being diverted

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from the deep meditation, which the learning of truth, not onely in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: matter of Naturall Justice, but also of all other Sciences necessarily

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: requireth, receive the Notions of their duty, chiefly from Divines

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the Pulpit, and partly from such of their Neighbours, or familiar

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: acquaintance, as having the Faculty of discoursing readily, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: plausibly, seem wiser and better learned in cases of Law, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Conscience, than themselves. And the Divines, and such others as make

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shew of Learning, derive their knowledge from the Universities, and from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Schooles of Law, or from the Books, which by men eminent in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: those Schooles, and Universities have been published. It is therefore

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: manifest, that the Instruction of the people, dependeth wholly, on the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: right teaching of Youth in the Universities. But are not (may some men

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: say) the Universities of England learned enough already to do that? or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is it you will undertake to teach the Universities? Hard questions. Yet

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to the first, I doubt not to answer; that till towards the later end of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Henry the Eighth, the Power of the Pope, was alwayes upheld against the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Power of the Common-wealth, principally by the Universities; and that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the doctrines maintained by so many Preachers, against the Soveraign

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Power of the King, and by so many Lawyers, and others, that had their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: education there, is a sufficient argument, that though the Universities

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: were not authors of those false doctrines, yet they knew not how to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: plant the true. For in such a contradiction of Opinions, it is most

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: certain, that they have not been sufficiently instructed; and 'tis no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: wonder, if they yet retain a relish of that subtile liquor, wherewith

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they were first seasoned, against the Civill Authority. But to the later

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: question, it is not fit, nor needfull for me to say either I, or No: for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: any man that sees what I am doing, may easily perceive what I think.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The safety of the People, requireth further, from him, or them that have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Soveraign Power, that Justice be equally administred to all degrees

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of People; that is, that as well the rich, and mighty, as poor and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: obscure persons, may be righted of the injuries done them; so as the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: great, may have no greater hope of impunity, when they doe violence,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: dishonour, or any Injury to the meaner sort, than when one of these,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: does the like to one of them: For in this consisteth Equity; to which,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as being a Precept of the Law of Nature, a Soveraign is as much subject,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as any of the meanest of his People. All breaches of the Law, are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: offences against the Common-wealth: but there be some, that are also

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: against private Persons. Those that concern the Common-wealth onely, may

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: without breach of Equity be pardoned; for every man may pardon what is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: done against himselfe, according to his own discretion. But an offence

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: against a private man, cannot in Equity be pardoned, without the consent

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of him that is injured; or reasonable satisfaction.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Inequality of Subjects, proceedeth from the Acts of Soveraign Power;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and therefore has no more place in the presence of the Soveraign; that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is to say, in a Court of Justice, then the Inequality between Kings,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and their Subjects, in the presence of the King of Kings. The honour of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: great Persons, is to be valued for their beneficence, and the aydes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they give to men of inferiour rank, or not at all. And the violences,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: oppressions, and injuries they do, are not extenuated, but aggravated by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the greatnesse of their persons; because they have least need to commit

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them. The consequences of this partiality towards the great, proceed in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: this manner. Impunity maketh Insolence; Insolence Hatred; and Hatred,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: an Endeavour to pull down all oppressing and contumelious greatnesse,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: though with the ruine of the Common-wealth.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Equall Taxes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To Equall Justice, appertaineth also the Equall imposition of Taxes;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the equality whereof dependeth not on the Equality of riches, but on the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Equality of the debt, that every man oweth to the Common-wealth for his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: defence. It is not enough, for a man to labour for the maintenance

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of his life; but also to fight, (if need be,) for the securing of his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: labour. They must either do as the Jewes did after their return from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: captivity, in re-edifying the Temple, build with one hand, and hold the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sword in the other; or else they must hire others to fight for them. For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Impositions that are layd on the People by the Soveraign Power, are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: nothing else but the Wages, due to them that hold the publique Sword,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to defend private men in the exercise of severall Trades, and Callings.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Seeing then the benefit that every one receiveth thereby, is the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: enjoyment of life, which is equally dear to poor, and rich; the debt

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which a poor man oweth them that defend his life, is the same which a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: rich man oweth for the defence of his; saving that the rich, who have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the service of the poor, may be debtors not onely for their own persons,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but for many more. Which considered, the Equality of Imposition,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consisteth rather in the Equality of that which is consumed, than of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: riches of the persons that consume the same. For what reason is there,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that he which laboureth much, and sparing the fruits of his labour,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consumeth little, should be more charged, then he that living idlely,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: getteth little, and spendeth all he gets; seeing the one hath no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: more protection from the Common-wealth, then the other? But when the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Impositions, are layd upon those things which men consume, every man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: payeth Equally for what he useth: Nor is the Common-wealth defrauded, by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the luxurious waste of private men.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Publique Charity

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And whereas many men, by accident unevitable, become unable to maintain

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: themselves by their labour; they ought not to be left to the Charity

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of private persons; but to be provided for, (as far-forth as the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: necessities of Nature require,) by the Lawes of the Common-wealth. For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as it is Uncharitablenesse in any man, to neglect the impotent; so it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is in the Soveraign of a Common-wealth, to expose them to the hazard of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such uncertain Charity.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Prevention Of Idlenesse

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But for such as have strong bodies, the case is otherwise: they are to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be forced to work; and to avoyd the excuse of not finding employment,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there ought to be such Lawes, as may encourage all manner of Arts; as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Navigation, Agriculture, Fishing, and all manner of Manifacture that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: requires labour. The multitude of poor, and yet strong people still

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: encreasing, they are to be transplanted into Countries not sufficiently

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: inhabited: where neverthelesse, they are not to exterminate those they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: find there; but constrain them to inhabit closer together, and not range

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a great deal of ground, to snatch what they find; but to court each

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: little Plot with art and labour, to give them their sustenance in due

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: season. And when all the world is overchargd with Inhabitants, then the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: last remedy of all is Warre; which provideth for every man, by Victory,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or Death.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Good Lawes What

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To the care of the Soveraign, belongeth the making of Good Lawes. But

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: what is a good Law? By a Good Law, I mean not a Just Law: for no Law can

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be Unjust. The Law is made by the Soveraign Power, and all that is done

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by such Power, is warranted, and owned by every one of the people; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that which every man will have so, no man can say is unjust. It is in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Lawes of a Common-wealth, as in the Lawes of Gaming: whatsoever

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Gamesters all agree on, is Injustice to none of them. A good Law

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is that, which is Needfull, for the Good Of The People, and withall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Perspicuous.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Such As Are Necessary

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For the use of Lawes, (which are but Rules Authorised) is not to bind

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the People from all Voluntary actions; but to direct and keep them in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such a motion, as not to hurt themselves by their own impetuous desires,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: rashnesse, or indiscretion, as Hedges are set, not to stop Travellers,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but to keep them in the way. And therefore a Law that is not Needfull,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: having not the true End of a Law, is not Good. A Law may be conceived to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be Good, when it is for the benefit of the Soveraign; though it be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not Necessary for the People; but it is not so. For the good of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign and People, cannot be separated. It is a weak Soveraign, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: has weak Subjects; and a weak People, whose Soveraign wanteth Power to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: rule them at his will. Unnecessary Lawes are not good Lawes; but trapps

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for Mony: which where the right of Soveraign Power is acknowledged, are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: superfluous; and where it is not acknowledged, unsufficient to defend

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the People.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Such As Are Perspicuous

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Perspicuity, consisteth not so much in the words of the Law it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: selfe, as in a Declaration of the Causes, and Motives, for which it was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: made. That is it, that shewes us the meaning of the Legislator, and the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: meaning of the Legislator known, the Law is more easily understood

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by few, than many words. For all words, are subject to ambiguity;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and therefore multiplication of words in the body of the Law, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: multiplication of ambiguity: Besides it seems to imply, (by too much

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: diligence,) that whosoever can evade the words, is without the compasse

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Law. And this is a cause of many unnecessary Processes. For when

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: I consider how short were the Lawes of antient times; and how they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: grew by degrees still longer; me thinks I see a contention between the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Penners, and Pleaders of the Law; the former seeking to circumscribe

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the later; and the later to evade their circumscriptions; and that the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Pleaders have got the Victory. It belongeth therefore to the Office of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Legislator, (such as is in all Common-wealths the Supreme

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Representative, be it one Man, or an Assembly,) to make the reason

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Perspicuous, why the Law was made; and the Body of the Law it selfe, as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: short, but in as proper, and significant termes, as may be.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Punishments

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: It belongeth also to the Office of the Soveraign, to make a right

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: application of Punishments, and Rewards. And seeing the end of punishing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is not revenge, and discharge of choler; but correction, either of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: offender, or of others by his example; the severest Punishments are to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be inflicted for those Crimes, that are of most Danger to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Publique; such as are those which proceed from malice to the Government

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: established; those that spring from contempt of Justice; those that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: provoke Indignation in the Multitude; and those, which unpunished, seem

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Authorised, as when they are committed by Sonnes, Servants, or Favorites

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of men in Authority: For Indignation carrieth men, not onely against the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Actors, and Authors of Injustice; but against all Power that is likely

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to protect them; as in the case of Tarquin; when for the Insolent act of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: one of his Sonnes, he was driven out of Rome, and the Monarchy it selfe

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: dissolved. But Crimes of Infirmity; such as are those which proceed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from great provocation, from great fear, great need, or from ignorance

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whether the Fact be a great Crime, or not, there is place many times for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lenity, without prejudice to the Common-wealth; and Lenity when there is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such place for it, is required by the Law of Nature. The Punishment of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Leaders, and teachers in a Commotion; not the poore seduced People,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: when they are punished, can profit the Common-wealth by their example.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To be severe to the People, is to punish that ignorance, which may in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: great part be imputed to the Soveraign, whose fault it was, they were no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: better instructed.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Rewards

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In like manner it belongeth to the Office, and Duty of the Soveraign,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to apply his Rewards alwayes so, as there may arise from them benefit

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to the Common-wealth: wherein consisteth their Use, and End; and is then

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: done, when they that have well served the Common-wealth, are with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as little expence of the Common Treasure, as is possible, so well

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: recompenced, as others thereby may be encouraged, both to serve the same

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as faithfully as they can, and to study the arts by which they may be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: enabled to do it better. To buy with Mony, or Preferment, from a Popular

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ambitious Subject, to be quiet, and desist from making ill impressions

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the mindes of the People, has nothing of the nature of Reward; (which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is ordained not for disservice, but for service past;) nor a signe of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Gratitude, but of Fear: nor does it tend to the Benefit, but to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Dammage of the Publique. It is a contention with Ambition, like that of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Hercules with the Monster Hydra, which having many heads, for every one

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that was vanquished, there grew up three. For in like manner, when the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: stubbornnesse of one Popular man, is overcome with Reward, there arise

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: many more (by the Example) that do the same Mischiefe, in hope of like

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Benefit: and as all sorts of Manifacture, so also Malice encreaseth by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: being vendible. And though sometimes a Civill warre, may be differred,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by such wayes as that, yet the danger growes still the greater, and the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Publique ruine more assured. It is therefore against the Duty of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign, to whom the Publique Safety is committed, to Reward those

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that aspire to greatnesse by disturbing the Peace of their Country, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not rather to oppose the beginnings of such men, with a little danger,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: than after a longer time with greater.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Counsellours

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Another Businesse of the Soveraign, is to choose good Counsellours;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: I mean such, whose advice he is to take in the Government of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth. For this word Counsell, Consilium, corrupted from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Considium, is a large signification, and comprehendeth all Assemblies

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of men that sit together, not onely to deliberate what is to be done

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hereafter, but also to judge of Facts past, and of Law for the present.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: I take it here in the first sense onely: And in this sense, there is no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: choyce of Counsell, neither in a Democracy, nor Aristocracy; because the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: persons Counselling are members of the person Counselled. The choyce

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Counsellours therefore is to Monarchy; In which, the Soveraign that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: endeavoureth not to make choyce of those, that in every kind are the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: most able, dischargeth not his Office as he ought to do. The most able

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Counsellours, are they that have least hope of benefit by giving evill

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Counsell, and most knowledge of those things that conduce to the Peace,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Defence of the Common-wealth. It is a hard matter to know who

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: expecteth benefit from publique troubles; but the signes that guide to a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: just suspicion, is the soothing of the people in their unreasonable,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or irremediable grievances, by men whose estates are not sufficient to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: discharge their accustomed expences, and may easily be observed by any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: one whom it concerns to know it. But to know, who has most knowledge of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Publique affaires, is yet harder; and they that know them, need them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a great deale the lesse. For to know, who knowes the Rules almost of any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Art, is a great degree of the knowledge of the same Art; because no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man can be assured of the truth of anothers Rules, but he that is first

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: taught to understand them. But the best signes of Knowledge of any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Art, are, much conversing in it, and constant good effects of it. Good

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Counsell comes not by Lot, nor by Inheritance; and therefore there is no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: more reason to expect good Advice from the rich, or noble, in matter

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of State, than in delineating the dimensions of a fortresse; unlesse we

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shall think there needs no method in the study of the Politiques, (as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there does in the study of Geometry,) but onely to be lookers on; which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is not so. For the Politiques is the harder study of the two. Whereas

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in these parts of Europe, it hath been taken for a Right of certain

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: persons, to have place in the highest Councell of State by Inheritance;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it is derived from the Conquests of the antient Germans; wherein many

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: absolute Lords joyning together to conquer other Nations, would not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: enter in to the Confederacy, without such Priviledges, as might be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: marks of difference in time following, between their Posterity, and the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: posterity of their Subjects; which Priviledges being inconsistent with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Soveraign Power, by the favour of the Soveraign, they may seem to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: keep; but contending for them as their Right, they must needs by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: degrees let them go, and have at last no further honour, than adhaereth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: naturally to their abilities.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And how able soever be the Counsellours in any affaire, the benefit

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of their Counsell is greater, when they give every one his Advice, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: reasons of it apart, than when they do it in an Assembly, by way of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Orations; and when they have praemeditated, than when they speak on the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sudden; both because they have more time, to survey the consequences

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of action; and are lesse subject to be carried away to contradiction,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: through Envy, Emulation, or other Passions arising from the difference

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of opinion.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The best Counsell, in those things that concern not other Nations, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: onely the ease, and benefit the Subjects may enjoy, by Lawes that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: look onely inward, is to be taken from the generall informations, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: complaints of the people of each Province, who are best acquainted

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with their own wants, and ought therefore, when they demand nothing in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: derogation of the essentiall Rights of Soveraignty, to be diligently

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: taken notice of. For without those Essentiall Rights, (as I have often

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: before said,) the Common-wealth cannot at all subsist.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Commanders

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: A Commander of an Army in chiefe, if he be not Popular, shall not be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: beloved, nor feared as he ought to be by his Army; and consequently

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: cannot performe that office with good successe. He must therefore be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Industrious, Valiant, Affable, Liberall and Fortunate, that he may gain

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: an opinion both of sufficiency, and of loving his Souldiers. This is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Popularity, and breeds in the Souldiers both desire, and courage, to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: recommend themselves to his favour; and protects the severity of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Generall, in punishing (when need is) the Mutinous, or negligent

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Souldiers. But this love of Souldiers, (if caution be not given of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Commanders fidelity,) is a dangerous thing to Soveraign Power;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: especially when it is in the hands of an Assembly not popular. It

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: belongeth therefore to the safety of the People, both that they be good

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Conductors, and faithfull subjects, to whom the Soveraign Commits his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Armies.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But when the Soveraign himselfe is Popular, that is, reverenced and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: beloved of his People, there is no danger at all from the Popularity of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Subject. For Souldiers are never so generally unjust, as to side with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their Captain; though they love him, against their Soveraign, when they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: love not onely his Person, but also his Cause. And therefore those,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: who by violence have at any time suppressed the Power of their Lawfull

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign, before they could settle themselves in his place, have been

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: alwayes put to the trouble of contriving their Titles, to save the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: People from the shame of receiving them. To have a known Right to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign Power, is so popular a quality, as he that has it needs no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: more, for his own part, to turn the hearts of his Subjects to him, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that they see him able absolutely to govern his own Family: Nor, on the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: part of his enemies, but a disbanding of their Armies. For the greatest

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and most active part of Mankind, has never hetherto been well contented

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with the present.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Concerning the Offices of one Soveraign to another, which are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: comprehended in that Law, which is commonly called the Law of Nations,

author: Thomas Hobbes
