text: I need not say any thing in this place; because the Law of Nations, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Law of Nature, is the same thing. And every Soveraign hath the same

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Right, in procuring the safety of his People, that any particular man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: can have, in procuring the safety of his own Body. And the same Law,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that dictateth to men that have no Civil Government, what they ought to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: do, and what to avoyd in regard of one another, dictateth the same to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealths, that is, to the Consciences of Soveraign Princes, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign Assemblies; there being no Court of Naturall Justice, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the Conscience onely; where not Man, but God raigneth; whose Lawes,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (such of them as oblige all Mankind,) in respect of God, as he is the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Author of Nature, are Naturall; and in respect of the same God, as he is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: King of Kings, are Lawes. But of the Kingdome of God, as King of Kings,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and as King also of a peculiar People, I shall speak in the rest of this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: discourse.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CHAPTER XXXI. OF THE KINGDOME OF GOD BY NATURE

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Scope Of The Following Chapters

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: That the condition of meer Nature, that is to say, of absolute Liberty,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such as is theirs, that neither are Soveraigns, nor Subjects, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Anarchy, and the condition of Warre: That the Praecepts, by which men

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are guided to avoyd that condition, are the Lawes of Nature: That

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Common-wealth, without Soveraign Power, is but a word, without

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: substance, and cannot stand: That Subjects owe to Soveraigns, simple

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Obedience, in all things, wherein their obedience is not repugnant

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to the Lawes of God, I have sufficiently proved, in that which I have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: already written. There wants onely, for the entire knowledge of Civill

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: duty, to know what are those Lawes of God. For without that, a man knows

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not, when he is commanded any thing by the Civill Power, whether it be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: contrary to the Law of God, or not: and so, either by too much civill

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: obedience, offends the Divine Majesty, or through feare of offending

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: God, transgresses the commandements of the Common-wealth. To avoyd both

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: these Rocks, it is necessary to know what are the Lawes Divine. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: seeing the knowledge of all Law, dependeth on the knowledge of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign Power; I shall say something in that which followeth, of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: KINGDOME OF GOD.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Who Are Subjects In The Kingdome Of God

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "God is King, let the Earth rejoice," saith the Psalmist. (Psal. 96. 1).

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And again, "God is King though the Nations be angry; and he that sitteth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: on the Cherubins, though the earth be moved." (Psal. 98. 1). Whether

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: men will or not, they must be subject alwayes to the Divine Power. By

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: denying the Existence, or Providence of God, men may shake off their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ease, but not their Yoke. But to call this Power of God, which extendeth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it selfe not onely to Man, but also to Beasts, and Plants, and Bodies

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: inanimate, by the name of Kingdome, is but a metaphoricall use of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the word. For he onely is properly said to Raigne, that governs his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Subjects, by his Word, and by promise of Rewards to those that obey

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it, and by threatning them with Punishment that obey it not. Subjects

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore in the Kingdome of God, are not Bodies Inanimate, nor

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: creatures Irrationall; because they understand no Precepts as his: Nor

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Atheists; nor they that believe not that God has any care of the actions

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of mankind; because they acknowledge no Word for his, nor have hope of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his rewards, or fear of his threatnings. They therefore that believe

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there is a God that governeth the world, and hath given Praecepts, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: propounded Rewards, and Punishments to Mankind, are Gods Subjects; all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the rest, are to be understood as Enemies.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: A Threefold Word Of God, Reason, Revelation, Prophecy

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To rule by Words, requires that such Words be manifestly made known;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for else they are no Lawes: For to the nature of Lawes belongeth a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sufficient, and clear Promulgation, such as may take away the excuse of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ignorance; which in the Lawes of men is but of one onely kind, and that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is, Proclamation, or Promulgation by the voyce of man. But God

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: declareth his Lawes three wayes; by the Dictates of Naturall Reason, By

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Revelation, and by the Voyce of some Man, to whom by the operation of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Miracles, he procureth credit with the rest. From hence there ariseth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a triple Word of God, Rational, Sensible, and Prophetique: to which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Correspondeth a triple Hearing; Right Reason, Sense Supernaturall, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Faith. As for Sense Supernaturall, which consisteth in Revelation, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Inspiration, there have not been any Universall Lawes so given, because

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: God speaketh not in that manner, but to particular persons, and to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: divers men divers things.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: A Twofold Kingdome Of God, Naturall And Prophetique From the difference

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: between the other two kinds of Gods Word, Rationall, and Prophetique,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there may be attributed to God, a two-fold Kingdome, Naturall, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Prophetique: Naturall, wherein he governeth as many of Mankind as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: acknowledge his Providence, by the naturall Dictates of Right Reason;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And Prophetique, wherein having chosen out one peculiar Nation (the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Jewes) for his Subjects, he governed them, and none but them, not onely

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by naturall Reason, but by Positive Lawes, which he gave them by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: mouths of his holy Prophets. Of the Naturall Kingdome of God I intend to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: speak in this Chapter.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Right Of Gods Soveraignty Is Derived From His Omnipotence The Right

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Nature, whereby God reigneth over men, and punisheth those that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: break his Lawes, is to be derived, not from his Creating them, as if

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he required obedience, as of Gratitude for his benefits; but from his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Irresistible Power. I have formerly shewn, how the Soveraign Right

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ariseth from Pact: To shew how the same Right may arise from Nature,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: requires no more, but to shew in what case it is never taken away.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Seeing all men by Nature had Right to All things, they had Right every

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: one to reigne over all the rest. But because this Right could not be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: obtained by force, it concerned the safety of every one, laying by that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Right, to set up men (with Soveraign Authority) by common consent,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to rule and defend them: whereas if there had been any man of Power

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Irresistible; there had been no reason, why he should not by that Power

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have ruled, and defended both himselfe, and them, according to his own

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: discretion. To those therefore whose Power is irresistible, the dominion

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of all men adhaereth naturally by their excellence of Power; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consequently it is from that Power, that the Kingdome over men, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Right of afflicting men at his pleasure, belongeth Naturally to God

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Almighty; not as Creator, and Gracious; but as Omnipotent. And though

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Punishment be due for Sinne onely, because by that word is understood

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Affliction for Sinne; yet the Right of Afflicting, is not alwayes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: derived from mens Sinne, but from Gods Power.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sinne Not The Cause Of All Affliction

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: This question, "Why Evill men often Prosper, and Good men suffer

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Adversity," has been much disputed by the Antient, and is the same

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with this of ours, "By what Right God dispenseth the Prosperities and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Adversities of this life;" and is of that difficulty, as it hath shaken

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the faith, not onely of the Vulgar, but of Philosophers, and which is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: more, of the Saints, concerning the Divine Providence. "How Good," saith

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: David, "is the God of Israel to those that are Upright in Heart; and yet

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: my feet were almost gone, my treadings had well-nigh slipt; for I was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: grieved at the Wicked, when I saw the Ungodly in such Prosperity."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And Job, how earnestly does he expostulate with God, for the many

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Afflictions he suffered, notwithstanding his Righteousnesse? This

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: question in the case of Job, is decided by God himselfe, not by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: arguments derived from Job's Sinne, but his own Power. For whereas the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: friends of Job drew their arguments from his Affliction to his Sinne,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and he defended himselfe by the conscience of his Innocence, God

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: himselfe taketh up the matter, and having justified the Affliction by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: arguments drawn from his Power, such as this "Where was thou when I

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: layd the foundations of the earth," and the like, both approved

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Job's Innocence, and reproved the Erroneous doctrine of his friends.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Conformable to this doctrine is the sentence of our Saviour, concerning

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the man that was born Blind, in these words, "Neither hath this man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sinned, nor his fathers; but that the works of God might be made

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: manifest in him." And though it be said "That Death entred into the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: world by sinne," (by which is meant that if Adam had never sinned, he had

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: never dyed, that is, never suffered any separation of his soule from his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: body,) it follows not thence, that God could not justly have Afflicted

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him, though he had not Sinned, as well as he afflicteth other living

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: creatures, that cannot sinne.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Divine Lawes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Having spoken of the Right of Gods Soveraignty, as grounded onely on

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nature; we are to consider next, what are the Divine Lawes, or Dictates

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Naturall Reason; which Lawes concern either the naturall Duties of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: one man to another, or the Honour naturally due to our Divine Soveraign.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The first are the same Lawes of Nature, of which I have spoken already

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the 14. and 15. Chapters of this Treatise; namely, Equity, Justice,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Mercy, Humility, and the rest of the Morall Vertues. It remaineth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore that we consider, what Praecepts are dictated to men, by their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Naturall Reason onely, without other word of God, touching the Honour

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Worship of the Divine Majesty.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Honour And Worship What

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Honour consisteth in the inward thought, and opinion of the Power, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Goodnesse of another: and therefore to Honour God, is to think as Highly

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of his Power and Goodnesse, as is possible. And of that opinion, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: externall signes appearing in the Words, and Actions of men, are called

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Worship; which is one part of that which the Latines understand by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: word Cultus: For Cultus signifieth properly, and constantly, that labour

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which a man bestowes on any thing, with a purpose to make benefit by it.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Now those things whereof we make benefit, are either subject to us, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the profit they yeeld, followeth the labour we bestow upon them, as a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: naturall effect; or they are not subject to us, but answer our labour,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: according to their own Wills. In the first sense the labour bestowed on

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Earth, is called Culture; and the education of Children a Culture of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their mindes. In the second sense, where mens wills are to be wrought to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: our purpose, not by Force, but by Compleasance, it signifieth as much as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Courting, that is, a winning of favour by good offices; as by praises,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by acknowledging their Power, and by whatsoever is pleasing to them from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whom we look for any benefit. And this is properly Worship: in which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sense Publicola, is understood for a Worshipper of the People, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Cultus Dei, for the Worship of God.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Severall Signes Of Honour

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: From internall Honour, consisting in the opinion of Power and Goodnesse,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: arise three Passions; Love, which hath reference to Goodnesse; and Hope,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Fear, that relate to Power: And three parts of externall worship;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Praise, Magnifying, and Blessing: The subject of Praise, being

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Goodnesse; the subject of Magnifying, and Blessing, being Power, and the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: effect thereof Felicity. Praise, and Magnifying are significant both by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Words, and Actions: By Words, when we say a man is Good, or Great:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: By Actions, when we thank him for his Bounty, and obey his Power. The

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: opinion of the Happinesse of another, can onely be expressed by words.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Worship Naturall And Arbitrary

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: There be some signes of Honour, (both in Attributes and Actions,) that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be Naturally so; as amongst Attributes, Good, Just, Liberall, and the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: like; and amongst Actions, Prayers, Thanks, and Obedience. Others are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: so by Institution, or Custome of men; and in some times and places are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Honourable; in others Dishonourable; in others Indifferent: such as are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Gestures in Salutation, Prayer, and Thanksgiving, in different

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: times and places, differently used. The former is Naturall; the later

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Arbitrary Worship.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Worship Commanded And Free

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And of Arbitrary Worship, there bee two differences: For sometimes it is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Commanded, sometimes Voluntary Worship: Commanded, when it is such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as hee requireth, who is Worshipped: Free, when it is such as the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Worshipper thinks fit. When it is Commanded, not the words, or gestures,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but the obedience is the Worship. But when Free, the Worship consists

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the opinion of the beholders: for if to them the words, or actions by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which we intend honour, seem ridiculous, and tending to contumely; they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are not Worship; because a signe is not a signe to him that giveth it,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but to him to whom it is made; that is, to the spectator.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Worship Publique And Private

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Again, there is a Publique, and a Private Worship. Publique, is the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Worship that a Common-wealth performeth, as one Person. Private, is that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which a Private person exhibiteth. Publique, in respect of the whole

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth, is Free; but in respect of Particular men it is not so.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Private, is in secret Free; but in the sight of the multitude, it is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: never without some Restraint, either from the Lawes, or from the Opinion

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of men; which is contrary to the nature of Liberty.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The End Of Worship

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The End of Worship amongst men, is Power. For where a man seeth another

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: worshipped he supposeth him powerfull, and is the readier to obey him;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which makes his Power greater. But God has no Ends: the worship we do

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him, proceeds from our duty, and is directed according to our capacity,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by those rules of Honour, that Reason dictateth to be done by the weak

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to the more potent men, in hope of benefit, for fear of dammage, or in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thankfulnesse for good already received from them.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Attributes Of Divine Honour

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: That we may know what worship of God is taught us by the light of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nature, I will begin with his Attributes. Where, First, it is manifest,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: we ought to attribute to him Existence: For no man can have the will to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: honour that, which he thinks not to have any Beeing.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Secondly, that those Philosophers, who sayd the World, or the Soule of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the World was God, spake unworthily of him; and denyed his Existence:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For by God, is understood the cause of the World; and to say the World

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is God, is to say there is no cause of it, that is, no God.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Thirdly, to say the World was not Created, but Eternall, (seeing that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which is Eternall has no cause,) is to deny there is a God.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Fourthly, that they who attributing (as they think) Ease to God, take

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from him the care of Mankind; take from him his Honour: for it takes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: away mens love, and fear of him; which is the root of Honour.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Fifthly, in those things that signifie Greatnesse, and Power; to say he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is Finite, is not to Honour him: For it is not a signe of the Will to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Honour God, to attribute to him lesse than we can; and Finite, is lesse

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: than we can; because to Finite, it is easie to adde more.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Therefore to attribute Figure to him, is not Honour; for all Figure is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Finite:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nor to say we conceive, and imagine, or have an Idea of him, in our

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: mind: for whatsoever we conceive is Finite:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Not to attribute to him Parts, or Totality; which are the Attributes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: onely of things Finite:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nor to say he is this, or that Place: for whatsoever is in Place, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: bounded, and Finite:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nor that he is Moved, or Resteth: for both these Attributes ascribe to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him Place:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nor that there be more Gods than one; because it implies them all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Finite: for there cannot be more than one Infinite: Nor to ascribe to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him (unlesse Metaphorically, meaning not the Passion, but the Effect)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Passions that partake of Griefe; as Repentance, Anger, Mercy: or of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Want; as Appetite, Hope, Desire; or of any Passive faculty: For Passion,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is Power limited by somewhat else.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And therefore when we ascribe to God a Will, it is not to be understood,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as that of Man, for a Rationall Appetite; but as the Power, by which he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: effecteth every thing.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Likewise when we attribute to him Sight, and other acts of Sense; as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: also Knowledge, and Understanding; which in us is nothing else, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a tumult of the mind, raised by externall things that presse the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: organicall parts of mans body: For there is no such thing in God; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: being things that depend on naturall causes, cannot be attributed to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Hee that will attribute to God, nothing but what is warranted by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: naturall Reason, must either use such Negative Attributes, as Infinite,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Eternall, Incomprehensible; or Superlatives, as Most High, Most Great,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and the like; or Indefinite, as Good, Just, Holy, Creator; and in such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sense, as if he meant not to declare what he is, (for that were to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: circumscribe him within the limits of our Fancy,) but how much wee

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: admire him, and how ready we would be to obey him; which is a signe of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Humility, and of a Will to honour him as much as we can: For there is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but one Name to signifie our Conception of his Nature, and that is, I

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: AM: and but one Name of his Relation to us, and that is God; in which is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: contained Father, King, and Lord.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Actions That Are Signes Of Divine Honour

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Concerning the actions of Divine Worship, it is a most generall Precept

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Reason, that they be signes of the Intention to Honour God; such as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are, First, Prayers: For not the Carvers, when they made Images, were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thought to make them Gods; but the People that Prayed to them.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Secondly, Thanksgiving; which differeth from Prayer in Divine Worship,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: no otherwise, than that Prayers precede, and Thanks succeed the benefit;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the end both of the one, and the other, being to acknowledge God, for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Author of all benefits, as well past, as future.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Thirdly, Gifts; that is to say, Sacrifices, and Oblations, (if they be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the best,) are signes of Honour: for they are Thanksgivings.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Fourthly, Not to swear by any but God, is naturally a signe of Honour:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for it is a confession that God onely knoweth the heart; and that no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: mans wit, or strength can protect a man against Gods vengence on the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: perjured.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Fifthly, it is a part of Rationall Worship, to speak Considerately

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of God; for it argues a Fear of him, and Fear, is a confession of his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Power. Hence followeth, That the name of God is not to be used rashly,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and to no purpose; for that is as much, as in Vain: And it is to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: no purpose; unlesse it be by way of Oath, and by order of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth, to make Judgements certain; or between Common-wealths,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to avoyd Warre. And that disputing of Gods nature is contrary to his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Honour: For it is supposed, that in this naturall Kingdome of God, there

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is no other way to know any thing, but by naturall Reason; that is, from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Principles of naturall Science; which are so farre from teaching us

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: any thing of Gods nature, as they cannot teach us our own nature, nor

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the nature of the smallest creature living. And therefore, when men out

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Principles of naturall Reason, dispute of the Attributes of God,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they but dishonour him: For in the Attributes which we give to God, we

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are not to consider the signification of Philosophicall Truth; but the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: signification of Pious Intention, to do him the greatest Honour we are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: able. From the want of which consideration, have proceeded the volumes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of disputation about the Nature of God, that tend not to his Honour, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to the honour of our own wits, and learning; and are nothing else but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: inconsiderate, and vain abuses of his Sacred Name.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sixthly, in Prayers, Thanksgivings, Offerings and Sacrifices, it is a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Dictate of naturall Reason, that they be every one in his kind the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: best, and most significant of Honour. As for example, that Prayers, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Thanksgiving, be made in Words and Phrases, not sudden, nor light, nor

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Plebeian; but beautifull and well composed; For else we do not God

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as much honour as we can. And therefore the Heathens did absurdly, to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: worship Images for Gods: But their doing it in Verse, and with Musick,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: both of Voyce, and Instruments, was reasonable. Also that the Beasts

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they offered in sacrifice, and the Gifts they offered, and their actions

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in Worshipping, were full of submission, and commemorative of benefits

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: received, was according to reason, as proceeding from an intention to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: honour him.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Seventhly, Reason directeth not onely to worship God in Secret; but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: also, and especially, in Publique, and in the sight of men: For without

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that, (that which in honour is most acceptable) the procuring others to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: honour him, is lost.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lastly, Obedience to his Lawes (that is, in this case to the Lawes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Nature,) is the greatest worship of all. For as Obedience is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: more acceptable to God than sacrifice; so also to set light by his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Commandements, is the greatest of all contumelies. And these are the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lawes of that Divine Worship, which naturall Reason dictateth to private

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: men.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Publique Worship Consisteth In Uniformity

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But seeing a Common-wealth is but one Person, it ought also to exhibite

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to God but one Worship; which then it doth, when it commandeth it to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: exhibited by Private men, Publiquely. And this is Publique Worship; the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: property whereof, is to be Uniforme: For those actions that are done

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: differently, by different men, cannot be said to be a Publique Worship.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And therefore, where many sorts of Worship be allowed, proceeding from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the different Religions of Private men, it cannot be said there is any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Publique Worship, nor that the Common-wealth is of any Religion at all.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: All Attributes Depend On The Lawes Civill

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And because words (and consequently the Attributes of God) have their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: signification by agreement, and constitution of men; those Attributes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are to be held significative of Honour, that men intend shall so be; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whatsoever may be done by the wills of particular men, where there is no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Law but Reason, may be done by the will of the Common-wealth, by Lawes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Civill. And because a Common-wealth hath no Will, nor makes no Lawes,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but those that are made by the Will of him, or them that have the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign Power; it followeth, that those Attributes which the Soveraign

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ordaineth, in the Worship of God, for signes of Honour, ought to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: taken and used for such, by private men in their publique Worship.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Not All Actions

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But because not all Actions are signes by Constitution; but some are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Naturally signes of Honour, others of Contumely, these later (which are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: those that men are ashamed to do in the sight of them they reverence)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: cannot be made by humane power a part of Divine worship; nor the former

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (such as are decent, modest, humble Behaviour) ever be separated from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it. But whereas there be an infinite number of Actions, and Gestures, of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: an indifferent nature; such of them as the Common-wealth shall ordain to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be Publiquely and Universally in use, as signes of Honour, and part of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Gods Worship, are to be taken and used for such by the Subjects. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that which is said in the Scripture, "It is better to obey God than

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: men," hath place in the kingdome of God by Pact, and not by Nature.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Naturall Punishments

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Having thus briefly spoken of the Naturall Kingdome of God, and his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Naturall Lawes, I will adde onely to this Chapter a short declaration of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his Naturall Punishments. There is no action of man in this life, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is not the beginning of so long a chayn of Consequences, as no humane

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Providence, is high enough, to give a man a prospect to the end. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in this Chayn, there are linked together both pleasing and unpleasing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: events; in such manner, as he that will do any thing for his pleasure,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: must engage himselfe to suffer all the pains annexed to it; and these

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: pains, are the Naturall Punishments of those actions, which are the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: beginning of more Harme that Good. And hereby it comes to passe, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Intemperance, is naturally punished with Diseases; Rashnesse, with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Mischances; Injustice, with the Violence of Enemies; Pride, with Ruine;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Cowardise, with Oppression; Negligent government of Princes, with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Rebellion; and Rebellion, with Slaughter. For seeing Punishments

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are consequent to the breach of Lawes; Naturall Punishments must be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: naturally consequent to the breach of the Lawes of Nature; and therfore

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: follow them as their naturall, not arbitrary effects.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Conclusion Of The Second Part

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And thus farre concerning the Constitution, Nature, and Right of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraigns; and concerning the Duty of Subjects, derived from the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Principles of Naturall Reason. And now, considering how different

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: this Doctrine is, from the Practise of the greatest part of the world,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: especially of these Western parts, that have received their Morall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: learning from Rome, and Athens; and how much depth of Morall Philosophy

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is required, in them that have the Administration of the Soveraign

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Power; I am at the point of believing this my labour, as uselesse,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and the Common-wealth of Plato; For he also is of opinion that it is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: impossible for the disorders of State, and change of Governments by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Civill Warre, ever to be taken away, till Soveraigns be Philosophers.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But when I consider again, that the Science of Naturall Justice, is the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: onely Science necessary for Soveraigns, and their principall Ministers;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and that they need not be charged with the Sciences Mathematicall, (as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by Plato they are,) further, than by good Lawes to encourage men to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the study of them; and that neither Plato, nor any other Philosopher

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hitherto, hath put into order, and sufficiently, or probably proved all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Theoremes of Morall doctrine, that men may learn thereby, both how

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to govern, and how to obey; I recover some hope, that one time or other,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: this writing of mine, may fall into the hands of a Soveraign, who will

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consider it himselfe, (for it is short, and I think clear,) without the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: help of any interested, or envious Interpreter; and by the exercise of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: entire Soveraignty, in protecting the Publique teaching of it, convert

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: this Truth of Speculation, into the Utility of Practice.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: PART III. OF A CHRISTIAN COMMON-WEALTH

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CHAPTER XXXII. OF THE PRINCIPLES OF CHRISTIAN POLITIQUES

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Word Of God Delivered By Prophets Is The Main Principle

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of Christian Politiques

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: I have derived the Rights of Soveraigne Power, and the duty of Subjects

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hitherto, from the Principles of Nature onely; such as Experience has

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: found true, or Consent (concerning the use of words) has made so; that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is to say, from the nature of Men, known to us by Experience, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from Definitions (of such words as are Essentiall to all Politicall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: reasoning) universally agreed on. But in that I am next to handle, which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is the Nature and Rights of a CHRISTIAN COMMON-WEALTH, whereof there

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: dependeth much upon Supernaturall Revelations of the Will of God; the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ground of my Discourse must be, not only the Naturall Word of God, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: also the Propheticall.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Neverthelesse, we are not to renounce our Senses, and Experience; nor

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (that which is the undoubted Word of God) our naturall Reason. For they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are the talents which he hath put into our hands to negotiate, till the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: coming again of our blessed Saviour; and therefore not to be folded up

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the Napkin of an Implicate Faith, but employed in the purchase of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Justice, Peace, and true Religion, For though there be many things in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Gods Word above Reason; that is to say, which cannot by naturall reason

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be either demonstrated, or confuted; yet there is nothing contrary

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to it; but when it seemeth so, the fault is either in our unskilfull

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Interpretation, or erroneous Ratiocination.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Therefore, when any thing therein written is too hard for our

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: examination, wee are bidden to captivate our understanding to the Words;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and not to labour in sifting out a Philosophicall truth by Logick, of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such mysteries as are not comprehensible, nor fall under any rule of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: naturall science. For it is with the mysteries of our Religion, as with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: wholsome pills for the sick, which swallowed whole, have the vertue to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: cure; but chewed, are for the most part cast up again without effect.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: What It Is To Captivate The Understanding

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But by the Captivity of our Understanding, is not meant a Submission of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Intellectual faculty, to the Opinion of any other man; but of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Will to Obedience, where obedience is due. For Sense, Memory,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Understanding, Reason, and Opinion are not in our power to change; but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: alwaies, and necessarily such, as the things we see, hear, and consider

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: suggest unto us; and therefore are not effects of our Will, but our Will

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of them. We then Captivate our Understanding and Reason, when we forbear

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: contradiction; when we so speak, as (by lawfull Authority) we are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: commanded; and when we live accordingly; which in sum, is Trust, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Faith reposed in him that speaketh, though the mind be incapable of any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Notion at all from the words spoken.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: How God Speaketh To Men

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: When God speaketh to man, it must be either immediately; or by mediation

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of another man, to whom he had formerly spoken by himself immediately.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: How God speaketh to a man immediately, may be understood by those well

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: enough, to whom he hath so spoken; but how the same should be understood

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by another, is hard, if not impossible to know. For if a man pretend to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: me, that God hath spoken to him supernaturally, and immediately, and I

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: make doubt of it, I cannot easily perceive what argument he can produce,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to oblige me to beleeve it. It is true, that if he be my Soveraign,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he may oblige me to obedience, so, as not by act or word to declare I

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: beleeve him not; but not to think any otherwise then my reason perswades

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: me. But if one that hath not such authority over me, shall pretend the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: same, there is nothing that exacteth either beleefe, or obedience.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For to say that God hath spoken to him in the Holy Scripture, is not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to say God hath spoken to him immediately, but by mediation of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Prophets, or of the Apostles, or of the Church, in such manner as he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: speaks to all other Christian men. To say he hath spoken to him in a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Dream, is no more than to say he dreamed that God spake to him; which is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not of force to win beleef from any man, that knows dreams are for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the most part naturall, and may proceed from former thoughts; and such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: dreams as that, from selfe conceit, and foolish arrogance, and false

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: opinion of a mans own godlinesse, or other vertue, by which he thinks he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hath merited the favour of extraordinary Revelation. To say he hath

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: seen a Vision, or heard a Voice, is to say, that he hath dreamed between

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sleeping and waking: for in such manner a man doth many times naturally

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: take his dream for a vision, as not having well observed his own

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: slumbering. To say he speaks by supernaturall Inspiration, is to say he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: finds an ardent desire to speak, or some strong opinion of himself, for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which he can alledge no naturall and sufficient reason. So that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: though God Almighty can speak to a man, by Dreams, Visions, Voice, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Inspiration; yet he obliges no man to beleeve he hath so done to him

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that pretends it; who (being a man), may erre, and (which is more) may

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: lie.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: By What Marks Prophets Are Known

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: How then can he, to whom God hath never revealed his Wil immediately

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (saving by the way of natural reason) know when he is to obey, or not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to obey his Word, delivered by him, that sayes he is a Prophet? (1 Kings

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 22) Of 400 Prophets, of whom the K. of Israel asked counsel, concerning

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the warre he made against Ramoth Gilead, only Micaiah was a true one.(1

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kings 13) The Prophet that was sent to prophecy against the Altar set up

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by Jeroboam, though a true Prophet, and that by two miracles done in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his presence appears to be a Prophet sent from God, was yet deceived by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: another old Prophet, that perswaded him as from the mouth of God, to eat

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and drink with him. If one Prophet deceive another, what certainty is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there of knowing the will of God, by other way than that of Reason? To

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which I answer out of the Holy Scripture, that there be two marks, by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which together, not asunder, a true Prophet is to be known. One is the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: doing of miracles; the other is the not teaching any other Religion than

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that which is already established. Asunder (I say) neither of these is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sufficient. (Deut. 13 v. 1,2,3,4,5 ) "If a Prophet rise amongst you, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Dreamer of dreams, and shall pretend the doing of a miracle, and the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: miracle come to passe; if he say, Let us follow strange Gods, which thou

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hast not known, thou shalt not hearken to him, &c. But that Prophet and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Dreamer of dreams shall be put to death, because he hath spoken to you

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to Revolt from the Lord your God." In which words two things are to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be observed, First, that God wil not have miracles alone serve for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: arguments, to approve the Prophets calling; but (as it is in the third

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: verse) for an experiment of the constancy of our adherence to himself.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For the works of the Egyptian Sorcerers, though not so great as those

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Moses, yet were great miracles. Secondly, that how great soever the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: miracle be, yet if it tend to stir up revolt against the King, or him

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that governeth by the Kings authority, he that doth such miracle, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not to be considered otherwise than as sent to make triall of their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: allegiance. For these words, "revolt from the Lord your God," are in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: this place equivalent to "revolt from your King." For they had made God

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their King by pact at the foot of Mount Sinai; who ruled them by Moses

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: only; for he only spake with God, and from time to time declared Gods

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Commandements to the people. In like manner, after our Saviour Christ

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: had made his Disciples acknowledge him for the Messiah, (that is to say,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for Gods anointed, whom the nation of the Jews daily expected for their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: King, but refused when he came,) he omitted not to advertise them of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: danger of miracles. "There shall arise," (saith he) "false Christs, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: false Prophets, and shall doe great wonders and miracles, even to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: seducing (if it were possible) of the very Elect." (Mat. 24. 24) By

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: yet are wee not to take their doctrin for Gods Word. St. Paul says

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: further to the Galatians, that "if himself, or an Angell from heaven

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: preach another Gospel to them, than he had preached, let him be

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Marks Of A Prophet In The Old Law, Miracles, And Doctrine

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Conformable To The Law

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And as Miracles, without preaching that Doctrine which God hath

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: established; so preaching the true Doctrine, without the doing of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Miracles, is an unsufficient argument of immediate Revelation. For if

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a man that teacheth not false Doctrine, should pretend to bee a Prophet

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: without shewing any Miracle, he is never the more to bee regarded for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his pretence, as is evident by Deut. 18. v. 21, 22. "If thou say in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thy heart, How shall we know that the Word (of the Prophet) is not that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which the Lord hath spoken. When the Prophet shall have spoken in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: name of the Lord, that which shall not come to passe, that's the word

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which the Lord hath not spoken, but the Prophet has spoken it out of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the pride of his own heart, fear him not." But a man may here again ask,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: When the Prophet hath foretold a thing, how shal we know whether it will

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: come to passe or not? For he may foretel it as a thing to arrive after

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a certain long time, longer then the time of mans life; or indefinitely,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that it will come to passe one time or other: in which case this mark

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of a Prophet is unusefull; and therefore the miracles that oblige us to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: beleeve a Prophet, ought to be confirmed by an immediate, or a not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: long deferr'd event. So that it is manifest, that the teaching of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Religion which God hath established, and the showing of a present

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Miracle, joined together, were the only marks whereby the Scripture

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: would have a true Prophet, that is to say immediate Revelation to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: acknowledged; neither of them being singly sufficient to oblige any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other man to regard what he saith.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Miracles Ceasing, Prophets Cease, The Scripture Supplies Their Place

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Seeing therefore Miracles now cease, we have no sign left, whereby to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: acknowledge the pretended Revelations, or Inspirations of any private

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man; nor obligation to give ear to any Doctrine, farther than it is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: conformable to the Holy Scriptures, which since the time of our Saviour,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: supply the want of all other Prophecy; and from which, by wise and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: careful ratiocination, all rules and precepts necessary to the knowledge

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of our duty both to God and man, without Enthusiasme, or supernaturall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Inspiration, may easily be deduced. And this Scripture is it, out of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which I am to take the Principles of my Discourse, concerning the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Rights of those that are the Supream Govenors on earth, of Christian

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealths; and of the duty of Christian Subjects towards their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraigns. And to that end, I shall speak in the next Chapter, or the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Books, Writers, Scope and Authority of the Bible.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CHAPTER XXXIII. OF THE NUMBER, ANTIQUITY, SCOPE, AUTHORITY,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: AND INTERPRETERS OF THE BOOKS OF HOLY SCRIPTURES

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of The Books Of Holy Scripture

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: By the Books of Holy SCRIPTURE, are understood those, which ought to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Canon, that is to say, the Rules of Christian life. And because all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Rules of life, which men are in conscience bound to observe, are Laws;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the question of the Scripture, is the question of what is Law throughout

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all Christendome, both Naturall, and Civill. For though it be not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: determined in Scripture, what Laws every Christian King shall constitute

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in his own Dominions; yet it is determined what laws he shall not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: constitute. Seeing therefore I have already proved, that Soveraigns

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in their own Dominions are the sole Legislators; those Books only are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Canonicall, that is, Law, in every nation, which are established for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such by the Soveraign Authority. It is true, that God is the Soveraign

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of all Soveraigns; and therefore, when he speaks to any Subject, he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ought to be obeyed, whatsoever any earthly Potentate command to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: contrary. But the question is not of obedience to God, but of When,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and What God hath said; which to Subjects that have no supernaturall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: revelation, cannot be known, but by that naturall reason, which guided

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them, for the obtaining of Peace and Justice, to obey the authority

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of their severall Common-wealths; that is to say, of their lawfull

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraigns. According to this obligation, I can acknowledge no other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Books of the Old Testament, to be Holy Scripture, but those which have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: been commanded to be acknowledged for such, by the Authority of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Church of England. What Books these are, is sufficiently known, without

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Catalogue of them here; and they are the same that are acknowledged

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by St. Jerome, who holdeth the rest, namely, the Wisdome of Solomon,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ecclesiasticus, Judith, Tobias, the first and second of Maccabees,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (though he had seen the first in Hebrew) and the third and fourth of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Esdras, for Apocrypha. Of the Canonicall, Josephus a learned Jew, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: wrote in the time of the Emperor Domitian, reckoneth Twenty Two, making

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the number agree with the Hebrew Alphabet. St. Jerome does the same,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: though they reckon them in different manner. For Josephus numbers Five

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Books of Moses, Thirteen of Prophets, that writ the History of their own

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: times (which how it agrees with the Prophets writings contained in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Bible wee shall see hereafter), and Four of Hymnes and Morall Precepts.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But St. Jerome reckons Five Books of Moses, Eight of Prophets, and Nine

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of other Holy writ, which he calls of Hagiographa. The Septuagint, who

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: were 70. learned men of the Jews, sent for by Ptolemy King of Egypt, to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: translate the Jewish Law, out of the Hebrew into the Greek, have left us

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: no other for holy Scripture in the Greek tongue, but the same that are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: received in the Church of England.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: As for the Books of the New Testament, they are equally acknowledged for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Canon by all Christian Churches, and by all sects of Christians, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: admit any Books at all for Canonicall.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Their Antiquity

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Who were the originall writers of the severall Books of Holy Scripture,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: has not been made evident by any sufficient testimony of other History,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (which is the only proof of matter of fact); nor can be by any arguments

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of naturall Reason; for Reason serves only to convince the truth (not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of fact, but) of consequence. The light therefore that must guide us in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: this question, must be that which is held out unto us from the Bookes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: themselves: And this light, though it show us not the writer of every

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: book, yet it is not unusefull to give us knowledge of the time, wherein

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they were written.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Pentateuch Not Written By Moses

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And first, for the Pentateuch, it is not argument enough that they were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: written by Moses, because they are called the five Books of Moses; no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: more than these titles, The Book of Joshua, the Book of Judges, The Book

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Ruth, and the Books of the Kings, are arguments sufficient to prove,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that they were written by Joshua, by the Judges, by Ruth, and by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kings. For in titles of Books, the subject is marked, as often as the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: writer. The History Of Livy, denotes the Writer; but the History Of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Scanderbeg, is denominated from the subject. We read in the last Chapter

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Deuteronomie, Ver. 6. concerning the sepulcher of Moses, "that no man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: knoweth of his sepulcher to this day," that is, to the day wherein those

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: words were written. It is therefore manifest, that those words were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: written after his interrement. For it were a strange interpretation, to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: say Moses spake of his own sepulcher (though by Prophecy), that it was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not found to that day, wherein he was yet living. But it may perhaps

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be alledged, that the last Chapter only, not the whole Pentateuch, was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: written by some other man, but the rest not: Let us therefore consider

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that which we find in the Book of Genesis, Chap. 12. Ver. 6 "And Abraham

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: passed through the land to the place of Sichem, unto the plain of Moreh,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and the Canaanite was then in the land;" which must needs bee the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: words of one that wrote when the Canaanite was not in the land; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consequently, not of Moses, who dyed before he came into it. Likewise

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Numbers 21. Ver. 14. the Writer citeth another more ancient Book,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Entituled, The Book of the Warres of the Lord, wherein were registred

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Acts of Moses, at the Red-sea, and at the brook of Arnon. It is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore sufficiently evident, that the five Books of Moses were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: written after his time, though how long after it be not so manifest.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But though Moses did not compile those Books entirely, and in the form

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: we have them; yet he wrote all that which hee is there said to have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: written: as for example, the Volume of the Law, which is contained, as

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Book of Joshua Written After His Time

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: set up twelve stones in the middest of Jordan, for a monument of their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: passage; (Josh 4. 9) of which the Writer saith thus, "They are there

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: unto this day;" (Josh 5. 9) for "unto this day", is a phrase that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: signifieth a time past, beyond the memory of man. In like manner, upon

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the saying of the Lord, that he had rolled off from the people the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Reproach of Egypt, the Writer saith, "The place is called Gilgal unto

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: raised in the Camp, (Josh. 7. 26) the Writer saith, "remaineth unto

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: this day;" which must needs bee therefore long after the time of Joshua.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Arguments of this kind there be many other; as Josh. 8. 29. 13. 13. 14.

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 21,26 6.24 10.4 15.19 17.6 and Ruth 1. 1. but especially Judg. 18. 30.

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of that Book, must be long after the time of the fact; that is, long

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: As for the two Books of the Kings, and the two books of the Chronicles,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: besides the places which mention such monuments, as the Writer saith,

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ezra And Nehemiah

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Books of Esdras and Nehemiah were written certainly after their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: return from captivity; because their return, the re-edification of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the walls and houses of Jerusalem, the renovation of the Covenant, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ordination of their policy are therein contained.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Esther

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The History of Queen Esther is of the time of the Captivity; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore the Writer must have been of the same time, or after it.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Job

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Book of Job hath no mark in it of the time wherein it was written:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and though it appear sufficiently (Exekiel 14.14, and James 5.11.)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that he was no fained person; yet the Book it self seemeth not to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a History, but a Treatise concerning a question in ancient time much

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: disputed, "why wicked men have often prospered in this world, and good

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: men have been afflicted;" and it is the most probably, because from the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: beginning, to the third verse of the third chapter, where the complaint

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Job beginneth, the Hebrew is (as St. Jerome testifies) in prose; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from thence to the sixt verse of the last chapter in Hexameter Verses;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and the rest of that chapter again in prose. So that the dispute is all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in verse; and the prose is added, but as a Preface in the beginning, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: an Epilogue in the end. But Verse is no usuall stile of such, as either

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are themselves in great pain, as Job; or of such as come to comfort

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them, as his friends; but in Philosophy, especially morall Philosophy,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in ancient time frequent.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Psalter

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Psalmes were written the most part by David, for the use of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Quire. To these are added some songs of Moses, and other holy men; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: some of them after the return from the Captivity; as the 137. and the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 126. whereby it is manifest that the Psalter was compiled, and put into

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the form it now hath, after the return of the Jews from Babylon.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Proverbs

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Proverbs, being a Collection of wise and godly Sayings, partly of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Solomon, partly of Agur the son of Jakeh; and partly of the Mother

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of King Lemuel, cannot probably be thought to have been collected by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Solomon, rather then by Agur, or the Mother of Lemues; and that, though

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the sentences be theirs, yet the collection or compiling them into this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: one Book, was the work of some other godly man, that lived after them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ecclesiastes And The Canticles

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Books of Ecclesiastes and the Canticles have nothing that was not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Solomons, except it be the Titles, or Inscriptions. For "The Words of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Preacher, the Son of David, King in Jerusalem;" and, "the Song of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Songs, which is Solomon's," seem to have been made for distinctions

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sake, then, when the Books of Scripture were gathered into one body of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Law; to the end, that not the Doctrine only, but the Authors also

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: might be extant.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Prophets

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of the Prophets, the most ancient, are Sophoniah, Jonas, Amos, Hosea,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Isaiah and Michaiah, who lived in the time of Amaziah, and Azariah,

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Register of his Prophecy, (for that is contained in these few words,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "Fourty dayes and Ninivy shall be destroyed,") but a History or Narration

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of his frowardenesse and disputing Gods commandements; so that there is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: small probability he should be the Author, seeing he is the subject of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it. But the Book of Amos is his Prophecy.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Jeremiah, Abdias, Nahum, and Habakkuk prophecyed in the time of Josiah.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ezekiel, Daniel, Aggeus, and Zacharias, in the Captivity.

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The New Testament

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Writers of the New Testament lived all in lesse then an age after

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Disciples, except St. Paul, and St. Luke; and consequently whatsoever

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was written by them, is as ancient as the time of the Apostles. But

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
