text: And so perhaps are some of those Books which are called Apocrypha, if

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: left out of the Canon, not for inconformity of Doctrine with the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: rest, but only because they are not found in the Hebrew. For after the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: conquest of Asia by Alexander the Great, there were few learned Jews,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that were not perfect in the Greek tongue. For the seventy Interpreters

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that converted the Bible into Greek, were all of them Hebrews; and we

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have extant the works of Philo and Josephus both Jews, written by them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: eloquently in Greek. But it is not the Writer, but the authority of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Church, that maketh a Book Canonicall.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Their Scope

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And although these Books were written by divers men, yet it is manifest

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Writers were all indued with one and the same Spirit, in that they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: conspire to one and the same end, which is the setting forth of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Rights of the Kingdome of God, the Father, Son, and Holy Ghost. For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Book of Genesis, deriveth the Genealogy of Gods people, from the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: creation of the World, to the going into Egypt: the other four Books of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Moses, contain the Election of God for their King, and the Laws which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hee prescribed for their Government: The Books of Joshua, Judges, Ruth,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Samuel, to the time of Saul, describe the acts of Gods people,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: till the time they cast off Gods yoke, and called for a King, after the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: manner of their neighbour nations; The rest of the History of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Old Testament, derives the succession of the line of David, to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Captivity, out of which line was to spring the restorer of the Kingdome

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of God, even our blessed Saviour God the Son, whose coming was foretold

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the Bookes of the Prophets, after whom the Evangelists writt his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: life, and actions, and his claim to the Kingdome, whilst he lived one

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: earth: and lastly, the Acts, and Epistles of the Apostles, declare the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: coming of God, the Holy Ghost, and the Authority he left with them, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their successors, for the direction of the Jews, and for the invitation

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Gentiles. In summe, the Histories and the Prophecies of the old

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Testament, and the Gospels, and Epistles of the New Testament, have had

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: one and the same scope, to convert men to the obedience of God; 1. in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Moses, and the Priests; 2. in the man Christ; and 3. in the Apostles and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the successors to Apostolicall power. For these three at several times

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: did represent the person of God: Moses, and his successors the High

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Priests, and Kings of Judah, in the Old Testament: Christ himself, in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the time he lived on earth: and the Apostles, and their successors, from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the day of Pentecost (when the Holy Ghost descended on them) to this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: day.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Question Of The Authority Of The Scriptures Stated.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: It is a question much disputed between the divers sects of Christian

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Religion, From Whence The Scriptures Derive Their Authority; which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: question is also propounded sometimes in other terms, as, How Wee Know

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Them To Be The Word Of God, or, Why We Beleeve Them To Be So: and the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: difficulty of resolving it, ariseth chiefly from the impropernesse of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the words wherein the question it self is couched. For it is beleeved

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: on all hands, that the first and originall Author of them is God; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consequently the question disputed, is not that. Again, it is manifest,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that none can know they are Gods Word, (though all true Christians

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: beleeve it,) but those to whom God himself hath revealed it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: supernaturally; and therefore the question is not rightly moved, of our

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Knowledge of it. Lastly, when the question is propounded of our Beleefe;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: because some are moved to beleeve for one, and others for other reasons,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there can be rendred no one generall answer for them all. The question

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: truly stated is, By What Authority They Are Made Law.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Their Authority And Interpretation

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: As far as they differ not from the Laws of Nature, there is no doubt,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but they are the Law of God, and carry their Authority with them,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: legible to all men that have the use of naturall reason: but this is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: no other Authority, then that of all other Morall Doctrine consonant to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Reason; the Dictates whereof are Laws, not Made, but Eternall.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: If they be made Law by God himselfe, they are of the nature of written

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Law, which are Laws to them only to whom God hath so sufficiently

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: published them, as no man can excuse himself, by saying, he know not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they were his.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: He therefore, to whom God hath not supernaturally revealed, that they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are his, nor that those that published them, were sent by him, is not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: obliged to obey them, by any Authority, but his, whose Commands have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: already the force of Laws; that is to say, by any other Authority, then

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that of the Common-wealth, residing in the Soveraign, who only has the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Legislative power. Again, if it be not the Legislative Authority of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Common-wealth, that giveth them the force of Laws, it must bee

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: some other Authority derived from God, either private, or publique:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: if private, it obliges onely him, to whom in particular God hath been

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: pleased to reveale it. For if every man should be obliged, to take for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Gods Law, what particular men, on pretence of private Inspiration, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Revelation, should obtrude upon him, (in such a number of men, that out

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of pride, and ignorance, take their own Dreams, and extravagant Fancies,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Madnesse, for testimonies of Gods Spirit; or out of ambition,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: pretend to such Divine testimonies, falsely, and contrary to their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: own consciences,) it were impossible that any Divine Law should be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: acknowledged. If publique, it is the Authority of the Common-wealth, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Church. But the Church, if it be one person, is the same thing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with a Common-wealth of Christians; called a Common-wealth, because it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consisteth of men united in one person, their Soveraign; and a Church,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: because it consisteth in Christian men, united in one Christian

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign. But if the Church be not one person, then it hath no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: authority at all; it can neither command, nor doe any action at all; nor

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is capable of having any power, or right to any thing; nor has any Will,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Reason, nor Voice; for all these qualities are personall. Now if the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whole number of Christians be not contained in one Common-wealth, they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are not one person; nor is there an Universall Church that hath any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: authority over them; and therefore the Scriptures are not made Laws,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by the Universall Church: or if it bee one Common-wealth, then all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christian Monarchs, and States are private persons, and subject to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: bee judged, deposed, and punished by an Universall Soveraigne of all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christendome. So that the question of the Authority of the Scriptures is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: reduced to this, "Whether Christian Kings, and the Soveraigne Assemblies

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in Christian Common-wealths, be absolute in their own Territories,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: immediately under God; or subject to one Vicar of Christ, constituted

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: over the Universall Church; to bee judged, condemned, deposed, and put

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to death, as hee shall think expedient, or necessary for the common

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: good."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Which question cannot bee resolved, without a more particular

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consideration of the Kingdome of God; from whence also, wee are to judge

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Authority of Interpreting the Scripture. For, whosoever hath a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: lawfull power over any Writing, to make it Law, hath the power also to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: approve, or disapprove the interpretation of the same.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CHAPTER XXXIV. OF THE SIGNIFICATION OF SPIRIT, ANGEL, AND INSPIRATION IN

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: THE BOOKS OF HOLY SCRIPTURE

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Body And Spirit How Taken In The Scripture

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Seeing the foundation of all true Ratiocination, is the constant

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Signification of words; which in the Doctrine following, dependeth not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (as in naturall science) on the Will of the Writer, nor (as in common

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: conversation) on vulgar use, but on the sense they carry in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Scripture; It is necessary, before I proceed any further, to determine,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: out of the Bible, the meaning of such words, as by their ambiguity, may

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: render what I am to inferre upon them, obscure, or disputable. I will

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: begin with the words BODY, and SPIRIT, which in the language of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Schools are termed, Substances, Corporeall, and Incorporeall.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Word Body, in the most generall acceptation, signifieth that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which filleth, or occupyeth some certain room, or imagined place; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: dependeth not on the imagination, but is a reall part of that we call

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Universe. For the Universe, being the Aggregate of all Bodies, there

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is no reall part thereof that is not also Body; nor any thing properly

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Body, that is not also part of (that Aggregate of all Bodies) the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Universe. The same also, because Bodies are subject to change, that is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to say, to variety of apparence to the sense of living creatures, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: called Substance, that is to say, Subject, to various accidents, as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sometimes to be Moved, sometimes to stand Still; and to seem to our

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: senses sometimes Hot, sometimes Cold, sometimes of one Colour, Smel,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Tast, or Sound, somtimes of another. And this diversity of Seeming,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (produced by the diversity of the operation of bodies, on the organs

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of our sense) we attribute to alterations of the Bodies that operate, &

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: call them Accidents of those Bodies. And according to this acceptation

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the word, Substance and Body, signifie the same thing; and therefore

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Substance Incorporeall are words, which when they are joined together,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: destroy one another, as if a man should say, an Incorporeall Body.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But in the sense of common people, not all the Universe is called Body,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but only such parts thereof as they can discern by the sense of Feeling,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to resist their force, or by the sense of their Eyes, to hinder them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from a farther prospect. Therefore in the common language of men, Aire,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Aeriall Substances, use not to be taken for Bodies, but (as often

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as men are sensible of their effects) are called Wind, or Breath, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (because the some are called in the Latine Spiritus) Spirits; as when

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they call that aeriall substance, which in the body of any living

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: creature, gives it life and motion, Vitall and Animall Spirits. But for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: those Idols of the brain, which represent Bodies to us, where they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are not, as in a Looking-glasse, in a Dream, or to a Distempered brain

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: waking, they are (as the Apostle saith generally of all Idols) nothing;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nothing at all, I say, there where they seem to bee; and in the brain

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it self, nothing but tumult, proceeding either from the action of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: objects, or from the disorderly agitation of the Organs of our Sense.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And men, that are otherwise imployed, then to search into their causes,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: know not of themselves, what to call them; and may therefore easily be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: perswaded, by those whose knowledge they much reverence, some to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: call them Bodies, and think them made of aire compacted by a power

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: supernaturall, because the sight judges them corporeall; and some to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: call them Spirits, because the sense of Touch discerneth nothing in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: place where they appear, to resist their fingers: So that the proper

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: signification of Spirit in common speech, is either a subtile, fluid,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and invisible Body, or a Ghost, or other Idol or Phantasme of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Imagination. But for metaphoricall significations, there be many: for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sometimes it is taken for Disposition or Inclination of the mind; as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: when for the disposition to controwl the sayings of other men, we say,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: A Spirit Contradiction; For A Disposition to Uncleannesse, An Unclean

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Spirit; for Perversenesse, A Froward Spirit; for Sullennesse, A Dumb

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Spirit, and for Inclination To Godlinesse, And Gods Service, the Spirit

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of God: sometimes for any eminent ability, or extraordinary passion,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or disease of the mind, as when Great Wisdome is called the Spirit Of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Wisdome; and Mad Men are said to be Possessed With A Spirit.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Other signification of Spirit I find no where any; and where none

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of these can satisfie the sense of that word in Scripture, the place

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: falleth not under humane Understanding; and our Faith therein consisteth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not in our Opinion, but in our Submission; as in all places where God

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is said to be a Spirit; or where by the Spirit of God, is meant God

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: himselfe. For the nature of God is incomprehensible; that is to say, we

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: understand nothing of What He Is, but only That He Is; and therefore the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Attributes we give him, are not to tell one another, What He Is, Nor

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to signifie our opinion of his Nature, but our desire to honor him with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such names as we conceive most honorable amongst our selves.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Spirit Of God Taken In The Scripture Sometimes For A Wind, Or Breath

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Gen. 1. 2. "The Spirit of God moved upon the face of the Waters." Here

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: if by the Spirit of God be meant God himself, then is Motion attributed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to God, and consequently Place, which are intelligible only of Bodies,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and not of substances incorporeall; and so the place is above our

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: understanding, that can conceive nothing moved that changes not place,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or that has not dimension; and whatsoever has dimension, is Body. But

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the meaning of those words is best understood by the like place, Gen.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 8. 1. Where when the earth was covered with Waters, as in the beginning,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: God intending to abate them, and again to discover the dry land, useth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: like words, "I will bring my Spirit upon the Earth, and the waters shall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be diminished:" in which place by Spirit is understood a Wind, (that is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: an Aire or Spirit Moved,) which might be called (as in the former place)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Spirit of God, because it was Gods Work.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Secondly, For Extraordinary Gifts Of The Understanding

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Gen. 41. 38. Pharaoh calleth the Wisdome of Joseph, the Spirit of God.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For Joseph having advised him to look out a wise and discreet man, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to set him over the land of Egypt, he saith thus, "Can we find such a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man as this is, in whom is the Spirit of God?" and Exod. 28.3. "Thou

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shalt speak (saith God) to all that are wise hearted, whom I have filled

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with the Spirit of Wisdome, to make Aaron Garments, to consecrate him."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Where extraordinary Understanding, though but in making Garments, as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: being the Gift of God, is called the Spirit of God. The same is found

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: again, Exod. 31.3,4,5,6. and 35.31. And Isaiah 11.2,3. where the Prophet

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: speaking of the Messiah, saith, "The Spirit of the Lord shall abide upon

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him, the Spirit of wisdome and understanding, the Spirit of counsell,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and fortitude; and the Spirit of the fear of the Lord." Where manifestly

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is meant, not so many Ghosts, but so many eminent Graces that God would

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: give him.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Thirdly, For Extraordinary Affections

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In the Book of Judges, an extraordinary Zeal, and Courage in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: defence of Gods people, is called the Spirit of God; as when it excited

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Othoniel, Gideon, Jeptha, and Samson to deliver them from servitude,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Judg. 3.10. 6.34. 11.29. 13.25. 14.6,19. And of Saul, upon the newes of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the insolence of the Ammonites towards the men of Jabeth Gilead, it is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: said (1 Sam.11.6.) that "The Spirit of God came upon Saul, and his Anger

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (or, as it is in the Latine, His Fury) was kindled greatly." Where it is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not probable was meant a Ghost, but an extraordinary Zeal to punish the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: cruelty of the Ammonites. In like manner by the Spirit of God, that came

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: upon Saul, when hee was amongst the Prophets that praised God in Songs,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Musick (1 Sam.19.20.) is to be understood, not a Ghost, but an

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: unexpected and sudden Zeal to join with them in their devotions.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Fourthly, For The Gift Of Prediction By Dreams And Visions

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The false Prophet Zedekiah, saith to Micaiah (1 Kings 22.24.) "Which way

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: went the Spirit of the Lord from me to speak to thee?" Which cannot be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: understood of a Ghost; for Micaiah declared before the Kings of Israel

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Judah, the event of the battle, as from a Vision, and not as from a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Spirit, speaking in him.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In the same manner it appeareth, in the Books of the Prophets, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: though they spake by the Spirit of God, that is to say, by a speciall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: grace of Prediction; yet their knowledge of the future, was not by a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ghost within them, but by some supernaturall Dream or Vision.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Fiftly, For Life

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Gen. 2.7. It is said, "God made man of the dust of the Earth, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: breathed into his nostrills (spiraculum vitae) the breath of life, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man was made a living soul." There the Breath of Life inspired by God,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: signifies no more, but that God gave him life; And (Job 27.3.) "as long

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as the Spirit of God is in my nostrils;" is no more then to say, "as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: long as I live." So in Ezek. 1.20. "the Spirit of life was in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: wheels," is equivalent to, "the wheels were alive." And (Ezek. 2.30.)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "the spirit entred into me, and set me on my feet," that is, "I

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: recovered my vitall strength;" not that any Ghost, or incorporeal

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: substance entred into, and possessed his body.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sixtly, For A Subordination To Authority

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In the 11 chap. of Numbers. verse 17. "I will take (saith God) of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Spirit, which is upon thee, and will put it upon them, and they shall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: bear the burthen of the people with thee;" that is, upon the seventy

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Elders: whereupon two of the seventy are said to prophecy in the campe;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of whom some complained, and Joshua desired Moses to forbid them; which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Moses would not doe. Whereby it appears; that Joshua knew not they had

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: received authority so to do, and prophecyed according to the mind of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Moses, that is to say, by a Spirit, or Authority subordinate to his own.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In the like sense we read (Deut. 34.9.) that "Joshua was full of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Spirit of wisdome," because Moses had laid his hands upon him: that is,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: because he was Ordained by Moses, to prosecute the work hee had himselfe

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: begun, (namely, the bringing of Gods people into the promised land), but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: prevented by death, could not finish.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In the like sense it is said, (Rom. 8.9.) "If any man have not the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Spirit of Christ, he is none of his:" not meaning thereby the Ghost of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christ, but a Submission to his Doctrine. As also (1 John 4.2.) "Hereby

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: you shall know the Spirit of God; Every Spirit that confesseth that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Jesus Christ is come in the flesh, is of God;" by which is meant the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Spirit of unfained Christianity, or Submission to that main Article of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christian faith, that Jesus is the Christ; which cannot be interpreted

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of a Ghost.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Likewise these words (Luke 4.1.) "And Jesus full of the Holy Ghost"

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (that is, as it is exprest, Mat. 4.1. and Mar. 1.12. "of the Holy

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Spirit",) may be understood, for Zeal to doe the work for which hee was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sent by God the Father: but to interpret it of a Ghost, is to say, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: God himselfe (for so our Saviour was,) was filled with God; which is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: very unproper, and unsignificant. How we came to translate Spirits, by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the word Ghosts, which signifieth nothing, neither in heaven, nor earth,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but the Imaginary inhabitants of mans brain, I examine not: but this I

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: say, the word Spirit in the text signifieth no such thing; but either

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: properly a reall Substance, or Metaphorically, some extraordinary

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ability of Affection of the Mind, or of the Body.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Seventhly, For Aeriall Bodies

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Disciples of Christ, seeing him walking upon the sea, (Mat. 14.26.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Marke 6.49.) supposed him to be a Spirit, meaning thereby an Aeriall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Body, and not a Phantasme: for it is said, they all saw him; which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: cannot be understood of the delusions of the brain, (which are not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: common to many at once, as visible Bodies are; but singular, because of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the differences of Fancies), but of Bodies only. In like manner, where

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he was taken for a Spirit, by the same Apostles (Luke 24.3,7.): So also

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (Acts 12.15) when St. Peter was delivered out of Prison, it would not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be beleeved; but when the Maid said he was at the dore, they said it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was his Angel; by which must be meant a corporeall substance, or we must

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: say, the Disciples themselves did follow the common opinion of both Jews

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Gentiles, that some such apparitions were not Imaginary, but Reall;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and such as needed not the fancy of man for their Existence: These the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Jews called Spirits, and Angels, Good or Bad; as the Greeks called the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: same by the name of Daemons. And some such apparitions may be reall, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: substantiall; that is to say, subtile Bodies, which God can form by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the same power, by which he formed all things, and make use of, as of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ministers, and Messengers (that is to say, Angels) to declare his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: will, and execute the same when he pleaseth, in extraordinary and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: supernaturall manner. But when hee hath so formed them they are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Substances, endued with dimensions, and take up roome, and can be moved

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from place to place, which is peculiar to Bodies; and therefore are not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ghosts Incorporeall, that is to say, Ghosts that are in No Place;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that is to say, that are No Where; that is to say, that seeming to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Somewhat, are Nothing. But if corporeall be taken in the most vulgar

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: manner, for such Substances as are perceptible by our externall Senses;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: then is Substance Incorporeall, a thing not Imaginary, but Reall;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: namely, a thin Substance Invisible, but that hath the same dimensions

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that are in grosser Bodies.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Angel What

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: By the name of ANGEL, is signified generally, a Messenger; and most

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: often, a Messenger of God: And by a Messenger of God, is signified, any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thing that makes known his extraordinary Presence; that is to say, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: extraordinary manifestation of his power, especially by a Dream, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Vision.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Concerning the creation of Angels, there is nothing delivered in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Scriptures. That they are Spirits, is often repeated: but by the name of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Spirit, is signified both in Scripture, and vulgarly, both amongst Jews,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Gentiles, sometimes thin Bodies; as the Aire, the Wind, the Spirits

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Vitall, and Animall, of living creatures; and sometimes the Images

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that rise in the fancy in Dreams, and Visions; which are not reall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Substances, but accidents of the brain; yet when God raiseth them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: supernaturally, to signifie his Will, they are not unproperly termed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Gods Messengers, that is to say, his Angels.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And as the Gentiles did vulgarly conceive the Imagery of the brain, for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: things really subsistent without them, and not dependent on the fancy;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and out of them framed their opinions of Daemons, Good and Evill; which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: because they seemed to subsist really, they called Substances; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: because they could not feel them with their hands, Incorporeall: so also

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Jews upon the same ground, without any thing in the Old Testament

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that constrained them thereunto, had generally an opinion, (except the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sect of the Sadduces,) that those apparitions (which it pleased God

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sometimes to produce in the fancie of men, for his own service, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore called them his Angels) were substances, not dependent on the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: fancy, but permanent creatures of God; whereof those which they thought

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: were good to them, they esteemed the Angels of God, and those they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thought would hurt them, they called Evill Angels, or Evill Spirits;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such as was the Spirit of Python, and the Spirits of Mad-men, of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lunatiques, and Epileptiques: For they esteemed such as were troubled

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with such diseases, Daemoniaques.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But if we consider the places of the Old Testament where Angels are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: mentioned, we shall find, that in most of them, there can nothing else

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be understood by the word Angel, but some image raised (supernaturally)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the fancy, to signifie the presence of God in the execution of some

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: supernaturall work; and therefore in the rest, where their nature is not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: exprest, it may be understood in the same manner.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For we read Gen. 16. that the same apparition is called, not onely an

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Angel, but God; where that which (verse 7.) is called the Angel of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Lord, in the tenth verse, saith to Agar, "I will multiply thy seed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: exceedingly;" that is, speaketh in the person of God. Neither was this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: apparition a Fancy figured, but a Voice. By which it is manifest,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that Angel signifieth there, nothing but God himself, that caused Agar

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: supernaturally to apprehend a voice supernaturall, testifying Gods

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: speciall presence there. Why therefore may not the Angels that appeared

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to Lot, and are called Gen. 19.13. Men; and to whom, though they were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but two, Lot speaketh (ver. 18.) as but one, and that one, as God, (for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the words are, "Lot said unto them, Oh not so my Lord") be understood of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: images of men, supernaturally formed in the Fancy; as well as before by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Angel was understood a fancyed Voice? When the Angel called to Abraham

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: out of heaven, to stay his hand (Gen. 22.11.) from slaying Isaac, there

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was no Apparition, but a Voice; which neverthelesse was called properly

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: enough a Messenger, or Angel of God, because it declared Gods will

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: supernaturally, and saves the labour of supposing any permanent Ghosts.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Angels which Jacob saw on the Ladder of Heaven (Gen. 28.12.) were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Vision of his sleep; therefore onely Fancy, and a Dream; yet being

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: supernaturall, and signs of Gods Speciall presence, those apparitions

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are not improperly called Angels. The same is to be understood

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (Gen.31.11.) where Jacob saith thus, "The Angel of the Lord appeared to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: mee in my sleep." For an apparition made to a man in his sleep, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that which all men call a Dreame, whether such Dreame be naturall, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: supernaturall: and that which there Jacob calleth an Angel, was God

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: himselfe; for the same Angel saith (verse 13.) "I am the God of Bethel."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Also (Exod.14.9.) the Angel that went before the Army of Israel to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Red Sea, and then came behind it, is (verse 19.) the Lord himself; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he appeared not in the form of a beautifull man, but in form (by day)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of a Pillar Of Cloud and (by night) in form of a Pillar Of Fire; and yet

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: this Pillar was all the apparition, and Angel promised to Moses (Exod.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 14.9.) for the Armies guide: For this cloudy pillar, is said, to have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: descended, and stood at the dore of the Tabernacle, and to have talked

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with Moses.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: There you see Motion, and Speech, which are commonly attributed to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Angels, attributed to a Cloud, because the Cloud served as a sign of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Gods presence; and was no lesse an Angel, then if it had had the form of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Man, or Child of never so great beauty; or Wings, as usually they are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: painted, for the false instruction of common people. For it is not the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shape; but their use, that makes them Angels. But their use is to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: significations of Gods presence in supernaturall operations; As when

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Moses (Exod. 33.14.) had desired God to goe along with the Campe, (as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he had done alwaies before the making of the Golden Calfe,) God did not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: answer, "I will goe," nor "I will send an Angel in my stead;" but thus,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "my presence shall goe with thee."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To mention all the places of the Old Testament where the name of Angel

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is found, would be too long. Therefore to comprehend them all at once,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: I say, there is no text in that part of the Old Testament, which the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Church of England holdeth for Canonicall, from which we can conclude,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there is, or hath been created, any permanent thing (understood by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: name of Spirit or Angel,) that hath not quantity; and that may not be,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by the understanding divided; that is to say, considered by parts; so

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as one part may bee in one place, and the next part in the next place

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to it; and, in summe, which is not (taking Body for that, which is some

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: what, or some where) Corporeall; but in every place, the sense will bear

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the interpretation of Angel, for Messenger; as John Baptist is called

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: an Angel, and Christ the Angel of the Covenant; and as (according to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: same Analogy) the Dove, and the Fiery Tongues, in that they were signes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Gods speciall presence, might also be called Angels. Though we find

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in Daniel two names of Angels, Gabriel, and Michael; yet is cleer out of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the text it selfe, (Dan. 12.1) that by Michael is meant Christ, not as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: an Angel, but as a Prince: and that Gabriel (as the like apparitions

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: made to other holy men in their sleep) was nothing but a supernaturall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: phantasme, by which it seemed to Daniel, in his dream, that two Saints

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: being in talke, one of them said to the other, "Gabriel, let us make

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: this man understand his Vision:" For God needeth not, to distinguish

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his Celestiall servants by names, which are usefull onely to the short

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: memories of Mortalls. Nor in the New Testament is there any place, out

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of which it can be proved, that Angels (except when they are put for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such men, as God hath made the Messengers, and Ministers of his word,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or works) are things permanent, and withall incorporeall. That they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are permanent, may bee gathered from the words of our Saviour himselfe,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (Mat. 25.41.) where he saith, it shall be said to the wicked in the last

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: day, "Go ye cursed into everlasting fire prepared for the Devil and his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Angels:" which place is manifest for the permanence of Evill Angels,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (unlesse wee might think the name of Devill and his Angels may be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: understood of the Churches Adversaries and their Ministers;) but then

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it is repugnant to their Immateriality; because Everlasting fire is no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: punishment to impatible substances, such as are all things Incorporeall.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Angels therefore are not thence proved to be Incorporeall. In like

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: manner where St. Paul sayes (1 Cor. 6.3.) "Knew ye not that wee shall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: judge the Angels?" And (2 Pet. 2.4.) "For if God spared not the Angels

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that sinned, but cast them down into Hell." And (Jude 1,6.) "And the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Angels that kept not their first estate, but left their owne habitation,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hee hath reserved in everlasting chaines under darknesse unto the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Judgement of the last day;" though it prove the Permanence of Angelicall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: nature, it confirmeth also their Materiality. And (Mat. 22.30.) In the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: resurrection men doe neither marry, nor give in marriage, but are as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Angels of God in heaven:" but in the resurrection men shall be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Permanent, and not Incorporeall; so therefore also are the Angels.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: There be divers other places out of which may be drawn the like

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: conclusion. To men that understand the signification of these words,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Substance, and Incorporeall; as Incorporeall is taken not for subtile

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: body, but for Not Body, they imply a contradiction: insomuch as to say,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: an Angel, or Spirit is (in that sense) an Incorporeall Substance, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to say in effect, there is no Angel nor Spirit at all. Considering

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore the signification of the word Angel in the Old Testament, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the nature of Dreams and Visions that happen to men by the ordinary way

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Nature; I was enclined to this opinion, that Angels were nothing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but supernaturall apparitions of the Fancy, raised by the speciall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and extraordinary operation of God, thereby to make his presence and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: commandements known to mankind, and chiefly to his own people. But the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: many places of the New Testament, and our Saviours own words, and in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such texts, wherein is no suspicion of corruption of the Scripture, have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: extorted from my feeble Reason, an acknowledgement, and beleef, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there be also Angels substantiall, and permanent. But to beleeve they be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in no place, that is to say, no where, that is to say, nothing, as they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (though indirectly) say, that will have them Incorporeall, cannot by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Scripture bee evinced.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Inspiration What

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: On the signification of the word Spirit, dependeth that of the word

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: INSPIRATION; which must either be taken properly; and then it is nothing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but the blowing into a man some thin and subtile aire, or wind, in such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: manner as a man filleth a bladder with his breath; or if Spirits be not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: corporeal, but have their existence only in the fancy, it is nothing but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the blowing in of a Phantasme; which is improper to say, and impossible;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for Phantasmes are not, but only seem to be somewhat. That word

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore is used in the Scripture metaphorically onely: As (Gen. 2.7.)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: where it is said, that God Inspired into man the breath of life, no more

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is meant, then that God gave unto him vitall motion. For we are not to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: think that God made first a living breath, and then blew it into Adam

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: after he was made, whether that breath were reall, or seeming; but only

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as it is (Acts 17.25.) "that he gave him life and breath;" that is,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: made him a living creature. And where it is said (2 Tim. 3.16.) "all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Scripture is given by Inspiration from God," speaking there of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Scripture of the Old Testament, it is an easie metaphor, to signifie,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that God enclined the spirit or mind of those Writers, to write that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which should be usefull, in teaching, reproving, correcting, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: instructing men in the way of righteous living. But where St. Peter (2

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Pet. 1.21.) saith, that "Prophecy came not in old time by the will

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of man, but the holy men of God spake as they were moved by the Holy

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Spirit," by the Holy Spirit, is meant the voice of God in a Dream, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Vision supernaturall, which is not Inspiration; Nor when our Saviour

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: breathing on his Disciples, said, "Receive the Holy Spirit," was that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Breath the Spirit, but a sign of the spirituall graces he gave unto

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them. And though it be said of many, and of our Saviour himself, that he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was full of the Holy Spirit; yet that Fulnesse is not to be understood

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for Infusion of the substance of God, but for accumulation of his gifts,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such as are the gift of sanctity of life, of tongues, and the like,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whether attained supernaturally, or by study and industry; for in all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: cases they are the gifts of God. So likewise where God sayes (Joel

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 2.28.) "I will powre out my Spirit upon all flesh, and your Sons and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: your Daughters shall prophecy, your Old men shall dream Dreams, and your

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Young men shall see Visions," wee are not to understand it in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: proper sense, as if his Spirit were like water, subject to effusion, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: infusion; but as if God had promised to give them Propheticall Dreams,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Visions. For the proper use of the word Infused, in speaking of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the graces of God, is an abuse of it; for those graces are Vertues, not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Bodies to be carryed hither and thither, and to be powred into men, as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: into barrels.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In the same manner, to take Inspiration in the proper sense, or to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: say that Good Spirits entred into men to make them prophecy, or Evill

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Spirits into those that became Phrenetique, Lunatique, or Epileptique,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is not to take the word in the sense of the Scripture; for the Spirit

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there is taken for the power of God, working by causes to us unknown. As

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: also (Acts 2.2.) the wind, that is there said to fill the house wherein

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Apostles were assembled on the day of Pentecost, is not to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: understood for the Holy Spirit, which is the Deity it self; but for an

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them the internall graces, and holy vertues hee thought requisite for

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CHAPTER XXXV. OF THE SIGNIFICATION IN SCRIPTURE OF KINGDOME OF GOD, OF

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: HOLY, SACRED, AND SACRAMENT

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kingdom Of God Taken By Divines Metaphorically But In The Scriptures

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Properly

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Kingdome of God in the Writings of Divines, and specially in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sermons, and Treatises of Devotion, is taken most commonly for Eternall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Felicity, after this life, in the Highest Heaven, which they also call

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Kingdome of Glory; and sometimes for (the earnest of that felicity)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sanctification, which they terme the Kingdome of Grace, but never

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for the Monarchy, that is to say, the Soveraign Power of God over

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: any Subjects acquired by their own consent, which is the proper

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: signification of Kingdome.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To the contrary, I find the KINGDOME OF GOD, to signifie in most places

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Scripture, a Kingdome Properly So Named, constituted by the Votes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the People of Israel in peculiar manner; wherein they chose God

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for their King by Covenant made with him, upon Gods promising them the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: possession of the land of Canaan; and but seldom metaphorically;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and then it is taken for Dominion Over Sinne; (and only in the New

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Testament;) because such a Dominion as that, every Subject shall have in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Kingdome of God, and without prejudice to the Soveraign.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: From the very Creation, God not only reigned over all men Naturally by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his might; but also had Peculiar Subjects, whom he commanded by a Voice,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as one man speaketh to another. In which manner he Reigned over Adam,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and gave him commandement to abstaine from the tree of cognizance of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Good and Evill; which when he obeyed not, but tasting thereof, took upon

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him to be as God, judging between Good and Evill, not by his Creators

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: commandement, but by his own sense, his punishment was a privation of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the estate of Eternall life, wherein God had at first created him: And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: afterwards God punished his posterity, for their vices, all but eight

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: persons, with an universall deluge; And in these eight did consist the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: then Kingdome Of God.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Originall Of The Kingdome Of God

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: After this, it pleased God to speak to Abraham, and (Gen. 17.7,8.) to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: make a Covenant with him in these words, "I will establish my Covenant

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: between me, and thee, and thy seed after thee in their generations,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for an everlasting Covenant, to be a God to thee, and to thy seed after

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: wherein thou art a stranger, all the land of Canaan for an everlasting

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is either meant of the succession of one High Priest after another, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: else it accordeth not with St. Peter, nor with the exercise of the High

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Priesthood; For there was never any but the High Priest onely, that was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to informe the People of Gods Will; nor any Convocation of Priests ever

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: allowed to enter into the Sanctum Sanctorum.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Again, the title of a Holy Nation confirmes the same: For Holy

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: signifies, that which is Gods by speciall, not by generall Right. All

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Earth (as is said in the text) is Gods; but all the Earth is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not called Holy, but that onely which is set apart for his especiall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: service, as was the Nation of the Jews. It is therefore manifest enough

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by this one place, that by the Kingdome of God, is properly meant a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth, instituted (by the consent of those which were to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: subject thereto) for their Civill Government, and the regulating of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their behaviour, not onely towards God their King, but also towards one

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: another in point of justice, and towards other Nations both in peace and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: warre; which properly was a Kingdome, wherein God was King, and the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: High priest was to be (after the death of Moses) his sole Viceroy, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lieutenant.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But there be many other places that clearly prove the same. As first (1

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sam. 8.7.) when the Elders of Israel (grieved with the corruption of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Sons of Samuel) demanded a King, Samuel displeased therewith, prayed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: unto the Lord; and the Lord answering said unto him, "Hearken unto the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: voice of the People, for they have not rejected thee, but they have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: rejected me, that I should not reign over them." Out of which it is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: evident, that God himself was then their King; and Samuel did not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: command the people, but only delivered to them that which God from time

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to time appointed him.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Again, (1 Sam. 12.12.) where Samuel saith to the People, "When yee saw

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that Nahash King of the Children of Ammon came against you, ye said unto

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: me, Nay, but a King shall reign over us, when the Lord your God was your

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: King:" It is manifest that God was their King, and governed the Civill

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: State of their Common-wealth.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And after the Israelites had rejected God, the Prophets did foretell his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: restitution; as (Isaiah 24.23.) "Then the Moon shall be confounded, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Sun ashamed when the Lord of Hosts shall reign in Mount Zion, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in Jerusalem;" where he speaketh expressely of his Reign in Zion, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Jerusalem; that is, on Earth. And (Micah 4.7.) "And the Lord shall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: reign over them in Mount Zion:" This Mount Zion is in Jerusalem upon the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Earth. And (Ezek. 20.33.) "As I live, saith the Lord God, surely with a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: mighty hand, and a stretched out arme, and with fury powred out, I wil

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: rule over you; and (verse 37.) I will cause you to passe under the rod,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and I will bring you into the bond of the Covenant;" that is, I will

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: reign over you, and make you to stand to that Covenant which you made

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with me by Moses, and brake in your rebellion against me in the days of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Samuel, and in your election of another King.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And in the New testament, the Angel Gabriel saith of our Saviour (Luke

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 1.32,33) "He shall be great, and be called the Son of the Most High,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and the Lord shall give him the throne of his Father David; and he shall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: reign over the house of Jacob for ever; and of his Kingdome there shall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be no end." This is also a Kingdome upon Earth; for the claim whereof,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as an enemy to Caesar, he was put to death; the title of his crosse,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was, Jesus of Nazareth, King of the Jews; hee was crowned in scorn with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a crown of Thornes; and for the proclaiming of him, it is said of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Disciples (Acts 17.7.) "That they did all of them contrary to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the decrees of Caesar, saying there was another King, one Jesus. The

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kingdome therefore of God, is a reall, not a metaphoricall Kingdome; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: so taken, not onely in the Old Testament, but the New; when we say, "For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thine is the Kingdome, the Power, and Glory," it is to be understood of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Gods Kingdome, by force of our Covenant, not by the Right of Gods Power;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for such a Kingdome God alwaies hath; so that it were superfluous to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: say in our prayer, "Thy Kingdome come," unlesse it be meant of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Restauration of that Kingdome of God by Christ, which by revolt of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Israelites had been interrupted in the election of Saul. Nor had it been

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: proper to say, "The Kingdome of Heaven is at hand," or to pray, "Thy

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kingdome come," if it had still continued.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: There be so many other places that confirm this interpretation, that it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: were a wonder there is no greater notice taken of it, but that it gives

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: too much light to Christian Kings to see their right of Ecclesiastical

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Government. This they have observed, that in stead of a Sacerdotall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kingdome, translate, a Kingdome of Priests: for they may as well

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: translate a Royall Priesthood, (as it is in St. Peter) into a Priesthood

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Kings. And whereas, for a Peculiar People, they put a Pretious Jewel,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or Treasure, a man might as well call the speciall Regiment, or Company

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of a Generall, the Generalls pretious Jewel, or his Treasure.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In short, the Kingdome of God is a Civill Kingdome; which consisted,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: first in the obligation of the people of Israel to those Laws, which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Moses should bring unto them from Mount Sinai; and which afterwards the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: High Priest of the time being, should deliver to them from before the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Cherubins in the Sanctum Sanctorum; and which kingdome having been cast

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: off, in the election of Saul, the Prophets foretold, should be restored

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by Christ; and the Restauration whereof we daily pray for, when we

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: say in the Lords Prayer, "Thy Kingdome come;" and the Right whereof we

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: acknowledge, when we adde, "For thine is the Kingdome, the Power, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Glory, for ever and ever, Amen;" and the Proclaiming whereof, was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Preaching of the Apostles; and to which men are prepared, by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Teachers of the Gospel; to embrace which Gospel, (that is to say, to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: promise obedience to Gods government) is, to bee in the Kingdome of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Grace, because God hath gratis given to such the power to bee the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: subjects (that is, Children) of God hereafter, when Christ shall come

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in Majesty to judge the world, and actually to govern his owne people,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which is called the Kingdome of Glory. If the Kingdome of God (called

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: also the Kingdome of Heaven, from the gloriousnesse, and admirable

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: height of that throne) were not a Kingdome which God by his Lieutenant,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or Vicars, who deliver his Commandements to the people, did exercise on

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Earth; there would not have been so much contention, and warre, about

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: who it is, by whom God speaketh to us; neither would many Priests have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: troubled themselves with Spirituall Jurisdiction, nor any King have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: denied it them.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Out of this literall interpretation of the Kingdome of God, ariseth also

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the true interpretation of the word HOLY. For it is a word, which in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Gods Kingdome answereth to that, which men in their Kingdomes use to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: call Publique, or the Kings.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The King of any Countrey is the Publique Person, or Representative of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all his own Subjects. And God the King of Israel was the Holy One of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Israel. The Nation which is subject to one earthly Soveraign, is the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nation of that Soveraign, that is, of the Publique Person. So the Jews,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: who were Gods Nation, were called (Exod. 19.6.) "a Holy Nation." For by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Holy, is alwaies understood, either God himselfe, or that which is Gods

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in propriety; as by Publique is alwaies meant, either the Person of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth it self, or something that is so the Common-wealths, as no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: private person can claim any propriety therein.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Therefore the Sabbath (Gods day) is a Holy Day; the Temple, (Gods house)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Holy House; Sacrifices, Tithes, and Offerings (Gods tribute) Holy

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Duties; Priests, Prophets, and anointed Kings, under Christ (Gods

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ministers) Holy Men; The Coelestiall ministring Spirits (Gods

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Messengers) Holy Angels; and the like: and wheresoever the word Holy is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: taken properly, there is still something signified of Propriety, gotten

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by consent. In saying "Hallowed be thy name," we do but pray to God for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: grace to keep the first Commandement, of "having no other Gods but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Him." Mankind is Gods Nation in propriety: but the Jews only were a Holy

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nation. Why, but because they became his Propriety by covenant.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sacred What

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And the word Profane, is usually taken in the Scripture for the same

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with Common; and consequently their contraries, Holy, and Proper, in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kingdome of God must be the same also. But figuratively, those men also

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are called Holy, that led such godly lives, as if they had forsaken all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: worldly designes, and wholly devoted, and given themselves to God.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In the proper sense, that which is made Holy by Gods appropriating or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: separating it to his own use, is said to be Sanctified by God, as the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Seventh day in the fourth Commandement; and as the Elect in the New

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Testament were said to bee Sanctified, when they were endued with the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Spirit of godlinesse. And that which is made Holy by the dedication of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: men, and given to God, so as to be used onely in his publique service,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is called also SACRED, and said to be consecrated, as Temples, and other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Houses of Publique Prayer, and their Utensils, Priests, and Ministers,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Victimes, Offerings, and the externall matter of Sacraments.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Degrees of Sanctity

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of Holinesse there be degrees: for of those things that are set apart

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for the service of God, there may bee some set apart again, for a neerer

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and more especial service. The whole Nation of the Israelites were a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: people Holy to God; yet the tribe of Levi was amongst the Israelites a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Holy tribe; and amongst the Levites, the Priests were yet more Holy; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: amongst the Priests, the High Priest was the most Holy. So the Land

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Judea was the Holy Land; but the Holy City wherein God was to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: worshipped, was more Holy; and again, the Temples more Holy than the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: City; and the Sanctum Sanctorum more Holy than the rest of the Temple.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sacrament

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: A SACRAMENT, is a separation of some visible thing from common use;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and a consecration of it to Gods service, for a sign, either of our

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: admission into the Kingdome of God, to be of the number of his peculiar

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: people, or for a Commemoration of the same. In the Old Testament, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sign of Admission was Circumcision; in the New Testament, Baptisme. The

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Commemoration of it in the Old Testament, was the Eating (at a certain

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: time, which was Anniversary) of the Paschall Lamb; by which they were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: put in mind of the night wherein they were delivered out of their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: bondage in Egypt; and in the New Testament, the celebrating of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lords Supper; by which, we are put in mind, of our deliverance from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the bondage of sin, by our Blessed Saviours death upon the crosse. The

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sacraments of Admission, are but once to be used, because there needs

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but one Admission; but because we have need of being often put in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: mind of our deliverance, and of our Allegeance, The Sacraments of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Commemoration have need to be reiterated. And these are the principall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sacraments, and as it were the solemne oathes we make of our

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Alleageance. There be also other Consecrations, that may be called

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sacraments, as the word implyeth onely Consecration to Gods service; but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as it implies an oath, or promise of Alleageance to God, there were no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other in the Old Testament, but Circumcision, and the Passover; nor

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are there any other in the New Testament, but Baptisme, and the Lords

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Supper.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CHAPTER XXXVI. OF THE WORD OF GOD, AND OF PROPHETS

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Word What

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: When there is mention of the Word of God, or of Man, it doth not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: signifie a part of Speech, such as Grammarians call a Nown, or a Verb,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or any simple voice, without a contexture with other words to make it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: significative; but a perfect Speech or Discourse, whereby the speaker

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Affirmeth, Denieth, Commandeth, Promiseth, Threateneth, Wisheth, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Interrogateth. In which sense it is not Vocabulum, that signifies a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Word; but Sermo, (in Greek Logos) that is some Speech, Discourse, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Saying.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Words Spoken By God And Concerning God, Both Are Called Gods Word

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In Scripture

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Again, if we say the Word of God, or of Man, it may bee understood

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sometimes of the Speaker, (as the words that God hath spoken, or that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Man hath spoken): In which sense, when we say, the Gospel of St.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Matthew, we understand St. Matthew to be the Writer of it: and sometimes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Subject: In which sense, when we read in the Bible, "The words

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the days of the Kings of Israel, or Judah," 'tis meant, that the acts

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that were done in those days, were the Subject of those Words; And in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Greek, which (in the Scripture) retaineth many Hebraismes, by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Word of God is oftentimes meant, not that which is spoken by God, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: concerning God, and his government; that is to say, the Doctrine of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Religion: Insomuch, as it is all one, to say Logos Theou, and Theologia;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which is, that Doctrine which wee usually call Divinity, as is manifest

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by the places following (Acts 13.46.) "Then Paul and Barnabas waxed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: bold, and said, It was necessary that the Word of God should first

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have been spoken to you, but seeing you put it from you, and judge your

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: selves unworthy of everlasting life, loe, we turn to the Gentiles."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: That which is here called the Word of god, was the Doctrine of Christian

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Religion; as it appears evidently by that which goes before. And (Acts

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 5.20.) where it is said to the Apostles by an Angel, "Go stand and speak

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the Temple, all the Words of this life;" by the Words of this life,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is meant, the Doctrine of the Gospel; as is evident by what they did in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Temple, and is expressed in the last verse of the same Chap. "Daily

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the Temple, and in every house they ceased not to teach and preach

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christ Jesus:" In which place it is manifest, that Jesus Christ was the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: subject of this Word of Life; or (which is all one) the subject of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Words of this Life Eternall, that our saviour offered them. So (Acts

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 15.7.) the Word of God, is called the Word of the Gospel, because it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: containeth the Doctrine of the Kingdome of Christ; and the same Word

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (Rom. 10.8,9.) is called the Word of Faith; that is, as is there

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: expressed, the Doctrine of Christ come, and raised from the dead. Also

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (Mat. 13. 19.) "When any one heareth the Word of the Kingdome;" that is,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Doctrine of the Kingdome taught by Christ. Again, the same Word, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: said (Acts 12. 24.) "to grow and to be multiplied;" which to understand

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Evangelicall Doctrine is easie, but of the Voice, or Speech

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of God, hard and strange. In the same sense the Doctrine of Devils,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: signifieth not the Words of any Devill, but the Doctrine of Heathen men

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: concerning Daemons, and those Phantasms which they worshipped as Gods.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Considering these two significations of the WORD OF GOD, as it is taken

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in Scripture, it is manifest in this later sense (where it is taken for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Doctrine of the Christian Religion,) that the whole scripture is the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Word of God: but in the former sense not so. For example, though these

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: words, "I am the Lord thy God, &c." to the end of the Ten Commandements,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: were spoken by God to Moses; yet the Preface, "God spake these words

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and said," is to be understood for the Words of him that wrote the holy

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: History. The Word of God, as it is taken for that which he hath spoken,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is understood sometimes Properly, sometimes Metaphorically. Properly,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as the words, he hath spoken to his Prophets; Metaphorically, for his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Wisdome, Power, and eternall Decree, in making the world; in which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sense, those Fiats, "Let there be light," "Let there be a firmament,"

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "Let us make man," &c. (Gen. 1.) are the Word of God. And in the same

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sense it is said (John 1.3.) "All things were made by it, and without it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was nothing made that was made; And (Heb. 1.3.) "He upholdeth all things

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by the word of his Power;" that is, by the Power of his Word; that is,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by his Power; and (Heb. 11.3.) "The worlds were framed by the Word

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of God;" and many other places to the same sense: As also amongst the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Latines, the name of Fate, which signifieth properly The Word Spoken, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: taken in the same sense.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Secondly, For The Effect Of His Word

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Secondly, for the effect of his Word; that is to say, for the thing it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: self, which by his Word is Affirmed, Commanded, Threatned, or Promised;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as (Psalm 105.19.) where Joseph is said to have been kept in prison,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "till his Word was come;" that is, till that was come to passe which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he had (Gen. 40.13.) foretold to Pharaohs Butler, concerning his being

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: restored to his office: for there by His Word Was Come, is meant, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thing it self was come to passe. So also (1 King. 18.36.) Elijah saith

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to God, "I have done all these thy Words," in stead of "I have done all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: these things at thy Word," or commandement: and (Jer. 17.15.) "Where is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Word of the Lord," is put for, "Where is the Evill he threatened:"

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And (Ezek. 12.28.) "There shall none of my Words be prolonged any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: more:" by "Words" are understood those Things, which God promised to his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: people. And in the New Testament (Mat. 24.35.) "heaven and earth shal

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: pass away, but my Words shall not pass away;" that is, there is nothing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that I have promised or foretold, that shall not come to passe. And in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: this sense it is, that St. John the Evangelist, and, I think, St. John

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: onely calleth our Saviour himself as in the flesh "the Word of God

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (as Joh. 1.14.) the Word was made Flesh;" that is to say, the Word, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Promise that Christ should come into the world, "who in the beginning

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was with God;" that is to say, it was in the purpose of God the Father,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to send God the Son into the world, to enlighten men in the way of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Eternall life, but it was not till then put in execution, and actually

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: incarnate; So that our Saviour is there called "the Word," not because

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he was the promise, but the thing promised. They that taking occasion

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from this place, doe commonly call him the Verbe of God, do but render

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the text more obscure. They might as well term him the Nown of God:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for as by Nown, so also by Verbe, men understand nothing but a part

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of speech, a voice, a sound, that neither affirms, nor denies, nor

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: commands, nor promiseth, nor is any substance corporeall, or spirituall;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and therefore it cannot be said to bee either God, or Man; whereas our

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Saviour is both. And this Word which St. John in his Gospel saith was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with God, is (in his 1 Epistle, verse 1.) called "the Word of Life;" and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (verse 2.) "The eternall life, which was with the Father:" so that he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: can be in no other sense called the Word, then in that, wherein he is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: called Eternall life; that is, "he that hath procured us Eternall life,"

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by his comming in the flesh. So also (Apocalypse 19.13.) the Apostle

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: speaking of Christ, clothed in a garment dipt in bloud, saith; his name

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is "the Word of God;" which is to be understood, as if he had said his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: name had been, "He that was come according to the purpose of God from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the beginning, and according to his Word and promises delivered by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Prophets." So that there is nothing here of the Incarnation of a Word,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but of the Incarnation of God the Son, therefore called the Word,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: because his Incarnation was the Performance of the Promise; In like

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: manner as the Holy Ghost is called The Promise. (Acts 1.4. Luke 24.49.)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Thirdly, For The Words Of Reason And Equity

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: There are also places of the Scripture, where, by the Word of God, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: signified such Words as are consonant to reason, and equity, though

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: spoken sometimes neither by prophet, nor by a holy man. For Pharaoh

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Necho was an Idolator; yet his Words to the good King Josiah, in which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he advised him by Messengers, not to oppose him in his march against

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Carchemish, are said to have proceeded from the mouth of God; and that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Josiah not hearkning to them, was slain in the battle; as is to be read

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 2 Chron. 35. vers. 21,22,23. It is true, that as the same History is

author: Thomas Hobbes
