text: related in the first book of Esdras, not Pharaoh, but Jeremiah spake

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: these words to Josiah, from the mouth of the Lord. But wee are to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: give credit to the Canonicall Scripture, whatsoever be written in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Apocrypha.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Word of God, is then also to be taken for the Dictates of reason,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and equity, when the same is said in the Scriptures to bee written in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: mans heart; as Psalm 36.31. Jerem. 31.33. Deut.30.11, 14. and many other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: like places.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Divers Acceptions Of The Word Prophet

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The name of PROPHET, signifieth in Scripture sometimes Prolocutor; that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is, he that speaketh from God to Man, or from man to God: And sometimes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Praedictor, or a foreteller of things to come; And sometimes one that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: speaketh incoherently, as men that are distracted. It is most frequently

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: used in the sense of speaking from God to the People. So Moses, Samuel,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Elijah, Isaiah, Jeremiah, and others were Prophets. And in this sense

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the High Priest was a Prophet, for he only went into the Sanctum

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sanctorum, to enquire of God; and was to declare his answer to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: people. And therefore when Caiphas said, it was expedient that one man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: should die for the people, St. John saith (chap. 11.51.) that "He spake

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not this of himselfe, but being High Priest that year, he prophesied

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that one man should dye for the nation." Also they that in Christian

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Congregations taught the people, (1 Cor. 14.3.) are said to Prophecy. In

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the like sense it is, that God saith to Moses (Exod. 4.16.) concerning

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Aaron, "He shall be thy Spokes-man to the People; and he shall be to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thee a mouth, and thou shalt be to him in stead of God;" that which here

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is Spokesman, is (chap.7.1.) interpreted Prophet; "See (saith God)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: I have made thee a God to Pharaoh, and Aaron thy Brother shall be thy

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Prophet." In the sense of speaking from man to God, Abraham is called

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Prophet (Genes. 20.7.) where God in a Dream speaketh to Abimelech

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in this manner, "Now therefore restore the man his wife, for he is a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Prophet, and shall pray for thee;" whereby may be also gathered,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that the name of Prophet may be given, not unproperly to them that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in Christian Churches, have a Calling to say publique prayers for the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Congregation. In the same sense, the Prophets that came down from the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: High place (or Hill of God) with a Psaltery, and a Tabret, and a Pipe,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and a Harp (1 Sam. 10.5,6.) and (vers. 10.) Saul amongst them, are said

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to Prophecy, in that they praised God, in that manner publiquely. In the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: like sense, is Miriam (Exod. 15.20.) called a Prophetesse. So is it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: also to be taken (1 Cor. 11.4,5.) where St. Paul saith, "Every man that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: prayeth or prophecyeth with his head covered, &c. and every woman that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: prayeth or prophecyeth with her head uncovered: For Prophecy in that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: place, signifieth no more, but praising God in Psalmes, and Holy Songs;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which women might doe in the Church, though it were not lawfull for them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to speak to the Congregation. And in this signification it is, that the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Poets of the Heathen, that composed Hymnes and other sorts of Poems in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the honor of their Gods, were called Vates (Prophets) as is well enough

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: known by all that are versed in the Books of the Gentiles, and as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is evident (Tit. 1.12.) where St. Paul saith of the Cretians, that a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Prophet of their owne said, they were Liars; not that St. Paul held

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their Poets for Prophets, but acknowledgeth that the word Prophet was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: commonly used to signifie them that celebrated the honour of God in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Verse

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Praediction Of Future Contingents, Not Alwaies Prophecy

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: When by Prophecy is meant Praediction, or foretelling of future

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Contingents; not only they were Prophets, who were Gods Spokesmen, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: foretold those things to others, which God had foretold to them; but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: also all those Imposters, that pretend by the helpe of familiar spirits,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or by superstitious divination of events past, from false causes, to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: foretell the like events in time to come: of which (as I have declared

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: already in the 12. chapter of this Discourse) there be many kinds, who

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: gain in the opinion of the common sort of men, a greater reputation

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Prophecy, by one casuall event that may bee but wrested to their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: purpose, than can be lost again by never so many failings. Prophecy is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not an art, nor (when it is taken for Praediction) a constant Vocation;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but an extraordinary, and temporary Employment from God, most often of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Good men, but sometimes also of the Wicked. The woman of Endor, who

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is said to have had a familiar spirit, and thereby to have raised a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Phantasme of Samuel, and foretold Saul his death, was not therefore a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Prophetesse; for neither had she any science, whereby she could raise

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such a Phantasme; nor does it appear that God commanded the raising of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it; but onely guided that Imposture to be a means of Sauls terror and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: discouragement; and by consequent, of the discomfiture, by which he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: fell. And for Incoherent Speech, it was amongst the Gentiles taken for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: one sort of Prophecy, because the Prophets of their Oracles, intoxicated

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with a spirit, or vapour from the cave of the Pythian Oracle at Delphi,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: were for the time really mad, and spake like mad-men; of whose loose

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: words a sense might be made to fit any event, in such sort, as all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: bodies are said to be made of Materia prima. In the Scripture I find

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it also so taken (1 Sam. 18. 10.) in these words, "And the Evill spirit

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: came upon Saul, and he Prophecyed in the midst of the house."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Manner How God Hath Spoken To The Prophets

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And although there be so many significations in Scripture of the word

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Prophet; yet is that the most frequent, in which it is taken for him,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to whom God speaketh immediately, that which the Prophet is to say from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him, to some other man, or to the people. And hereupon a question may

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be asked, in what manner God speaketh to such a Prophet. Can it (may some

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: say) be properly said, that God hath voice and language, when it cannot

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be properly said, he hath a tongue, or other organs, as a man? The

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Prophet David argueth thus, "Shall he that made the eye, not see? or he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that made the ear, not hear?" But this may be spoken, not (as usually) to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: signifie Gods nature, but to signifie our intention to honor him. For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to See, and Hear, are Honorable Attributes, and may be given to God, to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: declare (as far as our capacity can conceive) his Almighty power. But

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: if it were to be taken in the strict, and proper sense, one might argue

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from his making of all parts of mans body, that he had also the same use

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of them which we have; which would be many of them so uncomely, as it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: would be the greatest contumely in the world to ascribe them to him.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Therefore we are to interpret Gods speaking to men immediately, for that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: way (whatsoever it be), by which God makes them understand his will: And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the wayes whereby he doth this, are many; and to be sought onely in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Holy Scripture: where though many times it be said, that God spake to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: this, and that person, without declaring in what manner; yet there be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: again many places, that deliver also the signes by which they were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to acknowledge his presence, and commandement; and by these may be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: understood, how he spake to many of the rest.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To The Extraordinary Prophets Of The Old Testament He Spake

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: By Dreams, Or Visions

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In what manner God spake to Adam, and Eve, and Cain, and Noah, is not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: expressed; nor how he spake to Abraham, till such time as he came out of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his own countrey to Sichem in the land of Canaan; and then (Gen. 12.7.)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: God is said to have Appeared to him. So there is one way, whereby God

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: made his presence manifest; that is, by an Apparition, or Vision. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: again, (Gen. 15.1.) The Word of the Lord came to Abraham in a Vision;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that is to say, somewhat, as a sign of Gods presence, appeared as Gods

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Messenger, to speak to him. Again, the Lord appeared to Abraham (Gen.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 18. 1.) by an apparition of three Angels; and to Abimelech (Gen. 20. 3.)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in a dream: To Lot (Gen. 19. 1.) by an apparition of Two Angels: And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to Hagar (Gen. 21. 17.) by the apparition of one Angel: And to Abraham

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: again (Gen. 22. 11.) by the apparition of a voice from heaven: And (Gen.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 26. 24.) to Isaac in the night; (that is, in his sleep, or by dream):

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And to Jacob (Gen. 18. 12.) in a dream; that is to say (as are the words

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the text) "Jacob dreamed that he saw a ladder, &c." And (Gen. 32. 1.)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in a Vision of Angels: And to Moses (Exod. 3.2.) in the apparition of a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: flame of fire out of the midst of a bush: And after the time of Moses,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (where the manner how God spake immediately to man in the Old Testament,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is expressed) hee spake alwaies by a Vision, or by a Dream; as to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Gideon, Samuel, Eliah, Elisha, Isaiah, Ezekiel, and the rest of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Prophets; and often in the New Testament, as to Joseph, to St. Peter, to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: St. Paul, and to St. John the Evangelist in the Apocalypse.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Onely to Moses hee spake in a more extraordinary manner in Mount Sinai,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and in the Tabernacle; and to the High Priest in the Tabernacle, and in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Sanctum Sanctorum of the Temple. But Moses, and after him the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: High Priests were Prophets of a more eminent place, and degree in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Gods favour; And God himself in express words declareth, that to other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Prophets hee spake in Dreams and Visions, but to his servant Moses, in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such manner as a man speaketh to his friend. The words are these (Numb.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 12. 6,7,8.) "If there be a Prophet among you, I the Lord will make my

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: self known to him in a Vision, and will speak unto him in a Dream. My

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: servant Moses is not so, who is faithfull in all my house; with him I

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: will speak mouth to mouth, even apparently, not in dark speeches; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the similitude of the Lord shall he behold." And (Exod. 33. 11.) "The

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lord spake to Moses face to face, as a man speaketh to his friend."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And yet this speaking of God to Moses, was by mediation of an Angel, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Angels, as appears expressely, Acts 7. ver. 35. and 53. and Gal. 3. 19.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and was therefore a Vision, though a more cleer Vision than was given to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other Prophets. And conformable hereunto, where God saith (Deut. 13. 1.)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "If there arise amongst you a Prophet, or Dreamer of Dreams," the later

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: word is but the interpretation of the former. And (Joel 2. 28.) "Your

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sons and your daughters shall Prophecy; your old men shall dream Dreams,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and your young men shall see Visions:" where again, the word Prophecy is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: expounded by Dream, and Vision. And in the same manner it was, that God

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: spake to Solomon, promising him Wisdome, Riches, and Honor; for the text

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: saith, (1 Kings 3. 15.) "And Solomon awoak, and behold it was a Dream:"

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: So that generally the Prophets extraordinary in the old Testament took

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: notice of the Word of God no otherwise, than from their Dreams, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Visions, that is to say, from the imaginations which they had in their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sleep, or in an Extasie; which imaginations in every true Prophet were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: supernaturall; but in false Prophets were either naturall, or feigned.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The same Prophets were neverthelesse said to speak by the Spirit; as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (Zach. 7. 12.) where the Prophet speaking of the Jewes, saith, "They

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: made their hearths hard as Adamant, lest they should hear the law, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the words which the Lord of Hosts hath sent in his Spirit by the former

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Prophets." By which it is manifest, that speaking by the Spirit, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Inspiration, was not a particular manner of Gods speaking, different

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from Vision, when they that were said to speak by the Spirit, were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: extraordinary Prophets, such as for every new message, were to have a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: particular Commission, or (which is all one) a new Dream, or Vision.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To Prophets Of Perpetuall Calling, And Supreme, God Spake In The

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Old Testament From The Mercy Seat, In A Manner Not Expressed In The

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Scripture. Of Prophets, that were so by a perpetuall Calling in the Old

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Testament, some were Supreme, and some Subordinate: Supreme were first

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Moses; and after him the High Priest, every one for his time, as long

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as the Priesthood was Royall; and after the people of the Jews, had

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: rejected God, that he should no more reign over them, those Kings which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: submitted themselves to Gods government, were also his chief Prophets;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and the High Priests office became Ministeriall. And when God was to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consulted, they put on the holy vestments, and enquired of the Lord,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as the King commanded them, and were deprived of their office, when

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the King thought fit. For King Saul (1 Sam. 13. 9.) commanded the burnt

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: offering to be brought, and (1 Sam. 14. 18.) he commands the Priest to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: bring the Ark neer him; and (ver. 19.) again to let it alone, because he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: saw an advantage upon his enemies. And in the same chapter Saul asketh

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: counsell of God. In like manner King David, after his being anointed,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: though before he had possession of the Kingdome, is said to "enquire

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Lord" (1 Sam. 23. 2.) whether he should fight against the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Philistines at Keilah; and (verse 10.) David commandeth the Priest to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: bring him the Ephod, to enquire whether he should stay in Keilah,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or not. And King Solomon (1 Kings 2. 27.) took the Priesthood from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Abiathar, and gave it (verse 35.) to Zadoc. Therefore Moses, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the High Priests, and the pious Kings, who enquired of God on all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: extraordinary occasions, how they were to carry themselves, or what

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: event they were to have, were all Soveraign Prophets. But in what manner

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: God spake unto them, is not manifest. To say that when Moses went up to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: God in Mount Sinai, it was a Dream, or Vision, such as other Prophets

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: had, is contrary to that distinction which God made between Moses, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other Prophets, Numb. 12. 6,7,8. To say God spake or appeared as he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is in his own nature, is to deny his Infinitenesse, Invisibility,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Incomprehensibility. To say he spake by Inspiration, or Infusion of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Holy Spirit, as the Holy Spirit signifieth the Deity, is to make Moses

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: equall with Christ, in whom onely the Godhead (as St. Paul speaketh Col.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 2.9.) dwelleth bodily. And lastly, to say he spake by the Holy Spirit,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as it signifieth the graces, or gifts of the Holy Spirit, is to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: attribute nothing to him supernaturall. For God disposeth men to Piety,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Justice, Mercy, Truth, Faith, and all manner of Vertue, both Morall,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Intellectuall, by doctrine, example, and by severall occasions,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: naturall, and ordinary.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And as these ways cannot be applyed to God, in his speaking to Moses, at

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Mount Sinai; so also, they cannot be applyed to him, in his speaking

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to the High Priests, from the Mercy-Seat. Therefore in what manner God

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: spake to those Soveraign Prophets of the Old Testament, whose office

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it was to enquire of him, is not intelligible. In the time of the New

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Testament, there was no Soveraign Prophet, but our Saviour; who was both

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: God that spake, and the Prophet to whom he spake.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To Prophets Of Perpetuall Calling, But Subordinate, God Spake By The

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Spirit. To subordinate Prophets of perpetuall Calling, I find not any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: place that proveth God spake to them supernaturally; but onely in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such manner, as naturally he inclineth men to Piety, to Beleef, to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Righteousnesse, and to other vertues all other Christian Men. Which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: way, though it consist in Constitution, Instruction, Education, and the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: occasions and invitements men have to Christian vertues; yet it is truly

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: attributed to the operation of the Spirit of God, or Holy Spirit

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (which we in our language call the Holy Ghost): For there is no good

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: inclination, that is not of the operation of God. But these operations

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are not alwaies supernaturall. When therefore a Prophet is said to speak

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the Spirit, or by the Spirit of God, we are to understand no more,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but that he speaks according to Gods will, declared by the supreme

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Prophet. For the most common acceptation of the word Spirit, is in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: signification of a mans intention, mind, or disposition.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In the time of Moses, there were seventy men besides himself, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Prophecyed in the Campe of the Israelites. In what manner God spake to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them, is declared in the 11 of Numbers, verse 25. "The Lord came down in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a cloud, and spake unto Moses, and took of the Spirit that was upon him,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and gave it to the seventy Elders. And it came to passe, when the Spirit

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: rested upon them, they Prophecyed, and did not cease," By which it is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: manifest, first, that their Prophecying to the people, was subservient,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and subordinate to the Prophecying of Moses; for that God took of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Spirit of Moses, to put upon them; so that they Prophecyed as Moses

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: would have them: otherwise they had not been suffered to Prophecy at

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all. For there was (verse 27.) a complaint made against them to Moses;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Joshua would have Moses to have forbidden them; which he did not,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but said to Joshua, Bee not jealous in my behalf. Secondly, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Spirit of God in that place, signifieth nothing but the Mind and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Disposition to obey, and assist Moses in the administration of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Government. For if it were meant they had the substantial Spirit of God;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that is, the Divine nature, inspired into them, then they had it in no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: lesse manner than Christ himself, in whom onely the Spirit of God dwelt

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: bodily. It is meant therefore of the Gift and Grace of God, that guided

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them to co-operate with Moses; from whom their Spirit was derived. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it appeareth (verse 16.) that, they were such as Moses himself should

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: appoint for Elders and Officers of the People: For the words are,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "Gather unto me seventy men, whom thou knowest to be Elders and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Officers of the people:" where, "thou knowest," is the same with "thou

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: appointest," or "hast appointed to be such." For we are told

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: before (Exod. 18.) that Moses following the counsell of Jethro his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Father-in-law, did appoint Judges, and Officers over the people, such as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: feared God; and of these, were those Seventy, whom God by putting upon

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them Moses spirit, inclined to aid Moses in the Administration of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kingdome: and in this sense the Spirit of God is said (1 Sam. 16. 13,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 14.) presently upon the anointing of David, to have come upon David, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: left Saul; God giving his graces to him he chose to govern his people,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and taking them away from him, he rejected. So that by the Spirit is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: meant Inclination to Gods service; and not any supernaturall Revelation.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: God Sometimes Also Spake By Lots

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: God spake also many times by the event of Lots; which were ordered by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such as he had put in Authority over his people. So wee read that God

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: manifested by the Lots which Saul caused to be drawn (1 Sam. 14. 43.)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the fault that Jonathan had committed, in eating a honey-comb, contrary

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to the oath taken by the people. And (Josh. 18. 10.) God divided the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: land of Canaan amongst the Israelite, by the "lots that Joshua did cast

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: before the Lord in Shiloh." In the same manner it seemeth to be, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: God discovered (Joshua 7.16., &c.) the crime of Achan. And these are the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: wayes whereby God declared his Will in the Old Testament.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: All which ways he used also in the New Testament. To the Virgin Mary, by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Vision of an Angel: To Joseph in a Dream: again to Paul in the way

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to Damascus in a Vision of our Saviour: and to Peter in the Vision of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a sheet let down from heaven, with divers sorts of flesh, of clean and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: unclean, beasts; and in prison, by Vision of an Angel: And to all the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Apostles, and Writers of the New Testament, by the graces of his Spirit;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and to the Apostles again (at the choosing of Matthias in the place of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Judas Iscariot) by lot.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Every Man Ought To Examine The Probability Of A Pretended Prophets

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Calling

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Seeing then all Prophecy supposeth Vision, or Dream, (which two, when

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they be naturall, are the same,) or some especiall gift of God, so

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: rarely observed in mankind, as to be admired where observed; and seeing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as well such gifts, as the most extraordinary Dreams, and Visions, may

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: proceed from God, not onely by his supernaturall, and immediate, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: also by his naturall operation, and by mediation of second causes;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there is need of Reason and Judgement to discern between naturall, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: supernaturall Gifts, and between naturall, and supernaturall Visions, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Dreams. And consequently men had need to be very circumspect, and wary,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in obeying the voice of man, that pretending himself to be a Prophet,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: requires us to obey God in that way, which he in Gods name telleth us to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be the way to happinesse. For he that pretends to teach men the way of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: so great felicity, pretends to govern them; that is to say, to rule, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: reign over them; which is a thing, that all men naturally desire, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is therefore worthy to be suspected of Ambition and Imposture; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consequently, ought to be examined, and tryed by every man, before hee

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: yeeld them obedience; unlesse he have yeelded it them already, in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the institution of a Common-wealth; as when the Prophet is the Civill

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign, or by the Civil Soveraign Authorized. And if this examination

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Prophets, and Spirits, were not allowed to every one of the people,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it had been to no purpose, to set out the marks, by which every man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: might be able, to distinguish between those, whom they ought, and those

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whom they ought not to follow. Seeing therefore such marks are set out

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (Deut. 13. 1,&c.) to know a Prophet by; and (1 John 4.1.&C) to know a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Spirit by: and seeing there is so much Prophecying in the Old Testament;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and so much Preaching in the New Testament against Prophets; and so much

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: greater a number ordinarily of false Prophets, then of true; every

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: one is to beware of obeying their directions, at their own perill. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: first, that there were many more false than true Prophets, appears by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: this, that when Ahab (1 Kings 12.) consulted four hundred Prophets, they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: were all false Imposters, but onely one Michaiah. And a little before

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the time of the Captivity, the Prophets were generally lyars. "The

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Prophets" (saith the Lord by Jerem. cha. 14. verse 14.) "prophecy Lies

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in my name. I sent them not, neither have I commanded them, nor spake

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: unto them, they prophecy to you a false Vision, a thing of naught; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the deceit of their heart." In so much as God commanded the People by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the mouth of the Prophet Jeremiah (chap. 23. 16.) not to obey them.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "Thus saith the Lord of Hosts, hearken not unto the words of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Prophets, that prophecy to you. They make you vain, they speak a Vision

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of their own heart, and not out of the mouth of the Lord."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: All Prophecy But Of The Soveraign Prophet Is To Be Examined

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: By Every Subject

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Seeing then there was in the time of the Old Testament, such quarrells

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: amongst the Visionary Prophets, one contesting with another, and asking

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: When departed the Spirit from me, to go to thee? as between Michaiah,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and the rest of the four hundred; and such giving of the Lye to one

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: another, (as in Jerem. 14.14.) and such controversies in the New

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Testament at this day, amongst the Spirituall Prophets: Every man then

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was, and now is bound to make use of his Naturall Reason, to apply to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all Prophecy those Rules which God hath given us, to discern the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: true from the false. Of which rules, in the Old Testament, one was,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: conformable doctrine to that which Moses the Soveraign Prophet had

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: taught them; and the other the miraculous power of foretelling what God

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: would bring to passe, as I have already shown out of Deut. 13. 1. &c.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and in the New Testament there was but one onely mark; and that was the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: preaching of this Doctrine, That Jesus Is The Christ, that is, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: King of the Jews, promised in the Old Testament. Whosoever denyed that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Article, he was a false Prophet, whatsoever miracles he might seem to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: work; and he that taught it was a true Prophet. For St. John (1 Epist,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 4. 2, &c) speaking expressely of the means to examine Spirits, whether

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they be of God, or not; after he hath told them that there would arise

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: false Prophets, saith thus, "Hereby know ye the Spirit of God. Every

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Spirit that confesseth that Jesus Christ is come in the flesh, is of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: God;" that is, is approved and allowed as a Prophet of God: not that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he is a godly man, or one of the Elect, for this, that he confesseth,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: professeth, or preacheth Jesus to be the Christ; but for that he is a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Prophet avowed. For God sometimes speaketh by Prophets, whose persons he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hath not accepted; as he did by Baalam; and as he foretold Saul of his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: death, by the Witch of Endor. Again in the next verse, "Every Spirit

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that confesseth not that Jesus Christ is come in the Flesh, is not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Christ. And this is the Spirit of Antichrist." So that the rule is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: perfect on both sides; that he is a true Prophet, which preacheth the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Messiah already come, in the person of Jesus; and he a false one that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: denyeth him come, and looketh for him in some future Imposter, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shall take upon him that honour falsely, whom the Apostle there properly

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: calleth Antichrist. Every man therefore ought to consider who is the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign Prophet; that is to say, who it is, that is Gods Viceregent

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: on earth; and hath next under God, the Authority of Governing Christian

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: men; and to observe for a Rule, that Doctrine, which in the name of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: God, hee commanded to bee taught; and thereby to examine and try out

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the truth of those Doctrines, which pretended Prophets with miracles, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: without, shall at any time advance: and if they find it contrary to that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Rule, to doe as they did, that came to Moses, and complained that there

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: were some that Prophecyed in the Campe, whose Authority so to doe they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: doubted of; and leave to the Soveraign, as they did to Moses to uphold,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or to forbid them, as hee should see cause; and if hee disavow them,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: then no more to obey their voice; or if he approve them, then to obey

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them, as men to whom God hath given a part of the Spirit of their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraigne. For when Christian men, take not their Christian Soveraign,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for Gods Prophet; they must either take their owne Dreams, for the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: prophecy they mean to bee governed by, and the tumour of their own

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hearts for the Spirit of God; or they must suffer themselves to bee lead

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by some strange Prince; or by some of their fellow subjects, that can

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: bewitch them, by slander of the government, into rebellion, without

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other miracle to confirm their calling, then sometimes an extraordinary

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: successe, and Impunity; and by this means destroying all laws, both

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: divine, and humane, reduce all Order, Government, and Society, to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: first Chaos of Violence, and Civill warre.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CHAPTER XXXVII. OF MIRACLES, AND THEIR USE

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: A Miracle Is A Work That Causeth Admiration

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: By Miracles are signified the Admirable works of God: & therefore they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are also called Wonders. And because they are for the most part, done,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for a signification of his commandement, in such occasions, as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: without them, men are apt to doubt, (following their private naturall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: reasoning,) what he hath commanded, and what not, they are commonly in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Holy Scripture, called Signes, in the same sense, as they are called by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Latines, Ostenta, and Portenta, from shewing, and fore-signifying

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that, which the Almighty is about to bring to passe.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And Must Therefore Be Rare, Whereof There Is No Naturall Cause Known

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To understand therefore what is a Miracle, we must first understand what

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: works they are, which men wonder at, and call Admirable. And there be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but two things which make men wonder at any event: The one is, if it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be strange, that is to say, such, as the like of it hath never, or very

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: rarely been produced: The other is, if when it is produced, we cannot

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: imagine it to have been done by naturall means, but onely by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: immediate hand of God. But when wee see some possible, naturall cause of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it, how rarely soever the like has been done; or if the like have been

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: often done, how impossible soever it be to imagine a naturall means

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thereof, we no more wonder, nor esteem it for a Miracle.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Therefore, if a Horse, or Cow should speak, it were a Miracle; because

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: both the thing is strange, & the Naturall cause difficult to imagin: So

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: also were it, to see a strange deviation of nature, in the production

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of some new shape of a living creature. But when a man, or other Animal,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: engenders his like, though we know no more how this is done, than the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other; yet because 'tis usuall, it is no Miracle. In like manner, if a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man be metamorphosed into a stone, or into a pillar, it is a Miracle;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: because strange: but if a peece of wood be so changed; because we see it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: often, it is no Miracle: and yet we know no more, by what operation of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: God, the one is brought to passe, than the other.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The first Rainbow that was seen in the world, was a Miracle, because the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: first; and consequently strange; and served for a sign from God, placed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in heaven, to assure his people, there should be no more an universall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: destruction of the world by Water. But at this day, because they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are frequent, they are not Miracles, neither to them that know their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: naturall causes, nor to them who know them not. Again, there be many

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: rare works produced by the Art of man: yet when we know they are done;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: because thereby wee know also the means how they are done, we count them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not for Miracles, because not wrought by the immediate hand of God, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by mediation of humane Industry.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: That Which Seemeth A Miracle To One Man, May Seem Otherwise To Another

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Furthermore, seeing Admiration and Wonder, is consequent to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: knowledge and experience, wherewith men are endued, some more, some

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: lesse; it followeth, that the same thing, may be a Miracle to one, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not to another. And thence it is, that ignorant, and superstitious men

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: make great Wonders of those works, which other men, knowing to proceed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from Nature, (which is not the immediate, but the ordinary work of God,)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: admire not at all: As when Ecclipses of the Sun and Moon have been taken

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for supernaturall works, by the common people; when neverthelesse, there

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: were others, could from their naturall causes, have foretold the very

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hour they should arrive: Or, as when a man, by confederacy, and secret

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: intelligence, getting knowledge of the private actions of an ignorant,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: unwary man, thereby tells him, what he has done in former time; it seems

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to him a Miraculous thing; but amongst wise, and cautelous men, such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Miracles as those, cannot easily be done.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The End Of Miracles

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Again, it belongeth to the nature of a Miracle, that it be wrought for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the procuring of credit to Gods Messengers, Ministers, and Prophets,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that thereby men may know, they are called, sent, and employed by God,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and thereby be the better inclined to obey them. And therefore, though

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the creation of the world, and after that the destruction of all living

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: creatures in the universall deluge, were admirable works; yet because

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they were not done to procure credit to any Prophet, or other Minister

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of God, they use not to be called Miracles. For how admirable soever any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: work be, the Admiration consisteth not in that it could be done, because

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: men naturally beleeve the Almighty can doe all things, but because he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: does it at the Prayer, or Word of a man. But the works of God in Egypt,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by the hand of Moses, were properly Miracles; because they were done

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with intention to make the people of Israel beleeve, that Moses came

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: unto them, not out of any design of his owne interest, but as sent from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: God. Therefore after God had commanded him to deliver the Israelites

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from the Egyptian bondage, when he said (Exod 4.1. &c.) "They will not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: beleeve me, but will say, the Lord hath not appeared unto me," God gave

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him power, to turn the Rod he had in his hand into a Serpent, and again

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to return it into a Rod; and by putting his hand into his bosome, to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: make it leprous; and again by pulling it out to make it whole, to make

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Children of Israel beleeve (as it is verse 5.) that the God of their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Fathers had appeared unto him; And if that were not enough, he gave

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him power to turn their waters into bloud. And when hee had done these

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Miracles before the people, it is said (verse 41.) that "they beleeved

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him." Neverthelesse, for fear of Pharaoh, they durst not yet obey him.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Therefore the other works which were done to plague Pharaoh and the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Egyptians, tended all to make the Israelites beleeve in Moses, and were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: properly Miracles. In like manner if we consider all the Miracles

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: done by the hand of Moses, and all the rest of the Prophets, till the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Captivity; and those of our Saviour, and his Apostles afterward; we

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shall find, their end was alwaies to beget, or confirm beleefe, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they came not of their own motion, but were sent by God. Wee may further

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: observe in Scripture, that the end of Miracles, was to beget beleef,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not universally in all men, elect, and reprobate; but in the elect

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: only; that is to say, is such as God had determined should become his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Subjects. For those miraculous plagues of Egypt, had not for end, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: conversion of Pharaoh; For God had told Moses before, that he would

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: harden the heart of Pharaoh, that he should not let the people goe: And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: when he let them goe at last, not the Miracles perswaded him, but the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: plagues forced him to it. So also of our Saviour, it is written, (Mat.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 13. 58.) that he wrought not many Miracles in his own countrey, because

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of their unbeleef; and (in Marke 6.5.) in stead of, "he wrought not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: many," it is, "he could work none." It was not because he wanted power;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which to say, were blasphemy against God; nor that the end of Miracles

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was not to convert incredulous men to Christ; for the end of all the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Miracles of Moses, of Prophets, of our Saviour, and of his Apostles

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was to adde men to the Church; but it was, because the end of their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Miracles, was to adde to the Church (not all men, but) such as should

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be saved; that is to say, such as God had elected. Seeing therefore

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: our Saviour sent from his Father, hee could not use his power in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: conversion of those, whom his Father had rejected. They that expounding

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: this place of St. Marke, say, that his word, "Hee could not," is put

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for, "He would not," do it without example in the Greek tongue, (where

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Would Not, is put sometimes for Could Not, in things inanimate, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have no will; but Could Not, for Would Not, never,) and thereby lay

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a stumbling block before weak Christians; as if Christ could doe no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Miracles, but amongst the credulous.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Definition Of A Miracle

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: From that which I have here set down, of the nature, and use of a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Miracle, we may define it thus, "A MIRACLE, is a work of God, (besides

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his operation by the way of Nature, ordained in the Creation,) done

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for the making manifest to his elect, the mission of an extraordinary

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Minister for their salvation."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And from this definition, we may inferre; First, that in all Miracles,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the work done, is not the effect of any vertue in the Prophet; because

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it is the effect of the immediate hand of God; that is to say God hath

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: done it, without using the Prophet therein, as a subordinate cause.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Secondly, that no Devil, Angel, or other created Spirit, can do a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Miracle. For it must either be by vertue of some naturall science, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by Incantation, that is, vertue of words. For if the Inchanters do it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by their own power independent, there is some power that proceedeth not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from God; which all men deny: and if they doe it by power given them,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: then is the work not from the immediate hand of God, but naturall, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consequently no Miracle.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: There be some texts of Scripture, that seem to attribute the power of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: working wonders (equall to some of those immediate Miracles, wrought

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by God himself,) to certain Arts of Magick, and Incantation. As for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: example, when we read that after the Rod of Moses being cast on the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ground became a Serpent, (Exod. 7. 11.) "the Magicians of Egypt did the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: like by their Enchantments;" and that after Moses had turned the waters

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Egyptian Streams, Rivers, Ponds, and Pooles of water into blood,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (Exod. 7. 22.) "the Magicians of Egypt did so likewise, with their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Enchantments;" and that after Moses had by the power of God brought

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: frogs upon the land, (Exod. 8. 7.) "the Magicians also did so with their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Enchantments, and brought up frogs upon the land of Egypt;" will not a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man be apt to attribute Miracles to Enchantments; that is to say, to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: efficacy of the sound of Words; and think the same very well proved out

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of this, and other such places? and yet there is no place of Scripture,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that telleth us what on Enchantment is. If therefore Enchantment be not,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as many think it, a working of strange effects by spells, and words;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but Imposture, and delusion, wrought by ordinary means; and so far

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from supernaturall, as the Impostors need not the study so much as of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: naturall causes, but the ordinary ignorance, stupidity, and superstition

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of mankind, to doe them; those texts that seem to countenance the power

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Magick, Witchcraft, and Enchantment, must needs have another sense,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: than at first sight they seem to bear.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: That Men Are Apt To Be Deceived By False Miracles

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For it is evident enough, that Words have no effect, but on those

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that understand them; and then they have no other, but to signifie the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: intentions, or passions of them that speak; and thereby produce, hope,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: fear, or other passions, or conceptions in the hearer. Therefore when a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Rod seemeth a Serpent, or the Water Bloud, or any other Miracle seemeth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: done by Enchantment; if it be not to the edification of Gods people,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not the Rod, nor the Water, nor any other thing is enchanted; that is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to say, wrought upon by the Words, but the Spectator. So that all the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Miracle consisteth in this, that the Enchanter has deceived a man; which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is no Miracle, but a very easie matter to doe.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For such is the ignorance, and aptitude to error generally of all men,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but especially of them that have not much knowledge of naturall causes,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and of the nature, and interests of men; as by innumerable and easie

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: tricks to be abused. What opinion of miraculous power, before it was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: known there was a Science of the course of the Stars, might a man have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: gained, that should have told the people, This hour, or day the Sun

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: should be darkned? A juggler by the handling of his goblets, and other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: trinkets, if it were not now ordinarily practised, would be thought

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to do his wonders by the power at least of the Devil. A man that hath

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: practised to speak by drawing in of his breath, (which kind of men in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: antient time were called Ventriloqui,) and so make the weaknesse of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his voice seem to proceed, not from the weak impulsion of the organs

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Speech, but from distance of place, is able to make very many men

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: beleeve it is a voice from Heaven, whatsoever he please to tell them.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And for a crafty man, that hath enquired into the secrets, and familiar

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: confessions that one man ordinarily maketh to another of his actions and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: adventures past, to tell them him again is no hard matter; and yet there

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be many, that by such means as that, obtain the reputation of being

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Conjurers. But it is too long a businesse, to reckon up the severall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sorts of those men, which the Greeks called Thaumaturgi, that is to say,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: workers of things wonderfull; and yet these do all they do, by their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: own single dexterity. But if we looke upon the Impostures wrought by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Confederacy, there is nothing how impossible soever to be done, that is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: impossible to bee beleeved. For two men conspiring, one to seem lame,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the other to cure him with a charme, will deceive many: but many

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: conspiring, one to seem lame, another so to cure him, and all the rest

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to bear witnesse; will deceive many more.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Cautions Against The Imposture Of Miracles

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In this aptitude of mankind, to give too hasty beleefe to pretended

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Miracles, there can be no better, nor I think any other caution, than

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that which God hath prescribed, first by Moses, (as I have said before

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the precedent chapter,) in the beginning of the 13. and end of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 18. of Deuteronomy; That wee take not any for Prophets, that teach any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other Religion, then that which Gods Lieutenant, (which at that time was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Moses,) hath established; nor any, (though he teach the same Religion,)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whose Praediction we doe not see come to passe. Moses therefore in his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: time, and Aaron, and his successors in their times, and the Soveraign

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Governour of Gods people, next under God himself, that is to say, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Head of the Church in all times, are to be consulted, what doctrine

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he hath established, before wee give credit to a pretended Miracle, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Prophet. And when that is done, the thing they pretend to be a Miracle,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: we must both see it done, and use all means possible to consider,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whether it be really done; and not onely so, but whether it be such, as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: no man can do the like by his naturall power, but that it requires the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: immediate hand of God. And in this also we must have recourse to Gods

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lieutenant; to whom in all doubtfull cases, wee have submitted our

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: private judgments. For Example; if a man pretend, that after certain

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: words spoken over a peece of bread, that presently God hath made it not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: bread, but a God, or a man, or both, and neverthelesse it looketh still

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as like bread as ever it did; there is no reason for any man to think

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it really done; nor consequently to fear him, till he enquire of God,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by his Vicar, or Lieutenant, whether it be done, or not. If he say not,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: then followeth that which Moses saith, (Deut. 18. 22.) "he hath spoken

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it presumptuously, thou shalt not fear him." If he say 'tis done, then

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he is not to contradict it. So also if wee see not, but onely hear tell

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of a Miracle, we are to consult the Lawful Church; that is to say, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: lawful Head thereof, how far we are to give credit to the relators of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it. And this is chiefly the case of men, that in these days live under

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christian Soveraigns. For in these times, I do not know one man, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ever saw any such wondrous work, done by the charm, or at the word,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or prayer of a man, that a man endued but with a mediocrity of reason,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: would think supernaturall: and the question is no more, whether what wee

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: see done, be a Miracle; whether the Miracle we hear, or read of, were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a reall work, and not the Act of a tongue, or pen; but in plain terms,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whether the report be true, or a lye. In which question we are not every

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: one, to make our own private Reason, or Conscience, but the Publique

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Reason, that is, the reason of Gods Supreme Lieutenant, Judge; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: indeed we have made him Judge already, if wee have given him a Soveraign

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: power, to doe all that is necessary for our peace and defence. A private

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man has alwaies the liberty, (because thought is free,) to beleeve,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or not beleeve in his heart, those acts that have been given out for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Miracles, according as he shall see, what benefit can accrew by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: mens belief, to those that pretend, or countenance them, and thereby

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: conjecture, whether they be Miracles, or Lies. But when it comes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to confession of that faith, the Private Reason must submit to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Publique; that is to say, to Gods Lieutenant. But who is this Lieutenant

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of God, and Head of the Church, shall be considered in its proper place

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thereafter.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CHAPTER XXXVIII. OF THE SIGNIFICATION IN SCRIPTURE OF ETERNALL LIFE,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: HELL, SALVATION, THE WORLD TO COME, AND REDEMPTION

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The maintenance of Civill Society, depending on Justice; and Justice on

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the power of Life and Death, and other lesse Rewards and Punishments,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: residing in them that have the Soveraignty of the Common-wealth; It

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is impossible a Common-wealth should stand, where any other than the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign, hath a power of giving greater rewards than Life; and of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: inflicting greater punishments than Death. Now seeing Eternall Life is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a greater reward, than the Life Present; and Eternall Torment a greater

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: punishment than the Death of Nature; It is a thing worthy to be well

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: considered, of all men that desire (by obeying Authority) to avoid

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the calamities of Confusion, and Civill war, what is meant in Holy

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Scripture, by Life Eternall, and Torment Eternall; and for what

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: offences, against whom committed, men are to be Eternally Tormented; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for what actions, they are to obtain Eternall Life.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Place Of Adams Eternity If He Had Not Sinned, The Terrestrial Paradise

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And first we find, that Adam was created in such a condition of life,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as had he not broken the commandement of God, he had enjoyed it in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Paradise of Eden Everlastingly. For there was the Tree of Life; whereof

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he was so long allowed to eat, as he should forbear to eat of the tree

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Knowledge of Good an Evill; which was not allowed him. And therefore

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as soon as he had eaten of it, God thrust him out of Paradise, "lest he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: should put forth his hand, and take also of the tree of life, and live

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for ever." (Gen. 3. 22.) By which it seemeth to me, (with submission

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: neverthelesse both in this, and in all questions, whereof the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: determination dependeth on the Scriptures, to the interpretation of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Bible authorized by the Common-wealth, whose Subject I am,) that Adam if

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he had not sinned, had had an Eternall Life on Earth: and that Mortality

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: entred upon himself, and his posterity, by his first Sin. Not that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: actuall Death then entred; for Adam then could never have had children;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whereas he lived long after, and saw a numerous posterity ere he dyed.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But where it is said, "In the day that thou eatest thereof, thou shalt

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: surely die," it must needs bee meant of his Mortality, and certitude

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of death. Seeing then Eternall life was lost by Adams forfeiture, in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: committing sin, he that should cancell that forfeiture was to recover

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thereby, that Life again. Now Jesus Christ hath satisfied for the sins

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of all that beleeve in him; and therefore recovered to all beleevers,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that ETERNALL LIFE, which was lost by the sin of Adam. And in this sense

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it is, that the comparison of St. Paul holdeth (Rom. 5.18, 19.) "As by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the offence of one, Judgment came upon all men to condemnation, even

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: so by the righteousnesse of one, the free gift came upon all men

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to Justification of Life." Which is again (1 Cor. 15.21,22) more

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: perspicuously delivered in these words, "For since by man came death, by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man came also the resurrection of the dead. For as in Adam all die, even

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: so in Christ shall all be made alive."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Texts Concerning The Place Of Life Eternall For Beleevers

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Concerning the place wherein men shall enjoy that Eternall Life, which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christ hath obtained for them, the texts next before alledged seem to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: make it on Earth. For if as in Adam, all die, that is, have forfeited

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Paradise, and Eternall Life on Earth; even so in Christ all shall be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: made alive; then all men shall be made to live on Earth; for else

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the comparison were not proper. Hereunto seemeth to agree that of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Psalmist, (Psal. 133.3.) "Upon Zion God commanded the blessing, even

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Life for evermore;" for Zion, is in Jerusalem, upon Earth: as also that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of S. Joh. (Rev. 2.7.) "To him that overcommeth I will give to eat of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the tree of life, which is in the midst of the Paradise of God." This

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was the tree of Adams Eternall life; but his life was to have been on

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Earth. The same seemeth to be confirmed again by St. Joh. (Rev. 21.2.)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: where he saith, "I John saw the Holy City, New Jerusalem, coming down

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from God out of heaven, prepared as a Bride adorned for her husband:"

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and again v. 10. to the same effect: As if he should say, the new

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Jerusalem, the Paradise of God, at the coming again of Christ, should

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: come down to Gods people from Heaven, and not they goe up to it from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Earth. And this differs nothing from that, which the two men in white

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: clothing (that is, the two Angels) said to the Apostles, that were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: looking upon Christ ascending (Acts 1.11.) "This same Jesus, who is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: taken up from you into Heaven, shall so come, as you have seen him go up

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: into Heaven." Which soundeth as if they had said, he should come down

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to govern them under his Father, Eternally here; and not take them up

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to govern them in Heaven; and is conformable to the Restauration of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kingdom of God, instituted under Moses; which was a Political government

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Jews on Earth. Again, that saying of our Saviour (Mat. 22.30.)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "that in the Resurrection they neither marry, nor are given in marriage,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but are as the Angels of God in heaven," is a description of an Eternall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Life, resembling that which we lost in Adam in the point of Marriage.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For seeing Adam, and Eve, if they had not sinned, had lived on Earth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Eternally, in their individuall persons; it is manifest, they should

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not continually have procreated their kind. For if Immortals should have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: generated, as Mankind doth now; the Earth in a small time, would not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have been able to afford them a place to stand on. The Jews that asked

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: our Saviour the question, whose wife the woman that had married many

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: brothers, should be, in the resurrection, knew not what were the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consequences of Immortality; that there shal be no Generation, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consequently no marriage, no more than there is Marriage, or generation

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: among the Angels. The comparison between that Eternall life which Adam

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: lost, and our Saviour by his Victory over death hath recovered; holdeth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: also in this, that as Adam lost Eternall Life by his sin, and yet lived

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: after it for a time; so the faithful Christian hath recovered Eternal

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Life by Christs passion, though he die a natural death, and remaine dead

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for a time; namely, till the Resurrection. For as Death is reckoned from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Condemnation of Adam, not from the Execution; so life is reckoned

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from the Absolution, not from the Resurrection of them that are elected

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in Christ.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ascension Into Heaven

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: That the place wherein men are to live Eternally, after the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Resurrection, is the Heavens, meaning by Heaven, those parts of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: world, which are the most remote from Earth, as where the stars are,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or above the stars, in another Higher Heaven, called Caelum Empyreum,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (whereof there is no mention in Scripture, nor ground in Reason) is not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: easily to be drawn from any text that I can find. By the Kingdome of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Heaven, is meant the Kingdome of the King that dwelleth in Heaven; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his Kingdome was the people of Israel, whom he ruled by the Prophets

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his Lieutenants, first Moses, and after him Eleazar, and the Soveraign

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Priests, till in the days of Samuel they rebelled, and would have a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: mortall man for their King, after the manner of other Nations. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: when our Saviour Christ, by the preaching of his Ministers, shall have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: perswaded the Jews to return, and called the Gentiles to his obedience,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: then shall there be a new Kingdome of Heaven, because our King shall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: then be God, whose Throne is Heaven; without any necessity evident in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Scripture, that man shall ascend to his happinesse any higher than

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Gods Footstool the Earth. On the contrary, we find written (Joh. 3.13.)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that "no man hath ascended into Heaven, but he that came down from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Heaven, even the Son of man, that is in Heaven." Where I observe by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: way, that these words are not, as those which go immediately before, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: words of our Saviour, but of St. John himself; for Christ was then not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in Heaven, but upon the Earth. The like is said of David (Acts 2.34.)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: where St. Peter, to prove the Ascension of Christ, using the words of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Psalmist, (Psal. 16.10.) "Thou wilt not leave my soule in Hell, nor

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: suffer thine Holy one to see corruption," saith, they were spoken (not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of David, but) of Christ; and to prove it, addeth this Reason, "For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: David is not ascended into Heaven." But to this a man may easily answer,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and say, that though their bodies were not to ascend till the generall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: day of Judgment, yet their souls were in Heaven as soon as they were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: departed from their bodies; which also seemeth to be confirmed by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: words of our Saviour (Luke 20.37,38.) who proving the Resurrection out

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the word of Moses, saith thus, "That the dead are raised, even Moses

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shewed, at the bush, when he calleth the Lord, the God of Abraham, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob. For he is not a God of the Dead,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but of the Living; for they all live to him." But if these words be to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be understood only of the Immortality of the Soul, they prove not at all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that which our Saviour intended to prove, which was the Resurrection

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Body, that is to say, the Immortality of the Man. Therefore our

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Saviour meaneth, that those Patriarchs were Immortall; not by a property

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consequent to the essence, and nature of mankind, but by the will of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: God, that was pleased of his mere grace, to bestow Eternall Life upon

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the faithfull. And though at that time the Patriarchs and many other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: faithfull men were Dead, yet as it is in the text, they Lived To God;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that is, they were written in the Book of Life with them that were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: absolved of their sinnes, and ordained to Life eternall at the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Resurrection. That the Soul of man is in its own nature Eternall, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a living Creature independent on the Body; or that any meer man is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Immortall, otherwise than by the Resurrection in the last day, (except

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Enos and Elias,) is a doctrine not apparent in Scripture. The whole 14.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Chapter of Job, which is the speech not of his friends, but of himselfe,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is a complaint of this Mortality of Nature; and yet no contradiction of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Immortality at the Resurrection. "There is hope of a tree," (saith

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hee verse 7.) "if it be cast down, Though the root thereof wax old, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the stock thereof die in the ground, yet when it scenteth the water

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it will bud, and bring forth boughes like a Plant. But man dyeth, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: wasteth away, yea, man giveth up the Ghost, and where is he?" and (verse

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 12.) "man lyeth down, and riseth not, till the heavens be no more." But

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: when is it, that the heavens shall be no more? St. Peter tells us, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it is at the generall Resurrection. For in his 2. Epistle, 3. Chapter,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and 7. verse, he saith, that "the Heavens and the Earth that are now,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are reserved unto fire against the day of Judgment, and perdition of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ungodly men," and (verse 12.) "looking for, and hasting to the comming

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of God, wherein the Heavens shall be on fire, and shall be dissolved,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and the Elements shall melt with fervent heat. Neverthelesse, we

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: according to the promise look for new Heavens, and a new Earth, wherein

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: dwelleth righteousnesse." Therefore where Job saith, man riseth not till

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Heavens be no more; it is all one, as if he had said, the Immortall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Life (and Soule and Life in the Scripture, do usually signifie the same

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thing) beginneth not in man, till the Resurrection, and day of Judgment;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and hath for cause, not his specificall nature, and generation; but the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Promise. For St. Peter saies not, "Wee look for new heavens, and a new

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: earth, (from Nature) but from Promise."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lastly, seeing it hath been already proved out of divers evident places

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Scripture, in the 35. chapter of this book, that the Kingdom of God

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is a Civil Common-wealth, where God himself is Soveraign, by vertue

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: first of the Old, and since of the New Covenant, wherein he reigneth by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his Vicar, or Lieutenant; the same places do therefore also prove, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: after the comming again of our Saviour in his Majesty, and glory, to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: reign actually, and Eternally; the Kingdom of God is to be on Earth. But

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: because this doctrine (though proved out of places of Scripture not few,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: nor obscure) will appear to most men a novelty; I doe but propound

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it; maintaining nothing in this, or any other paradox of Religion;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but attending the end of that dispute of the sword, concerning the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Authority, (not yet amongst my Countrey-men decided,) by which all sorts

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of doctrine are to bee approved, or rejected; and whose commands, both

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in speech, and writing, (whatsoever be the opinions of private men) must

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by all men, that mean to be protected by their Laws, be obeyed. For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the points of doctrine concerning the Kingdome (of) God, have so great

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: influence on the Kingdome of Man, as not to be determined, but by them,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that under God have the Soveraign Power.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Place After Judgment, Of Those Who Were Never In The Kingdome

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of God, Or Having Been In, Are Cast Out

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: As the Kingdome of God, and Eternall Life, so also Gods Enemies, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their Torments after Judgment, appear by the Scripture, to have their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: place on Earth. The name of the place, where all men remain till the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Resurrection, that were either buryed, or swallowed up of the Earth, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: usually called in Scripture, by words that signifie Under Ground; which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Latines read generally Infernus, and Inferni, and the Greeks Hades;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that is to say, a place where men cannot see; and containeth as well the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Grave, as any other deeper place. But for the place of the damned after

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Resurrection, it is not determined, neither in the Old, nor New

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Testament, by any note of situation; but onely by the company: as that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it shall bee, where such wicked men were, as God in former times in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: extraordinary, and miraculous manner, had destroyed from off the face of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Earth: As for Example, that they are in Inferno, in Tartarus, or in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the bottomelesse pit; because Corah, Dathan, and Abirom, were swallowed

author: Thomas Hobbes
