text: up alive into the earth. Not that the Writers of the Scripture would

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have us beleeve, there could be in the globe of the Earth, which is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not only finite, but also (compared to the height of the Stars) of no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: considerable magnitude, a pit without a bottome; that is, a hole of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: infinite depth, such as the Greeks in their Daemonologie (that is to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: say, in their doctrine concerning Daemons,) and after them, the Romans

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: called Tartarus; of which Virgill sayes,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Bis patet in praeceps, tantem tenditque sub umbras,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Quantus ad aethereum coeli suspectus Olympum:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for that is a thing the proportion of Earth to Heaven cannot bear: but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that wee should beleeve them there, indefinitely, where those men are,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: on whom God inflicted that Exemplary punnishment.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Congregation Of Giants

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Again, because those mighty men of the Earth, that lived in the time

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Noah, before the floud, (which the Greeks called Heroes, and the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Scripture Giants, and both say, were begotten, by copulation of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: children of God, with the children of men,) were for their wicked life

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: destroyed by the generall deluge; the place of the Damned, is therefore

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: also sometimes marked out, by the company of those deceased Giants; as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Proverbs 21.16. "The man that wandreth out of the way of understanding,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shall remain in the congregation of the Giants," and Job 26.5. "Behold

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Giants groan under water, and they that dwell with them." Here

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the place of the Damned, is under the water. And Isaiah 14.9. "Hell is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: troubled how to meet thee," (that is, the King of Babylon) "and will

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: displace the Giants for thee:" and here again the place of the Damned,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (if the sense be literall,) is to be under water.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lake Of Fire

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Thirdly, because the Cities of Sodom, and Gomorrah, by the extraordinary

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: wrath of God, were consumed for their wickednesse with Fire and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Brimstone, and together with them the countrey about made a stinking

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: bituminous Lake; the place of the Damned is sometimes expressed by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Fire, and a Fiery Lake: as in the Apocalypse ch.21.8. "But the timorous,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: incredulous, and abominable, and Murderers, and Whoremongers, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sorcerers, and Idolators, and all Lyars, shall have their part in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lake that burneth with Fire, and Brimstone; which is the second Death."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: So that it is manifest, that Hell Fire, which is here expressed by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Metaphor, from the reall Fire of Sodome, signifieth not any certain

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: kind, or place of Torment; but is to be taken indefinitely, for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Destruction, as it is in the 20. Chapter, at the 14. verse; where it is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: said, that "Death and Hell were cast into the Lake of Fire;" that is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to say, were abolished, and destroyed; as if after the day of Judgment,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there shall be no more Dying, nor no more going into Hell; that is, no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: more going to Hades (from which word perhaps our word Hell is derived,)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which is the same with no more Dying.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Utter Darknesse

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Fourthly, from the Plague of Darknesse inflicted on the Egyptians, of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which it is written (Exod. 10.23.) "They saw not one another, neither

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: rose any man from his place for three days; but all the Children of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Israel had light in their dwellings;" the place of the wicked after

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Judgment, is called Utter Darknesse, or (as it is in the originall)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Darknesse Without. And so it is expressed (Mat. 22.13.) where the King

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: commandeth his Servants, "to bind hand and foot the man that had not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: on his Wedding garment, and to cast him out," Eis To Skotos To Exoteron,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Externall Darknesse, or Darknesse Without: which though translated Utter

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Darknesse, does not signifie How Great, but Where that darknesse is to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be; namely, Without The Habitation of Gods Elect.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Gehenna, And Tophet

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lastly, whereas there was a place neer Jerusalem, called the Valley of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Children of Hinnon; in a part whereof, called Tophet, the Jews had

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: committed most grievous Idolatry, sacrificing their children to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Idol Moloch; and wherein also God had afflicted his enemies with most

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: grievous punishments; and wherein Josias had burnt the Priests of Moloch

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: upon their own Altars, as appeareth at large in the 2 of Kings chap. 23.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the place served afterwards, to receive the filth, and garbage which was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: carried thither, out of the City; and there used to be fires made, from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: time to time, to purifie the aire, and take away the stench of Carrion.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: From this abominable place, the Jews used ever after to call the place

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Damned, by the name of Gehenna, or Valley of Hinnon. And this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Gehenna, is that word, which is usually now translated HELL; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from the fires from time to time there burning, we have the notion of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Everlasting, and Unquenchable Fire.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of The Literall Sense Of The Scripture Concerning Hell

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Seeing now there is none, that so interprets the Scripture, as that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: after the day of Judgment, the wicked are all Eternally to be punished

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the Valley of Hinnon; or that they shall so rise again, as to be ever

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: after under ground, or under water; or that after the Resurrection, they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shall no more see one another; nor stir from one place to another; it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: followeth, me thinks, very necessarily, that that which is thus said

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: concerning Hell Fire, is spoken metaphorically; and that therefore there

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is a proper sense to bee enquired after, (for of all Metaphors there is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: some reall ground, that may be expressed in proper words) both of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Place of Hell, and the nature of Hellish Torment, and Tormenters.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Satan, Devill, Not Proper Names, But Appellatives

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And first for the Tormenters, wee have their nature, and properties,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: exactly and properly delivered by the names of, The Enemy, or Satan;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Accuser, or Diabolus; The Destroyer, or Abbadon. Which significant

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: names, Satan, Devill, Abbadon, set not forth to us any Individuall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: person, as proper names use to doe; but onely an office, or quality;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and are therefore Appellatives; which ought not to have been left

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: untranslated, as they are, in the Latine, and Modern Bibles; because

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thereby they seem to be the proper names of Daemons; and men are the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: more easily seduced to beleeve the doctrine of Devills; which at that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: time was the Religion of the Gentiles, and contrary to that of Moses,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and of Christ.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And because by the Enemy, the Accuser, and Destroyer, is meant, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Enemy of them that shall be in the Kingdome of God; therefore if the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kingdome of God after the Resurrection, bee upon the Earth, (as in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: former Chapter I have shewn by Scripture it seems to be,) The Enemy,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and his Kingdome must be on Earth also. For so also was it, in the time

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: before the Jews had deposed God. For Gods Kingdome was in Palestine;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and the Nations round about, were the Kingdomes of the Enemy; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consequently by Satan, is meant any Earthly Enemy of the Church.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Torments Of Hell

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Torments of Hell, are expressed sometimes, by "weeping, and gnashing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of teeth," as Mat. 8.12. Sometimes, by "the worm of Conscience;" as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Isa.66.24. and Mark 9.44, 46, 48; sometimes, by Fire, as in the place

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: now quoted, "where the worm dyeth not, and the fire is not quenched,"

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and many places beside: sometimes by "Shame, and contempt," as Dan.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 12.2. "And many of them that sleep in the dust of the Earth, shall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: awake; some to Everlasting life; and some to shame, and everlasting

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: contempt." All which places design metaphorically a grief, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: discontent of mind, from the sight of that Eternall felicity in others,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which they themselves through their own incredulity, and disobedience

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have lost. And because such felicity in others, is not sensible but by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: comparison with their own actuall miseries; it followeth that they are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to suffer such bodily paines, and calamities, as are incident to those,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: who not onely live under evill and cruell Governours, but have also for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Enemy, the Eternall King of the Saints, God Almighty. And amongst these

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: bodily paines, is to be reckoned also to every one of the wicked a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: second Death. For though the Scripture bee clear for an universall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Resurrection; yet wee do not read, that to any of the Reprobate is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: promised an Eternall life. For whereas St. Paul (1 Cor. 15.42, 43.) to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the question concerning what bodies men shall rise with again, saith,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that "the body is sown in corruption, and is raised in incorruption; It

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is sown in dishonour, it is raised in glory; it is sown in weaknesse, it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is raised in power;" Glory and Power cannot be applyed to the bodies of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the wicked: Nor can the name of Second Death, bee applyed to those

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that can never die but once: And although in Metaphoricall speech, a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Calamitous life Everlasting, may bee called an Everlasting Death yet it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: cannot well be understood of a Second Death. The fire prepared for the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: wicked, is an Everlasting Fire: that is to say, the estate wherein

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: no man can be without torture, both of body and mind, after the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Resurrection, shall endure for ever; and in that sense the Fire shall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be unquenchable, and the torments Everlasting: but it cannot thence be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: inferred, that hee who shall be cast into that fire, or be tormented

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with those torments, shall endure, and resist them so, as to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: eternally burnt, and tortured, and yet never be destroyed, nor die. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: though there be many places that affirm Everlasting Fire, and Torments

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (into which men may be cast successively one after another for ever;)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: yet I find none that affirm there shall bee an Eternall Life therein of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: any individuall person; but on the contrary, an Everlasting Death, which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is the Second Death: (Apoc. 20. 13,14.) "For after Death, and the Grave

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shall have delivered up the dead which were in them, and every man be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: judged according to his works; Death and the Grave shall also be cast

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: into the Lake of Fire. This is the Second Death." Whereby it is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: evident, that there is to bee a Second Death of every one that shall bee

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: condemned at the day of Judgement, after which hee shall die no more.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Joyes Of Life Eternall, And Salvation The Same Thing,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Salvation From Sin, And From Misery, All One

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The joyes of Life Eternall, are in Scripture comprehended all under the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: name of SALVATION, or Being Saved. To be saved, is to be secured, either

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: respectively, against speciall Evills, or absolutely against all Evill,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: comprehending Want, Sicknesse, and Death it self. And because man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was created in a condition Immortall, not subject to corruption, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consequently to nothing that tendeth to the dissolution of his nature;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and fell from that happinesse by the sin of Adam; it followeth, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to be Saved From Sin, is to be saved from all the Evill, and Calamities

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that Sinne hath brought upon us. And therefore in the Holy Scripture,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Remission of Sinne, and Salvation from Death and Misery, is the same

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thing, as it appears by the words of our Saviour, who having cured a man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sick of the Palsey, by saying, (Mat. 9.2.) "Son be of good cheer, thy

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sins be forgiven thee;" and knowing that the Scribes took for blasphemy,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that a man should pretend to forgive Sins, asked them (v.5.) "whether

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it were easier to say, Thy Sinnes be forgiven thee, or, Arise and walk;"

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: signifying thereby, that it was all one, as to the saving of the sick,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to say, "Thy Sins are forgiven," and "Arise and walk;" and that he used

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that form of speech, onely to shew he had power to forgive Sins. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it is besides evident in reason, that since Death and Misery, were the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: punishments of Sin, the discharge of Sinne, must also be a discharge

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Death and Misery; that is to say, Salvation absolute, such as the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: faithfull are to enjoy after the day of Judgment, by the power, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: favour of Jesus Christ, who for that cause is called our SAVIOUR.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Concerning Particular Salvations, such as are understood, 1 Sam. 14.39.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "as the Lord liveth that saveth Israel," that is, from their temporary

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: enemies, and 2 Sam. 22.4. "Thou art my Saviour, thou savest me from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: violence;" and 2 Kings 13.5. "God gave the Israelites a Saviour, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: so they were delivered from the hand of the Assyrians," and the like,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: I need say nothing; there being neither difficulty, nor interest, to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: corrupt the interpretation of texts of that kind.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Place Of Eternall Salvation

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But concerning the Generall Salvation, because it must be in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kingdome of Heaven, there is great difficulty concerning the Place.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: On one side, by Kingdome (which is an estate ordained by men for their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: perpetuall security against enemies, and want) it seemeth that this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Salvation should be on Earth. For by Salvation is set forth unto us,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a glorious Reign of our King, by Conquest; not a safety by Escape:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and therefore there where we look for Salvation, we must look also

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for Triumph; and before Triumph, for Victory; and before Victory, for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Battell; which cannot well be supposed, shall be in Heaven. But how good

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: soever this reason may be, I will not trust to it, without very evident

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: places of Scripture. The state of Salvation is described at large,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "Look upon Zion, the City of our solemnities, thine eyes shall see

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Jerusalem a quiet habitation, a tabernacle that shall not be taken down;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not one of the stakes thereof shall ever be removed, neither shall any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the cords thereof be broken.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But there the glorious Lord will be unto us a place of broad rivers, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: streams; wherein shall goe no Gally with oares; neither shall gallant

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ship passe thereby.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For the Lord is our Judge, the Lord is our Lawgiver, the Lord is our

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: King, he will save us.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Thy tacklings are loosed; they could not well strengthen their mast;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they could not spread the sail: then is the prey of a great spoil

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: divided; the lame take the prey.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And the Inhabitant shall not say, I am sicke; the people that shall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: dwell therein shall be forgiven their Iniquity."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In which words wee have the place from whence Salvation is to proceed,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "Jerusalem, a quiet habitation;" the Eternity of it, "a tabernacle that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shall not be taken down," &c. The Saviour of it, "the Lord, their Judge,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their Lawgiver, their King, he will save us;" the Salvation, "the Lord

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shall be to them as a broad mote of swift waters," &c. the condition of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their Enemies, "their tacklings are loose, their masts weake, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: lame shal take the spoil of them." The condition of the Saved,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "The Inhabitants shall not say, I am sick:" And lastly, all this is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: comprehended in Forgivenesse of sin, "The people that dwell therein

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shall be forgiven their iniquity." By which it is evident, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Salvation shall be on Earth, then, when God shall reign, (at the coming

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: again of Christ) in Jerusalem; and from Jerusalem shall proceed the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Salvation of the Gentiles that shall be received into Gods Kingdome; as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is also more expressely declared by the same Prophet, Chap. 66.20, 21.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "And they," (that is, the Gentiles who had any Jew in bondage) "shall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: bring all your brethren, for an offering to the Lord, out of all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: nations, upon horses, and in charets, and in litters, and upon mules,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and upon swift beasts, to my holy mountain, Jerusalem, saith the Lord,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as the Children of Israel bring an offering in a clean vessell into

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the House of the Lord. And I will also take of them for Priests and for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Levites, saith the Lord:" Whereby it is manifest, that the chief seat of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Gods Kingdome (which is the Place, from whence the Salvation of us that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: were Gentiles, shall proceed) shall be Jerusalem; And the same is also

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: confirmed by our Saviour, in his discourse with the woman of Samaria,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: concerning the place of Gods worship; to whom he saith, John 4.22. that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Samaritans worshipped they know not what, but the Jews worship what

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they knew, "For Salvation is of the Jews (Ex Judais, that is, begins at

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Jews): as if he should say, you worship God, but know not by whom

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he wil save you, as we doe, that know it shall be one of the tribe

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Judah, a Jew, not a Samaritan. And therefore also the woman not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: impertinently answered him again, "We know the Messias shall come." So

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that which our saviour saith, "Salvation is from the Jews," is the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: same that Paul sayes (Rom. 1.16,17.) "The Gospel is the power of God to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Salvation to every one that beleeveth; To the Jew first, and also to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Greek. For therein is the righteousnesse of God revealed from faith to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: faith;" from the faith of the Jew, to the faith of the Gentile. In

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the like sense the Prophet Joel describing the day of Judgment, (chap.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 2.30,31.) that God would "shew wonders in heaven, and in earth, bloud,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and fire, and pillars of smoak. The Sun should be turned to darknesse,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and the Moon into bloud, before the great and terrible day of the Lord

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: come," he addeth verse 32. "and it shall come to passe, that whosoever

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shall call upon the name of the Lord, shall be saved. For in Mount Zion,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and in Jerusalem shall be Salvation." And Obadiah verse 17 saith

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the same, "Upon Mount Zion shall be Deliverance; and there shall be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: holinesse, and the house of Jacob shall possesse their possessions,"

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that is, the possessions of the Heathen, which possessions he expresseth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: more particularly in the following verses, by the Mount of Esau, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Land of the Philistines, the Fields of Ephraim, of Samaria, Gilead, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Cities of the South, and concludes with these words, "the Kingdom

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shall be the Lords." All these places are for Salvation, and the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kingdome of God (after the day of Judgement) upon Earth. On the other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: side, I have not found any text that can probably be drawn, to prove

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: any Ascension of the Saints into Heaven; that is to say, into any Coelum

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Empyreum, or other aetheriall Region; saving that it is called the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kingdome of Heaven; which name it may have, because God, that was King

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Jews, governed them by his commands, sent to Moses by Angels from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Heaven, to reduce them to their obedience; and shall send him thence

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: again, to rule both them, and all other faithfull men, from the day of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Judgment, Everlastingly: or from that, that the Throne of this our Great

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: King is in Heaven; whereas the Earth is but his Footstoole. But that the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Subjects of God should have any place as high as his throne, or higher

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: than his Footstoole, it seemeth not sutable to the dignity of a King,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: nor can I find any evident text for it in holy Scripture.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: From this that hath been said of the Kingdom of God, and of Salvation,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it is not hard to interpret, what is meant by the WORLD TO COME. There

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are three worlds mentioned in Scripture, the Old World, the Present

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: World, and the World to Come. Of the first, St. Peter speaks, (2 Pet.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 2.5.) "If God spared not the Old World, but saved Noah the eighth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: person, a Preacher of righteousnesse, bringing the flood upon the world

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the ungodly," &c. So the First World, was from Adam to the generall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Flood. Of the present World, our Saviour speaks (John 18.36.) "My

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kingdome is not of this World." For he came onely to teach men the way

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Salvation, and to renew the Kingdome of his Father, by his doctrine.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of the World to come, St. Peter speaks, (2 Pet. 3. 13.) "Neverthelesse

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: we according to his promise look for new Heavens, and a new Earth." This

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is that WORLD, wherein Christ coming down from Heaven, in the clouds,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with great power, and glory, shall send his Angels, and shall gather

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: together his elect, from the four winds, and from the uttermost parts

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Earth, and thence forth reign over them, (under his Father)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Everlastingly.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Redemption

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Salvation of a sinner, supposeth a precedent REDEMPTION; for he that is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: once guilty of Sin, is obnoxious to the Penalty of the same; and must

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: pay (or some other for him) such Ransome, as he that is offended, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: has him in his power, shall require. And seeing the person offended, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Almighty God, in whose power are all things; such Ransome is to be paid

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: before Salvation can be acquired, as God hath been pleased to require.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: By this Ransome, is not intended a satisfaction for Sin, equivalent to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Offence, which no sinner for himselfe, nor righteous man can ever be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: able to make for another; The dammage a man does to another, he may make

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: amends for by restitution, or recompence, but sin cannot be taken

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: away by recompence; for that were to make the liberty to sin, a thing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: vendible. But sins may bee pardoned to the repentant, either Gratis, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: upon such penalty, as God is pleased to accept. That which God usually

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: accepted in the Old Testament, was some Sacrifice, or Oblation. To

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: forgive sin is not an act of Injustice, though the punishment have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: been threatned. Even amongst men, though the promise of Good, bind the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: promiser; yet threats, that is to say, promises, of Evill, bind them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not; much lesse shall they bind God, who is infinitely more mercifull

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: then men. Our Saviour Christ therefore to Redeem us, did not in that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sense satisfie for the Sins of men, as that his Death, of its own

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: vertue, could make it unjust in God to punish sinners with Eternall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: death; but did make that Sacrifice, and Oblation of himself, at his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: first coming, which God was pleased to require, for the Salvation at his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: second coming, of such as in the mean time should repent, and beleeve in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him. And though this act of our Redemption, be not alwaies in Scripture

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: called a Sacrifice, and Oblation, but sometimes a Price, yet by Price

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: we are not to understand any thing, by the value whereof, he could claim

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: right to a pardon for us, from his offended Father, but that Price which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: God the Father was pleased in mercy to demand.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CHAPTER XXXIX. OF THE SIGNIFICATION IN SCRIPTURE OF THE WORD CHURCH

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Church The Lords House

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The word Church, (Ecclesia) signifieth in the Books of Holy Scripture

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: divers things. Sometimes (though not often) it is taken for Gods House,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that is to say, for a Temple, wherein Christians assemble to perform

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: holy duties publiquely; as, 1 Cor. 14. ver. 34. "Let your women keep

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: silence in the Churches:" but this is Metaphorically put, for the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Congregation there assembled; and hath been since used for the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Edifice it self, to distinguish between the Temples of Christians, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Idolaters. The Temple of Jerusalem was Gods House, and the House of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Prayer; and so is any Edifice dedicated by Christians to the worship of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christ, Christs House: and therefore the Greek Fathers call it Kuriake,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Lords House; and thence, in our language it came to be called Kyrke,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Church.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ecclesia Properly What

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Church (when not taken for a House) signifieth the same that Ecclesia

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: signified in the Grecian Common-wealths; that is to say, a Congregation,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or an Assembly of Citizens, called forth, to hear the Magistrate speak

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: unto them; and which in the Common-wealth of Rome was called Concio, as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he that spake was called Ecclesiastes, and Concionator. And when they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: were called forth by lawfull Authority, (Acts 19.39.) it was Ecclesia

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Legitima, a Lawfull Church, Ennomos Ecclesia. But when they were excited

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by tumultuous, and seditious clamor, then it was a confused Church,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ecclesia Sugkechumene.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: It is taken also sometimes for the men that have right to be of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Congregation, though not actually assembled; that is to say, for the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whole multitude of Christian men, how far soever they be dispersed: as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (Act. 8.3.) where it is said, that "Saul made havock of the Church:" And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in this sense is Christ said to be Head of the Church. And sometimes for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a certain part of Christians, as (Col. 4.15.) "Salute the Church that is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in his house." Sometimes also for the Elect onely; as (Ephes. 5.27.) "A

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Glorious Church, without spot, or wrinkle, holy, and without blemish;"

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which is meant of the Church Triumphant, or, Church To Come. Sometimes,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for a Congregation assembled, of professors of Christianity, whether

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their profession be true, or counterfeit, as it is understood, Mat.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 18.17. where it is said, "Tell it to the Church, and if hee neglect to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hear the Church, let him be to thee as a Gentile, or Publican."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In What Sense The Church Is One Person Church Defined

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And in this last sense only it is that the Church can be taken for one

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Person; that is to say, that it can be said to have power to will, to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: pronounce, to command, to be obeyed, to make laws, or to doe any other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: action whatsoever; For without authority from a lawfull Congregation,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whatsoever act be done in a concourse of people, it is the particular

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: act of every one of those that were present, and gave their aid to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: performance of it; and not the act of them all in grosse, as of one

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: body; much lesse that act of them that were absent, or that being

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: present, were not willing it should be done. According to this sense, I

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: define a CHURCH to be, "A company of men professing Christian Religion,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: united in the person of one Soveraign; at whose command they ought to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: assemble, and without whose authority they ought not to assemble." And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: because in all Common-wealths, that Assembly, which is without warrant

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from the Civil Soveraign, is unlawful; that Church also, which is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: assembled in any Common-wealth, that hath forbidden them to assemble, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: an unlawfull Assembly.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: A Christian Common-wealth, And A Church All One

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: It followeth also, that there is on Earth, no such universall Church as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all Christians are bound to obey; because there is no power on Earth, to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which all other Common-wealths are subject: There are Christians, in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Dominions of severall Princes and States; but every one of them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is subject to that Common-wealth, whereof he is himself a member; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consequently, cannot be subject to the commands of any other Person.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And therefore a Church, such as one as is capable to Command, to Judge,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Absolve, Condemn, or do any other act, is the same thing with a Civil

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth, consisting of Christian men; and is called a Civill

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: State, for that the subjects of it are Men; and a Church, for that the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: subjects thereof are Christians. Temporall and Spirituall Government,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are but two words brought into the world, to make men see double, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: mistake their Lawfull Soveraign. It is true, that the bodies of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: faithfull, after the Resurrection shall be not onely Spirituall, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Eternall; but in this life they are grosse, and corruptible. There

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is therefore no other Government in this life, neither of State, nor

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Religion, but Temporall; nor teaching of any doctrine, lawfull to any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Subject, which the Governour both of the State, and of the Religion,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: forbiddeth to be taught: And that Governor must be one; or else there

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: must needs follow Faction, and Civil war in the Common-wealth, between

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Church and State; between Spiritualists, and Temporalists; between

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Sword Of Justice, and the Shield Of Faith; and (which is more) in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: every Christian mans own brest, between the Christian, and the Man.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Doctors of the Church, are called Pastors; so also are Civill

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraignes: But if Pastors be not subordinate one to another, so

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as that there may bee one chief Pastor, men will be taught contrary

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Doctrines, whereof both may be, and one must be false. Who that one

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: chief Pastor is, according to the law of Nature, hath been already

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shewn; namely, that it is the Civill Soveraign; And to whom the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Scripture hath assigned that Office, we shall see in the Chapters

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: following.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CHAPTER XL

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: OF THE RIGHTS OF THE KINGDOME OF GOD, IN ABRAHAM, MOSES, HIGH PRIESTS,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: AND THE KINGS OF JUDAH

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Soveraign Rights Of Abraham

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Father of the Faithfull, and first in the Kingdome of God by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Covenant, was Abraham. For with him was the Covenant first made; wherein

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he obliged himself, and his seed after him, to acknowledge and obey the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: commands of God; not onely such, as he could take notice of, (as Morall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Laws,) by the light of Nature; but also such, as God should in speciall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: manner deliver to him by Dreams and Visions. For as to the Morall law,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they were already obliged, and needed not have been contracted withall,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by promise of the Land of Canaan. Nor was there any Contract, that could

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: adde to, or strengthen the Obligation, by which both they, and all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: men else were bound naturally to obey God Almighty: And therefore the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Covenant which Abraham made with God, was to take for the Commandement

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of God, that which in the name of God was commanded him, in a Dream, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Vision, and to deliver it to his family, and cause them to observe the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: same.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Abraham Had The Sole Power Of Ordering The Religion Of His Own People

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In this Contract of God with Abraham, wee may observe three points of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: important consequence in the government of Gods people. First, that at

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the making of this Covenant, God spake onely to Abraham; and therefore

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: contracted not with any of his family, or seed, otherwise then as their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: wills (which make the essence of all Covenants) were before the Contract

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: involved in the will of Abraham; who was therefore supposed to have had

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a lawfull power, to make them perform all that he covenanted for them.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: According whereunto (Gen 18.18, 19.) God saith, "All the Nations of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Earth shall be blessed in him, For I know him that he will command his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: children and his houshold after him, and they shall keep the way of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lord." From whence may be concluded this first point, that they to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whom God hath not spoken immediately, are to receive the positive

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: commandements of God, from their Soveraign; as the family and seed of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Abraham did from Abraham their Father, and Lord, and Civill Soveraign.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And Consequently in every Common-wealth, they who have no supernaturall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Revelation to the contrary, ought to obey the laws of their own

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign, in the externall acts and profession of Religion. As for the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: inward Thought, and beleef of men, which humane Governours can take no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: notice of, (for God onely knoweth the heart) they are not voluntary, nor

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the effect of the laws, but of the unrevealed will, and of the power of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: God; and consequently fall not under obligation.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: No Pretence Of Private Spirit Against The Religion Of Abraham

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: From whence proceedeth another point, that it was not unlawfull for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Abraham, when any of his Subjects should pretend Private Vision, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Spirit, or other Revelation from God, for the countenancing of any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: doctrine which Abraham should forbid, or when they followed, or adhered

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to any such pretender, to punish them; and consequently that it is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: lawfull now for the Soveraign to punish any man that shall oppose his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Private Spirit against the Laws: For hee hath the same place in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth, that Abraham had in his own Family.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Abraham Sole Judge, And Interpreter Of What God Spake

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: There ariseth also from the same, a third point; that as none but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Abraham in his family, so none but the Soveraign in a Christian

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth, can take notice what is, or what is not the Word of God.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For God spake onely to Abraham; and it was he onely, that was able

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to know what God said, and to interpret the same to his family: And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore also, they that have the place of Abraham in a Common-wealth,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are the onely Interpreters of what God hath spoken.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Authority Of Moses Whereon Grounded

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The same Covenant was renewed with Isaac; and afterwards with Jacob; but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: afterwards no more, till the Israelites were freed from the Egyptians,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and arrived at the Foot of Mount Sinai: and then it was renewed by Moses

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (as I have said before, chap. 35.) in such manner, as they became from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that time forward the Peculiar Kingdome of God; whose Lieutenant was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Moses, for his owne time; and the succession to that office was setled

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: upon Aaron, and his heirs after him, to bee to God a Sacerdotall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kingdome for ever.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: By this constitution, a Kingdome is acquired to God. But seeing Moses

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: had no authority to govern the Israelites, as a successor to the right

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Abraham, because he could not claim it by inheritance; it appeareth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not as yet, that the people were obliged to take him for Gods

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lieutenant, longer than they beleeved that God spake unto him. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore his authority (notwithstanding the Covenant they made with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: God) depended yet merely upon the opinion they had of his Sanctity,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and of the reality of his Conferences with God, and the verity of his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Miracles; which opinion coming to change, they were no more obliged to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: take any thing for the law of God, which he propounded to them in Gods

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: name. We are therefore to consider, what other ground there was, of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their obligation to obey him. For it could not be the commandement of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: God that could oblige them; because God spake not to them immediately,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but by the mediation of Moses Himself; And our Saviour saith of himself,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (John 5. 31.) "If I bear witnesse of my self, my witnesse is not true,"

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: much lesse if Moses bear witnesse of himselfe, (especially in a claim of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kingly power over Gods people) ought his testimony to be received. His

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: authority therefore, as the authority of all other Princes, must be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: grounded on the Consent of the People, and their Promise to obey him.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And so it was: for "the people" (Exod. 20.18.) "when they saw the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Thunderings, and the Lightnings, and the noyse of the Trumpet, and the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: mountaine smoaking, removed, and stood a far off. And they said unto

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Moses, speak thou with us, and we will hear, but let not God speak with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: us lest we die." Here was their promise of obedience; and by this it was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they obliged themselves to obey whatsoever he should deliver unto them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for the Commandement of God.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Moses Was (Under God) Soveraign Of The Jews, All His Own Time,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Though Aaron Had The Priesthood

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And notwithstanding the Covenant constituted a Sacerdotall Kingdome,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that is to say, a Kingdome hereditary to Aaron; yet that is to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: understood of the succession, after Moses should bee dead. For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whosoever ordereth, and establisheth the Policy, as first founder of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Common-wealth (be it Monarchy, Aristocracy, or Democracy) must needs

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have Soveraign Power over the people all the while he is doing of it.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And that Moses had that power all his own time, is evidently affirmed in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Scripture. First, in the text last before cited, because the people

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: promised obedience, not to Aaron but to him. Secondly, (Exod. 24.1, 2.)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "And God said unto Moses, Come up unto the Lord, thou, and Aaron, Nadab

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Abihu, and seventy of the Elders of Israel. And Moses alone shall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: come neer the Lord, but they shall not come nigh, neither shall the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: people goe up with him." By which it is plain, that Moses who was alone

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: called up to God, (and not Aaron, nor the other Priests, nor the Seventy

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Elders, nor the People who were forbidden to come up) was alone he, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: represented to the Israelites the Person of God; that is to say, was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their sole Soveraign under God. And though afterwards it be said (verse

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 9.) "Then went up Moses, and Aaron, Nadab, and Abihu, and seventy of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Elders of Israel, and they saw the God of Israel, and there was under

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his feet, as it were a paved work of a saphire stone," &c. yet this was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not till after Moses had been with God before, and had brought to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the people the words which God had said to him. He onely went for the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: businesse of the people; the others, as the Nobles of his retinue, were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: admitted for honour to that speciall grace, which was not allowed to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the people; which was, (as in the verse after appeareth) to see God and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: live. "God laid not his hand upon them, they saw God and did eat and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: drink" (that is, did live), but did not carry any commandement from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him to the people. Again, it is every where said, "The Lord spake unto

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Moses," as in all other occasions of Government; so also in the ordering

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Ceremonies of Religion, contained in the 25, 26, 27, 28, 29, 30,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and 31 Chapters of Exodus, and throughout Leviticus: to Aaron seldome.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Calfe that Aaron made, Moses threw into the fire. Lastly, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: question of the Authority of Aaron, by occasion of his and Miriams

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: mutiny against Moses, was (Numbers 12.) judged by God himself for Moses.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: So also in the question between Moses, and the People, when Corah,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Dathan, and Abiram, and two hundred and fifty Princes of the Assembly

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "gathered themselves together" (Numbers 16. 3) "against Moses, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: against Aaron, and said unto them, 'Ye take too much upon you, seeing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all the congregation are Holy, every one of them, and the Lord is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: amongst them, why lift you up your selves above the congregation of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lord?'" God caused the Earth to swallow Corah, Dathan, and Abiram with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their wives and children alive, and consumed those two hundred and fifty

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Princes with fire. Therefore neither Aaron, nor the People, nor any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Aristocracy of the chief Princes of the People, but Moses alone had next

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: under God the Soveraignty over the Israelites: And that not onely in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: causes of Civill Policy, but also of Religion; For Moses onely spake

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with God, and therefore onely could tell the People, what it was that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: God required at their hands. No man upon pain of death might be so

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: presumptuous as to approach the Mountain where God talked with Moses.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "Thou shalt set bounds" (saith the Lord, Exod 19. 12.) "to the people

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: round about, and say, Take heed to your selves that you goe not up into

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Mount, or touch the border of it; whosoever toucheth the Mount shall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: surely be put to death." and again (verse 21.) "Get down, charge the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: people, lest they break through unto the Lord to gaze." Out of which we

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: may conclude, that whosoever in a Christian Common-wealth holdeth the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: place of Moses, is the sole Messenger of God, and Interpreter of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his Commandements. And according hereunto, no man ought in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: interpretation of the Scripture to proceed further then the bounds which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are set by their severall Soveraigns. For the Scriptures since God now

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: speaketh in them, are the Mount Sinai; the bounds whereof are the Laws

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of them that represent Gods Person on Earth. To look upon them and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therein to behold the wondrous works of God, and learn to fear him is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: allowed; but to interpret them; that is, to pry into what God saith to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him whom he appointeth to govern under him, and make themselves Judges

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whether he govern as God commandeth him, or not, is to transgresse the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: bounds God hath set us, and to gaze upon God irreverently.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: All Spirits Were Subordinate To The Spirit Of Moses

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: There was no Prophet in the time of Moses, nor pretender to the Spirit

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of God, but such as Moses had approved, and Authorized. For there were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in his time but Seventy men, that are said to Prophecy by the Spirit of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: God, and these were of all Moses his election; concerning whom God saith

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to Moses (Numb. 11.16.) "Gather to mee Seventy of the Elders of Israel,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whom thou knowest to be the Elders of the People." To these God imparted

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his Spirit; but it was not a different Spirit from that of Moses; for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it is said (verse 25.) "God came down in a cloud, and took of the Spirit

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that was upon Moses, and gave it to the Seventy Elders." But as I have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shewn before (chap. 36.) by Spirit, is understood the Mind; so that the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sense of the place is no other than this, that God endued them with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a mind conformable, and subordinate to that of Moses, that they might

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Prophecy, that is to say, speak to the people in Gods name, in such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: manner, as to set forward (as Ministers of Moses, and by his authority)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such doctrine as was agreeable to Moses his doctrine. For they were but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ministers; and when two of them Prophecyed in the Camp, it was thought

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a new and unlawfull thing; and as it is in the 27. and 28. verses of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the same Chapter, they were accused of it, and Joshua advised Moses to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: forbid them, as not knowing that it was by Moses his Spirit that they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Prophecyed. By which it is manifest, that no Subject ought to pretend to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Prophecy, or to the Spirit, in opposition to the doctrine established by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him, whom God hath set in the place of Moses.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: After Moses The Soveraignty Was In The High Priest

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Aaron being dead, and after him also Moses, the Kingdome, as being a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sacerdotall Kingdome, descended by vertue of the Covenant, to Aarons

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Son, Eleazar the High Priest: And God declared him (next under himself)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for Soveraign, at the same time that he appointed Joshua for the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Generall of their Army. For thus God saith expressely (Numb. 27.21.)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: concerning Joshua; "He shall stand before Eleazar the Priest, who shall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ask counsell for him, before the Lord, at his word shall they goe out,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and at his word they shall come in, both he, and all the Children of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Israel with him:" Therefore the Supreme Power of making War and Peace,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was in the Priest. The Supreme Power of Judicature belonged also to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the High Priest: For the Book of the Law was in their keeping; and the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Priests and Levites onely were the subordinate Judges in causes Civill,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as appears in Deut. 17.8, 9, 10. And for the manner of Gods worship,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there was never doubt made, but that the High Priest till the time

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Saul, had the Supreme Authority. Therefore the Civill and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ecclesiasticall Power were both joined together in one and the same

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: person, the High Priest; and ought to bee so, in whosoever governeth by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Divine Right; that is, by Authority immediate from God.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of The Soveraign Power Between The Time Of Joshua And Of Saul

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: After the death of Joshua, till the time of Saul, the time between is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: noted frequently in the Book of Judges, "that there was in those dayes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: no King in Israel;" and sometimes with this addition, that "every

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man did that which was right in his own eyes." By which is to bee

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: understood, that where it is said, "there was no King," is meant, "there

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was no Soveraign Power" in Israel. And so it was, if we consider the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Act, and Exercise of such power. For after the death of Joshua, &

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Eleazar, "there arose another generation" (Judges 2.10.) "that knew not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Lord, nor the works which he had done for Israel, but did evill in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the sight of the Lord, and served Baalim." And the Jews had that quality

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which St. Paul noteth, "to look for a sign," not onely before they would

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: submit themselves to the government of Moses, but also after they had

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: obliged themselves by their submission. Whereas Signs, and Miracles had

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for End to procure Faith, not to keep men from violating it, when they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have once given it; for to that men are obliged by the law of Nature.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But if we consider not the Exercise, but the Right of governing, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign power was still in the High Priest. Therefore whatsoever

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: obedience was yeelded to any of the Judges, (who were men chosen by God

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: extraordinarily, to save his rebellious subjects out of the hands of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the enemy,) it cannot bee drawn into argument against the Right the High

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Priest had to the Soveraign Power, in all matters, both of Policy and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Religion. And neither the Judges, nor Samuel himselfe had an ordinary,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but extraordinary calling to the Government; and were obeyed by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Israelites, not out of duty, but out of reverence to their favour

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with God, appearing in their wisdome, courage, or felicity. Hitherto

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore the Right of Regulating both the Policy, and the Religion,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: were inseparable.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of The Rights Of The Kings Of Israel

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To the Judges, succeeded Kings; And whereas before, all authority, both

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in Religion, and Policy, was in the High Priest; so now it was all in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the King. For the Soveraignty over the people, which was before, not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: onely by vertue of the Divine Power, but also by a particular pact of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Israelites in God, and next under him, in the High Priest, as his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Viceregent on earth, was cast off by the People, with the consent of God

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: himselfe. For when they said to Samuel (1 Sam. 8.5.) "make us a King to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: judge us, like all the Nations," they signified that they would no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: more bee governed by the commands that should bee laid upon them by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Priest, in the name of God; but by one that should command them in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: same manner that all other nations were commanded; and consequently in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: deposing the High Priest of Royall authority, they deposed that peculiar

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Government of God. And yet God consented to it, saying to Samuel (verse

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 7.) "Hearken unto the voice of the People, in all that they shall say

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: unto thee; for they have not rejected thee, but they have rejected mee,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that I should not reign over them." Having therefore rejected God, in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whose Right the Priests governed, there was no authority left to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Priests, but such as the King was pleased to allow them; which was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: more, or lesse, according as the Kings were good, or evill. And for the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Government of Civill affaires, it is manifest, it was all in the hands

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the King. For in the same Chapter, verse 20. They say they will be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: like all the Nations; that their King shall be their Judge, and goe

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: before them, and fight their battells; that is, he shall have the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whole authority, both in Peace and War. In which is contained also the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ordering of Religion; for there was no other Word of God in that time,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by which to regulate Religion, but the Law of Moses, which was their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Civill Law. Besides, we read (1 Kings 2.27.) that Solomon "thrust out

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Abiathar from being Priest before the Lord:" He had therefore authority

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: over the High Priest, as over any other Subject; which is a great

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: mark of Supremacy in Religion. And we read also (1 Kings 8.) that hee

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: dedicated the Temple; that he blessed the People; and that he himselfe

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in person made that excellent prayer, used in the Consecrations of all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Churches, and houses of Prayer; which is another great mark of Supremacy

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in Religion. Again, we read (2 Kings 22.) that when there was question

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: concerning the Book of the Law found in the Temple, the same was not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: decided by the High Priest, but Josiah sent both him, and others to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: enquire concerning it, of Hulda, the Prophetesse; which is another mark

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Supremacy in Religion. Lastly, wee read (1 Chro. 26.30.) that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: David made Hashabiah and his brethren, Hebronites, Officers of Israel

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: among them Westward, "in all businesse of the Lord, and in the service

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the King." Likewise (verse 32.) that hee made other Hebronites,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "rulers over the Reubenites, the Gadites, and the halfe tribe of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Manasseh" (these were the rest of Israel that dwelt beyond Jordan) "for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: every matter pertaining to God, and affairs of the King." Is not this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: full Power, both Temporall and Spirituall, as they call it, that would

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: divide it? To conclude; from the first institution of Gods Kingdome, to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Captivity, the Supremacy of Religion, was in the same hand with that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Civill Soveraignty; and the Priests office after the election of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Saul, was not Magisteriall, but Ministeriall.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Practice Of Supremacy In Religion, Was Not In The Time Of The Kings,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: According To The Right Thereof

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Notwithstanding the government both in Policy and Religion, were joined,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: first in the High Priests, and afterwards in the Kings, so far forth as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: concerned the Right; yet it appeareth by the same Holy History, that the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: people understood it not; but there being amongst them a great part, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: probably the greatest part, that no longer than they saw great miracles,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or (which is equivalent to a miracle) great abilities, or great felicity

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the enterprises of their Governours, gave sufficient credit, either

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to the fame of Moses, or to the Colloquies between God and the Priests;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they took occasion as oft as their Governours displeased them, by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: blaming sometimes the Policy, sometimes the Religion, to change the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Government, or revolt from their Obedience at their pleasure: And from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thence proceeded from time to time the civill troubles, divisions, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: calamities of the Nation. As for example, after the death of Eleazar and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Joshua, the next generation which had not seen the wonders of God, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: were left to their own weak reason, not knowing themselves obliged

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by the Covenant of a Sacerdotall Kingdome, regarded no more the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Commandement of the Priest, nor any law of Moses, but did every man that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which was right in his own eyes; and obeyed in Civill affairs, such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: men, as from time to time they thought able to deliver them from the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: neighbour Nations that oppressed them; and consulted not with God (as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they ought to doe,) but with such men, or women, as they guessed to bee

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Prophets by their Praedictions of things to come; and thought they had

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: an Idol in their Chappel, yet if they had a Levite for their Chaplain,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they made account they worshipped the God of Israel.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And afterwards when they demanded a King, after the manner of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: nations; yet it was not with a design to depart from the worship of God

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their King; but despairing of the justice of the sons of Samuel, they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: would have a King to judg them in Civill actions; but not that they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: would allow their King to change the Religion which they thought was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: recommended to them by Moses. So that they alwaies kept in store a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: pretext, either of Justice, or Religion, to discharge themselves of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their obedience, whensoever they had hope to prevaile. Samuel was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: displeased with the people, for that they desired a King, (for God was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their King already, and Samuel had but an authority under him); yet did

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Samuel, when Saul observed not his counsell, in destroying Agag as God

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: had commanded, anoint another King, namely David, to take the succession

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from his heirs. Rehoboam was no Idolater; but when the people thought

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him an Oppressor; that Civil pretence carried from him ten Tribes to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Jeroboam an Idolater. And generally through the whole History of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kings, as well of Judah, as of Israel, there were Prophets that alwaies

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: controlled the Kings, for transgressing the Religion; and sometimes also

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for Errours of State; (2 Chro. 19. 2.) as Jehosaphat was reproved by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Prophet Jehu, for aiding the King of Israel against the Syrians;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Hezekiah, by Isaiah, for shewing his treasures to the Ambassadors of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Babylon. By all which it appeareth, that though the power both of State

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Religion were in the Kings; yet none of them were uncontrolled

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the use of it, but such as were gracious for their own naturall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: abilities, or felicities. So that from the practise of those times,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there can no argument be drawn, that the right of Supremacy in Religion

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was not in the Kings, unlesse we place it in the Prophets; and conclude,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that because Hezekiah praying to the Lord before the Cherubins, was not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: answered from thence, nor then, but afterwards by the Prophet Isaiah,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore Isaiah was supreme Head of the Church; or because Josiah

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consulted Hulda the Prophetesse, concerning the Book of the Law, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore neither he, nor the High Priest, but Hulda the Prophetesse had

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Supreme authority in matter of Religion; which I thinke is not the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: opinion of any Doctor.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: After The Captivity The Jews Had No Setled Common-wealth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: During the Captivity, the Jews had no Common-wealth at all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And after their return, though they renewed their Covenant with God, yet

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there was no promise made of obedience, neither to Esdras, nor to any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other; And presently after they became subjects to the Greeks (from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whose Customes, and Daemonology, and from the doctrine of the Cabalists,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their Religion became much corrupted): In such sort as nothing can be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: gathered from their confusion, both in State and Religion, concerning

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Supremacy in either. And therefore so far forth as concerneth the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Old Testament, we may conclude, that whosoever had the Soveraignty

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Common-wealth amongst the Jews, the same had also the Supreme

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Authority in matter of Gods externall worship; and represented Gods

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Person; that is the person of God the Father; though he were not called

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by the name of Father, till such time as he sent into the world his Son

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Jesus Christ, to redeem mankind from their sins, and bring them into his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Everlasting Kingdome, to be saved for evermore. Of which we are to speak

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the Chapter following.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CHAPTER XLI. OF THE OFFICE OF OUR BLESSED SAVIOUR

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Three Parts Of The Office Of Christ

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: We find in Holy Scripture three parts of the Office of the Messiah: the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: first of a Redeemer, or Saviour: The second of a Pastor, Counsellour,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or Teacher, that is, of a Prophet sent from God, to convert such as God

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hath elected to Salvation; The third of a King, and Eternall King, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: under his Father, as Moses and the High Priests were in their severall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: times. And to these three parts are corespondent three times. For our

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Redemption he wrought at his first coming, by the Sacrifice, wherein

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he offered up himself for our sinnes upon the Crosse: our conversion

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he wrought partly then in his own Person; and partly worketh now by his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ministers; and will continue to work till his coming again. And after

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his coming again, shall begin that his glorious Reign over his elect,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which is to last eternally.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: His Office As A Redeemer

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To the Office of a Redeemer, that is, of one that payeth the Ransome of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sin, (which Ransome is Death,) it appertaineth, that he was Sacrificed,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and thereby bare upon his own head, and carryed away from us our

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: iniquities, in such sort as God had required. Not that the death of one

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man, though without sinne, can satisfie for the offences of all men,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the rigour of Justice, but in the Mercy of God, that ordained such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sacrifices for sin, as he was pleased in his mercy to accept. In the old

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Law (as we may read, Leviticus the 16.) the Lord required, that there

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: should every year once, bee made an Atonement for the Sins of all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Israel, both Priests, and others; for the doing whereof, Aaron alone was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to sacrifice for himself and the Priests a young Bullock; and for the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: rest of the people, he was to receive from them two young Goates, of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which he was to Sacrifice one; but as for the other, which was the Scape

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Goat, he was to lay his hands on the head thereof, and by a confession

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the iniquities of the people, to lay them all on that head, and then

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by some opportune man, to cause the Goat to be led into the wildernesse,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and there to Escape, and carry away with him the iniquities of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: people. As the Sacrifice of the one Goat was a sufficient (because an

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: acceptable) price for the Ransome of all Israel; so the death of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Messiah, is a sufficient price, for the Sins of all mankind, because

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there was no more required. Our Saviour Christs sufferings seem to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: here figured, as cleerly, as in the oblation of Isaac, or in any other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: type of him in the Old Testament: He was both the sacrificed Goat, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Scape Goat; "Hee was oppressed, and he was afflicted (Isa. 53.7.);

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he opened not his mouth; he brought as a lamb to the slaughter, and as a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sheep is dumbe before the shearer, so opened he not his mouth:" Here he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is the Sacrificed Goat. "He hath born our Griefs, (ver.4.) and carried

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: our sorrows;" And again, (ver. 6.) "the Lord hath laid upon him the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: iniquities of us all:" And so he is the Scape Goat. "He was cut off from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the land of the living (ver. 8.) for the transgression of my People:"

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: There again he is the Sacrificed Goat. And again (ver. 11.) "he shall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: bear their sins:" Hee is the Scape Goat. Thus is the Lamb of God

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: equivalent to both those Goates; sacrificed, in that he dyed; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: escaping, in his Resurrection; being raised opportunely by his Father,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and removed from the habitation of men in his Ascension.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christs Kingdome Not Of This World

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For as much therefore, as he that Redeemeth, hath no title to the Thing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Redeemed, before the Redemption, and Ransome paid; and this Ransome was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Death of the Redeemer; it is manifest, that our Saviour (as man) was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not King of those that he Redeemed, before hee suffered death; that is,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: during that time hee conversed bodily on the Earth. I say, he was not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: then King in present, by vertue of the Pact, which the faithfull make

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with him in Baptisme; Neverthelesse, by the renewing of their Pact with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: God in Baptisme, they were obliged to obey him for King, (under his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Father) whensoever he should be pleased to take the Kingdome upon him.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: According whereunto, our Saviour himself expressely saith, (John 18.36.)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "My Kingdome is not of this world." Now seeing the Scripture maketh

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: mention but of two worlds; this that is now, and shall remain to the day

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Judgment, (which is therefore also called, The Last Day;) and that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which shall bee a new Heaven, and a new Earth; the Kingdome of Christ

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is not to begin till the general Resurrection. And that is it which our

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Saviour saith, (Mat. 16.27.) "The Son of man shall come in the glory

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of his Father, with his Angels; and then he shall reward every man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: according to his works." To reward every man according to his works, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to execute the Office of a King; and this is not to be till he come in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the glory of his Father, with his Angells. When our Saviour saith,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (Mat. 23.2.) "The Scribes and Pharisees sit in Moses seat; All therefore

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whatsoever they bid you doe, that observe and doe;" hee declareth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: plainly, that hee ascribeth Kingly Power, for that time, not to

author: Thomas Hobbes
