text: himselfe, but to them. And so hee hath also, where he saith, (Luke

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 12.14.) "Who made mee a Judge, or Divider over you?" And (John 12.47.)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "I came not to judge the world, but to save the world." And yet our

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Saviour came into this world that hee might bee a King, and a Judge in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the world to come: For hee was the Messiah, that is, the Christ, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is, the Anointed Priest, and the Soveraign Prophet of God; that is to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: say, he was to have all the power that was in Moses the Prophet, in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: High Priests that succeeded Moses, and in the Kings that succeeded the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Priests. And St. John saies expressely (chap. 5. ver. 22.) "The Father

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: judgeth no man, but hath committed all judgment to the Son." And this is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not repugnant to that other place, "I came not to judge the world:" for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: this is spoken of the world present, the other of the world to come; as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: also where it is said, that at the second coming of Christ, (Mat. 19.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 28.) "Yee that have followed me in the Regeneration, when the Son of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man shall sit in the throne of his Glory, yee shall also sit on twelve

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thrones, judging the twelve tribes of Israel."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The End Of Christs Comming Was To Renew The Covenant Of The Kingdome

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of God, And To Perswade The Elect To Imbrace It, Which Was The Second

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Part Of His Office

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: If then Christ while hee was on Earth, had no Kingdome in this World,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to what end was his first coming? It was to restore unto God, by a new

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Covenant, the Kingdome, which being his by the Old Covenant, had been

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: cut off by the rebellion of the Israelites in the election of Saul.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Which to doe, he was to preach unto them, that he was the Messiah, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is, the King promised to them by the Prophets; and to offer himselfe in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sacrifice for the sinnes of them that should by faith submit themselves

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thereto; and in case the nation generally should refuse him, to call

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to his obedience such as should beleeve in him amongst the Gentiles. So

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that there are two parts of our Saviours Office during his aboad upon

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Earth; One to Proclaim himself the Christ; and another by Teaching,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and by working of Miracles, to perswade, and prepare men to live so, as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to be worthy of the Immortality Beleevers were to enjoy, at such time as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he should come in majesty, to take possession of his Fathers Kingdome.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And therefore it is, that the time of his preaching, is often by himself

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: called the Regeneration; which is not properly a Kingdome, and thereby

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a warrant to deny obedience to the Magistrates that then were, (for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hee commanded to obey those that sate then in Moses chaire, and to pay

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: tribute to Caesar;) but onely an earnest of the Kingdome of God that was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to come, to those to whom God had given the grace to be his disciples,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and to beleeve in him; For which cause the Godly are said to bee already

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the Kingdome of Grace, as naturalized in that heavenly Kingdome.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Preaching Of Christ Not Contrary To The Then Law Of The Jews,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nor Of Caesar

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Hitherto therefore there is nothing done, or taught by Christ, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: tendeth to the diminution of the Civill Right of the Jewes, or of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Caesar. For as touching the Common-wealth which then was amongst

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Jews, both they that bare rule amongst them, that they that were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: governed, did all expect the Messiah, and Kingdome of God; which they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: could not have done if their Laws had forbidden him (when he came) to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: manifest, and declare himself. Seeing therefore he did nothing, but by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Preaching, and Miracles go about to prove himselfe to be that Messiah,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hee did therein nothing against their laws. The Kingdome hee claimed was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to bee in another world; He taught all men to obey in the mean time them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that sate in Moses seat: he allowed them to give Caesar his tribute, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: refused to take upon himselfe to be a Judg. How then could his words,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or actions bee seditious, or tend to the overthrow of their then Civill

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Government? But God having determined his sacrifice, for the reduction

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of his elect to their former covenanted obedience, for the means,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whereby he would bring the same to effect, made use of their malice,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and ingratitude. Nor was it contrary to the laws of Caesar. For though

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Pilate himself (to gratifie the Jews) delivered him to be crucified; yet

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: before he did so, he pronounced openly, that he found no fault in him:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And put for title of his condemnation, not as the Jews required, "that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he pretended to be King;" but simply, "That hee was King of the Jews;"

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and notwithstanding their clamour, refused to alter it; saying, "What I

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have written, I have written."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Third Part Of His Office Was To Be King (Under His Father)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of The Elect

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: As for the third part of his Office, which was to be King, I have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: already shewn that his Kingdome was not to begin till the Resurrection.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But then he shall be King, not onely as God, in which sense he is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: King already, and ever shall be, of all the Earth, in vertue of his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: omnipotence; but also peculiarly of his own Elect, by vertue of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: pact they make with him in their Baptisme. And therefore it is, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: our Saviour saith (Mat. 19.28.) that his Apostles should sit upon twelve

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thrones, judging the twelve tribes of Israel, "When the Son of man shall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sit in the throne of his glory;" whereby he signified that he should

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: reign then in his humane nature; and (Mat. 16.27.) "The Son of man shall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: come in the glory of his Father, with his Angels, and then he shall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: reward every man according to his works." The same we may read, Marke

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 13..26. and 14.26. and more expressely for the time, Luke 22.29, 30. "I

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: appoint unto you a Kingdome, as my Father hath appointed to mee, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: you may eat and drink at my table in my Kingdome, and sit on thrones

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: judging the twelve tribes of Israel." By which it is manifest that the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kingdome of Christ appointed to him by his Father, is not to be before

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Son of Man shall come in Glory, and make his Apostles Judges of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the twelve tribes of Israel. But a man may here ask, seeing there is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: no marriage in the Kingdome of Heaven, whether men shall then eat, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: drink; what eating therefore is meant in this place? This is expounded

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by our Saviour (John 6.27.) where he saith, "Labour not for the meat

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which perisheth, but for that meat which endureth unto everlasting

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: life, which the Son of man shall give you." So that by eating at Christs

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: table, is meant the eating of the Tree of Life; that is to say, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: enjoying of Immortality, in the Kingdome of the Son of Man. By which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: places, and many more, it is evident, that our Saviours Kingdome is to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: bee exercised by him in his humane nature.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christs Authority In The Kingdome Of God Subordinate To His Father

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Again, he is to be King then, no otherwise than as subordinate, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Viceregent of God the Father, as Moses was in the wildernesse; and as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the High Priests were before the reign of Saul; and as the Kings were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: after it. For it is one of the Prophecies concerning Christ, that he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: should be like (in Office) to Moses; "I will raise them up a Prophet

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (saith the Lord, Deut. 18.18.) from amongst their Brethren like unto

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thee, and will put my words into his mouth," and this similitude with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Moses, is also apparent in the actions of our Saviour himself, whilest

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he was conversant on Earth. For as Moses chose twelve Princes of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: tribes, to govern under him; so did our Saviour choose twelve Apostles,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: who shall sit on twelve thrones, and judge the twelve tribes of Israel;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And as Moses authorized Seventy Elders, to receive the Spirit of God,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and to Prophecy to the people, that is, (as I have said before,) to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: speak unto them in the name of God; so our Saviour also ordained seventy

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Disciples, to preach his Kingdome, and Salvation to all Nations. And as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: when a complaint was made to Moses, against those of the Seventy that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: prophecyed in the camp of Israel, he justified them in it, as being

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: subservient therein to his government; so also our Saviour, when St.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: John complained to him of a certain man that cast out Devills in his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: name, justified him therein, saying, (Luke 9.50.) "Forbid him not, for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hee that is not against us, is on our part."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Again, our Saviour resembled Moses in the institution of Sacraments,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: both of Admission into the Kingdome of God, and of Commemoration of his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: deliverance of his Elect from their miserable condition. As the Children

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Israel had for Sacrament of their Reception into the Kingdome of God,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: before the time of Moses, the rite of Circumcision, which rite having

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: been omitted in the Wildernesse, was again restored as soon as they came

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: into the land of Promise; so also the Jews, before the coming of our

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Saviour, had a rite of Baptizing, that is, of washing with water all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: those that being Gentiles, embraced the God of Israel. This rite St.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: John the Baptist used in the reception of all them that gave their names

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to the Christ, whom hee preached to bee already come into the world; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: our Saviour instituted the same for a Sacrament to be taken by all that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: beleeved in him. From what cause the rite of Baptisme first proceeded,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is not expressed formally in the Scripture; but it may be probably

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thought to be an imitation of the law of Moses, concerning Leprousie;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: wherein the Leprous man was commanded to be kept out of the campe of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Israel for a certain time; after which time being judged by the Priest

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to be clean, hee was admitted into the campe after a solemne Washing.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And this may therefore bee a type of the Washing in Baptisme; wherein

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such men as are cleansed of the Leprousie of Sin by Faith, are received

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: into the Church with the solemnity of Baptisme. There is another

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: conjecture drawn from the Ceremonies of the Gentiles, in a certain case

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that rarely happens; and that is, when a man that was thought dead,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: chanced to recover, other men made scruple to converse with him, as they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: would doe to converse with a Ghost, unlesse hee were received again into

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the number of men, by Washing, as Children new born were washed from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the uncleannesse of their nativity, which was a kind of new birth. This

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ceremony of the Greeks, in the time that Judaea was under the Dominion

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Alexander, and the Greeks his successors, may probably enough have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: crept into the Religion of the Jews. But seeing it is not likely our

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Saviour would countenance a Heathen rite, it is most likely it proceeded

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from the Legall Ceremony of Washing after Leprosie. And for the other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sacraments, of eating the Paschall Lambe, it is manifestly imitated in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Sacrament of the Lords Supper; in which the Breaking of the Bread,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and the pouring out of the Wine, do keep in memory our deliverance from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Misery of Sin, by Christs Passion, as the eating of the Paschall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lambe, kept in memory the deliverance of the Jewes out of the Bondage of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Egypt. Seeing therefore the authority of Moses was but subordinate, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hee but a Lieutenant to God; it followeth, that Christ, whose authority,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as man, was to bee like that of Moses, was no more but subordinate to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the authority of his Father. The same is more expressely signified, by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that that hee teacheth us to pray, "Our Father, Let thy Kingdome come;"

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and, "For thine is the Kingdome, the power and the Glory;" and by that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it is said, that "Hee shall come in the Glory of his Father;" and by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that which St. Paul saith, (1 Cor. 15.24.) "then commeth the end, when

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hee shall have delivered up the Kingdome to God, even the Father;" and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by many other most expresse places.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: One And The Same God Is The Person Represented By Moses, And By Christ

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Our Saviour therefore, both in Teaching, and Reigning, representeth (as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Moses Did) the Person of God; which God from that time forward, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not before, is called the Father; and being still one and the same

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: substance, is one Person as represented by Moses, and another Person as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: represented by his Sonne the Christ. For Person being a relative to a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Representer, it is consequent to plurality of Representers, that there

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: bee a plurality of Persons, though of one and the same Substance.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CHAPTER XLII. OF POWER ECCLESIASTICALL

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For the understanding of POWER ECCLESIASTICALL, what, and in whom it is,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: we are to distinguish the time from the Ascension of our Saviour, into

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: two parts; one before the Conversion of Kings, and men endued with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign Civill Power; the other after their Conversion. For it was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: long after the Ascension, before any King, or Civill Soveraign embraced,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and publiquely allowed the teaching of Christian Religion.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of The Holy Spirit That Fel On The Apostles

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And for the time between, it is manifest, that the Power

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ecclesiasticall, was in the Apostles; and after them in such as were by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them ordained to Preach the Gospell, and to convert men to Christianity,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and to direct them that were converted in the way of Salvation; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: after these the Power was delivered again to others by these ordained,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and this was done by Imposition of hands upon such as were ordained; by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which was signified the giving of the Holy Spirit, or Spirit of God, to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: those whom they ordained Ministers of God, to advance his Kingdome.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: So that Imposition of hands, was nothing else but the Seal of their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Commission to Preach Christ, and teach his Doctrine; and the giving of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Holy Ghost by that ceremony of Imposition of hands, was an imitation

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of that which Moses did. For Moses used the same ceremony to his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Minister Joshua, as wee read Deuteronomy 34. ver. 9. "And Joshua the son

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Nun was full of the Spirit of Wisdome; for Moses had laid his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hands upon him." Our Saviour therefore between his Resurrection, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ascension, gave his Spirit to the Apostles; first, by "Breathing on

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them, and saying," (John 20.22.) "Receive yee the Holy Spirit;" and after

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his Ascension (Acts 2.2, 3.) by sending down upon them, a "mighty wind,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Cloven tongues of fire;" and not by Imposition of hands; as neither

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: did God lay his hands on Moses; and his Apostles afterward, transmitted

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the same Spirit by Imposition of hands, as Moses did to Joshua. So that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it is manifest hereby, in whom the Power Ecclesiasticall continually

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: remained, in those first times, where there was not any Christian

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth; namely, in them that received the same from the Apostles,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by successive laying on of hands.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of The Trinity

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Here wee have the Person of God born now the third time. For as Moses,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and the High Priests, were Gods Representative in the Old Testament;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and our Saviour himselfe as Man, during his abode on earth: So the Holy

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ghost, that is to say, the Apostles, and their successors, in the Office

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Preaching, and Teaching, that had received the Holy Spirit, have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Represented him ever since. But a Person, (as I have shewn before,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: [chapt. 16.].) is he that is Represented, as often as hee is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Represented; and therefore God, who has been Represented (that is,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Personated) thrice, may properly enough be said to be three Persons;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: though neither the word Person, nor Trinity be ascribed to him in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Bible. St. John indeed (1 Epist. 5.7.) saith, "There be three that bear

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: witnesse in heaven, the Father, the Word, and the Holy Spirit; and these

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Three are One:" But this disagreeth not, but accordeth fitly with three

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Persons in the proper signification of Persons; which is, that which is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Represented by another. For so God the Father, as Represented by Moses,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is one Person; and as Represented by his Sonne, another Person, and as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Represented by the Apostles, and by the Doctors that taught by authority

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from them derived, is a third Person; and yet every Person here, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Person of one and the same God. But a man may here ask, what it was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whereof these three bare witnesse. St. John therefore tells us (verse

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 11.) that they bear witnesse, that "God hath given us eternall life

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in his Son." Again, if it should be asked, wherein that testimony

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: appeareth, the Answer is easie; for he hath testified the same by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: miracles he wrought, first by Moses; secondly, by his Son himself; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: lastly by his Apostles, that had received the Holy Spirit; all which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in their times Represented the Person of God; and either prophecyed, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: preached Jesus Christ. And as for the Apostles, it was the character

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Apostleship, in the twelve first and great Apostles, to bear

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Witnesse of his Resurrection; as appeareth expressely (Acts 1. ver.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 21,22.) where St Peter, when a new Apostle was to be chosen in the place

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Judas Iscariot, useth these words, "Of these men which have companied

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with us all the time that the Lord Jesus went in and out amongst us,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: beginning at the Baptisme of John, unto that same day that hee was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: taken up from us, must one bee ordained to be a Witnesse with us of his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Resurrection:" which words interpret the Bearing of Witnesse, mentioned

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by St. John. There is in the same place mentioned another Trinity of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Witnesses in Earth. For (ver. 8.) he saith, "there are three that bear

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Witnesse in Earth, the Spirit, and the Water, and the Bloud; and these

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: three agree in one:" that is to say, the graces of Gods Spirit, and the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: two Sacraments, Baptisme, and the Lords Supper, which all agree in one

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Testimony, to assure the consciences of beleevers, of eternall life; of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which Testimony he saith (verse 10.) "He that beleeveth on the Son of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man hath the Witnesse in himselfe." In this Trinity on Earth the Unity

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is not of the thing; for the Spirit, the Water, and the Bloud, are not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the same substance, though they give the same testimony: But in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Trinity of Heaven, the Persons are the persons of one and the same God,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: though Represented in three different times and occasions. To conclude,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the doctrine of the Trinity, as far as can be gathered directly from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Scripture, is in substance this; that God who is alwaies One and the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: same, was the Person Represented by Moses; the Person Represented by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his Son Incarnate; and the Person Represented by the Apostles. As

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Represented by the Apostles, the Holy Spirit by which they spake, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: God; As Represented by his Son (that was God and Man), the Son is that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: God; As represented by Moses, and the High Priests, the Father, that is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to say, the Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, is that God: From whence

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: we may gather the reason why those names Father, Son, and Holy Spirit in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the signification of the Godhead, are never used in the Old Testament:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For they are Persons, that is, they have their names from Representing;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which could not be, till divers men had Represented Gods Person in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ruling, or in directing under him.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Thus wee see how the Power Ecclesiasticall was left by our Saviour

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to the Apostles; and how they were (to the end they might the better

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: exercise that Power,) endued with the Holy Spirit, which is therefore

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: called sometime in the New Testament Paracletus which signifieth an

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Assister, or one called to for helpe, though it bee commonly translated

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Comforter. Let us now consider the Power it selfe, what it was, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: over whom.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Power Ecclesiasticall Is But The Power To Teach

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Cardinall Bellarmine in his third generall Controversie, hath handled a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: great many questions concerning the Ecclesiasticall Power of the Pope

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Rome; and begins with this, Whether it ought to be Monarchicall,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Aristocraticall, or Democraticall. All which sorts of Power, are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign, and Coercive. If now it should appear, that there is no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Coercive Power left them by our Saviour; but onely a Power to proclaim

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Kingdom of Christ, and to perswade men to submit themselves

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thereunto; and by precepts and good counsell, to teach them that have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: submitted, what they are to do, that they may be received into the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kingdom of God when it comes; and that the Apostles, and other Ministers

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Gospel, are our Schoolemasters, and not our Commanders, and their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Precepts not Laws, but wholesome Counsells then were all that dispute in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: vain.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: An Argument Thereof, The Power Of Christ Himself

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: I have shewn already (in the last Chapter,) that the Kingdome of Christ

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is not of this world: therefore neither can his Ministers (unlesse they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be Kings,) require obedience in his name. For if the Supreme King, have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not his Regall Power in this world; by what authority can obedience be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: required to his Officers? As my Father sent me, (so saith our Saviour)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: I send you. But our Saviour was sent to perswade the Jews to return to,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and to invite the Gentiles, to receive the Kingdome of his Father, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not to reign in Majesty, no not, as his Fathers Lieutenant, till the day

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Judgment.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: From The Name Of Regeneration

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The time between the Ascension, and the generall Resurrection, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: called, not a Reigning, but a Regeneration; that is, a Preparation

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of men for the second and glorious coming of Christ, at the day of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Judgment; as appeareth by the words of our Saviour, Mat. 19.28. "You

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that have followed me in the Regeneration, when the Son of man shall sit

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the throne of his glory, you shall also sit upon twelve Thrones;" And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of St. Paul (Ephes. 6.15.) "Having your feet shod with the Preparation

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Gospell of Peace."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: From The Comparison Of It, With Fishing, Leaven, Seed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And is compared by our Saviour, to Fishing; that is, to winning men

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to obedience, not by Coercion, and Punishing; but by Perswasion: and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore he said not to his Apostles, hee would make them so many

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nimrods, Hunters Of Men; But Fishers Of Men. It is compared also to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Leaven; to Sowing of Seed, and to the Multiplication of a grain of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Mustard-seed; by all which Compulsion is excluded; and consequently

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there can in that time be no actual Reigning. The work of Christs

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ministers, is Evangelization; that is, a Proclamation of Christ, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a preparation for his second comming; as the Evangelization of John

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Baptist, was a preparation to his first coming.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: From The Nature Of Faith:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Again, the Office of Christs Ministers in this world, is to make men

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Beleeve, and have Faith in Christ: But Faith hath no relation to, nor

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: dependence at all upon Compulsion, or Commandement; but onely upon

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: certainty, or probability of Arguments drawn from Reason, or from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: something men beleeve already. Therefore the Ministers of Christ in this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: world, have no Power by that title, to Punish any man for not Beleeving,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or for Contradicting what they say; they have I say no Power by that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: title of Christs Ministers, to Punish such: but if they have Soveraign

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Civill Power, by politick institution, then they may indeed lawfully

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Punish any Contradiction to their laws whatsoever: And St. Paul, of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: himselfe and other then Preachers of the Gospell saith in expresse

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: words, (2 Cor. 1.24.) "Wee have no Dominion over your Faith, but are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Helpers of your Joy."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: From The Authority Christ Hath Left To Civill Princes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Another Argument, that the Ministers of Christ in this present world

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have no right of Commanding, may be drawn from the lawfull Authority

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which Christ hath left to all Princes, as well Christians, as Infidels.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: St. Paul saith (Col. 3.20.) "Children obey your Parents in all things;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for this is well pleasing to the Lord." And ver. 22. "Servants obey in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all things your Masters according to the flesh, not with eye-service, as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: men-pleasers, but in singlenesse of heart, as fearing the Lord;" This is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: spoken to them whose Masters were Infidells; and yet they are bidden

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to obey them In All Things. And again, concerning obedience to Princes.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (Rom. 13. the first 6. verses) exhorting to "be subject to the Higher

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Powers," he saith, "that all Power is ordained of God;" and "that we

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ought to be subject to them, not onely for" fear of incurring their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "wrath, but also for conscience sake." And St. Peter, (1 Epist. chap. 2e

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ver. 13, 14, 15.) "Submit your selves to every Ordinance of Man, for the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lords sake, whether it bee to the King, as Supreme, or unto Governours,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as to them that be sent by him for the punishment of evill doers, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for the praise of them that doe well; for so is the will of God."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And again St. Paul (Tit. 3.1.) "Put men in mind to be subject to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Principalities, and Powers, and to obey Magistrates." These Princes, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Powers, whereof St. Peter, and St. Paul here speak, were all Infidels;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: much more therefore we are to obey those Christians, whom God hath

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ordained to have Soveraign Power over us. How then can wee be obliged

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to doe any thing contrary to the Command of the King, or other Soveraign

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Representant of the Common-wealth, whereof we are members, and by whom

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: we look to be protected? It is therefore manifest, that Christ hath not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: left to his Ministers in this world, unlesse they be also endued with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Civill Authority, any authority to Command other men.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: What Christians May Do To Avoid Persecution

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But what (may some object) if a King, or a Senate, or other Soveraign

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Person forbid us to beleeve in Christ? To this I answer, that such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: forbidding is of no effect, because Beleef, and Unbeleef never follow

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: mens Commands. Faith is a gift of God, which Man can neither give, nor

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: take away by promise of rewards, or menaces of torture. And if it be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: further asked, What if wee bee commanded by our lawfull Prince, to say

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with our tongue, wee beleeve not; must we obey such command? Profession

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with the tongue is but an externall thing, and no more then any other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: gesture whereby we signifie our obedience; and wherein a Christian,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: holding firmely in his heart the Faith of Christ, hath the same liberty

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which the Prophet Elisha allowed to Naaman the Syrian. Naaman was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: converted in his heart to the God of Israel; For hee saith (2 Kings

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 5.17.) "Thy servant will henceforth offer neither burnt offering, nor

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sacrifice unto other Gods but unto the Lord. In this thing the Lord

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: pardon thy servant, that when my Master goeth into the house of Rimmon

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to worship there, and he leaneth on my hand, and I bow my selfe in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: house of Rimmon; when I bow my selfe in the house of Rimmon, the Lord

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: pardon thy servant in this thing." This the Prophet approved, and bid

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him "Goe in peace." Here Naaman beleeved in his heart; but by bowing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: before the Idol Rimmon, he denyed the true God in effect, as much as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: if he had done it with his lips. But then what shall we answer to our

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Saviours saying, "Whosoever denyeth me before men, I will deny him

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: before my Father which is in Heaven?" This we may say, that whatsoever

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Subject, as Naaman was, is compelled to in obedience to his Soveraign,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and doth it not in order to his own mind, but in order to the laws of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his country, that action is not his, but his Soveraigns; nor is it he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that in this case denyeth Christ before men, but his Governour, and the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: law of his countrey. If any man shall accuse this doctrine, as repugnant

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to true, and unfeigned Christianity; I ask him, in case there should be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a subject in any Christian Common-wealth, that should be inwardly in his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: heart of the Mahometan Religion, whether if his Soveraign Command him to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: bee present at the divine service of the Christian Church, and that on

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: pain of death, he think that Mamometan obliged in conscience to suffer

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: death for that cause, rather than to obey that command of his lawful

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Prince. If he say, he ought rather to suffer death, then he authorizeth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all private men, to disobey their Princes, in maintenance of their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Religion, true, or false; if he say, he ought to bee obedient, then he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: alloweth to himself, that which hee denyeth to another, contrary to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: words of our Saviour, "Whatsoever you would that men should doe unto

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: you, that doe yee unto them;" and contrary to the Law of Nature, (which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is the indubitable everlasting Law of God) "Do not to another, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which thou wouldest not he should doe unto thee."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of Martyrs

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But what then shall we say of all those Martyrs we read of in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: History of the Church, that they have needlessely cast away their lives?

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For answer hereunto, we are to distinguish the persons that have been

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for that cause put to death; whereof some have received a Calling to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: preach, and professe the Kingdome of Christ openly; others have had no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such Calling, nor more has been required of them than their owne faith.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The former sort, if they have been put to death, for bearing witnesse to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: this point, that Jesus Christ is risen from the dead, were true Martyrs;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For a Martyr is, (to give the true definition of the word) a Witnesse of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Resurrection of Jesus the Messiah; which none can be but those

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that conversed with him on earth, and saw him after he was risen: For a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Witnesse must have seen what he testifieth, or else his testimony is not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: good. And that none but such, can properly be called Martyrs of Christ,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is manifest out of the words of St. Peter, Act. 1.21, 22. "Wherefore of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: these men which have companyed with us all the time that the Lord Jesus

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: went in and out amongst us, beginning from the Baptisme of John unto

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that same day hee was taken up from us, must one be ordained to be a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Martyr (that is a Witnesse) with us of his Resurrection:" Where we

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: may observe, that he which is to bee a Witnesse of the truth of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Resurrection of Christ, that is to say, of the truth of this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: fundamentall article of Christian Religion, that Jesus was the Christ,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: must be some Disciple that conversed with him, and saw him before, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: after his Resurrection; and consequently must be one of his originall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Disciples: whereas they which were not so, can Witnesse no more, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that their antecessors said it, and are therefore but Witnesses of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other mens testimony; and are but second Martyrs, or Martyrs of Christs

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Witnesses.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: He, that to maintain every doctrine which he himself draweth out of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the History of our Saviours life, and of the Acts, or Epistles of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Apostles; or which he beleeveth upon the authority of a private man,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: wil oppose the Laws and Authority of the Civill State, is very far from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: being a Martyr of Christ, or a Martyr of his Martyrs. 'Tis one Article

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: onely, which to die for, meriteth so honorable a name; and that Article

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is this, that Jesus Is The Christ; that is to say, He that hath redeemed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: us, and shall come again to give us salvation, and eternall life in his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: glorious Kingdome. To die for every tenet that serveth the ambition,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or profit of the Clergy, is not required; nor is it the Death of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Witnesse, but the Testimony it self that makes the Martyr: for the word

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: signifieth nothing else, but the man that beareth Witnesse, whether he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be put to death for his testimony, or not.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Also he that is not sent to preach this fundamentall article, but taketh

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it upon him of his private authority, though he be a Witnesse, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consequently a Martyr, either primary of Christ, or secondary of his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Apostles, Disciples, or their Successors; yet is he not obliged to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: suffer death for that cause; because being not called thereto, tis

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not required at his hands; nor ought hee to complain, if he loseth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the reward he expecteth from those that never set him on work. None

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore can be a Martyr, neither of the first, nor second degree, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have not a warrant to preach Christ come in the flesh; that is to say,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: none, but such as are sent to the conversion of Infidels. For no man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is a Witnesse to him that already beleeveth, and therefore needs no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Witnesse; but to them that deny, or doubt, or have not heard it. Christ

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sent his Apostles, and his Seventy Disciples, with authority to preach;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he sent not all that beleeved: And he sent them to unbeleevers; "I send

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: you (saith he) as sheep amongst wolves;" not as sheep to other sheep.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Argument From The Points Of Their Commission

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lastly the points of their Commission, as they are expressely set down

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the Gospel, contain none of them any authority over the Congregation.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To Preach

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: We have first (Mat. 10.) that the twelve Apostles were sent "to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: lost sheep of the house of Israel," and commanded to Preach, "that the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kingdome of God was at hand." Now Preaching in the originall, is that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: act, which a Crier, Herald, or other Officer useth to doe publiquely in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Proclaiming of a King. But a Crier hath not right to Command any man.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And (Luke 10.2.) the seventy Disciples are sent out, "as Labourers,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not as Lords of the Harvest;" and are bidden (verse 9.) to say, "The

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kingdome of God is come nigh unto you;" and by Kingdome here is meant,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not the Kingdome of Grace, but the Kingdome of Glory; for they are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: bidden to denounce it (ver. 11.) to those Cities which shall not receive

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them, as a threatning, that it shall be more tolerable in that day for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sodome, than for such a City. And (Mat. 20.28.) our Saviour telleth his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Disciples, that sought Priority of place, their Office was to minister,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: even as the Son of man came, not to be ministred unto, but to minister.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Preachers therefore have not Magisteriall, but Ministeriall power: "Bee

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not called Masters, (saith our Saviour, Mat. 23.10) for one is your

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Master, even Christ."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And Teach

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Another point of their Commission, is, to Teach All Nations; as it is in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Mat. 28.19. or as in St. Mark 16.15 "Goe into all the world, and Preach

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Gospel to every creature." Teaching therefore, and Preaching is the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: same thing. For they that Proclaim the comming of a King, must withall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: make known by what right he commeth, if they mean men shall submit

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: themselves unto him: As St. Paul did to the Jews of Thessalonica,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: when "three Sabbath days he reasoned with them out of the Scriptures,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: opening, and alledging that Christ must needs have suffered, and risen

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: again from the dead, and that this Jesus is Christ." But to teach out

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Old Testament that Jesus was Christ, (that is to say, King,)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and risen from the dead, is not to say, that men are bound after they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: beleeve it, to obey those that tell them so, against the laws, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: commands of their Soveraigns; but that they shall doe wisely, to expect

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the coming of Christ hereafter, in Patience, and Faith, with Obedience

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to their present Magistrates.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To Baptize;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Another point of their Commission, is to Baptize, "in the name of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost." What is Baptisme?

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Dipping into water. But what is it to Dip a man into the water in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: name of any thing? The meaning of these words of Baptisme is this. He

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that is Baptized, is Dipped or Washed, as a sign of becomming a new man,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and a loyall subject to that God, whose Person was represented in old

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: time by Moses, and the High Priests, when he reigned over the Jews; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to Jesus Christ, his Sonne, God, and Man, that hath redeemed us, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shall in his humane nature Represent his Fathers Person in his eternall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kingdome after the Resurrection; and to acknowledge the Doctrine of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Apostles, who assisted by the Spirit of the Father, and of the Son, were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: left for guides to bring us into that Kingdome, to be the onely, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: assured way thereunto. This, being our promise in Baptisme; and the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Authority of Earthly Soveraigns being not to be put down till the day of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Judgment; (for that is expressely affirmed by S. Paul 1 Cor. 15. 22, 23,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 24. where he saith, "As in Adam all die, so in Christ all shall be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: made alive. But every man in his owne order, Christ the first fruits,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: afterward they that are Christs, at his comming; Then Commeth the end,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: when he shall have delivered up the Kingdome of God, even the Father,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: when he shall have put down all Rule, and all Authority and Power")

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it is manifest, that we do not in Baptisme constitute over us another

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: authority, by which our externall actions are to be governed in this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: life; but promise to take the doctrine of the Apostles for our direction

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the way to life eternall.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And To Forgive, And Retain Sinnes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Power of Remission, And Retention Of Sinnes, called also the Power

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Loosing, and Binding, and sometimes the Keyes Of The Kingdome Of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Heaven, is a consequence of the Authority to Baptize, or refuse to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Baptize. For Baptisme is the Sacrament of Allegeance, of them that are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to be received into the Kingdome of God; that is to say, into Eternall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: life; that is to say, to Remission of Sin: For as Eternall life was lost

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by the Committing, so it is recovered by the Remitting of mens Sins. The

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: end of Baptisme is Remission of Sins: and therefore St. Peter, when they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that were converted by his Sermon on the day of Pentecost, asked what

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they were to doe, advised them to "repent, and be Baptized in the name

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Jesus, for the Remission of Sins." And therefore seeing to Baptize

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is to declare the Reception of men into Gods Kingdome; and to refuse to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Baptize is to declare their Exclusion; it followeth, that the Power

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to declare them Cast out, or Retained in it, was given to the same

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Apostles, and their Substitutes, and Successors. And therefore after our

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Saviour had breathed upon them, saying, (John 20.22.) "Receive the Holy

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ghost," hee addeth in the next verse, "Whose soever Sins ye Remit,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they are Remitted unto them; and whose soever Sins ye Retain, they are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Retained." By which words, is not granted an Authority to Forgive, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Retain Sins, simply and absolutely, as God Forgiveth or Retaineth them,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: who knoweth the Heart of man, and truth of his Penitence and Conversion;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but conditionally, to the Penitent: And this Forgivenesse, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Absolution, in case the absolved have but a feigned Repentance, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thereby without other act, or sentence of the Absolvent, made void,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and hath no effect at all to Salvation, but on the contrary, to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Aggravation of his Sin. Therefore the Apostles, and their Successors,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are to follow but the outward marks of Repentance; which appearing, they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have no Authority to deny Absolution; and if they appeare not, they have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: no authority to Absolve. The same also is to be observed in Baptisme:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for to a converted Jew, or Gentile, the Apostles had not the Power to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: deny Baptisme; nor to grant it to the Un-penitent. But seeing no man is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: able to discern the truth of another mans Repentance, further than by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: externall marks, taken from his words, and actions, which are subject to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hypocrisie; another question will arise, Who it is that is constituted

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Judge of those marks. And this question is decided by our Saviour

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: himself; (Mat. 18. 15, 16, 17.) "If thy Brother (saith he) shall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: trespasse against thee, go and tell him his fault between thee, and him

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: alone; if he shall hear thee, thou hast gained thy Brother. But if he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: will not hear thee, then take with thee one, or two more. And if he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shall neglect to hear them, tell it unto the Church, let him be unto

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thee as an Heathen man, and a Publican." By which it is manifest, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Judgment concerning the truth of Repentance, belonged not to any one

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Man, but to the Church, that is, to the Assembly of the Faithfull, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to them that have authority to bee their Representant. But besides the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Judgment, there is necessary also the pronouncing of Sentence: And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: this belonged alwaies to the Apostle, or some Pastor of the Church,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as Prolocutor; and of this our Saviour speaketh in the 18 verse,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "Whatsoever ye shall bind on earth, shall be bound in heaven; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whatsoever ye shall loose on earth, shall be loosed in heaven." And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: comformable hereunto was the practise of St. Paul (1 Cor. 5.3, 4, & 5.)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: where he saith, "For I verily, as absent in body, but present in spirit,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have determined already, as though I were present, concerning him that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hath so done this deed; In the name of our Lord Jesus Christ when ye

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are gathered together, and my spirit, with the power of our Lord Jesus

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christ, To deliver such a one to Satan;" that is to say, to cast him

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: out of the Church, as a man whose Sins are not Forgiven. Paul here

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: pronounceth the Sentence; but the Assembly was first to hear the Cause,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (for St. Paul was absent;) and by consequence to condemn him. But in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the same chapter (ver. 11, 12.) the Judgment in such a case is more

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: expressely attributed to the Assembly: "But now I have written unto

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: you, not to keep company, if any man that is called a Brother be a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Fornicator, &c. with such a one no not to eat. For what have I to do to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: judg them that are without? Do not ye judg them that are within?"

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Sentence therefore by which a man was put out of the Church, was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: pronounced by the Apostle, or Pastor; but the Judgment concerning the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: merit of the cause, was in the Church; that is to say, (as the times

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: were before the conversion of Kings, and men that had Soveraign

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Authority in the Common-wealth,) the Assembly of the Christians dwelling

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the same City; as in Corinth, in the Assembly of the Christians of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Corinth.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of Excommunication

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: This part of the Power of the Keyes, by which men were thrust out from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Kingdome of God, is that which is called Excommunication; and to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: excommunicate, is in the Originall, Aposunagogon Poiein, To Cast Out Of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Synagogue; that is, out of the place of Divine service; a word drawn

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from the custom of the Jews, to cast out of their Synagogues, such as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they thought in manners, or doctrine, contagious, as Lepers were by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Law of Moses separated from the congregation of Israel, till such time

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as they should be by the Priest pronounced clean.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Use Of Excommunication Without Civill Power.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Use and Effect of Excommunication, whilest it was not yet

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: strengthened with the Civill Power, was no more, than that they, who

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: were not Excommunicate, were to avoid the company of them that were.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: It was not enough to repute them as Heathen, that never had been

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christians; for with such they might eate, and drink; which with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Excommunicate persons they might not do; as appeareth by the words of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: St. Paul, (1 Cor. 5. ver. 9, 10, &c.) where he telleth them, he had

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: formerly forbidden them to "company with Fornicators;" but (because that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: could not bee without going out of the world,) he restraineth it to such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Fornicators, and otherwise vicious persons, as were of the brethren;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "with such a one" (he saith) they ought not to keep company, "no, not to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: eat." And this is no more than our Saviour saith (Mat. 18.17.) "Let

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him be to thee as a Heathen, and as a Publican." For Publicans (which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: signifieth Farmers, and Receivers of the revenue of the Common-wealth)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: were so hated, and detested by the Jews that were to pay for it, as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that Publican and Sinner were taken amongst them for the same thing:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Insomuch, as when our Saviour accepted the invitation of Zacchaeus a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Publican; though it were to Convert him, yet it was objected to him as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Crime. And therefore, when our Saviour, to Heathen, added Publican, he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: did forbid them to eat with a man Excommunicate.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: As for keeping them out of their Synagogues, or places of Assembly, they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: had no Power to do it, but that of the owner of the place, whether he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: were Christian, or Heathen. And because all places are by right, in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Dominion of the Common-wealth; as well hee that was Excommunicated, as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hee that never was Baptized, might enter into them by Commission from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Civill Magistrate; as Paul before his conversion entred into their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Synagogues at Damascus, (Acts 9.2.) to apprehend Christians, men and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: women, and to carry them bound to Jerusalem, by Commission from the High

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Priest.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of No Effect Upon An Apostate

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: By which it appears, that upon a Christian, that should become an

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Apostate, in a place where the Civill Power did persecute, or not assist

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Church, the effect of Excommunication had nothing in it, neither of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: dammage in this world, nor of terrour: Not of terrour, because of their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: unbeleef; nor of dammage, because they returned thereby into the favour

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the world; and in the world to come, were to be in no worse estate,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: then they which never had beleeved. The dammage redounded rather to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Church, by provocation of them they cast out, to a freer execution of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their malice.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But Upon The Faithfull Only

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Excommunication therefore had its effect onely upon those, that beleeved

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that Jesus Christ was to come again in Glory, to reign over, and to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: judge both the quick, and the dead, and should therefore refuse entrance

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: into his Kingdom, to those whose Sins were Retained; that is, to those

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that were Excommunicated by the Church. And thence it is that St. Paul

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: calleth Excommunication, a delivery of the Excommunicate person to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Satan. For without the Kingdom of Christ, all other Kingdomes after

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Judgment, are comprehended in the Kingdome of Satan. This is it that the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: faithfull stood in fear of, as long as they stood Excommunicate, that is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to say, in an estate wherein their sins were not Forgiven. Whereby wee

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: may understand, that Excommunication in the time that Christian Religion

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was not authorized by the Civill Power, was used onely for a correction

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of manners, not of errours in opinion: for it is a punishment, whereof

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: none could be sensible but such as beleeved, and expected the coming

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: again of our Saviour to judge the world; and they who so beleeved,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: needed no other opinion, but onely uprightnesse of life, to be saved.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For What Fault Lyeth Excommunication

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: There Lyeth Excommunication for Injustice; as (Mat. 18.) If thy Brother

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: offend thee, tell it him privately; then with Witnesses; lastly, tell

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Church; and then if he obey not, "Let him be to thee as an Heathen

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man, and a Publican." And there lyeth Excommunication for a Scandalous

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Life, as (1 Cor. 5. 11.) "If any man that is called a Brother, be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Fornicator, or Covetous, or an Idolater, or a Drunkard, or an

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Extortioner, with such a one yee are not to eat." But to Excommunicate a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man that held this foundation, that Jesus Was The Christ, for difference

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of opinion in other points, by which that Foundation was not destroyed,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there appeareth no authority in the Scripture, nor example in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Apostles. There is indeed in St. Paul (Titus 3.10.) a text that seemeth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to be to the contrary. "A man that is an Haeretique, after the first

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and second admonition, reject." For an Haeretique, is he, that being a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: member of the Church, teacheth neverthelesse some private opinion, which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Church has forbidden: and such a one, S. Paul adviseth Titus, after

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the first, and second admonition, to Reject. But to Reject (in this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: place) is not to Excommunicate the Man; But to Give Over Admonishing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Him, To Let Him Alone, To Set By Disputing With Him, as one that is to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be convinced onely by himselfe. The same Apostle saith (2 Tim. 2.23.)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "Foolish and unlearned questions avoid;" The word Avoid in this place,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Reject in the former, is the same in the Originall, paraitou: but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Foolish questions may bee set by without Excommunication. And again,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (Tit. 3.93) "Avoid Foolish questions," where the Originall, periistaso,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (set them by) is equivalent to the former word Reject. There is no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other place that can so much as colourably be drawn, to countenance

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Casting out of the Church faithfull men, such as beleeved the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: foundation, onely for a singular superstructure of their own, proceeding

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: perhaps from a good & pious conscience. But on the contrary, all such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: places as command avoiding such disputes, are written for a Lesson to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Pastors, (such as Timothy and Titus were) not to make new Articles of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Faith, by determining every small controversie, which oblige men to a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: needlesse burthen of Conscience, or provoke them to break the union of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Church. Which Lesson the Apostles themselves observed well. S. Peter

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and S. Paul, though their controversie were great, (as we may read

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in Gal. 2.11.) yet they did not cast one another out of the Church.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Neverthelesse, during the Apostles time, there were other Pastors that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: observed it not; As Diotrephes (3 John 9. &c.) who cast out of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Church, such as S. John himself thought fit to be received into it, out

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of a pride he took in Praeeminence; so early it was, that Vainglory, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ambition had found entrance into the Church of Christ.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of Persons Liable To Excommunication

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: That a man be liable to Excommunication, there be many conditions

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: requisite; as First, that he be a member of some Commonalty, that is to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: say, of some lawfull Assembly, that is to say, of some Christian

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Church, that hath power to judge of the cause for which hee is to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: bee Excommunicated. For where there is no community, there can bee no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Excommunication; nor where there is no power to Judge, can there bee any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: power to give Sentence. From hence it followeth, that one Church cannot

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be Excommunicated by another: For either they have equall power

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to Excommunicate each other, in which case Excommunication is not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Discipline, nor an act of Authority, but Schisme, and Dissolution of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: charity; or one is so subordinate to the other, as that they both

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have but one voice, and then they be but one Church; and the part

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Excommunicated, is no more a Church, but a dissolute number of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: individuall persons.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And because the sentence of Excommunication, importeth an advice, not to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: keep company, nor so much as to eat with him that is Excommunicate, if

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Soveraign Prince, or Assembly bee Excommunicate, the sentence is of no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: effect. For all Subjects are bound to be in the company and presence of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their own Soveraign (when he requireth it) by the law of Nature; nor

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: can they lawfully either expell him from any place of his own Dominion,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whether profane or holy; nor go out of his Dominion, without his leave;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: much lesse (if he call them to that honour,) refuse to eat with him. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as to other Princes and States, because they are not parts of one and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the same congregation, they need not any other sentence to keep

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them from keeping company with the State Excommunicate: for the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: very Institution, as it uniteth many men into one Community; so it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: dissociateth one Community from another: so that Excommunication is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not needfull for keeping Kings and States asunder; nor has any further

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: effect then is in the nature of Policy it selfe; unlesse it be to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: instigate Princes to warre upon one another.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nor is the Excommunication of a Christian Subject, that obeyeth the laws

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of his own Soveraign, whether Christian, or Heathen, of any effect. For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: if he beleeve that "Jesus is the Christ, he hath the Spirit of God" (1

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Joh. 4.1.) "and God dwelleth in him, and he in God," (1 Joh. 4.15.) But

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hee that hath the Spirit of God; hee that dwelleth in God; hee in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whom God dwelleth, can receive no harm by the Excommunication of men.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Therefore, he that beleeveth Jesus to be the Christ, is free from all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the dangers threatned to persons Excommunicate. He that beleeveth it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not, is no Christian. Therefore a true and unfeigned Christian is not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: liable to Excommunication; Nor he also that is a professed Christian,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: till his Hypocrisy appear in his Manners, that is, till his behaviour

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: bee contrary to the law of his Soveraign, which is the rule of Manners,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and which Christ and his Apostles have commanded us to be subject to.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For the Church cannot judge of Manners but by externall Actions, which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Actions can never bee unlawfull, but when they are against the Law of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Common-wealth.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: If a mans Father, or Mother, or Master bee Excommunicate, yet are not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Children forbidden to keep them Company, nor to Eat with them; for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that were (for the most part) to oblige them not to eat at all, for want

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of means to get food; and to authorise them to disobey their Parents,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Masters, contrary to the Precept of the Apostles.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In summe, the Power of Excommunication cannot be extended further than

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to the end for which the Apostles and Pastors of the Church have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their Commission from our Saviour; which is not to rule by Command and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Coaction, but by Teaching and Direction of men in the way of Salvation

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the world to come. And as a Master in any Science, may abandon his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Scholar, when hee obstinately neglecteth the practise of his rules; but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not accuse him of Injustice, because he was never bound to obey him:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: so a Teacher of Christian doctrine may abandon his Disciples that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: obstinately continue in an unchristian life; but he cannot say, they doe

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him wrong, because they are not obliged to obey him: For to a Teacher

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that shall so complain, may be applyed the Answer of God to Samuel in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the like place, (1 Sam. 8.) "They have not rejected thee, but mee."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Excommunication therefore when it wanteth the assistance of the Civill

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Power, as it doth, when a Christian State, or Prince is Excommunicate

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by a forain Authority, is without effect; and consequently ought to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be without terrour. The name of Fulmen Excommunicationis (that is, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Thunderbolt Of Excommunication) proceeded from an imagination of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Bishop of Rome, which first used it, that he was King of Kings, as the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Heathen made Jupiter King of the Gods; and assigned him in their Poems,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Pictures, a Thunderbolt, wherewith to subdue, and punish the Giants,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that should dare to deny his power: Which imagination was grounded on

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: two errours; one, that the Kingdome of Christ is of this world, contrary

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to our Saviours owne words, "My Kingdome is not of this world;" the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other, that hee is Christs Vicar, not onely over his owne Subjects,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but over all the Christians of the World; whereof there is no ground in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Scripture, and the contrary shall bee proved in its due place.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of The Interpreter Of The Scriptures Before Civill Soveraigns

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Became Christians

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: St. Paul coming to Thessalonica, where was a Synagogue of the Jews,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (Acts 17.2, 3.) "As his manner was, went in unto them, and three Sabbath

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: dayes reasoned with them out of the Scriptures, Opening and alledging,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that Christ must needs have suffered and risen again from the dead; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that this Jesus whom he preached was the Christ." The Scriptures here

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: mentioned were the Scriptures of the Jews, that is, the Old Testament.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The men, to whom he was to prove that Jesus was the Christ, and risen

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: again from the dead, were also Jews, and did beleeve already, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they were the Word of God. Hereupon (as it is verse 4.) some of them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: beleeved, and (as it is in the 5. ver.) some beleeved not. What was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the reason, when they all beleeved the Scripture, that they did not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all beleeve alike; but that some approved, others disapproved the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Interpretation of St. Paul that cited them; and every one Interpreted

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them to himself? It was this; S. Paul came to them without any Legall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Commission, and in the manner of one that would not Command, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Perswade; which he must needs do, either by Miracles, as Moses did

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to the Israelites in Egypt, that they might see his Authority in Gods

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: works; or by Reasoning from the already received Scripture, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they might see the truth of his doctrine in Gods Word. But whosoever

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: perswadeth by reasoning from principles written, maketh him to whom hee

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: speaketh Judge, both of the meaning of those principles, and also of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: force of his inferences upon them. If these Jews of Thessalonica were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not, who else was the Judge of what S. Paul alledged out of Scripture?

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: If S. Paul, what needed he to quote any places to prove his doctrine? It

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: had been enough to have said, I find it so in Scripture, that is to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: say, in your Laws, of which I am Interpreter, as sent by Christ. The

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Interpreter therefore of the Scripture, to whose Interpretation the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Jews of Thessalonica were bound to stand, could be none: every one might

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: beleeve, or not beleeve, according as the Allegations seemed to himselfe

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to be agreeable, or not agreeable to the meaning of the places alledged.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And generally in all cases of the world, hee that pretendeth any proofe,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: maketh Judge of his proofe him to whom he addresseth his speech. And as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to the case of the Jews in particular, they were bound by expresse words

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (Deut. 17.) to receive the determination of all hard questions, from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Priests and Judges of Israel for the time being. But this is to bee

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: understood of the Jews that were yet unconverted.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For the Conversion of the Gentiles, there was no use of alledging the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Scriptures, which they beleeved not. The Apostles therefore laboured by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Reason to confute their Idolatry; and that done, to perswade them to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: faith of Christ, by their testimony of his Life, and Resurrection. So

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that there could not yet bee any controversie concerning the authority

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to Interpret Scripture; seeing no man was obliged during his infidelity,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to follow any mans Interpretation of any Scripture, except his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraigns Interpretation of the Laws of his countrey.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Let us now consider the Conversion it self, and see what there was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therein, that could be cause of such an obligation. Men were converted

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to no other thing then to the Beleef of that which the Apostles

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: preached: And the Apostles preached nothing, but that Jesus was the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christ, that is to say, the King that was to save them, and reign over

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them eternally in the world to come; and consequently that hee was not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: dead, but risen again from the dead, and gone up into Heaven, and should

author: Thomas Hobbes
