text: come again one day to judg the world, (which also should rise again to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be judged,) and reward every man according to his works. None of them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: preached that himselfe, or any other Apostle was such an Interpreter

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Scripture, as all that became Christians, ought to take their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Interpretation for Law. For to Interpret the Laws, is part of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Administration of a present Kingdome; which the Apostles had not. They

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: prayed then, and all other Pastors ever since, "Let thy Kingdome come;"

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and exhorted their Converts to obey their then Ethnique Princes. The New

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Testament was not yet published in one Body. Every of the Evangelists

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was Interpreter of his own Gospel; and every Apostle of his own Epistle;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And of the Old Testament, our Saviour himselfe saith to the Jews (John

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 5. 39.) "Search the Scriptures; for in them yee thinke to have eternall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: life, and they are they that testifie of me." If hee had not meant they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: should Interpret them, hee would not have bidden them take thence the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: proof of his being the Christ; he would either have Interpreted them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: himselfe, or referred them to the Interpretation of the Priests.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: When a difficulty arose, the Apostles and Elders of the Church assembled

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: themselves together, and determined what should bee preached, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: taught, and how they should Interpret the Scriptures to the People;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but took not from the People the liberty to read, and Interpret them to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: themselves. The Apostles sent divers Letters to the Churches, and other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Writings for their instruction; which had been in vain, if they had not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: allowed them to Interpret, that is, to consider the meaning of them.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And as it was in the Apostles time, it must be till such time as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there should be Pastors, that could authorise an Interpreter, whose

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Interpretation should generally be stood to: But that could not be till

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kings were Pastors, or Pastors Kings.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of The Power To Make Scripture Law

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: There be two senses, wherein a Writing may be said to be Canonicall;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for Canon, signifieth a Rule; and a Rule is a Precept, by which a man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is guided, and directed in any action whatsoever. Such Precepts, though

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: given by a Teacher to his Disciple, or a Counsellor to his friend,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: without power to Compell him to observe them, are neverthelesse Canons;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: because they are Rules: But when they are given by one, whom he that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: receiveth them is bound to obey, then are those Canons, not onely Rules,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but Laws: The question therefore here, is of the Power to make the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Scriptures (which are the Rules of Christian Faith) Laws.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of The Ten Commandements

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: That part of the Scripture, which was first Law, was the Ten

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Commandements, written in two Tables of Stone, and delivered by God

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: himselfe to Moses; and by Moses made known to the people. Before that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: time there was no written Law of God, who as yet having not chosen any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: people to bee his peculiar Kingdome, had given no Law to men, but the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Law of Nature, that is to say, the Precepts of Naturall Reason, written

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in every mans own heart. Of these two Tables, the first containeth the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: law of Soveraignty; 1. That they should not obey, nor honour the Gods of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other Nations, in these words, "Non habebis Deos alienos coram me," that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is, "Thou shalt not have for Gods, the Gods that other Nations worship;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but onely me:" whereby they were forbidden to obey, or honor, as their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: King and Governour, any other God, than him that spake unto them then by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Moses, and afterwards by the High Priest. 2. That they "should not make

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: any Image to represent him;" that is to say, they were not to choose to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: themselves, neither in heaven, nor in earth, any Representative of their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: own fancying, but obey Moses and Aaron, whom he had appointed to that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: office. 3. That "they should not take the Name of God in vain;" that is,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they should not speak rashly of their King, nor dispute his Right,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: nor the commissions of Moses and Aaron, his Lieutenants. 4. That "they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: should every Seventh day abstain from their ordinary labour," and employ

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that time in doing him Publique Honor. The second Table containeth the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Duty of one man towards another, as "To honor Parents; Not to kill;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Not to Commit Adultery; Not to steale; Not to corrupt Judgment by false

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: witnesse;" and finally, "Not so much as to designe in their heart the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: doing of any injury one to another." The question now is, Who it was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that gave to these written Tables the obligatory force of Lawes. There

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is no doubt but that they were made Laws by God himselfe: But because a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Law obliges not, nor is Law to any, but to them that acknowledge it to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be the act of the Soveraign, how could the people of Israel that were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: forbidden to approach the Mountain to hear what God said to Moses, be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: obliged to obedience to all those laws which Moses propounded to them?

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Some of them were indeed the Laws of Nature, as all the Second Table;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and therefore to be acknowledged for Gods Laws; not to the Israelites

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: alone, but to all people: But of those that were peculiar to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Israelites, as those of the first Table, the question remains; saving

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that they had obliged themselves, presently after the propounding of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them, to obey Moses, in these words (Exod. 20.19.) "Speak them thou to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: us, and we will hear thee; but let not God speak to us, lest we die." It

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was therefore onely Moses then, and after him the High Priest, whom (by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Moses) God declared should administer this his peculiar Kingdome, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: had on Earth, the power to make this short Scripture of the Decalogue

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to bee Law in the Common-wealth of Israel. But Moses, and Aaron, and the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: succeeding High Priests were the Civill Soveraigns. Therefore hitherto,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Canonizing, or making of the Scripture Law, belonged to the Civill

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraigne.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of The Judicial, And Leviticall Law

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Judiciall Law, that is to say, the Laws that God prescribed to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Magistrates of Israel, for the rule of their administration of Justice,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and of the Sentences, or Judgments they should pronounce, in Pleas

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: between man and man; and the Leviticall Law, that is to say, the rule

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that God prescribed touching the Rites and Ceremonies of the Priests and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Levites, were all delivered to them by Moses onely; and therefore also

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: became Lawes, by vertue of the same promise of obedience to Moses.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Whether these laws were then written, or not written, but dictated to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the People by Moses (after his forty dayes being with God in the Mount)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by word of mouth, is not expressed in the Text; but they were all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: positive Laws, and equivalent to holy Scripture, and made Canonicall by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Moses the Civill Soveraign.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Second Law

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: After the Israelites were come into the Plains of Moab over against

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Jericho, and ready to enter into the land of Promise, Moses to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: former Laws added divers others; which therefore are called Deuteronomy:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that is, Second Laws. And are (as it is written, Deut. 29.1.) "The words

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of a Covenant which the Lord commanded Moses to make with the Children

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Israel, besides the Covenant which he made with them in Horeb." For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: having explained those former Laws, in the beginning of the Book of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Deuteronomy, he addeth others, that begin at the 12. Cha. and continue

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to the end of the 26. of the same Book. This Law (Deut. 27.1.) they were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: commanded to write upon great stones playstered over, at their passing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: over Jordan: This Law also was written by Moses himself in a Book; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: delivered into the hands of the "Priests, and to the Elders of Israel,"

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (Deut. 31.9.) and commanded (ve. 26.) "to be put in the side of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Arke;" for in the Ark it selfe was nothing but the Ten Commandements.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: This was the Law, which Moses (Deuteronomy 17.18.) commanded the Kings

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Israel should keep a copie of: And this is the Law, which having been

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: long time lost, was found again in the Temple in the time of Josiah,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and by his authority received for the Law of God. But both Moses at the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: writing, and Josiah at the recovery thereof, had both of them the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Civill Soveraignty. Hitherto therefore the Power of making Scripture

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Canonicall, was in the Civill Soveraign.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Besides this Book of the Law, there was no other Book, from the time of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Moses, till after the Captivity, received amongst the Jews for the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Law of God. For the Prophets (except a few) lived in the time of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Captivity it selfe; and the rest lived but a little before it; and were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: so far from having their Prophecies generally received for Laws, as that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their persons were persecuted, partly by false Prophets, and partly by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Kings which were seduced by them. And this Book it self, which was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: confirmed by Josiah for the Law of God, and with it all the History of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Works of God, was lost in the Captivity, and sack of the City of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Jerusalem, as appears by that of 2 Esdras 14.21. "Thy Law is burnt;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefor no man knoweth the things that are done of thee, of the works

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that shall begin." And before the Captivity, between the time when the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Law was lost, (which is not mentioned in the Scripture, but may probably

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be thought to be the time of Rehoboam, when Shishak King of Egypt took

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the spoils of the Temple,(1 Kings 14.26.)) and the time of Josiah,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: when it was found againe, they had no written Word of God, but ruled

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: according to their own discretion, or by the direction of such, as each

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of them esteemed Prophets.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Old Testament, When Made Canonicall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: From whence we may inferre, that the Scriptures of the Old Testament,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which we have at this day, were not Canonicall, nor a Law unto the Jews,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: till the renovation of their Covenant with God at their return from the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Captivity, and restauration of their Common-wealth under Esdras. But

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from that time forward they were accounted the Law of the Jews, and for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such translated into Greek by Seventy Elders of Judaea, and put into the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Library of Ptolemy at Alexandria, and approved for the Word of God. Now

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: seeing Esdras was the High Priest, and the High Priest was their Civill

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraigne, it is manifest, that the Scriptures were never made Laws,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but by the Soveraign Civill Power.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The New Testament Began To Be Canonicall Under Christian Soveraigns By

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Writings of the Fathers that lived in the time before that Christian

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Religion was received, and authorised by Constantine the Emperour, we

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: may find, that the Books wee now have of the New Testament, were held by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Christians of that time (except a few, in respect of whose paucity

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the rest were called the Catholique Church, and others Haeretiques) for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the dictates of the Holy Ghost; and consequently for the Canon, or Rule

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Faith: such was the reverence and opinion they had of their Teachers;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as generally the reverence that the Disciples bear to their first

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Masters, in all manner of doctrine they receive from them, is not small.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Therefore there is no doubt, but when S. Paul wrote to the Churches he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: had converted; or any other Apostle, or Disciple of Christ, to those

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which had then embraced Christ, they received those their Writings for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the true Christian Doctrine. But in that time, when not the Power and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Authority of the Teacher, but the Faith of the Hearer caused them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to receive it, it was not the Apostles that made their own Writings

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Canonicall, but every Convert made them so to himself.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But the question here, is not what any Christian made a Law, or Canon

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to himself, (which he might again reject, by the same right he received

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it;) but what was so made a Canon to them, as without injustice they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: could not doe any thing contrary thereunto. That the New Testament

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: should in this sense be Canonicall, that is to say, a Law in any place

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: where the Law of the Common-wealth had not made it so, is contrary to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the nature of a Law. For a Law, (as hath been already shewn) is the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Commandement of that Man, or Assembly, to whom we have given Soveraign

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Authority, to make such Rules for the direction of our actions, as hee

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shall think fit; and to punish us, when we doe any thing contrary to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: same. When therefore any other man shall offer unto us any other Rules,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which the Soveraign Ruler hath not prescribed, they are but Counsell,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Advice; which, whether good, or bad, hee that is counselled, may

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: without injustice refuse to observe, and when contrary to the Laws

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: already established, without injustice cannot observe, how good soever

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he conceiveth it to be. I say, he cannot in this case observe the same

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in his actions, nor in his discourse with other men; though he may

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: without blame beleeve the his private Teachers, and wish he had the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: liberty to practise their advice; and that it were publiquely received

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for Law. For internall faith is in its own nature invisible, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consequently exempted from all humane jurisdiction; whereas the words,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and actions that proceed from it, as breaches of our Civil obedience,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are injustice both before God and Man. Seeing then our Saviour hath

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: denyed his Kingdome to be in this world, seeing he hath said, he came

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not to judge, but to save the world, he hath not subjected us to other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Laws than those of the Common-wealth; that is, the Jews to the Law

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Moses, (which he saith (Mat. 5.) he came not to destroy, but to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: fulfill,) and other Nations to the Laws of their severall Soveraigns,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and all men to the Laws of Nature; the observing whereof, both he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: himselfe, and his Apostles have in their teaching recommended to us, as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a necessary condition of being admitted by him in the last day into his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: eternall Kingdome, wherein shall be Protection, and Life everlasting.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Seeing then our Saviour, and his Apostles, left not new Laws to oblige

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: us in this world, but new Doctrine to prepare us for the next; the Books

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the New Testament, which containe that Doctrine, untill obedience to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them was commanded, by them that God hath given power to on earth to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Legislators, were not obligatory Canons, that is, Laws, but onely good,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and safe advice, for the direction of sinners in the way to salvation,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which every man might take, and refuse at his owne perill, without

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: injustice.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Again, our Saviour Christs Commission to his Apostles, and Disciples,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was to Proclaim his Kingdome (not present, but) to come; and to Teach

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all Nations; and to Baptize them that should beleeve; and to enter into

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the houses of them that should receive them; and where they were not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: received, to shake off the dust of their feet against them; but not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to call for fire from heaven to destroy them, nor to compell them to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: obedience by the Sword. In all which there is nothing of Power, but of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Perswasion. He sent them out as Sheep unto Wolves, not as Kings to their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Subjects. They had not in Commission to make Laws; but to obey, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: teach obedience to Laws made; and consequently they could not make their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Writings obligatory Canons, without the help of the Soveraign Civill

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Power. And therefore the Scripture of the New Testament is there only

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Law, where the lawfull Civill Power hath made it so. And there also the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: King, or Soveraign, maketh it a Law to himself; by which he subjecteth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: himselfe, not to the Doctor, or Apostle, that converted him, but to God

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: himself, and his Son Jesus Christ, as immediately as did the Apostles

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: themselves.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of The Power Of Councells To Make The Scripture Law

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: That which may seem to give the New Testament, in respect of those that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have embraced Christian Doctrine, the force of Laws, in the times, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: places of persecution, is the decrees they made amongst themselves in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their Synods. For we read (Acts 15.28.) the stile of the Councell of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Apostles, the Elders, and the whole Church, in this manner, "It seemed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: good to the Holy Ghost, and to us, to lay upon you no greater burthen

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: than these necessary things, &C." which is a stile that signifieth a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Power to lay a burthen on them that had received their Doctrine. Now

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "to lay a burthen on another," seemeth the same that "to oblige;" and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore the Acts of that Councell were Laws to the then Christians.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Neverthelesse, they were no more Laws than are these other Precepts,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "Repent, Be Baptized; Keep the Commandements; Beleeve the Gospel; Come

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: unto me; Sell all that thou hast; Give it to the poor;" and "Follow

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: me;" which are not Commands, but Invitations, and Callings of men to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christianity, like that of Esay 55.1. "Ho, every man that thirsteth,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: come yee to the waters, come, and buy wine and milke without money."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For first, the Apostles power was no other than that of our Saviour,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to invite men to embrace the Kingdome of God; which they themselves

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: acknowledged for a Kingdome (not present, but) to come; and they that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have no Kingdome, can make no Laws. And secondly, if their Acts of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Councell, were Laws, they could not without sin be disobeyed. But we

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: read not any where, that they who received not the Doctrine of Christ,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: did therein sin; but that they died in their sins; that is, that their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sins against the Laws to which they owed obedience, were not pardoned.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And those Laws were the Laws of Nature, and the Civill Laws of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: State, whereto every Christian man had by pact submitted himself. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore by the Burthen, which the Apostles might lay on such as they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: had converted, are not to be understood Laws, but Conditions, proposed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to those that sought Salvation; which they might accept, or refuse at

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their own perill, without a new sin, though not without the hazard of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: being condemned, and excluded out of the Kingdome of God for their sins

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: past. And therefore of Infidels, S. John saith not, the wrath of God

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shall "come" upon them, but "the wrath of God remaineth upon them;"

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and not that they shall be condemned; but that "they are condemned

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: already."(John 3.36, 3.18) Nor can it be conceived, that the benefit

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Faith, "is Remission of sins" unlesse we conceive withall, that the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: dammage of Infidelity, is "the Retention of the same sins."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But to what end is it (may some man aske), that the Apostles, and other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Pastors of the Church, after their time, should meet together, to agree

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: upon what Doctrine should be taught, both for Faith and Manners, if no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man were obliged to observe their Decrees? To this may be answered, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Apostles, and Elders of that Councell, were obliged even by their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: entrance into it, to teach the Doctrine therein concluded, and decreed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to be taught, so far forth, as no precedent Law, to which they were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: obliged to yeeld obedience, was to the contrary; but not that all other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christians should be obliged to observe, what they taught. For though

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they might deliberate what each of them should teach; yet they could

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not deliberate what others should do, unless their Assembly had had

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Legislative Power; which none could have but Civill Soveraigns. For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: though God be the Soveraign of all the world, we are not bound to take

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for his Law, whatsoever is propounded by every man in his name; nor any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thing contrary to the Civill Law, which God hath expressely commanded us

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to obey.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Seeing then the Acts of Councell of the Apostles, were then no Laws,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but Councells; much lesse are Laws the Acts of any other Doctors,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or Councells since, if assembled without the Authority of the Civill

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign. And consequently, the Books of the New Testament, though most

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: perfect Rules of Christian Doctrine, could not be made Laws by any other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: authority then that of Kings, or Soveraign Assemblies.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The first Councell, that made the Scriptures we now have, Canon, is not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: extant: For that Collection the first Bishop of Rome after S. Peter, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: subject to question: For though the Canonicall books bee there reckoned

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: up; yet these words, "Sint vobis omnibus Clericis & Laicis Libris

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: venerandi, &c." containe a distinction of Clergy, and Laity, that was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not in use so neer St. Peters time. The first Councell for setling the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Canonicall Scripture, that is extant, is that of Laodicea, Can. 59.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which forbids the reading of other Books then those in the Churches;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which is a Mandate that is not addressed to every Christian, but to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: those onely that had authority to read any publiquely in the Church;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that is, to Ecclesiastiques onely.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of The Right Of Constituting Ecclesiasticall Officers In The Time

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of The Apostles

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of Ecclesiastical Officers in the time of the Apostles, some were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Magisteriall, some Ministeriall. Magisteriall were the Offices

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of preaching of the Gospel of the Kingdom of God to Infidels; of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: administring the Sacraments, and Divine Service; and of teaching the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Rules of Faith and Manners to those that were converted. Ministeriall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was the Office of Deacons, that is, of them that were appointed to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: administration of the secular necessities of the Church, at such time

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as they lived upon a common stock of mony, raised out of the voluntary

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: contributions of the faithfull.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Amongst the Officers Magisteriall, the first, and principall were the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Apostles; whereof there were at first but twelve; and these were chosen

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and constituted by our Saviour himselfe; and their Office was not onely

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to Preach, Teach, and Baptize, but also to be Martyrs, (Witnesses of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: our Saviours Resurrection.) This Testimony, was the specificall, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: essentiall mark; whereby the Apostleship was distinguished from other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Magistracy Ecclesiasticall; as being necessary for an Apostle, either to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have seen our Saviour after his Resurrection, or to have conversed with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him before, and seen his works, and other arguments of his Divinity,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whereby they might be taken for sufficient Witnesses. And therefore at

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the election of a new Apostle in the place of Judas Iscariot, S. Peter

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: saith (Acts 1.21,22.) "Of these men that have companyed with us, all the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: time that the Lord Jesus went in and out among us, beginning from the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Baptisme of John unto that same day that he was taken up from us, must

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: one be ordained to be a Witnesse with us of his Resurrection:" where, by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: this word Must, is implyed a necessary property of an Apostle, to have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: companyed with the first and prime Apostles in the time that our Saviour

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: manifested himself in the flesh.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Matthias Made Apostle By The Congregation.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The first Apostle, of those which were not constituted by Christ in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: time he was upon the Earth, was Matthias, chosen in this manner: There

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: were assembled together in Jerusalem about 120 Christians (Acts 1.15.)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: These appointed two, Joseph the Just, and Matthias (ver. 23.) and caused

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: lots to be drawn; "and (ver. 26.) the Lot fell on Matthias and he was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: numbred with the Apostles." So that here we see the ordination of this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Apostle, was the act of the Congregation, and not of St. Peter, nor of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the eleven, otherwise then as Members of the Assembly.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Paul And Barnabas Made Apostles By The Church Of Antioch

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: After him there was never any other Apostle ordained, but Paul and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Barnabas, which was done (as we read Acts 13.1,2,3.) in this manner.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "There were in the Church that was at Antioch, certaine Prophets, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Teachers; as Barnabas, and Simeon that was called Niger, and Lucius of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Cyrene, and Manaen; which had been brought up with Herod the Tetrarch,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Saul. As they ministred unto the Lord, and fasted, the Holy Ghost

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: said, 'Separate mee Barnabas, and Saul for the worke whereunto I have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: called them.' And when they had fasted, and prayed, and laid their hands

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: on them, they sent them away."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: By which it is manifest, that though they were called by the Holy Ghost,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their Calling was declared unto them, and their Mission authorized by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the particular Church of Antioch. And that this their calling was to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Apostleship, is apparent by that, that they are both called (Acts

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 14.14.) Apostles: And that it was by vertue of this act of the Church of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Antioch, that they were Apostles, S. Paul declareth plainly (Rom. 1.1.)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in that hee useth the word, which the Holy Ghost used at his calling:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For he stileth himself, "An Apostle separated unto the Gospel of God;"

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: alluding to the words of the Holy Ghost, "Separate me Barnabas and Saul,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: &c." But seeing the work of an Apostle, was to be a Witnesse of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Resurrection of Christ, and man may here aske, how S. Paul that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: conversed not with our Saviour before his passion, could know he was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: risen. To which it is easily answered, that our Saviour himself appeared

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to him in the way to Damascus, from Heaven, after his Ascension; "and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: chose him for a vessell to bear his name before the Gentiles, and Kings,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Children of Israel;" and consequently (having seen the Lord after

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his passion) was a competent Witnesse of his Resurrection: And as for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Barnabas, he was a Disciple before the Passion. It is therefore evident

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that Paul, and Barnabas were Apostles; and yet chosen, and authorized

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (not by the first Apostles alone, but) by the Church of Antioch; as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Matthias was chosen, and authorized by the Church of Jerusalem.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: What Offices In The Church Are Magisteriall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Bishop, a word formed in our language, out of the Greek Episcopus,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: signifieth an overseer, or Superintendent of any businesse, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: particularly a Pastor or Shepherd; and thence by metaphor was taken, not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: only amongst the Jews that were originally Shepherds, but also amongst

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Heathen, to signifie the Office of a King, or any other Ruler,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or Guide of People, whether he ruled by Laws, or Doctrine. And so

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Apostles were the first Christian Bishops, instituted by Christ

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: himselfe: in which sense the Apostleship of Judas is called (Acts 1.20.)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his Bishoprick. And afterwards, when there were constituted Elders in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Christian Churches, with charge to guide Christs flock by their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: doctrine, and advice; these Elders were also called Bishops. Timothy was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: an Elder (which word Elder, in the New Testament is a name of Office, as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: well as of Age;) yet he was also a Bishop. And Bishops were then content

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with the Title of Elders. Nay S. John himselfe, the Apostle beloved of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: our Lord, beginneth his Second Epistle with these words, "The Elder to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Elect Lady." By which it is evident, that Bishop, Pastor, Elder,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Doctor, that is to say, Teacher, were but so many divers names of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the same Office in the time of the Apostles. For there was then no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: government by Coercion, but only by Doctrine, and Perswading. The

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kingdome of God was yet to come, in a new world; so that there could

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be no authority to compell in any Church, till the Common-wealth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: had embraced the Christian Faith; and consequently no diversity of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Authority, though there were diversity of Employments.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Besides these Magisteriall employments in the Church, namely Apostles,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Bishops, Elders, Pastors, and Doctors, whose calling was to proclaim

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christ to the Jews, and Infidels, and to direct, and teach those that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: beleeved we read in the New Testament of no other. For by the names

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Evangelists and Prophets, is not signified any Office, but severall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Gifts, by which severall men were profitable to the Church: as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Evangelists, by writing the life and acts of our Saviour; such as were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: S. Matthew and S. John Apostles, and S. Marke and S. Luke Disciples, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whosoever else wrote of that subject, (as S. Thomas, and S. Barnabas are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: said to have done, though the Church have not received the Books

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that have gone under their names:) and as Prophets, by the gift of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: interpreting the Old Testament; and sometimes by declaring their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: speciall Revelations to the Church. For neither these gifts, nor the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: gifts of Languages, nor the gift of Casting out Devils, or of Curing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other diseases, nor any thing else did make an Officer in the Church,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: save onely the due calling and election to the charge of Teaching.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ordination Of Teachers

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: As the Apostles, Matthias, Paul, and Barnabas, were not made by our

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Saviour himself, but were elected by the Church, that is, by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Assembly of Christians; namely, Matthias by the Church of Jerusalem,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Paul, and Barnabas by the Church of Antioch; so were also the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Presbyters, and Pastors in other Cities, elected by the Churches of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: those Cities. For proof whereof, let us consider, first, how S. Paul

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: proceeded in the Ordination of Presbyters, in the Cities where he had

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: converted men to the Christian Faith, immediately after he and Barnabas

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: had received their Apostleship. We read (Acts 14.23.) that "they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ordained Elders in every Church;" which at first sight may be taken for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: an Argument, that they themselves chose, and gave them their authority:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But if we consider the Originall text, it will be manifest, that they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: were authorized, and chosen by the Assembly of the Christians of each

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: City. For the words there are, "cheirotonesantes autoispresbuterous kat

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ekklesian," that is, "When they had Ordained them Elders by the Holding

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: up of Hands in every Congregation." Now it is well enough known, that in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all those Cities, the manner of choosing Magistrates, and Officers,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was by plurality of suffrages; and (because the ordinary way of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: distinguishing the Affirmative Votes from the Negatives, was by Holding

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: up of Hands) to ordain an Officer in any of the Cities, was no more

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but to bring the people together, to elect them by plurality of Votes,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whether it were by plurality of elevated hands, or by plurality of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: voices, or plurality of balls, or beans, or small stones, of which every

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man cast in one, into a vessell marked for the Affirmative, or Negative;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for divers Cities had divers customes in that point. It was therefore

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Assembly that elected their own Elders: the Apostles were onely

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Presidents of the Assembly to call them together for such Election, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to pronounce them Elected, and to give them the benediction, which now

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is called Consecration. And for this cause they that were Presidents

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Assemblies, as (in the absence of the Apostles) the Elders were,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: were called proestotes, and in Latin Antistities; which words signifie

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Principall Person of the Assembly, whose office was to number the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Votes, and to declare thereby who was chosen; and where the Votes were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: equall, to decide the matter in question, by adding his own; which is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Office of a President in Councell. And (because all the Churches

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: had their Presbyters ordained in the same manner,) where the word is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Constitute, (as Titus 1.5.) "ina katasteses kata polin presbuterous,"

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "For this cause left I thee in Crete, that thou shouldest constitute

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Elders in every City," we are to understand the same thing; namely, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hee should call the faithfull together, and ordain them Presbyters by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: plurality of suffrages. It had been a strange thing, if in a Town, where

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: men perhaps had never seen any Magistrate otherwise chosen then by an

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Assembly, those of the Town becomming Christians, should so much as have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thought on any other way of Election of their Teachers, and Guides, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is to say, of their Presbyters, (otherwise called Bishops,) then this of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: plurality of suffrages, intimated by S. Paul (Acts 14.23.) in the word

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Cheirotonesantes: Nor was there ever any choosing of Bishops, (before

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Emperors found it necessary to regulate them in order to the keeping

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the peace amongst them,) but by the Assemblies of the Christians in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: every severall Town.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The same is also confirmed by the continuall practise even to this day,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the Election of the Bishops of Rome. For if the Bishop of any place,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: had the right of choosing another, to the succession of the Pastorall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Office, in any City, at such time as he went from thence, to plant the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: same in another place; much more had he had the Right, to appoint his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: successour in that place, in which he last resided and dyed: And we find

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not, that ever any Bishop of Rome appointed his successor. For they were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a long time chosen by the People, as we may see by the sedition raised

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: about the Election, between Damascus, and Ursinicus; which Ammianus

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Marcellinus saith was so great, that Juventius the Praefect, unable to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: keep the peace between them, was forced to goe out of the City; and that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there were above an hundred men found dead upon that occasion in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Church it self. And though they afterwards were chosen, first, by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whole Clergy of Rome, and afterwards by the Cardinalls; yet never any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was appointed to the succession by his predecessor. If therefore they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: pretended no right to appoint their successors, I think I may reasonably

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: conclude, they had no right to appoint the new power; which none could

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: take from the Church to bestow on them, but such as had a lawfull

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: authority, not onely to Teach, but to Command the Church; which none

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: could doe, but the Civill Soveraign.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ministers Of The Church What

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The word Minister in the Originall Diakonos signifieth one that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: voluntarily doth the businesse of another man; and differeth from a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Servant onely in this, that Servants are obliged by their condition,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to what is commanded them; whereas Ministers are obliged onely by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their undertaking, and bound therefore to no more than that they have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: undertaken: So that both they that teach the Word of God, and they that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: administer the secular affairs of the Church, are both Ministers, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they are Ministers of different Persons. For the Pastors of the Church,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: called (Acts 6.4.) "The Ministers of the Word," are Ministers of Christ,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whose Word it is: But the Ministery of a Deacon, which is called (verse

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 2. of the same Chapter) "Serving of Tables," is a service done to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Church, or Congregation: So that neither any one man, nor the whole

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Church, could ever of their Pastor say, he was their Minister; but of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Deacon, whether the charge he undertook were to serve tables, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: distribute maintenance to the Christians, when they lived in each City

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: on a common stock, or upon collections, as in the first times, or to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: take a care of the House of Prayer, or of the Revenue, or other worldly

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: businesse of the Church, the whole Congregation might properly call him

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their Minister.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For their employment, as Deacons, was to serve the Congregation; though

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: upon occasion they omitted not to preach the Gospel, and maintain the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Doctrine of Christ, every one according to his gifts, as S. Steven did;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and both to Preach, and Baptize, as Philip did: For that Philip, which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (Act. 8. 5.) Preached the Gospel at Samaria, and (verse 38.) Baptized

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Eunuch, was Philip the Deacon, not Philip the Apostle. For it is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: manifest (verse 1.) that when Philip preached in Samaria, the Apostles

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: were at Jerusalem, and (verse 14.) "When they heard that Samaria had

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: received the Word of God, sent Peter and John to them;" by imposition of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whose hands, they that were Baptized (verse 15.) received (which before

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by the Baptisme of Philip they had not received) the Holy Ghost. For it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was necessary for the conferring of the Holy Ghost, that their Baptisme

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: should be administred, or confirmed by a Minister of the Word, not by a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Minister of the Church. And therefore to confirm the Baptisme of those

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that Philip the Deacon had Baptized, the Apostles sent out of their own

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: number from Jerusalem to Samaria, Peter, and John; who conferred on them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that before were but Baptized, those graces that were signs of the Holy

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Spirit, which at that time did accompany all true Beleevers; which what

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they were may be understood by that which S. Marke saith (chap. 16.17.)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "These signs follow them that beleeve in my Name; they shall cast out

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Devills; they shall speak with new tongues; They shall take up Serpents,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and if they drink any deadly thing, it shall not hurt them; They shall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: lay hands on the sick, and they shall recover." This to doe, was it that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Philip could not give; but the Apostles could, and (as appears by this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: place) effectually did to every man that truly beleeved, and was by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Minister of Christ himself Baptized: which power either Christs

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ministers in this age cannot conferre, or else there are very few true

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Beleevers, or Christ hath very few Ministers.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And How Chosen What

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: That the first Deacons were chosen, not by the Apostles, but by a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Congregation of the Disciples; that is, of Christian men of all sorts,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is manifest out of Acts 6. where we read that the Twelve, after the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: number of Disciples was multiplyed, called them together, and having

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: told them, that it was not fit that the Apostles should leave the Word

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of God, and serve tables, said unto them (verse 3.) "Brethren looke you

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: out among you seven men of honest report, full of the Holy Ghost, and of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Wisdome, whom we may appoint over this businesse." Here it is manifest,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that though the Apostles declared them elected; yet the Congregation

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: chose them; which also, (verse the fift) is more expressely said, where

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it is written, that "the saying pleased the multitude, and they chose

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: seven, &c."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of Ecclesiasticall Revenue, Under The Law Of Moses

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Under the Old Testament, the Tribe of Levi were onely capable of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Priesthood, and other inferiour Offices of the Church. The land

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was divided amongst the other Tribes (Levi excepted,) which by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: subdivision of the Tribe of Joseph, into Ephraim and Manasses, were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: still twelve. To the Tribe of Levi were assigned certain Cities for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their habitation, with the suburbs for their cattell: but for their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: portion, they were to have the tenth of the fruits of the land of their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Brethren. Again, the Priests for their maintenance had the tenth of that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: tenth, together with part of the oblations, and sacrifices. For God had

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: said to Aaron (Numb. 18. 20.) "Thou shalt have no inheritance in their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: land, neither shalt thou have any part amongst them, I am thy part, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thine inheritance amongst the Children of Israel." For God being then

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: King, and having constituted the Tribe of Levi to be his Publique

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ministers, he allowed them for their maintenance, the Publique revenue,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that is to say, the part that God had reserved to himself; which were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Tythes, and Offerings: and that it is which is meant, where God saith, I

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: am thine inheritance. And therefore to the Levites might not unfitly

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be attributed the name of Clergy from Kleros, which signifieth Lot, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Inheritance; not that they were heirs of the Kingdome of God, more than

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other; but that Gods inheritance, was their maintenance. Now seeing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in this time God himself was their King, and Moses, Aaron, and the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: succeeding High Priests were his Lieutenants; it is manifest, that the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Right of Tythes, and Offerings was constituted by the Civill Power.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: After their rejection of God in the demand of a King, they enjoyed still

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the same revenue; but the Right thereof was derived from that, that the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kings did never take it from them: for the Publique Revenue was at

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the disposing of him that was the Publique Person; and that (till the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Captivity) was the King. And again, after the return from the Captivity,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they paid their Tythes as before to the Priest. Hitherto therefore

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Church Livings were determined by the Civill Soveraign.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In Our Saviours Time, And After

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of the maintenance of our Saviour, and his Apostles, we read onely they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: had a Purse, (which was carried by Judas Iscariot;) and, that of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Apostles, such as were Fisher-men, did sometimes use their trade; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that when our Saviour sent the Twelve Apostles to Preach, he forbad them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "to carry Gold, and Silver, and Brasse in their purses, for that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the workman is worthy of his hire:" (Mat. 10. 9,10.) By which it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is probable, their ordinary maintenance was not unsuitable to their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: employment; for their employment was (ver. 8.) "freely to give, because

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they had freely received;" and their maintenance was the Free Gift of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: those that beleeved the good tyding they carryed about of the coming

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Messiah their Saviour. To which we may adde, that which was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: contributed out of gratitude, by such as our Saviour had healed of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: diseases; of which are mentioned "Certain women (Luke 8. 2,3.) which had

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: been healed of evill spirits and infirmities; Mary Magdalen, out of whom

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: went seven Devills; and Joanna the wife of Chuza, Herods Steward; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Susanna, and many others, which ministred unto him of their substance.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: After our Saviours Ascension, the Christians of every City lived in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common, (Acts 4. 34.) upon the mony which was made of the sale of their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: lands and possessions, and laid down at the feet of the Apostles, of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: good will, not of duty; for "whilest the Land remained (saith S. Peter

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to Ananias Acts 5.4.) was it not thine? and after it was sold, was it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not in thy power?" which sheweth he needed not to have saved his land,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: nor his money by lying, as not being bound to contribute any thing at

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all, unlesse he had pleased. And as in the time of the Apostles, so also

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all the time downward, till after Constantine the Great, we shall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: find, that the maintenance of the Bishops, and Pastors of the Christian

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Church, was nothing but the voluntary contribution of them that had

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: embraced their Doctrine. There was yet no mention of Tythes: but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such was in the time of Constantine, and his Sons, the affection of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christians to their Pastors, as Ammianus Marcellinus saith (describing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the sedition of Damasus and Ursinicus about the Bishopricke,) that it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was worth their contention, in that the Bishops of those times by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: liberality of their flock, and especially of Matrons, lived splendidly,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: were carryed in Coaches, and sumptuous in their fare and apparell.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Ministers Of The Gospel Lived On The Benevolence Of Their Flocks

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But here may some ask, whether the Pastor were then bound to live upon

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: voluntary contribution, as upon almes, "For who (saith S. Paul 1 Cor. 9.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 7.) goeth to war at his own charges? or who feedeth a flock, and eatheth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not of the milke of the flock?" And again, (1 Cor. 9. 13.) "Doe ye not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: know that they which minister about holy things, live of the things of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Temple; and they which wait at the Altar, partake with the Altar;"

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that is to say, have part of that which is offered at the Altar for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their maintenance? And then he concludeth, "Even so hath the Lord

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: appointed, that they which preach the Gospel should live of the Gospel.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: From which place may be inferred indeed, that the Pastors of the Church

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ought to be maintained by their flocks; but not that the Pastors were to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: determine, either the quantity, or the kind of their own allowance, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be (as it were) their own Carvers. Their allowance must needs therefore

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be determined, either by the gratitude, and liberality of every

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: particular man of their flock, or by the whole Congregation. By the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whole Congregation it could not be, because their Acts were then no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Laws: Therefore the maintenance of Pastors, before Emperours and Civill

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraigns had made Laws to settle it, was nothing but Benevolence. They

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that served at the Altar lived on what was offered. In what court should

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they sue for it, who had no Tribunalls? Or if they had Arbitrators

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: amongst themselves, who should execute their Judgments, when they had no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: power to arme their Officers? It remaineth therefore, that there could

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be no certaine maintenance assigned to any Pastors of the Church, but by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the whole Congregation; and then onely, when their Decrees should have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the force (not onely of Canons, but also) of Laws; which Laws could not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be made, but by Emperours, Kings, or other Civill Soveraignes. The Right

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Tythes in Moses Law, could not be applyed to the then Ministers

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Gospell; because Moses and the High Priests were the Civill

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraigns of the people under God, whose Kingdom amongst the Jews was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: present; whereas the Kingdome of God by Christ is yet to come.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Hitherto hath been shewn what the Pastors of the Church are; what are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the points of their Commission (as that they were to Preach, to Teach,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to Baptize, to be Presidents in their severall Congregations;) what is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ecclesiasticall Censure, viz. Excommunication, that is to say, in those

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: places where Christianity was forbidden by the Civill Laws, a putting

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of themselves out of the company of the Excommunicate, and where

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christianity was by the Civill Law commanded, a putting the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Excommunicate out of the Congregations of Christians; who elected the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Pastors and Ministers of the Church, (that it was, the Congregation);

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: who consecrated and blessed them, (that it was the Pastor); what was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their due revenue, (that it was none but their own possessions,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and their own labour, and the voluntary contributions of devout and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: gratefull Christians). We are to consider now, what Office those persons

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have, who being Civill Soveraignes, have embraced also the Christian

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Faith.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Civill Soveraign Being A Christian Hath The Right Of Appointing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Pastors

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And first, we are to remember, that the Right of Judging what

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Doctrines are fit for Peace, and to be taught the Subjects, is in all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealths inseparably annexed (as hath been already proved cha.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 18.) to the Soveraign Power Civill, whether it be in one Man, or in one

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Assembly of men. For it is evident to the meanest capacity, that mens

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: actions are derived from the opinions they have of the Good, or Evill,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which from those actions redound unto themselves; and consequently,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: men that are once possessed of an opinion, that their obedience to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Soveraign Power, will bee more hurtfull to them, than their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: disobedience, will disobey the Laws, and thereby overthrow the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth, and introduce confusion, and Civill war; for the avoiding

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whereof, all Civill Government was ordained. And therefore in all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealths of the Heathen, the Soveraigns have had the name of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Pastors of the People, because there was no Subject that could lawfully

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Teach the people, but by their permission and authority.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: This Right of the Heathen Kings, cannot bee thought taken from them by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their conversion to the Faith of Christ; who never ordained, that Kings

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for beleeving in him, should be deposed, that is, subjected to any but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: himself, or (which is all one) be deprived of the power necessary for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the conservation of Peace amongst their Subjects, and for their defence

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: against foraign Enemies. And therefore Christian Kings are still the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Supreme Pastors of their people, and have power to ordain what Pastors

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they please, to teach the Church, that is, to teach the People committed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to their charge.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Again, let the right of choosing them be (as before the conversion

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Kings) in the Church, for so it was in the time of the Apostles

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: themselves (as hath been shewn already in this chapter); even so also

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Right will be in the Civill Soveraign, Christian. For in that he is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Christian, he allowes the Teaching; and in that he is the Soveraign

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (which is as much as to say, the Church by Representation,) the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Teachers hee elects, are elected by the Church. And when an Assembly of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christians choose their Pastor in a Christian Common-wealth, it is the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign that electeth him, because tis done by his Authority; In the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: same manner, as when a Town choose their Maior, it is the act of him

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that hath the Soveraign Power: For every act done, is the act of him,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: without whose consent it is invalid. And therefore whatsoever examples

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: may be drawn out of History, concerning the Election of Pastors, by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: People, or by the Clergy, they are no arguments against the Right of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: any Civill Soveraign, because they that elected them did it by his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Authority.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Seeing then in every Christian Common-wealth, the Civill Soveraign is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Supreme Pastor, to whose charge the whole flock of his Subjects is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: committed, and consequently that it is by his authority, that all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other Pastors are made, and have power to teach, and performe all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other Pastorall offices; it followeth also, that it is from the Civill

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign, that all other Pastors derive their right of Teaching,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Preaching, and other functions pertaining to that Office; and that they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are but his Ministers; in the same manner as the Magistrates of Towns,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Judges in Courts of Justice, and Commanders of Armies, are all but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ministers of him that is the Magistrate of the whole Common-wealth,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Judge of all Causes, and Commander of the whole Militia, which is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: alwayes the Civill Soveraign. And the reason hereof, is not because they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that Teach, but because they that are to Learn, are his Subjects.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For let it be supposed, that a Christian King commit the Authority of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ordaining Pastors in his Dominions to another King, (as divers Christian

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kings allow that power to the Pope;) he doth not thereby constitute a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Pastor over himself, nor a Soveraign Pastor over his People; for that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: were to deprive himself of the Civill Power; which depending on the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: opinion men have of their Duty to him, and the fear they have of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Punishment in another world, would depend also on the skill, and loyalty

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Doctors, who are no lesse subject, not only to Ambition, but also

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to Ignorance, than any other sort of men. So that where a stranger hath

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: authority to appoint Teachers, it is given him by the Soveraign in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whose Dominions he teacheth. Christian Doctors are our Schoolmasters

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to Christianity; But Kings are Fathers of Families, and may receive

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Schoolmasters for their Subjects from the recommendation of a stranger,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but not from the command; especially when the ill teaching them shall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: redound to the great and manifest profit of him that recommends them:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: nor can they be obliged to retain them, longer than it is for the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Publique good; the care of which they stand so long charged withall, as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they retain any other essentiall Right of the Soveraignty.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Pastorall Authority Of Soveraigns Only Is De Jure Divino,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: That Of Other Pastors Is Jure Civili

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: If a man therefore should ask a Pastor, in the execution of his Office,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as the chief Priests and Elders of the people (Mat. 21.23.) asked our

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Saviour, "By what authority dost thou these things, and who gave thee

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: this authority:" he can make no other just Answer, but that he doth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it by the Authority of the Common-wealth, given him by the King, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Assembly that representeth it. All Pastors, except the Supreme, execute

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their charges in the Right, that is by the Authority of the Civill

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign, that is, Jure Civili. But the King, and every other Soveraign

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: executeth his Office of Supreme Pastor, by immediate Authority from God,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that is to say, In Gods Right, or Jure Divino. And therefore none but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kings can put into their Titles (a mark of their submission to God onely

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ) Dei Gratia Rex, &c. Bishops ought to say in the beginning of their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Mandates, "By the favour of the Kings Majesty, Bishop of such a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Diocesse;" or as Civill Ministers, "In his Majesties Name." For in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: saying, Divina Providentia, which is the same with Dei Gratia, though

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: disguised, they deny to have received their authority from the Civill

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: State; and sliely slip off the Collar of their Civill Subjection,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: contrary to the unity and defence of the Common-wealth.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christian Kings Have Power To Execute All Manner Of Pastoral Function

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But if every Christian Soveraign be the Supreme Pastor of his own

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Subjects, it seemeth that he hath also the Authority, not only to Preach

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (which perhaps no man will deny;) but also to Baptize, and to Administer

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Sacrament of the Lords Supper; and to Consecrate both Temples, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Pastors to Gods service; which most men deny; partly because they use

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not to do it; and partly because the Administration of Sacraments,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Consecration of Persons, and Places to holy uses, requireth the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Imposition of such mens hands, as by the like Imposition successively

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from the time of the Apostles have been ordained to the like Ministery.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For proof therefore that Christian Kings have power to Baptize, and to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Consecrate, I am to render a reason, both why they use not to doe it,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and how, without the ordinary ceremony of Imposition of hands, they are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: made capable of doing it, when they will.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: There is no doubt but any King, in case he were skilfull in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sciences, might by the same Right of his Office, read Lectures of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them himself, by which he authorizeth others to read them in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Universities. Neverthelesse, because the care of the summe of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: businesse of the Common-wealth taketh up his whole time, it were not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: convenient for him to apply himself in Person to that particular. A King

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: may also if he please, sit in Judgment, to hear and determine all manner

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Causes, as well as give others authority to doe it in his name; but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that the charge that lyeth upon him of Command and Government, constrain

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him to bee continually at the Helm, and to commit the Ministeriall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Offices to others under him. In the like manner our Saviour (who surely

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: had power to Baptize) Baptized none himselfe, but sent his Apostles and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Disciples to Baptize. (John 4.2.) So also S. Paul, by the necessity of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Preaching in divers and far distant places, Baptized few: Amongst all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Corinthians he Baptized only Crispus, Cajus, and Stephanus; (1

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Cor.1.14,16.) and the reason was, because his principall Charge was to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Preach. (1 Cor. 1.17.) Whereby it is manifest, that the greater Charge,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (such as is the Government of the Church,) is a dispensation for the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: lesse. The reason therefore why Christian Kings use not to Baptize, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: evident, and the same, for which at this day there are few Baptized by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Bishops, and by the Pope fewer.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And as concerning Imposition of Hands, whether it be needfull, for the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: authorizing of a King to Baptize, and Consecrate, we may consider thus.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Imposition of Hands, was a most ancient publique ceremony amongst the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Jews, by which was designed, and made certain, the person, or other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thing intended in a mans prayer, blessing, sacrifice, consecration,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: condemnation, or other speech. So Jacob in blessing the children of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Joseph (Gen. 48.14.) "Laid his right Hand on Ephraim the younger, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his left Hand on Manasseh the first born;" and this he did Wittingly

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (though they were so presented to him by Joseph, as he was forced in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: doing it to stretch out his arms acrosse) to design to whom he intended

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the greater blessing. So also in the sacrificing of the Burnt offering,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Aaron is commanded (Exod. 29.10.) "to Lay his Hands on the head of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: bullock;" and (ver. 15.) "to Lay his Hand on the head of the ramme."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The same is also said again, Levit. 1.4. & 8.14. Likewise Moses when he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ordained Joshua to be Captain of the Israelites, that is, consecrated

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him to Gods service, (Numb. 27.23.) "Laid his hands upon him, and gave

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him his Charge," designing and rendring certain, who it was they were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to obey in war. And in the consecration of the Levites (Numb. 8.10.) God

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: commanded that "the Children of Israel should Put their Hands upon the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Levites." And in the condemnation of him that had blasphemed the Lord

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (Levit. 24.14.) God commanded that "all that heard him should Lay their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Hands on his head, and that all the Congregation should stone him." And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: why should they only that heard him, Lay their Hands upon him, and not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: rather a Priest, Levite, or other Minister of Justice, but that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: none else were able to design, and demonstrate to the eyes of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Congregation, who it was that had blasphemed, and ought to die? And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to design a man, or any other thing, by the Hand to the Eye is lesse

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: subject to mistake, than when it is done to the Eare by a Name.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And so much was this ceremony observed, that in blessing the whole

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Congregation at once, which cannot be done by Laying on of Hands, yet

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "Aaron (Levit. 9.22.) did lift up his Hand towards the people when he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: blessed them." And we read also of the like ceremony of Consecration of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Temples amongst the Heathen, as that the Priest laid his Hands on

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: some post of the Temple, all the while he was uttering the words of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Consecration. So naturall it is to design any individuall thing, rather

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by the Hand, to assure the Eyes, than by Words to inform the Eare in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: matters of Gods Publique service.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: This ceremony was not therefore new in our Saviours time. For Jairus

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (Mark 5.23.) whose daughter was sick, besought our Saviour (not to heal

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: her, but) "to Lay his Hands upon her, that shee might bee healed." And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (Matth. 19.13.) "they brought unto him little children, that hee should

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Put his Hands on them, and Pray."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: According to this ancient Rite, the Apostles, and Presbyters, and the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Presbytery it self, Laid Hands on them whom they ordained Pastors, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: withall prayed for them that they might receive the Holy Ghost; and that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not only once, but sometimes oftner, when a new occasion was presented:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but the end was still the same, namely a punctuall, and religious

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: designation of the person, ordained either to the Pastorall Charge

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in general, or to a particular Mission: so (Act. 6.6.) "The Apostles

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Prayed, and Laid their Hands" on the seven Deacons; which was done,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not to give them the Holy Ghost, (for they were full of the Holy Ghost

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: before thy were chosen, as appeareth immediately before, verse 3.) but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to design them to that Office. And after Philip the Deacon had converted

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: certain persons in Samaria, Peter and John went down (Act. 8.17.)" and

author: Thomas Hobbes
