text: laid their Hands on them, and they received the Holy Ghost." And not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: only an Apostle, but a Presbyter had this power: For S. Paul adviseth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Timothy (1 Tim. 5.22.) "Lay Hands suddenly on no man;" that is, designe

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: no man rashly to the Office of a Pastor. The whole Presbytery Laid their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Hands on Timothy, as we read 1 Tim. 4.14. but this is to be understood,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as that some did it by the appointment of the Presbytery, and most

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: likely their Proestos, or Prolocutor, which it may be was St. Paul

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: himself. For in his 2 Epist. to Tim. ver. 6. he saith to him, "Stirre up

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the gift of God which is in thee, by the Laying on of my Hands:" where

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: note by the way, that by the Holy ghost, is not meant the third Person

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the Trinity, but the Gifts necessary to the Pastorall Office. We read

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: also, that St. Paul had Imposition of Hands twice; once from Ananias at

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Damascus (Acts 9.17,18.) at the time of his Baptisme; and again (Acts

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 13.3.) at Antioch, when he was first sent out to Preach. The use then of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: this ceremony considered in the Ordination of Pastors, was to design

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Person to whom they gave such Power. But if there had been then any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christian, that had had the Power of Teaching before; the Baptizing of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him, that is the making of him a Christian, had given him no new Power,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but had onely caused him to preach true Doctrine, that is, to use

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his Power aright; and therefore the Imposition of Hands had been

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: unnecessary; Baptisme it selfe had been sufficient. But every Soveraign,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: before Christianity, had the power of Teaching, and Ordaining Teachers;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and therefore Christianity gave them no new Right, but only directed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them in the way of teaching truth; and consequently they needed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: no Imposition of Hands (besides that which is done in Baptisme) to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: authorize them to exercise any part of the Pastorall Function, as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: namely, to Baptize, and Consecrate. And in the Old Testament, though

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Priest only had right to Consecrate, during the time that the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraignty was in the High Priest; yet it was not so when the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraignty was in the King: For we read (1 Kings 8.) That Solomon

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Blessed the People, Consecrated the Temple, and pronounced that Publique

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Prayer, which is the pattern now for Consecration of all Christian

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Churches, and Chappels: whereby it appears, he had not only the right

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Ecclesiasticall Government; but also of exercising Ecclesiasticall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Functions.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Civill Soveraigne If A Christian, Is Head Of The Church

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In His Own Dominions

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: From this consolidation of the Right Politique, and Ecclesiastique in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christian Soveraigns, it is evident, they have all manner of Power over

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their Subjects, that can be given to man, for the government of mens

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: externall actions, both in Policy, and Religion; and may make such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Laws, as themselves shall judge fittest, for the government of their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: own Subjects, both as they are the Common-wealth, and as they are the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Church: for both State, and Church are the same men.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: If they please therefore, they may (as many Christian Kings now doe)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: commit the government of their Subjects in matters of Religion to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Pope; but then the Pope is in that point Subordinate to them, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: exerciseth that Charge in anothers Dominion Jure Civili, in the Right of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Civill Soveraign; not Jure Divino, in Gods Right; and may therefore

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be discharged of that Office, when the Soveraign for the good of his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Subjects shall think it necessary. They may also if they please,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: commit the care of Religion to one Supreme Pastor, or to an Assembly of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Pastors; and give them what power over the Church, or one over another,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they think most convenient; and what titles of honor, as of Bishops,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Archbishops, Priests, or Presbyters, they will; and make such Laws for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their maintenance, either by Tithes, or otherwise, as they please,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: so they doe it out of a sincere conscience, of which God onely is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Judge. It is the Civill Soveraign, that is to appoint Judges, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Interpreters of the Canonicall Scriptures; for it is he that maketh them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Laws. It is he also that giveth strength to Excommunications; which but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for such Laws and Punishments, as may humble obstinate Libertines, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: reduce them to union with the rest of the Church, would bee

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: contemned. In summe, he hath the Supreme Power in all causes, as well

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ecclesiasticall, as Civill, as far as concerneth actions, and words, for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: these onely are known, and may be accused; and of that which cannot be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: accused, there is no Judg at all, but God, that knoweth the heart.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And these Rights are incident to all Soveraigns, whether Monarchs, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Assemblies: for they that are the Representants of a Christian People,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are Representants of the Church: for a Church, and a Common-wealth of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christian People, are the same thing.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Cardinal Bellarmines Books De Summo Pontifice Considered

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Though this that I have here said, and in other places of this Book,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: seem cleer enough for the asserting of the Supreme Ecclesiasticall Power

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to Christian Soveraigns; yet because the Pope of Romes challenge to that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Power universally, hath been maintained chiefly, and I think as strongly

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as is possible, by Cardinall Bellarmine, in his Controversie De Summo

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Pontifice; I have thought it necessary, as briefly as I can, to examine

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the grounds, and strength of his Discourse.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The First Book

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of five Books he hath written of this subject, the first containeth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: three Questions: One, Which is simply the best government, Monarchy,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Aristocracy, or Democracy; and concludeth for neither, but for a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: government mixt of all there: Another, which of these is the best

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Government of the Church; and concludeth for the mixt, but which should

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: most participate of Monarchy: the third, whether in this mixt Monarchy,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: St. Peter had the place of Monarch. Concerning his first Conclusion, I

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have already sufficiently proved (chapt. 18.) that all Governments which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: men are bound to obey, are Simple, and Absolute. In Monarchy there is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but One Man Supreme; and all other men that have any kind of Power in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the State, have it by his Commission, during his pleasure; and execute

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it in his name: And in Aristocracy, and Democracy, but One Supreme

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Assembly, with the same Power that in Monarchy belongeth to the Monarch,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which is not a Mixt, but an Absolute Soveraignty. And of the three

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sorts, which is the best, is not to be disputed, where any one of them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is already established; but the present ought alwaies to be preferred,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: maintained, and accounted best; because it is against both the Law of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nature, and the Divine positive Law, to doe any thing tending to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: subversion thereof. Besides, it maketh nothing to the Power of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: any Pastor, (unlesse he have the Civill Soveraignty,) what kind of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Government is the best; because their Calling is not to govern men by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Commandement, but to teach them, and perswade them by Arguments, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: leave it to them to consider, whether they shall embrace, or reject the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Doctrine taught. For Monarchy, Aristocracy, and Democracy, do mark out

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: unto us three sorts of Soveraigns, not of Pastors; or, as we may say,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: three sorts of Masters of Families, not three sorts of Schoolmasters for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their children.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And therefore the second Conclusion, concerning the best form of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Government of the Church, is nothing to the question of the Popes Power

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: without his own Dominions: For in all other Common-wealths his Power (if

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hee have any at all) is that of the Schoolmaster onely, and not of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Master of the Family.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For the third Conclusion, which is, that St. Peter was Monarch of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Church, he bringeth for his chiefe argument the place of S. Matth.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (chap. 16.18, 19.) "Thou art Peter, And upon this rock I will build my

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Church, &c. And I will give thee the keyes of Heaven; whatsoever thou

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shalt bind on Earth, shall be bound in Heaven, and whatsoever thou shalt

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: loose on Earth, shall be loosed in Heaven." Which place well considered,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: proveth no more, but that the Church of Christ hath for foundation one

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: onely Article; namely, that which Peter in the name of all the Apostles

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: professing, gave occasion to our Saviour to speak the words here cited;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which that wee may cleerly understand, we are to consider, that our

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Saviour preached by himself, by John Baptist, and by his Apostles,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: nothing but this Article of Faith, "that he was the Christ;" all other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Articles requiring faith no otherwise, than as founded on that. John

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: began first, (Mat. 3.2.) preaching only this, "The Kingdome of God is at

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hand." Then our Saviour himself (Mat. 4.17.) preached the same: And to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his Twelve Apostles, when he gave them their Commission (Mat. 10.7.)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there is no mention of preaching any other Article but that. This was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the fundamentall Article, that is the Foundation of the Churches Faith.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Afterwards the Apostles being returned to him, he asketh them all, (Mat.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 16.13) not Peter onely, "Who men said he was;" and they answered, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "some said he was John the Baptist, some Elias, and others Jeremias,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or one of the Prophets:" Then (ver. 15.) he asked them all again, (not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Peter onely) "Whom say yee that I am?" Therefore Peter answered (for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them all) "Thou art Christ, the Son of the Living God;" which I said is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Foundation of the Faith of the whole Church; from which our Saviour

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: takes the occasion of saying, "Upon this stone I will build my Church;"

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: By which it is manifest, that by the Foundation-Stone of the Church, was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: meant the Fundamentall Article of the Churches Faith. But why then (will

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: some object) doth our Saviour interpose these words, "Thou art Peter"?

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: If the originall of this text had been rigidly translated, the reason

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: would easily have appeared: We are therefore to consider, that the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Apostle Simon, was surnamed Stone, (which is the signification of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Syriacke word Cephas, and of the Greek word Petrus). Our Saviour

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore after the confession of that Fundamentall Article, alluding

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to his name, said (as if it were in English) thus, Thou art "Stone," and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: upon this Stone I will build my Church: which is as much as to say, this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Article, that "I am the Christ," is the Foundation of all the Faith I

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: require in those that are to bee members of my Church: Neither is this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: allusion to a name, an unusuall thing in common speech: But it had been

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a strange, and obscure speech, if our Saviour intending to build his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Church on the Person of St. Peter, had said, "thou art a Stone, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: upon this Stone I will build my Church," when it was so obvious without

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ambiguity to have said, "I will build my Church on thee; and yet there

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: had been still the same allusion to his name.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And for the following words, "I will give thee the Keyes of Heaven, &c."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it is no more than what our Saviour gave also to all the rest of his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Disciples (Matth. 18.18.) "Whatsoever yee shall bind on Earth, shall be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: bound in Heaven. And whatsoever ye shall loose on Earth, shall be loosed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in Heaven." But howsoever this be interpreted, there is no doubt but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Power here granted belongs to all Supreme Pastors; such as are all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christian Civill Soveraignes in their own Dominions. In so much, as if

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: St. Peter, or our Saviour himself had converted any of them to beleeve

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him, and to acknowledge his Kingdome; yet because his Kingdome is not of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: this world, he had left the supreme care of converting his subjects to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: none but him; or else hee must have deprived him of the Soveraignty,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to which the Right of Teaching is inseparably annexed. And thus much in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: refutation of his first Book, wherein hee would prove St. Peter to have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: been the Monarch Universall of the Church, that is to say, of all the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christians in the world.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Second Book

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The second Book hath two Conclusions: One, that S. Peter was Bishop

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Rome, and there dyed: The other, that the Popes of Rome are his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Successors. Both which have been disputed by others. But supposing them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to be true; yet if by Bishop of Rome bee understood either the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Monarch of the Church, or the Supreme Pastor of it; not Silvester, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Constantine (who was the first Christian Emperour) was that Bishop; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as Constantine, so all other Christian Emperors were of Right supreme

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Bishops of the Roman Empire; I say of the Roman Empire, not of all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christendome: For other Christian Soveraigns had the same Right in their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: severall Territories, as to an Office essentially adhaerent to their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraignty. Which shall serve for answer to his second Book.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Third Book

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In the third Book, he handleth the question whether the Pope be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Antichrist. For my part, I see no argument that proves he is so, in that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sense that Scripture useth the name: nor will I take any argument from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the quality of Antichrist, to contradict the Authority he exerciseth,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or hath heretofore exercised in the Dominions of any other Prince, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: State.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: It is evident that the Prophets of the Old Testament foretold, and the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Jews expected a Messiah, that is, a Christ, that should re-establish

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: amongst them the kingdom of God, which had been rejected by them in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the time of Samuel, when they required a King after the manner of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other Nations. This expectation of theirs, made them obnoxious to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Imposture of all such, as had both the ambition to attempt the attaining

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Kingdome, and the art to deceive the People by counterfeit

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: miracles, by hypocriticall life, or by orations and doctrine plausible.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Our Saviour therefore, and his Apostles forewarned men of False

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Prophets, and of False Christs. False Christs, are such as pretend to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be the Christ, but are not, and are called properly Antichrists, in such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sense, as when there happeneth a Schisme in the Church by the election

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of two Popes, the one calleth the other Antipapa, or the false Pope.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And therefore Antichrist in the proper signification hath two essentiall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: marks; One, that he denyeth Jesus to be Christ; and another that he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: professeth himselfe to bee Christ. The first Mark is set down by S. John

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in his 1 Epist. 4. ch. 3. ver. "Every Spirit that confesseth not that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Jesus Christ is come in the flesh, is not of God; And this is the Spirit

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Antichrist." The other Mark is expressed in the words of our Saviour,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (Mat. 24.5.) "Many shall come in my name, saying, I am Christ;" and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: again, "If any man shall say unto you, Loe, here is Christ, there is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christ beleeve it not." And therefore Antichrist must be a False Christ,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that is, some one of them that shall pretend themselves to be Christ.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And out of these two Marks, "to deny Jesus to be the Christ," and to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "affirm himselfe to be the Christ," it followeth, that he must also be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: an "Adversary of the true Christ," which is another usuall signification

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the word Antichrist. But of these many Antichrists, there is one

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: speciall one, O Antichristos, The Antichrist, or Antichrist definitely,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as one certaine person; not indefinitely An Antichrist. Now seeing the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Pope of Rome, neither pretendeth himself, nor denyeth Jesus to be the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christ, I perceive not how he can be called Antichrist; by which word

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is not meant, one that falsely pretendeth to be His Lieutenant, or Vicar

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Generall, but to be Hee. There is also some Mark of the time of this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: speciall Antichrist, as (Mat. 24.15.) when that abominable Destroyer,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: spoken of by Daniel, (Dan. 9. 27.) shall stand in the Holy place, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such tribulation as was not since the beginning of the world, nor ever

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shall be again, insomuch as if it were to last long, (ver. 22.) "no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: flesh could be saved; but for the elects sake those days shall be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shortened" (made fewer). But that tribulation is not yet come; for it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is to be followed immediately (ver. 29.) by a darkening of the Sun

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Moon, a falling of the Stars, a concussion of the Heavens, and the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: glorious coming again of our Saviour, in the cloudes. And therefore The

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Antichrist is not yet come; whereas, many Popes are both come and gone.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: It is true, the Pope in taking upon him to give Laws to all Christian

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kings, and Nations, usurpeth a Kingdome in this world, which Christ took

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not on him: but he doth it not As Christ, but as For Christ, wherein

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there is nothing of the Antichrist.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Fourth Book

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In the fourth Book, to prove the Pope to be the supreme Judg in all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: questions of Faith and Manners, (which is as much as to be the absolute

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Monarch of all Christians in the world,) be bringeth three Propositions:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The first, that his Judgments are Infallible: The second, that he can

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: make very Laws, and punish those that observe them not: The third, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: our Saviour conferred all Jurisdiction Ecclesiasticall on the Pope of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Rome.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Texts For The Infallibility Of The Popes Judgement In Points Of Faith

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For the Infallibility of his Judgments, he alledgeth the Scriptures: and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: first, that of Luke 22.31. "Simon, Simon, Satan hath desired you that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hee may sift you as wheat; but I have prayed for thee, that thy faith

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: faile not; and when thou art converted, strengthen thy Brethren." This,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: according to Bellarmines exposition, is, that Christ gave here to Simon

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Peter two priviledges: one, that neither his Faith should fail, neither

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he, nor any of his successors should ever define any point concerning

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Faith, or Manners erroneously, or contrary to the definition of a former

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Pope: Which is a strange, and very much strained interpretation. But he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that with attention readeth that chapter, shall find there is no place

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the whole Scripture, that maketh more against the Popes Authority,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: than this very place. The Priests and Scribes seeking to kill our

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Saviour at the Passeover, and Judas possessed with a resolution to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: betray him, and the day of killing the Passeover being come, our Saviour

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: celebrated the same with his Apostles, which he said, till the Kingdome

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of God was come hee would doe no more; and withall told them, that one

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of them was to betray him: Hereupon they questioned, which of them it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: should be; and withall (seeing the next Passeover their Master would

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: celebrate should be when he was King) entred into a contention, who

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: should then be the greater man. Our Saviour therefore told them, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Kings of the Nations had Dominion over their Subjects, and are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: called by a name (in Hebrew) that signifies Bountifull; but I cannot

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be so to you, you must endeavour to serve one another; I ordain you a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kingdome, but it is such as my Father hath ordained mee; a Kingdome that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: I am now to purchase with my blood, and not to possesse till my second

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: coming; then yee shall eat and drink at my Table, and sit on Thrones,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: judging the twelve Tribes of Israel: And then addressing himself to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: St. Peter, he saith, Simon, Simon, Satan seeks by suggesting a present

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: domination, to weaken your faith of the future; but I have prayed for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thee, that thy faith shall not fail; Thou therefore (Note this,) being

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: converted, and understanding my Kingdome as of another world, confirm

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the same faith in thy Brethren: To which S. Peter answered (as one that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: no more expected any authority in this world) "Lord I am ready to goe

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with thee, not onely to Prison, but to Death." Whereby it is manifest,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: S. Peter had not onely no jurisdiction given him in this world, but a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: charge to teach all the other Apostles, that they also should have none.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And for the Infallibility of St. Peters sentence definitive in matter

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Faith, there is no more to be attributed to it out of this Text, than

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that Peter should continue in the beleef of this point, namely, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christ should come again, and possesse the Kingdome at the day of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Judgement; which was not given by the Text to all his Successors; for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: wee see they claim it in the World that now is.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The second place is that of Matth. 16. "Thou art Peter, and upon this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: rocke I will build my Church, and the gates of Hell shall not prevail

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: against it." By which (as I have already shewn in this chapter) is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: proved no more, than that the gates of Hell shall not prevail against

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the confession of Peter, which gave occasion to that speech; namely

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: this, That Jesus Is Christ The Sonne Of God.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The third text is John 21. ver. 16,17. "Feed my sheep;" which contains

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: no more but a Commission of Teaching: And if we grant the rest of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Apostles to be contained in that name of Sheep; then it is the supreme

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Power of Teaching: but it was onely for the time that there were no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christian Soveraigns already possessed of that Supremacy. But I have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: already proved, that Christian Soveraignes are in their owne Dominions

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the supreme Pastors, and instituted thereto, by vertue of their being

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Baptized, though without other Imposition of Hands. For such imposition

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: being a Ceremony of designing the person, is needlesse, when hee is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: already designed to the Power of Teaching what Doctrine he will, by his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: institution to an Absolute Power over his Subjects. For as I have proved

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: before, Soveraigns are supreme Teachers (in generall) by their Office

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and therefore oblige themselves (by their Baptisme) to teach the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Doctrine of Christ: And when they suffer others to teach their people,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they doe it at the perill of their own souls; for it is at the hands

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Heads of Families that God will require the account of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: instruction of his Children and Servants. It is of Abraham himself,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not of a hireling, that God saith (Gen. 18.19) "I know him that he will

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: command his Children, and his houshold after him, that they keep the way

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Lord, and do justice and judgement.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The fourth place is that of Exod. 28.30. "Thou shalt put in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Breastplate of Judgment, the Urim and the Thummin:" which hee saith is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: interpreted by the Septuagint, delosin kai aletheian, that is, Evidence

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Truth: And thence concludeth, God had given Evidence, and Truth,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (which is almost infallibility,) to the High Priest. But be it Evidence

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Truth it selfe that was given; or be it but Admonition to the Priest

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to endeavour to inform himself cleerly, and give judgment uprightly;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: yet in that it was given to the High Priest, it was given to the Civill

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign: For next under God was the High Priest in the Common-wealth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Israel; and is an argument for Evidence and Truth, that is, for the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ecclesiasticall Supremacy of Civill Soveraigns over their own Subjects,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: against the pretended Power of the Pope. These are all the Texts hee

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: bringeth for the Infallibility of the Judgement of the Pope, in point of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Faith.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Texts For The Same In Point Of Manners

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For the Infallibility of his Judgment concerning Manners, hee bringeth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: one Text, which is that of John 16.13. "When the Spirit of truth is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: come, hee will lead you into all truth" where (saith he) by All Truth,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is meant, at least, All Truth Necessary To Salvation. But with this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: mitigation, he attributeth no more Infallibility to the Pope, than to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: any man that professeth Christianity, and is not to be damned: For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: if any man erre in any point, wherein not to erre is necessary to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Salvation, it is impossible he should be saved; for that onely is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: necessary to Salvation, without which to be saved is impossible. What

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: points these are, I shall declare out of the Scripture in the Chapter

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: following. In this place I say no more, but that though it were granted,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Pope could not possibly teach any error at all, yet doth not this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: entitle him to any Jurisdiction in the Dominions of another Prince,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: unlesse we shall also say, a man is obliged in conscience to set on

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: work upon all occasions the best workman, even then also when he hath

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: formerly promised his work to another.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Besides the Text, he argueth from Reason, thus, If the Pope could erre

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in necessaries, then Christ hath not sufficiently provided for the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Churches Salvation; because he hath commanded her to follow the Popes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: directions. But this Reason is invalid, unlesse he shew when, and where

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christ commanded that, or took at all any notice of a Pope: Nay granting

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whatsoever was given to S. Peter was given to the Pope; yet seeing there

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is in the Scripture no command to any man to obey St. Peter, no man can

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: bee just, that obeyeth him, when his commands are contrary to those of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his lawfull Soveraign.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lastly, it hath not been declared by the Church, nor by the Pope

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: himselfe, that he is the Civill Soveraign of all the Christians in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: world; and therefore all Christians are not bound to acknowledge his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Jurisdiction in point of Manners. For the Civill Soveraignty, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: supreme Judicature in controversies of Manners, are the same thing: And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Makers of Civill Laws, are not onely Declarers, but also Makers

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the justice, and injustice of actions; there being nothing in mens

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Manners that makes them righteous, or unrighteous, but their conformity

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with the Law of the Soveraign. And therefore when the Pope challengeth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Supremacy in controversies of Manners, hee teacheth men to disobey the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Civill Soveraign; which is an erroneous Doctrine, contrary to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: many precepts of our Saviour and his Apostles, delivered to us in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Scripture.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To prove the Pope has Power to make Laws, he alledgeth many places; as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: first, Deut. 17.12. "The man that will doe presumptuously, and will not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hearken unto the Priest, (that standeth to Minister there before the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lord thy God, or unto the Judge,) even that man shall die, and thou

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shalt put away the evill from Israel." For answer whereunto, we are to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: remember that the High Priest (next and immediately under God) was the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Civill Soveraign; and all Judges were to be constituted by him. The

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: words alledged sound therefore thus. "The man that will presume to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: disobey the Civill Soveraign for the time being, or any of his Officers

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the execution of their places, that man shall die, &c." which is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: cleerly for the Civill Soveraignty, against the Universall power of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Pope.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Secondly, he alledgeth that of Matth. 16. "Whatsoever yee shall bind,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: &c." and interpreteth it for such Binding as is attributed (Matth.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 23.4.) to the Scribes and Pharisees, "They bind heavy burthens, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: grievous to be born, and lay them on mens shoulders;" by which is meant

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (he sayes) Making of Laws; and concludes thence, the Pope can make

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Laws. But this also maketh onely for the Legislative power of Civill

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraigns: For the Scribes, and Pharisees sat in Moses Chaire,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but Moses next under God was Soveraign of the People of Israel: and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore our Saviour commanded them to doe all that they should say,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but not all that they should do. That is, to obey their Laws, but not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: follow their Example.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The third place, is John 21.16. "Feed my sheep;" which is not a Power

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to make Laws, but a command to Teach. Making Laws belongs to the Lord of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Family; who by his owne discretion chooseth his Chaplain, as also a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Schoolmaster to Teach his children.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The fourth place John 20.21. is against him. The words are, "As my

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Father sent me, so send I you." But our Saviour was sent to Redeem (by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his Death) such as should Beleeve; and by his own, and his Apostles

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: preaching to prepare them for their entrance into his Kingdome; which he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: himself saith, is not of this world, and hath taught us to pray for the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: coming of it hereafter, though hee refused (Acts 1.6,7.) to tell his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Apostles when it should come; and in which, when it comes, the twelve

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Apostles shall sit on twelve Thrones (every one perhaps as high as that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of St. Peter) to judge the twelve tribes of Israel. Seeing then God the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Father sent not our Saviour to make Laws in this present world, wee may

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: conclude from the Text, that neither did our Saviour send S. Peter to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: make Laws here, but to perswade men to expect his second comming with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a stedfast faith; and in the mean time, if Subjects, to obey their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Princes; and if Princes, both to beleeve it themselves, and to do their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: best to make their Subjects doe the same; which is the Office of a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Bishop. Therefore this place maketh most strongly for the joining of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ecclesiasticall Supremacy to the Civill Soveraignty, contrary to that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which Cardinall Bellarmine alledgeth it for.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The fift place is Acts 15.28. "It hath seemed good to the Holy Spirit,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and to us, to lay upon you no greater burden, than these necessary

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: things, that yee abstaine from meats offered to Idols, and from bloud,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and from things strangled, and from fornication." Here hee notes the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: word Laying Of Burdens for the Legislative Power. But who is there,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that reading this Text, can say, this stile of the Apostles may not as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: properly be used in giving Counsell, as in making Laws? The stile of a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Law is, We Command: But, We Think Good, is the ordinary stile of them,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that but give Advice; and they lay a Burthen that give Advice, though

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it bee conditionall, that is, if they to whom they give it, will

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: attain their ends: And such is the Burthen, of abstaining from things

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: strangled, and from bloud; not absolute, but in case they will not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: erre. I have shewn before (chap. 25.) that Law, is distinguished from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Counsell, in this, that the reason of a Law, is taken from the designe,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and benefit of him that prescribeth it; but the reason of a Counsell,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from the designe, and benefit of him, to whom the Counsell is given. But

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: here, the Apostles aime onely at the benefit of the converted Gentiles,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: namely their Salvation; not at their own benefit; for having done their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: endeavour, they shall have their reward, whether they be obeyed, or not.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And therefore the Acts of this Councell, were not Laws, but Counsells.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The sixt place is that of Rom. 13. "Let every Soul be subject to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Higher Powers, for there is no Power but of God;" which is meant, he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: saith not onely of Secular, but also of Ecclesiasticall Princes. To

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which I answer, first, that there are no Ecclesiasticall Princes but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: those that are also Civill Soveraignes; and their Principalities exceed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not the compasse of their Civill Soveraignty; without those bounds

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: though they may be received for Doctors, they cannot be acknowledged for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Princes. For if the Apostle had meant, we should be subject both to our

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: own Princes, and also to the Pope, he had taught us a doctrine, which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christ himself hath told us is impossible, namely, "to serve two

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Masters." And though the Apostle say in another place, "I write these

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: things being absent, lest being present I should use sharpnesse,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: according to the Power which the Lord hath given me;" it is not, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he challenged a Power either to put to death, imprison, banish, whip,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or fine any of them, which are Punishments; but onely to Excommunicate,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which (without the Civill Power) is no more but a leaving of their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: company, and having no more to doe with them, than with a Heathen man,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or a Publican; which in many occasions might be a greater pain to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Excommunicant, than to the Excommunicate.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The seventh place is 1 Cor. 4.21. "Shall I come unto you with a Rod, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in love, and the spirit of lenity?" But here again, it is not the Power

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of a Magistrate to punish offenders, that is meant by a Rod; but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: onely the Power of Excommunication, which is not in its owne nature

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Punishment, but onely a Denouncing of punishment, that Christ shall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: inflict, when he shall be in possession of his Kingdome, at the day of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Judgment. Nor then also shall it bee properly a Punishment, as upon a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Subject that hath broken the Law; but a Revenge, as upon an Enemy, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Revolter, that denyeth the Right of our Saviour to the Kingdome: And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore this proveth not the Legislative Power of any Bishop, that has

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not also the Civill Power.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The eighth place is, Timothy 3.2. "A Bishop must be the husband but of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: one wife, vigilant, sober, &c." which he saith was a Law. I thought that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: none could make a Law in the Church, but the Monarch of the Church, St.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Peter. But suppose this Precept made by the authority of St. Peter;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: yet I see no reason why to call it a Law, rather than an Advice, seeing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Timothy was not a Subject, but a Disciple of St. Paul; nor the flock

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: under the charge of Timothy, his Subjects in the Kingdome, but his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Scholars in the Schoole of Christ: If all the Precepts he giveth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Timothy, be Laws, why is not this also a Law, "Drink no longer water,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but use a little wine for thy healths sake"? And why are not also

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Precepts of good Physitians, so many Laws? but that it is not the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Imperative manner of speaking, but an absolute Subjection to a Person,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that maketh his Precept Laws.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In like manner, the ninth place, 1 Tim. 5. 19. "Against an Elder

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: receive not an accusation, but before two or three Witnesses," is a wise

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Precept, but not a Law.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The tenth place is, Luke 10.16. "He that heareth you, heareth mee; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he that despiseth you, despiseth me." And there is no doubt, but he that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: despiseth the Counsell of those that are sent by Christ, despiseth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Counsell of Christ himself. But who are those now that are sent by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christ, but such as are ordained Pastors by lawfull Authority? and who

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are lawfully ordained, that are not ordained by the Soveraign

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Pastor? and who is ordained by the Soveraign Pastor in a Christian

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth, that is not ordained by the authority of the Soveraign

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thereof? Out of this place therefore it followeth, that he which heareth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his Soveraign being a Christian, heareth Christ; and hee that despiseth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Doctrine which his King being a Christian, authorizeth, despiseth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Doctrine of Christ (which is not that which Bellarmine intendeth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: here to prove, but the contrary). But all this is nothing to a Law. Nay

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: more, a Christian King, as a Pastor, and Teacher of his Subjects, makes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not thereby his Doctrines Laws. He cannot oblige men to beleeve; though

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as a Civill Soveraign he may make Laws suitable to his Doctrine, which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: may oblige men to certain actions, and sometimes to such as they would

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not otherwise do, and which he ought not to command; and yet when

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they are commanded, they are Laws; and the externall actions done in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: obedience to them, without the inward approbation, are the actions of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Soveraign, and not of the Subject, which is in that case but as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: an instrument, without any motion of his owne at all; because God hath

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: commanded to obey them.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The eleventh, is every place, where the Apostle for Counsell, putteth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: some word, by which men use to signifie Command; or calleth the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: following of his Counsell, by the name of Obedience. And therefore they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are alledged out of 1 Cor. 11.2. "I commend you for keeping my Precepts

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as I delivered them to you." The Greek is, "I commend you for keeping

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: those things I delivered to you, as I delivered them." Which is far from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: signifying that they were Laws, or any thing else, but good Counsell.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And that of 1 Thess. 4.2. "You know what commandements we gave you:"

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: where the Greek word is paraggelias edokamen, equivalent to paredokamen,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: what wee delivered to you, as in the place next before alledged, which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: does not prove the Traditions of the Apostles, to be any more than

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Counsells; though as is said in the 8th verse, "he that despiseth them,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: despiseth not man, but God": For our Saviour himself came not to Judge,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that is, to be King in this world; but to Sacrifice himself for Sinners,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and leave Doctors in his Church, to lead, not to drive men to Christ,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: who never accepteth forced actions, (which is all the Law produceth,)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but the inward conversion of the heart; which is not the work of Laws,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but of Counsell, and Doctrine.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And that of 2 Thess. 3.14. "If any man Obey not our word by this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Epistle, note that man, and have no company with him, that he may bee

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ashamed": where from the word Obey, he would inferre, that this Epistle

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was a Law to the Thessalonians. The Epistles of the Emperours were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: indeed Laws. If therefore the Epistle of S. Paul were also a Law, they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: were to obey two Masters. But the word Obey, as it is in the Greek

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: upakouei, signifieth Hearkening To, or Putting In Practice, not onely

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that which is Commanded by him that has right to punish, but also that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which is delivered in a way of Counsell for our good; and therefore St.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Paul does not bid kill him that disobeys, nor beat, nor imprison, nor

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: amerce him, which Legislators may all do; but avoid his company, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he may bee ashamed: whereby it is evident, it was not the Empire of an

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Apostle, but his Reputation amongst the Faithfull, which the Christians

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: stood in awe of.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The last place is that of Heb. 13.17. "Obey your Leaders, and submit

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: your selves to them, for they watch for your souls, as they that must

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: give account:" And here also is intended by Obedience, a following of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their Counsell: For the reason of our Obedience, is not drawn from the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: will and command of our Pastors, but from our own benefit, as being the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Salvation of our Souls they watch for, and not for the Exaltation of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their own Power, and Authority. If it were meant here, that all they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: teach were Laws, then not onely the Pope, but every Pastor in his Parish

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: should have Legislative Power. Again, they that are bound to obey, their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Pastors, have no power to examine their commands. What then shall wee

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: say to St. John who bids us (1 Epist. chap. 4. ver. 1.) "Not to beleeve

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: every Spirit, but to try the Spirits whether they are of God, because

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: many false Prophets are gone out into the world"? It is therefore

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: manifest, that wee may dispute the Doctrine of our Pastors; but no man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: can dispute a Law. The Commands of Civill Soveraigns are on all sides

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: granted to be Laws: if any else can make a Law besides himselfe, all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth, and consequently all Peace, and Justice must cease; which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is contrary to all Laws, both Divine and Humane. Nothing therefore can

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be drawn from these, or any other places of Scripture, to prove the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Decrees of the Pope, where he has not also the Civill Soveraignty, to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Laws.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Question Of Superiority Between The Pope And Other Bishops The last

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: point hee would prove, is this, "That our Saviour Christ has committed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ecclesiasticall Jurisdiction immediately to none but the Pope." Wherein

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he handleth not the Question of Supremacy between the Pope and Christian

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kings, but between the Pope and other Bishops. And first, he sayes it is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: agreed, that the Jurisdiction of Bishops, is at least in the generall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: De Jure Divino, that is, in the Right of God; for which he alledges S.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Paul, Ephes. 4.11. where hee sayes, that Christ after his Ascension

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: into heaven, "gave gifts to men, some Apostles, some Prophets, and some

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Evangelists, and some Pastors, and some Teachers:" And thence inferres,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they have indeed their Jurisdiction in Gods Right; but will not grant

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they have it immediately from God, but derived through the Pope. But if

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a man may be said to have his Jurisdiction De Jure Divino, and yet not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: immediately; what lawfull Jurisdiction, though but Civill, is there in a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christian Common-wealth, that is not also De Jure Divino? For Christian

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kings have their Civill Power from God immediately; and the Magistrates

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: under him exercise their severall charges in vertue of his Commission;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: wherein that which they doe, is no lesse De Jure Divino Mediato, than

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that which the Bishops doe, in vertue of the Popes Ordination. All

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: lawfull Power is of God, immediately in the Supreme Governour, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: mediately in those that have Authority under him: So that either hee

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: must grant every Constable in the State, to hold his Office in the Right

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of God; or he must not hold that any Bishop holds his so, besides the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Pope himselfe.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But this whole Dispute, whether Christ left the Jurisdiction to the Pope

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: onely, or to other Bishops also, if considered out of these places where

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Pope has the Civill Soveraignty, is a contention De Lana Caprina:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For none of them (where they are not Soveraigns) has any Jurisdiction

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: at all. For Jurisdiction is the Power of hearing and determining Causes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: between man and man; and can belong to none, but him that hath the Power

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to prescribe the Rules of Right and Wrong; that is, to make Laws;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and with the Sword of Justice to compell men to obey his Decisions,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: pronounced either by himself, or by the Judges he ordaineth thereunto;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which none can lawfully do, but the Civill Soveraign.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Therefore when he alledgeth out of the 6 of Luke, that our Saviour

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: called his Disciples together, and chose twelve of them which he named

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Apostles, he proveth that he Elected them (all, except Matthias, Paul

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Barnabas,) and gave them Power and Command to Preach, but not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to Judge of Causes between man and man: for that is a Power which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he refused to take upon himselfe, saying, "Who made me a Judge, or a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Divider, amongst you?" and in another place, "My Kingdome is not of this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: world." But hee that hath not the Power to hear, and determine Causes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: between man and man, cannot be said to have any Jurisdiction at all. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: yet this hinders not, but that our Saviour gave them Power to Preach and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Baptize in all parts of the world, supposing they were not by their own

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: lawfull Soveraign forbidden: For to our own Soveraigns Christ himself,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and his Apostles have in sundry places expressely commanded us in all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: things to be obedient.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The arguments by which he would prove, that Bishops receive their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Jurisdiction from the Pope (seeing the Pope in the Dominions of other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Princes hath no Jurisdiction himself,) are all in vain. Yet because they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: prove, on the contrary, that all Bishops receive Jurisdiction when they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have it from their Civill Soveraigns, I will not omit the recitall of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The first, is from Numbers 11. where Moses not being able alone to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: undergoe the whole burthen of administring the affairs of the People of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Israel, God commanded him to choose Seventy Elders, and took part of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the spirit of Moses, to put it upon those Seventy Elders: by which it is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: understood, not that God weakened the spirit of Moses, for that had not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: eased him at all; but that they had all of them their authority from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him; wherein he doth truly, and ingenuously interpret that place. But

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: seeing Moses had the entire Soveraignty in the Common-wealth of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Jews, it is manifest, that it is thereby signified, that they had their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Authority from the Civill Soveraign: and therefore that place proveth,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that Bishops in every Christian Common-wealth have their Authority from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Civill Soveraign; and from the Pope in his own Territories only, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not in the Territories of any other State.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The second argument, is from the nature of Monarchy; wherein all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Authority is in one Man, and in others by derivation from him: But the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Government of the Church, he says, is Monarchicall. This also makes for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christian Monarchs. For they are really Monarchs of their own people;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that is, of their own Church (for the Church is the same thing with a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christian people;) whereas the Power of the Pope, though hee were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: S. Peter, is neither Monarchy, nor hath any thing of Archicall, nor

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Craticall, but onely of Didacticall; For God accepteth not a forced, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a willing obedience.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The third, is, from that the Sea of S. Peter is called by S. Cyprian,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Head, the Source, the Roote, the Sun, from whence the Authority

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Bishops is derived. But by the Law of Nature (which is a better

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Principle of Right and Wrong, than the word of any Doctor that is but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a man) the Civill Soveraign in every Common-wealth, is the Head, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Source, the Root, and the Sun, from which all Jurisdiction is derived.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And therefore, the Jurisdiction of Bishops, is derived from the Civill

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The fourth, is taken from the Inequality of their Jurisdictions: For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: if God (saith he) had given it them immediately, he had given aswell

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Equality of Jurisdiction, as of Order: But wee see, some are Bishops but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of own Town, some of a hundred Towns, and some of many whole Provinces;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which differences were not determined by the command of God; their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Jurisdiction therefore is not of God, but of Man; and one has a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: greater, another a lesse, as it pleaseth the Prince of the Church. Which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: argument, if he had proved before, that the Pope had had an Universall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Jurisdiction over all Christians, had been for his purpose. But seeing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that hath not been proved, and that it is notoriously known, the large

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Jurisdiction of the Pope was given him by those that had it, that is,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by the Emperours of Rome, (for the Patriarch of Constantinople, upon the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: same title, namely, of being Bishop of the Capitall City of the Empire,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Seat of the Emperour, claimed to be equal to him,) it followeth,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that all other Bishops have their Jurisdiction from the Soveraigns of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the place wherein they exercise the same: And as for that cause they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have not their Authority De Jure Divino; so neither hath the Pope his De

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Jure Divino, except onely where hee is also the Civill Soveraign.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: His fift argument is this, "If Bishops have their Jurisdiction

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: immediately from God, the Pope could not take it from them, for he can

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: doe nothing contrary to Gods ordination;" And this consequence is good,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and well proved. "But, (saith he) the Pope can do this, and has done

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it." This also is granted, so he doe it in his own Dominions, or in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Dominions of any other Prince that hath given him that Power; but not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: universally, in Right of the Popedome: For that power belongeth to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: every Christian Soveraign, within the bounds of his owne Empire, and is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: inseparable from the Soveraignty. Before the People of Israel had (by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the commandment of God to Samuel) set over themselves a King, after the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: manner of other Nations, the High Priest had the Civill Government; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: none but he could make, nor depose an inferiour Priest: But that Power

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was afterwards in the King, as may be proved by this same argument of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Bellarmine; For if the Priest (be he the High Priest or any other) had

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his Jurisdiction immediately from God, then the King could not take it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from him; "for he could do nothing contrary to Gods ordinance: But it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is certain, that King Solomon (1 Kings 2.26.) deprived Abiathar the High

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Priest of his office, and placed Zadok (verse 35.) in his room. Kings

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore may in the like manner Ordaine, and Deprive Bishops, as they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shall thinke fit, for the well governing of their Subjects.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: His sixth argument is this, If Bishops have their Jurisdiction De Jure

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Divino (that is, immediately from God,) they that maintaine it, should

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: bring some Word of God to prove it: But they can bring none. The

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: argument is good; I have therefore nothing to say against it. But it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is an argument no lesse good, to prove the Pope himself to have no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Jurisdiction in the Dominion of any other Prince.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lastly, hee bringeth for argument, the testimony of two Popes, Innocent,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Leo; and I doubt not but hee might have alledged, with as good

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: reason, the testimonies of all the Popes almost since S. Peter: For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: considering the love of Power naturally implanted in mankind, whosoever

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: were made Pope, he would be tempted to uphold the same opinion.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Neverthelesse, they should therein but doe, as Innocent, and Leo did,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: bear witnesse of themselves, and therefore their witness should not be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: good.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of The Popes Temporall Power

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In the fift Book he hath four Conclusions. The first is, "That the Pope

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in not Lord of all the world:" the second, "that the Pope is not Lord

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of all the Christian world:" The third, "That the Pope (without his owne

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Territory) has not any Temporall Jurisdiction DIRECTLY:" These three

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Conclusions are easily granted. The fourth is, "That the Pope has (in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Dominions of other Princes) the Supreme Temporall Power INDIRECTLY:"

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which is denyed; unlesse he mean by Indirectly, that he has gotten it by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Indirect means; then is that also granted. But I understand, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: when he saith he hath it Indirectly, he means, that such Temporall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Jurisdiction belongeth to him of Right, but that this Right is but a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Consequence of his Pastorall Authority, the which he could not exercise,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: unlesse he have the other with it: And therefore to the Pastorall Power

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (which he calls Spirituall) the Supreme Power Civill is necessarily

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: annexed; and that thereby hee hath a Right to change Kingdomes, giving

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them to one, and taking them from another, when he shall think it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: conduces to the Salvation of Souls.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Before I come to consider the Arguments by which hee would prove this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: doctrine, it will not bee amisse to lay open the Consequences of it;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that Princes, and States, that have the Civill Soveraignty in their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: severall Common-wealths, may bethink themselves, whether it bee

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: convenient for them, and conducing to the good of their Subjects, of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whom they are to give an account at the day of Judgment, to admit the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: same.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: When it is said, the Pope hath not (in the Territories of other States)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Supreme Civill Power Directly; we are to understand, he doth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not challenge it, as other Civill Soveraigns doe, from the originall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: submission thereto of those that are to be governed. For it is evident,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and has already been sufficiently in this Treatise demonstrated, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Right of all Soveraigns, is derived originally from the consent of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: every one of those that are to bee governed; whether they that choose

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him, doe it for their common defence against an Enemy, as when they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: agree amongst themselves to appoint a Man, or an Assembly of men to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: protect them; or whether they doe it, to save their lives, by submission

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to a conquering Enemy. The Pope therefore, when he disclaimeth the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Supreme Civill Power over other States Directly, denyeth no more, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that his Right cometh to him by that way; He ceaseth not for all that,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to claime it another way; and that is, (without the consent of them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that are to be governed) by a Right given him by God, (which hee calleth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Indirectly,) in his Assumption to the Papacy. But by what way soever he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: pretend, the Power is the same; and he may (if it bee granted to be his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Right) depose Princes and States, as often as it is for the Salvation

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Soules, that is, as often as he will; for he claimeth also the Sole

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Power to Judge, whether it be to the salvation of mens Souls, or not.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And this is the Doctrine, not onely that Bellarmine here, and many other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Doctors teach in their Sermons and Books, but also that some

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Councells have decreed, and the Popes have decreed, and the Popes have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: accordingly, when the occasion hath served them, put in practise. For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the fourth Councell of Lateran held under Pope Innocent the third, (in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the third Chap. De Haereticis,) hath this Canon. "If a King at the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Popes admonition, doe not purge his Kingdome of Haeretiques, and being

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Excommunicate for the same, make not satisfaction within a year, his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: subjects are absolved of their Obedience." And the practise hereof hath

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: been seen on divers occasions; as in the Deposing of Chilperique, King

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of France; in the Translation of the Roman Empire to Charlemaine; in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Oppression of John King of England; in Transferring the Kingdome

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Navarre; and of late years, in the League against Henry the third of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: France, and in many more occurrences. I think there be few Princes that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consider not this as Injust, and Inconvenient; but I wish they would

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all resolve to be Kings, or Subjects. Men cannot serve two Masters: They

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ought therefore to ease them, either by holding the Reins of Government

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: wholly in their own hands; or by wholly delivering them into the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hands of the Pope; that such men as are willing to be obedient, may be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: protected in their obedience. For this distinction of Temporall, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Spirituall Power is but words. Power is as really divided, and as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: dangerously to all purposes, by sharing with another Indirect Power, as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with a Direct one. But to come now to his Arguments.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The first is this, "The Civill Power is subject to the Spirituall:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Therefore he that hath the Supreme Power Spirituall, hath right to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: command Temporall Princes, and dispose of their Temporalls in order to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Spirituall. As for the distinction of Temporall, and Spirituall,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: let us consider in what sense it may be said intelligibly, that the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Temporall, or Civill Power is subject to the Spirituall. There be but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: two ways that those words can be made sense. For when wee say, one Power

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is subject to another Power, the meaning either is, that he which hath

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the one, is subject to him that hath the other; or that the one Power is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to the other, as the means to the end. For wee cannot understand, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: one Power hath Power over another Power; and that one Power can have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Right or Command over another: For Subjection, Command, Right, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Power are accidents, not of Powers, but of Persons: One Power may be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: subordinate to another, as the art of a Sadler, to the art of a Rider.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: If then it be granted, that the Civill Government be ordained as a means

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to bring us to a Spirituall felicity; yet it does not follow, that if a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: King have the Civill Power, and the Pope the Spirituall, that therefore

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the King is bound to obey the Pope, more then every Sadler is bound to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: obey every Rider. Therefore as from Subordination of an Art, cannot be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: inferred the Subjection of the Professor; so from the Subordination of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Government, cannot be inferred the Subjection of the Governor. When

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore he saith, the Civill Power is Subject to the Spirituall, his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: meaning is, that the Civill Soveraign, is Subject to the Spirituall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign. And the Argument stands thus, "The Civil Soveraign, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: subject to the Spirituall; Therefore the Spirituall Prince may

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: command Temporall Princes." Where the conclusion is the same, with the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Antecedent he should have proved. But to prove it, he alledgeth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: first, this reason, "Kings and Popes, Clergy and Laity make but one

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth; that is to say, but one Church: And in all Bodies the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Members depend one upon another: But things Spirituall depend not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of things Temporall: Therefore, Temporall depend on Spirituall. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore are Subject to them." In which Argumentation there be two

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: grosse errours: one is, that all Christian Kings, Popes, Clergy, and all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other Christian men, make but one Common-wealth: For it is evident that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: France is one Common-wealth, Spain another, and Venice a third, &c. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: these consist of Christians; and therefore also are severall Bodies

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Christians; that is to say, severall Churches: And their severall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraigns Represent them, whereby they are capable of commanding and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: obeying, of doing and suffering, as a natural man; which no Generall or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Universall Church is, till it have a Representant; which it hath not on

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Earth: for if it had, there is no doubt but that all Christendome were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: one Common-wealth, whose Soveraign were that Representant, both in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: things Spirituall and Temporall: And the Pope, to make himself this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Representant, wanteth three things that our Saviour hath not given

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him, to Command, and to Judge, and to Punish, otherwise than (by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Excommunication) to run from those that will not Learn of him: For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: though the Pope were Christs onely Vicar, yet he cannot exercise his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: government, till our Saviours second coming: And then also it is not the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Pope, but St. Peter himselfe, with the other Apostles, that are to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Judges of the world.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The other errour in this his first Argument is, that he sayes, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Members of every Common-wealth, as of a naturall Body, depend one of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: another: It is true, they cohaere together; but they depend onely on the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign, which is the Soul of the Common-wealth; which failing, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth is dissolved into a Civill war, no one man so much

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as cohaering to another, for want of a common Dependance on a known

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign; Just as the Members of the naturall Body dissolve into Earth,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for want of a Soul to hold them together. Therefore there is nothing in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: this similitude, from whence to inferre a dependance of the Laity on the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Clergy, or of the Temporall Officers on the Spirituall; but of both on

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Civill Soveraign; which ought indeed to direct his Civill commands

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to the Salvation of Souls; but is not therefore subject to any but God

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: himselfe. And thus you see the laboured fallacy of the first Argument,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to deceive such men as distinguish not between the Subordination of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Actions in the way to the End; and the Subjection of Persons one to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: another in the administration of the Means. For to every End, the Means

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are determined by Nature, or by God himselfe supernaturally: but the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Power to make men use the Means, is in every nation resigned (by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Law of Nature, which forbiddeth men to violate their Faith given) to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Civill Soveraign.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: His second Argument is this, "Every Common-wealth, (because it is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: supposed to be perfect and sufficient in it self,) may command any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other Common-wealth, not subject to it, and force it to change the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: administration of the Government, nay depose the Prince, and set another

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in his room, if it cannot otherwise defend it selfe against the injuries

author: Thomas Hobbes
