text: he goes about to doe them: much more may a Spirituall Common-wealth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: command a Temporall one to change the administration of their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Government, and may depose Princes, and institute others, when they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: cannot otherwise defend the Spirituall Good."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: That a Common-wealth, to defend it selfe against injuries, may lawfully

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: doe all that he hath here said, is very true; and hath already in that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which hath gone before been sufficiently demonstrated. And if it were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: also true, that there is now in this world a Spirituall Common-wealth,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: distinct from a Civill Common-wealth, then might the Prince thereof,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: upon injury done him, or upon want of caution that injury be not done

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him in time to come, repaire, and secure himself by Warre; which is in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: summe, deposing, killing, or subduing, or doing any act of Hostility.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But by the same reason, it would be no lesse lawfull for a Civill

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign, upon the like injuries done, or feared, to make warre

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: upon the Spirituall Soveraign; which I beleeve is more than Cardinall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Bellarmine would have inferred from his own proposition.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But Spirituall Common-wealth there is none in this world: for it is the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: same thing with the Kingdome of Christ; which he himselfe saith, is not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of this world; but shall be in the next world, at the Resurrection, when

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they that have lived justly, and beleeved that he was the Christ, shall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (though they died Naturall bodies) rise Spirituall bodies; and then it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is, that our Saviour shall judge the world, and conquer his Adversaries,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and make a Spirituall Common-wealth. In the mean time, seeing there are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: no men on earth, whose bodies are Spirituall; there can be no Spirituall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth amongst men that are yet in the flesh; unlesse wee call

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Preachers, that have Commission to Teach, and prepare men for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their reception into the Kingdome of Christ at the Resurrection, a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealth; which I have proved to bee none.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The third Argument is this; "It is not lawfull for Christians to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: tolerate an Infidel, or Haereticall King, in case he endeavour to draw

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them to his Haeresie, or Infidelity. But to judge whether a King draw

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his subjects to Haeresie, or not, belongeth to the Pope. Therefore hath

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Pope Right, to determine whether the Prince be to be deposed, or not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: deposed."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To this I answer, that both these assertions are false. For Christians,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (or men of what Religion soever,) if they tolerate not their King,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whatsoever law hee maketh, though it bee concerning Religion, doe

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: violate their faith, contrary to the Divine Law, both Naturall and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Positive: Nor is there any Judge of Haeresie amongst Subjects, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their own Civill Soveraign; for "Haeresie is nothing else, but a private

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: opinion, obstinately maintained, contrary to the opinion which the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Publique Person (that is to say, the Representant of the Common-wealth)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hath commanded to bee taught." By which it is manifest, that an

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: opinion publiquely appointed to bee taught, cannot be Haeresie; nor the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign Princes that authorize them, Haeretiques. For Haeretiques are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: none but private men, that stubbornly defend some Doctrine, prohibited

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by their lawful Soveraigns.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But to prove that Christians are not to tolerate Infidell, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Haereticall Kings, he alledgeth a place in Deut. 17. where God

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: forbiddeth the Jews, when they shall set a King over themselves, to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: choose a stranger; And from thence inferreth, that it is unlawfull for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Christian, to choose a King, that is not a Christian. And 'tis true,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that he that is a Christian, that is, hee that hath already obliged

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: himself to receive our Saviour when he shall come, for his King, shal

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: tempt God too much in choosing for King in this world, one that hee

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: knoweth will endeavour, both by terrour, and perswasion to make him

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: violate his faith. But, it is (saith hee) the same danger, to choose one

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that is not a Christian, for King, and not to depose him, when hee

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is chosen. To this I say, the question is not of the danger of not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: deposing; but of the Justice of deposing him. To choose him, may in some

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: cases bee unjust; but to depose him, when he is chosen, is in no case

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Just. For it is alwaies violation of faith, and consequently against the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Law of Nature, which is the eternal Law of God. Nor doe wee read, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: any such Doctrine was accounted Christian in the time of the Apostles;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: nor in the time of the Romane Emperours, till the Popes had the Civill

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraignty of Rome. But to this he hath replyed, that the Christians of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: old, deposed not Nero, nor Diocletian, nor Julian, nor Valens an Arrian,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for this cause onely, that they wanted Temporall forces. Perhaps so. But

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: did our Saviour, who for calling for, might have had twelve Legions

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of immortall, invulnerable Angels to assist him, want forces to depose

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Caesar, or at least Pilate, that unjustly, without finding fault in him,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: delivered him to the Jews to bee crucified? Or if the Apostles wanted

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Temporall forces to depose Nero, was it therefore necessary for them in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their Epistles to the new made Christians, to teach them, (as they did)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to obey the Powers constituted over them, (whereof Nero in that time was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: one,) and that they ought to obey them, not for fear of their wrath,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but for conscience sake? Shall we say they did not onely obey, but also

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: teach what they meant not, for want of strength? It is not therefore

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for want of strength, but for conscience sake, that Christians are to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: tolerate their Heathen Princes, or Princes (for I cannot call any one

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whose Doctrine is the Publique Doctrine, an Haeretique) that authorize

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the teaching of an Errour. And whereas for the Temporall Power of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Pope, he alledgeth further, that St. Paul (1 Cor. 6.) appointed Judges

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: under the Heathen Princes of those times, such as were not ordained by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: those Princes; it is not true. For St. Paul does but advise them,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to take some of their Brethren to compound their differences, as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Arbitrators, rather than to goe to law one with another before the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Heathen Judges; which is a wholsome Precept, and full of Charity, fit

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to bee practised also in the Best Christian Common-wealths. And for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the danger that may arise to Religion, by the Subjects tolerating of an

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Heathen, or an Erring Prince, it is a point, of which a Subject is no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: competent Judge; or if hee bee, the Popes Temporall Subjects may judge

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: also of the Popes Doctrine. For every Christian Prince, as I have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: formerly proved, is no lesse Supreme Pastor of his own Subjects, than

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Pope of his.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The fourth Argument, is taken from the Baptisme of Kings; wherein, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they may be made Christians they submit their Scepters to Christ; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: promise to keep, and defend the Christian Faith. This is true; for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christian Kings are no more but Christs Subjects: but they may, for all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that, bee the Popes Fellowes; for they are Supreme Pastors of their own

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Subjects; and the Pope is no more but King, and Pastor, even in Rome it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: selfe.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The fifth Argument, is drawn from the words spoken by our Saviour, Feed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: My Sheep; by which was give all Power necessary for a Pastor; as the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Power to chase away Wolves, such as are Haeretiques; the Power to shut

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: up Rammes, if they be mad, or push at the other Sheep with their Hornes,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such as are Evill (though Christian) Kings; and Power to give the Flock

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: convenient food: From whence hee inferreth, that St. Peter had these

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: three Powers given him by Christ. To which I answer, that the last of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: these Powers, is no more than the Power, or rather Command to Teach.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For the first, which is to chase away Wolves, that is, Haeretiques, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: place hee quoteth is (Matth. 7.15.) "Beware of false Prophets which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: come to you in Sheeps clothing, but inwardly are ravening Wolves."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But neither are Haeretiques false Prophets, or at all Prophets: nor

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (admitting Haeretiques for the Wolves there meant,) were the Apostles

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: commanded to kill them, or if they were Kings, to depose them; but to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: beware of, fly, and avoid them: nor was it to St. Peter, nor to any of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Apostles, but to the multitude of the Jews that followed him into

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the mountain, men for the most part not yet converted, that hee gave

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: this Counsell, to Beware of false Prophets: which therefore if it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: conferre a Power of chasing away Kings, was given, not onely to private

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: men; but to men that were not at all Christians. And as to the Power

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Separating, and Shutting up of furious Rammes, (by which hee meaneth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christian Kings that refuse to submit themselves to the Roman Pastor,)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: our Saviour refused to take upon him that Power in this world himself,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but advised to let the Corn and Tares grow up together till the day of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Judgment: much lesse did hee give it to St. Peter, or can S. Peter give

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it to the Popes. St. Peter, and all other Pastors, are bidden to esteem

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: those Christians that disobey the Church, that is, (that disobey the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christian Soveraigne) as Heathen men, and as Publicans. Seeing then men

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: challenge to the Pope no authority over Heathen Princes, they ought to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: challenge none over those that are to bee esteemed as Heathen.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But from the Power to Teach onely, hee inferreth also a Coercive Power

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the Pope, over Kings. The Pastor (saith he) must give his flock

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: convenient food: Therefore the Pope may, and ought to compell Kings to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: doe their duty. Out of which it followeth, that the Pope, as Pastor of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christian men, is King of Kings: which all Christian Kings ought indeed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: either to Confesse, or else they ought to take upon themselves the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Supreme Pastorall Charge, every one in his own Dominion.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: His sixth, and last Argument, is from Examples. To which I answer,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: first, that Examples prove nothing; Secondly, that the Examples he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: alledgeth make not so much as a probability of Right. The fact of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Jehoiada, in Killing Athaliah (2 Kings 11.) was either by the Authority

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of King Joash, or it was a horrible Crime in the High Priest, which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (ever after the election of King Saul) was a mere Subject. The fact of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: St. Ambrose, in Excommunicating Theodosius the Emperour, (if it were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: true hee did so,) was a Capitall Crime. And for the Popes, Gregory 1.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Greg. 2. Zachary, and Leo 3. their Judgments are void, as given in their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: own Cause; and the Acts done by them conformably to this Doctrine, are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the greatest Crimes (especially that of Zachary) that are incident to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Humane Nature. And thus much of Power Ecclesiasticall; wherein I had

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: been more briefe, forbearing to examine these Arguments of Bellarmine,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: if they had been his, as a Private man, and not as the Champion of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Papacy, against all other Christian Princes, and States.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CHAPTER XLIII. OF WHAT IS NECESSARY FOR A MANS RECEPTION INTO THE

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: KINGDOME OF HEAVEN.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Difficulty Of Obeying God And Man Both At Once

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The most frequent praetext of Sedition, and Civill Warre, in Christian

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealths hath a long time proceeded from a difficulty, not yet

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sufficiently resolved, of obeying at once, both God, and Man, then

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: when their Commandements are one contrary to the other. It is manifest

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: enough, that when a man receiveth two contrary Commands, and knows that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: one of them is Gods, he ought to obey that, and not the other, though

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it be the command even of his lawfull Soveraign (whether a Monarch, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Soveraign Assembly,) or the command of his Father. The difficulty

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore consisteth in this, that men when they are commanded in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: name of God, know not in divers Cases, whether the command be from God,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or whether he that commandeth, doe but abuse Gods name for some private

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ends of his own. For as there ware in the Church of the Jews, many false

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Prophets, that sought reputation with the people, by feigned Dreams, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Visions; so there have been in all times in the Church of Christ, false

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Teachers, that seek reputation with the people, by phantasticall and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: false Doctrines; and by such reputation (as is the nature of Ambition,)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to govern them for their private benefit.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Is None To Them That Distinguish Between What Is, And What Is Not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Necessary To Salvation

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But this difficulty of obeying both God, and the Civill Soveraign on

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: earth, to those that can distinguish between what is Necessary, and what

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is not Necessary for their Reception into the Kingdome of God, is of no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: moment. For if the command of the Civill Soveraign bee such, as that it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: may be obeyed, without the forfeiture of life Eternall; not to obey it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is unjust; and the precept of the Apostle takes place; "Servants obey

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: your Masters in all things;" and, "Children obey your Parents in all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: things;" and the precept of our Saviour, "The Scribes and Pharisees sit

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in Moses Chaire, All therefore they shall say, that observe, and doe."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But if the command be such, as cannot be obeyed, without being damned

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to Eternall Death, then it were madnesse to obey it, and the Counsell

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of our Saviour takes place, (Mat. 10. 28.) "Fear not those that kill the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: body, but cannot kill the soule." All men therefore that would avoid,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: both the punishments that are to be in this world inflicted, for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: disobedience to their earthly Soveraign, and those that shall be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: inflicted in the world to come for disobedience to God, have need be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: taught to distinguish well between what is, and what is not Necessary to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Eternall Salvation.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: All That Is Necessary To Salvation Is Contained In Faith And Obedience

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: All that is NECESSARY to Salvation, is contained in two Vertues, Faith

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in Christ, and Obedience to Laws. The latter of these, if it were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: perfect, were enough to us. But because wee are all guilty of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: disobedience to Gods Law, not onely originally in Adam, but also

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: actually by our own transgressions, there is required at our hands now,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not onely Obedience for the rest of our time, but also a Remission of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sins for the time past; which Remission is the reward of our Faith

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in Christ. That nothing else is Necessarily required to Salvation, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: manifest from this, that the Kingdome of Heaven, is shut to none but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to Sinners; that is to say, to the disobedient, or transgressors of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Law; nor to them, in case they Repent, and Beleeve all the Articles of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christian Faith, Necessary to Salvation.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: What Obedience Is Necessary;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Obedience required at our hands by God, that accepteth in all our

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: actions the Will for the Deed, is a serious Endeavour to Obey him;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and is called also by all such names as signifie that Endeavour. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore Obedience, is sometimes called by the names of Charity, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Love, because they imply a Will to Obey; and our Saviour himself maketh

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: our Love to God, and to one another, a Fulfilling of the whole Law: and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sometimes by the name of Righteousnesse; for Righteousnesse is but the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: will to give to every one his owne, that is to say, the will to obey

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Laws: and sometimes by the name of Repentance; because to Repent,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: implyeth a turning away from sinne, which is the same, with the return

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the will to Obedience. Whosoever therefore unfeignedly desireth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to fulfill the Commandements of God, or repenteth him truely of his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: transgressions, or that loveth God with all his heart, and his neighbor

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as himself, hath all the Obedience Necessary to his Reception into the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kingdome of God: For if God should require perfect Innocence, there

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: could no flesh be saved.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And To What Laws

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But what Commandements are those that God hath given us? Are all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: those Laws which were given to the Jews by the hand of Moses, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Commandements of God? If they bee, why are not Christians taught to obey

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them? If they be not, what others are so, besides the Law of Nature? For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: our Saviour Christ hath not given us new Laws, but Counsell to observe

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: those wee are subject to; that is to say, the Laws of Nature, and the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Laws of our severall Soveraigns: Nor did he make any new Law to the Jews

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in his Sermon on the Mount, but onely expounded the Laws of Moses, to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which they were subject before. The Laws of God therefore are none

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but the Laws of Nature, whereof the principall is, that we should

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not violate our Faith, that is, a commandement to obey our Civill

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraigns, which wee constituted over us, by mutuall pact one with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: another. And this Law of God, that commandeth Obedience to the Law

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Civill, commandeth by consequence Obedience to all the Precepts of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Bible, which (as I have proved in the precedent Chapter) is there onely

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Law, where the Civill Soveraign hath made it so; and in other places but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Counsell; which a man at his own perill, may without injustice refuse to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: obey.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In The Faith Of A Christian, Who Is The Person Beleeved

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Knowing now what is the Obedience Necessary to Salvation, and to whom

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it is due; we are to consider next concerning Faith, whom, and why we

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: beleeve; and what are the Articles, or Points necessarily to be beleeved

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by them that shall be saved. And first, for the Person whom we beleeve,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: because it is impossible to beleeve any Person, before we know what he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: saith, it is necessary he be one that wee have heard speak. The Person

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore, whom Abraham, Isaac, Jacob, Moses and the Prophets beleeved,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was God himself, that spake unto them supernaturally: And the Person,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whom the Apostles and Disciples that conversed with Christ beleeved, was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: our Saviour himself. But of them, to whom neither God the Father, nor

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: our Saviour ever spake, it cannot be said, that the Person whom they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: beleeved, was God. They beleeved the Apostles, and after them the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Pastors and Doctors of the Church, that recommended to their faith the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: History of the Old and New Testament: so that the Faith of Christians

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ever since our Saviours time, hath had for foundation, first, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: reputation of their Pastors, and afterward, the authority of those that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: made the Old and New Testament to be received for the Rule of Faith;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which none could do but Christian Soveraignes; who are therefore the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Supreme Pastors, and the onely Persons, whom Christians now hear speak

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from God; except such as God speaketh to, in these days supernaturally.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But because there be many false Prophets "gone out into the world,"

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other men are to examine such Spirits (as St. John advised us, 1

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Epistle, Chap. 4. ver.1.) "whether they be of God, or not." And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore, seeing the Examination of Doctrines belongeth to the Supreme

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Pastor, the Person which all they that have no speciall revelation are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to beleeve, is (in every Common-wealth) the Supreme Pastor, that is to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: say, the Civill Soveraigne.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Causes Of Christian Faith

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The causes why men beleeve any Christian Doctrine, are various; For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Faith is the gift of God; and he worketh it in each severall man, by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such wayes, as it seemeth good unto himself. The most ordinary immediate

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: cause of our beleef, concerning any point of Christian Faith, is, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: wee beleeve the Bible to be the Word of God. But why wee beleeve the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Bible to be the Word of God, is much disputed, as all questions must

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: needs bee, that are not well stated. For they make not the question

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to be, "Why we Beleeve it," but "How wee Know it;" as if Beleeving and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Knowing were all one. And thence while one side ground their Knowledge

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: upon the Infallibility of the Church, and the other side, on the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Testimony of the Private Spirit, neither side concludeth what it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: pretends. For how shall a man know the Infallibility of the Church, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by knowing first the Infallibility of the Scripture? Or how shall a man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: know his own Private spirit to be other than a beleef, grounded upon the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Authority, and Arguments of his Teachers; or upon a Presumption of his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: own Gifts? Besides, there is nothing in the Scripture, from which can be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: inferred the Infallibility of the Church; much lesse, of any particular

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Church; and least of all, the Infallibility of any particular man.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Faith Comes By Hearing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: It is manifest, therefore, that Christian men doe not know, but onely

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: beleeve the Scripture to be the Word of God; and that the means of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: making them beleeve which God is pleased to afford men ordinarily, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: according to the way of Nature, that is to say, from their Teachers.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: It is the Doctrine of St. Paul concerning Christian Faith in generall,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (Rom. 10.17.) "Faith cometh by Hearing," that is, by Hearing our lawfull

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Pastors. He saith also (ver. 14,15. of the same Chapter) "How shall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they beleeve in him of whom they have not heard? and how shall they hear

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: without a Preacher? and how shall they Preach, except they be sent?"

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Whereby it is evident, that the ordinary cause of beleeving that the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Scriptures are the Word of God, is the same with the cause of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: beleeving of all other Articles of our Faith, namely, the Hearing of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: those that are by the Law allowed and appointed to Teach us, as our

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Parents in their Houses, and our Pastors in the Churches: Which also

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is made more manifest by experience. For what other cause can there bee

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: assigned, why in Christian Common-wealths all men either beleeve, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: at least professe the Scripture to bee the Word of God, and in other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealths scarce any; but that in Christian Common-wealths they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are taught it from their infancy; and in other places they are taught

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: otherwise?

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But if Teaching be the cause of Faith, why doe not all beleeve? It is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: certain therefore that Faith is the gift of God, and hee giveth it to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whom he will. Neverthelesse, because of them to whom he giveth it, he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: giveth it by the means of Teachers, the immediate cause of Faith is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Hearing. In a School where many are taught, and some profit, others

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: profit not, the cause of learning in them that profit, is the Master;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: yet it cannot be thence inferred, that learning is not the gift of God.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: All good things proceed from God; yet cannot all that have them, say

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they are Inspired; for that implies a gift supernaturall, and the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: immediate hand of God; which he that pretends to, pretends to be a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Prophet, and is subject to the examination of the Church.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But whether men Know, or Beleeve, or Grant the Scriptures to be the Word

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of God; if out of such places of them, as are without obscurity, I

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shall shew what Articles of Faith are necessary, and onely necessary for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Salvation, those men must needs Know, Beleeve, or Grant the same.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Onely Necessary Article Of Christian Faith, The (Unum Necessarium)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Onely Article of Faith, which the Scripture maketh simply Necessary to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Salvation, is this, that JESUS IS THE CHRIST. By the name of Christ, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: understood the King, which God had before promised by the Prophets of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Old Testament, to send into the world, to reign (over the Jews,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and over such of other nations as should beleeve in him) under himself

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: eternally; and to give them that eternall life, which was lost by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sin of Adam. Which when I have proved out of Scripture, I will further

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shew when, and in what sense some other Articles may bee also called

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Necessary.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Proved From The Scope Of The Evangelists

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For Proof that the Beleef of this Article, Jesus Is The Christ, is all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Faith required to Salvation, my first Argument shall bee from the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Scope of the Evangelists; which was by the description of the life of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: our Saviour, to establish that one Article, Jesus Is The Christ. The

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: summe of St. Matthews Gospell is this, That Jesus was of the stock of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: David; Born of a Virgin; which are the Marks of the true Christ: That

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Magi came to worship him as King of the Jews: That Herod for the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: same cause sought to kill him: That John Baptist proclaimed him: That

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he preached by himselfe, and his Apostles that he was that King; That

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he taught the Law, not as a Scribe, but as a man of Authority: That he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: cured diseases by his Word onely, and did many other Miracles, which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: were foretold the Christ should doe: That he was saluted King when he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: entered into Jerusalem: That he fore-warned them to beware of all others

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that should pretend to be Christ: That he was taken, accused, and put

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to death, for saying, hee was King: That the cause of his condemnation

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: written on the Crosse, was JESUS OF NAZARETH, THE KING OF THE JEWES.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: All which tend to no other end than this, that men should beleeve,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that Jesus Is The Christ. Such therefore was the Scope of St. Matthews

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Gospel. But the Scope of all the Evangelists (as may appear by reading

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them) was the same. Therefore the Scope of the whole Gospell, was the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: establishing of that onely Article. And St. John expressely makes it his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: conclusion, John 20. 31. "These things are written, that you may know

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that Jesus is the Christ, the Son of the living God."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: From The Sermons Of The Apostles:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: My second Argument is taken from the Subject of the Sermons of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Apostles, both whilest our Saviour lived on earth, and after his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ascension. The Apostles in our Saviours time were sent, Luke 9.2. to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Preach the Kingdome of God: For neither there, nor Mat. 10.7. giveth he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: any Commission to them, other than this, "As ye go, Preach, saying, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kingdome of Heaven is at hand;" that is, that Jesus is the Messiah, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christ, the King which was to come. That their Preaching also after his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ascension was the same, is manifest out of Acts 17.6. "They drew (saith

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: St. Luke) Jason and certain Brethren unto the Rulers of the City,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: crying, These that have turned the world upside down are come hither

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: also, whom Jason hath received. And these all do contrary to the Decrees

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Caesar, saying, that there is another King, one Jesus:" And out of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the 2.&3. verses of the same Chapter, where it is said, that St. Paul

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "as his manner was, went in unto them; and three Sabbath dayes reasoned

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with them out of the Scriptures; opening and alledging, that Christ must

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: needs have suffered, and risen againe from the dead, and that this Jesus

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (whom he preached) is Christ."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: From The Easinesse Of The Doctrine:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The third Argument is, from those places of Scripture, by which all the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Faith required to Salvation is declared to be Easie. For if an inward

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: assent of the mind to all the Doctrines concerning Christian Faith now

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: taught, (whereof the greatest part are disputed,) were necessary to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Salvation, there would be nothing in the world so hard, as to be a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christian. The Thief upon the Crosse though repenting, could not have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: been saved for saying, "Lord remember me when thou commest into thy

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kingdome;" by which he testified no beleefe of any other Article, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: this, That Jesus Was The King. Nor could it bee said (as it is Mat.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 11. 30.) that "Christs yoke is Easy, and his burthen Light:" Nor that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "Little Children beleeve in him," as it is Matth. 18.6. Nor could St.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Paul have said (1 Cor. 1. 21.) "It pleased God by the Foolishnesse of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: preaching, to save them that beleeve:" Nor could St. Paul himself have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: been saved, much lesse have been so great a Doctor of the Church

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: so suddenly, that never perhaps thought of Transsubstantiation, nor

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Purgatory, nor many other Articles now obtruded.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: From Formall And Cleer Texts

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The fourth Argument is taken from places expresse, and such as receive

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: no controversie of Interpretation; as first, John 5. 39. "Search the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Scriptures, for in them yee thinke yee have eternall life; and they are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they that testifie of mee." Our Saviour here speaketh of the Scriptures

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: onely of the Old Testament; for the Jews at that time could not search

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Scriptures of the New Testament, which were not written. But the Old

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Testament hath nothing of Christ, but the Markes by which men might

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: know him when hee came; as that he should descend from David, be born at

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Bethlehem, and of a Virgin; doe great Miracles, and the like. Therefore

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to beleeve that this Jesus was He, was sufficient to eternall life: but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: more than sufficient is not Necessary; and consequently no other Article

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is required. Again, (John 11. 26.) "Whosoever liveth and beleeveth in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: mee, shall not die eternally," Therefore to beleeve in Christ, is faith

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sufficient to eternall life; and consequently no more faith than that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is Necessary, But to beleeve in Jesus, and to beleeve that Jesus is the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christ, is all one, as appeareth in the verses immediately following.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For when our Saviour (verse 26.) had said to Martha, "Beleevest thou

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: this?" she answereth (verse 27.) "Yea Lord, I beleeve that thou art the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christ, the Son of God, which should come into the world;" Therefore

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: this Article alone is faith sufficient to life eternall; and more than

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sufficient is not Necessary. Thirdly, John 20. 31. "These things are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: written that yee might beleeve, that Jesus is the Christ, the Son of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: God, and that beleeving yee might have life through his name." There, to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: beleeve that Jesus Is The Christ, is faith sufficient to the obtaining

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of life; and therefore no other Article is Necessary. Fourthly, 1 John

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 4. 2. "Every Spirit that confesseth that Jesus Christ is come in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: flesh, is of God." And 1 Joh. 5. 1. "whosoever beleeveth that Jesus is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Christ, is born of God." And verse 5. "Who is hee that overcommeth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the world, but he that beleeveth that Jesus is the Son of God?" Fiftly,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Act. 8. ver. 36, 37. "See (saith the Eunuch) here is water, what doth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hinder me to be baptized? And Philip said, If thou beleevest with all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thy heart thou mayst. And hee answered and said, I beleeve that Jesus

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christ is the Son of God." Therefore this Article beleeved, Jesus Is The

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christ, is sufficient to Baptisme, that is to say, to our Reception into

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Kingdome of God, and by consequence, onely Necessary. And generally

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in all places where our Saviour saith to any man, "Thy faith hath saved

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thee," the cause he saith it, is some Confession, which directly, or by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consequence, implyeth a beleef, that Jesus Is The Christ.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: From That It Is The Foundation Of All Other Articles

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The last Argument is from the places, where this Article is made the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Foundation of Faith: For he that holdeth the Foundation shall bee saved.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Which places are first, Mat. 24.23. "If any man shall say unto you, Loe,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: here is Christ, or there, beleeve it not, for there shall arise false

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christs, and false Prophets, and shall shew great signes and wonders,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: &c." Here wee see, this Article Jesus Is The Christ, must bee held,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: though hee that shall teach the contrary should doe great miracles. The

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: second place is Gal. 1. 8. "Though we, or an Angell from Heaven preach

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: any other Gospell unto you, than that wee have preached unto you, let

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him bee accursed." But the Gospell which Paul, and the other Apostles,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: preached, was onely this Article, that Jesus Is The Christ; Therefore

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for the Beleef of this Article, we are to reject the Authority of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: an Angell from heaven; much more of any mortall man, if he teach the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: contrary. This is therefore the Fundamentall Article of Christian Faith.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: A third place is, 1 Joh. 4.1. "Beloved, beleeve not every spirit. Hereby

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: yee shall know the Spirit of God; every spirit that confesseth that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Jesus Christ is come in the flesh, is of God." By which it is evident,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that this Article, is the measure, and rule, by which to estimate,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and examine all other Articles; and is therefore onely Fundamentall.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: A fourth is, Matt. 16.18. where after St. Peter had professed this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Article, saying to our Saviour, "Thou art Christ the Son of the living

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: God," Our Saviour answered, "Thou art Peter, and upon this Rock I will

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: build my Church:" from whence I inferre, that this Article is that,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: on which all other Doctrines of the Church are built, as on their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Foundation. A fift is (1 Cor. 3. ver. 11, 12, &c.) "Other Foundation can

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: no man lay, than that which is laid, Jesus is the Christ. Now if any man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: build upon this Foundation, Gold, Silver, pretious Stones, Wood, Hay,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Stubble; Every mans work shall be made manifest; For the Day shall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: declare it, because it shall be revealed by fire, and the fire shall try

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: every mans work, of what sort it is. If any mans work abide, which he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hath built thereupon, he shall receive a reward: If any mans work shall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: bee burnt, he shall suffer losse; but he himself shall be saved, yet so

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as by fire." Which words, being partly plain and easie to understand,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and partly allegoricall and difficult; out of that which is plain, may

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be inferred, that Pastors that teach this Foundation, that Jesus Is The

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christ, though they draw from it false consequences, (which all men are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sometimes subject to,) they may neverthelesse bee saved; much more that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they may bee saved, who being no Pastors, but Hearers, beleeve that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which is by their lawfull Pastors taught them. Therefore the beleef of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: this Article is sufficient; and by consequence there is no other Article

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Faith Necessarily required to Salvation.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Now for the part which is Allegoricall, as "That the fire shall try

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: every mans work," and that "They shall be saved, but so as by fire,"

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or "through fire," (for the originall is dia puros,) it maketh nothing

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: against this conclusion which I have drawn from the other words, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are plain. Neverthelesse, because upon this place there hath been an

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: argument taken, to prove the fire of Purgatory, I will also here offer

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: you my conjecture concerning the meaning of this triall of Doctrines,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and saving of men as by Fire. The Apostle here seemeth to allude to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the words of the Prophet Zachary, Ch. 13. 8,9. who speaking of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Restauration of the Kingdome of God, saith thus, "Two parts therein

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shall be cut off, and die, but the third shall be left therein; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: I will bring the third part through the Fire, and will refine them as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Silver is refined, and will try them as Gold is tryed; they shall call

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: on the name of the Lord, and I will hear them." The day of Judgment, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the day of the Restauration of the Kingdome of God; and at that day

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it is, that St. Peter tells us (2 Pet. 3. v.7, 10, 12.) shall be the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Conflagration of the world, wherein the wicked shall perish; but the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: remnant which God will save, shall passe through that Fire, unhurt,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and be therein (as Silver and Gold are refined by the fire from their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: drosse) tryed, and refined from their Idolatry, and be made to call upon

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the name of the true God. Alluding whereto St. Paul here saith, that The

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Day (that is, the Day of Judgment, the Great Day of our Saviours comming

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to restore the Kingdome of God in Israel) shall try every mans doctrine,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by Judging, which are Gold, Silver, Pretious Stones, Wood, Hay, Stubble;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And then they that have built false Consequences on the true Foundation,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shall see their Doctrines condemned; neverthelesse they themselves

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shall be saved, and passe unhurt through this universall Fire, and live

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: eternally, to call upon the name of the true and onely God. In which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sense there is nothing that accordeth not with the rest of Holy

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Scripture, or any glimpse of the fire of Purgatory.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In What Sense Other Articles May Be Called Necessary

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But a man may here aske, whether it bee not as necessary to Salvation,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to beleeve, that God is Omnipotent; Creator of the world; that Jesus

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christ is risen; and that all men else shall rise again from the dead

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: at the last day; as to beleeve, that Jesus Is The Christ. To which I

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: answer, they are; and so are many more Articles: but they are such, as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are contained in this one, and may be deduced from it, with more, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: lesse difficulty. For who is there that does not see, that they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: who beleeve Jesus to be the Son of the God of Israel, and that the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Israelites had for God the Omnipotent Creator of all things, doe therein

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: also beleeve, that God is the Omnipotent Creator of all things? Or how

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: can a man beleeve, that Jesus is the King that shall reign eternally,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: unlesse hee beleeve him also risen again from the dead? For a dead man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: cannot exercise the Office of a King. In summe, he that holdeth this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Foundation, Jesus Is The Christ, holdeth Expressely all that hee

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: seeth rightly deduced from it, and Implicitely all that is consequent

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thereunto, though he have not skill enough to discern the consequence.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And therefore it holdeth still good, that the beleef of this one Article

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is sufficient faith to obtaine remission of sinnes to the Penitent, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consequently to bring them into the Kingdome of Heaven.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: That Faith, And Obedience Are Both Of Them Necessary To Salvation

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Now that I have shewn, that all the Obedience required to Salvation,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consisteth in the will to obey the Law of God, that is to say, in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Repentance; and all the Faith required to the same, is comprehended in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the beleef of this Article, Jesus Is The Christ; I will further alledge

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: those places of the Gospell, that prove, that all that is Necessary to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Salvation is contained in both these joined together. The men to whom

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: St. Peter preached on the day of Pentecost, next after the Ascension

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of our Saviour, asked him, and the rest of the Apostles, saying, (Act.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 2.37.) "Men and Brethren what shall we doe?" to whom St. Peter answered

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (in the next verse) "Repent, and be Baptized every one of you, for the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: remission of sins, and ye shall receive the gift of the Holy Ghost."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Therefore Repentance, and Baptisme, that is, beleeving that Jesus Is The

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christ, is all that is Necessary to Salvation. Again, our Saviour being

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: asked by a certain Ruler, (Luke 18.18.) "What shall I doe to inherit

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: eternall life?" Answered (verse 20) "Thou knowest the Commandements,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Doe not commit Adultery, Doe not Kill, Doe not Steal, Doe not bear false

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: witnesse, Honor thy Father, and thy Mother;" which when he said he had

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: observed, our Saviour added, "Sell all thou hast, give it to the Poor,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and come and follow me:" which was as much as to say, Relye on me that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: am the King: Therefore to fulfill the Law, and to beleeve that Jesus

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is the King, is all that is required to bring a man to eternall life.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Thirdly, St. Paul saith (Rom. 1.17.) "The Just shall live by Faith;" not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: every one, but the Just; therefore Faith and Justice (that is, the Will

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To Be Just, or Repentance) are all that is Necessary to life eternall.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And (Mark 1.15.) our Saviour preached, saying, "The time is fulfilled,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and the Kingdom of God is at hand, Repent and Beleeve the Evangile,"

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that is, the Good news that the Christ was come. Therefore to Repent,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and to Beleeve that Jesus is the Christ, is all that is required to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Salvation.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: What Each Of Them Contributes Thereunto

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Seeing then it is Necessary that Faith, and Obedience (implyed in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: word Repentance) do both concurre to our Salvation; the question

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by which of the two we are Justified, is impertinently disputed.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Neverthelesse, it will not be impertinent, to make manifest in what

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: manner each of them contributes thereunto; and in what sense it is said,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that we are to be Justified by the one, and by the other. And first,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: if by Righteousnesse be understood the Justice of the Works themselves,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there is no man that can be saved; for there is none that hath not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: transgressed the Law of God. And therefore when wee are said to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Justified by Works, it is to be understood of the Will, which God doth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: alwaies accept for the Work it selfe, as well in good, as in evill men.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And in this sense onely it is, that a man is called Just, or Unjust; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that his Justice Justifies him, that is, gives him the title, in Gods

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: acceptation, of Just; and renders him capable of Living By His Faith,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which before he was not. So that Justice Justifies in that that sense,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in which to Justifie, is the same that to Denominate A Man Just; and not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the signification of discharging the Law; whereby the punishment of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his sins should be unjust.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But a man is then also said to be Justified, when his Plea, though in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it selfe unsufficient, is accepted; as when we Plead our Will, our

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Endeavour to fulfill the Law, and Repent us of our failings, and God

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: accepteth it for the Performance it selfe: And because God accepteth not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Will for the Deed, but onely in the Faithfull; it is therefore Faith

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that makes good our Plea; and in this sense it is, that Faith onely

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Justifies: So that Faith and Obedience are both Necessary to Salvation;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: yet in severall senses each of them is said to Justifie.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Obedience To God And To The Civill Soveraign Not Inconsistent

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Whether Christian, Having thus shewn what is Necessary to Salvation; it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is not hard to reconcile our Obedience to the Civill Soveraign; who is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: either Christian, or Infidel. If he bee a Christian, he alloweth the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: beleefe of this Article, that Jesus Is The Christ; and of all the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Articles that are contained in, or are evident consequence deduced from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it: which is all the Faith Necessary to Salvation. And because he is a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign, he requireth Obedience to all his owne, that is, to all the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Civill Laws; in which also are contained all the Laws of Nature, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is, all the Laws of God: for besides the Laws of Nature, and the Laws of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Church, which are part of the Civill Law, (for the Church that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: can make Laws is the Common-wealth,) there bee no other Laws Divine.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Whosoever therefore obeyeth his Christian Soveraign, is not thereby

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hindred, neither from beleeving, nor from obeying God. But suppose that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Christian King should from this Foundation, Jesus Is The Christ, draw

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: some false consequences, that is to say, make some superstructions of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Hay, or Stubble, and command the teaching of the same; yet seeing St.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Paul says, he shal be saved; much more shall he be saved, that teacheth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them by his command; and much more yet, he that teaches not, but onely

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: beleeves his lawfull Teacher. And in case a Subject be forbidden by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Civill Soveraign to professe some of those his opinions, upon

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: what grounds can he disobey? Christian Kings may erre in deducing a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Consequence, but who shall Judge? Shall a private man Judge, when the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: question is of his own obedience? or shall any man Judg but he that is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: appointed thereto by the Church, that is, by the Civill Soveraign that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: representeth it? or if the Pope, or an Apostle Judge, may he not erre

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in deducing of a consequence? did not one of the two, St. Peter, or St.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Paul erre in a superstructure, when St. Paul withstood St. Peter to his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: face? There can therefore be no contradiction between the Laws of God,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and the Laws of a Christian Common-wealth.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Or Infidel

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And when the Civill Soveraign is an Infidel, every one of his own

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Subjects that resisteth him, sinneth against the Laws of God (for such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as are the Laws of Nature,) and rejecteth the counsell of the Apostles,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that admonisheth all Christians to obey their Princes, and all Children

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Servants to obey they Parents, and Masters, in all things. And for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their Faith, it is internall, and invisible; They have the licence that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Naaman had, and need not put themselves into danger for it. But if they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: do, they ought to expect their reward in Heaven, and not complain of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their Lawfull Soveraign; much lesse make warre upon him. For he that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is not glad of any just occasion of Martyrdome, has not the faith be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: professeth, but pretends it onely, to set some colour upon his own

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: contumacy. But what Infidel King is so unreasonable, as knowing he has

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Subject, that waiteth for the second comming of Christ, after the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: present world shall be burnt, and intendeth then to obey him (which is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the intent of beleeving that Jesus is the Christ,) and in the mean time

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thinketh himself bound to obey the Laws of that Infidel King, (which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all Christians are obliged in conscience to doe,) to put to death, or to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: persecute such a Subject?

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And thus much shall suffice, concerning the Kingdome of God, and Policy

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ecclesiasticall. Wherein I pretend not to advance any Position of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: my own, but onely to shew what are the Consequences that seem to me

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: deducible from the Principles of Christian Politiques, (which are the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: holy Scriptures,) in confirmation of the Power of Civill Soveraigns, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Duty of their Subjects. And in the allegation of Scripture, I have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: endeavoured to avoid such Texts as are of obscure, or controverted

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Interpretation; and to alledge none, but is such sense as is most plain,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and agreeable to the harmony and scope of the whole Bible; which was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: written for the re-establishment of the Kingdome of God in Christ. For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it is not the bare Words, but the Scope of the writer that giveth the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: true light, by which any writing is to bee interpreted; and they that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: insist upon single Texts, without considering the main Designe, can

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: derive no thing from them cleerly; but rather by casting atomes of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Scripture, as dust before mens eyes, make every thing more obscure than

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it is; an ordinary artifice of those that seek not the truth, but their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: own advantage.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CHAPTER XLIV. OF SPIRITUALL DARKNESSE FROM MISINTERPRETATION OF

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: SCRIPTURE

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Kingdome Of Darknesse What

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Besides these Soveraign Powers, Divine, and Humane, of which I have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hitherto discoursed, there is mention in Scripture of another Power,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: namely, (Eph. 6. 12.), that of "the Rulers of the Darknesse of this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: world," (Mat. 12. 26.), "the Kingdome of Satan," and, (Mat. 9. 34.), "the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Principality of Beelzebub over Daemons," that is to say, over Phantasmes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that appear in the Air: For which cause Satan is also called (Eph. 2.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 2.) "the Prince of the Power of the Air;" and (because he ruleth in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: darknesse of this world) (Joh. 16. 11.) "The Prince of this world;" And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in consequence hereunto, they who are under his Dominion, in opposition

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to the faithfull (who are the Children Of The Light) are called the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Children Of Darknesse. For seeing Beelzebub is Prince of Phantasmes,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Inhabitants of his Dominion of Air and Darknesse, the Children of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Darknesse, and these Daemons, Phantasmes, or Spirits of Illusion,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: signifie allegorically the same thing. This considered, the Kingdome

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Darknesse, as it is set forth in these, and other places of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Scripture, is nothing else but a "Confederacy of Deceivers, that to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: obtain dominion over men in this present world, endeavour by dark, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: erroneous Doctrines, to extinguish in them the Light, both of Nature,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and of the Gospell; and so to dis-prepare them for the Kingdome of God

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to come."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Church Not Yet Fully Freed Of Darknesse

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: As men that are utterly deprived from their Nativity, of the light

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the bodily Eye, have no Idea at all, of any such light; and no man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: conceives in his imagination any greater light, than he hath at some

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: time, or other perceived by his outward Senses: so also is it of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: light of the Gospel, and of the light of the Understanding, that no man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: can conceive there is any greater degree of it, than that which he hath

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: already attained unto. And from hence it comes to passe, that men

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have no other means to acknowledge their owne Darknesse, but onely by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: reasoning from the un-forseen mischances, that befall them in their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ways; The Darkest part of the Kingdome of Satan, is that which is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: without the Church of God; that is to say, amongst them that beleeve not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in Jesus Christ. But we cannot say, that therefore the Church enjoyeth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (as the land of Goshen) all the light, which to the performance of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the work enjoined us by God, is necessary. Whence comes it, that in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christendome there has been, almost from the time of the Apostles,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such justling of one another out of their places, both by forraign,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Civill war? such stumbling at every little asperity of their own

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: fortune, and every little eminence of that of other men? and such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: diversity of ways in running to the same mark, Felicity, if it be not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Night amongst us, or at least a Mist? wee are therefore yet in the Dark.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Four Causes Of Spirituall Darknesse

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Enemy has been here in the Night of our naturall Ignorance, and sown

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the tares of Spirituall Errors; and that, First, by abusing, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: putting out the light of the Scriptures: For we erre, not knowing the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Scriptures. Secondly, by introducing the Daemonology of the Heathen

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Poets, that is to say, their fabulous Doctrine concerning Daemons, which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are but Idols, or Phantasms of the braine, without any reall nature of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their own, distinct from humane fancy; such as are dead mens Ghosts, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Fairies, and other matter of old Wives tales. Thirdly, by mixing with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Scripture divers reliques of the Religion, and much of the vain and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: erroneous Philosophy of the Greeks, especially of Aristotle. Fourthly,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by mingling with both these, false, or uncertain Traditions, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: fained, or uncertain History. And so we come to erre, by "giving heed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to seducing Spirits," and the Daemonology of such "as speak lies in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Hypocrisie," (or as it is in the Originall, 1 Tim. 4.1,2. "of those that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: play the part of lyars") "with a seared conscience," that is, contrary

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to their own knowledge. Concerning the first of these, which is the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Seducing of men by abuse of Scripture, I intend to speak briefly in this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Chapter.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Errors From Misinterpreting The Scriptures, Concerning The Kingdome

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of God

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The greatest, and main abuse of Scripture, and to which almost all the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: rest are either consequent, or subservient, is the wresting of it, to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: prove that the Kingdome of God, mentioned so often in the Scripture, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the present Church, or multitude of Christian men now living, or that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: being dead, are to rise again at the last day: whereas the Kingdome of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: God was first instituted by the Ministery of Moses, over the Jews onely;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: who were therefore called his Peculiar People; and ceased afterward, in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the election of Saul, when they refused to be governed by God any more,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and demanded a King after the manner of the nations; which God himself

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consented unto, as I have more at large proved before, in the 35.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Chapter. After that time, there was no other Kingdome of God in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: world, by any Pact, or otherwise, than he ever was, is, and shall be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: King, of all men, and of all creatures, as governing according to his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Will, by his infinite Power. Neverthelesse, he promised by his Prophets

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to restore this his Government to them again, when the time he hath in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his secret counsell appointed for it shall bee fully come, and when they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shall turn unto him by repentance, and amendment of life; and not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: onely so, but he invited also the Gentiles to come in, and enjoy the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: happinesse of his Reign, on the same conditions of conversion and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: repentance; and hee promised also to send his Son into the world, to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: expiate the sins of them all by his death, and to prepare them by his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Doctrine, to receive him at his second coming: Which second coming not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: yet being, the Kingdome of God is not yet come, and wee are not now

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: under any other Kings by Pact, but our Civill Soveraigns; saving onely,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that Christian men are already in the Kingdome of Grace, in as much as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they have already the Promise of being received at his comming againe.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: As That The Kingdome Of God Is The Present Church

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Consequent to this Errour, that the present Church is Christs Kingdome,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there ought to be some one Man, or Assembly, by whose mouth our Saviour

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (now in heaven) speaketh, giveth law, and which representeth his person

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to all Christians, or divers Men, or divers Assemblies that doe the same

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to divers parts of Christendome. This power Regal under Christ, being

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: challenged, universally by that Pope, and in particular Common-wealths

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by Assemblies of the Pastors of the place, (when the Scripture gives it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to none but to Civill Soveraigns,) comes to be so passionately disputed,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that it putteth out the Light of Nature, and causeth so great a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Darknesse in mens understanding, that they see not who it is to whom

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they have engaged their obedience.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And That The Pope Is His Vicar Generall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Consequent to this claim of the Pope to Vicar Generall of Christ in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: present Church, (supposed to be that Kingdom of his, to which we are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: addressed in the Gospel,) is the Doctrine, that it is necessary for a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christian King, to receive his Crown by a Bishop; as if it were from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that Ceremony, that he derives the clause of Dei Gratia in his title;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and that then onely he is made King by the favour of God, when he is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: crowned by the authority of Gods universall Viceregent on earth; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that every Bishop whosoever be his Soveraign, taketh at his Consecration

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: an oath of absolute Obedience to the Pope, Consequent to the same, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Doctrine of the fourth Councell of Lateran, held under Pope Innocent

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the third, (Chap. 3. De Haereticis.) "That if a King at the Popes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: admonition, doe not purge his Kingdome of Haeresies, and being

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: excommunicate for the same, doe not give satisfaction within a year,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his Subjects are absolved of the bond of their obedience." Where, by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Haeresies are understood all opinions which the Church of Rome hath

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: forbidden to be maintained. And by this means, as often as there is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: any repugnancy between the Politicall designes of the Pope, and other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christian Princes, as there is very often, there ariseth such a Mist

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: amongst their Subjects, that they know not a stranger that thrusteth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: himself into the throne of their lawfull Prince, from him whom they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: had themselves placed there; and in this Darknesse of mind, are made to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: fight one against another, without discerning their enemies from their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: friends, under the conduct of another mans ambition.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And That The Pastors Are The Clergy

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: From the same opinion, that the present Church is the Kingdome of God,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it proceeds that Pastours, Deacons, and all other Ministers of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Church, take the name to themselves of the Clergy, giving to other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christians the name of Laity, that is, simply People. For Clergy

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: signifies those, whose maintenance is that Revenue, which God having

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: reserved to himselfe during his Reigne over the Israelites, assigned

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to the tribe of Levi (who were to be his publique Ministers, and had no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: portion of land set them out to live on, as their brethren) to be their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: inheritance. The Pope therefore, (pretending the present Church to be,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as the Realme of Israel, the Kingdome of God) challenging to himselfe

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and his subordinate Ministers, the like revenue, as the Inheritance of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: God, the name of Clergy was sutable to that claime. And thence it is,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that Tithes, or other tributes paid to the Levites, as Gods Right,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: amongst the Israelites, have a long time been demanded, and taken of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christians, by Ecclesiastiques, Jure Divino, that is, in Gods Right. By

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which meanes, the people every where were obliged to a double tribute;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: one to the State, another to the Clergy; whereof, that to the Clergy,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: being the tenth of their revenue, is double to that which a King of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Athens (and esteemed a Tyrant) exacted of his subjects for the defraying

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of all publique charges: For he demanded no more but the twentieth part;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and yet abundantly maintained therewith the Commonwealth. And in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kingdome of the Jewes, during the Sacerdotall Reigne of God, the Tithes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Offerings were the whole Publique Revenue.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: From the same mistaking of the present Church for the Kingdom of God,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: came in the distinction betweene the Civill and the Canon Laws: The

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: civil Law being the acts of Soveraigns in their own Dominions, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Canon Law being the Acts of the Pope in the same Dominions. Which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Canons, though they were but Canons, that is, Rules Propounded, and but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: voluntarily received by Christian Princes, till the translation of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Empire to Charlemain; yet afterwards, as the power of the Pope

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: encreased, became Rules Commanded, and the Emperours themselves (to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: avoyd greater mischiefes, which the people blinded might be led into)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: were forced to let them passe for Laws.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: From hence it is, that in all Dominions, where the Popes Ecclesiasticall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: power is entirely received, Jewes, Turkes, and Gentiles, are in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Roman Church tolerated in their Religion, as farre forth, as in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: exercise and profession thereof they offend not against the civill

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: power: whereas in a Christian, though a stranger, not to be of the Roman

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Religion, is Capitall; because the Pope pretendeth that all Christians

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are his Subjects. For otherwise it were as much against the law of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nations, to persecute a Christian stranger, for professing the Religion

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of his owne country, as an Infidell; or rather more, in as much as they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that are not against Christ, are with him.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: From the same it is, that in every Christian State there are certaine

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: men, that are exempt, by Ecclesiasticall liberty, from the tributes, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from the tribunals of the Civil State; for so are the secular Clergy,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: besides Monks and Friars, which in many places, bear so great a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: proportion to the common people, as if need were, there might be raised

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: out of them alone, an Army, sufficient for any warre the Church militant

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: should imploy them in, against their owne, or other Princes.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Error From Mistaking Consecration For Conjuration

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: A second generall abuse of Scripture, is the turning of Consecration

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: into Conjuration, or Enchantment. To Consecrate, is in Scripture, to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Offer, Give, or Dedicate, in pious and decent language and gesture, a

author: Thomas Hobbes
