text: man, or any other thing to God, by separating of it from common use;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that is to say, to Sanctifie, or make it Gods, and to be used only by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: those, whom God hath appointed to be his Publike Ministers, (as I have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: already proved at large in the 35. Chapter;) and thereby to change, not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the thing Consecrated, but onely the use of it, from being Profane

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and common, to be Holy, and peculiar to Gods service. But when by such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: words, the nature of qualitie of the thing it selfe, is pretended to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: changed, it is not Consecration, but either an extraordinary worke of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: God, or a vaine and impious Conjuration. But seeing (for the frequency

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of pretending the change of Nature in their Consecrations,) it cannot

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be esteemed a work extraordinary, it is no other than a Conjuration or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Incantation, whereby they would have men to beleeve an alteration of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nature that is not, contrary to the testimony of mans Sight, and of all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the rest of his Senses. As for example, when the Priest, in stead of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Consecrating Bread and Wine to Gods peculiar service in the Sacrament of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Lords Supper, (which is but a separation of it from the common use,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to signifie, that is, to put men in mind of their Redemption, by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Passion of Christ, whose body was broken, and blood shed upon the Crosse

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for our transgressions,) pretends, that by saying of the words of our

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Saviour, "This is my Body," and "This is my Blood," the nature of Bread

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is no more there, but his very Body; notwithstanding there appeared not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to the Sight, or other Sense of the Receiver, any thing that appeareth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not before the Consecration. The Egyptian Conjurers, that are said

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to have turned their Rods to Serpents, and the Water into Bloud, are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thought but to have deluded the senses of the Spectators by a false shew

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of things, yet are esteemed Enchanters: But what should wee have thought

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of them, if there had appeared in their Rods nothing like a Serpent, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the Water enchanted, nothing like Bloud, nor like any thing else but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Water, but that they had faced down the King, that they were Serpents

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that looked like Rods, and that it was Bloud that seemed Water? That

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: had been both Enchantment, and Lying. And yet in this daily act of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Priest, they doe the very same, by turning the holy words into the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: manner of a Charme, which produceth nothing now to the Sense; but they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: face us down, that it hath turned the Bread into a Man; nay more, into

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a God; and require men to worship it, as if it were our Saviour himself

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: present God and Man, and thereby to commit most grosse Idolatry. For if

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it bee enough to excuse it of Idolatry, to say it is no more Bread, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: God; why should not the same excuse serve the Egyptians, in case they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: had the faces to say, the Leeks, and Onyons they worshipped, were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not very Leeks, and Onyons, but a Divinity under their Species, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: likenesse. The words, "This is my Body," are aequivalent to these,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "This signifies, or represents my Body;" and it is an ordinary figure of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Speech: but to take it literally, is an abuse; nor though so taken, can

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it extend any further, than to the Bread which Christ himself with his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: own hands Consecrated. For hee never said, that of what Bread soever,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: any Priest whatsoever, should say, "This is my Body," or, "This is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christs Body," the same should presently be transubstantiated. Nor did

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Church of Rome ever establish this Transubstantiation, till the time

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Innocent the third; which was not above 500. years agoe, when the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Power of Popes was at the Highest, and the Darknesse of the time grown

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: so great, as men discerned not the Bread that was given them to eat,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: especially when it was stamped with the figure of Christ upon the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Crosse, as if they would have men beleeve it were Transubstantiated, not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: onely into the Body of Christ, but also into the Wood of his Crosse, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that they did eat both together in the Sacrament.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Incantation In The Ceremonies Of Baptisme

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The like incantation, in stead of Consecration, is used also in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sacrament of Baptisme: Where the abuse of Gods name in each severall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Person, and in the whole Trinity, with the sign of the Crosse at each

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: name, maketh up the Charm: As first, when they make the Holy water, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Priest saith, "I Conjure thee, thou Creature of Water, in the name of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: God the Father Almighty, and in the name of Jesus Christ his onely Son

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: our Lord, and in vertue of the Holy Ghost, that thou become Conjured

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: water, to drive away all the Powers of the Enemy, and to eradicate, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: supplant the Enemy, &c." And the same in the Benediction of the Salt

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to be mingled with it; "That thou become Conjured Salt, that all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Phantasmes, and Knavery of the Devills fraud may fly and depart from the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: place wherein thou art sprinkled; and every unclean Spirit bee Conjured

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by Him that shall come to judge the quicke and the dead." The same in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Benediction of the Oyle. "That all the Power of the Enemy, all the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Host of the Devill, all Assaults and Phantasmes of Satan, may be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: driven away by this Creature of Oyle." And for the Infant that is to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Baptized, he is subject to many Charms; First, at the Church dore the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Priest blows thrice in the Childs face, and sayes, "Goe out of him

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: unclean Spirit, and give place to the Holy Ghost the Comforter." As

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: if all Children, till blown on by the Priest were Daemoniaques: Again,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: before his entrance into the Church, he saith as before, "I Conjure

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thee, &c. to goe out, and depart from this Servant of God:" And again

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the same Exorcisme is repeated once more before he be Baptized. These,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and some other Incantations, and Consecrations, in administration of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sacraments of Baptisme, and the Lords Supper; wherein every thing that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: serveth to those holy men (except the unhallowed Spittle of the Priest)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hath some set form of Exorcisme.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In Marriage, In Visitation Of The Sick, And In Consecration Of Places

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nor are the other rites, as of Marriage, of Extreme Unction, of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Visitation of the Sick, of Consecrating Churches, and Church-yards, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the like, exempt from Charms; in as much as there is in them the use of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Enchanted Oyle, and Water, with the abuse of the Crosse, and of the holy

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: word of David, "Asperges me Domine Hyssopo," as things of efficacy to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: drive away Phantasmes, and Imaginery Spirits.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Errors From Mistaking Eternall Life, And Everlasting Death

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Another generall Error, is from the Misinterpretation of the words

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Eternall Life, Everlasting Death, and the Second Death. For though we

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: read plainly in Holy Scripture, that God created Adam in an estate of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Living for Ever, which was conditionall, that is to say, if he disobeyed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not his Commandement; which was not essentiall to Humane Nature, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consequent to the vertue of the Tree of Life; whereof hee had liberty

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to eat, as long as hee had not sinned; and that hee was thrust out of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Paradise after he had sinned, lest hee should eate thereof, and live for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ever; and that Christs Passion is a Discharge of sin to all that beleeve

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: on him; and by consequence, a restitution of Eternall Life, to all the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Faithfull, and to them onely: yet the Doctrine is now, and hath been a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: long time far otherwise; namely, that every man hath Eternity of Life by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nature, in as much as his Soul is Immortall: So that the flaming Sword

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: at the entrance of Paradise, though it hinder a man from coming to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Tree of Life, hinders him not from the Immortality which God took from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him for his Sin; nor makes him to need the sacrificing of Christ, for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the recovering of the same; and consequently, not onely the faithfull

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and righteous, but also the wicked, and the Heathen, shall enjoy

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Eternall Life, without any Death at all; much lesse a Second, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Everlasting Death. To salve this, it is said, that by Second, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Everlasting Death, is meant a Second, and Everlasting Life, but in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Torments; a Figure never used, but in this very Case.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: All which Doctrine is founded onely on some of the obscurer places of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the New Testament; which neverthelesse, the whole scope of the Scripture

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: considered, are cleer enough in a different sense, and unnecessary to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Christian Faith. For supposing that when a man dies, there remaineth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: nothing of him but his carkasse; cannot God that raised inanimated dust

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and clay into a living creature by his Word, as easily raise a dead

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: carkasse to life again, and continue him alive for Ever, or make him

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: die again, by another Word? The Soule in Scripture, signifieth alwaies,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: either the Life, or the Living Creature; and the Body and Soule jointly,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Body Alive. In the fift day of the Creation, God said, Let the water

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: produce Reptile Animae Viventis, the creeping thing that hath in it a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Living Soule; the English translate it, "that hath Life:" And again,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: God created Whales, "& omnem animam viventem;" which in the English is,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "every living Creature:" And likewise of Man, God made him of the dust

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the earth, and breathed in his face the breath of Life, "& factus est

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Homo in animam viventem," that is, "and Man was made a Living Creature;"

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And after Noah came out of the Arke, God saith, hee will no more smite

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "omnem animam viventem," that is "every Living Creature;" And Deut.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 12.23. "Eate not the Bloud, for the Bloud is the Soule;" that is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "the Life." From which places, if by Soule were meant a Substance

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Incorporeall, with an existence separated from the Body, it might as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: well be inferred of any other living Creature, as of Man. But that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Souls of the Faithfull, are not of their own Nature, but by Gods

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: speciall Grace, to remaine in their bodies, from the Resurrection to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all Eternity, I have already I think sufficiently proved out of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Scriptures, in the 38. Chapter. And for the places of the New Testament,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: where it is said that any man shall be cast Body and Soul into Hell

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: fire, it is no more than Body and Life; that is to say, they shall be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: cast alive into the perpetuall fire of Gehenna.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: As The Doctrine Of Purgatory, And Exorcismes, And Invocation Of Saints

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: This window it is, that gives entrance to the Dark Doctrine, first, of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Eternall Torments; and afterwards of Purgatory, and consequently of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: walking abroad, especially in places Consecrated, Solitary, or Dark, of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Ghosts of men deceased; and thereby to the pretences of Exorcisme

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Conjuration of Phantasmes; as also of Invocation of men dead; and to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Doctrine of Indulgences; that is to say, of exemption for a time,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or for ever, from the fire of Purgatory, wherein these Incorporeall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Substances are pretended by burning to be cleansed, and made fit

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for Heaven. For men being generally possessed before the time of our

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Saviour, by contagion of the Daemonology of the Greeks, of an opinion,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that the Souls of men were substances distinct from their Bodies, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore that when the Body was dead, the Soule of every man, whether

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: godly, or wicked, must subsist somewhere by vertue of its own nature,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: without acknowledging therein any supernaturall gift of Gods; the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Doctors of the Church doubted a long time, what was the place, which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they were to abide in, till they should be re-united to their Bodies in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Resurrection; supposing for a while, they lay under the Altars: but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: afterward the Church of Rome found it more profitable, to build for them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: this place of Purgatory; which by some other Churches in this later age,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: has been demolished.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Texts Alledged For The Doctrines Aforementioned Have Been Answered

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Before

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Let us now consider, what texts of Scripture seem most to confirm these

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: three generall Errors, I have here touched. As for those which Cardinall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Bellarmine hath alledged, for the present Kingdome of God administred by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Pope, (than which there are none that make a better show of proof,)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: I have already answered them; and made it evident, that the Kingdome

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of God, instituted by Moses, ended in the election of Saul: After which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: time the Priest of his own authority never deposed any King. That which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the High Priest did to Athaliah, was not done in his own right, but in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the right of the young King Joash her Son: But Solomon in his own right

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: deposed the High Priest Abiathar, and set up another in his place. The

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: most difficult place to answer, of all those than can be brought,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to prove the Kingdome of God by Christ is already in this world, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: alledged, not by Bellarmine, nor any other of the Church of Rome; but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by Beza; that will have it to begin from the Resurrection of Christ.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But whether hee intend thereby, to entitle the Presbytery to the Supreme

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Power Ecclesiasticall in the Common-wealth of Geneva, (and consequently

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to every Presbytery in every other Common-wealth,) or to Princes,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and other Civill Soveraignes, I doe not know. For the Presbytery hath

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: challenged the power to Excommunicate their owne Kings, and to bee the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Supreme Moderators in Religion, in the places where they have that form

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Church government, no lesse then the Pope challengeth it universally.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Answer To The Text On Which Beza Infereth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: That The Kingdome Of Christ Began At The Resurrection The words are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (Marke 9.1.) "Verily, I say unto you, that there be some of them that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: stand here, which shall not tast of death, till they have seene the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kingdome of God come with power." Which words, if taken grammatically,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: make it certaine, that either some of those men that stood by Christ at

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that time, are yet alive; or else, that the Kingdome of God must be now

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in this present world. And then there is another place more difficult:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For when the Apostles after our Saviours Resurrection, and immediately

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: before his Ascension, asked our Saviour, saying, (Acts.1.6.) "Wilt thou

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: at this time restore again the Kingdome to Israel," he answered them,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "It is not for you to know the times and the seasons, which the Father

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hath put in his own power; But ye shall receive power by the comming of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Holy Ghost upon you, and yee shall be my (Martyrs) witnesses both in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Jerusalem, & in all Judaea, and in Samaria, and unto the uttermost part

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Earth:" Which is as much as to say, My Kingdome is not yet come,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: nor shall you foreknow when it shall come, for it shall come as a theefe

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the night; But I will send you the Holy Ghost, and by him you shall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have power to beare witnesse to all the world (by your preaching) of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: my Resurrection, and the workes I have done, and the doctrine I have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: taught, that they may beleeve in me, and expect eternall life, at my

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: comming againe: How does this agree with the comming of Christs Kingdome

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: at the Resurrection? And that which St. Paul saies (1 Thessal. 1.9, 10.)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "That they turned from Idols, to serve the living and true God, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to waite for his Sonne from Heaven:" Where to waite for his Sonne from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Heaven, is to wait for his comming to be King in power; which were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not necessary, if this Kingdome had beene then present. Againe, if the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kingdome of God began (as Beza on that place (Mark 9.1.) would have it)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: at the Resurrection; what reason is there for Christians ever since the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Resurrection to say in their prayers, "Let thy Kingdome Come"? It

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is therefore manifest, that the words of St. Mark are not so to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: interpreted. There be some of them that stand here (saith our Saviour)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that shall not tast of death till they have seen the Kingdome of God

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: come in power. If then this Kingdome were to come at the Resurrection

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Christ, why is it said, "some of them" rather than all? For they all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: lived till after Christ was risen.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Explication Of The Place In Mark 9.1

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But they that require an exact interpretation of this text, let them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: interpret first the like words of our Saviour to St. Peter concerning

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: St. John, (chap. 21.22.) "If I will that he tarry till I come, what is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that to thee?" upon which was grounded a report that hee should not dye:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Neverthelesse the truth of that report was neither confirmed, as well

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: grounded; nor refuted, as ill grounded on those words; but left as a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: saying not understood. The same difficulty is also in the place of St.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Marke. And if it be lawfull to conjecture at their meaning, by that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which immediately followes, both here, and in St. Luke, where the same

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is againe repeated, it is not unprobable, to say they have relation

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to the Transfiguration, which is described in the verses immediately

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: following; where it is said, that "After six dayes Jesus taketh with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him Peter, and James, and John (not all, but some of his Disciples)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and leadeth them up into an high mountaine apart by themselves, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was transfigured before them. And his rayment became shining, exceeding

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: white as snow; so as no Fuller on earth can white them. And there

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: appeared unto them Elias with Moses, and they were talking with Jesus,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: &c." So that they saw Christ in Glory and Majestie, as he is to come;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: insomuch as "They were sore afraid." And thus the promise of our Saviour

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was accomplished by way of Vision: For it was a Vision, as may probably

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: bee inferred out of St. Luke, that reciteth the same story (ch. 9. ve.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 28.) and saith, that Peter and they that were with him, were heavy with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sleep; But most certainly out of Matth. 17.9. (where the same is again

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: related;) for our Saviour charged them, saying, "Tell no man the Vision

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: untill the Son of man be Risen from the dead." Howsoever it be, yet

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there can from thence be taken no argument, to prove that the Kingdome

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of God taketh beginning till the day of Judgement.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Abuse Of Some Other Texts In Defence Of The Power Of The Pope

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: As for some other texts, to prove the Popes Power over civill

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraignes (besides those of Bellarmine;) as that the two Swords that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christ and his Apostles had amongst them, were the Spirituall and the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Temporall Sword, which they say St. Peter had given him by Christ: And,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that of the two Luminaries, the greater signifies the Pope, and the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: lesser the King; One might as well inferre out of the first verse of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Bible, that by Heaven is meant the Pope, and by Earth the King: Which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is not arguing from Scripture, but a wanton insulting over Princes, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: came in fashion after the time the Popes were growne so secure of their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: greatnesse, as to contemne all Christian Kings; and Treading on the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: necks of Emperours, to mocke both them, and the Scripture, in the words

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the 91. Psalm, "Thou shalt Tread upon the Lion and the Adder, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: young Lion and the Dragon thou shalt Trample under thy feet."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Manner Of Consecrations In The Scripture, Was Without Exorcisms

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: As for the rites of Consecration, though they depend for the most part

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: upon the discretion and judgement of the governors of the Church,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and not upon the Scriptures; yet those governors are obliged to such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: direction, as the nature of the action it selfe requireth; as that the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ceremonies, words, and gestures, be both decent, and significant, or at

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: least conformable to the action. When Moses consecrated the Tabernacle,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Altar, and the Vessels belonging to them (Exod. 40.) he anointed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them with the Oyle which God had commanded to bee made for that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: purpose; and they were holy; There was nothing Exorcised, to drive away

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Phantasmes. The same Moses (the civill Soveraigne of Israel) when he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consecrated Aaron (the High Priest,) and his Sons, did wash them with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Water, (not Exorcised water,) put their Garments upon them, and anointed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them with Oyle; and they were sanctified, to minister unto the Lord

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the Priests office; which was a simple and decent cleansing, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: adorning them, before hee presented them to God, to be his servants.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: When King Solomon, (the civill Soveraigne of Israel) consecrated the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Temple hee had built, (2 Kings 8.) he stood before all the Congregation

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Israel; and having blessed them, he gave thanks to God, for putting

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: into the heart of his father, to build it; and for giving to himselfe

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the grace to accomplish the same; and then prayed unto him, first,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to accept that House, though it were not sutable to his infinite

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Greatnesse; and to hear the prayers of his Servants that should pray

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therein, or (if they were absent) towards it; and lastly, he offered a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sacrifice of Peace-offering, and the House was dedicated. Here was no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Procession; the King stood still in his first place; no Exorcised Water;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: no Asperges Me, nor other impertinent application of words spoken upon

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: another occasion; but a decent, and rationall speech, and such as in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: making to God a present of his new built House, was most conformable

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to the occasion. We read not that St. John did Exorcise the Water

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Jordan; nor Philip the Water of the river wherein he baptized the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Eunuch; nor that any Pastor in the time of the Apostles, did take his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: spittle, and put it to the nose of the person to be Baptized, and say,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "In odorem suavitatis," that is, "for a sweet savour unto the Lord;"

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: wherein neither the Ceremony of Spittle, for the uncleannesse; nor the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: application of that Scripture for the levity, can by any authority of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man be justified.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Immortality Of Mans Soule, Not Proved By Scripture To Be Of Nature,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But Of Grace

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To prove that the Soule separated from the Body liveth eternally, not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: onely the Soules of the Elect, by especiall grace, and restauration of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Eternall Life which Adam lost by Sinne, and our Saviour restored

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by the Sacrifice of himself, to the Faithfull, but also the Soules

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Reprobates, as a property naturally consequent to the essence of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: mankind, without other grace of God, but that which is universally given

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to all mankind; there are divers places, which at the first sight seem

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sufficiently to serve the turn: but such, as when I compare them with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that which I have before (Chapter 38.) alledged out of the 14 of Job,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: seem to mee much more subject to a divers interpretation, than the words

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Job.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And first there are the words of Solomon (Ecclesiastes 12.7.) "Then

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shall the Dust return to Dust, as it was, and the Spirit shall return to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: God that gave it." Which may bear well enough (if there be no other text

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: directly against it) this interpretation, that God onely knows, (but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Man not,) what becomes of a mans spirit, when he expireth; and the same

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Solomon, in the same Book, (Chap. 3. ver. 20,21.) delivereth in the same

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sentence in the sense I have given it: His words are, "All goe, (man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and beast) to the same place; all are of the dust, and all turn to dust

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: again; who knoweth that the spirit of Man goeth upward, and the spirit

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Beast goeth downward to the earth?" That is, none knows but God;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nor is it an unusuall phrase to say of things we understand not, "God

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: knows what," and "God knows where." That of Gen. 5.24. "Enoch walked

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with God, and he was not; for God took him;" which is expounded Heb.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 13.5. "He was translated, that he should not die; and was not found,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: because God had translated him. For before his Translation, he had this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: testimony, that he pleased God," making as much for the Immortality

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Body, as of the Soule, proveth, that this his translation was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: peculiar to them that please God; not common to them with the wicked;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and depending on Grace, not on Nature. But on the contrary, what

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: interpretation shall we give, besides the literall sense of the words of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Solomon (Eccles. 3.19.) "That which befalleth the Sons of Men, befalleth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Beasts, even one thing befalleth them; as the one dyeth, so doth the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other; yea, they have all one breath (one spirit;) so that a Man hath no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: praeeminence above a Beast, for all is vanity." By the literall sense,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: here is no Naturall Immortality of the Soule; nor yet any repugnancy

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with the Life Eternall, which the Elect shall enjoy by Grace. And (chap.

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

text: Eternall Torments What

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Tophet, or in what place soever, may continue for ever; and there may

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Answer Of The Texts Alledged For Purgatory

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Upon this Doctrine of the Naturall Eternity of separated Soules, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: founded (as I said) the Doctrine of Purgatory. For supposing Eternall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Life by Grace onely, there is no Life, but the Life of the Body; and no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Immortality till the Resurrection. The texts for Purgatory alledged by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Bellarmine out of the Canonicall Scripture of the old Testament, are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: first, the Fasting of David for Saul and Jonathan, mentioned (2 Kings,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 1. 12.); and againe, (2 Sam. 3. 35.) for the death of Abner. This

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Fasting of David, he saith, was for the obtaining of something for them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: at Gods hands, after their death; because after he had Fasted to procure

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the recovery of his owne child, assoone as he know it was dead, he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: called for meate. Seeing then the Soule hath an existence separate from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Body, and nothing can be obtained by mens Fasting for the Soules

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that are already either in Heaven, or Hell, it followeth that there be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: some Soules of dead men, what are neither in Heaven, nor in Hell; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore they must bee in some third place, which must be Purgatory.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And thus with hard straining, hee has wrested those places to the proofe

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of a Purgatory; whereas it is manifest, that the ceremonies of Mourning,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Fasting, when they are used for the death of men, whose life was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not profitable to the Mourners, they are used for honours sake to their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: persons; and when tis done for the death of them by whose life the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Mourners had benefit, it proceeds from their particular dammage: And so

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: David honoured Saul, and Abner, with his Fasting; and in the death of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his owne child, recomforted himselfe, by receiving his ordinary food.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In the other places, which he alledgeth out of the old Testament, there

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is not so much as any shew, or colour of proofe. He brings in every text

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: wherein there is the word Anger, or Fire, or Burning, or Purging, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Clensing, in case any of the Fathers have but in a Sermon rhetorically

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: applied it to the Doctrine of Purgatory, already beleeved. The first

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: verse of Psalme, 37. "O Lord rebuke me not in thy wrath, nor chasten me

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in thy hot displeasure:" What were this to Purgatory, if Augustine had

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not applied the Wrath to the fire of Hell, and the Displeasure, to that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Purgatory? And what is it to Purgatory, that of Psalme, 66. 12. "Wee

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: went through fire and water, and thou broughtest us to a moist place;"

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and other the like texts, (with which the Doctors of those times

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: entended to adorne, or extend their Sermons, or Commentaries) haled to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their purposes by force of wit?

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Places Of The New Testament For Purgatory Answered

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But he alledgeth other places of the New Testament, that are not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: so easie to be answered: And first that of Matth. 12.32. "Whosoever

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: speaketh a word against the Sonne of man, it shall be forgiven him; but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whosoever speaketh against the Holy Ghost, it shall not bee forgiven

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him neither in this world, nor in the world to come:" Where he will have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Purgatory to be the World to come, wherein some sinnes may be forgiven,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which in this World were not forgiven: notwithstanding that it is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: manifest, there are but three Worlds; one from the Creation to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Flood, which was destroyed by Water, and is called in Scripture the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Old World; another from the Flood to the day of Judgement, which is the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Present World, and shall bee destroyed by Fire; and the third, which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shall bee from the day of Judgement forward, everlasting, which is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: called the World To Come; and in which it is agreed by all, there shall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be no Purgatory; And therefore the World to come, and Purgatory, are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: inconsistent. But what then can bee the meaning of those our Saviours

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: words? I confesse they are very hardly to bee reconciled with all the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Doctrines now unanimously received: Nor is it any shame, to confesse the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: profoundnesse of the Scripture, to bee too great to be sounded by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shortnesse of humane understanding. Neverthelesse, I may propound such

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: things to the consideration of more learned Divines, as the text it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: selfe suggesteth. And first, seeing to speake against the Holy Ghost, as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: being the third Person of the Trinity, is to speake against the Church,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in which the Holy Ghost resideth; it seemeth the comparison is made,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: betweene the Easinesse of our Saviour, in bearing with offences done to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him while he was on earth, and the Severity of the Pastors after him,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: against those which should deny their authority, which was from the Holy

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ghost: As if he should say, You that deny my Power; nay you that shall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: crucifie me, shall be pardoned by mee, as often as you turne unto mee by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Repentance: But if you deny the Power of them that teach you hereafter,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by vertue of the Holy Ghost, they shall be inexorable, and shall not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: forgive you, but persecute you in this World, and leave you without

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: absolution, (though you turn to me, unlesse you turn also to them,) to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the punishments (as much as lies in them) of the World to come: And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: so the words may be taken as a Prophecy, or Praediction concerning the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: times, as they have along been in the Christian Church: Or if this be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not the meaning, (for I am not peremptory in such difficult places,)

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Repentance of some sinners: And there is also another place, that

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Cor. 15. 29.) "What shall they doe which are Baptized for the dead, if

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Scripture, to inquire if there be no clearer place that contradicts

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them. Onely of thus much, I see evident Scripture, to perswade men, that

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: glorious, spirituall, and immortall Body.

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Originall Of Daemonology

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The impression made on the organs of Sight, by lucide Bodies, either in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: one direct line, or in many lines, reflected from Opaque, or refracted

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in the passage through Diaphanous Bodies, produceth in living Creatures,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in whom God hath placed such Organs, an Imagination of the Object, from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whence the Impression proceedeth; which Imagination is called Sight; and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: seemeth not to bee a meer Imagination, but the Body it selfe without

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: us; in the same manner, as when a man violently presseth his eye, there

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: appears to him a light without, and before him, which no man perceiveth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but himselfe; because there is indeed no such thing without him, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: onely a motion in the interiour organs, pressing by resistance

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: outward, that makes him think so. And the motion made by this pressure,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: continuing after the object which caused it is removed, is that we call

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Imagination, and Memory, and (in sleep, and sometimes in great distemper

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the organs by Sicknesse, or Violence) a Dream: of which things I have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: already spoken briefly, in the second and third Chapters.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: This nature of Sight having never been discovered by the ancient

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: pretenders to Naturall Knowledge; much lesse by those that consider not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: things so remote (as that Knowledge is) from their present use; it was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hard for men to conceive of those Images in the Fancy, and in the Sense,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: otherwise, than of things really without us: Which some (because they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: vanish away, they know not whither, nor how,) will have to be absolutely

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Incorporeall, that is to say Immateriall, of Formes without Matter;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Colour and Figure, without any coloured or figured Body; and that they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: can put on Aiery bodies (as a garment) to make them Visible when

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they will to our bodily Eyes; and others say, are Bodies, and living

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Creatures, but made of Air, or other more subtile and aethereall Matter,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which is, then, when they will be seen, condensed. But Both of them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: agree on one generall appellation of them, DAEMONS. As if the Dead of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whom they Dreamed, were not Inhabitants of their own Brain, but of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Air, or of Heaven, or Hell; not Phantasmes, but Ghosts; with just

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as much reason, as if one should say, he saw his own Ghost in a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Looking-Glasse, or the Ghosts of the Stars in a River; or call the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ordinary apparition of the Sun, of the quantity of about a foot, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Daemon, or Ghost of that great Sun that enlighteneth the whole visible

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: world: And by that means have feared them, as things of an unknown, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is, of an unlimited power to doe them good, or harme; and consequently,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: given occasion to the Governours of the Heathen Common-wealths to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: regulate this their fear, by establishing that DAEMONOLOGY (in which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Poets, as Principal Priests of the Heathen Religion, were specially

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: employed, or reverenced) to the Publique Peace, and to the Obedience of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Subjects necessary thereunto; and to make some of them Good Daemons,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and others Evill; the one as a Spurre to the Observance, the other, as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Reines to withhold them from Violation of the Laws.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: What Were The Daemons Of The Ancients

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Daemons, appeareth partly in the Genealogie of their Gods, written by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Hesiod, one of the most ancient Poets of the Graecians; and partly in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other Histories; of which I have observed some few before, in the 12.

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: How That Doctrine Was Spread

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Graecians, by their Colonies and Conquests, communicated their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Language and Writings into Asia, Egypt, and Italy; and therein, by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: necessary consequence their Daemonology, or (as St. Paul calles it)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "their Doctrines of Devils;" And by that meanes, the contagion was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: derived also to the Jewes, both of Judaea, and Alexandria, and other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: parts, whereinto they were dispersed. But the name of Daemon they did

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not (as the Graecians) attribute to Spirits both Good, and Evill; but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to the Evill onely: And to the Good Daemons they gave the name of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Spirit of God; and esteemed those into whose bodies they entred to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Prophets. In summe, all singularity if Good, they attributed to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Spirit of God; and if Evill, to some Daemon, but a kakodaimen, an Evill

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Daemon, that is, a Devill. And therefore, they called Daemoniaques, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is, possessed by the Devill, such as we call Madmen or Lunatiques; or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such as had the Falling Sicknesse; or that spoke any thing, which they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for want of understanding, thought absurd: As also of an Unclean person

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in a notorious degree, they used to say he had an Unclean Spirit; of a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Dumbe man, that he had a Dumbe Devill; and of John Baptist (Math. 11.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 18.) for the singularity of his fasting, that he had a Devill; and of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: our Saviour, because he said, hee that keepeth his sayings should not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: see Death In Aeternum, (John 8. 52.) "Now we know thou hast a Devill;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Abraham is dead, and the Prophets are dead:" And again, because he said

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (John 7. 20.) "They went about to kill him," the people answered, "Thou

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hast a Devill, who goeth about to kill thee?" Whereby it is manifest,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that the Jewes had the same opinions concerning Phantasmes, namely, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they were not Phantasmes that is, Idols of the braine, but things reall,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and independent on the Fancy.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Why Our Saviour Controlled It Not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Which doctrine if it be not true, why (may some say) did not our Saviour

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: contradict it, and teach the Contrary? nay why does he use on diverse

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: occasions, such forms of speech as seem to confirm it? To this I answer,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that first, where Christ saith, "A Spirit hath not flesh and bone,"

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: though hee shew that there be Spirits, yet he denies not that they are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Bodies: And where St. Paul sais, "We shall rise Spirituall Bodies," he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: acknowledgeth the nature of Spirits, but that they are Bodily Spirits;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which is not difficult to understand. For Air and many other things

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are Bodies, though not Flesh and Bone, or any other grosse body, to bee

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: discerned by the eye. But when our Saviour speaketh to the Devill, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: commandeth him to go out of a man, if by the Devill, be meant a Disease,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as Phrenesy, or Lunacy, or a corporeal Spirit, is not the speech

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: improper? can Diseases heare? or can there be a corporeall Spirit in a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Body of Flesh and Bone, full already of vitall and animall Spirits?

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Are there not therefore Spirits, that neither have Bodies, nor are meer

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Imaginations? To the first I answer, that the addressing of our Saviours

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: command to the Madnesse, or Lunacy he cureth, is no more improper, then

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was his rebuking of the Fever, or of the Wind, and Sea; for neither

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: do these hear: Or than was the command of God, to the Light, to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Firmament, to the Sunne, and Starres, when he commanded them to bee; for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they could not heare before they had a beeing. But those speeches are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not improper, because they signifie the power of Gods Word: no more

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore is it improper, to command Madnesse, or Lunacy (under the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: appellation of Devils, by which they were then commonly understood,)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to depart out of a mans body. To the second, concerning their being

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Incorporeall, I have not yet observed any place of Scripture, from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whence it can be gathered, that any man was ever possessed with any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other Corporeal Spirit, but that of his owne, by which his body is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: naturally moved.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Scriptures Doe Not Teach That Spirits Are Incorporeall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Our Saviour, immediately after the Holy Ghost descended upon him in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: form of a Dove, is said by St. Matthew (Chapt. 4. 1.) to have been "led

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: up by the Spirit into the Wildernesse;" and the same is recited (Luke 4.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 1.) in these words, "Jesus being full of the Holy Ghost, was led in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Spirit into the Wildernesse;" Whereby it is evident, that by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Spirit there, is meant the Holy Ghost. This cannot be interpreted for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Possession: For Christ, and the Holy Ghost, are but one and the same

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: substance; which is no possession of one substance, or body, by another.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And whereas in the verses following, he is said "to have been taken

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: up by the Devill into the Holy City, and set upon a pinnacle of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Temple," shall we conclude thence that hee was possessed of the Devill,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or carryed thither by violence? And again, "carryed thence by the Devill

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: into an exceeding high mountain, who shewed him them thence all the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kingdomes of the world:" herein, wee are not to beleeve he was either

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: possessed, or forced by the Devill; nor that any Mountaine is high

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: enough, (according to the literall sense,) to shew him one whole

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Hemisphere. What then can be the meaning of this place, other than that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he went of himself into the Wildernesse; and that this carrying of him

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: up and down, from the Wildernesse to the City, and from thence into a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Mountain, was a Vision? Conformable whereunto, is also the phrase of St.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Luke, that hee was led into the Wildernesse, not By, but In the Spirit:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whereas concerning His being Taken up into the Mountaine, and unto the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Pinnacle of the Temple, hee speaketh as St. Matthew doth. Which suiteth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with the nature of a Vision.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Again, where St. Luke sayes of Judas Iscariot, that "Satan entred into

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him, and thereupon that he went and communed with the Chief Priests, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Captaines, how he might betray Christ unto them:" it may be answered,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that by the Entring of Satan (that is the Enemy) into him, is meant, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hostile and traiterous intention of selling his Lord and Master. For as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by the Holy Ghost, is frequently in Scripture understood, the Graces and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: good Inclinations given by the Holy Ghost; so by the Entring of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Satan, may bee understood the wicked Cogitations, and Designes of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Adversaries of Christ, and his Disciples. For as it is hard to say,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that the Devill was entred into Judas, before he had any such hostile

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: designe; so it is impertinent to say, he was first Christs Enemy in his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: heart, and that the Devill entred into him afterwards. Therefore the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Entring of Satan, and his Wicked Purpose, was one and the same thing.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But if there be no Immateriall Spirit, nor any Possession of mens bodies

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by any Spirit Corporeall, it may again be asked, why our Saviour and his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Apostles did not teach the People so; and in such cleer words, as they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: might no more doubt thereof. But such questions as these, are more

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: curious, than necessary for a Christian mans Salvation. Men may as well

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: aske, why Christ that could have given to all men Faith, Piety, and all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: manner of morall Vertues, gave it to some onely, and not to all: and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: why he left the search of naturall Causes, and Sciences, to the naturall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Reason and Industry of men, and did not reveal it to all, or any man

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: supernaturally; and many other such questions: Of which neverthelesse

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there may be alledged probable and pious reasons. For as God, when he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: brought the Israelites into the Land of Promise, did not secure them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therein, by subduing all the Nations round about them; but left many of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them, as thornes in their sides, to awaken from time to time their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Piety and Industry: so our Saviour, in conducting us toward his heavenly

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Kingdome, did not destroy all the difficulties of Naturall Questions;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but left them to exercise our Industry, and Reason; the Scope of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his preaching, being onely to shew us this plain and direct way to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Salvation, namely, the beleef of this Article, "that he was the Christ,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Son of the living God, sent into the world to sacrifice himselfe for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: our Sins, and at his comming again, gloriously to reign over his Elect,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and to save them from their Enemies eternally:" To which, the opinion

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Possession by Spirits, or Phantasmes, are no impediment in the way;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: though it be to some an occasion of going out of the way, and to follow

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their own Inventions. If wee require of the Scripture an account of all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: questions, which may be raised to trouble us in the performance of Gods

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: commands; we may as well complaine of Moses for not having set downe the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: time of the creation of such Spirits, as well as of the Creation of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Earth, and Sea, and of Men, and Beasts. To conclude, I find in Scripture

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that there be Angels, and Spirits, good and evill; but not that they are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Incorporeall, as are the Apparitions men see in the Dark, or in a Dream,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or Vision; which the Latines call Spectra, and took for Daemons. And I

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: find that there are Spirits Corporeal, (though subtile and Invisible;)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but not that any mans body was possessed, or inhabited by them; And that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Bodies of the Saints shall be such, namely, Spirituall Bodies, as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: St. Paul calls them.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Church

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Neverthelesse, the contrary Doctrine, namely, that there be Incorporeall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Spirits, hath hitherto so prevailed in the Church, that the use of

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thereupon built; and (though rarely and faintly practised) is not yet

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: totally given over. That there were many Daemoniaques in the Primitive

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Church, and few Mad-men, and other such singular diseases; whereas in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: these times we hear of, and see many Mad-men, and few Daemoniaques,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: proceeds not from the change of Nature; but of Names. But how it comes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to passe, that whereas heretofore the Apostles, and after them for a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: time, the Pastors of the Church, did cure those singular Diseases, which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: now they are not seen to doe; as likewise, why it is not in the power of

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to speak with new Tongues, to take up Serpents, to drink deadly Poison

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: without harm taking, and to cure the Sick by the laying on of their

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: were given to the Church, for no longer a time, than men trusted wholly

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to Christ, and looked for their felicity onely in his Kingdome to come;

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Another Relique Of Gentilisme, Worshipping Images, Left In The Church

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Not Brought Into It

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Another relique of Gentilisme, is the Worship of Images, neither

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: instituted by Moses in the Old, nor by Christ in the New Testament; nor

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: yet brought in from the Gentiles; but left amongst them, after they had

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: given their names to Christ. Before our Saviour preached, it was the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: generall Religion of the Gentiles, to worship for Gods, those Apparences

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that remain in the Brain from the impression of externall Bodies upon

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the organs of their Senses, which are commonly called Ideas, Idols,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Phantasmes, Conceits, as being Representations of those externall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Bodies, which cause them, and have nothing in them of reality, no more

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: than there is in the things that seem to stand before us in a Dream:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And this is the reason why St. Paul says, "Wee know that an Idol is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nothing:" Not that he thought that an Image of Metall, Stone, or Wood,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was nothing; but that the thing which they honored, or feared in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Image, and held for a God, was a meer Figment, without place,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: habitation, motion, or existence, but in the motions of the Brain.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And the worship of these with Divine Honour, is that which is in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Scripture called Idolatry, and Rebellion against God. For God being King

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Jews, and his Lieutenant being first Moses, and afterward the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: High Priest; if the people had been permitted to worship, and pray to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Images, (which are Representations of their own Fancies,) they had

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: had no farther dependence on the true God, of whom there can be no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: similitude; nor on his prime Ministers, Moses, and the High Priests;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but every man had governed himself according to his own appetite, to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: utter eversion of the Common-wealth, and their own destruction for want

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Union. And therefore the first Law of God was, "They should not take

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for Gods, ALIENOS DEOS, that is, the Gods of other nations, but that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: onely true God, who vouchsafed to commune with Moses, and by him to give

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them laws and directions, for their peace, and for their salvation

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from their enemies." And the second was, that "they should not make to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: themselves any Image to Worship, of their own Invention." For it is the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: same deposing of a King, to submit to another King, whether he be set up

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by a neighbour nation, or by our selves.

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to God; as to worship his Footstool: And lastly, some other texts, by

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: examine the force of those places, to prove that which is pretended, I

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: must first explain what is to be understood by Worshipping, and what by
