text: nature, secret, and internall in the heart. But the inward thoughts of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: men, which appeare outwardly in their words and actions, are the signes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of our Honoring, and these goe by the name of WORSHIP, in Latine,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CULTUS. Therefore, to Pray to, to Swear by, to Obey, to bee Diligent,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Officious in Serving: in summe, all words and actions that betoken

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Fear to Offend, or Desire to Please, is Worship, whether those words

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and actions be sincere, or feigned: and because they appear as signes of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Honoring, are ordinarily also called Honor.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Distinction Between Divine And Civill Worship

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Worship we exhibite to those we esteem to be but men, as to Kings,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and men in Authority, is Civill Worship: But the worship we exhibite

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to that which we think to bee God, whatsoever the words, ceremonies,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: gestures, or other actions be, is Divine Worship. To fall prostrate

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: before a King, in him that thinks him but a Man, is but Civill Worship:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And he that but putteth off his hat in the Church, for this cause, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he thinketh it the House of God, worshippeth with Divine Worship. They

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that seek the distinction of Divine and Civill Worship, not in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: intention of the Worshipper, but in the Words douleia, and latreia,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: deceive themselves. For whereas there be two sorts of Servants; that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sort, which is of those that are absolutely in the power of their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Masters, as Slaves taken in war, and their Issue, whose bodies are not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in their own power, (their lives depending on the Will of their Masters,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in such manner as to forfeit them upon the least disobedience,) and that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are bought and sold as Beasts, were called Douloi, that is properly,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Slaves, and their Service, Douleia: The other, which is of those that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: serve (for hire, or in hope of benefit from their Masters) voluntarily;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are called Thetes; that is, Domestique Servants; to whose service the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Masters have no further right, than is contained in the Covenants made

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: betwixt them. These two kinds of Servants have thus much common to them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: both, that their labour is appointed them by another, whether, as a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Slave, or a voluntary Servant: And the word Latris, is the general name

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of both, signifying him that worketh for another, whether, as a Slave,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or a voluntary Servant: So that Latreia signifieth generally all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Service; but Douleia the service of Bondmen onely, and the condition of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Slavery: And both are used in Scripture (to signifie our Service of God)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: promiscuously. Douleia, because we are Gods Slaves; Latreia, because

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: wee Serve him: and in all kinds of Service is contained, not onely

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Obedience, but also Worship, that is, such actions, gestures, and words,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as signifie Honor.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: An Image What Phantasmes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: An IMAGE (in the most strict signification of the word) is the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Resemblance of some thing visible: In which sense the Phantasticall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Formes, Apparitions, or Seemings of Visible Bodies to the Sight, are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: onely Images; such as are the Shew of a man, or other thing in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Water, by Reflexion, or Refraction; or of the Sun, or Stars by Direct

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Vision in the Air; which are nothing reall in the things seen, nor in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the place where thy seem to bee; nor are their magnitudes and figures

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the same with that of the object; but changeable, by the variation of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the organs of Sight, or by glasses; and are present oftentimes in our

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Imagination, and in our Dreams, when the object is absent; or changed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: into other colours, and shapes, as things that depend onely upon the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Fancy. And these are the Images which are originally and most properly

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: called Ideas, and IDOLS, and derived from the language of the Graecians,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: with whom the word Eido signifieth to See. They are also called

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: PHANTASMES, which is in the same language, Apparitions. And from these

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Images it is that one of the faculties of mans Nature, is called the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Imagination. And from hence it is manifest, that there neither is, nor

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: can bee any Image made of a thing Invisible.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: It is also evident, that there can be no Image of a thing Infinite: for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all the Images, and Phantasmes that are made by the Impression of things

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: visible, are figured: but Figure is a quantity every way determined: And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: therefore there can bee no Image of God: nor of the Soule of Man; nor of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Spirits, but onely of Bodies Visible, that is, Bodies that have light in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: themselves, or are by such enlightened.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Fictions; Materiall Images

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And whereas a man can fancy Shapes he never saw; making up a Figure out

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the parts of divers creatures; as the Poets make their Centaures,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Chimaeras, and other Monsters never seen: So can he also give Matter to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: those Shapes, and make them in Wood, Clay or Metall. And these are also

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: called Images, not for the resemblance of any corporeall thing, but for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the resemblance of some Phantasticall Inhabitants of the Brain of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Maker. But in these Idols, as they are originally in the Brain, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as they are painted, carved, moulded, or moulten in matter, there is a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: similitude of the one to the other, for which the Materiall Body made

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by Art, may be said to be the Image of the Phantasticall Idoll made by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nature.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But in a larger use of the word Image, is contained also, any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Representation of one thing by another. So an earthly Soveraign may be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: called the Image of God: And an inferiour Magistrate the Image of an

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: earthly Soveraign. And many times in the Idolatry of the Gentiles there

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was little regard to the similitude of their Materiall Idoll to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Idol in their fancy, and yet it was called the Image of it. For a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Stone unhewn has been set up for Neptune, and divers other shapes far

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: different from the shapes they conceived of their Gods. And at this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: day we see many Images of the Virgin Mary, and other Saints, unlike one

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: another, and without correspondence to any one mans Fancy; and yet serve

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: well enough for the purpose they were erected for; which was no more but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by the Names onely, to represent the Persons mentioned in the History;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to which every man applyeth a Mentall Image of his owne making, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: none at all. And thus an Image in the largest sense, is either the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Resemblance, or the Representation of some thing Visible; or both

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: together, as it happeneth for the most part.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But the name of Idoll is extended yet further in Scripture, to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: signifie also the Sunne, or a Starre, or any other Creature, visible or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: invisible, when they are worshipped for Gods.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Idolatry What

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Having shewn what is Worship, and what an Image; I will now put them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: together, and examine what that IDOLATRY is, which is forbidden in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Second Commandement, and other places of the Scripture.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To worship an Image, is voluntarily to doe those externall acts, which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are signes of honoring either the matter of the Image, which is Wood,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Stone, or Metall, or some other visible creature; or the Phantasme of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the brain, for the resemblance, or representation whereof, the matter

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was formed and figured; or both together, as one animate Body, composed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Matter and the Phantasme, as of a Body and Soule.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To be uncovered, before a man of Power and Authority, or before the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Throne of a Prince, or in such other places as hee ordaineth to that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: purpose in his absence, is to Worship that man, or Prince with Civill

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Worship; as being a signe, not of honoring the stoole, or place, but the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Person; and is not Idolatry. But if hee that doth it, should suppose the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soule of the Prince to be in the Stool, or should present a Petition to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Stool, it were Divine Worship, and Idolatry.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To pray to a King for such things, as hee is able to doe for us, though

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: we prostrate our selves before him, is but Civill Worship; because we

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: acknowledge no other power in him, but humane: But voluntarily to pray

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: unto him for fair weather, or for any thing which God onely can doe

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for us, is Divine Worship, and Idolatry. On the other side, if a King

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: compell a man to it by the terrour of Death, or other great corporall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: punishment, it is not Idolatry: For the Worship which the Soveraign

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: commandeth to bee done unto himself by the terrour of his Laws, is not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a sign that he that obeyeth him, does inwardly honour him as a God, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that he is desirous to save himselfe from death, or from a miserable

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: life; and that which is not a sign of internall honor, is no Worship;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and therefore no Idolatry. Neither can it bee said, that hee that does

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it, scandalizeth, or layeth any stumbling block before his Brother;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: because how wise, or learned soever he be that worshippeth in that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: manner, another man cannot from thence argue, that he approveth it; but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that he doth it for fear; and that it is not his act, but the act of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To worship God, in some peculiar Place, or turning a mans face towards

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: an Image, or determinate Place, is not to worship, or honor the Place,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or Image; but to acknowledge it Holy, that is to say, to acknowledge

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Image, or the Place to be set apart from common use: for that is the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: meaning of the word Holy; which implies no new quality in the Place, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Image; but onely a new Relation by Appropriation to God; and therefore

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is not Idolatry; no more than it was Idolatry to worship God before

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Brazen Serpent; or for the Jews when they were out of their owne

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: countrey, to turn their faces (when they prayed) toward the Temple of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Jerusalem; or for Moses to put off his Shoes when he was before the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Flaming Bush, the ground appertaining to Mount Sinai; which place God

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: had chosen to appear in, and to give his Laws to the People of Israel,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and was therefore Holy ground, not by inhaerent sanctity, but by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: separation to Gods use; or for Christians to worship in the Churches,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which are once solemnly dedicated to God for that purpose, by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Authority of the King, or other true Representant of the Church. But to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: worship God, is inanimating, or inhibiting, such Image, or place; that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is to say, an infinite substance in a finite place, is Idolatry: for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such finite Gods, are but Idols of the brain, nothing reall; and are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: commonly called in the Scripture by the names of Vanity, and Lyes, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Nothing. Also to worship God, not as inanimating, or present in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: place, or Image; but to the end to be put in mind of him, or of some

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: works of his, in case the Place, or Image be dedicated, or set up

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by private authority, and not by the authority of them that are our

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign Pastors, is Idolatry. For the Commandement is, "Thou shalt not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: make to thy selfe any graven image." God commanded Moses to set up the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Brazen Serpent; hee did not make it to himselfe; it was not therefore

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: against the Commandement. But the making of the Golden Calfe by Aaron,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and the People, as being done without authority from God, was Idolatry;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not onely because they held it for God, but also because they made it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for a Religious use, without warrant either from God their Soveraign, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from Moses, that was his Lieutenant.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Gentiles worshipped for Gods, Jupiter, and others; that living, were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: men perhaps that had done great and glorious Acts; and for the Children

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of God, divers men and women, supposing them gotten between an Immortall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Deity, and a mortall man. This was Idolatry, because they made them so

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to themselves, having no authority from God, neither in his eternall Law

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Reason, nor in his positive and revealed Will. But though our Saviour

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was a man, whom wee also beleeve to bee God Immortall, and the Son of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: God; yet this is no Idolatry; because wee build not that beleef upon

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: our own fancy, or judgment, but upon the Word of God revealed in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Scriptures. And for the adoration of the Eucharist, if the words of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christ, "This is my Body," signifie, "that he himselfe, and the seeming

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: bread in his hand; and not onely so, but that all the seeming morsells

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of bread that have ever since been, and any time hereafter shall bee

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consecrated by Priests, bee so many Christs bodies, and yet all of them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but one body," then is that no Idolatry, because it is authorized by our

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Saviour: but if that text doe not signifie that, (for there is no other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that can be alledged for it,) then, because it is a worship of humane

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: institution, it is Idolatry. For it is not enough to say, God can

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: transubstantiate the Bread into Christs Body: For the Gentiles also held

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: God to be Omnipotent; and might upon that ground no lesse excuse their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Idolatry, by pretending, as well as others, as transubstantiation of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their Wood, and Stone into God Almighty.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Whereas there be, that pretend Divine Inspiration, to be a supernaturall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: entring of the Holy Ghost into a man, and not an acquisition of Gods

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: grace, by doctrine, and study; I think they are in a very dangerous

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Dilemma. For if they worship not the men whom they beleeve to be so

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: inspired, they fall into Impiety; as not adoring Gods supernaturall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Presence. And again, if they worship them, they commit Idolatry; for the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Apostles would never permit themselves to be so worshipped. Therefore

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the safest way is to beleeve, that by the Descending of the Dove upon

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Apostles; and by Christs Breathing on them, when hee gave them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Holy Ghost; and by the giving of it by Imposition of Hands, are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: understood the signes which God hath been pleased to use, or ordain to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be used, of his promise to assist those persons in their study to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Preach his Kingdome, and in their Conversation, that it might not be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Scandalous, but Edifying to others.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Scandalous Worship Of Images

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Besides the Idolatrous Worship of Images, there is also a Scandalous

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Worship of them; which is also a sin; but not Idolatry. For Idolatry is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to worship by signes of an internall, and reall honour: but Scandalous

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Worship, is but Seeming Worship; and may sometimes bee joined with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: an inward, and hearty detestation, both of the Image, and of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Phantasticall Daemon, or Idol, to which it is dedicated; and proceed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: onely from the fear of death, or other grievous punishment; and is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: neverthelesse a sin in them that so worship, in case they be men whose

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: actions are looked at by others, as lights to guide them by; because

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: following their ways, they cannot but stumble, and fall in the way of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Religion: Whereas the example of those we regard not, works not on us

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: at all, but leaves us to our own diligence and caution; and consequently

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are no causes of our falling.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: If therefore a Pastor lawfully called to teach and direct others, or any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: other, of whose knowledge there is a great opinion, doe externall honor

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to an Idol for fear; unlesse he make his feare, and unwillingnesse to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it, as evident as the worship; he Scandalizeth his Brother, by seeming

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to approve Idolatry. For his Brother, arguing from the action of his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: teacher, or of him whose knowledge he esteemeth great, concludes it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to bee lawfull in it selfe. And this Scandall, is Sin, and a Scandall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: given. But if one being no Pastor, nor of eminent reputation for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: knowledge in Christian Doctrine, doe the same, and another follow him;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: this is no Scandall given; for he had no cause to follow such example:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but is a pretence of Scandall which hee taketh of himselfe for an excuse

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: before men: For an unlearned man, that is in the power of an idolatrous

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: King, or State, if commanded on pain of death to worship before an

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Idoll, hee detesteth the Idoll in his heart, hee doth well; though if he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: had the fortitude to suffer death, rather than worship it, he should

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: doe better. But if a Pastor, who as Christs Messenger, has undertaken to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: teach Christs Doctrine to all nations, should doe the same, it were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not onely a sinfull Scandall, in respect of other Christian mens

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consciences, but a perfidious forsaking of his charge.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The summe of that which I have said hitherto, concerning the Worship of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Images, is that, that he that worshippeth in an Image, or any Creature,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: either the Matter thereof, or any Fancy of his own, which he thinketh

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to dwell in it; or both together; or beleeveth that such things hear

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: his Prayers, or see his Devotions, without Ears, or Eyes, committeth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Idolatry: and he that counterfeiteth such Worship for fear of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: punishment, if he bee a man whose example hath power amongst his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Brethren, committeth a sin: But he that worshippeth the Creator of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: world before such an Image, or in such a place as he hath not made, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: chosen of himselfe, but taken from the commandement of Gods Word, as the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Jewes did in worshipping God before the Cherubins, and before the Brazen

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Serpent for a time, and in, or towards the Temple of Jerusalem, which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was also but for a time, committeth not Idolatry.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Now for the Worship of Saints, and Images, and Reliques, and other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: things at this day practised in the Church of Rome, I say they are not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: allowed by the Word of God, not brought into the Church of Rome, from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Doctrine there taught; but partly left in it at the first conversion

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Gentiles; and afterwards countenanced, and confirmed, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: augmented by the Bishops of Rome.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Answer To The Argument From The Cherubins, And Brazen Serpent

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: As for the proofs alledged out of Scripture, namely, those examples

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Images appointed by God to bee set up; They were not set up for the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: people, or any man to worship; but that they should worship God himselfe

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: before them: as before the Cherubins over the Ark, and the Brazen

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Serpent. For we read not, that the Priest, or any other did worship the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Cherubins; but contrarily wee read (2 Kings 18.4.) that Hezekiah brake

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in pieces the Brazen Serpent which Moses had set up, because the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: People burnt incense to it. Besides, those examples are not put for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: our Imitation, that we also should set up Images, under pretence

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of worshipping God before them; because the words of the second

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Commandement, "Thou shalt not make to thy selfe any graven Image, &c."

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: distinguish between the Images that God commanded to be set up, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: those which wee set up to our selves. And therefore from the Cherubins,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or Brazen Serpent, to the Images of mans devising; and from the Worship

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: commanded by God, to the Will-Worship of men, the argument is not good.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: This also is to bee considered, that as Hezekiah brake in pieces the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Brazen Serpent, because the Jews did worship it, to the end they should

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: doe so no more; so also Christian Soveraigns ought to break down the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Images which their Subjects have been accustomed to worship; that there

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be no more occasion of such Idolatry. For at this day, the ignorant

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: People, where Images are worshipped, doe really beleeve there is a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Divine Power in the Images; and are told by their Pastors, that some

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of them have spoken; and have bled; and that miracles have been done by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them; which they apprehend as done by the Saint, which they think either

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is the Image it self, or in it. The Israelites, when they worshipped the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Calfe, did think they worshipped the God that brought them out of Egypt;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and yet it was Idolatry, because they thought the Calfe either was

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that God, or had him in his belly. And though some man may think it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: impossible for people to be so stupid, as to think the Image to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: God, or a Saint; or to worship it in that notion; yet it is manifest

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in Scripture to the contrary; where when the Golden Calfe was made, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: people said, (Exod. 32. 2.) "These are thy Gods O Israel;" and where the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Images of Laban (Gen. 31.30.) are called his Gods. And wee see daily by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: experience in all sorts of People, that such men as study nothing but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their food and ease, are content to beleeve any absurdity, rather than

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to trouble themselves to examine it; holding their faith as it were by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: entaile unalienable, except by an expresse and new Law.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Painting Of Fancies No Idolatry: Abusing Them To Religious Worship Is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: But they inferre from some other places, that it is lawfull to paint

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Angels, and also God himselfe: as from Gods walking in the Garden; from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Jacobs seeing God at the top of the ladder; and from other Visions, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Dreams. But Visions, and Dreams whether naturall, or supernaturall, are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: but Phantasmes: and he that painteth an Image of any of them, maketh not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: an Image of God, but of his own Phantasm, which is, making of an Idol. I

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

text: of Common-wealths but the Popular, (such as was at that time the state

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Athens,) Tyranny. All Kings they called Tyrants; and the Aristocracy

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the thirty Governours set up there by the Lacedemonians that subdued

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them, the thirty Tyrants: As also to call the condition of the people

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: under the Democracy, Liberty. A Tyrant originally signified no more

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: simply, but a Monarch: But when afterwards in most parts of Greece that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: kind of government was abolished, the name began to signifie, not onely

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the thing it did before, but with it, the hatred which the Popular

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: States bare towards it: As also the name of King became odious after the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: deposing of the Kings in Rome, as being a thing naturall to all men,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to conceive some great Fault to be signified in any Attribute, that is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: given in despight, and to a great Enemy. And when the same men shall be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: displeased with those that have the administration of the Democracy,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or Aristocracy, they are not to seek for disgraceful names to expresse

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their anger in; but call readily the one Anarchy, and the other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Oligarchy, or the Tyranny Of A Few. And that which offendeth the People,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is no other thing, but that they are governed, not as every one of them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: would himselfe, but as the Publique Representant, be it one Man, or an

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Assembly of men thinks fit; that is, by an Arbitrary government: for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which they give evill names to their Superiors; never knowing (till

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: perhaps a little after a Civill warre) that without such Arbitrary

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: government, such Warre must be perpetuall; and that it is Men, and Arms,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not Words, and Promises, that make the Force and Power of the Laws.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: That Not Men, But Law Governs

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And therefore this is another Errour of Aristotles Politiques, that in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a wel ordered Common-wealth, not Men should govern, but the Laws. What

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man, that has his naturall Senses, though he can neither write nor read,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: does not find himself governed by them he fears, and beleeves can kill

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or hurt him when he obeyeth not? or that beleeves the Law can hurt him;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that is, Words, and Paper, without the Hands, and Swords of men? And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: this is of the number of pernicious Errors: for they induce men, as oft

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as they like not their Governours, to adhaere to those that call them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Tyrants, and to think it lawfull to raise warre against them: And yet

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they are many times cherished from the Pulpit, by the Clergy.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Laws Over The Conscience

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: There is another Errour in their Civill Philosophy (which they never

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: learned of Aristotle, nor Cicero, nor any other of the Heathen,) to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: extend the power of the Law, which is the Rule of Actions onely, to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: very Thoughts, and Consciences of men, by Examination, and Inquisition

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of what they Hold, notwithstanding the Conformity of their Speech and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Actions: By which, men are either punished for answering the truth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of their thoughts, or constrained to answer an untruth for fear of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: punishment. It is true, that the Civill Magistrate, intending to employ

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a Minister in the charge of Teaching, may enquire of him, if hee bee

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: content to Preach such, and such Doctrines; and in case of refusall,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: may deny him the employment: But to force him to accuse himselfe of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Opinions, when his Actions are not by Law forbidden, is against the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Law of Nature; and especially in them, who teach, that a man shall bee

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: damned to Eternall and extream torments, if he die in a false opinion

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: concerning an Article of the Christian Faith. For who is there, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: knowing there is so great danger in an error, when the naturall care

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of himself, compelleth not to hazard his Soule upon his own judgement,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: rather than that of any other man that is unconcerned in his damnation?

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Private Interpretation Of Law

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For a Private man, without the Authority of the Common-wealth, that is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to say, without permission from the Representant thereof, to Interpret

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Law by his own Spirit, is another Error in the Politiques; but not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: drawn from Aristotle, nor from any other of the Heathen Philosophers.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For none of them deny, but that in the Power of making Laws, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: comprehended also the Power of Explaining them when there is need. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are not the Scriptures, in all places where they are Law, made Law by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Authority of the Common-wealth, and consequently, a part of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Civill Law?

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Of the same kind it is also, when any but the Soveraign restraineth in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: any man that power which the Common-wealth hath not restrained: as they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: do, that impropriate the Preaching of the Gospell to one certain Order

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of men, where the Laws have left it free. If the State give me leave to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: preach, or teach; that is, if it forbid me not, no man can forbid me.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: If I find my selfe amongst the Idolaters of America, shall I that am a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Christian, though not in Orders, think it a sin to preach Jesus Christ,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: till I have received Orders from Rome? or when I have preached, shall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: not I answer their doubts, and expound the Scriptures to them; that is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shall I not Teach? But for this may some say, as also for administring

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to them the Sacraments, the necessity shall be esteemed for a sufficient

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Mission; which is true: But this is true also, that for whatsoever,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a dispensation is due for the necessity, for the same there needs no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: dispensation, when there is no Law that forbids it. Therefore to deny

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: these Functions to those, to whom the Civill Soveraigne hath not denyed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: them, is a taking away of a lawfull Liberty, which is contrary to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Doctrine of Civill Government.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Language Of Schoole-Divines

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: More examples of Vain Philosophy, brought into Religion by the Doctors

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Schoole-Divinity, might be produced; but other men may if they please

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: observe them of themselves. I shall onely adde this, that the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Writings of Schoole-Divines, are nothing else for the most part, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: insignificant Traines of strange and barbarous words, or words otherwise

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: used, then in the common use of the Latine tongue; such as would pose

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Cicero, and Varro, and all the Grammarians of ancient Rome. Which if any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: man would see proved, let him (as I have said once before) see whether

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: he can translate any Schoole-Divine into any of the Modern tongues, as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: French, English, or any other copious language: for that which cannot

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in most of these be made Intelligible, is no Intelligible in the Latine.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Which Insignificancy of language, though I cannot note it for false

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Philosophy; yet it hath a quality, not onely to hide the Truth, but also

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to make men think they have it, and desist from further search.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Errors From Tradition

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Lastly, for the errors brought in from false, or uncertain History, what

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is all the Legend of fictitious Miracles, in the lives of the Saints;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and all the Histories of Apparitions, and Ghosts, alledged by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Doctors of the Romane Church, to make good their Doctrines of Hell, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: purgatory, the power of Exorcisme, and other Doctrines which have no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: warrant, neither in Reason, nor Scripture; as also all those Traditions

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: which they call the unwritten Word of God; but old Wives Fables?

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Whereof, though they find dispersed somewhat in the Writings of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: ancient Fathers; yet those Fathers were men, that might too easily

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: beleeve false reports; and the producing of their opinions for testimony

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the truth of what they beleeved, hath no other force with them that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (according to the Counsell of St. John 1 Epist. chap. 4. verse 1.)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: examine Spirits, than in all things that concern the power of the Romane

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Church, (the abuse whereof either they suspected not, or had benefit

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by it,) to discredit their testimony, in respect of too rash beleef of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: reports; which the most sincere men, without great knowledge of naturall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: causes, (such as the Fathers were) are commonly the most subject to: For

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: naturally, the best men are the least suspicious of fraudulent purposes.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Gregory the Pope, and S. Bernard have somewhat of Apparitions of Ghosts,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that said they were in Purgatory; and so has our Beda: but no where, I

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: beleeve, but by report from others. But if they, or any other, relate

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: any such stories of their own knowledge, they shall not thereby confirm

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the more such vain reports; but discover their own Infirmity, or Fraud.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Suppression Of Reason

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: With the Introduction of False, we may joyn also the suppression of True

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Philosophy, by such men, as neither by lawfull authority, nor sufficient

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: study, are competent Judges of the truth. Our own Navigations make

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: manifest, and all men learned in humane Sciences, now acknowledge there

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are Antipodes: And every day it appeareth more and more, that Years, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Dayes are determined by Motions of the Earth. Neverthelesse, men that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have in their Writings but supposed such Doctrine, as an occasion to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: lay open the reasons for, and against it, have been punished for it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: by Authority Ecclesiasticall. But what reason is there for it? Is it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: because such opinions are contrary to true Religion? that cannot be,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: if they be true. Let therefore the truth be first examined by competent

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Judges, or confuted by them that pretend to know the contrary. Is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it because they be contrary to the Religion established? Let them be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: silenced by the Laws of those, to whom the Teachers of them are subject;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that is, by the Laws Civill: For disobedience may lawfully be punished

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in them, that against the Laws teach even true Philosophy. Is it because

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they tend to disorder in Government, as countenancing Rebellion, or

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sedition? then let them be silenced, and the Teachers punished by vertue

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of his power to whom the care of the Publique quiet is committed; which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is the Authority Civill. For whatsoever Power Ecclesiastiques take upon

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: themselves (in any place where they are subject to the State) in their

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: CHAPTER XLVII. OF THE BENEFIT THAT PROCEEDETH FROM SUCH DARKNESSE,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: AND TO WHOM IT ACCREWETH

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: He That Receiveth Benefit By A Fact, Is Presumed To Be The Author

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Cicero maketh honorable mention of one of the Cassii, a severe Judge

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: amongst the Romans, for a custome he had, in Criminal causes, (when the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: testimony of the witnesses was not sufficient,) to ask the Accusers,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Cui Bono; that is to say, what Profit, Honor, or other Contentment, the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: accused obtained, or expected by the Fact. For amongst Praesumptions,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: there is none that so evidently declareth the Author, as doth the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: BENEFIT of the Action. By the same rule I intend in this place to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: examine, who they may be, that have possessed the People so long in this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: part of Christendome, with these Doctrines, contrary to the Peaceable

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Societies of Mankind.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: That The Church Militant Is The Kingdome Of God, Was First Taught By

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: The Church Of Rome

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And first, to this Error, That The Present Church Now Militant On Earth,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Is The Kingdome Of God, (that is, the Kingdome of Glory, or the Land of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Promise; not the Kingdome of Grace, which is but a Promise of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Land,) are annexed these worldly Benefits, First, that the Pastors,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Teachers of the Church, are entitled thereby, as Gods Publique

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ministers, to a Right of Governing the Church; and consequently (because

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Church, and Common-wealth are the same Persons) to be Rectors, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Governours of the Common-wealth. By this title it is, that the Pope

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: prevailed with the subjects of all Christian Princes, to beleeve, that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to disobey him, was to disobey Christ himselfe; and in all differences

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: between him and other Princes, (charmed with the word Power Spirituall,)

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to abandon their lawfull Soveraigns; which is in effect an universall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Monarchy over all Christendome. For though they were first invested in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the right of being Supreme Teachers of Christian Doctrine, by, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: under Christian Emperors, within the limits of the Romane Empire (as is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: acknowledged by themselves) by the title of Pontifex Maximus, who was an

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Officer subject to the Civill State; yet after the Empire was divided,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and dissolved, it was not hard to obtrude upon the people already

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: subject to them, another Title, namely, the Right of St. Peter; not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: onely to save entire their pretended Power; but also to extend the same

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: over the same Christian Provinces, though no more united in the Empire

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Rome. This Benefit of an Universall Monarchy, (considering the desire

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of men to bear Rule) is a sufficient Presumption, that the popes that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: pretended to it, and for a long time enjoyed it, were the Authors of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Doctrine, by which it was obtained; namely, that the Church now

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: on Earth, is the Kingdome of Christ. For that granted, it must be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: understood, that Christ hath some Lieutenant amongst us, by whom we are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to be told what are his Commandements.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: After that certain Churches had renounced this universall Power of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Pope, one would expect in reason, that the Civill Soveraigns in all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: those Churches, should have recovered so much of it, as (before they had

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: unadvisedly let it goe) was their own Right, and in their own hands.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And in England it was so in effect; saving that they, by whom the Kings

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: administred the Government of Religion, by maintaining their imployment

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to be in Gods Right, seemed to usurp, if not a Supremacy, yet an

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Independency on the Civill Power: and they but seemed to usurp it, in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as much as they acknowledged a Right in the King, to deprive them of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Exercise of their Functions at his pleasure.

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: began at the Resurrection of our Saviour, was still retained. But Cui

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: expected: to have a Soveraign Power over the People. For what is it for

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Gods publique Service in his own Kingdom? and with force to resist

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: without Authority from the Civill Soveraign, to excommunicate any

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: an unlawfull Power over their Brethren? The Authors therefore of this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Darknesse in Religion, are the Romane, and the Presbyterian Clergy.

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To this head, I referre also all those Doctrines, that serve them to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: keep the possession of this spirituall Soveraignty after it is gotten.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: As first, that the Pope In His Publique Capacity Cannot Erre. For who

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: is there, that beleeving this to be true, will not readily obey him in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whatsoever he commands?

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

author: Thomas Hobbes

text: another evill seed, not differing much from the former. For to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Justification of the Cause of a Conqueror, the Reproach of the Cause

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Conquered, is for the most part necessary: but neither of them

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: necessary for the Obligation of the Conquered. And thus much I have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: thought fit to say upon the Review of the first and second part of this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Discourse.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In the 35th Chapter, I have sufficiently declared out of the Scripture,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that in the Common-wealth of the Jewes, God himselfe was made the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraign, by Pact with the People; who were therefore called his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Peculiar People, to distinguish them from the rest of the world, over

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: whom God reigned not by their Consent, but by his own Power: And that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in this Kingdome Moses was Gods Lieutenant on Earth; and that it was he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that told them what Laws God appointed to doe Execution; especially

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in Capitall Punishments; not then thinking it a matter of so necessary

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: consideration, as I find it since. Wee know that generally in all

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Common-wealths, the Execution of Corporeall Punishments, was either put

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: upon the Guards, or other Souldiers of the Soveraign Power; or given

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to those, in whom want of means, contempt of honour, and hardnesse of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: heart, concurred, to make them sue for such an Office. But amongst the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Israelites it was a Positive Law of God their Soveraign, that he that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was convicted of a capitall Crime, should be stoned to death by the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: People; and that the Witnesses should cast the first Stone, and after

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Witnesses, then the rest of the People. This was a Law that designed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: who were to be the Executioners; but not that any one should throw a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Stone at him before Conviction and Sentence, where the Congregation

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: was Judge. The Witnesses were neverthelesse to be heard before they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: proceeded to Execution, unlesse the Fact were committed in the presence

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Congregation it self, or in sight of the lawfull Judges; for

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: then there needed no other Witnesses but the Judges themselves.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Neverthelesse, this manner of proceeding being not throughly understood,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: hath given occasion to a dangerous opinion, that any man may kill

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: another, is some cases, by a Right of Zeal; as if the Executions done

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: upon Offenders in the Kingdome of God in old time, proceeded not from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Soveraign Command, but from the Authority of Private Zeal: which, if

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: we consider the texts that seem to favour it, is quite contrary.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: First, where the Levites fell upon the People, that had made and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: worshipped the Golden Calfe, and slew three thousand of them; it was by

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Commandement of Moses, from the mouth of God; as is manifest, Exod.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 32.27. And when the Son of a woman of Israel had blasphemed God, they

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that heard it, did not kill him, but brought him before Moses, who

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: put him under custody, till God should give Sentence against him; as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: appears, Levit. 25.11, 12. Again, (Numbers 25.6, 7.) when Phinehas

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: killed Zimri and Cosbi, it was not by right of Private Zeale: Their

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Crime was committed in the sight of the Assembly; there needed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: no Witnesse; the Law was known, and he the heir apparent to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Soveraignty; and which is the principall point, the Lawfulnesse of his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Act depended wholly upon a subsequent Ratification by Moses, whereof he

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: had no cause to doubt. And this Presumption of a future Ratification, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sometimes necessary to the safety [of] a Common-wealth; as in a sudden

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Rebellion, any man that can suppresse it by his own Power in the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Countrey where it begins, may lawfully doe it, and provide to have it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ratified, or Pardoned, whilest it is in doing, or after it is done. Also

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Numb. 35.30. it is expressely said, "Whosoever shall kill the Murtherer,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: shall kill him upon the word of Witnesses:" but Witnesses suppose

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a formall Judicature, and consequently condemn that pretence of Jus

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Zelotarum. The Law of Moses concerning him that enticeth to Idolatry,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (that is to say, in the Kingdome of God to a renouncing of his

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Allegiance) (Deut. 13.8.) forbids to conceal him, and commands the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Accuser to cause him to be put to death, and to cast the first stone at

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: him; but not to kill him before he be Condemned. And (Deut. 17. ver.4,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 5, 6.) the Processe against Idolatry is exactly set down: For God there

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: speaketh to the People, as Judge, and commandeth them, when a man is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Accused of Idolatry, to Enquire diligently of the Fact, and finding it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: true, then to Stone him; but still the hand of the Witnesse throweth

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the first stone. This is not Private Zeal, but Publique Condemnation. In

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: like manner when a Father hath a rebellious Son, the Law is (Deut. 21.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: 18.) that he shall bring him before the Judges of the Town, and all the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: people of the Town shall Stone him. Lastly, by pretence of these Laws

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it was, that St. Steven was Stoned, and not by pretence of Private Zeal:

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for before hee was carried away to Execution, he had Pleaded his Cause

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: before the High Priest. There is nothing in all this, nor in any other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: part of the Bible, to countenance Executions by Private Zeal; which

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: being oftentimes but a conjunction of Ignorance and Passion, is against

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: both the Justice and Peace of a Common-wealth.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In the 36th Chapter I have said, that it is not declared in what

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: manner God spake supernaturally to Moses: Not that he spake not to him

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: sometimes by Dreams and Visions, and by a supernaturall Voice, as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to other Prophets: For the manner how he spake unto him from the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Mercy-seat, is expressely set down (Numbers 7.89.) in these words,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: "From that time forward, when Moses entred into the Tabernacle of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Congregation to speak with God, he heard a Voice which spake unto him

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from over the Mercy-Seate, which is over the Arke of the Testimony, from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: between the Cherubins he spake unto him." But it is not declared in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: what consisted the praeeminence of the manner of Gods speaking to Moses,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: above that of his speaking to other Prophets, as to Samuel, and to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Abraham, to whom he also spake by a Voice, (that is, by Vision) Unlesse

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the difference consist in the cleernesse of the Vision. For Face

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to Face, and Mouth to Mouth, cannot be literally understood of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Infinitenesse, and Incomprehensibility of the Divine Nature.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And as to the whole Doctrine, I see not yet, but the principles of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it are true and proper; and the Ratiocination solid. For I ground the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Civill Right of Soveraigns, and both the Duty and Liberty of Subjects,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: upon the known naturall Inclinations of Mankind, and upon the Articles

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of the Law of Nature; of which no man, that pretends but reason enough

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: to govern his private family, ought to be ignorant. And for the Power

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ecclesiasticall of the same Soveraigns, I ground it on such Texts, as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: are both evident in themselves, and consonant to the Scope of the whole

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Scripture. And therefore am perswaded, that he that shall read it with

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: a purpose onely to be informed, shall be informed by it. But for those

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: that by Writing, or Publique Discourse, or by their eminent actions,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have already engaged themselves to the maintaining of contrary opinions,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: they will not bee so easily satisfied. For in such cases, it is naturall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: for men, at one and the same time, both to proceed in reading, and to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: lose their attention, in the search of objections to that they had read

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: before: Of which, in a time wherein the interests of men are changed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: (seeing much of that Doctrine, which serveth to the establishing of a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: new Government, must needs be contrary to that which conduced to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: dissolution of the old,) there cannot choose but be very many.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: In that part which treateth of a Christian Common-wealth, there are

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: some new Doctrines, which, it may be, in a State where the contrary were

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: already fully determined, were a fault for a Subject without leave to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: divulge, as being an usurpation of the place of a Teacher. But in this

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: time, that men call not onely for Peace, but also for Truth, to offer

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such Doctrines as I think True, and that manifestly tend to Peace and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Loyalty, to the consideration of those that are yet in deliberation, is

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: no more, but to offer New Wine, to bee put into New Cask, that bothe may

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: be preserved together. And I suppose, that then, when Novelty can breed

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: no trouble, nor disorder in a State, men are not generally so much

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: inclined to the reverence of Antiquity, as to preferre Ancient Errors,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: before New and well proved Truth.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: There is nothing I distrust more than my Elocution; which neverthelesse

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: I am confident (excepting the Mischances of the Presse) is not obscure.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: That I have neglected the Ornament of quoting ancient Poets, Orators,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and Philosophers, contrary to the custome of late time, (whether I have

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: done well or ill in it,) proceedeth from my judgment, grounded on many

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: reasons. For first, all Truth of Doctrine dependeth either upon Reason,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: or upon Scripture; both which give credit to many, but never receive it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: from any Writer. Secondly, the matters in question are not of Fact, but

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of Right, wherein there is no place for Witnesses. There is scarce any

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of those old Writers, that contradicteth not sometimes both himself,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: and others; which makes their Testimonies insufficient. Fourthly,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: such Opinions as are taken onely upon Credit of Antiquity, are not

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: intrinsically the Judgment of those that cite them, but Words that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: passe (like gaping) from mouth to mouth. Fiftly, it is many times with a

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: fraudulent Designe that men stick their corrupt Doctrine with the Cloves

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: of other mens Wit. Sixtly, I find not that the Ancients they cite, took

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it for an Ornament, to doe the like with those that wrote before them.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Seventhly, it is an argument of Indigestion, when Greek and Latine

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Sentences unchewed come up again, as they use to doe, unchanged. Lastly,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: though I reverence those men of Ancient time, that either have written

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Truth perspicuously, or set us in a better way to find it out our

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: selves; yet to the Antiquity it self I think nothing due: For if we will

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: reverence the Age, the Present is the Oldest. If the Antiquity of the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Writer, I am not sure, that generally they to whom such honor is given,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: were more Ancient when they wrote, than I am that am Writing: But if it

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: bee well considered, the praise of Ancient Authors, proceeds not from

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the reverence of the Dead, but from the competition, and mutuall envy of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Living.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: To conclude, there is nothing in this whole Discourse, nor in that I

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: writ before of the same Subject in Latine, as far as I can perceive,

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: contrary either to the Word of God, or to good Manners; or to the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: disturbance of the Publique Tranquillity. Therefore I think it may be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: profitably printed, and more profitably taught in the Universities, in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: case they also think so, to whom the judgment of the same belongeth.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: For seeing the Universities are the Fountains of Civill, and Morall

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Doctrine, from whence the Preachers, and the Gentry, drawing such water

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as they find, use to sprinkle the same (both from the Pulpit, and in

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: their Conversation) upon the People, there ought certainly to be

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: great care taken, to have it pure, both from the Venime of Heathen

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Politicians, and from the Incantation of Deceiving Spirits. And by that

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: means the most men, knowing their Duties, will be the less subject to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: serve the Ambition of a few discontented persons, in their purposes

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: against the State; and be the lesse grieved with the Contributions

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: necessary for their Peace, and Defence; and the Governours themselves

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: have the lesse cause, to maintain at the Common charge any greater

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Army, than is necessary to make good the Publique Liberty, against the

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Invasions and Encroachments of forraign Enemies.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: And thus I have brought to an end my Discourse of Civill and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Ecclesiasticall Government, occasioned by the disorders of the present

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: time, without partiality, without application, and without other

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: designe, than to set before mens eyes the mutuall Relation between

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Protection and Obedience; of which the condition of Humane Nature, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: the Laws Divine, (both Naturall and Positive) require an inviolable

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: observation. And though in the revolution of States, there can be no

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: very good Constellation for Truths of this nature to be born under, (as

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: having an angry aspect from the dissolvers of an old Government, and

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: seeing but the backs of them that erect a new;) yet I cannot think

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: it will be condemned at this time, either by the Publique Judge of

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: Doctrine, or by any that desires the continuance of Publique Peace. And

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: in this hope I return to my interrupted Speculation of Bodies Naturall;

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: wherein, (if God give me health to finish it,) I hope the Novelty will

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: as much please, as in the Doctrine of this Artificiall Body it useth to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: offend. For such Truth, as opposeth no man profit, nor pleasure, is to

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: all men welcome.

author: Thomas Hobbes
text: FINIS
