author: John Stuart Mill
text: _To the beloved and deplored memory of her who was the inspirer, and in

author: John Stuart Mill
text: part the author, of all that is best in my writings--the friend and wife

author: John Stuart Mill
text: whose exalted sense of truth and right was my strongest incitement, and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: whose approbation was my chief reward--I dedicate this volume. Like all

author: John Stuart Mill
text: that I have written for many years, it belongs as much to her as to me;

author: John Stuart Mill
text: but the work as it stands has had, in a very insufficient degree, the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: inestimable advantage of her revision; some of the most important

author: John Stuart Mill
text: portions having been reserved for a more careful re-examination, which

author: John Stuart Mill
text: they are now never destined to receive. Were I but capable of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: interpreting to the world one-half the great thoughts and noble feelings

author: John Stuart Mill
text: which are buried in her grave, I should be the medium of a greater

author: John Stuart Mill
text: benefit to it than is ever likely to arise from anything that I can

author: John Stuart Mill
text: write, unprompted and unassisted by her all but unrivalled wisdom._

author: John Stuart Mill
text: INTRODUCTION.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: I.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: John Stuart Mill was born on 20th May 1806. He was a delicate child, and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the extraordinary education designed by his father was not calculated to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: develop and improve his physical powers. "I never was a boy," he says;

author: John Stuart Mill
text: "never played cricket." His exercise was taken in the form of walks with

author: John Stuart Mill
text: his father, during which the elder Mill lectured his son and examined

author: John Stuart Mill
text: him on his work. It is idle to speculate on the possible results of a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: different treatment. Mill remained delicate throughout his life, but was

author: John Stuart Mill
text: endowed with that intense mental energy which is so often combined with

author: John Stuart Mill
text: physical weakness. His youth was sacrificed to an idea; he was designed

author: John Stuart Mill
text: by his father to carry on his work; the individuality of the boy was

author: John Stuart Mill
text: unimportant. A visit to the south of France at the age of fourteen, in

author: John Stuart Mill
text: company with the family of General Sir Samuel Bentham, was not without

author: John Stuart Mill
text: its influence. It was a glimpse of another atmosphere, though the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: studious habits of his home life were maintained. Moreover, he derived

author: John Stuart Mill
text: from it his interest in foreign politics, which remained one of his

author: John Stuart Mill
text: characteristics to the end of his life. In 1823 he was appointed junior

author: John Stuart Mill
text: clerk in the Examiners' Office at the India House.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Mill's first essays were written in the _Traveller_ about a year before

author: John Stuart Mill
text: he entered the India House. From that time forward his literary work was

author: John Stuart Mill
text: uninterrupted save by attacks of illness. His industry was stupendous.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: He wrote articles on an infinite variety of subjects, political,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: metaphysical, philosophic, religious, poetical. He discovered Tennyson

author: John Stuart Mill
text: for his generation, he influenced the writing of Carlyle's _French

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Revolution_ as well as its success. And all the while he was engaged in

author: John Stuart Mill
text: studying and preparing for his more ambitious works, while he rose step

author: John Stuart Mill
text: by step at the India Office. His _Essays on Unsettled Questions in

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Political Economy_ were written in 1831, although they did not appear

author: John Stuart Mill
text: until thirteen years later. His _System of Logic_, the design of which

author: John Stuart Mill
text: was even then fashioning itself in his brain, took thirteen years to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: complete, and was actually published before the _Political Economy_. In

author: John Stuart Mill
text: 1844 appeared the article on Michelet, which its author anticipated

author: John Stuart Mill
text: would cause some discussion, but which did not create the sensation he

author: John Stuart Mill
text: expected. Next year there were the "Claims of Labour" and "Guizot," and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: in 1847 his articles on Irish affairs in the _Morning Chronicle_. These

author: John Stuart Mill
text: years were very much influenced by his friendship and correspondence

author: John Stuart Mill
text: with Comte, a curious comradeship between men of such different

author: John Stuart Mill
text: temperament. In 1848 Mill published his _Political Economy_, to which he

author: John Stuart Mill
text: had given his serious study since the completion of his _Logic_. His

author: John Stuart Mill
text: articles and reviews, though they involved a good deal of work--as, for

author: John Stuart Mill
text: instance, the re-perusal of the _Iliad_ and the _Odyssey_ in the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: original before reviewing Grote's _Greece_--were recreation to the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: student. The year 1856 saw him head of the Examiners' Office in the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: India House, and another two years brought the end of his official work,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: owing to the transfer of India to the Crown. In the same year his wife

author: John Stuart Mill
text: died. _Liberty_ was published shortly after, as well as the _Thoughts on

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Parliamentary Reform_, and no year passed without Mill making important

author: John Stuart Mill
text: contributions on the political, philosophical, and ethical questions of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the day.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Seven years after the death of his wife, Mill was invited to contest

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Westminster. His feeling on the conduct of elections made him refuse to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: take any personal action in the matter, and he gave the frankest

author: John Stuart Mill
text: expression to his political views, but nevertheless he was elected by a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: large majority. He was not a conventional success in the House; as a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: speaker he lacked magnetism. But his influence was widely felt. "For the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: sake of the House of Commons at large," said Mr. Gladstone, "I rejoiced

author: John Stuart Mill
text: in his advent and deplored his disappearance. He did us all good." After

author: John Stuart Mill
text: only three years in Parliament, he was defeated at the next General

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Election by Mr. W. H. Smith. He retired to Avignon, to the pleasant

author: John Stuart Mill
text: little house where the happiest years of his life had been spent in the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: companionship of his wife, and continued his disinterested labours. He

author: John Stuart Mill
text: completed his edition of his father's _Analysis of the Mind_, and also

author: John Stuart Mill
text: produced, in addition to less important work, _The Subjection of Women_,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: in which he had the active co-operation of his step-daughter. A book on

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Socialism was under consideration, but, like an earlier study of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Sociology, it never was written. He died in 1873, his last years being

author: John Stuart Mill
text: spent peacefully in the pleasant society of his step-daughter, from

author: John Stuart Mill
text: whose tender care and earnest intellectual sympathy he caught maybe a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: far-off reflection of the light which had irradiated his spiritual life.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: II.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: The circumstances under which John Stuart Mill wrote his _Liberty_ are

author: John Stuart Mill
text: largely connected with the influence which Mrs. Taylor wielded over his

author: John Stuart Mill
text: career. The dedication is well known. It contains the most extraordinary

author: John Stuart Mill
text: panegyric on a woman that any philosopher has ever penned. "Were I but

author: John Stuart Mill
text: capable of interpreting to the world one-half the great thoughts and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: noble feelings which are buried in her grave, I should be the medium of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: a greater benefit to it than is ever likely to arise from anything that

author: John Stuart Mill
text: I can write, unprompted and unassisted by her all but unrivalled

author: John Stuart Mill
text: wisdom." It is easy for the ordinary worldly cynicism to curl a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: sceptical lip over sentences like these. There may be exaggeration of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: sentiment, the necessary and inevitable reaction of a man who was

author: John Stuart Mill
text: trained according to the "dry light" of so unimpressionable a man as

author: John Stuart Mill
text: James Mill, the father; but the passage quoted is not the only one in

author: John Stuart Mill
text: which John Stuart Mill proclaims his unhesitating belief in the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: intellectual influence of his wife. The treatise on _Liberty_ was

author: John Stuart Mill
text: written especially under her authority and encouragement, but there are

author: John Stuart Mill
text: many earlier references to the power which she exercised over his mind.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Mill was introduced to her as early as 1831, at a dinner-party at Mr.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Taylor's house, where were present, amongst others, Roebuck, W. J. Fox,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and Miss Harriet Martineau. The acquaintance rapidly ripened into

author: John Stuart Mill
text: intimacy and the intimacy into friendship, and Mill was never weary of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: expatiating on all the advantages of so singular a relationship. In some

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of the presentation copies of his work on _Political Economy_, he wrote

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the following dedication:--"To Mrs. John Taylor, who, of all persons

author: John Stuart Mill
text: known to the author, is the most highly qualified either to originate or

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to appreciate speculation on social advancement, this work is with the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: highest respect and esteem dedicated." An article on the enfranchisement

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of women was made the occasion for another encomium. We shall hardly be

author: John Stuart Mill
text: wrong in attributing a much later book, _The Subjection of Women_,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: published in 1869, to the influence wielded by Mrs. Taylor. Finally, the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: pages of the _Autobiography_ ring with the dithyrambic praise of his

author: John Stuart Mill
text: "almost infallible counsellor."

author: John Stuart Mill
text: The facts of this remarkable intimacy can easily be stated. The

author: John Stuart Mill
text: deductions are more difficult. There is no question that Mill's

author: John Stuart Mill
text: infatuation was the cause of considerable trouble to his acquaintances

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and friends. His father openly taxed him with being in love with another

author: John Stuart Mill
text: man's wife. Roebuck, Mrs. Grote, Mrs. Austin, Miss Harriet Martineau

author: John Stuart Mill
text: were amongst those who suffered because they made some allusion to a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: forbidden subject. Mrs. Taylor lived with her daughter in a lodging in

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the country; but in 1851 her husband died, and then Mill made her his

author: John Stuart Mill
text: wife. Opinions were widely divergent as to her merits; but every one

author: John Stuart Mill
text: agreed that up to the time of her death, in 1858, Mill was wholly lost

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to his friends. George Mill, one of Mill's younger brothers, gave it as

author: John Stuart Mill
text: his opinion that she was a clever and remarkable woman, but "nothing

author: John Stuart Mill
text: like what John took her to be." Carlyle, in his reminiscences, described

author: John Stuart Mill
text: her with ambiguous epithets. She was "vivid," "iridescent," "pale and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: passionate and sad-looking, a living-romance heroine of the royalist

author: John Stuart Mill
text: volition and questionable destiny." It is not possible to make much of a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: judgment like this, but we get on more certain ground when we discover

author: John Stuart Mill
text: that Mrs. Carlyle said on one occasion that "she is thought to be

author: John Stuart Mill
text: dangerous," and that Carlyle added that she was worse than dangerous,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: she was patronising. The occasion when Mill and his wife were brought

author: John Stuart Mill
text: into close contact with the Carlyles is well known. The manuscript of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the first volume of the _French Revolution_ had been lent to Mill, and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: was accidentally burnt by Mrs. Mill's servant. Mill and his wife drove

author: John Stuart Mill
text: up to Carlyle's door, the wife speechless, the husband so full of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: conversation that he detained Carlyle with desperate attempts at

author: John Stuart Mill
text: loquacity for two hours. But Dr. Garnett tells us, in his _Life of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Carlyle_, that Mill made a substantial reparation for the calamity for

author: John Stuart Mill
text: which he was responsible by inducing the aggrieved author to accept half

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of the L200 which he offered. Mrs. Mill, as I have said, died in 1858,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: after seven years of happy companionship with her husband, and was

author: John Stuart Mill
text: buried at Avignon. The inscription which Mill wrote for her grave is too

author: John Stuart Mill
text: characteristic to be omitted:--"Her great and loving heart, her noble

author: John Stuart Mill
text: soul, her clear, powerful, original, and comprehensive intellect, made

author: John Stuart Mill
text: her the guide and support, the instructor in wisdom and the example in

author: John Stuart Mill
text: goodness, as she was the sole earthly delight of those who had the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: happiness to belong to her. As earnest for all public good as she was

author: John Stuart Mill
text: generous and devoted to all who surrounded her, her influence has been

author: John Stuart Mill
text: felt in many of the greatest improvements of the age, and will be in

author: John Stuart Mill
text: those still to come. Were there even a few hearts and intellects like

author: John Stuart Mill
text: hers, this earth would already become the hoped-for Heaven." These lines

author: John Stuart Mill
text: prove the intensity of Mill's feeling, which is not afraid of abundant

author: John Stuart Mill
text: verbiage; but they also prove that he could not imagine what the effect

author: John Stuart Mill
text: would be on others, and, as Grote said, only Mill's reputation could

author: John Stuart Mill
text: survive these and similar displays.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Every one will judge for himself of this romantic episode in Mill's

author: John Stuart Mill
text: career, according to such experience as he may possess of the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: philosophic mind and of the value of these curious but not infrequent

author: John Stuart Mill
text: relationships. It may have been a piece of infatuation, or, if we prefer

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to say so, it may have been the most gracious and the most human page in

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Mill's career. Mrs. Mill may have flattered her husband's vanity by

author: John Stuart Mill
text: echoing his opinions, or she may have indeed been an Egeria, full of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: inspiration and intellectual helpfulness. What usually happens in these

author: John Stuart Mill
text: cases,--although the philosopher himself, through his belief in the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: equality of the sexes, was debarred from thinking so,--is the extremely

author: John Stuart Mill
text: valuable action and reaction of two different classes and orders of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: mind. To any one whose thoughts have been occupied with the sphere of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: abstract speculation, the lively and vivid presentment of concrete fact

author: John Stuart Mill
text: comes as a delightful and agreeable shock. The instinct of the woman

author: John Stuart Mill
text: often enables her not only to apprehend but to illustrate a truth for

author: John Stuart Mill
text: which she would be totally unable to give the adequate philosophic

author: John Stuart Mill
text: reasoning. On the other hand, the man, with the more careful logical

author: John Stuart Mill
text: methods and the slow processes of formal reasoning, is apt to suppose

author: John Stuart Mill
text: that the happy intuition which leaps to the conclusion is really based

author: John Stuart Mill
text: on the intellectual processes of which he is conscious in his own case.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Thus both parties to the happy contract are equally pleased. The

author: John Stuart Mill
text: abstract truth gets the concrete illustration; the concrete illustration

author: John Stuart Mill
text: finds its proper foundation in a series of abstract inquiries. Perhaps

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Carlyle's epithets of "iridescent" and "vivid" refer incidentally to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Mrs. Mill's quick perceptiveness, and thus throw a useful light on the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: mutual advantages of the common work of husband and wife. But it savours

author: John Stuart Mill
text: almost of impertinence even to attempt to lift the veil on a mystery

author: John Stuart Mill
text: like this. It is enough to say, perhaps, that however much we may

author: John Stuart Mill
text: deplore the exaggeration of Mill's references to his wife, we recognise

author: John Stuart Mill
text: that, for whatever reason, the pair lived an ideally happy life.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: It still, however, remains to estimate the extent to which Mrs. Taylor,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: both before and after her marriage with Mill, made actual contributions

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to his thoughts and his public work. Here I may be perhaps permitted to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: avail myself of what I have already written in a previous work.[1] Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: gives us abundant help in this matter in the _Autobiography_. When first

author: John Stuart Mill
text: he knew her, his thoughts were turning to the subject of Logic. But his

author: John Stuart Mill
text: published work on the subject owed nothing to her, he tells us, in its

author: John Stuart Mill
text: doctrines. It was Mill's custom to write the whole of a book so as to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: get his general scheme complete, and then laboriously to re-write it in

author: John Stuart Mill
text: order to perfect the phrases and the composition. Doubtless Mrs. Taylor

author: John Stuart Mill
text: was of considerable help to him as a critic of style. But to be a critic

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of doctrine she was hardly qualified. Mill has made some clear

author: John Stuart Mill
text: admissions on this point. "The only actual revolution which has ever

author: John Stuart Mill
text: taken place in my modes of thinking was already complete,"[2] he says,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: before her influence became paramount. There is a curiously humble

author: John Stuart Mill
text: estimate of his own powers (to which Dr. Bain has called attention),

author: John Stuart Mill
text: which reads at first sight as if it contradicted this. "During the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: greater part of my literary life I have performed the office in relation

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to her, which, from a rather early period, I had considered as the most

author: John Stuart Mill
text: useful part that I was qualified to take in the domain of thought, that

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of an interpreter of original thinkers, and mediator between them and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the public." So far it would seem that Mill had sat at the feet of his

author: John Stuart Mill
text: oracle; but observe the highly remarkable exception which is made in the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: following sentence:--"For I had always a humble opinion of my own powers

author: John Stuart Mill
text: as an original thinker, _except in abstract science (logic, metaphysics,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and the theoretic principles of political economy and politics.)_"[3] If

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Mill then was an original thinker in logic, metaphysics, and the science

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of economy and politics, it is clear that he had not learnt these from

author: John Stuart Mill
text: her lips. And to most men logic and metaphysics may be safely taken as

author: John Stuart Mill
text: forming a domain in which originality of thought, if it can be honestly

author: John Stuart Mill
text: professed, is a sufficient title of distinction.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Mrs. Taylor's assistance in the _Political Economy_ is confined to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: certain definite points. The purely scientific part was, we are assured,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: not learnt from her. "But it was chiefly her influence which gave to the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: book that general tone by which it is distinguished from all previous

author: John Stuart Mill
text: expositions of political economy that had any pretensions to be

author: John Stuart Mill
text: scientific, and which has made it so useful in conciliating minds which

author: John Stuart Mill
text: those previous expositions had repelled. This tone consisted chiefly in

author: John Stuart Mill
text: making the proper distinction between the laws of the production of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: wealth, which are real laws of Nature, dependent on the properties of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: objects, and the modes of its distribution, which, subject to certain

author: John Stuart Mill
text: conditions, depend on human will.... _I had indeed partially learnt this

author: John Stuart Mill
text: view of things from the thoughts awakened in me by the speculations of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: St. Simonians_; but it was made a living principle, pervading and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: animating the book, by my wife's promptings."[4] The part which is

author: John Stuart Mill
text: italicised is noticeable. Here, as elsewhere, Mill thinks out the matter

author: John Stuart Mill
text: by himself; the concrete form of the thoughts is suggested or prompted

author: John Stuart Mill
text: by the wife. Apart from this "general tone," Mill tells us that there

author: John Stuart Mill
text: was a specific contribution. "The chapter which has had a greater

author: John Stuart Mill
text: influence on opinion than all the rest, that on the Probable Future of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the Labouring Classes, is entirely due to her. In the first draft of the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: book that chapter did not exist. She pointed out the need of such a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: chapter, and the extreme imperfection of the book without it; she was

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the cause of my writing it." From this it would appear that she gave

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Mill that tendency to Socialism which, while it lends a progressive

author: John Stuart Mill
text: spirit to his speculations on politics, at the same time does not

author: John Stuart Mill
text: manifestly accord with his earlier advocacy of peasant proprietorships.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Nor, again, is it, on the face of it, consistent with those doctrines of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: individual liberty which, aided by the intellectual companionship of his

author: John Stuart Mill
text: wife, he propounded in a later work. The ideal of individual freedom is

author: John Stuart Mill
text: not the ideal of Socialism, just as that invocation of governmental aid

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to which the Socialist resorts is not consistent with the theory of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: _laisser-faire_. Yet _Liberty_ was planned by Mill and his wife in

author: John Stuart Mill
text: concert. Perhaps a slight visionariness of speculation was no less the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: attribute of Mrs. Mill than an absence of rigid logical principles. Be

author: John Stuart Mill
text: this as it may, she undoubtedly checked the half-recognised leanings of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: her husband in the direction of Coleridge and Carlyle. Whether this was

author: John Stuart Mill
text: an instance of her steadying influence,[5] or whether it added one more

author: John Stuart Mill
text: unassimilated element to Mill's diverse intellectual sustenance, may be

author: John Stuart Mill
text: wisely left an open question. We cannot, however, be wrong in

author: John Stuart Mill
text: attributing to her the parentage of one book of Mill, _The Subjection of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Women_. It is true that Mill had before learnt that men and women ought

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to be equal in legal, political, social, and domestic relations. This

author: John Stuart Mill
text: was a point on which he had already fallen foul of his father's essay on

author: John Stuart Mill
text: _Government_. But Mrs. Taylor had actually written on this very point,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and the warmth and fervour of Mill's denunciations of women's servitude

author: John Stuart Mill
text: were unmistakably caught from his wife's view of the practical

author: John Stuart Mill
text: disabilities entailed by the feminine position.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: III.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: _Liberty_ was published in 1859, when the nineteenth century was half

author: John Stuart Mill
text: over, but in its general spirit and in some of its special tendencies

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the little tract belongs rather to the standpoint of the eighteenth

author: John Stuart Mill
text: century than to that which saw its birth. In many of his speculations

author: John Stuart Mill
text: John Stuart Mill forms a sort of connecting link between the doctrines

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of the earlier English empirical school and those which we associate

author: John Stuart Mill
text: with the name of Mr. Herbert Spencer. In his _Logic_, for instance, he

author: John Stuart Mill
text: represents an advance on the theories of Hume, and yet does not see how

author: John Stuart Mill
text: profoundly the victories of Science modify the conclusions of the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: earlier thinker. Similarly, in his _Political Economy_, he desires to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: improve and to enlarge upon Ricardo, and yet does not advance so far as

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the modifications of political economy by Sociology, indicated by some

author: John Stuart Mill
text: later--and especially German--speculations on the subject. In the tract

author: John Stuart Mill
text: on _Liberty_, Mill is advocating the rights of the individual as against

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Society at the very opening of an era that was rapidly coming to the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: conclusion that the individual had no absolute rights against Society.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: The eighteenth century view is that individuals existed first, each with

author: John Stuart Mill
text: their own special claims and responsibilities; that they deliberately

author: John Stuart Mill
text: formed a Social State, either by a contract or otherwise; and that then

author: John Stuart Mill
text: finally they limited their own action out of regard for the interests of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the social organism thus arbitrarily produced. This is hardly the view

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of the nineteenth century. It is possible that logically the individual

author: John Stuart Mill
text: is prior to the State; historically and in the order of Nature, the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: State is prior to the individual. In other words, such rights as every

author: John Stuart Mill
text: single personality possesses in a modern world do not belong to him by

author: John Stuart Mill
text: an original ordinance of Nature, but are slowly acquired in the growth

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and development of the social state. It is not the truth that individual

author: John Stuart Mill
text: liberties were forfeited by some deliberate act when men made themselves

author: John Stuart Mill
text: into a Commonwealth. It is more true to say, as Aristotle said long ago,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: that man is naturally a political animal, that he lived under strict

author: John Stuart Mill
text: social laws as a mere item, almost a nonentity, as compared with the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Order, Society, or Community to which he belonged, and that such

author: John Stuart Mill
text: privileges as he subsequently acquired have been obtained in virtue of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: his growing importance as a member of a growing organisation. But if

author: John Stuart Mill
text: this is even approximately true, it seriously restricts that liberty of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the individual for which Mill pleads. The individual has no chance,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: because he has no rights, against the social organism. Society can

author: John Stuart Mill
text: punish him for acts or even opinions which are anti-social in character.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: His virtue lies in recognising the intimate communion with his fellows.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: His sphere of activity is bounded by the common interest. Just as it is

author: John Stuart Mill
text: an absurd and exploded theory that all men are originally equal, so it

author: John Stuart Mill
text: is an ancient and false doctrine to protest that a man has an individual

author: John Stuart Mill
text: liberty to live and think as he chooses in any spirit of antagonism to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: that larger body of which he forms an insignificant part.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Nowadays this view of Society and of its development, which we largely

author: John Stuart Mill
text: owe to the _Philosophie Positive_ of M. Auguste Comte, is so familiar

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and possibly so damaging to the individual initiative, that it becomes

author: John Stuart Mill
text: necessary to advance and proclaim the truth which resides in an opposite

author: John Stuart Mill
text: theory. All progress, as we are aware, depends on the joint process of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: integration and differentiation; synthesis, analysis, and then a larger

author: John Stuart Mill
text: synthesis seem to form the law of development. If it ever comes to pass

author: John Stuart Mill
text: that Society is tyrannical in its restrictions of the individual, if, as

author: John Stuart Mill
text: for instance in some forms of Socialism, based on deceptive analogies of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Nature's dealings, the type is everything and the individual nothing, it

author: John Stuart Mill
text: must be confidently urged in answer that the fuller life of the future

author: John Stuart Mill
text: depends on the manifold activities, even though they may be

author: John Stuart Mill
text: antagonistic, of the individual. In England, at all events, we know that

author: John Stuart Mill
text: government in all its different forms, whether as King, or as a caste

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of nobles, or as an oligarchical plutocracy, or even as trades unions,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: is so dwarfing in its action that, for the sake of the future, the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: individual must revolt. Just as our former point of view limited the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: value of Mill's treatise on _Liberty_, so these considerations tend to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: show its eternal importance. The omnipotence of Society means a dead

author: John Stuart Mill
text: level of uniformity. The claim of the individual to be heard, to say

author: John Stuart Mill
text: what he likes, to do what he likes, to live as he likes, is absolutely

author: John Stuart Mill
text: necessary, not only for the variety of elements without which life is

author: John Stuart Mill
text: poor, but also for the hope of a future age. So long as individual

author: John Stuart Mill
text: initiative and effort are recognised as a vital element in English

author: John Stuart Mill
text: history, so long will Mill's _Liberty_, which he confesses was based on

author: John Stuart Mill
text: a suggestion derived from Von Humboldt, remain as an indispensable

author: John Stuart Mill
text: contribution to the speculations, and also to the health and sanity, of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the world.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: What his wife really was to Mill, we shall, perhaps, never know. But

author: John Stuart Mill
text: that she was an actual and vivid force, which roused the latent

author: John Stuart Mill
text: enthusiasm of his nature, we have abundant evidence. And when she died

author: John Stuart Mill
text: at Avignon, though his friends may have regained an almost estranged

author: John Stuart Mill
text: companionship, Mill was, personally, the poorer. Into the sorrow of that

author: John Stuart Mill
text: bereavement we cannot enter: we have no right or power to draw the veil.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: It is enough to quote the simple words, so eloquent of an unspoken

author: John Stuart Mill
text: grief--"I can say nothing which could describe, even in the faintest

author: John Stuart Mill
text: manner, what that loss was and is. But because I know that she would

author: John Stuart Mill
text: have wished it, I endeavour to make the best of what life I have left,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and to work for her purposes with such diminished strength as can be

author: John Stuart Mill
text: derived from thoughts of her, and communion with her memory."

author: John Stuart Mill
text: W. L. COURTNEY.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: The grand, leading principle, towards which every argument

author: John Stuart Mill
text: unfolded in these pages directly converges, is the absolute and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: essential importance of human development in its richest

author: John Stuart Mill
text: diversity.--WILHELM VON HUMBOLDT: _Sphere and Duties of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: ON LIBERTY.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: CHAPTER I.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: INTRODUCTORY.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: The subject of this Essay is not the so-called Liberty of the Will, so

author: John Stuart Mill
text: unfortunately opposed to the misnamed doctrine of Philosophical

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Necessity; but Civil, or Social Liberty: the nature and limits of the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: power which can be legitimately exercised by society over the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: individual. A question seldom stated, and hardly ever discussed, in

author: John Stuart Mill
text: general terms, but which profoundly influences the practical

author: John Stuart Mill
text: controversies of the age by its latent presence, and is likely soon to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: make itself recognised as the vital question of the future. It is so far

author: John Stuart Mill
text: from being new, that in a certain sense, it has divided mankind, almost

author: John Stuart Mill
text: from the remotest ages; but in the stage of progress into which the more

author: John Stuart Mill
text: civilised portions of the species have now entered, it presents itself

author: John Stuart Mill
text: under new conditions, and requires a different and more fundamental

author: John Stuart Mill
text: treatment.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: The struggle between Liberty and Authority is the most conspicuous

author: John Stuart Mill
text: feature in the portions of history with which we are earliest familiar,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: particularly in that of Greece, Rome, and England. But in old times this

author: John Stuart Mill
text: contest was between subjects, or some classes of subjects, and the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: government. By liberty, was meant protection against the tyranny of the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: political rulers. The rulers were conceived (except in some of the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: popular governments of Greece) as in a necessarily antagonistic position

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to the people whom they ruled. They consisted of a governing One, or a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: governing tribe or caste, who derived their authority from inheritance

author: John Stuart Mill
text: or conquest, who, at all events, did not hold it at the pleasure of the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: governed, and whose supremacy men did not venture, perhaps did not

author: John Stuart Mill
text: desire, to contest, whatever precautions might be taken against its

author: John Stuart Mill
text: oppressive exercise. Their power was regarded as necessary, but also as

author: John Stuart Mill
text: highly dangerous; as a weapon which they would attempt to use against

author: John Stuart Mill
text: their subjects, no less than against external enemies. To prevent the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: weaker members of the community from being preyed upon by innumerable

author: John Stuart Mill
text: vultures, it was needful that there should be an animal of prey

author: John Stuart Mill
text: stronger than the rest, commissioned to keep them down. But as the king

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of the vultures would be no less bent upon preying on the flock than any

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of the minor harpies, it was indispensable to be in a perpetual attitude

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of defence against his beak and claws. The aim, therefore, of patriots,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: was to set limits to the power which the ruler should be suffered to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: exercise over the community; and this limitation was what they meant by

author: John Stuart Mill
text: liberty. It was attempted in two ways. First, by obtaining a recognition

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of certain immunities, called political liberties or rights, which it

author: John Stuart Mill
text: was to be regarded as a breach of duty in the ruler to infringe, and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: which if he did infringe, specific resistance, or general rebellion, was

author: John Stuart Mill
text: held to be justifiable. A second, and generally a later expedient, was

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the establishment of constitutional checks; by which the consent of the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: community, or of a body of some sort, supposed to represent its

author: John Stuart Mill
text: interests, was made a necessary condition to some of the more important

author: John Stuart Mill
text: acts of the governing power. To the first of these modes of limitation,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the ruling power, in most European countries, was compelled, more or

author: John Stuart Mill
text: less, to submit. It was not so with the second; and to attain this, or

author: John Stuart Mill
text: when already in some degree possessed, to attain it more completely,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: became everywhere the principal object of the lovers of liberty. And so

author: John Stuart Mill
text: long as mankind were content to combat one enemy by another, and to be

author: John Stuart Mill
text: ruled by a master, on condition of being guaranteed more or less

author: John Stuart Mill
text: efficaciously against his tyranny, they did not carry their aspirations

author: John Stuart Mill
text: beyond this point.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: A time, however, came, in the progress of human affairs, when men ceased

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to think it a necessity of nature that their governors should be an

author: John Stuart Mill
text: independent power, opposed in interest to themselves. It appeared to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: them much better that the various magistrates of the State should be

author: John Stuart Mill
text: their tenants or delegates, revocable at their pleasure. In that way

author: John Stuart Mill
text: alone, it seemed, could they have complete security that the powers of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: government would never be abused to their disadvantage. By degrees, this

author: John Stuart Mill
text: new demand for elective and temporary rulers became the prominent object

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of the exertions of the popular party, wherever any such party existed;

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and superseded, to a considerable extent, the previous efforts to limit

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: The object of this Essay is to assert one very simple principle, as

author: John Stuart Mill
text: entitled to govern absolutely the dealings of society with the

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of public opinion. That principle is, that the sole end for which

author: John Stuart Mill
text: mankind are warranted, individually or collectively, in interfering with

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the liberty of action of any of their number, is self-protection. That

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: member of a civilised community, against his will, is to prevent harm to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: others. His own good, either physical or moral, is not a sufficient

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: concerns others. In the part which merely concerns himself, his

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

text: This, then, is the appropriate region of human liberty. It comprises,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: first, the inward domain of consciousness; demanding liberty of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: conscience, in the most comprehensive sense; liberty of thought and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: feeling; absolute freedom of opinion and sentiment on all subjects,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: practical or speculative, scientific, moral, or theological. The liberty

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of expressing and publishing opinions may seem to fall under a different

author: John Stuart Mill
text: principle, since it belongs to that part of the conduct of an individual

author: John Stuart Mill
text: which concerns other people; but, being almost of as much importance as

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the liberty of thought itself, and resting in great part on the same

author: John Stuart Mill
text: reasons, is practically inseparable from it. Secondly, the principle

author: John Stuart Mill
text: requires liberty of tastes and pursuits; of framing the plan of our life

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to suit our own character; of doing as we like, subject to such

author: John Stuart Mill
text: consequences as may follow: without impediment from our

author: John Stuart Mill
text: fellow-creatures, so long as what we do does not harm them, even though

author: John Stuart Mill
text: they should think our conduct foolish, perverse, or wrong. Thirdly, from

author: John Stuart Mill
text: this liberty of each individual, follows the liberty, within the same

author: John Stuart Mill
text: limits, of combination among individuals; freedom to unite, for any

author: John Stuart Mill
text: purpose not involving harm to others: the persons combining being

author: John Stuart Mill
text: supposed to be of full age, and not forced or deceived.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: No society in which these liberties are not, on the whole, respected, is

author: John Stuart Mill
text: free, whatever may be its form of government; and none is completely

author: John Stuart Mill
text: free in which they do not exist absolute and unqualified. The only

author: John Stuart Mill
text: freedom which deserves the name, is that of pursuing our own good in our

author: John Stuart Mill
text: own way, so long as we do not attempt to deprive others of theirs, or

author: John Stuart Mill
text: impede their efforts to obtain it. Each is the proper guardian of his

author: John Stuart Mill
text: own health, whether bodily, or mental and spiritual. Mankind are greater

author: John Stuart Mill
text: gainers by suffering each other to live as seems good to themselves,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: than by compelling each to live as seems good to the rest.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Though this doctrine is anything but new, and, to some persons, may have

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the air of a truism, there is no doctrine which stands more directly

author: John Stuart Mill
text: opposed to the general tendency of existing opinion and practice.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Society has expended fully as much effort in the attempt (according to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: its lights) to compel people to conform to its notions of personal, as

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of social excellence. The ancient commonwealths thought themselves

author: John Stuart Mill
text: entitled to practise, and the ancient philosophers countenanced, the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: regulation of every part of private conduct by public authority, on the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: ground that the State had a deep interest in the whole bodily and mental

author: John Stuart Mill
text: discipline of every one of its citizens; a mode of thinking which may

author: John Stuart Mill
text: have been admissible in small republics surrounded by powerful enemies,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: in constant peril of being subverted by foreign attack or internal

author: John Stuart Mill
text: commotion, and to which even a short interval of relaxed energy and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: self-command might so easily be fatal, that they could not afford to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: wait for the salutary permanent effects of freedom. In the modern world,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the greater size of political communities, and above all, the separation

author: John Stuart Mill
text: between spiritual and temporal authority (which placed the direction of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: men's consciences in other hands than those which controlled their

author: John Stuart Mill
text: worldly affairs), prevented so great an interference by law in the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: details of private life; but the engines of moral repression have been

author: John Stuart Mill
text: wielded more strenuously against divergence from the reigning opinion in

author: John Stuart Mill
text: self-regarding, than even in social matters; religion, the most powerful

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of the elements which have entered into the formation of moral feeling,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: having almost always been governed either by the ambition of a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: hierarchy, seeking control over every department of human conduct, or by

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the spirit of Puritanism. And some of those modern reformers who have

author: John Stuart Mill
text: placed themselves in strongest opposition to the religions of the past,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: have been noway behind either churches or sects in their assertion of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the right of spiritual domination: M. Comte, in particular, whose social

author: John Stuart Mill
text: system, as unfolded in his _Traite de Politique Positive_, aims at

author: John Stuart Mill
text: establishing (though by moral more than by legal appliances) a despotism

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of society over the individual, surpassing anything contemplated in the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: political ideal of the most rigid disciplinarian among the ancient

author: John Stuart Mill
text: philosophers.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Apart from the peculiar tenets of individual thinkers, there is also in

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the world at large an increasing inclination to stretch unduly the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: powers of society over the individual, both by the force of opinion and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: even by that of legislation: and as the tendency of all the changes

author: John Stuart Mill
text: taking place in the world is to strengthen society, and diminish the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: power of the individual, this encroachment is not one of the evils which

author: John Stuart Mill
text: tend spontaneously to disappear, but, on the contrary, to grow more and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: more formidable. The disposition of mankind, whether as rulers or as

author: John Stuart Mill
text: fellow-citizens to impose their own opinions and inclinations as a rule

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of conduct on others, is so energetically supported by some of the best

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and by some of the worst feelings incident to human nature, that it is

author: John Stuart Mill
text: hardly ever kept under restraint by anything but want of power; and as

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the power is not declining, but growing, unless a strong barrier of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: moral conviction can be raised against the mischief, we must expect, in

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the present circumstances of the world, to see it increase.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: It will be convenient for the argument, if, instead of at once entering

author: John Stuart Mill
text: upon the general thesis, we confine ourselves in the first instance to a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: single branch of it, on which the principle here stated is, if not

author: John Stuart Mill
text: fully, yet to a certain point, recognised by the current opinions. This

author: John Stuart Mill
text: one branch is the Liberty of Thought: from which it is impossible to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: separate the cognate liberty of speaking and of writing. Although these

author: John Stuart Mill
text: liberties, to some considerable amount, form part of the political

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: institutions, the grounds, both philosophical and practical, on which

author: John Stuart Mill
text: they rest, are perhaps not so familiar to the general mind, nor so

author: John Stuart Mill
text: thoroughly appreciated by many even of the leaders of opinion, as might

author: John Stuart Mill
text: have been expected. Those grounds, when rightly understood, are of much

author: John Stuart Mill
text: wider application than to only one division of the subject, and a

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: about to say will be new, may therefore, I hope, excuse me, if on a

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: CHAPTER II.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: OF THE LIBERTY OF THOUGHT AND DISCUSSION.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: The time, it is to be hoped, is gone by, when any defence would be

author: John Stuart Mill
text: necessary of the "liberty of the press" as one of the securities against

author: John Stuart Mill
text: corrupt or tyrannical government. No argument, we may suppose, can now

author: John Stuart Mill
text: be needed, against permitting a legislature or an executive, not

author: John Stuart Mill
text: identified in interest with the people, to prescribe opinions to them,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and determine what doctrines or what arguments they shall be allowed to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: hear. This aspect of the question, besides, has been so often and so

author: John Stuart Mill
text: triumphantly enforced by preceding writers, that it need not be

author: John Stuart Mill
text: specially insisted on in this place. Though the law of England, on the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: subject of the press, is as servile to this day as it was in the time of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the Tudors, there is little danger of its being actually put in force

author: John Stuart Mill
text: against political discussion, except during some temporary panic, when

author: John Stuart Mill
text: fear of insurrection drives ministers and judges from their

author: John Stuart Mill
text: propriety;[6] and, speaking generally, it is not, in constitutional

author: John Stuart Mill
text: countries, to be apprehended that the government, whether completely

author: John Stuart Mill
text: responsible to the people or not, will often attempt to control the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: expression of opinion, except when in doing so it makes itself the organ

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of the general intolerance of the public. Let us suppose, therefore,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: that the government is entirely at one with the people, and never thinks

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of exerting any power of coercion unless in agreement with what it

author: John Stuart Mill
text: conceives to be their voice. But I deny the right of the people to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: exercise such coercion, either by themselves or by their government. The

author: John Stuart Mill
text: power itself is illegitimate. The best government has no more title to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: it than the worst. It is as noxious, or more noxious, when exerted in

author: John Stuart Mill
text: accordance with public opinion, than when in or opposition to it. If all

author: John Stuart Mill
text: mankind minus one, were of one opinion, and only one person were of the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: contrary opinion, mankind would be no more justified in silencing that

author: John Stuart Mill
text: one person, than he, if he had the power, would be justified in

author: John Stuart Mill
text: silencing mankind. Were an opinion a personal possession of no value

author: John Stuart Mill
text: except to the owner; if to be obstructed in the enjoyment of it were

author: John Stuart Mill
text: simply a private injury, it would make some difference whether the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: injury was inflicted only on a few persons or on many. But the peculiar

author: John Stuart Mill
text: evil of silencing the expression of an opinion is, that it is robbing

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the human race; posterity as well as the existing generation; those who

author: John Stuart Mill
text: dissent from the opinion, still more than those who hold it. If the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: opinion is right, they are deprived of the opportunity of exchanging

author: John Stuart Mill
text: error for truth: if wrong, they lose, what is almost as great a benefit,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the clearer perception and livelier impression of truth, produced by its

author: John Stuart Mill
text: collision with error.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: It is necessary to consider separately these two hypotheses, each of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: which has a distinct branch of the argument corresponding to it. We can

author: John Stuart Mill
text: never be sure that the opinion we are endeavouring to stifle is a false

author: John Stuart Mill
text: opinion; and if we were sure, stifling it would be an evil still.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: First: the opinion which it is attempted to suppress by authority may

author: John Stuart Mill
text: possibly be true. Those who desire to suppress it, of course deny its

author: John Stuart Mill
text: truth; but they are not infallible. They have no authority to decide the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: question for all mankind, and exclude every other person from the means

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of judging. To refuse a hearing to an opinion, because they are sure

author: John Stuart Mill
text: that it is false, is to assume that _their_ certainty is the same thing

author: John Stuart Mill
text: as _absolute_ certainty. All silencing of discussion is an assumption

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of infallibility. Its condemnation may be allowed to rest on this common

author: John Stuart Mill
text: argument, not the worse for being common.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Unfortunately for the good sense of mankind, the fact of their

author: John Stuart Mill
text: fallibility is far from carrying the weight in their practical judgment,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: which is always allowed to it in theory; for while every one well knows

author: John Stuart Mill
text: himself to be fallible, few think it necessary to take any precautions

author: John Stuart Mill
text: against their own fallibility, or admit the supposition that any

author: John Stuart Mill
text: opinion, of which they feel very certain, may be one of the examples of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the error to which they acknowledge themselves to be liable. Absolute

author: John Stuart Mill
text: princes, or others who are accustomed to unlimited deference, usually

author: John Stuart Mill
text: feel this complete confidence in their own opinions on nearly all

author: John Stuart Mill
text: subjects. People more happily situated, who sometimes hear their

author: John Stuart Mill
text: opinions disputed, and are not wholly unused to be set right when they

author: John Stuart Mill
text: are wrong, place the same unbounded reliance only on such of their

author: John Stuart Mill
text: opinions as are shared by all who surround them, or to whom they

author: John Stuart Mill
text: habitually defer: for in proportion to a man's want of confidence in his

author: John Stuart Mill
text: own solitary judgment, does he usually repose, with implicit trust, on

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the infallibility of "the world" in general. And the world, to each

author: John Stuart Mill
text: individual, means the part of it with which he comes in contact; his

author: John Stuart Mill
text: party, his sect, his church, his class of society: the man may be

author: John Stuart Mill
text: called, by comparison, almost liberal and large-minded to whom it means

author: John Stuart Mill
text: anything so comprehensive as his own country or his own age. Nor is his

author: John Stuart Mill
text: faith in this collective authority at all shaken by his being aware that

author: John Stuart Mill
text: other ages, countries, sects, churches, classes, and parties have

author: John Stuart Mill
text: thought, and even now think, the exact reverse. He devolves upon his own

author: John Stuart Mill
text: world the responsibility of being in the right against the dissentient

author: John Stuart Mill
text: worlds of other people; and it never troubles him that mere accident has

author: John Stuart Mill
text: decided which of these numerous worlds is the object of his reliance,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and that the same causes which make him a Churchman in London, would

author: John Stuart Mill
text: have made him a Buddhist or a Confucian in Pekin. Yet it is as evident

author: John Stuart Mill
text: in itself as any amount of argument can make it, that ages are no more

author: John Stuart Mill
text: infallible than individuals; every age having held many opinions which

author: John Stuart Mill
text: subsequent ages have deemed not only false but absurd; and it is as

author: John Stuart Mill
text: certain that many opinions, now general, will be rejected by future

author: John Stuart Mill
text: ages, as it is that many, once general, are rejected by the present.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: The objection likely to be made to this argument, would probably take

author: John Stuart Mill
text: some such form as the following. There is no greater assumption of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: infallibility in forbidding the propagation of error, than in any other

author: John Stuart Mill
text: thing which is done by public authority on its own judgment and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: responsibility. Judgment is given to men that they may use it. Because

author: John Stuart Mill
text: it may be used erroneously, are men to be told that they ought not to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: use it at all? To prohibit what they think pernicious, is not claiming

author: John Stuart Mill
text: exemption from error, but fulfilling the duty incumbent on them,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: although fallible, of acting on their conscientious conviction. If we

author: John Stuart Mill
text: were never to act on our opinions, because those opinions may be wrong,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: we should leave all our interests uncared for, and all our duties

author: John Stuart Mill
text: unperformed. An objection which applies to all conduct, can be no valid

author: John Stuart Mill
text: objection to any conduct in particular. It is the duty of governments,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and of individuals, to form the truest opinions they can; to form them

author: John Stuart Mill
text: carefully, and never impose them upon others unless they are quite sure

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of being right. But when they are sure (such reasoners may say), it is

author: John Stuart Mill
text: not conscientiousness but cowardice to shrink from acting on their

author: John Stuart Mill
text: opinions, and allow doctrines which they honestly think dangerous to the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: welfare of mankind, either in this life or in another, to be scattered

author: John Stuart Mill
text: abroad without restraint, because other people, in less enlightened

author: John Stuart Mill
text: times, have persecuted opinions now believed to be true. Let us take

author: John Stuart Mill
text: care, it may be said, not to make the same mistake: but governments and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: nations have made mistakes in other things, which are not denied to be

author: John Stuart Mill
text: fit subjects for the exercise of authority: they have laid on bad taxes,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: made unjust wars. Ought we therefore to lay on no taxes, and, under

author: John Stuart Mill
text: whatever provocation, make no wars? Men, and governments, must act to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the best of their ability. There is no such thing as absolute certainty,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: but there is assurance sufficient for the purposes of human life. We

author: John Stuart Mill
text: may, and must, assume our opinion to be true for the guidance of our own

author: John Stuart Mill
text: conduct: and it is assuming no more when we forbid bad men to pervert

author: John Stuart Mill
text: society by the propagation of opinions which we regard as false and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: pernicious.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: I answer that it is assuming very much more. There is the greatest

author: John Stuart Mill
text: difference between presuming an opinion to be true, because, with every

author: John Stuart Mill
text: opportunity for contesting it, it has not been refuted, and assuming its

author: John Stuart Mill
text: truth for the purpose of not permitting its refutation. Complete liberty

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of contradicting and disproving our opinion, is the very condition which

author: John Stuart Mill
text: justifies us in assuming its truth for purposes of action; and on no

author: John Stuart Mill
text: other terms can a being with human faculties have any rational assurance

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of being right.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: When we consider either the history of opinion, or the ordinary conduct

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of human life, to what is it to be ascribed that the one and the other

author: John Stuart Mill
text: are no worse than they are? Not certainly to the inherent force of the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: human understanding; for, on any matter not self-evident, there are

author: John Stuart Mill
text: ninety-nine persons totally incapable of judging of it, for one who is

author: John Stuart Mill
text: capable; and the capacity of the hundredth person is only comparative;

author: John Stuart Mill
text: for the majority of the eminent men of every past generation held many

author: John Stuart Mill
text: opinions now known to be erroneous, and did or approved numerous things

author: John Stuart Mill
text: which no one will now justify. Why is it, then, that there is on the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: whole a preponderance among mankind of rational opinions and rational

author: John Stuart Mill
text: conduct? If there really is this preponderance--which there must be,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: unless human affairs are, and have always been, in an almost desperate

author: John Stuart Mill
text: state--it is owing to a quality of the human mind, the source of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: everything respectable in man either as an intellectual or as a moral

author: John Stuart Mill
text: being, namely, that his errors are corrigible. He is capable of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: rectifying his mistakes, by discussion and experience. Not by experience

author: John Stuart Mill
text: alone. There must be discussion, to show how experience is to be

author: John Stuart Mill
text: interpreted. Wrong opinions and practices gradually yield to fact and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: argument: but facts and arguments, to produce any effect on the mind,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: must be brought before it. Very few facts are able to tell their own

author: John Stuart Mill
text: story, without comments to bring out their meaning. The whole strength

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and value, then, of human judgment, depending on the one property, that

author: John Stuart Mill
text: it can be set right when it is wrong, reliance can be placed on it only

author: John Stuart Mill
text: when the means of setting it right are kept constantly at hand. In the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: case of any person whose judgment is really deserving of confidence, how

author: John Stuart Mill
text: has it become so? Because he has kept his mind open to criticism of his

author: John Stuart Mill
text: opinions and conduct. Because it has been his practice to listen to all

author: John Stuart Mill
text: that could be said against him; to profit by as much of it as was just,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and expound to himself, and upon occasion to others, the fallacy of what

author: John Stuart Mill
text: was fallacious. Because he has felt, that the only way in which a human

author: John Stuart Mill
text: being can make some approach to knowing the whole of a subject, is by

author: John Stuart Mill
text: hearing what can be said about it by persons of every variety of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: opinion, and studying all modes in which it can be looked at by every

author: John Stuart Mill
text: character of mind. No wise man ever acquired his wisdom in any mode but

author: John Stuart Mill
text: this; nor is it in the nature of human intellect to become wise in any

author: John Stuart Mill
text: other manner. The steady habit of correcting and completing his own

author: John Stuart Mill
text: opinion by collating it with those of others, so far from causing doubt

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and hesitation in carrying it into practice, is the only stable

author: John Stuart Mill
text: foundation for a just reliance on it: for, being cognisant of all that

author: John Stuart Mill
text: can, at least obviously, be said against him, and having taken up his

author: John Stuart Mill
text: position against all gainsayers--knowing that he has sought for

author: John Stuart Mill
text: objections and difficulties, instead of avoiding them, and has shut out

author: John Stuart Mill
text: no light which can be thrown upon the subject from any quarter--he has a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: right to think his judgment better than that of any person, or any

author: John Stuart Mill
text: multitude, who have not gone through a similar process.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: It is not too much to require that what the wisest of mankind, those who

author: John Stuart Mill
text: are best entitled to trust their own judgment, find necessary to warrant

author: John Stuart Mill
text: their relying on it, should be submitted to by that miscellaneous

author: John Stuart Mill
text: collection of a few wise and many foolish individuals, called the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: public. The most intolerant of churches, the Roman Catholic Church, even

author: John Stuart Mill
text: at the canonisation of a saint, admits, and listens patiently to, a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: "devil's advocate." The holiest of men, it appears, cannot be admitted

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to posthumous honours, until all that the devil could say against him is

author: John Stuart Mill
text: known and weighed. If even the Newtonian philosophy were not permitted

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to be questioned, mankind could not feel as complete assurance of its

author: John Stuart Mill
text: truth as they now do. The beliefs which we have most warrant for, have

author: John Stuart Mill
text: no safeguard to rest on, but a standing invitation to the whole world to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: prove them unfounded. If the challenge is not accepted, or is accepted

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and the attempt fails, we are far enough from certainty still; but we

author: John Stuart Mill
text: have done the best that the existing state of human reason admits of; we

author: John Stuart Mill
text: have neglected nothing that could give the truth a chance of reaching

author: John Stuart Mill
text: us: if the lists are kept open, we may hope that if there be a better

author: John Stuart Mill
text: truth, it will be found when the human mind is capable of receiving it;

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and in the meantime we may rely on having attained such approach to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: truth, as is possible in our own day. This is the amount of certainty

author: John Stuart Mill
text: attainable by a fallible being, and this the sole way of attaining it.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Strange it is, that men should admit the validity of the arguments for

author: John Stuart Mill
text: free discussion, but object to their being "pushed to an extreme;" not

author: John Stuart Mill
text: seeing that unless the reasons are good for an extreme case, they are

author: John Stuart Mill
text: not good for any case. Strange that they should imagine that they are

author: John Stuart Mill
text: not assuming infallibility, when they acknowledge that there should be

author: John Stuart Mill
text: free discussion on all subjects which can possibly be _doubtful_, but

author: John Stuart Mill
text: think that some particular principle or doctrine should be forbidden to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: be questioned because it is _so certain_, that is, because _they are

author: John Stuart Mill
text: certain_ that it is certain. To call any proposition certain, while

author: John Stuart Mill
text: there is any one who would deny its certainty if permitted, but who is

author: John Stuart Mill
text: not permitted, is to assume that we ourselves, and those who agree with

author: John Stuart Mill
text: us, are the judges of certainty, and judges without hearing the other

author: John Stuart Mill
text: side.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: In the present age--which has been described as "destitute of faith, but

author: John Stuart Mill
text: terrified at scepticism"--in which people feel sure, not so much that

author: John Stuart Mill
text: their opinions are true, as that they should not know what to do without

author: John Stuart Mill
text: them--the claims of an opinion to be protected from public attack are

author: John Stuart Mill
text: rested not so much on its truth, as on its importance to society. There

author: John Stuart Mill
text: are, it is alleged, certain beliefs, so useful, not to say indispensable

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to well-being, that it is as much the duty of governments to uphold

author: John Stuart Mill
text: those beliefs, as to protect any other of the interests of society. In a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: case of such necessity, and so directly in the line of their duty,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: something less than infallibility may, it is maintained, warrant, and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: even bind, governments, to act on their own opinion, confirmed by the

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: thought, that none but bad men would desire to weaken these salutary

author: John Stuart Mill
text: beliefs; and there can be nothing wrong, it is thought, in restraining

author: John Stuart Mill
text: bad men, and prohibiting what only such men would wish to practise.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: This mode of thinking makes the justification of restraints on

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: responsibility of claiming to be an infallible judge of opinions. But

author: John Stuart Mill
text: those who thus satisfy themselves, do not perceive that the assumption

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: usefulness of an opinion is itself matter of opinion: as disputable, as

author: John Stuart Mill
text: open to discussion, and requiring discussion as much, as the opinion

author: John Stuart Mill
text: itself. There is the same need of an infallible judge of opinions to

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the most active and inquiring intellects find it advisable to keep the

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: The sort of men who can be looked for under it, are either mere

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: all great subjects are meant for their hearers, and are not those which

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Those in whose eyes this reticence on the part of heretics is no evil,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: should consider in the first place, that in consequence of it there is

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: prevented from spreading, do not disappear. But it is not the minds of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: heretics that are deteriorated most, by the ban placed on all inquiry

author: John Stuart Mill
text: which does not end in the orthodox conclusions. The greatest harm done

author: John Stuart Mill
text: is to those who are not heretics, and whose whole mental development is

author: John Stuart Mill
text: cramped, and their reason cowed, by the fear of heresy. Who can compute

author: John Stuart Mill
text: what the world loses in the multitude of promising intellects combined

author: John Stuart Mill
text: with timid characters, who dare not follow out any bold, vigorous,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: independent train of thought, lest it should land them in something

text: which would admit of being considered irreligious or immoral? Among

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: with an intellect which he cannot silence, and exhausts the resources of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: ingenuity in attempting to reconcile the promptings of his conscience

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and reason with orthodoxy, which yet he does not, perhaps, to the end

author: John Stuart Mill
text: succeed in doing. No one can be a great thinker who does not recognise,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: that as a thinker it is his first duty to follow his intellect to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: whatever conclusions it may lead. Truth gains more even by the errors of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: one who, with due study and preparation, thinks for himself, than by the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: true opinions of those who only hold them because they do not suffer

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: thinkers, that freedom of thinking is required. On the contrary, it is

author: John Stuart Mill
text: as much, and even more indispensable, to enable average human beings to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: attain the mental stature which they are capable of. There have been,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and may again be, great individual thinkers, in a general atmosphere of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: mental slavery. But there never has been, nor ever will be, in that

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: temporary approach to such a character, it has been because the dread

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of heterodox speculation was for a time suspended. Where there is a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: tacit convention that principles are not to be disputed; where the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: discussion of the greatest questions which can occupy humanity is

author: John Stuart Mill
text: considered to be closed, we cannot hope to find that generally high

author: John Stuart Mill
text: scale of mental activity which has made some periods of history so

author: John Stuart Mill
text: remarkable. Never when controversy avoided the subjects which are large

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and important enough to kindle enthusiasm, was the mind of a people

author: John Stuart Mill
text: stirred up from its foundations, and the impulse given which raised even

author: John Stuart Mill
