author: John Stuart Mill
text: thinking beings. Of such we have had an example in the condition of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Europe during the times immediately following the Reformation; another,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: though limited to the Continent and to a more cultivated class, in the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: speculative movement of the latter half of the eighteenth century; and a

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Germany during the Goethian and Fichtean period. These periods differed

author: John Stuart Mill
text: widely in the particular opinions which they developed; but were alike

author: John Stuart Mill
text: in this, that during all three the yoke of authority was broken. In

author: John Stuart Mill
text: each, an old mental despotism had been thrown off, and no new one had

author: John Stuart Mill
text: yet taken its place. The impulse given at these three periods has made

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Let us now pass to the second division of the argument, and dismissing

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the supposition that any of the received opinions may be false, let us

author: John Stuart Mill
text: assume them to be true, and examine into the worth of the manner in

author: John Stuart Mill
text: which they are likely to be held, when their truth is not freely and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: openly canvassed. However unwillingly a person who has a strong opinion

author: John Stuart Mill
text: may admit the possibility that his opinion may be false, he ought to be

author: John Stuart Mill
text: moved by the consideration that however true it may be, if it is not

author: John Stuart Mill
text: fully, frequently, and fearlessly discussed, it will be held as a dead

author: John Stuart Mill
text: dogma, not a living truth.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: There is a class of persons (happily not quite so numerous as formerly)

author: John Stuart Mill
text: who think it enough if a person assents undoubtingly to what they think

author: John Stuart Mill
text: true, though he has no knowledge whatever of the grounds of the opinion,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and could not make a tenable defence of it against the most superficial

author: John Stuart Mill
text: objections. Such persons, if they can once get their creed taught from

author: John Stuart Mill
text: authority, naturally think that no good, and some harm, comes of its

author: John Stuart Mill
text: being allowed to be questioned. Where their influence prevails, they

author: John Stuart Mill
text: make it nearly impossible for the received opinion to be rejected wisely

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and considerately, though it may still be rejected rashly and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: ignorantly; for to shut out discussion entirely is seldom possible, and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: when it once gets in, beliefs not grounded on conviction are apt to give

author: John Stuart Mill
text: way before the slightest semblance of an argument. Waiving, however,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: this possibility--assuming that the true opinion abides in the mind, but

author: John Stuart Mill
text: abides as a prejudice, a belief independent of, and proof against,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: argument--this is not the way in which truth ought to be held by a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: rational being. This is not knowing the truth. Truth, thus held, is but

author: John Stuart Mill
text: one superstition the more, accidentally clinging to the words which

author: John Stuart Mill
text: enunciate a truth.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: If the intellect and judgment of mankind ought to be cultivated, a thing

author: John Stuart Mill
text: which Protestants at least do not deny, on what can these faculties be

author: John Stuart Mill
text: more appropriately exercised by any one, than on the things which

author: John Stuart Mill
text: concern him so much that it is considered necessary for him to hold

author: John Stuart Mill
text: opinions on them? If the cultivation of the understanding consists in

author: John Stuart Mill
text: one thing more than in another, it is surely in learning the grounds of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: one's own opinions. Whatever people believe, on subjects on which it is

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of the first importance to believe rightly, they ought to be able to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: defend against at least the common objections. But, some one may say,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: "Let them be _taught_ the grounds of their opinions. It does not follow

author: John Stuart Mill
text: that opinions must be merely parroted because they are never heard

author: John Stuart Mill
text: controverted. Persons who learn geometry do not simply commit the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: theorems to memory, but understand and learn likewise the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: demonstrations; and it would be absurd to say that they remain ignorant

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of the grounds of geometrical truths, because they never hear any one

author: John Stuart Mill
text: deny, and attempt to disprove them." Undoubtedly: and such teaching

author: John Stuart Mill
text: suffices on a subject like mathematics, where there is nothing at all to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: be said on the wrong side of the question. The peculiarity of the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: evidence of mathematical truths is, that all the argument is on one

author: John Stuart Mill
text: side. There are no objections, and no answers to objections. But on

author: John Stuart Mill
text: every subject on which difference of opinion is possible, the truth

author: John Stuart Mill
text: depends on a balance to be struck between two sets of conflicting

author: John Stuart Mill
text: reasons. Even in natural philosophy, there is always some other

author: John Stuart Mill
text: explanation possible of the same facts; some geocentric theory instead

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of heliocentric, some phlogiston instead of oxygen; and it has to be

author: John Stuart Mill
text: shown why that other theory cannot be the true one: and until this is

author: John Stuart Mill
text: shown, and until we know how it is shown, we do not understand the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: grounds of our opinion. But when we turn to subjects infinitely more

author: John Stuart Mill
text: complicated, to morals, religion, politics, social relations, and the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: business of life, three-fourths of the arguments for every disputed

author: John Stuart Mill
text: opinion consist in dispelling the appearances which favour some opinion

author: John Stuart Mill
text: different from it. The greatest orator, save one, of antiquity, has left

author: John Stuart Mill
text: it on record that he always studied his adversary's case with as great,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: if not with still greater, intensity than even his own. What Cicero

author: John Stuart Mill
text: practised as the means of forensic success, requires to be imitated by

author: John Stuart Mill
text: all who study any subject in order to arrive at the truth. He who knows

author: John Stuart Mill
text: only his own side of the case, knows little of that. His reasons may be

author: John Stuart Mill
text: good, and no one may have been able to refute them. But if he is equally

author: John Stuart Mill
text: unable to refute the reasons on the opposite side; if he does not so

author: John Stuart Mill
text: much as know what they are, he has no ground for preferring either

author: John Stuart Mill
text: opinion. The rational position for him would be suspension of judgment,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and unless he contents himself with that, he is either led by

author: John Stuart Mill
text: authority, or adopts, like the generality of the world, the side to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: which he feels most inclination. Nor is it enough that he should hear

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the arguments of adversaries from his own teachers, presented as they

author: John Stuart Mill
text: state them, and accompanied by what they offer as refutations. That is

author: John Stuart Mill
text: not the way to do justice to the arguments, or bring them into real

author: John Stuart Mill
text: contact with his own mind. He must be able to hear them from persons who

author: John Stuart Mill
text: actually believe them; who defend them in earnest, and do their very

author: John Stuart Mill
text: utmost for them. He must know them in their most plausible and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: persuasive form; he must feel the whole force of the difficulty which

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the true view of the subject has to encounter and dispose of; else he

author: John Stuart Mill
text: will never really possess himself of the portion of truth which meets

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and removes that difficulty. Ninety-nine in a hundred of what are called

author: John Stuart Mill
text: educated men are in this condition; even of those who can argue fluently

author: John Stuart Mill
text: for their opinions. Their conclusion may be true, but it might be false

author: John Stuart Mill
text: for anything they know: they have never thrown themselves into the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: mental position of those who think differently from them, and considered

author: John Stuart Mill
text: what such persons may have to say; and consequently they do not, in any

author: John Stuart Mill
text: proper sense of the word, know the doctrine which they themselves

author: John Stuart Mill
text: profess. They do not know those parts of it which explain and justify

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the remainder; the considerations which show that a fact which seemingly

author: John Stuart Mill
text: conflicts with another is reconcilable with it, or that, of two

author: John Stuart Mill
text: apparently strong reasons, one and not the other ought to be preferred.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: All that part of the truth which turns the scale, and decides the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: judgment of a completely informed mind, they are strangers to; nor is it

author: John Stuart Mill
text: ever really known, but to those who have attended equally and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: impartially to both sides, and endeavoured to see the reasons of both in

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the strongest light. So essential is this discipline to a real

author: John Stuart Mill
text: understanding of moral and human subjects, that if opponents of all

author: John Stuart Mill
text: important truths do not exist, it is indispensable to imagine them, and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: supply them with the strongest arguments which the most skilful devil's

author: John Stuart Mill
text: advocate can conjure up.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: To abate the force of these considerations, an enemy of free discussion

author: John Stuart Mill
text: may be supposed to say, that there is no necessity for mankind in

author: John Stuart Mill
text: general to know and understand all that can be said against or for their

author: John Stuart Mill
text: opinions by philosophers and theologians. That it is not needful for

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: capable of answering them, so that nothing likely to mislead

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to authority for the rest, and being aware that they have neither

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: may repose in the assurance that all those which have been raised have

author: John Stuart Mill
text: been or can be answered, by those who are specially trained to the task.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Conceding to this view of the subject the utmost that can be claimed for

author: John Stuart Mill
text: it by those most easily satisfied with the amount of understanding of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: truth which ought to accompany the belief of it; even so, the argument

author: John Stuart Mill
text: for free discussion is no way weakened. For even this doctrine

author: John Stuart Mill
text: acknowledges that mankind ought to have a rational assurance that all

author: John Stuart Mill
text: objections have been satisfactorily answered; and how are they to be

author: John Stuart Mill
text: answered if that which requires to be answered is not spoken? or how can

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the answer be known to be satisfactory, if the objectors have no

author: John Stuart Mill
text: opportunity of showing that it is unsatisfactory? If not the public, at

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: difficulties, must make themselves familiar with those difficulties in

author: John Stuart Mill
text: their most puzzling form; and this cannot be accomplished unless they

author: John Stuart Mill
text: are freely stated, and placed in the most advantageous light which they

author: John Stuart Mill
text: admit of. The Catholic Church has its own way of dealing with this

author: John Stuart Mill
text: embarrassing problem. It makes a broad separation between those who can

author: John Stuart Mill
text: be permitted to receive its doctrines on conviction, and those who must

author: John Stuart Mill
text: accept them on trust. Neither, indeed, are allowed any choice as to what

author: John Stuart Mill
text: they will accept; but the clergy, such at least as can be fully confided

author: John Stuart Mill
text: in, may admissibly and meritoriously make themselves acquainted with the

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: read heretical books; the laity, not unless by special permission, hard

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to be obtained. This discipline recognises a knowledge of the enemy's

author: John Stuart Mill
text: case as beneficial to the teachers, but finds means, consistent with

author: John Stuart Mill
text: this, of denying it to the rest of the world: thus giving to the _elite_

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: superiority which its purposes require; for though culture without

author: John Stuart Mill
text: freedom never made a large and liberal mind, it can make a clever _nisi

author: John Stuart Mill
text: prius_ advocate of a cause. But in countries professing Protestantism,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: this resource is denied; since Protestants hold, at least in theory,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: that the responsibility for the choice of a religion must be borne by

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: writings which are read by the instructed can be kept from the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: uninstructed. If the teachers of mankind are to be cognisant of all that

author: John Stuart Mill
text: they ought to know, everything must be free to be written and published

author: John Stuart Mill
text: without restraint.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: If, however, the mischievous operation of the absence of free

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: any part, the shell and husk only of the meaning is retained, the finer

author: John Stuart Mill
text: essence being lost. The great chapter in human history which this fact

author: John Stuart Mill
text: occupies and fills, cannot be too earnestly studied and meditated on.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: It is illustrated in the experience of almost all ethical doctrines and

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: ceases to spread further. When either of these results has become

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: To what an extent doctrines intrinsically fitted to make the deepest

text: recorded deliverances of the Founder of Christianity, and which have

author: John Stuart Mill
text: been entirely thrown aside in the system of ethics erected on the basis

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of those deliverances by the Christian Church. And this being so, I

author: John Stuart Mill
text: think it a great error to persist in attempting to find in the Christian

author: John Stuart Mill
text: doctrine that complete rule for our guidance, which its author intended

author: John Stuart Mill
text: it to sanction and enforce, but only partially to provide. I believe,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: too, that this narrow theory is becoming a grave practical evil,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: detracting greatly from the value of the moral training and instruction,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: which so many well-meaning persons are now at length exerting themselves

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to promote. I much fear that by attempting to form the mind and feelings

author: John Stuart Mill
text: on an exclusively religious type, and discarding those secular

author: John Stuart Mill
text: standards (as for want of a better name they may be called) which

author: John Stuart Mill
text: heretofore co-existed with and supplemented the Christian ethics,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: receiving some of its spirit, and infusing into it some of theirs, there

author: John Stuart Mill
text: will result, and is even now resulting, a low, abject, servile type of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: character, which, submit itself as it may to what it deems the Supreme

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Will, is incapable of rising to or sympathising in the conception of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Supreme Goodness. I believe that other ethics than any which can be

author: John Stuart Mill
text: evolved from exclusively Christian sources, must exist side by side with

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Christian ethics to produce the moral regeneration of mankind; and that

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the Christian system is no exception to the rule, that in an imperfect

author: John Stuart Mill
text: state of the human mind, the interests of truth require a diversity of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: opinions. It is not necessary that in ceasing to ignore the moral truths

author: John Stuart Mill
text: not contained in Christianity, men should ignore any of those which it

author: John Stuart Mill
text: does contain. Such prejudice, or oversight, when it occurs, is

author: John Stuart Mill
text: altogether an evil; but it is one from which we cannot hope to be always

author: John Stuart Mill
text: exempt, and must be regarded as the price paid for an inestimable good.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: The exclusive pretension made by a part of the truth to be the whole,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: must and ought to be protested against, and if a reactionary impulse

author: John Stuart Mill
text: should make the protestors unjust in their turn, this one-sidedness,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: like the other, may be lamented, but must be tolerated. If Christians

author: John Stuart Mill
text: would teach infidels to be just to Christianity, they should themselves

author: John Stuart Mill
text: be just to infidelity. It can do truth no service to blink the fact,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: known to all who have the most ordinary acquaintance with literary

author: John Stuart Mill
text: history, that a large portion of the noblest and most valuable moral

author: John Stuart Mill
text: teaching has been the work, not only of men who did not know, but of men

author: John Stuart Mill
text: who knew and rejected, the Christian faith.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: I do not pretend that the most unlimited use of the freedom of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: enunciating all possible opinions would put an end to the evils of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: religious or philosophical sectarianism. Every truth which men of narrow

author: John Stuart Mill
text: capacity are in earnest about, is sure to be asserted, inculcated, and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: in many ways even acted on, as if no other truth existed in the world,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: or at all events none that could limit or qualify the first. I

author: John Stuart Mill
text: acknowledge that the tendency of all opinions to become sectarian is not

author: John Stuart Mill
text: cured by the freest discussion, but is often heightened and exacerbated

author: John Stuart Mill
text: thereby; the truth which ought to have been, but was not, seen, being

author: John Stuart Mill
text: rejected all the more violently because proclaimed by persons regarded

author: John Stuart Mill
text: as opponents. But it is not on the impassioned partisan, it is on the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: calmer and more disinterested bystander, that this collision of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: opinions works its salutary effect. Not the violent conflict between

author: John Stuart Mill
text: parts of the truth, but the quiet suppression of half of it, is the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: formidable evil: there is always hope when people are forced to listen

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to both sides; it is when they attend only to one that errors harden

author: John Stuart Mill
text: into prejudices, and truth itself ceases to have the effect of truth, by

author: John Stuart Mill
text: being exaggerated into falsehood. And since there are few mental

author: John Stuart Mill
text: attributes more rare than that judicial faculty which can sit in

author: John Stuart Mill
text: intelligent judgment between two sides of a question, of which only one

author: John Stuart Mill
text: is represented by an advocate before it, truth has no chance but in

author: John Stuart Mill
text: proportion as every side of it, every opinion which embodies any

author: John Stuart Mill
text: fraction of the truth, not only finds advocates, but is so advocated as

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to be listened to.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: We have now recognised the necessity to the mental well-being of mankind

author: John Stuart Mill
text: (on which all their other well-being depends) of freedom of opinion, and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: freedom of the expression of opinion, on four distinct grounds; which we

author: John Stuart Mill
text: will now briefly recapitulate.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: First, if any opinion is compelled to silence, that opinion may, for

author: John Stuart Mill
text: aught we can certainly know, be true. To deny this is to assume our own

author: John Stuart Mill
text: infallibility.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Secondly, though the silenced opinion be an error, it may, and very

author: John Stuart Mill
text: commonly does, contain a portion of truth; and since the general or

author: John Stuart Mill
text: prevailing opinion on any subject is rarely or never the whole truth, it

author: John Stuart Mill
text: is only by the collision of adverse opinions, that the remainder of the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: truth has any chance of being supplied.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Thirdly, even if the received opinion be not only true, but the whole

author: John Stuart Mill
text: truth; unless it is suffered to be, and actually is, vigorously and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: earnestly contested, it will, by most of those who receive it, be held

author: John Stuart Mill
text: in the manner of a prejudice, with little comprehension or feeling of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: its rational grounds. And not only this, but, fourthly, the meaning of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the doctrine itself will be in danger of being lost, or enfeebled, and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: deprived of its vital effect on the character and conduct: the dogma

author: John Stuart Mill
text: becoming a mere formal profession, inefficacious for good, but cumbering

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the ground, and preventing the growth of any real and heartfelt

author: John Stuart Mill
text: conviction, from reason or personal experience.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Before quitting the subject of freedom of opinion, it is fit to take

author: John Stuart Mill
text: some notice of those who say, that the free expression of all opinions

author: John Stuart Mill
text: should be permitted, on condition that the manner be temperate, and do

author: John Stuart Mill
text: not pass the bounds of fair discussion. Much might be said on the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: impossibility of fixing where these supposed bounds are to be placed;

author: John Stuart Mill
text: for if the test be offence to those whose opinion is attacked, I think

author: John Stuart Mill
text: experience testifies that this offence is given whenever the attack is

author: John Stuart Mill
text: telling and powerful, and that every opponent who pushes them hard, and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: whom they find it difficult to answer, appears to them, if he shows any

author: John Stuart Mill
text: strong feeling on the subject, an intemperate opponent. But this, though

author: John Stuart Mill
text: an important consideration in a practical point of view, merges in a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: more fundamental objection. Undoubtedly the manner of asserting an

author: John Stuart Mill
text: opinion, even though it be a true one, may be very objectionable, and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: may justly incur severe censure. But the principal offences of the kind

author: John Stuart Mill
text: are such as it is mostly impossible, unless by accidental self-betrayal,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to bring home to conviction. The gravest of them is, to argue

author: John Stuart Mill
text: sophistically, to suppress facts or arguments, to misstate the elements

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of the case, or misrepresent the opposite opinion. But all this, even to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the most aggravated degree, is so continually done in perfect good

author: John Stuart Mill
text: faith, by persons who are not considered, and in many other respects may

author: John Stuart Mill
text: not deserve to be considered, ignorant or incompetent, that it is rarely

author: John Stuart Mill
text: possible on adequate grounds conscientiously to stamp the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: misrepresentation as morally culpable; and still less could law presume

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to interfere with this kind of controversial misconduct. With regard to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: what is commonly meant by intemperate discussion, namely invective,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: sarcasm, personality, and the like, the denunciation of these weapons

author: John Stuart Mill
text: would deserve more sympathy if it were ever proposed to interdict them

author: John Stuart Mill
text: equally to both sides; but it is only desired to restrain the employment

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of them against the prevailing opinion: against the unprevailing they

author: John Stuart Mill
text: may not only be used without general disapproval, but will be likely to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: obtain for him who uses them the praise of honest zeal and righteous

author: John Stuart Mill
text: indignation. Yet whatever mischief arises from their use, is greatest

author: John Stuart Mill
text: when they are employed against the comparatively defenceless; and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: whatever unfair advantage can be derived by any opinion from this mode

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of asserting it, accrues almost exclusively to received opinions. The

author: John Stuart Mill
text: worst offence of this kind which can be committed by a polemic, is to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: stigmatise those who hold the contrary opinion as bad and immoral men.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: To calumny of this sort, those who hold any unpopular opinion are

author: John Stuart Mill
text: peculiarly exposed, because they are in general few and uninfluential,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and nobody but themselves feel much interest in seeing justice done

author: John Stuart Mill
text: them; but this weapon is, from the nature of the case, denied to those

author: John Stuart Mill
text: who attack a prevailing opinion: they can neither use it with safety to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: themselves, nor, if they could, would it do anything but recoil on their

author: John Stuart Mill
text: own cause. In general, opinions contrary to those commonly received can

author: John Stuart Mill
text: only obtain a hearing by studied moderation of language, and the most

author: John Stuart Mill
text: cautious avoidance of unnecessary offence, from which they hardly ever

author: John Stuart Mill
text: deviate even in a slight degree without losing ground: while unmeasured

author: John Stuart Mill
text: vituperation employed on the side of the prevailing opinion, really does

author: John Stuart Mill
text: deter people from professing contrary opinions, and from listening to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: those who profess them. For the interest, therefore, of truth and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: justice, it is far more important to restrain this employment of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: vituperative language than the other; and, for example, if it were

author: John Stuart Mill
text: necessary to choose, there would be much more need to discourage

author: John Stuart Mill
text: offensive attacks on infidelity, than on religion. It is, however,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: obvious that law and authority have no business with restraining either,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: while opinion ought, in every instance, to determine its verdict by the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: circumstances of the individual case; condemning every one, on whichever

author: John Stuart Mill
text: side of the argument he places himself, in whose mode of advocacy either

author: John Stuart Mill
text: want of candour, or malignity, bigotry, or intolerance of feeling

author: John Stuart Mill
text: manifest themselves; but not inferring these vices from the side which

author: John Stuart Mill
text: a person takes, though it be the contrary side of the question to our

author: John Stuart Mill
text: own: and giving merited honour to every one, whatever opinion he may

author: John Stuart Mill
text: hold, who has calmness to see and honesty to state what his opponents

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and their opinions really are, exaggerating nothing to their discredit,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: keeping nothing back which tells, or can be supposed to tell, in their

author: John Stuart Mill
text: favour. This is the real morality of public discussion; and if often

author: John Stuart Mill
text: violated, I am happy to think that there are many controversialists who

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to a great extent observe it, and a still greater number who

author: John Stuart Mill
text: conscientiously strive towards it.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: [6] These words had scarcely been written, when, as if to give them an

author: John Stuart Mill
text: emphatic contradiction, occurred the Government Press Prosecutions of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: 1858. That ill-judged interference with the liberty of public discussion

author: John Stuart Mill
text: has not, however, induced me to alter a single word in the text, nor has

author: John Stuart Mill
text: it at all weakened my conviction that, moments of panic excepted, the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: era of pains and penalties for political discussion has, in our own

author: John Stuart Mill
text: country, passed away. For, in the first place, the prosecutions were not

author: John Stuart Mill
text: persisted in; and, in the second, they were never, properly speaking,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: political prosecutions. The offence charged was not that of criticising

author: John Stuart Mill
text: institutions, or the acts or persons of rulers, but of circulating what

author: John Stuart Mill
text: was deemed an immoral doctrine, the lawfulness of Tyrannicide.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: If the arguments of the present chapter are of any validity, there ought

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to exist the fullest liberty of professing and discussing, as a matter

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of ethical conviction, any doctrine, however immoral it may be

author: John Stuart Mill
text: considered. It would, therefore, be irrelevant and out of place to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: examine here, whether the doctrine of Tyrannicide deserves that title. I

author: John Stuart Mill
text: shall content myself with saying, that the subject has been at all times

author: John Stuart Mill
text: one of the open questions of morals; that the act of a private citizen

author: John Stuart Mill
text: in striking down a criminal, who, by raising himself above the law, has

author: John Stuart Mill
text: placed himself beyond the reach of legal punishment or control, has been

author: John Stuart Mill
text: accounted by whole nations, and by some of the best and wisest of men,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: not a crime, but an act of exalted virtue; and that, right or wrong, it

author: John Stuart Mill
text: is not of the nature of assassination, but of civil war. As such, I hold

author: John Stuart Mill
text: that the instigation to it, in a specific case, may be a proper subject

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of punishment, but only if an overt act has followed, and at least a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: probable connection can be established between the act and the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: instigation. Even then, it is not a foreign government, but the very

author: John Stuart Mill
text: government assailed, which alone, in the exercise of self-defence, can

author: John Stuart Mill
text: legitimately punish attacks directed against its own existence.

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: [10] Ample warning may be drawn from the large infusion of the passions

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of a persecutor, which mingled with the general display of the worst

author: John Stuart Mill
text: parts of our national character on the occasion of the Sepoy

author: John Stuart Mill
text: insurrection. The ravings of fanatics or charlatans from the pulpit may

author: John Stuart Mill
text: be unworthy of notice; but the heads of the Evangelical party have

author: John Stuart Mill
text: announced as their principle, for the government of Hindoos and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Mahomedans, that no schools be supported by public money in which the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Bible is not taught, and by necessary consequence that no public

author: John Stuart Mill
text: employment be given to any but real or pretended Christians. An

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Under-Secretary of State, in a speech delivered to his constituents on

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the 12th of November, 1857, is reported to have said: "Toleration of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: their faith" (the faith of a hundred millions of British subjects), "the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: superstition which they called religion, by the British Government, had

author: John Stuart Mill
text: had the effect of retarding the ascendency of the British name, and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: preventing the salutary growth of Christianity.... Toleration was the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: great corner-stone of the religious liberties of this country; but do

author: John Stuart Mill
text: not let them abuse that precious word toleration. As he understood it,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: it meant the complete liberty to all, freedom of worship, _among

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Christians, who worshipped upon the same foundation_. It meant

author: John Stuart Mill
text: toleration of all sects and denominations of _Christians who believed in

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the one mediation_." I desire to call attention to the fact, that a man

author: John Stuart Mill
text: who has been deemed fit to fill a high office in the government of this

author: John Stuart Mill
text: country, under a liberal Ministry, maintains the doctrine that all who

author: John Stuart Mill
text: do not believe in the divinity of Christ are beyond the pale of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: toleration. Who, after this imbecile display, can indulge the illusion

text: that religious persecution has passed away, never to return?

author: John Stuart Mill
text: CHAPTER III.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: OF INDIVIDUALITY, AS ONE OF THE ELEMENTS OF WELL-BEING.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Such being the reasons which make it imperative that human beings should

author: John Stuart Mill
text: be free to form opinions, and to express their opinions without reserve;

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and such the baneful consequences to the intellectual, and through that

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to the moral nature of man, unless this liberty is either conceded, or

author: John Stuart Mill
text: asserted in spite of prohibition; let us next examine whether the same

author: John Stuart Mill
text: reasons do not require that men should be free to act upon their

author: John Stuart Mill
text: opinions--to carry these out in their lives, without hindrance, either

author: John Stuart Mill
text: physical or moral, from their fellow-men, so long as it is at their own

author: John Stuart Mill
text: risk and peril. This last proviso is of course indispensable. No one

author: John Stuart Mill
text: pretends that actions should be as free as opinions. On the contrary,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: even opinions lose their immunity, when the circumstances in which they

author: John Stuart Mill
text: are expressed are such as to constitute their expression a positive

author: John Stuart Mill
text: instigation to some mischievous act. An opinion that corn-dealers are

author: John Stuart Mill
text: starvers of the poor, or that private property is robbery, ought to be

author: John Stuart Mill
text: unmolested when simply circulated through the press, but may justly

author: John Stuart Mill
text: incur punishment when delivered orally to an excited mob assembled

author: John Stuart Mill
text: before the house of a corn-dealer, or when handed about among the same

author: John Stuart Mill
text: mob in the form of a placard. Acts, of whatever kind, which, without

author: John Stuart Mill
text: justifiable cause, do harm to others, may be, and in the more important

author: John Stuart Mill
text: cases absolutely require to be, controlled by the unfavourable

author: John Stuart Mill
text: sentiments, and, when needful, by the active interference of mankind.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: The liberty of the individual must be thus far limited; he must not make

author: John Stuart Mill
text: himself a nuisance to other people. But if he refrains from molesting

author: John Stuart Mill
text: others in what concerns them, and merely acts according to his own

author: John Stuart Mill
text: inclination and judgment in things which concern himself, the same

author: John Stuart Mill
text: reasons which show that opinion should be free, prove also that he

author: John Stuart Mill
text: should be allowed, without molestation, to carry his opinions into

author: John Stuart Mill
text: practice at his own cost. That mankind are not infallible; that their

author: John Stuart Mill
text: truths, for the most part, are only half-truths; that unity of opinion,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: unless resulting from the fullest and freest comparison of opposite

author: John Stuart Mill
text: opinions, is not desirable, and diversity not an evil, but a good,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: until mankind are much more capable than at present of recognising all

author: John Stuart Mill
text: sides of the truth, are principles applicable to men's modes of action,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: not less than to their opinions. As it is useful that while mankind are

author: John Stuart Mill
text: imperfect there should be different opinions, so is it that there should

author: John Stuart Mill
text: be different experiments of living; that free scope should be given to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: varieties of character, short of injury to others; and that the worth of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: different modes of life should be proved practically, when any one

author: John Stuart Mill
text: thinks fit to try them. It is desirable, in short, that in things which

author: John Stuart Mill
text: do not primarily concern others, individuality should assert itself.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Where, not the person's own character, but the traditions or customs of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: other people are the rule of conduct, there is wanting one of the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: principal ingredients of human happiness, and quite the chief ingredient

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of individual and social progress.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: In maintaining this principle, the greatest difficulty to be encountered

author: John Stuart Mill
text: does not lie in the appreciation of means towards an acknowledged end,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: but in the indifference of persons in general to the end itself. If it

author: John Stuart Mill
text: were felt that the free development of individuality is one of the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: leading essentials of well-being; that it is not only a co-ordinate

author: John Stuart Mill
text: element with all that is designated by the terms civilisation,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: instruction, education, culture, but is itself a necessary part and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: condition of all those things; there would be no danger that liberty

author: John Stuart Mill
text: should be under-valued, and the adjustment of the boundaries between it

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and social control would present no extraordinary difficulty. But the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: evil is, that individual spontaneity is hardly recognised by the common

author: John Stuart Mill
text: modes of thinking, as having any intrinsic worth, or deserving any

author: John Stuart Mill
text: regard on its own account. The majority, being satisfied with the ways

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of mankind as they now are (for it is they who make them what they are),

author: John Stuart Mill
text: cannot comprehend why those ways should not be good enough for

author: John Stuart Mill
text: everybody; and what is more, spontaneity forms no part of the ideal of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the majority of moral and social reformers, but is rather looked on with

author: John Stuart Mill
text: jealousy, as a troublesome and perhaps rebellious obstruction to the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: general acceptance of what these reformers, in their own judgment, think

author: John Stuart Mill
text: would be best for mankind. Few persons, out of Germany, even comprehend

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the meaning of the doctrine which Wilhelm von Humboldt, so eminent both

author: John Stuart Mill
text: as a _savant_ and as a politician, made the text of a treatise--that

author: John Stuart Mill
text: "the end of man, or that which is prescribed by the eternal or immutable

author: John Stuart Mill
text: dictates of reason, and not suggested by vague and transient desires,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: is the highest and most harmonious development of his powers to a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: complete and consistent whole;" that, therefore, the object "towards

author: John Stuart Mill
text: which every human being must ceaselessly direct his efforts, and on

author: John Stuart Mill
text: which especially those who design to influence their fellow-men must

author: John Stuart Mill
text: ever keep their eyes, is the individuality of power and development;"

author: John Stuart Mill
text: that for this there are two requisites, "freedom, and a variety of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: situations;" and that from the union of these arise "individual vigour

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and manifold diversity," which combine themselves in "originality."[11]

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Little, however, as people are accustomed to a doctrine like that of Von

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Humboldt, and surprising as it may be to them to find so high a value

author: John Stuart Mill
text: attached to individuality, the question, one must nevertheless think,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: can only be one of degree. No one's idea of excellence in conduct is

author: John Stuart Mill
text: that people should do absolutely nothing but copy one another. No one

author: John Stuart Mill
text: would assert that people ought not to put into their mode of life, and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: into the conduct of their concerns, any impress whatever of their own

author: John Stuart Mill
text: judgment, or of their own individual character. On the other hand, it

author: John Stuart Mill
text: would be absurd to pretend that people ought to live as if nothing

author: John Stuart Mill
text: whatever had been known in the world before they came into it; as if

author: John Stuart Mill
text: experience had as yet done nothing towards showing that one mode of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: existence, or of conduct, is preferable to another. Nobody denies that

author: John Stuart Mill
text: people should be so taught and trained in youth, as to know and benefit

author: John Stuart Mill
text: by the ascertained results of human experience. But it is the privilege

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and proper condition of a human being, arrived at the maturity of his

author: John Stuart Mill
text: faculties, to use and interpret experience in his own way. It is for him

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to find out what part of recorded experience is properly applicable to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: his own circumstances and character. The traditions and customs of other

author: John Stuart Mill
text: people are, to a certain extent, evidence of what their experience has

author: John Stuart Mill
text: taught _them_; presumptive evidence, and as such, have a claim to his

author: John Stuart Mill
text: deference: but, in the first place, their experience may be too narrow;

author: John Stuart Mill
text: or they may not have interpreted it rightly. Secondly, their

author: John Stuart Mill
text: interpretation of experience may be correct, but unsuitable to him.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Customs are made for customary circumstances, and customary characters:

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and his circumstances or his character may be uncustomary. Thirdly,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: though the customs be both good as customs, and suitable to him, yet to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: conform to custom, merely _as_ custom, does not educate or develop in

author: John Stuart Mill
text: him any of the qualities which are the distinctive endowment of a human

author: John Stuart Mill
text: being. The human faculties of perception, judgment, discriminative

author: John Stuart Mill
text: feeling, mental activity, and even moral preference, are exercised only

author: John Stuart Mill
text: in making a choice. He who does anything because it is the custom, makes

author: John Stuart Mill
text: no choice. He gains no practice either in discerning or in desiring what

author: John Stuart Mill
text: is best. The mental and moral, like the muscular powers, are improved

author: John Stuart Mill
text: only by being used. The faculties are called into no exercise by doing a
