text: decided mental superiority who have a just claim to carry on their lives

author: John Stuart Mill
text: in their own way. There is no reason that all human existences should be

author: John Stuart Mill
text: constructed on some one, or some small number of patterns. If a person

author: John Stuart Mill
text: possesses any tolerable amount of common-sense and experience, his own

author: John Stuart Mill
text: mode of laying out his existence is the best, not because it is the best

author: John Stuart Mill
text: in itself, but because it is his own mode. Human beings are not like

author: John Stuart Mill
text: sheep; and even sheep are not undistinguishably alike. A man cannot get

author: John Stuart Mill
text: a coat or a pair of boots to fit him, unless they are either made to his

author: John Stuart Mill
text: measure, or he has a whole warehouseful to choose from: and is it easier

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to fit him with a life than with a coat, or are human beings more like

author: John Stuart Mill
text: one another in their whole physical and spiritual conformation than in

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the shape of their feet? If it were only that people have diversities of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: taste, that is reason enough for not attempting to shape them all after

author: John Stuart Mill
text: one model. But different persons also require different conditions for

author: John Stuart Mill
text: their spiritual development; and can no more exist healthily in the same

author: John Stuart Mill
text: moral, than all the variety of plants can in the same physical,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: atmosphere and climate. The same things which are helps to one person

author: John Stuart Mill
text: towards the cultivation of his higher nature, are hindrances to another.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: The same mode of life is a healthy excitement to one, keeping all his

author: John Stuart Mill
text: faculties of action and enjoyment in their best order, while to another

author: John Stuart Mill
text: it is a distracting burthen, which suspends or crushes all internal

author: John Stuart Mill
text: life. Such are the differences among human beings in their sources of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: pleasure, their susceptibilities of pain, and the operation on them of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: different physical and moral agencies, that unless there is a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: corresponding diversity in their modes of life, they neither obtain

author: John Stuart Mill
text: their fair share of happiness, nor grow up to the mental, moral, and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: aesthetic stature of which their nature is capable. Why then should

author: John Stuart Mill
text: tolerance, as far as the public sentiment is concerned, extend only to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: tastes and modes of life which extort acquiescence by the multitude of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: their adherents? Nowhere (except in some monastic institutions) is

author: John Stuart Mill
text: diversity of taste entirely unrecognised; a person may, without blame,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: either like or dislike rowing, or smoking, or music, or athletic

author: John Stuart Mill
text: exercises, or chess, or cards, or study, because both those who like

author: John Stuart Mill
text: each of these things, and those who dislike them, are too numerous to be

author: John Stuart Mill
text: put down. But the man, and still more the woman, who can be accused

author: John Stuart Mill
text: either of doing "what nobody does," or of not doing "what everybody

author: John Stuart Mill
text: does," is the subject of as much depreciatory remark as if he or she had

author: John Stuart Mill
text: committed some grave moral delinquency. Persons require to possess a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: title, or some other badge of rank, or of the consideration of people of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: rank, to be able to indulge somewhat in the luxury of doing as they like

author: John Stuart Mill
text: without detriment to their estimation. To indulge somewhat, I repeat:

author: John Stuart Mill
text: for whoever allow themselves much of that indulgence, incur the risk of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: something worse than disparaging speeches--they are in peril of a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: commission _de lunatico_, and of having their property taken from them

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and given to their relations.[13]

author: John Stuart Mill
text: There is one characteristic of the present direction of public opinion,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: peculiarly calculated to make it intolerant of any marked demonstration

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of individuality. The general average of mankind are not only moderate

author: John Stuart Mill
text: in intellect, but also moderate in inclinations: they have no tastes or

author: John Stuart Mill
text: wishes strong enough to incline them to do anything unusual, and they

author: John Stuart Mill
text: consequently do not understand those who have, and class all such with

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the wild and intemperate whom they are accustomed to look down upon.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Now, in addition to this fact which is general, we have only to suppose

author: John Stuart Mill
text: that a strong movement has set in towards the improvement of morals,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and it is evident what we have to expect. In these days such a movement

author: John Stuart Mill
text: has set in; much has actually been effected in the way of increased

author: John Stuart Mill
text: regularity of conduct, and discouragement of excesses; and there is a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: philanthropic spirit abroad, for the exercise of which there is no more

author: John Stuart Mill
text: inviting field than the moral and prudential improvement of our

author: John Stuart Mill
text: fellow-creatures. These tendencies of the times cause the public to be

author: John Stuart Mill
text: more disposed than at most former periods to prescribe general rules of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: conduct, and endeavour to make every one conform to the approved

author: John Stuart Mill
text: standard. And that standard, express or tacit, is to desire nothing

author: John Stuart Mill
text: strongly. Its ideal of character is to be without any marked character;

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to maim by compression, like a Chinese lady's foot, every part of human

author: John Stuart Mill
text: nature which stands out prominently, and tends to make the person

author: John Stuart Mill
text: markedly dissimilar in outline to commonplace humanity.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: As is usually the case with ideals which exclude one-half of what is

author: John Stuart Mill
text: desirable, the present standard of approbation produces only an inferior

author: John Stuart Mill
text: imitation of the other half. Instead of great energies guided by

author: John Stuart Mill
text: vigorous reason, and strong feelings strongly controlled by a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: conscientious will, its result is weak feelings and weak energies, which

author: John Stuart Mill
text: therefore can be kept in outward conformity to rule without any strength

author: John Stuart Mill
text: either of will or of reason. Already energetic characters on any large

author: John Stuart Mill
text: scale are becoming merely traditional. There is now scarcely any outlet

author: John Stuart Mill
text: for energy in this country except business. The energy expended in that

author: John Stuart Mill
text: may still be regarded as considerable. What little is left from that

author: John Stuart Mill
text: employment, is expended on some hobby; which may be a useful, even a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: philanthropic hobby, but is always some one thing, and generally a thing

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of small dimensions. The greatness of England is now all collective:

author: John Stuart Mill
text: individually small, we only appear capable of anything great by our

author: John Stuart Mill
text: habit of combining; and with this our moral and religious

author: John Stuart Mill
text: philanthropists are perfectly contented. But it was men of another

author: John Stuart Mill
text: stamp than this that made England what it has been; and men of another

author: John Stuart Mill
text: stamp will be needed to prevent its decline.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: The despotism of custom is everywhere the standing hindrance to human

author: John Stuart Mill
text: advancement, being in unceasing antagonism to that disposition to aim at

author: John Stuart Mill
text: something better than customary, which is called, according to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: circumstances, the spirit of liberty, or that of progress or

author: John Stuart Mill
text: improvement. The spirit of improvement is not always a spirit of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: liberty, for it may aim at forcing improvements on an unwilling people;

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and the spirit of liberty, in so far as it resists such attempts, may

author: John Stuart Mill
text: ally itself locally and temporarily with the opponents of improvement;

author: John Stuart Mill
text: but the only unfailing and permanent source of improvement is liberty,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: since by it there are as many possible independent centres of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: improvement as there are individuals. The progressive principle,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: however, in either shape, whether as the love of liberty or of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: improvement, is antagonistic to the sway of Custom, involving at least

author: John Stuart Mill
text: emancipation from that yoke; and the contest between the two constitutes

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the chief interest of the history of mankind. The greater part of the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: world has, properly speaking, no history, because the despotism of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Custom is complete. This is the case over the whole East. Custom is

author: John Stuart Mill
text: there, in all things, the final appeal; justice and right mean

author: John Stuart Mill
text: conformity to custom; the argument of custom no one, unless some tyrant

author: John Stuart Mill
text: intoxicated with power, thinks of resisting. And we see the result.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Those nations must once have had originality; they did not start out of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the ground populous, lettered, and versed in many of the arts of life;

author: John Stuart Mill
text: they made themselves all this, and were then the greatest and most

author: John Stuart Mill
text: powerful nations in the world. What are they now? The subjects or

author: John Stuart Mill
text: dependants of tribes whose forefathers wandered in the forests when

author: John Stuart Mill
text: theirs had magnificent palaces and gorgeous temples, but over whom

author: John Stuart Mill
text: custom exercised only a divided rule with liberty and progress. A

author: John Stuart Mill
text: people, it appears, may be progressive for a certain length of time, and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: then stop: when does it stop? When it ceases to possess individuality.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: If a similar change should befall the nations of Europe, it will not be

author: John Stuart Mill
text: in exactly the same shape: the despotism of custom with which these

author: John Stuart Mill
text: nations are threatened is not precisely stationariness. It proscribes

author: John Stuart Mill
text: singularity, but it does not preclude change, provided all change

author: John Stuart Mill
text: together. We have discarded the fixed costumes of our forefathers; every

author: John Stuart Mill
text: one must still dress like other people, but the fashion may change once

author: John Stuart Mill
text: or twice a year. We thus take care that when there is change, it shall

author: John Stuart Mill
text: be for change's sake, and not from any idea of beauty or convenience;

author: John Stuart Mill
text: for the same idea of beauty or convenience would not strike all the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: world at the same moment, and be simultaneously thrown aside by all at

author: John Stuart Mill
text: another moment. But we are progressive as well as changeable: we

author: John Stuart Mill
text: continually make new inventions in mechanical things, and keep them

author: John Stuart Mill
text: until they are again superseded by better; we are eager for improvement

author: John Stuart Mill
text: in politics, in education, even in morals, though in this last our idea

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of improvement chiefly consists in persuading or forcing other people to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: be as good as ourselves. It is not progress that we object to; on the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: contrary, we flatter ourselves that we are the most progressive people

author: John Stuart Mill
text: who ever lived. It is individuality that we war against: we should think

author: John Stuart Mill
text: we had done wonders if we had made ourselves all alike; forgetting that

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the unlikeness of one person to another is generally the first thing

author: John Stuart Mill
text: which draws the attention of either to the imperfection of his own type,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and the superiority of another, or the possibility, by combining the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: advantages of both, of producing something better than either. We have a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: warning example in China--a nation of much talent, and, in some

author: John Stuart Mill
text: respects, even wisdom, owing to the rare good fortune of having been

author: John Stuart Mill
text: provided at an early period with a particularly good set of customs, the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: work, in some measure, of men to whom even the most enlightened European

author: John Stuart Mill
text: must accord, under certain limitations, the title of sages and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: philosophers. They are remarkable, too, in the excellence of their

author: John Stuart Mill
text: apparatus for impressing, as far as possible, the best wisdom they

author: John Stuart Mill
text: possess upon every mind in the community, and securing that those who

author: John Stuart Mill
text: have appropriated most of it shall occupy the posts of honour and power.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Surely the people who did this have discovered the secret of human

author: John Stuart Mill
text: progressiveness, and must have kept themselves steadily at the head of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the movement of the world. On the contrary, they have become

author: John Stuart Mill
text: stationary--have remained so for thousands of years; and if they are

author: John Stuart Mill
text: ever to be farther improved, it must be by foreigners. They have

author: John Stuart Mill
text: succeeded beyond all hope in what English philanthropists are so

author: John Stuart Mill
text: industriously working at--in making a people all alike, all governing

author: John Stuart Mill
text: their thoughts and conduct by the same maxims and rules; and these are

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the fruits. The modern _regime_ of public opinion is, in an unorganised

author: John Stuart Mill
text: form, what the Chinese educational and political systems are in an

author: John Stuart Mill
text: organised; and unless individuality shall be able successfully to assert

author: John Stuart Mill
text: itself against this yoke, Europe, notwithstanding its noble antecedents

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and its professed Christianity, will tend to become another China.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: What is it that has hitherto preserved Europe from this lot? What has

author: John Stuart Mill
text: made the European family of nations an improving, instead of a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: stationary portion of mankind? Not any superior excellence in them,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: which, when it exists, exists as the effect, not as the cause; but their

author: John Stuart Mill
text: remarkable diversity of character and culture. Individuals, classes,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: nations, have been extremely unlike one another: they have struck out a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: great variety of paths, each leading to something valuable; and although

author: John Stuart Mill
text: at every period those who travelled in different paths have been

author: John Stuart Mill
text: intolerant of one another, and each would have thought it an excellent

author: John Stuart Mill
text: thing if all the rest could have been compelled to travel his road,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: their attempts to thwart each other's development have rarely had any

author: John Stuart Mill
text: permanent success, and each has in time endured to receive the good

author: John Stuart Mill
text: which the others have offered. Europe is, in my judgment, wholly

author: John Stuart Mill
text: indebted to this plurality of paths for its progressive and many-sided

author: John Stuart Mill
text: development. But it already begins to possess this benefit in a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: considerably less degree. It is decidedly advancing towards the Chinese

author: John Stuart Mill
text: ideal of making all people alike. M. de Tocqueville, in his last

author: John Stuart Mill
text: important work, remarks how much more the Frenchmen of the present day

author: John Stuart Mill
text: resemble one another, than did those even of the last generation. The

author: John Stuart Mill
text: same remark might be made of Englishmen in a far greater degree. In a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: passage already quoted from Wilhelm von Humboldt, he points out two

author: John Stuart Mill
text: things as necessary conditions of human development, because necessary

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to render people unlike one another; namely, freedom, and variety of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: situations. The second of these two conditions is in this country every

author: John Stuart Mill
text: day diminishing. The circumstances which surround different classes and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: individuals, and shape their characters, are daily becoming more

author: John Stuart Mill
text: assimilated. Formerly, different ranks, different neighbourhoods,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: different trades and professions, lived in what might be called

author: John Stuart Mill
text: different worlds; at present, to a great degree in the same.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Comparatively speaking, they now read the same things, listen to the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: same things, see the same things, go to the same places, have their

author: John Stuart Mill
text: hopes and fears directed to the same objects, have the same rights and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: liberties, and the same means of asserting them. Great as are the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: differences of position which remain, they are nothing to those which

author: John Stuart Mill
text: have ceased. And the assimilation is still proceeding. All the political

author: John Stuart Mill
text: changes of the age promote it, since they all tend to raise the low and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to lower the high. Every extension of education promotes it, because

author: John Stuart Mill
text: education brings people under common influences, and gives them access

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to the general stock of facts and sentiments. Improvements in the means

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of communication promote it, by bringing the inhabitants of distant

author: John Stuart Mill
text: places into personal contact, and keeping up a rapid flow of changes of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: residence between one place and another. The increase of commerce and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: manufactures promotes it, by diffusing more widely the advantages of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: easy circumstances, and opening all objects of ambition, even the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: highest, to general competition, whereby the desire of rising becomes no

author: John Stuart Mill
text: longer the character of a particular class, but of all classes. A more

author: John Stuart Mill
text: powerful agency than even all these, in bringing about a general

author: John Stuart Mill
text: similarity among mankind, is the complete establishment, in this and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: other free countries, of the ascendency of public opinion in the State.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: As the various social eminences which enabled persons entrenched on them

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to disregard the opinion of the multitude, gradually become levelled; as

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the very idea of resisting the will of the public, when it is positively

author: John Stuart Mill
text: known that they have a will, disappears more and more from the minds of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: practical politicians; there ceases to be any social support for

author: John Stuart Mill
text: non-conformity--any substantive power in society, which, itself opposed

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to the ascendency of numbers, is interested in taking under its

author: John Stuart Mill
text: protection opinions and tendencies at variance with those of the public.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: The combination of all these causes forms so great a mass of influences

author: John Stuart Mill
text: hostile to Individuality, that it is not easy to see how it can stand

author: John Stuart Mill
text: its ground. It will do so with increasing difficulty, unless the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: intelligent part of the public can be made to feel its value--to see

author: John Stuart Mill
text: that it is good there should be differences, even though not for the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: better, even though, as it may appear to them, some should be for the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: worse. If the claims of Individuality are ever to be asserted, the time

author: John Stuart Mill
text: is now, while much is still wanting to complete the enforced

author: John Stuart Mill
text: assimilation. It is only in the earlier stages that any stand can be

author: John Stuart Mill
text: successfully made against the encroachment. The demand that all other

author: John Stuart Mill
text: people shall resemble ourselves, grows by what it feeds on. If

author: John Stuart Mill
text: resistance waits till life is reduced _nearly_ to one uniform type, all

author: John Stuart Mill
text: deviations from that type will come to be considered impious, immoral,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: even monstrous and contrary to nature. Mankind speedily become unable to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: conceive diversity, when they have been for some time unaccustomed to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: see it.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: FOOTNOTES:

author: John Stuart Mill
text: [11] _The Sphere and Duties of Government_, from the German of Baron

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Wilhelm von Humboldt, pp. 11-13.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: [12] Sterling's _Essays_.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: [13] There is something both contemptible and frightful in the sort of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: evidence on which, of late years, any person can be judicially declared

author: John Stuart Mill
text: unfit for the management of his affairs; and after his death, his

author: John Stuart Mill
text: disposal of his property can be set aside, if there is enough of it to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: pay the expenses of litigation--which are charged on the property

author: John Stuart Mill
text: itself. All the minute details of his daily life are pried into, and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: whatever is found which, seen through the medium of the perceiving and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: describing faculties of the lowest of the low, bears an appearance

author: John Stuart Mill
text: unlike absolute commonplace, is laid before the jury as evidence of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: insanity, and often with success; the jurors being little, if at all,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: less vulgar and ignorant than the witnesses; while the judges, with that

author: John Stuart Mill
text: extraordinary want of knowledge of human nature and life which

author: John Stuart Mill
text: continually astonishes us in English lawyers, often help to mislead

author: John Stuart Mill
text: them. These trials speak volumes as to the state of feeling and opinion

author: John Stuart Mill
text: among the vulgar with regard to human liberty. So far from setting any

author: John Stuart Mill
text: value on individuality--so far from respecting the rights of each

author: John Stuart Mill
text: individual to act, in things indifferent, as seems good to his own

author: John Stuart Mill
text: judgment and inclinations, judges and juries cannot even conceive that a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: person in a state of sanity can desire such freedom. In former days,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: when it was proposed to burn atheists, charitable people used to suggest

author: John Stuart Mill
text: putting them in a madhouse instead: it would be nothing surprising

author: John Stuart Mill
text: nowadays were we to see this done, and the doers applauding themselves,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: because, instead of persecuting for religion, they had adopted so humane

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and Christian a mode of treating these unfortunates, not without a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: silent satisfaction at their having thereby obtained their deserts.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: CHAPTER IV.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: OF THE LIMITS TO THE AUTHORITY OF SOCIETY OVER THE INDIVIDUAL.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: What, then, is the rightful limit to the sovereignty of the individual

author: John Stuart Mill
text: over himself? Where does the authority of society begin? How much of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: human life should be assigned to individuality, and how much to society?

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Each will receive its proper share, if each has that which more

author: John Stuart Mill
text: particularly concerns it. To individuality should belong the part of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: life in which it is chiefly the individual that is interested; to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: society, the part which chiefly interests society.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Though society is not founded on a contract, and though no good purpose

author: John Stuart Mill
text: is answered by inventing a contract in order to deduce social

author: John Stuart Mill
text: obligations from it, every one who receives the protection of society

author: John Stuart Mill
text: owes a return for the benefit, and the fact of living in society renders

author: John Stuart Mill
text: it indispensable that each should be bound to observe a certain line of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: conduct towards the rest. This conduct consists, first, in not injuring

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the interests of one another; or rather certain interests which, either

author: John Stuart Mill
text: by express legal provision or by tacit understanding, ought to be

author: John Stuart Mill
text: considered as rights; and secondly, in each person's bearing his share

author: John Stuart Mill
text: (to be fixed on some equitable principle) of the labours and sacrifices

author: John Stuart Mill
text: incurred for defending the society or its members from injury and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: molestation. These conditions society is justified in enforcing, at all

author: John Stuart Mill
text: costs to those who endeavour to withhold fulfilment. Nor is this all

author: John Stuart Mill
text: that society may do. The acts of an individual may be hurtful to others,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: or wanting in due consideration for their welfare, without going the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: length of violating any of their constituted rights. The offender may

author: John Stuart Mill
text: then be justly punished by opinion though not by law. As soon as any

author: John Stuart Mill
text: part of a person's conduct affects prejudicially the interests of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: others, society has jurisdiction over it, and the question whether the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: general welfare will or will not be promoted by interfering with it,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: becomes open to discussion. But there is no room for entertaining any

author: John Stuart Mill
text: such question when a person's conduct affects the interests of no

author: John Stuart Mill
text: persons besides himself, or needs not affect them unless they like (all

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the persons concerned being of full age, and the ordinary amount of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: understanding). In all such cases there should be perfect freedom, legal

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and social, to do the action and stand the consequences.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: It would be a great misunderstanding of this doctrine, to suppose that

author: John Stuart Mill
text: it is one of selfish indifference, which pretends that human beings have

author: John Stuart Mill
text: no business with each other's conduct in life, and that they should not

author: John Stuart Mill
text: concern themselves about the well-doing or well-being of one another,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: unless their own interest is involved. Instead of any diminution, there

author: John Stuart Mill
text: is need of a great increase of disinterested exertion to promote the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: good of others. But disinterested benevolence can find other instruments

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to persuade people to their good, than whips and scourges, either of the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: literal or the metaphorical sort. I am the last person to undervalue the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: self-regarding virtues; they are only second in importance, if even

author: John Stuart Mill
text: second, to the social. It is equally the business of education to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: cultivate both. But even education works by conviction and persuasion as

author: John Stuart Mill
text: well as by compulsion, and it is by the former only that, when the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: period of education is past, the self-regarding virtues should be

author: John Stuart Mill
text: inculcated. Human beings owe to each other help to distinguish the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: better from the worse, and encouragement to choose the former and avoid

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the latter. They should be for ever stimulating each other to increased

author: John Stuart Mill
text: exercise of their higher faculties, and increased direction of their

author: John Stuart Mill
text: feelings and aims towards wise instead of foolish, elevating instead of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: degrading, objects and contemplations. But neither one person, nor any

author: John Stuart Mill
text: number of persons, is warranted in saying to another human creature of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: ripe years, that he shall not do with his life for his own benefit what

author: John Stuart Mill
text: he chooses to do with it. He is the person most interested in his own

author: John Stuart Mill
text: well-being: the interest which any other person, except in cases of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: strong personal attachment, can have in it, is trifling, compared with

author: John Stuart Mill
text: that which he himself has; the interest which society has in him

author: John Stuart Mill
text: individually (except as to his conduct to others) is fractional, and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: altogether indirect: while, with respect to his own feelings and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: circumstances, the most ordinary man or woman has means of knowledge

author: John Stuart Mill
text: immeasurably surpassing those that can be possessed by any one else. The

author: John Stuart Mill
text: interference of society to overrule his judgment and purposes in what

author: John Stuart Mill
text: only regards himself, must be grounded on general presumptions; which

author: John Stuart Mill
text: may be altogether wrong, and even if right, are as likely as not to be

author: John Stuart Mill
text: misapplied to individual cases, by persons no better acquainted with the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: circumstances of such cases than those are who look at them merely from

author: John Stuart Mill
text: without. In this department, therefore, of human affairs, Individuality

author: John Stuart Mill
text: has its proper field of action. In the conduct of human beings towards

author: John Stuart Mill
text: one another, it is necessary that general rules should for the most part

author: John Stuart Mill
text: be observed, in order that people may know what they have to expect; but

author: John Stuart Mill
text: in each person's own concerns, his individual spontaneity is entitled to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: free exercise. Considerations to aid his judgment, exhortations to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: strengthen his will, may be offered to him, even obtruded on him, by

author: John Stuart Mill
text: others; but he himself is the final judge. All errors which he is likely

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to commit against advice and warning, are far outweighed by the evil of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: allowing others to constrain him to what they deem his good.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: I do not mean that the feelings with which a person is regarded by

author: John Stuart Mill
text: others, ought not to be in any way affected by his self-regarding

author: John Stuart Mill
text: qualities or deficiencies. This is neither possible nor desirable. If he

author: John Stuart Mill
text: is eminent in any of the qualities which conduce to his own good, he is,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: so far, a proper object of admiration. He is so much the nearer to the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: ideal perfection of human nature. If he is grossly deficient in those

author: John Stuart Mill
text: qualities, a sentiment the opposite of admiration will follow. There is

author: John Stuart Mill
text: a degree of folly, and a degree of what may be called (though the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: phrase is not unobjectionable) lowness or depravation of taste, which,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: though it cannot justify doing harm to the person who manifests it,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: renders him necessarily and properly a subject of distaste, or, in

author: John Stuart Mill
text: extreme cases, even of contempt: a person could not have the opposite

author: John Stuart Mill
text: qualities in due strength without entertaining these feelings. Though

author: John Stuart Mill
text: doing no wrong to any one, a person may so act as to compel us to judge

author: John Stuart Mill
text: him, and feel to him, as a fool, or as a being of an inferior order: and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: since this judgment and feeling are a fact which he would prefer to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: avoid, it is doing him a service to warn him of it beforehand, as of any

author: John Stuart Mill
text: other disagreeable consequence to which he exposes himself. It would be

author: John Stuart Mill
text: well, indeed, if this good office were much more freely rendered than

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the common notions of politeness at present permit, and if one person

author: John Stuart Mill
text: could honestly point out to another that he thinks him in fault, without

author: John Stuart Mill
text: being considered unmannerly or presuming. We have a right, also, in

author: John Stuart Mill
text: various ways, to act upon our unfavourable opinion of any one, not to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the oppression of his individuality, but in the exercise of ours. We are

author: John Stuart Mill
text: not bound, for example, to seek his society; we have a right to avoid it

author: John Stuart Mill
text: (though not to parade the avoidance), for we have a right to choose the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: society most acceptable to us. We have a right, and it may be our duty,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to caution others against him, if we think his example or conversation

author: John Stuart Mill
text: likely to have a pernicious effect on those with whom he associates. We

author: John Stuart Mill
text: may give others a preference over him in optional good offices, except

author: John Stuart Mill
text: those which tend to his improvement. In these various modes a person may

author: John Stuart Mill
text: suffer very severe penalties at the hands of others, for faults which

author: John Stuart Mill
text: directly concern only himself; but he suffers these penalties only in so

author: John Stuart Mill
text: far as they are the natural, and, as it were, the spontaneous

author: John Stuart Mill
text: consequences of the faults themselves, not because they are purposely

author: John Stuart Mill
text: inflicted on him for the sake of punishment. A person who shows

author: John Stuart Mill
text: rashness, obstinacy, self-conceit--who cannot live within moderate

author: John Stuart Mill
text: means--who cannot restrain himself from hurtful indulgences--who pursues

author: John Stuart Mill
text: animal pleasures at the expense of those of feeling and intellect--must

author: John Stuart Mill
text: expect to be lowered in the opinion of others, and to have a less share

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of their favourable sentiments; but of this he has no right to complain,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: unless he has merited their favour by special excellence in his social

author: John Stuart Mill
text: relations, and has thus established a title to their good offices, which

author: John Stuart Mill
text: is not affected by his demerits towards himself.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: What I contend for is, that the inconveniences which are strictly

author: John Stuart Mill
text: inseparable from the unfavourable judgment of others, are the only ones

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to which a person should ever be subjected for that portion of his

author: John Stuart Mill
text: conduct and character which concerns his own good, but which does not

author: John Stuart Mill
text: affect the interests of others in their relations with him. Acts

author: John Stuart Mill
text: injurious to others require a totally different treatment. Encroachment

author: John Stuart Mill
text: on their rights; infliction on them of any loss or damage not justified

author: John Stuart Mill
text: by his own rights; falsehood or duplicity in dealing with them; unfair

author: John Stuart Mill
text: or ungenerous use of advantages over them; even selfish abstinence from

author: John Stuart Mill
text: defending them against injury--these are fit objects of moral

author: John Stuart Mill
text: reprobation, and, in grave cases, of moral retribution and punishment.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: And not only these acts, but the dispositions which lead to them, are

author: John Stuart Mill
text: properly immoral, and fit subjects of disapprobation which may rise to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: abhorrence. Cruelty of disposition; malice and ill-nature; that most

author: John Stuart Mill
text: anti-social and odious of all passions, envy; dissimulation and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: insincerity; irascibility on insufficient cause, and resentment

author: John Stuart Mill
text: disproportioned to the provocation; the love of domineering over others;

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the desire to engross more than one's share of advantages (the [Greek:

author: John Stuart Mill
text: pleonexia] of the Greeks); the pride which derives gratification from

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the abasement of others; the egotism which thinks self and its concerns

author: John Stuart Mill
text: more important than everything else, and decides all doubtful questions

author: John Stuart Mill
text: in its own favour;--these are moral vices, and constitute a bad and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: odious moral character: unlike the self-regarding faults previously

author: John Stuart Mill
text: mentioned, which are not properly immoralities, and to whatever pitch

author: John Stuart Mill
text: they may be carried, do not constitute wickedness. They may be proofs of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: any amount of folly, or want of personal dignity and self-respect; but

author: John Stuart Mill
text: they are only a subject of moral reprobation when they involve a breach

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of duty to others, for whose sake the individual is bound to have care

author: John Stuart Mill
text: for himself. What are called duties to ourselves are not socially

author: John Stuart Mill
text: obligatory, unless circumstances render them at the same time duties to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: others. The term duty to oneself, when it means anything more than

author: John Stuart Mill
text: prudence, means self-respect or self-development; and for none of these

author: John Stuart Mill
text: is any one accountable to his fellow-creatures, because for none of them

author: John Stuart Mill
text: is it for the good of mankind that he be held accountable to them.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: The distinction between the loss of consideration which a person may

author: John Stuart Mill
text: rightly incur by defect of prudence or of personal dignity, and the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: reprobation which is due to him for an offence against the rights of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: others, is not a merely nominal distinction. It makes a vast difference

author: John Stuart Mill
text: both in our feelings and in our conduct towards him, whether he

author: John Stuart Mill
text: displeases us in things in which we think we have a right to control

author: John Stuart Mill
text: him, or in things in which we know that we have not. If he displeases

author: John Stuart Mill
text: us, we may express our distaste, and we may stand aloof from a person as

author: John Stuart Mill
text: well as from a thing that displeases us; but we shall not therefore feel

author: John Stuart Mill
text: called on to make his life uncomfortable. We shall reflect that he

author: John Stuart Mill
text: already bears, or will bear, the whole penalty of his error; if he

author: John Stuart Mill
text: spoils his life by mismanagement, we shall not, for that reason, desire

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to spoil it still further: instead of wishing to punish him, we shall

author: John Stuart Mill
text: rather endeavour to alleviate his punishment, by showing him how he may

author: John Stuart Mill
text: avoid or cure the evils his conduct tends to bring upon him. He may be

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to us an object of pity, perhaps of dislike, but not of anger or

author: John Stuart Mill
text: resentment; we shall not treat him like an enemy of society: the worst

author: John Stuart Mill
text: we shall think ourselves justified in doing is leaving him to himself,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: if we do not interfere benevolently by showing interest or concern for

author: John Stuart Mill
text: him. It is far otherwise if he has infringed the rules necessary for the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: protection of his fellow-creatures, individually or collectively. The

author: John Stuart Mill
text: evil consequences of his acts do not then fall on himself, but on

author: John Stuart Mill
text: others; and society, as the protector of all its members, must retaliate

author: John Stuart Mill
text: on him; must inflict pain on him for the express purpose of punishment,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and must take care that it be sufficiently severe. In the one case, he

author: John Stuart Mill
text: is an offender at our bar, and we are called on not only to sit in

author: John Stuart Mill
text: judgment on him, but, in one shape or another, to execute our own

author: John Stuart Mill
text: sentence: in the other case, it is not our part to inflict any suffering

author: John Stuart Mill
text: on him, except what may incidentally follow from our using the same

author: John Stuart Mill
text: liberty in the regulation of our own affairs, which we allow to him in

author: John Stuart Mill
text: his.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: The distinction here pointed out between the part of a person's life

author: John Stuart Mill
text: which concerns only himself, and that which concerns others, many

author: John Stuart Mill
text: persons will refuse to admit. How (it may be asked) can any part of the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: conduct of a member of society be a matter of indifference to the other

author: John Stuart Mill
text: members? No person is an entirely isolated being; it is impossible for a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: person to do anything seriously or permanently hurtful to himself,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: without mischief reaching at least to his near connections, and often

author: John Stuart Mill
text: far beyond them. If he injures his property, he does harm to those who

author: John Stuart Mill
text: directly or indirectly derived support from it, and usually diminishes,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: by a greater or less amount, the general resources of the community. If

author: John Stuart Mill
text: he deteriorates his bodily or mental faculties, he not only brings evil

author: John Stuart Mill
text: upon all who depended on him for any portion of their happiness, but

author: John Stuart Mill
text: disqualifies himself for rendering the services which he owes to his

author: John Stuart Mill
text: fellow-creatures generally; perhaps becomes a burthen on their affection

author: John Stuart Mill
text: or benevolence; and if such conduct were very frequent, hardly any

author: John Stuart Mill
text: offence that is committed would detract more from the general sum of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: good. Finally, if by his vices or follies a person does no direct harm

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to others, he is nevertheless (it may be said) injurious by his example;

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and ought to be compelled to control himself, for the sake of those whom

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the sight or knowledge of his conduct might corrupt or mislead.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: And even (it will be added) if the consequences of misconduct could be

author: John Stuart Mill
text: confined to the vicious or thoughtless individual, ought society to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: abandon to their own guidance those who are manifestly unfit for it? If

author: John Stuart Mill
text: protection against themselves is confessedly due to children and persons

author: John Stuart Mill
text: under age, is not society equally bound to afford it to persons of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: mature years who are equally incapable of self-government? If gambling,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: or drunkenness, or incontinence, or idleness, or uncleanliness, are as

author: John Stuart Mill
text: injurious to happiness, and as great a hindrance to improvement, as many

author: John Stuart Mill
text: or most of the acts prohibited by law, why (it may be asked) should not

author: John Stuart Mill
text: law, so far as is consistent with practicability and social convenience,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: endeavour to repress these also? And as a supplement to the unavoidable

author: John Stuart Mill
text: imperfections of law, ought not opinion at least to organise a powerful

author: John Stuart Mill
text: police against these vices, and visit rigidly with social penalties

author: John Stuart Mill
text: those who are known to practise them? There is no question here (it may

author: John Stuart Mill
text: be said) about restricting individuality, or impeding the trial of new

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and original experiments in living. The only things it is sought to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: prevent are things which have been tried and condemned from the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: beginning of the world until now; things which experience has shown not

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to be useful or suitable to any person's individuality. There must be

author: John Stuart Mill
text: some length of time and amount of experience, after which a moral or

author: John Stuart Mill
text: prudential truth may be regarded as established: and it is merely

author: John Stuart Mill
text: desired to prevent generation after generation from falling over the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: same precipice which has been fatal to their predecessors.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: I fully admit that the mischief which a person does to himself, may

author: John Stuart Mill
text: seriously affect, both through their sympathies and their interests,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: those nearly connected with him, and in a minor degree, society at

author: John Stuart Mill
text: large. When, by conduct of this sort, a person is led to violate a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: distinct and assignable obligation to any other person or persons, the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: case is taken out of the self-regarding class, and becomes amenable to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: moral disapprobation in the proper sense of the term. If, for example,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: a man, through intemperance or extravagance, becomes unable to pay his

author: John Stuart Mill
text: debts, or, having undertaken the moral responsibility of a family,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: becomes from the same cause incapable of supporting or educating them,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: he is deservedly reprobated, and might be justly punished; but it is for

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the breach of duty to his family or creditors, not for the extravagance.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: If the resources which ought to have been devoted to them, had been

author: John Stuart Mill
text: diverted from them for the most prudent investment, the moral

author: John Stuart Mill
text: culpability would have been the same. George Barnwell murdered his uncle

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to get money for his mistress, but if he had done it to set himself up

author: John Stuart Mill
text: in business, he would equally have been hanged. Again, in the frequent

author: John Stuart Mill
text: case of a man who causes grief to his family by addiction to bad habits,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: he deserves reproach for his unkindness or ingratitude; but so he may

author: John Stuart Mill
text: for cultivating habits not in themselves vicious, if they are painful to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: those with whom he passes his life, or who from personal ties are

author: John Stuart Mill
text: dependent on him for their comfort. Whoever fails in the consideration

author: John Stuart Mill
text: generally due to the interests and feelings of others, not being

author: John Stuart Mill
text: compelled by some more imperative duty, or justified by allowable

author: John Stuart Mill
text: self-preference, is a subject of moral disapprobation for that failure,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: but not for the cause of it, nor for the errors, merely personal to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: himself, which may have remotely led to it. In like manner, when a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: person disables himself, by conduct purely self-regarding, from the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: performance of some definite duty incumbent on him to the public, he is

author: John Stuart Mill
text: guilty of a social offence. No person ought to be punished simply for

author: John Stuart Mill
text: being drunk; but a soldier or a policeman should be punished for being

author: John Stuart Mill
text: drunk on duty. Whenever, in short, there is a definite damage, or a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: definite risk of damage, either to an individual or to the public, the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: case is taken out of the province of liberty, and placed in that of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: morality or law.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: But with regard to the merely contingent, or, as it may be called,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: constructive injury which a person causes to society, by conduct which

author: John Stuart Mill
text: neither violates any specific duty to the public, nor occasions

author: John Stuart Mill
text: perceptible hurt to any assignable individual except himself; the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: inconvenience is one which society can afford to bear, for the sake of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the greater good of human freedom. If grown persons are to be punished

author: John Stuart Mill
text: for not taking proper care of themselves, I would rather it were for

author: John Stuart Mill
text: their own sake, than under pretence of preventing them from impairing

author: John Stuart Mill
text: their capacity of rendering to society benefits which society does not

author: John Stuart Mill
text: pretend it has a right to exact. But I cannot consent to argue the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: point as if society had no means of bringing its weaker members up to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: its ordinary standard of rational conduct, except waiting till they do

author: John Stuart Mill
text: something irrational, and then punishing them, legally or morally, for

author: John Stuart Mill
text: it. Society has had absolute power over them during all the early

author: John Stuart Mill
text: portion of their existence: it has had the whole period of childhood and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: nonage in which to try whether it could make them capable of rational

author: John Stuart Mill
text: conduct in life. The existing generation is master both of the training

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and the entire circumstances of the generation to come; it cannot indeed

author: John Stuart Mill
text: make them perfectly wise and good, because it is itself so lamentably

author: John Stuart Mill
text: deficient in goodness and wisdom; and its best efforts are not always,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: in individual cases, its most successful ones; but it is perfectly well

author: John Stuart Mill
text: able to make the rising generation, as a whole, as good as, and a little

author: John Stuart Mill
text: better than, itself. If society lets any considerable number of its

author: John Stuart Mill
text: members grow up mere children, incapable of being acted on by rational

author: John Stuart Mill
text: consideration of distant motives, society has itself to blame for the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: consequences. Armed not only with all the powers of education, but with

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the ascendency which the authority of a received opinion always

author: John Stuart Mill
text: exercises over the minds who are least fitted to judge for themselves;

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and aided by the _natural_ penalties which cannot be prevented from

author: John Stuart Mill
text: falling on those who incur the distaste or the contempt of those who

author: John Stuart Mill
text: know them; let not society pretend that it needs, besides all this, the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: power to issue commands and enforce obedience in the personal concerns

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of individuals, in which, on all principles of justice and policy, the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: decision ought to rest with those who are to abide the consequences. Nor

author: John Stuart Mill
text: is there anything which tends more to discredit and frustrate the better

author: John Stuart Mill
text: means of influencing conduct, than a resort to the worse. If there be

author: John Stuart Mill
text: among those whom it is attempted to coerce into prudence or temperance,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: any of the material of which vigorous and independent characters are

author: John Stuart Mill
text: made, they will infallibly rebel against the yoke. No such person will

author: John Stuart Mill
text: ever feel that others have a right to control him in his concerns, such

author: John Stuart Mill
text: as they have to prevent him from injuring them in theirs; and it easily

author: John Stuart Mill
text: comes to be considered a mark of spirit and courage to fly in the face

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of such usurped authority, and do with ostentation the exact opposite of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: what it enjoins; as in the fashion of grossness which succeeded, in the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: time of Charles II., to the fanatical moral intolerance of the Puritans.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: With respect to what is said of the necessity of protecting society

author: John Stuart Mill
text: from the bad example set to others by the vicious or the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: self-indulgent; it is true that bad example may have a pernicious

author: John Stuart Mill
text: effect, especially the example of doing wrong to others with impunity to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the wrong-doer. But we are now speaking of conduct which, while it does

author: John Stuart Mill
text: no wrong to others, is supposed to do great harm to the agent himself:

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and I do not see how those who believe this, can think otherwise than

author: John Stuart Mill
text: that the example, on the whole, must be more salutary than hurtful,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: since, if it displays the misconduct, it displays also the painful or

author: John Stuart Mill
text: degrading consequences which, if the conduct is justly censured, must be

author: John Stuart Mill
text: supposed to be in all or most cases attendant on it.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: But the strongest of all the arguments against the interference of the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: public with purely personal conduct, is that when it does interfere, the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: odds are that it interferes wrongly, and in the wrong place. On

author: John Stuart Mill
text: questions of social morality, of duty to others, the opinion of the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: public, that is, of an overruling majority, though often wrong, is

author: John Stuart Mill
text: likely to be still oftener right; because on such questions they are

author: John Stuart Mill
text: only required to judge of their own interests; of the manner in which

author: John Stuart Mill
text: some mode of conduct, if allowed to be practised, would affect

author: John Stuart Mill
text: themselves. But the opinion of a similar majority, imposed as a law on

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the minority, on questions of self-regarding conduct, is quite as

author: John Stuart Mill
text: likely to be wrong as right; for in these cases public opinion means, at

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the best, some people's opinion of what is good or bad for other people;

author: John Stuart Mill
text: while very often it does not even mean that; the public, with the most

author: John Stuart Mill
text: perfect indifference, passing over the pleasure or convenience of those

author: John Stuart Mill
text: whose conduct they censure, and considering only their own preference.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: There are many who consider as an injury to themselves any conduct which

author: John Stuart Mill
text: they have a distaste for, and resent it as an outrage to their feelings;

author: John Stuart Mill
text: as a religious bigot, when charged with disregarding the religious

author: John Stuart Mill
text: feelings of others, has been known to retort that they disregard his

author: John Stuart Mill
text: feelings, by persisting in their abominable worship or creed. But there

author: John Stuart Mill
text: is no parity between the feeling of a person for his own opinion, and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the feeling of another who is offended at his holding it; no more than

author: John Stuart Mill
text: between the desire of a thief to take a purse, and the desire of the

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: concern as his opinion or his purse. It is easy for any one to imagine

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: all uncertain matters undisturbed, and only requires them to abstain

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: where has there been seen a public which set any such limit to its

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: thinking of anything but the enormity of acting or feeling differently

author: John Stuart Mill
text: from itself; and this standard of judgment, thinly disguised, is held up

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to mankind as the dictate of religion and philosophy, by nine-tenths of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: all moralists and speculative writers. These teach that things are right

author: John Stuart Mill
text: because they are right; because we feel them to be so. They tell us to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: search in our own minds and hearts for laws of conduct binding on

author: John Stuart Mill
text: ourselves and on all others. What can the poor public do but apply these

author: John Stuart Mill
text: instructions, and make their own personal feelings of good and evil, if

author: John Stuart Mill
text: they are tolerably unanimous in them, obligatory on all the world?

author: John Stuart Mill
text: The evil here pointed out is not one which exists only in theory; and it

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: public of this age and country improperly invests its own preferences

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: are necessary, to show that the principle I maintain is of serious and

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: against imaginary evils. And it is not difficult to show, by abundant

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: until it encroaches on the most unquestionably legitimate liberty of the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: individual, is one of the most universal of all human propensities.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: As a first instance, consider the antipathies which men cherish on no

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: [14] The case of the Bombay Parsees is a curious instance in point. When

author: John Stuart Mill
text: this industrious and enterprising tribe, the descendants of the Persian

author: John Stuart Mill
text: fire-worshippers, flying from their native country before the Caliphs,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: arrived in Western India, they were admitted to toleration by the Hindoo

author: John Stuart Mill
text: sovereigns, on condition of not eating beef. When those regions

author: John Stuart Mill
text: afterwards fell under the dominion of Mahomedan conquerors, the Parsees

author: John Stuart Mill
text: obtained from them a continuance of indulgence, on condition of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: refraining from pork. What was at first obedience to authority became a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: second nature, and the Parsees to this day abstain both from beef and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: pork. Though not required by their religion, the double abstinence has

author: John Stuart Mill
text: had time to grow into a custom of their tribe; and custom, in the East,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: is a religion.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: CHAPTER V.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: APPLICATIONS.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: The principles asserted in these pages must be more generally admitted

author: John Stuart Mill
text: as the basis for discussion of details, before a consistent application

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of them to all the various departments of government and morals can be

author: John Stuart Mill
text: attempted with any prospect of advantage. The few observations I propose

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to make on questions of detail, are designed to illustrate the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: principles, rather than to follow them out to their consequences. I

author: John Stuart Mill
text: offer, not so much applications, as specimens of application; which may

author: John Stuart Mill
text: serve to bring into greater clearness the meaning and limits of the two

author: John Stuart Mill
text: maxims which together form the entire doctrine of this Essay, and to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: assist the judgment in holding the balance between them, in the cases

author: John Stuart Mill
text: where it appears doubtful which of them is applicable to the case.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: The maxims are, first, that the individual is not accountable to society

author: John Stuart Mill
text: for his actions, in so far as these concern the interests of no person

author: John Stuart Mill
text: but himself. Advice, instruction, persuasion, and avoidance by other

author: John Stuart Mill
text: people if thought necessary by them for their own good, are the only

author: John Stuart Mill
text: measures by which society can justifiably express its dislike or

author: John Stuart Mill
text: disapprobation of his conduct. Secondly, that for such actions as are

author: John Stuart Mill
text: prejudicial to the interests of others, the individual is accountable

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and may be subjected either to social or to legal punishments, if

author: John Stuart Mill
text: society is of opinion that the one or the other is requisite for its

author: John Stuart Mill
text: protection.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: In the first place, it must by no means be supposed, because damage, or

author: John Stuart Mill
text: probability of damage, to the interests of others, can alone justify the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: interference of society, that therefore it always does justify such

author: John Stuart Mill
text: interference. In many cases, an individual, in pursuing a legitimate

author: John Stuart Mill
text: object, necessarily and therefore legitimately causes pain or loss to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: others, or intercepts a good which they had a reasonable hope of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: obtaining. Such oppositions of interest between individuals often arise

author: John Stuart Mill
text: from bad social institutions, but are unavoidable while those

author: John Stuart Mill
text: institutions last; and some would be unavoidable under any institutions.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Whoever succeeds in an overcrowded profession, or in a competitive

author: John Stuart Mill
text: examination; whoever is preferred to another in any contest for an

author: John Stuart Mill
text: object which both desire, reaps benefit from the loss of others, from

author: John Stuart Mill
text: their wasted exertion and their disappointment. But it is, by common

author: John Stuart Mill
text: admission, better for the general interest of mankind, that persons

author: John Stuart Mill
text: should pursue their objects undeterred by this sort of consequences. In

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: feels called on to interfere, only when means of success have been

author: John Stuart Mill
text: employed which it is contrary to the general interest to permit--namely,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: fraud or treachery, and force.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Again, trade is a social act. Whoever undertakes to sell any description

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of goods to the public, does what affects the interest of other persons,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and of society in general; and thus his conduct, in principle, comes

author: John Stuart Mill
text: within the jurisdiction of society: accordingly, it was once held to be

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the duty of governments, in all cases which were considered of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: importance, to fix prices, and regulate the processes of manufacture.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: But it is now recognised, though not till after a long struggle, that

author: John Stuart Mill
text: both the cheapness and the good quality of commodities are most

author: John Stuart Mill
text: effectually provided for by leaving the producers and sellers perfectly

author: John Stuart Mill
text: free, under the sole check of equal freedom to the buyers for supplying

author: John Stuart Mill
text: themselves elsewhere. This is the so-called doctrine of Free Trade,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: which rests on grounds different from, though equally solid with, the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: principle of individual liberty asserted in this Essay. Restrictions on

author: John Stuart Mill
text: trade, or on production for purposes of trade, are indeed restraints;

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and all restraint, _qua_ restraint, is an evil: but the restraints in

author: John Stuart Mill
text: question affect only that part of conduct which society is competent to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: restrain, and are wrong solely because they do not really produce the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: results which it is desired to produce by them. As the principle of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: individual liberty is not involved in the doctrine of Free Trade, so

author: John Stuart Mill
text: neither is it in most of the questions which arise respecting the limits

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of that doctrine: as for example, what amount of public control is

author: John Stuart Mill
text: admissible for the prevention of fraud by adulteration; how far sanitary

author: John Stuart Mill
text: precautions, or arrangements to protect work-people employed in

author: John Stuart Mill
text: dangerous occupations, should be enforced on employers. Such questions

author: John Stuart Mill
text: involve considerations of liberty, only in so far as leaving people to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: themselves is always better, _caeteris paribus_, than controlling them:

author: John Stuart Mill
text: but that they may be legitimately controlled for these ends, is in

author: John Stuart Mill
text: principle undeniable. On the other hand, there are questions relating to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: interference with trade, which are essentially questions of liberty;

author: John Stuart Mill
text: such as the Maine Law, already touched upon; the prohibition of the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: importation of opium into China; the restriction of the sale of poisons;

author: John Stuart Mill
text: all cases, in short, where the object of the interference is to make it

author: John Stuart Mill
text: impossible or difficult to obtain a particular commodity. These

author: John Stuart Mill
text: interferences are objectionable, not as infringements on the liberty of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the producer or seller, but on that of the buyer.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: One of these examples, that of the sale of poisons, opens a new

author: John Stuart Mill
text: question; the proper limits of what may be called the functions of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: police; how far liberty may legitimately be invaded for the prevention

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of crime, or of accident. It is one of the undisputed functions of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: government to take precautions against crime before it has been

author: John Stuart Mill
text: committed, as well as to detect and punish it afterwards. The preventive

author: John Stuart Mill
text: function of government, however, is far more liable to be abused, to the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: prejudice of liberty, than the punitory function; for there is hardly

author: John Stuart Mill
text: any part of the legitimate freedom of action of a human being which

author: John Stuart Mill
text: would not admit of being represented, and fairly too, as increasing the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: facilities for some form or other of delinquency. Nevertheless, if a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: public authority, or even a private person, sees any one evidently

author: John Stuart Mill
text: preparing to commit a crime, they are not bound to look on inactive

author: John Stuart Mill
text: until the crime is committed, but may interfere to prevent it. If

author: John Stuart Mill
text: poisons were never bought or used for any purpose except the commission

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of murder, it would be right to prohibit their manufacture and sale.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: They may, however, be wanted not only for innocent but for useful

author: John Stuart Mill
text: purposes, and restrictions cannot be imposed in the one case without

author: John Stuart Mill
text: operating in the other. Again, it is a proper office of public authority

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to guard against accidents. If either a public officer or any one else

author: John Stuart Mill
text: saw a person attempting to cross a bridge which had been ascertained to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: be unsafe, and there were no time to warn him of his danger, they might

author: John Stuart Mill
text: seize him and turn him back, without any real infringement of his

author: John Stuart Mill
text: liberty; for liberty consists in doing what one desires, and he does not

author: John Stuart Mill
text: desire to fall into the river. Nevertheless, when there is not a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: certainty, but only a danger of mischief, no one but the person himself

author: John Stuart Mill
text: can judge of the sufficiency of the motive which may prompt him to incur

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the risk: in this case, therefore (unless he is a child, or delirious,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: or in some state of excitement or absorption incompatible with the full

author: John Stuart Mill
text: use of the reflecting faculty), he ought, I conceive, to be only warned

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of the danger; not forcibly prevented from exposing himself to it.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Similar considerations, applied to such a question as the sale of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: poisons, may enable us to decide which among the possible modes of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: regulation are or are not contrary to principle. Such a precaution, for

author: John Stuart Mill
text: example, as that of labelling the drug with some word expressive of its

author: John Stuart Mill
text: dangerous character, may be enforced without violation of liberty: the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: buyer cannot wish not to know that the thing he possesses has poisonous

author: John Stuart Mill
text: qualities. But to require in all cases the certificate of a medical

author: John Stuart Mill
text: practitioner, would make it sometimes impossible, always expensive, to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: obtain the article for legitimate uses. The only mode apparent to me, in

author: John Stuart Mill
text: which difficulties may be thrown in the way of crime committed through

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: purposes, consists in providing what, in the apt language of Bentham, is

author: John Stuart Mill
text: called "preappointed evidence." This provision is familiar to every one

author: John Stuart Mill
text: in the case of contracts. It is usual and right that the law, when a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: contract is entered into, should require as the condition of its

author: John Stuart Mill
text: enforcing performance, that certain formalities should be observed, such

author: John Stuart Mill
text: as signatures, attestation of witnesses, and the like, in order that in

author: John Stuart Mill
text: case of subsequent dispute, there may be evidence to prove that the

author: John Stuart Mill

text: circumstances to render it legally invalid: the effect being, to throw

author: John Stuart Mill

text: circumstances which, if known, would destroy their validity. Precautions

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of a similar nature might be enforced in the sale of articles adapted to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: be instruments of crime. The seller, for example, might be required to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: enter into a register the exact time of the transaction, the name and

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: purpose for which it was wanted, and record the answer he received. When

author: John Stuart Mill
text: there was no medical prescription, the presence of some third person

author: John Stuart Mill
