author: John Stuart Mill
text: there should afterwards be reason to believe that the article had been

author: John Stuart Mill
text: applied to criminal purposes. Such regulations would in general be no

author: John Stuart Mill
text: material impediment to obtaining the article, but a very considerable

author: John Stuart Mill
text: one to making an improper use of it without detection.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: The right inherent in society, to ward off crimes against itself by

author: John Stuart Mill
text: antecedent precautions, suggests the obvious limitations to the maxim,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: that purely self-regarding misconduct cannot properly be meddled with

author: John Stuart Mill
text: in the way of prevention or punishment. Drunkenness, for example, in

author: John Stuart Mill
text: ordinary cases, is not a fit subject for legislative interference; but I

author: John Stuart Mill
text: should deem it perfectly legitimate that a person, who had once been

author: John Stuart Mill
text: convicted of any act of violence to others under the influence of drink,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: should be placed under a special legal restriction, personal to himself;

author: John Stuart Mill
text: that if he were afterwards found drunk, he should be liable to a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: penalty, and that if when in that state he committed another offence,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the punishment to which he would be liable for that other offence should

author: John Stuart Mill
text: be increased in severity. The making himself drunk, in a person whom

author: John Stuart Mill
text: drunkenness excites to do harm to others, is a crime against others. So,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: again, idleness, except in a person receiving support from the public,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: or except when it constitutes a breach of contract, cannot without

author: John Stuart Mill
text: tyranny be made a subject of legal punishment; but if either from

author: John Stuart Mill
text: idleness or from any other avoidable cause, a man fails to perform his

author: John Stuart Mill
text: legal duties to others, as for instance to support his children, it is

author: John Stuart Mill
text: no tyranny to force him to fulfil that obligation, by compulsory labour,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: if no other means are available.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Again, there are many acts which, being directly injurious only to the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: agents themselves, ought not to be legally interdicted, but which, if

author: John Stuart Mill
text: done publicly, are a violation of good manners and coming thus within

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the category of offences against others may rightfully be prohibited. Of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: this kind are offences against decency; on which it is unnecessary to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: dwell, the rather as they are only connected indirectly with our

author: John Stuart Mill
text: subject, the objection to publicity being equally strong in the case of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: many actions not in themselves condemnable, nor supposed to be so.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: There is another question to which an answer must be found, consistent

author: John Stuart Mill
text: with the principles which have been laid down. In cases of personal

author: John Stuart Mill
text: conduct supposed to be blamable, but which respect for liberty precludes

author: John Stuart Mill
text: society from preventing or punishing, because the evil directly

author: John Stuart Mill
text: resulting falls wholly on the agent; what the agent is free to do, ought

author: John Stuart Mill
text: other persons to be equally free to counsel or instigate? This question

author: John Stuart Mill
text: is not free from difficulty. The case of a person who solicits another

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to do an act, is not strictly a case of self-regarding conduct. To give

author: John Stuart Mill
text: advice or offer inducements to any one, is a social act, and may

author: John Stuart Mill
text: therefore, like actions in general which affect others, be supposed

author: John Stuart Mill
text: amenable to social control. But a little reflection corrects the first

author: John Stuart Mill
text: impression, by showing that if the case is not strictly within the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: definition of individual liberty, yet the reasons on which the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: principle of individual liberty is grounded, are applicable to it. If

author: John Stuart Mill
text: people must be allowed, in whatever concerns only themselves, to act as

author: John Stuart Mill
text: seems best to themselves at their own peril, they must equally be free

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to consult with one another about what is fit to be so done; to exchange

author: John Stuart Mill
text: opinions, and give and receive suggestions. Whatever it is permitted to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: do, it must be permitted to advise to do. The question is doubtful, only

author: John Stuart Mill
text: when the instigator derives a personal benefit from his advice; when he

author: John Stuart Mill
text: makes it his occupation, for subsistence or pecuniary gain, to promote

author: John Stuart Mill
text: what society and the state consider to be an evil. Then, indeed, a new

author: John Stuart Mill
text: element of complication is introduced; namely, the existence of classes

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of persons with an interest opposed to what is considered as the public

author: John Stuart Mill
text: weal, and whose mode of living is grounded on the counteraction of it.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Ought this to be interfered with, or not? Fornication, for example, must

author: John Stuart Mill
text: be tolerated, and so must gambling; but should a person be free to be a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: pimp, or to keep a gambling-house? The case is one of those which lie on

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the exact boundary line between two principles, and it is not at once

author: John Stuart Mill
text: apparent to which of the two it properly belongs. There are arguments on

author: John Stuart Mill
text: both sides. On the side of toleration it may be said, that the fact of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: following anything as an occupation, and living or profiting by the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: practice of it, cannot make that criminal which would otherwise be

author: John Stuart Mill
text: admissible; that the act should either be consistently permitted or

author: John Stuart Mill
text: consistently prohibited; that if the principles which we have hitherto

author: John Stuart Mill
text: defended are true, society has no business, _as_ society, to decide

author: John Stuart Mill
text: anything to be wrong which concerns only the individual; that it cannot

author: John Stuart Mill
text: go beyond dissuasion, and that one person should be as free to persuade,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: as another to dissuade. In opposition to this it may be contended, that

author: John Stuart Mill
text: although the public, or the State, are not warranted in authoritatively

author: John Stuart Mill
text: deciding, for purposes of repression or punishment, that such or such

author: John Stuart Mill
text: conduct affecting only the interests of the individual is good or bad,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: they are fully justified in assuming, if they regard it as bad, that its

author: John Stuart Mill
text: being so or not is at least a disputable question: That, this being

author: John Stuart Mill
text: supposed, they cannot be acting wrongly in endeavouring to exclude the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: influence of solicitations which are not disinterested, of instigators

author: John Stuart Mill
text: who cannot possibly be impartial--who have a direct personal interest on

author: John Stuart Mill
text: one side, and that side the one which the State believes to be wrong,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and who confessedly promote it for personal objects only. There can

author: John Stuart Mill
text: surely, it may be urged, be nothing lost, no sacrifice of good, by so

author: John Stuart Mill
text: ordering matters that persons shall make their election, either wisely

author: John Stuart Mill
text: or foolishly, on their own prompting, as free as possible from the arts

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of persons who stimulate their inclinations for interested purposes of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: their own. Thus (it may be said) though the statutes respecting unlawful

author: John Stuart Mill
text: games are utterly indefensible--though all persons should be free to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: gamble in their own or each other's houses, or in any place of meeting

author: John Stuart Mill
text: established by their own subscriptions, and open only to the members and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: their visitors--yet public gambling-houses should not be permitted. It

author: John Stuart Mill
text: is true that the prohibition is never effectual, and that whatever

author: John Stuart Mill
text: amount of tyrannical power is given to the police, gambling-houses can

author: John Stuart Mill
text: always be maintained under other pretences; but they may be compelled to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: conduct their operations with a certain degree of secrecy and mystery,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: so that nobody knows anything about them but those who seek them; and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: more than this, society ought not to aim at. There is considerable force

author: John Stuart Mill
text: in these arguments; I will not venture to decide whether they are

author: John Stuart Mill
text: sufficient to justify the moral anomaly of punishing the accessary, when

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the principal is (and must be) allowed to go free; or fining or

author: John Stuart Mill
text: imprisoning the procurer, but not the fornicator, the gambling-house

author: John Stuart Mill
text: keeper, but not the gambler. Still less ought the common operations of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: buying and selling to be interfered with on analogous grounds. Almost

author: John Stuart Mill
text: every article which is bought and sold may be used in excess, and the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: sellers have a pecuniary interest in encouraging that excess; but no

author: John Stuart Mill
text: argument can be founded on this, in favour, for instance, of the Maine

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Law; because the class of dealers in strong drinks, though interested in

author: John Stuart Mill
text: their abuse, are indispensably required for the sake of their legitimate

author: John Stuart Mill
text: use. The interest, however, of these dealers in promoting intemperance

author: John Stuart Mill
text: is a real evil, and justifies the State in imposing restrictions and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: requiring guarantees, which but for that justification would be

author: John Stuart Mill
text: infringements of legitimate liberty.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: A further question is, whether the State, while it permits, should

author: John Stuart Mill
text: nevertheless indirectly discourage conduct which it deems contrary to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the best interests of the agent; whether, for example, it should take

author: John Stuart Mill
text: measures to render the means of drunkenness more costly, or add to the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: difficulty of procuring them, by limiting the number of the places of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: sale. On this as on most other practical questions, many distinctions

author: John Stuart Mill
text: require to be made. To tax stimulants for the sole purpose of making

author: John Stuart Mill
text: them more difficult to be obtained, is a measure differing only in

author: John Stuart Mill
text: degree from their entire prohibition; and would be justifiable only if

author: John Stuart Mill
text: that were justifiable. Every increase of cost is a prohibition, to those

author: John Stuart Mill
text: whose means do not come up to the augmented price; and to those who do,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: it is a penalty laid on them for gratifying a particular taste. Their

author: John Stuart Mill
text: choice of pleasures, and their mode of expending their income, after

author: John Stuart Mill
text: satisfying their legal and moral obligations to the State and to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: individuals, are their own concern, and must rest with their own

author: John Stuart Mill
text: judgment. These considerations may seem at first sight to condemn the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: selection of stimulants as special subjects of taxation for purposes of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: revenue. But it must be remembered that taxation for fiscal purposes is

author: John Stuart Mill
text: absolutely inevitable; that in most countries it is necessary that a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: considerable part of that taxation should be indirect; that the State,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: therefore, cannot help imposing penalties, which to some persons may be

author: John Stuart Mill
text: prohibitory, on the use of some articles of consumption. It is hence the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: duty of the State to consider, in the imposition of taxes, what

author: John Stuart Mill
text: commodities the consumers can best spare; and _a fortiori_, to select in

author: John Stuart Mill
text: preference those of which it deems the use, beyond a very moderate

author: John Stuart Mill
text: quantity, to be positively injurious. Taxation, therefore, of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: stimulants, up to the point which produces the largest amount of revenue

author: John Stuart Mill
text: (supposing that the State needs all the revenue which it yields) is not

author: John Stuart Mill
text: only admissible, but to be approved of.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: The question of making the sale of these commodities a more or less

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: are some by whom the facility would be abused, but is suited only to a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: state of society in which the labouring classes are avowedly treated as

author: John Stuart Mill
text: children or savages, and placed under an education of restraint, to fit

author: John Stuart Mill
text: them for future admission to the privileges of freedom. This is not the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: principle on which the labouring classes are professedly governed in any

author: John Stuart Mill
text: free country; and no person who sets due value on freedom will give his

author: John Stuart Mill
text: adhesion to their being so governed, unless after all efforts have been

author: John Stuart Mill
text: exhausted to educate them for freedom and govern them as freemen, and it

author: John Stuart Mill
text: has been definitively proved that they can only be governed as children.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: The bare statement of the alternative shows the absurdity of supposing

author: John Stuart Mill
text: that such efforts have been made in any case which needs be considered

author: John Stuart Mill
text: here. It is only because the institutions of this country are a mass of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: inconsistencies, that things find admittance into our practice which

author: John Stuart Mill
text: belong to the system of despotic, or what is called paternal,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: government, while the general freedom of our institutions precludes the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: exercise of the amount of control necessary to render the restraint of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: any real efficacy as a moral education.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: It was pointed out in an early part of this Essay, that the liberty of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the individual, in things wherein the individual is alone concerned,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: implies a corresponding liberty in any number of individuals to regulate

author: John Stuart Mill
text: by mutual agreement such things as regard them jointly, and regard no

author: John Stuart Mill
text: persons but themselves. This question presents no difficulty, so long as

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the will of all the persons implicated remains unaltered; but since that

author: John Stuart Mill
text: will may change, it is often necessary, even in things in which they

author: John Stuart Mill
text: alone are concerned, that they should enter into engagements with one

author: John Stuart Mill
text: another; and when they do, it is fit, as a general rule, that those

author: John Stuart Mill
text: engagements should be kept. Yet in the laws, probably, of every country,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: this general rule has some exceptions. Not only persons are not held to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: engagements which violate the rights of third parties, but it is

author: John Stuart Mill
text: sometimes considered a sufficient reason for releasing them from an

author: John Stuart Mill
text: engagement, that it is injurious to themselves. In this and most other

author: John Stuart Mill
text: civilised countries, for example, an engagement by which a person should

author: John Stuart Mill
text: sell himself, or allow himself to be sold, as a slave, would be null and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: void; neither enforced by law nor by opinion. The ground for thus

author: John Stuart Mill
text: limiting his power of voluntarily disposing of his own lot in life, is

author: John Stuart Mill
text: apparent, and is very clearly seen in this extreme case. The reason for

author: John Stuart Mill
text: not interfering, unless for the sake of others, with a person's

author: John Stuart Mill
text: voluntary acts, is consideration for his liberty. His voluntary choice

author: John Stuart Mill
text: is evidence that what he so chooses is desirable, or at the least

author: John Stuart Mill
text: endurable, to him, and his good is on the whole best provided for by

author: John Stuart Mill
text: allowing him to take his own means of pursuing it. But by selling

author: John Stuart Mill
text: himself for a slave, he abdicates his liberty; he foregoes any future

author: John Stuart Mill
text: use of it, beyond that single act. He therefore defeats, in his own

author: John Stuart Mill
text: case, the very purpose which is the justification of allowing him to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: dispose of himself. He is no longer free; but is thenceforth in a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: position which has no longer the presumption in its favour, that would

author: John Stuart Mill
text: be afforded by his voluntarily remaining in it. The principle of freedom

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to be allowed to alienate his freedom. These reasons, the force of which

author: John Stuart Mill
text: is so conspicuous in this peculiar case, are evidently of far wider

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: freedom, but that we should consent to this and the other limitation of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: it. The principle, however, which demands uncontrolled freedom of action

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: have become bound to one another, in things which concern no third

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of retractation. Baron Wilhelm von Humboldt, in the excellent essay from

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill

author: John Stuart Mill
text: its objects are frustrated unless the feelings of both the parties are

author: John Stuart Mill
text: in harmony with it, should require nothing more than the declared will

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of either party to dissolve it. This subject is too important, and too

author: John Stuart Mill
text: complicated, to be discussed in a parenthesis, and I touch on it only so

author: John Stuart Mill
text: far as is necessary for purposes of illustration. If the conciseness and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: generality of Baron Humboldt's dissertation had not obliged him in this

author: John Stuart Mill
text: instance to content himself with enunciating his conclusion without

author: John Stuart Mill
text: discussing the premises, he would doubtless have recognised that the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: question cannot be decided on grounds so simple as those to which he

author: John Stuart Mill
text: confines himself. When a person, either by express promise or by

author: John Stuart Mill
text: conduct, has encouraged another to rely upon his continuing to act in a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: certain way--to build expectations and calculations, and stake any part

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of his plan of life upon that supposition, a new series of moral

author: John Stuart Mill
text: obligations arises on his part towards that person, which may possibly

author: John Stuart Mill
text: be overruled, but cannot be ignored. And again, if the relation between

author: John Stuart Mill
text: two contracting parties has been followed by consequences to others; if

author: John Stuart Mill
text: it has placed third parties in any peculiar position, or, as in the case

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of marriage, has even called third parties into existence, obligations

author: John Stuart Mill
text: arise on the part of both the contracting parties towards those third

author: John Stuart Mill
text: persons, the fulfilment of which, or at all events the mode of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: fulfilment, must be greatly affected by the continuance or disruption of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the relation between the original parties to the contract. It does not

author: John Stuart Mill
text: follow, nor can I admit, that these obligations extend to requiring the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: fulfilment of the contract at all costs to the happiness of the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: reluctant party; but they are a necessary element in the question; and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: even if, as Von Humboldt maintains, they ought to make no difference in

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the _legal_ freedom of the parties to release themselves from the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: engagement (and I also hold that they ought not to make _much_

author: John Stuart Mill
text: difference), they necessarily make a great difference in the _moral_

author: John Stuart Mill
text: freedom. A person is bound to take all these circumstances into account,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: before resolving on a step which may affect such important interests of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: others; and if he does not allow proper weight to those interests, he is

author: John Stuart Mill
text: morally responsible for the wrong. I have made these obvious remarks for

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the better illustration of the general principle of liberty, and not

author: John Stuart Mill
text: because they are at all needed on the particular question, which, on the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: contrary, is usually discussed as if the interest of children was

author: John Stuart Mill
text: everything, and that of grown persons nothing.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: I have already observed that, owing to the absence of any recognised

author: John Stuart Mill
text: general principles, liberty is often granted where it should be

author: John Stuart Mill
text: withheld, as well as withheld where it should be granted; and one of the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: cases in which, in the modern European world, the sentiment of liberty

author: John Stuart Mill
text: is the strongest, is a case where, in my view, it is altogether

author: John Stuart Mill
text: misplaced. A person should be free to do as he likes in his own

author: John Stuart Mill
text: concerns; but he ought not to be free to do as he likes in acting for

author: John Stuart Mill
text: another, under the pretext that the affairs of another are his own

author: John Stuart Mill
text: affairs. The State, while it respects the liberty of each in what

author: John Stuart Mill
text: specially regards himself, is bound to maintain a vigilant control over

author: John Stuart Mill
text: his exercise of any power which it allows him to possess over others.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: This obligation is almost entirely disregarded in the case of the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: family relations, a case, in its direct influence on human happiness,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: more important than all others taken together. The almost despotic power

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of husbands over wives need not be enlarged upon here because nothing

author: John Stuart Mill
text: more is needed for the complete removal of the evil, than that wives

author: John Stuart Mill
text: should have the same rights, and should receive the protection of law in

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the same manner, as all other persons; and because, on this subject, the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: defenders of established injustice do not avail themselves of the plea

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of liberty, but stand forth openly as the champions of power. It is in

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the case of children, that misapplied notions of liberty are a real

author: John Stuart Mill
text: obstacle to the fulfilment by the State of its duties. One would almost

author: John Stuart Mill
text: think that a man's children were supposed to be literally, and not

author: John Stuart Mill
text: metaphorically, a part of himself, so jealous is opinion of the smallest

author: John Stuart Mill
text: interference of law with his absolute and exclusive control over them;

author: John Stuart Mill
text: more jealous than of almost any interference with his own freedom of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: action: so much less do the generality of mankind value liberty than

author: John Stuart Mill
text: power. Consider, for example, the case of education. Is it not almost a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: self-evident axiom, that the State should require and compel the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: education, up to a certain standard, of every human being who is born

author: John Stuart Mill
text: its citizen? Yet who is there that is not afraid to recognise and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: assert this truth? Hardly any one indeed will deny that it is one of the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: most sacred duties of the parents (or, as law and usage now stand, the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: father), after summoning a human being into the world, to give to that

author: John Stuart Mill
text: being an education fitting him to perform his part well in life towards

author: John Stuart Mill
text: others and towards himself. But while this is unanimously declared to be

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the father's duty, scarcely anybody, in this country, will bear to hear

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of obliging him to perform it. Instead of his being required to make any

author: John Stuart Mill
text: exertion or sacrifice for securing education to the child, it is left to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: his choice to accept it or not when it is provided gratis! It still

author: John Stuart Mill
text: remains unrecognised, that to bring a child into existence without a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: fair prospect of being able, not only to provide food for its body, but

author: John Stuart Mill
text: instruction and training for its mind, is a moral crime, both against

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the unfortunate offspring and against society; and that if the parent

author: John Stuart Mill
text: does not fulfil this obligation, the State ought to see it fulfilled, at

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the charge, as far as possible, of the parent.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Were the duty of enforcing universal education once admitted, there

author: John Stuart Mill
text: would be an end to the difficulties about what the State should teach,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and how it should teach, which now convert the subject into a mere

author: John Stuart Mill
text: battle-field for sects and parties, causing the time and labour which

author: John Stuart Mill
text: should have been spent in educating, to be wasted in quarrelling about

author: John Stuart Mill
text: education. If the government would make up its mind to _require_ for

author: John Stuart Mill
text: every child a good education, it might save itself the trouble of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: _providing_ one. It might leave to parents to obtain the education where

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and how they pleased, and content itself with helping to pay the school

author: John Stuart Mill
text: fees of the poorer class of children, and defraying the entire school

author: John Stuart Mill
text: expenses of those who have no one else to pay for them. The objections

author: John Stuart Mill
text: which are urged with reason against State education, do not apply to the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: enforcement of education by the State, but to the State's taking upon

author: John Stuart Mill
text: itself to direct that education; which is a totally different thing.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: That the whole or any large part of the education of the people should

author: John Stuart Mill
text: be in State hands, I go as far as any one in deprecating. All that has

author: John Stuart Mill
text: been said of the importance of individuality of character, and diversity

author: John Stuart Mill
text: in opinions and modes of conduct, involves, as of the same unspeakable

author: John Stuart Mill
text: importance, diversity of education. A general State education is a mere

author: John Stuart Mill
text: contrivance for moulding people to be exactly like one another; and as

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the mould in which it casts them is that which pleases the predominant

author: John Stuart Mill
text: power in the government, whether this be a monarch, a priesthood, an

author: John Stuart Mill
text: aristocracy, or the majority of the existing generation, in proportion

author: John Stuart Mill
text: as it is efficient and successful, it establishes a despotism over the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: mind, leading by natural tendency to one over the body. An education

author: John Stuart Mill
text: established and controlled by the State, should only exist, if it exist

author: John Stuart Mill
text: at all, as one among many competing experiments, carried on for the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: purpose of example and stimulus, to keep the others up to a certain

author: John Stuart Mill
text: standard of excellence. Unless, indeed, when society in general is in so

author: John Stuart Mill
text: backward a state that it could not or would not provide for itself any

author: John Stuart Mill
text: proper institutions of education, unless the government undertook the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: task; then, indeed, the government may, as the less of two great evils,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: take upon itself the business of schools and universities, as it may

author: John Stuart Mill
text: that of joint stock companies, when private enterprise, in a shape

author: John Stuart Mill
text: fitted for undertaking great works of industry, does not exist in the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: country. But in general, if the country contains a sufficient number of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: persons qualified to provide education under government auspices, the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: same persons would be able and willing to give an equally good education

author: John Stuart Mill
text: on the voluntary principle, under the assurance of remuneration afforded

author: John Stuart Mill
text: by a law rendering education compulsory, combined with State aid to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: those unable to defray the expense.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: The instrument for enforcing the law could be no other than public

author: John Stuart Mill
text: examinations, extending to all children, and beginning at an early age.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: An age might be fixed at which every child must be examined, to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: ascertain if he (or she) is able to read. If a child proves unable, the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: father, unless he has some sufficient ground of excuse, might be

author: John Stuart Mill
text: subjected to a moderate fine, to be worked out, if necessary, by his

author: John Stuart Mill
text: labour, and the child might be put to school at his expense. Once in

author: John Stuart Mill
text: every year the examination should be renewed, with a gradually extending

author: John Stuart Mill
text: range of subjects, so as to make the universal acquisition, and what is

author: John Stuart Mill
text: more, retention, of a certain minimum of general knowledge, virtually

author: John Stuart Mill
text: compulsory. Beyond that minimum, there should be voluntary examinations

author: John Stuart Mill
text: on all subjects, at which all who come up to a certain standard of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: proficiency might claim a certificate. To prevent the State from

author: John Stuart Mill
text: exercising, through these arrangements, an improper influence over

author: John Stuart Mill
text: opinion, the knowledge required for passing an examination (beyond the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: merely instrumental parts of knowledge, such as languages and their use)

author: John Stuart Mill
text: should, even in the higher class of examinations, be confined to facts

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and positive science exclusively. The examinations on religion,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: politics, or other disputed topics, should not turn on the truth or

author: John Stuart Mill
text: falsehood of opinions, but on the matter of fact that such and such an

author: John Stuart Mill
text: opinion is held, on such grounds, by such authors, or schools, or

author: John Stuart Mill
text: churches. Under this system, the rising generation would be no worse off

author: John Stuart Mill
text: in regard to all disputed truths, than they are at present; they would

author: John Stuart Mill
text: be brought up either churchmen or dissenters as they now are, the state

author: John Stuart Mill
text: merely taking care that they should be instructed churchmen, or

author: John Stuart Mill
text: instructed dissenters. There would be nothing to hinder them from being

author: John Stuart Mill
text: taught religion, if their parents chose, at the same schools where they

author: John Stuart Mill
text: were taught other things. All attempts by the state to bias the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: conclusions of its citizens on disputed subjects, are evil; but it may

author: John Stuart Mill
text: very properly offer to ascertain and certify that a person possesses the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: knowledge, requisite to make his conclusions, on any given subject,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: worth attending to. A student of philosophy would be the better for

author: John Stuart Mill
text: being able to stand an examination both in Locke and in Kant, whichever

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of the two he takes up with, or even if with neither: and there is no

author: John Stuart Mill
text: reasonable objection to examining an atheist in the evidences of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Christianity, provided he is not required to profess a belief in them.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: The examinations, however, in the higher branches of knowledge should, I

author: John Stuart Mill
text: conceive, be entirely voluntary. It would be giving too dangerous a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: power to governments, were they allowed to exclude any one from

author: John Stuart Mill
text: professions, even from the profession of teacher, for alleged deficiency

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of qualifications: and I think, with Wilhelm von Humboldt, that degrees,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: or other public certificates of scientific or professional acquirements,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: should be given to all who present themselves for examination, and stand

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the test; but that such certificates should confer no advantage over

author: John Stuart Mill
text: competitors, other than the weight which may be attached to their

author: John Stuart Mill
text: testimony by public opinion.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: It is not in the matter of education only, that misplaced notions of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: liberty prevent moral obligations on the part of parents from being

author: John Stuart Mill
text: recognised, and legal obligations from being imposed, where there are

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the strongest grounds for the former always, and in many cases for the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: latter also. The fact itself, of causing the existence of a human being,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: is one of the most responsible actions in the range of human life. To

author: John Stuart Mill
text: undertake this responsibility--to bestow a life which may be either a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: curse or a blessing--unless the being on whom it is to be bestowed will

author: John Stuart Mill
text: have at least the ordinary chances of a desirable existence, is a crime

author: John Stuart Mill
text: against that being. And in a country either over-peopled, or threatened

author: John Stuart Mill
text: with being so, to produce children, beyond a very small number, with

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the effect of reducing the reward of labour by their competition, is a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: serious offence against all who live by the remuneration of their

author: John Stuart Mill
text: labour. The laws which, in many countries on the Continent, forbid

author: John Stuart Mill
text: marriage unless the parties can show that they have the means of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: supporting a family, do not exceed the legitimate powers of the state:

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and whether such laws be expedient or not (a question mainly dependent

author: John Stuart Mill
text: on local circumstances and feelings), they are not objectionable as

author: John Stuart Mill
text: violations of liberty. Such laws are interferences of the state to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: prohibit a mischievous act--an act injurious to others, which ought to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: be a subject of reprobation, and social stigma, even when it is not

author: John Stuart Mill
text: deemed expedient to superadd legal punishment. Yet the current ideas of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: liberty, which bend so easily to real infringements of the freedom of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the individual, in things which concern only himself, would repel the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: attempt to put any restraint upon his inclinations when the consequence

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of their indulgence is a life, or lives, of wretchedness and depravity

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to the offspring, with manifold evils to those sufficiently within reach

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to be in any way affected by their actions. When we compare the strange

author: John Stuart Mill
text: respect of mankind for liberty, with their strange want of respect for

author: John Stuart Mill
text: it, we might imagine that a man had an indispensable right to do harm

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to others, and no right at all to please himself without giving pain to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: any one.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: I have reserved for the last place a large class of questions respecting

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the limits of government interference, which, though closely connected

author: John Stuart Mill
text: with the subject of this Essay, do not, in strictness, belong to it.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: These are cases in which the reasons against interference do not turn

author: John Stuart Mill
text: upon the principle of liberty: the question is not about restraining the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: actions of individuals, but about helping them: it is asked whether the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: government should do, or cause to be done, something for their benefit,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: instead of leaving it to be done by themselves, individually, or in

author: John Stuart Mill
text: voluntary combination.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: The objections to government interference, when it is not such as to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: involve infringement of liberty, may be of three kinds.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: The first is, when the thing to be done is likely to be better done by

author: John Stuart Mill
text: individuals than by the government. Speaking generally, there is no one

author: John Stuart Mill
text: so fit to conduct any business, or to determine how or by whom it shall

author: John Stuart Mill
text: be conducted, as those who are personally interested in it. This

author: John Stuart Mill
text: principle condemns the interferences, once so common, of the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: legislature, or the officers of government, with the ordinary processes

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of industry. But this part of the subject has been sufficiently enlarged

author: John Stuart Mill
text: upon by political economists, and is not particularly related to the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: principles of this Essay.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: The second objection is more nearly allied to our subject. In many

author: John Stuart Mill
text: cases, though individuals may not do the particular thing so well, on

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the average, as the officers of government, it is nevertheless desirable

author: John Stuart Mill
text: that it should be done by them, rather than by the government, as a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: means to their own mental education--a mode of strengthening their

author: John Stuart Mill
text: active faculties, exercising their judgment, and giving them a familiar

author: John Stuart Mill
text: knowledge of the subjects with which they are thus left to deal. This is

author: John Stuart Mill
text: a principal, though not the sole, recommendation of jury trial (in cases

author: John Stuart Mill
text: not political); of free and popular local and municipal institutions; of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the conduct of industrial and philanthropic enterprises by voluntary

author: John Stuart Mill
text: associations. These are not questions of liberty, and are connected with

author: John Stuart Mill
text: that subject only by remote tendencies; but they are questions of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: development. It belongs to a different occasion from the present to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: dwell on these things as parts of national education; as being, in

author: John Stuart Mill
text: truth, the peculiar training of a citizen, the practical part of the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: political education of a free people, taking them out of the narrow

author: John Stuart Mill
text: circle of personal and family selfishness, and accustoming them to the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: comprehension of joint interests, the management of joint

author: John Stuart Mill
text: concerns--habituating them to act from public or semi-public motives,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and guide their conduct by aims which unite instead of isolating them

author: John Stuart Mill
text: from one another. Without these habits and powers, a free constitution

author: John Stuart Mill
text: can neither be worked nor preserved, as is exemplified by the too-often

author: John Stuart Mill
text: transitory nature of political freedom in countries where it does not

author: John Stuart Mill
text: rest upon a sufficient basis of local liberties. The management of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: purely local business by the localities, and of the great enterprises of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: industry by the union of those who voluntarily supply the pecuniary

author: John Stuart Mill
text: means, is further recommended by all the advantages which have been set

author: John Stuart Mill
text: forth in this Essay as belonging to individuality of development, and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: diversity of modes of action. Government operations tend to be

author: John Stuart Mill
text: everywhere alike. With individuals and voluntary associations, on the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: contrary, there are varied experiments, and endless diversity of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: experience. What the State can usefully do, is to make itself a central

author: John Stuart Mill
text: depository, and active circulator and diffuser, of the experience

author: John Stuart Mill
text: resulting from many trials. Its business is to enable each

author: John Stuart Mill
text: experimentalist to benefit by the experiments of others, instead of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: tolerating no experiments but its own.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: The third, and most cogent reason for restricting the interference of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: government, is the great evil of adding unnecessarily to its power.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Every function superadded to those already exercised by the government,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: causes its influence over hopes and fears to be more widely diffused,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and converts, more and more, the active and ambitious part of the public

author: John Stuart Mill
text: into hangers-on of the government, or of some party which aims at

author: John Stuart Mill
text: becoming the government. If the roads, the railways, the banks, the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: insurance offices, the great joint-stock companies, the universities,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and the public charities, were all of them branches of the government;

author: John Stuart Mill
text: if, in addition, the municipal corporations and local boards, with all

author: John Stuart Mill
text: that now devolves on them, became departments of the central

author: John Stuart Mill
text: administration; if the employes of all these different enterprises were

author: John Stuart Mill
text: appointed and paid by the government, and looked to the government for

author: John Stuart Mill
text: every rise in life; not all the freedom of the press and popular

author: John Stuart Mill
text: constitution of the legislature would make this or any other country

author: John Stuart Mill
text: free otherwise than in name. And the evil would be greater, the more

author: John Stuart Mill
text: efficiently and scientifically the administrative machinery was

author: John Stuart Mill
text: constructed--the more skilful the arrangements for obtaining the best

author: John Stuart Mill
text: qualified hands and heads with which to work it. In England it has of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: late been proposed that all the members of the civil service of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: government should be selected by competitive examination, to obtain for

author: John Stuart Mill
text: those employments the most intelligent and instructed persons

author: John Stuart Mill
text: procurable; and much has been said and written for and against this

author: John Stuart Mill
text: proposal. One of the arguments most insisted on by its opponents, is

author: John Stuart Mill
text: that the occupation of a permanent official servant of the State does

author: John Stuart Mill
text: not hold out sufficient prospects of emolument and importance to attract

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the highest talents, which will always be able to find a more inviting

author: John Stuart Mill
text: career in the professions, or in the service of companies and other

author: John Stuart Mill
text: public bodies. One would not have been surprised if this argument had

author: John Stuart Mill
text: been used by the friends of the proposition, as an answer to its

author: John Stuart Mill
text: principal difficulty. Coming from the opponents it is strange enough.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: What is urged as an objection is the safety-valve of the proposed

author: John Stuart Mill
text: system. If indeed all the high talent of the country _could_ be drawn

author: John Stuart Mill
text: into the service of the government, a proposal tending to bring about

author: John Stuart Mill
text: that result might well inspire uneasiness. If every part of the business

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of society which required organised concert, or large and comprehensive

author: John Stuart Mill
text: views, were in the hands of the government, and if government offices

author: John Stuart Mill
text: were universally filled by the ablest men, all the enlarged culture and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: practised intelligence in the country, except the purely speculative,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: would be concentrated in a numerous bureaucracy, to whom alone the rest

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of the community would look for all things: the multitude for direction

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and dictation in all they had to do; the able and aspiring for personal

author: John Stuart Mill
text: advancement. To be admitted into the ranks of this bureaucracy, and when

author: John Stuart Mill
text: admitted, to rise therein, would be the sole objects of ambition. Under

author: John Stuart Mill
text: this regime, not only is the outside public ill-qualified, for want of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: practical experience, to criticise or check the mode of operation of the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: bureaucracy, but even if the accidents of despotic or the natural

author: John Stuart Mill
text: working of popular institutions occasionally raise to the summit a ruler

author: John Stuart Mill
text: or rulers of reforming inclinations, no reform can be effected which is

author: John Stuart Mill
text: contrary to the interest of the bureaucracy. Such is the melancholy

author: John Stuart Mill
text: condition of the Russian empire, as is shown in the accounts of those

author: John Stuart Mill
text: who have had sufficient opportunity of observation. The Czar himself is

author: John Stuart Mill
text: powerless against the bureaucratic body; he can send any one of them to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Siberia, but he cannot govern without them, or against their will. On

author: John Stuart Mill
text: every decree of his they have a tacit veto, by merely refraining from

author: John Stuart Mill
text: carrying it into effect. In countries of more advanced civilisation and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of a more insurrectionary spirit, the public, accustomed to expect

author: John Stuart Mill
text: everything to be done for them by the State, or at least to do nothing

author: John Stuart Mill
text: for themselves without asking from the State not only leave to do it,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: but even how it is to be done, naturally hold the State responsible for

author: John Stuart Mill
text: all evil which befalls them, and when the evil exceeds their amount of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: patience, they rise against the government and make what is called a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: revolution; whereupon somebody else, with or without legitimate

author: John Stuart Mill
text: authority from the nation, vaults into the seat, issues his orders to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the bureaucracy, and everything goes on much as it did before; the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: bureaucracy being unchanged, and nobody else being capable of taking

author: John Stuart Mill
text: their place.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: A very different spectacle is exhibited among a people accustomed to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: transact their own business. In France, a large part of the people

author: John Stuart Mill
text: having been engaged in military service, many of whom have held at least

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the rank of non-commissioned officers, there are in every popular

author: John Stuart Mill
text: insurrection several persons competent to take the lead, and improvise

author: John Stuart Mill
text: some tolerable plan of action. What the French are in military affairs,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the Americans are in every kind of civil business; let them be left

author: John Stuart Mill
text: without a government, every body of Americans is able to improvise one,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and to carry on that or any other public business with a sufficient

author: John Stuart Mill
text: amount of intelligence, order, and decision. This is what every free

author: John Stuart Mill
text: people ought to be: and a people capable of this is certain to be free;

author: John Stuart Mill
text: it will never let itself be enslaved by any man or body of men because

author: John Stuart Mill
text: these are able to seize and pull the reins of the central

author: John Stuart Mill
text: administration. No bureaucracy can hope to make such a people as this do

author: John Stuart Mill
text: or undergo anything that they do not like. But where everything is done

author: John Stuart Mill
text: through the bureaucracy, nothing to which the bureaucracy is really

author: John Stuart Mill
text: adverse can be done at all. The constitution of such countries is an

author: John Stuart Mill
text: organisation of the experience and practical ability of the nation, into

author: John Stuart Mill
text: a disciplined body for the purpose of governing the rest; and the more

author: John Stuart Mill
text: perfect that organisation is in itself, the more successful in drawing

author: John Stuart Mill
text: to itself and educating for itself the persons of greatest capacity from

author: John Stuart Mill
text: all ranks of the community, the more complete is the bondage of all, the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: members of the bureaucracy included. For the governors are as much the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: slaves of their organisation and discipline, as the governed are of the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: governors. A Chinese mandarin is as much the tool and creature of a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: despotism as the humblest cultivator. An individual Jesuit is to the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: utmost degree of abasement the slave of his order, though the order

author: John Stuart Mill
text: itself exists for the collective power and importance of its members.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: It is not, also, to be forgotten, that the absorption of all the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: principal ability of the country into the governing body is fatal,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: sooner or later, to the mental activity and progressiveness of the body

author: John Stuart Mill
text: itself. Banded together as they are--working a system which, like all

author: John Stuart Mill
text: systems, necessarily proceeds in a great measure by fixed rules--the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: official body are under the constant temptation of sinking into indolent

author: John Stuart Mill
text: routine, or, if they now and then desert that mill-horse round, of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: rushing into some half-examined crudity which has struck the fancy of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: some leading member of the corps: and the sole check to these closely

author: John Stuart Mill
text: allied, though seemingly opposite, tendencies, the only stimulus which

author: John Stuart Mill
text: can keep the ability of the body itself up to a high standard, is

author: John Stuart Mill
text: liability to the watchful criticism of equal ability outside the body.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: It is indispensable, therefore, that the means should exist,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: independently of the government, of forming such ability, and furnishing

author: John Stuart Mill
text: it with the opportunities and experience necessary for a correct

author: John Stuart Mill
text: judgment of great practical affairs. If we would possess permanently a

author: John Stuart Mill
text: skilful and efficient body of functionaries--above all, a body able to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: originate and willing to adopt improvements; if we would not have our

author: John Stuart Mill
text: bureaucracy degenerate into a pedantocracy, this body must not engross

author: John Stuart Mill
text: all the occupations which form and cultivate the faculties required for

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the government of mankind.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: To determine the point at which evils, so formidable to human freedom

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and advancement, begin, or rather at which they begin to predominate

author: John Stuart Mill
text: over the benefits attending the collective application of the force of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: society, under its recognised chiefs, for the removal of the obstacles

author: John Stuart Mill
text: which stand in the way of its well-being; to secure as much of the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: advantages of centralised power and intelligence, as can be had without

author: John Stuart Mill
text: turning into governmental channels too great a proportion of the general

author: John Stuart Mill
text: activity, is one of the most difficult and complicated questions in the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: art of government. It is, in a great measure, a question of detail, in

author: John Stuart Mill
text: which many and various considerations must be kept in view, and no

author: John Stuart Mill
text: absolute rule can be laid down. But I believe that the practical

author: John Stuart Mill
text: principle in which safety resides, the ideal to be kept in view, the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: standard by which to test all arrangements intended for overcoming the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: difficulty, may be conveyed in these words: the greatest dissemination

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of power consistent with efficiency; but the greatest possible

author: John Stuart Mill
text: centralisation of information, and diffusion of it from the centre.

author: John Stuart Mill
text: Thus, in municipal administration, there would be, as in the New England

author: John Stuart Mill
text: States, a very minute division among separate officers, chosen by the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: localities, of all business which is not better left to the persons

author: John Stuart Mill
text: directly interested; but besides this, there would be, in each

author: John Stuart Mill
text: department of local affairs, a central superintendence, forming a branch

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of the general government. The organ of this superintendence would

author: John Stuart Mill
text: concentrate, as in a focus, the variety of information and experience

author: John Stuart Mill
text: derived from the conduct of that branch of public business in all the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: localities, from everything analogous which is done in foreign

author: John Stuart Mill
text: countries, and from the general principles of political science. This

author: John Stuart Mill
text: central organ should have a right to know all that is done, and its

author: John Stuart Mill
text: special duty should be that of making the knowledge acquired in one

author: John Stuart Mill
text: place available for others. Emancipated from the petty prejudices and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: narrow views of a locality by its elevated position and comprehensive

author: John Stuart Mill
text: sphere of observation, its advice would naturally carry much authority;

author: John Stuart Mill
text: but its actual power, as a permanent institution, should, I conceive, be

author: John Stuart Mill
text: limited to compelling the local officers to obey the laws laid down for

author: John Stuart Mill
text: their guidance. In all things not provided for by general rules, those

author: John Stuart Mill
text: officers should be left to their own judgment, under responsibility to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: their constituents. For the violation of rules, they should be

author: John Stuart Mill
text: responsible to law, and the rules themselves should be laid down by the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: legislature; the central administrative authority only watching over

author: John Stuart Mill
text: their execution, and if they were not properly carried into effect,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: appealing, according to the nature of the case, to the tribunal to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: enforce the law, or to the constituencies to dismiss the functionaries

author: John Stuart Mill
text: who had not executed it according to its spirit. Such, in its general

author: John Stuart Mill
text: conception, is the central superintendence which the Poor Law Board is

author: John Stuart Mill
text: intended to exercise over the administrators of the Poor Rate throughout

author: John Stuart Mill
text: the country. Whatever powers the Board exercises beyond this limit, were

author: John Stuart Mill
text: right and necessary in that peculiar case, for the cure of rooted habits

author: John Stuart Mill
text: of maladministration in matters deeply affecting not the localities

author: John Stuart Mill
text: merely, but the whole community; since no locality has a moral right to

author: John Stuart Mill
text: make itself by mismanagement a nest of pauperism, necessarily

author: John Stuart Mill
text: overflowing into other localities, and impairing the moral and physical

author: John Stuart Mill
text: condition of the whole labouring community. The powers of administrative

author: John Stuart Mill
text: coercion and subordinate legislation possessed by the Poor Law Board

author: John Stuart Mill
text: (but which, owing to the state of opinion on the subject, are very

author: John Stuart Mill
text: scantily exercised by them), though perfectly justifiable in a case of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: first-rate national interest, would be wholly out of place in the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: superintendence of interests purely local. But a central organ of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: information and instruction for all the localities, would be equally

author: John Stuart Mill
text: valuable in all departments of administration. A government cannot have

author: John Stuart Mill
text: too much of the kind of activity which does not impede, but aids and

author: John Stuart Mill
text: stimulates, individual exertion and development. The mischief begins

author: John Stuart Mill
text: when, instead of calling forth the activity and powers of individuals

author: John Stuart Mill
text: and bodies, it substitutes its own activity for theirs; when, instead of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: informing, advising, and, upon occasion, denouncing, it makes them work

author: John Stuart Mill
text: in fetters, or bids them stand aside and does their work instead of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: them. The worth of a State, in the long run, is the worth of the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: individuals composing it; and a State which postpones the interests of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: _their_ mental expansion and elevation, to a little more of

author: John Stuart Mill
text: administrative skill, or of that semblance of it which practice gives,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: in the details of business; a State which dwarfs its men, in order that

author: John Stuart Mill
text: they may be more docile instruments in its hands even for beneficial

author: John Stuart Mill
text: purposes, will find that with small men no great thing can really be

author: John Stuart Mill
text: accomplished; and that the perfection of machinery to which it has

author: John Stuart Mill
text: sacrificed everything, will in the end avail it nothing, for want of the

author: John Stuart Mill
text: vital power which, in order that the machine might work more smoothly,

author: John Stuart Mill
text: it has preferred to banish.
